title: Fee Rise and Pay Freeze Seen Aiding City Hospitals
description: New reimbursement rates and improved collections for patient services will generate an extra $19.2million for the municipal hospitals and, with a saving of $22million from a wage freeze, could meet the budget squeeze on the Health and Hospitals Corporation, its president, Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., estimated yesterday.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Capital I11Prepared For the Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, July 31When the chairman of a House subcommittee that has been examining preparations for next year's Bicentennial observance here concluded three days of public hearings recently on the city's chaotic planning for the arrival of millions of tourists here in 1976, he made an only halffacetious proposal  call the whole thing off.

title: Program for Survival
description: New York City seems at last to be pointed in the direction of fiscal recovery. Between the austerity blueprint announced yesterday by Mayor Beame and its effective implementation lies a still yawning gulfbut at least the first step has been taken. The Mayor's program is desperately late; it is, however, on target.

title: LYNN KELLOGG SINGS ON BILL WITH MASON
description: Lynn Kellogg, a tall, willowy, flaxenhaired singer, is bringing an urbanized country sound to Reno Sweeney this week, an atmosphere that is also projected by Jae Mason, a husky hombre in boots and a modified cowboy hat who opens the bill.

title: Connally Fund Dinner Draws 3,000 in Texas
description: HOUSTON, July 31More than 3.000 supporters of John B. Connally paid from $25 to $1,000 apiece tonight to attend a fundraising dinner billed as a nonpartisan tribute to the former Governor.

title: Jersey Senate Votes For Insurance Pool In Malpractice Suits
description: TRENTON, July 31  The State Senate passed bills today that would establish a medical. malpractice insurance pool and place a $100million housing bond issue on the November ballot.

title: U.S. Releases Copies Of Pumpkin Papers
description: Copies of the pumpkin papers, a set of five microfilms used to implicate Alger Hiss as a Soviet spy, were released by the Justice Department yesterday.

title: The West's Summit
description: The slow rate of recovery in the industrial nations from the deepest recession and highest rate of unemployment since the Great Depression has finally forced the top leaders of the principal countries to take counsel together instead of relying entirely on separate measures, applied domestically.

title: Market Place
description: The saga is over nowbut the memory lingers on. Two years ago, the Ronson Corporation obtained a preliminary injunction in a Federal court barring a subsidiary of Liquifin, A.G., of Liechtenstein from proceeding with a tender offer to buy up to 52 per cent of the cigarettelighter and appliance maker's stock at $8.50 a share.

title: SOME TOLLS RISING
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday a 15cent increase in subway and bus fares to 50 cents, effective Sept. 1, with the introduction of a new token.

title: Fireman Injured in Blast
description: McKEES ROCKS, Pa., July 31 (AP)A series of explosions and a fire damaged a division of the Chemetron Corporation here yesterday and critically injured a fireman. Damage was estimated at $500,000. Fire officials said at least 100 acetylene gas cylinders blew up in the onestory National Cylinder Gas Company in this Pittsburgh suburb. The injured fireman, Walter Kotek, 24 years old, of McKees Rocks, was hit in the face by debris when one of the cylinders ruptured.

title: Austerity Budget Program Includes Proposals to Abolish Three City Agencies
description: Three New York City agencies would be abolished and two offices in one of the superagencies left over from the Lindsay administration would be partially merged in a package of budgetary measures announced yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: Symbols of Black Power
description: DETROIT, July 31Symbols of black presence and black political powersometimes as dramatic as a line of policemen standing their ground against a crowd of angry blacks have been skillfully used by city officials here to contain the disturbances that broke out in the northwest section of the city Monday night.

title: Scientists See Beautiful Corn In Illinois and Price Declines
description: A group of agronomists and county agricultural advisers associated with the University of Illinois reported. the most beautiful corn they had ever seen yesterday, and corn prices promptly moved down on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Nigeria's New Leader Delays Culture Festival
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 31 (Reuters)  Nigeria's new leader, Brig. Muritala Rufai Mohammed, has postponed the second World Black and African Festival of Arts and Culture, which had been scheduled to begin in midNovember with more than 70 countries participating.

title: Financier in Argentina Seized Again; Paid $1Million Ransom First Time
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 31A Britishborn financier, who was kidnapped by leftwing Argentine guerrillas two years ago and released after his company paid a reported $1million ransom was kidnapped again today, apparently by guerrillas.

title: 3 GOVERNORS VOTE TO KILL TOCKS DAM
description: NEWARK, July 31  The Governors of New Jersey, New York and Delaware asked Congress today to appropriate no money for construction of the Tocks Island Dam.

title: FACTORIES TRIM STOCKS FURTHER
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Manufacturers succeeded in reducing their inventories substantially in June for the fourth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BLUECROSS GETS $52MILLION RISE
description: TRENTON, July 31 (AP)The state today granted Blue Cross and Blue Shield a combined $52million rate increase to take effect Sept. 1 for smallgroup and individual subscribers.

title: POUND HITS LOW AGAINST DOLLAR
description: LONDON, July 31The beleaguered British pound fell briefly today to a record low exchange rate against the dollar. Although it recovered slightly later, money experts here predicted that the rate could fall to the $2 level by autumn.

title: Massachusetts Is Seeking 16 Railroad Freight Lines
description: BOSTON, July 31 (AP)Massachusetts will move to acquire 16 railroad freight lines, which would be abandoned under the rail reorganization plan pending in Congress, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said today.

title: 3 GOVERNORS VOTE TO KILL TOCKS DAM
description: NEWARK, July 31  The Governors of New Jersey, New York and Delaware asked Congress today to appropriate no money for construction of the Tocks Island Dam.

title: Byrne Urges U.S. to Keep ReserveGasoline Program
description: TRENTON, July 31 (AP)Governor Byrne today urged the Federal Government to continue keeping a reserve supply of petroleum products for emergencies.

title: Participants in the Helsinki Conference
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 The 35 states participating in the European security conference and their representatives here are as follows:

title: Israelis Bemused as Clergy Ousts Member Who Berated Top Rabbi
description: JERUSALEM, July 31Can a rabbi and Member of Parliament be excommunicated for denouncing the Chief Rabbi and likening him to President Idi Amin of Uganda?

title: The News Names O'Neill as Editor
description: The appointment of Michael J. O'Neill, executive editor of The Daily News, as editor of the paper was announced yesterday by W. H. James, the president and publisher.

title: M.A.C. Offers Plan to Gain Investor Confidence in City
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation called on Mayor Beame yesterday to implement a wide range of budgetary and management reformsbeyond the ones Mr. Beame announced himself  as essential to the restoration of investor confidence in city affairs.

title: Joan Little Prosecutors Contend Killing Was Part of Escape Plot
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 31The outlines of the state's murder case against Joan Little began to emerge today as the prosecution introduced as evidence the icepick found in the slain man's hand and offered testimony placing Miss Little in the area of the desk drawer where it was kept.

title: Text of Beanie Statement Calling for Financial Restraint and Service Cutbacks
description: We are struggling to overcome a crisis of confidence in our fiscal integrity. Its roots trace back more than a decade. The role of our cities has changed dramatically in response to national trends, heightened aspirations and shifting policy.

title: New Leader in Nigeria Replaces State Governors
description: LAGOS, Nigena, July 31 (Reuters)Nigeria's new ruler swore in new state governors today and said that the previous ones had been running their areas as private estates.

title: In Some Areas, Today's Temperature Is 98.6
description: GUILFORD, Conn.It is easy these days to lapse into complete cynicism about American Government. Every time we open a newspaper we discover another messfrom the wicked deeds of the Central Intelligence Agency to the ineptness of the White House and the stumbling incompetence of Congress.

title: James Jones: After Paris, a Farm
description: SAGAPONACK, L. I. James Jones, who writes mostly about wars, has es tablished a beachhead in the United States.

title: Namath 10 for 14 In Drill
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 31In what a poet might have described as a bosky dell, the Jets and Giants today exchanged grunts and groans.

title: Excerpts From the Brezhnev Address
description: Those who belong to the generation that lived through the horrors of the Second World War most vividly realize the historic significance of this conference. Its objectives also appeal to the mind and hearts of the generation of Europeans that has grown and is now living in conditions of peace and which justly believes that things cannot be otherwise.

title: SOME UNIONS BALK
description: Mayor Beame asked the City Council yesterday to give him the emergency power to freeze the wages of all city union workers as part of a broad austerity package.

title: 1,500 Protest New Means Test for U.S.Aided SocialService Programs
description: About 1,500 elderly people staged a brief rally outside the World Trade Center yesterday morning to protest new rules requiring means tests for participants, in a wide variety of federally financed socialservice programs.

title: INDEX UNCHANGED ON AMEX STOCKS
description: Activity on the American Stock Exchange was quiet yesterday with volume remaining low at 1.75million shares. The Amex index closed unchanged at 89.96.

title: SHERIFF INDICTED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: RIVERHEAD, LI., July 31The Sheriff of Suffolk County was indicted today on 13 counts of extortion and coercion stemming from charges that he persuaded subordinates and contractors to contribute to the Republican party and that he later punished recalcitrant contractors by terminating their contracts.

title: Notes on People
description: This is what we've been hoping for all along, said Marjorie Slayton, wife of Donald K. Slayton, looking at the spectacular Hawaiian view from the beach cottages at Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station, where the Apollo astronauts and their families spent the first of 10 days tonether yesterday. Mrs. Slayron ami Faye Stafford and Joan Brand, with the families' children, had arrived Wednesday night after an 11hour flight from Houston. Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, Vance D. Brand and Mr. Slayton had arrived after a somewhat longer flight nine days from liftoff to landingand a fiveday stopover in Tripler Army Hospital for tests and observation.

title: Bridge:
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 31Almost all of the thousands of bridge players, converging on the Americana Hotel here are looking forward to 10 days of play in the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. The main events will be the master mixed teams, the life master pairs and the Spingold teams.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO. PLANNING. A MERGER
description: The Beatrice Foods Company announced in Chicago yesterday that it had agreed in principle with Martha White Foods, Inc., of Nashville, Tenn., for a merger.

title: DR. RANDOLPH DWNES
description: Dr. Randolph C. Downes, professor emeritus of history at the University of Toledo, Ohio, and author of The Rise of Warren Gamaliel Harding, 18651920, a biography, died July 14 in Toledo. He was 74 years old and lived in Maumee, Ohio.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: (Loss)  After change In accounting methods

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 100 members of Project Return, a heroin addiction treatment program, chanted no more dope in a demonstration at Rockefeller Center and called on Congress to cut off all aid to Turkey. We are here to demonstrate against Turkey's resumption of poppy growing, said Norman Savage, the project's publicrelations director.

title: Uranium Transport Through the City Is Banned by Benin
description: A directive banning the transport of hazardous radioactive materials through the streets of the city was issued yesterday by Health Commissinner Lowell E. Bellin.

title: F.D.N.C. Files Suits Seeking Funds Owed Defunct Bank
description: SAN DIEGO, July 31 (AP)The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has filed Federal court suits seeking to collect $42million in promissory notes owed to C. Arnholt Smith's defunct United States National Bank by nine concerns controlled by Mr. Smith.

title: Death of Twin Doctors Is Tied to Barbiturates
description: The Medical Examiner's office concluded yesterday that twin brothers who share a gynecology practice and were found dead in their East Side apartment, were barbiturate addicts and died of acute withdrawal from pentobarbital.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: MRS. GANDHI SAYS INDIA MAKES GAINS
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhil has asserted that democracy is not dead in India and that measures taken under her Government's monthold declaration of emergency nave already led to improvements in social and economic life.

title: Lisbon Junta Is Approved; Key Army Unit Shaken Up
description: LISBON, July 31 The High Council of the Revolution, after an allnight meeting, today approved the setting up of a threeman military junta to rule this divided country.

title: Program of Fiscal and Management Reforms Proposed for the City by Municipal Assistance Corporation
description: Talk of New York as a city in crisis has been so common that to say it again runs the danger of being ignored. But this time the crisis is not only real and imminent, but also of an extent greater than any faced in the past, even during the years following the Great Depression of 1929. Between

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 8%
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.02billion, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $929million. Total retail store sales were about $11.43billion, up 8 per cent from last year's $10.57billion.

title: Layoff Rate at Factories Fell Sharply in June to 2%
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters) The layoff rate in manufacturing industries fell sharply in June to its lowest level since last October, the Labor Department has reported.

title: Credit Stiffening Seen As Bond Prices Decline
description: Prices weakened yesterday in the Government bond market after showing a flat trend for three days. Meanwhile, despite the lack of any overt action by the Federal Reserve in the money market, the feeling appeared to be growing in some financial quarters that the Fed's role of easing credit that began last autumn has come to an end.

title: A Children's Fund Is Aided by N.F.L.
description: The National Football League Charities announced yesterday a grant of $25,000 to the Troubled Childrens' Foundation of Hialeah. Fla.

title: Brezhnev at Helsinki
description: Leonid I. Brezhniv's remarks at the summit meeting Helsinki yesterday were at best deliberately ambiguous, while at worst they were a tough warning to the West against any illusions that the declaration on European security coming out of Helsinki will ease the policestate atmosphere of the Soviet Union.

title: Turkey Spurns Arms Offer by Ford to Reopen Bases
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31  Premier Suleyman Demirel of Turkey today rejected a plea from President Ford that he re?? open American military bases in Turkey in exchange for a grant of $50million in United States weapons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: ANN S. BRENNAN
description: Ann Schabbehar Brennan, an artist and former instructor of Fashion illustration at the Art Students League, died last Friday in Port Jervis, N. Y. She was 66 years old and lived in Matamoras. Pa.

title: KENNEDY CANDIDACY IS DENIED BY O'NEILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The House majority leader, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., reversing an earlier statement, said today he is now convinced that Senator Edward M. Kennedy will not seek the Democratic nomination in 1976. Representative O'Neill, who predicted last Sunday that the Massachusetts, Senator would be a candidate, called reporters to his Capitol office to explain how his opinion had changed.

title: And What Work Does Your Father Do? He's a Sanitationrnan and I'm Proud
description: What do you do when some people hold their noses when they pass your husband, when others act as though his work is the last job on earth, and when that job occasionally makes your children the target of unflattering remarks and jokes?

title: Turkish Closing Seems to Aid Premier
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 31Premier Suleyman Demirel has apparently quieted his domestic critics with the suspension of intelligencegathering activites at American bases in retaliation for the continued American arms embargo.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dr. John L. S. Hotloman Jr., president of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, estimated that new reimbursement rates and improved collections for patient services would generate $19.2million, and with $22million savings from wage freeze could meet the budget squeeze on the corporation this fiscal year

title: Cats, Cattle and PeopleBeware of DogDays
description: HOGEYE, Ark., July 28 Seth Timmons reports that he did not sleep well the other night because of a katydid that sang outside his window all night, long after the others had stopped.

title: Pennsy Reports a Deficit Of 114Million in Quarter
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday a $114.3million net loss for the second quarter, which was $79million greater than the $35.3million deficit reported in the like quarter a year ago. The railroad's net loss for the first half reached $242.2million, compared with $103.6million a year ago.

title: City Fiscal Developments
description: A wage freeze for all unionized city workers, effective. Sept. 1. It will cancel a 6 per cent increase due July 1, but allow credit for that raise for pension purposes for unions that accept the freeze voluntarily. Unions representing 175,000 workers have agreed, but the policemen, firemen and teachers refuse and face an imposed freeze.

title: PAPER SAYS ISRAEL HAS 10 ATOM BOMBS
description: BOSTON, July 31 (AP)Senior United States analysts say that Israel, has made more than 10 nuclear weapons and can deliver them hundreds of miles beyond her borders, The Boston Globe said today.

title: Rider's Cite Variety of Hardship To Be Caused by Fare Increase
description: Two small, elderly sisters, each wearing a cheerful broadbrimmed hat, stood on the corner of Broadway and 34th Street yesterday afternoon and sighed.

title: Simon Offers Plan to Pare CorporateDividend Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Secretary of the Treasury, William E. Simon unveiled today, before a skeptical House Ways and Means Committee, the Ford Administration's plan to improve the longterm health of the economy by reducing the taxes paid by both corporations and their shareholders.

title: U.S. Offers Guidelines on Transit Aid
description: The Government formally proposed yesterday the first national guidelines to be used in parceling out billions of dollars to urban areas to help in building and improving mass transit systems.

title: U.S. SPY SPENDING IS STILL UNKNOWN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31EImer B. Staats, the Controller General, told a House committee today that the General Accounting Office had no idea how much money was spent each year by the dozen or so agencies in the Federal intelligence community.

title: MIRIAM BAZERMAN
description: Miriam Kirshenberg Bazerman, an administrative assistant at the Audubon Society, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived at 150 West 79th Street.

title: UNION HEADS MET DUAL PRESSURES
description: Ken MeFeeley, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, reportedly wanted to accept the package agreed to yesterday by the Municipal Labor Committee, but was forced to reject it by pressure from within his union.

title: Kingman Hits 2 In Met Victory
description: PITTSBURGH, July 31With two mighty home runs off the bat of Dave Kingman, good for three runs, plus a tworun homer by Joe Torre, the New York Mets won the first game of their fivegame series with the firstplace Pittsburgh Pirates, 62, tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, had only a small downtown office and no functioning headquarters in Washington. Mr. Sanford has a headquarters with a fulltime staff headed by Jean Westwood, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. It is housed in a suite of rooms in an office building at 1028 Connecticut Avenue.

title: Kierbow Defeated In L.I. Tournament
description: MANHASSET, L.I., July 31 Tony Palafox of Sands Point, L.I., a former Mexican Davis Cup player, upset secondseeded Don Kierbow of Tiburon, Calif., 67, 62, 60, in the quarterfinals or the United States men's 35year division clay court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

title: 3 Musicians Are Killed in Ulster Ambush
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 31Five men were killed early today when a Protestant paramilitary unit ambushed a wellknown Dublin musical group on its way home after playing in Northern Ireland.

title: The News Names O'Neill as Editor
description: The appointment of Michael J. O'Neill, executive editor of The Daily News, as editor of the paper was announced yesterday by W. H. James, the president and publisher.

title: Brezhnev, at Parley, Sees Bar to Dictating to Others
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31  Leonid I. Brezhnev said at the European security conference today that its important conclusions for Europe's future would discourage any nation from telling another how to run its internal affairs.

title: Briton Declares Russians Undercut Shipping Rates
description: LONDON, July 31 (AP)The Soviet Union is undercutting shipping rates to earn foreign currency irrespective of making any profit, a British shipping expert charged today.

title: Stocks Retreat After Early Rise
description: Government reports or an upturn in factory orders and another decline in business inventories bouyed stock prices in early trading yesterday, but the list backed down in late trading, closing with little net change for the day.

title: ALUMINUM PRICES ALLOWED TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The Administration said today it would make no further effort to block price increases by major aluminum companies, scheduled to take effect in early August, despite misgivings about the impact on consumer prices.

title: Ford Net Off 36% but Above Estimates
description: DETROIT, July 31The Ford Motor Company today reported earnings of $107million for this year's second quarters, down 36.3 per cent from the year  earlier level but well above recent estimates of many analysts.

title: Fishing Menu Includes Fluke, Blues, Stripers
description: AREA AFluke continue in abundance in most of the waters off the New Jersey coast. Among the best spots have been Sea Girt, Spring Lake, Barnegat and Seaside Park, where catches averaging five pounds have been common. The best responses have come from squid, smelt, sand eels and killies. Blues have been in and out, according to most sources, but heavy schools, averaging from five to eight pounds, have been reported off the Klondike, six miles north of Point Pleasant, with moss bunker and chum, the main attraction. Fishermen at Barnegat have had the best luck with blues chumming at night and trolling during the daylight hours. An occasional tuna in the 10to20pound range has turned up around Barnegat and crabbing continues excellent all through Barnegat Bay.

title: New Fares, Tolls Effective on Sept. 1
description: Subways, 50 cents.

title: Business Loans Decline Again, Indicating Slow Recovery Pace
description: Business loans at leading New York City banks declined for the fourth consecutive week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday. Its report provided additional evidence that the national economic recovery is taking place slowly.

title: U.S. AIDE PREDICTS FOOD STAMP DROP
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The Department of Agriculture's food and nutrition administrator, Edward J. Hekman, testified at Senate hearings today that an improving economy should mean that the food stamp program will have fewer participants in 1980 than it has now.

title: New Hampshire Senate Election Set for Sept. 16
description: CONCORD. N. H., July 31Campaigning began today as the special election for United States Senator from New Hampshire was officially set for Sept. 16

title: WILLIAM L. HOWELL
description: William L. Howell, a member of the Weusi Nyumba Ya Sanaa Art Gallery in Harlem, an artists' cooperative gallery, and art director of the New Lafayette Theater, died last Friday of diabetes in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 32 years old.

title: Lisbon Junta Is Approved; Key Army Unit Shaken Up
description: LISBON, July 31  The High Council of the Revolution, after an allnight meeting, today approved the setting up of a threeman military junta to rule this divided country.

title: Head Wins Jersey Golf By 2 Shots
description: CHATHAM, N.J., July 31Gary Head of Mountain Ridge won the 48th annual New Jersey Professional Golfers Association's 54hole championship by two strokes at the Fairmount Country Club today.

title: Exchange Seat Price Off
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that a seat on the exchange was sold at $130,000, down $8;000 from the prior sale on July 16. The current market price of a membership,is $110,000 bid and $135,000 Offered. The highest price paid for a seat on the exchange in the last two years was,$138,000 on July 16 and the lowest price was $65,000 on Sept, 12. 1974.

title: Sensible CrimeBusting
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and police departments in four cities have announced an interesting experiment designed to develop and exchange new ideas for combating crime. The programessentially an effort to devise and test ways to involve citizens in anticrime effortsgrows out of the desire of F.B.I. Director Clarence Kelley, a former police chief himself, to find relatively simple ways for the bureau to help local police departments.

title: House Maneuver Upholds Arms Embargo on Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The Ford Administration's efforts to lift the arms embargo imposed by Congress against Turkey appeared to have collapsed late tonight when the House of Representatives refused to waive its rules and act on ending the ban before starting a month's recess tomorrow.

title: 2d Elephant Missing From Circus Is Seized
description: HUGO, Okla., July 31 (AP) Lilly, one of the two young female elephants who strayed from a circus camp in Hugo 19 days ago, was felled today by shots from a tranquilizer gun.

title: M.A.C. Offers Plan to Gain Investon Confidence in City
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation called on Mayor Beame yesterday to implement a wide range of budgetary and management reformsbeyond the ones Mr. Beanie announced himself  as essential to the restoration of investor confidence in city affairs.

title: Cats, Cattle and People  Beware of Dog Days
description: HOGEYE, Ark., July 28 Seth Timmons reports that he did not sleep well the other night because of a katydid that sang outside his window all night, long after the others had stopped.

title: People in Sports
description: George Bucci, the threetime allMetropolitan Conference guard at Manhattan has signed a multiyear contract with the New York Nets for an undisclosed sum. The 6foot3inch, 205pound Bucci was the Nets' secondround pick in the American Basketball Association draft. He was the thirdround choice, in the National Basketball Association, of the Buffalo Braves, who had no first and secondround selections. Although Bucci averaged 20 points a game for the Jaspers in his senior year, Kevin Loughery, the Nets' coach, is not expecting that much offense from him.

title: Wheelchair Five Wins
description: BRUGES, Belgium, July 31 (UPI)  The United States team in the Gold Cup Wheelchair basketball tournament defeated the Netherlands, 4935, today, completing the five scheduled games in its pool without a loss. The team now, enters the semifinals, meeting the secondplace team of the opposite pool, Britain tomorrow night.

title: Butz Hails Farm Prosperity
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 31. (AP)Rising farm prosperity in recent years has helped put more money into public tax coffers and has helped breathe new life into towns as well as the countryside, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today. Dr. Butz's remarks were in a speech prepared for a meeting of the Southern Legislative Conference Council of State Governments.

title: Fare Increase Is Sixth Since 1948 Nickel Ride
description: When the city's subway fare goes from 35 cents to 50 cents on Sept. 1, it will be the sixth fare increase here since July 1, 1948, when the 5cent fare that had been in effect since 1904, was raised from 5 to 10 cents. The 10cent fare lasted until July 25, 1953 when it rose to 15 cents.

title: SOME TOILS RISING
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday a 15cent increase in subway and bus fares to 50 cents, effective Sept 1, with the introduction of a new token.

title: Senate Votes Strip Mining Curb In Revision of Coal Lease Laws
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The Senate approved today a major revision of Federal coal leasing laws, imposing strict environmental standards twice vetoed by President Fordfor strip mining on such land.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Becky is almost 3 the age when a child is learning to walk smoothly and run fastit's a rotten time to break a leg.

title: BAN ON A PESTICIDE ASKED BY 2 GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) Two environmental groups asked the Environmental Protection Agency today to ban the pesticide endrin, charging that it was poisonous to wildlife and posed a possible cancer threat to man.

title: Waiirna Heads Monmouth Stakes Field
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 A balanced field of nine was entered today for the $100,000 Monmouth Invitational Handicap, which will have its 30th modern running at Monmouth Park on Saturday. First prize in the 1mile test will be $65,000, plus a model of the original portal of Old Monmouth Park, where the race had its inaugural in 1870.

title: Dr. Creamy Carolian's Patient
description: HARRISON, July 31Starting on the 10th tee, Samuel Jackson Snead, 62, shot a par 4 on his first hole, another par on his second, a bogey 6 on his third and a oar on his fourth. Then came a birdie 2 on the short 14th.

title: Giza Minnelli to Replace Gwen Verdon in Chicago
description: Liza Minnelli, Academy Award winner, has agreed to substitute for Gwen Verdon in the Broadway musical  (Chicago for a fiveweek period starting Aug. 8.

title: Deflated Yankees Ponder the Losses
description: In a recent Peanuts comic strip episode, Charlie Brown, the world's most lovable loser, stood on the pitcher's mound, questioning the motivation behind his baseball life.

title: Computerized Move By Banks Is Barred In U.S. Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters)A judge ruled today that a Federal order allowing banks to establish computerized transfer terminals off their premises is illegal.

title: BLACKMAIL MOVE LAID TO U.S. STEEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged the United States Steel Corporation today with trying to blackmail the Defense Department into relaxing Government cost accounting standards to obtain steel critically needed in the nuclear submarine program.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission dropped an antitrust complaint today against four big oil companies that it had accused of eliminating competition in the sale of tires, batteries and other automobile accessories.

title: Raise in Aid to the Aged, Blind And Disabled Signed in Albany
description: ALBANY, July 31  Four hundred thousand aged, blind and disabled people in the state supported by the Federal Supplemental Security Income program will get an 8 per cent increase in benefits under a bill signed today by Governor Carey.

title: A Note From the Underground, To Uncle Sam,
World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Event May Be Historic, But Talk Is Often Small
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 Historic is the byword of the European security conference. The leaders of the 35 states have been telling each other in succession that this is the way they think of this assemblage.

title: 750 Sanitationmen Escape Layoff Now
description: The jobs of 750 sanitationmen were saved only hours before they were scheduled to be laid off yesterday after Mayor Beanie said t??t new calculations would make it possible to retain them at least for a couple of months without allocating more money to the Sanitation Department's budget.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Patricia Q. Sheehan, Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, said the State Housing Finance Agency had approved $16million in mortgage loans to finance housing developments in three counties.

title: City Fiscal Developments
description: A wage freeze for all unionized city workers, effective Sept. 1. It will cancel a 6 per cent increase due July 1, but allow credit for that raise for pension purposes for unions that accept the freeze voluntarily. Unions representing 175,000 workers have agreed, but the policemen, firemen and teachers refuse and face an imposed freeze.

title: The Ballet: NureyevKain Swan Lake
description: It was Swan Lake time for the National Ballet of Canada again, and the production the company showed off so splendidly last year got a less splendid showcase in the first performance of the season Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Host to the Conference
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31Urho Kaleva Kekkonen is a pragmatic politician whose philosophy of conciliation with the Soviet Union has more than once brought him criticism in the West.

title: A Solid Gold Jubilee for Random House
description: On its 50th birthday today, Random House, the publishing company founded on borrowed money in 1925, will be accepting more than the usual congratulations. It has just sold Bantam Books the paperback rights to its bestselling novel Ragtime by E. L. Doctorow, for a whopping $1.85million. Industry sources said it was the highest price ever paid for paperback rights.

title: GERTRUDE M. DAVEY
description: Deaconess Gertrude May Davey of Union United Methodist Church in Brooklyn, died Wednesday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Thermometer Hits 93 As Heat Wave Glowers
description: Yesterday was the hottest day so far in a summer heat wave that may hold the city in its thrall for several more days.

title: Mayor's PayCut Speech in 1932 Echoes Hauntingly
description: Over the radio, the Mayor warned the 147,000 people on the New York City payroll that if they did not accept a voluntary pay cut their financially pressed city faced embarrassment, if not a defunct condition.

title: Bill to Extend Oil Control Voted, But Aides Predict a Veto by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 After rejecting successive Presidential proposals for a gradual decontrol of oil prices, Congress sent President Ford today a bill extending the legal authority for controls for six months beyond the expiration date of Aug. 31.

title: About New York
description: On Monday, Lieut. David Durk began his new assignment, keeping an eye on a halfdozen clerical workers in the office of the Queens detective commander.

title: BAR OWNER IS SEIZED IN SLAYING OF 2 MEN
description: Two men thought to be members of the Angels motorcycle gang were killed and a third critically wounded in Newton, Conn., yesterday by a bar proprietor who said he feared they would shoot him, the police said.

title: LABOR CHIEFS BACK GRAIN SALE THREAT
description: CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) With flour prices on the rise, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations gave its format backing today to a threat by maritimes unions to block the shipment of Soviet grain purchases

title: ROCEFELLER GIVES VIEW ON HIS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31It was Vice President Rockefeller's turn today to talk to news reporters about suggestions that he is too old and too liberal for the 1976 Republican ticket, and he termed the whole discussion a tempest in a teapot.

title: F.C.C. to Speed Washington Star Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Apparently reacting to unusually harsh public criticism of it by Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon, the Federal Communications Commission decided today to speed up the schedule for a hearing it had ordered earlier this week, whose original timing had raised fears for the survival of this city's only remaining afternoon newspaper, The Washington Star.

title: AGNEW TESTIMONY ON C.I.A. HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has asked the Senate Committee on Intelligence for an opportunity to testify about Central Intelligence Agency relationships with the military junta that ruled Greece from 1967 until 1974, authoritative Government sources said today.

title: New Technology tot Expand PayTelevision in the Fall
description: A relatively new communications technology, which was authorized by the Federal Communications Commission in 1970 with expectations that it would be used by business con?? and local governments for private television, will be employed this fall for the distribution of paytelevision in at least a dozen major cities.

title: City CashFlow Outlook Bleak for This Month
description: Three dates stand out in the city's worsening cashflow picture in the month of August, with the situation on the 22d offering the bleakest outlook.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: In an idle hour one day last week we thumbed through our card file of 203 starred restaurants visited during the last 20 months and jotted down a few retrospective masts, leasts, bests and worsts, as follows:

title: 27 on Taiwan Airliner Killed in Crash at Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 31 (UPI)At least 27 persons, including an American couple, were killed when a Taiwan dometic airliner carrying 76 passengers and crew members crashed today while making a second attempt to land at Taipei International Airport in a heavy rainstorm.

title: Long Island Wins Stoddard Cup Golf
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 31Long Island, which last won the Stoddard Cup in 1966, dominated the annual Metropolitan Golf Association triangular matches today by piling up 36 points to 27 for New Jersey and 8 for Westchester, the 1974 winner.

title: Books of The Times
description: If you fancy the romance of being shipwrecked, head for the southwest tip of England, where the Isles of Scilly and the coast of Cornwall lie in wait for you. Proportionate to their size, no islands in the world have a more lethal record than the Scillies, writes the novelist John Fowles in the introduction to Shipwreek, a haunting photographic record of maritime disaster, and few mainland coasts can, in this dark rivalry, surpass those of West Cornwall. Moreover, to add to the danger of the shoals and rocks, there was the ancient occupation of wreckingor wreckinducing and wreckplundering practiced Ly a people who had long suffered what Mr. Fowles names the atrocious economic disregard Ion the rest of England. Legend attests to traditions of dousing true beacons and mounting horn beacons to the heads of wandering clifftop cows. Betterauthenticated stories are told of murdering shipboard animals because of a too literal reading of an ancient Plantaganet statute whose gist in a 17thcentury formulation ran neither bird nor beast having escaped, for if anything had escaped alive, tis not be adjudged Wreck and could not then be plundered.

title: Advertising
description: Having discovered through consumer research that the American people are generally ignorant of our economic system, the Advertising Council is planning a publicservice advertising campaign to improve public understanding and awareness of the system.

title: 25Year Bonds Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The Treasury sold $800million of 25year bonds today at an average rate of 8.44 per cent. Tenders amounted to 82billion. Accepted tenders included 26 per cent of the bids at the highest yield.

title: UNION HEADS MET DUAL PRESSURES
description: Ken McFeeley, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, reportedly wanted to accept the package agreed to yesterday by the Municipal Labor Committee, but was forced to reject it by pressure from within his union.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 1, 1975

title: Hoffa Is Reported Missing
description: DETROIT, July 31James R. Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was reported missing by his family this morning after he failed to come home last night.

title: Confrontation Over Oil
description: The issue of energy policy is still unresolved, as Congress continues to flounder over the problem of how to restrict oil consumption and encourage oil productionwithout putting too heavy a burden on consumers and industrial oil users, and without endangering the stability of the economy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Issue and Debate
description: CHICAGO, July 31Earlier this month confusion and excitement shot through the commodity exchanges in Chicago and Kansas City as the word spread: The Russians are buying, the Russians are buying.

title: SALE TO SOVIET OF GRAIN ASSAYED
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) An Agriculture Department official said today the sale of grain to the Soviet Union would, have little impact on United States food prices, but he acknowledged some other Government agencies were not so certain of that.

title: Card of Thanks
description: SLUTSKYBen J. The Family of the late Ben J. Sfutsky of The Nevele, Fllenville, N.Y., expresses its deep gratitude for the maily messages of sympathy and condolence on our recent bereavement. MARION SLUTSKY

title: About Real Estate
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Ten years ago the Lowentheil family was building a rental apartment house called the Grenada in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. It was a luxury building, according to Howard Lowentheil, and its tenants were largely middle class professional People.

title: Brezhnev Leaves Early Second Straight Day
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 (AP)Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, made another early exit from a reception today, leaving a seaside garden party after only 20 minutes and violating etiquette in the process.

title: Kissinger Vows Clear Action If Israelis Ousted From U. N.
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31, (UPI)The United States will take definite and clear action if Israel is expelled from the United Nations, Secretary of State Kissinger said today.

title: Africans Back Talks With WhiteRuled Nations
description: KAMPALA Uganda, July 31 The Organization of African Unity today approved a declaration calling for further efforts to negotiate with whiteminority governments of southern Africa.

title: Sun Oil Earnings Slide by 58.1% in Second Quarter
EDNA M. JONES
description: Edna M. Jones, secretary of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., was found dead Wednesday in her apartment, 10 West 135th Street she was 66 years old.

title: U.N. CONFERENCE ENDS IN CONFLICT
description: GENEVA, July 31  Diplomats from the third world and industrialized nations ended a crucial United Nations conference today on a gloomy and uncertain note.

title: Massengale Leads Weiskopf By Shot With 65 at Westchester
description: HARRISON, N.Y., July 31Rik Massengale, who has yet to return the putter he borrowed last February, outfoxed difficult pin placements today and shot a 65 to lead the first round of the Westchester Classic.

title: Kinney Is Denied Writ On Jersey City Project
description: NEWARK, July 31  A threejudge Appellate Court panel today denied the National Kinney Corporation a 60day extension of its option to take on an $8.2million contract to develop 650 acres of the Jersey City waterfront.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Mayor Beame asked the City Council to give him the emergency power to freeze the wages of all municipal workers as part of a broad austerity program. The freeze was the principal proposal of a series of economies proposed by the Mayor to overcome a crisis of confidence in our fiscal integrity. Mr. Beame also asked for a freeze on the salaries of managerial employes at the July 1, 1973, level. Meanwhile, municipal unions, representing 175,000 employes, agreed to a voluntary graduated wage freeze, but the city's policemen, firemen and teachers refused to accept a freeze, and they face the prospect of having one imposed by the city. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Auto Output Up in Week
description: DETROIT, July 31American automobile production climbed this week while the auto companies announced plans to recall more workers from indefinite layoff.

title: In Memoriam
description: SMOLOWEAnson Frederick, Aug. 1, 1969. You had to go away, but every day you are in out hearts and minds with reverent and ?? love.

title: Pennsy Creditors Assail Valuations By U.S. Rail Body
description: The chairman of a group Of the Penn Central Railroad's Major secured creditors yesterday strongly criticized the $471  million net liquidating value that the United States Railway Association has placed on the transportation assets of the huge system.

title: Cuts in Medicaid Prompt Anxiety Over Health Care
description: TRENTON, July 31  New Jersey medical and dental officials predicted today a possible loss in the quality of health care for the poor as a result of new state regulations reducing Medicaid reimbursements by 10 per cent effective tomorrow.

title: CONSPIRACY DENIED BY SAN QUENTIN SIX
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 31Charles Garry, defense attorney for Johnny Spain, said today that his client was suffering from impaired consciousness on Aug. 21, 1971, the day he and five other persons allegedly murdered three guards and two inmates in an escape attempt at San Quentin prison.

title: The First Lady's Day: Shopping and Museum
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 (UPI)Betty Ford, saying she was enjoying every minute, shopped again today in Helsinki's outdoor market, toured a historical museum and attended a lunch on a fortress island in the harbor.

title: Plan Spurs Prices of M.A.C. Bonds
description: Prices of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds, which have become Wall Street's thermometer of New York City's fiscal health, improved further yesterday on expanding investor interest in the oncemoribund issues.

title: CROP PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UP 3%
description: Prices fanners receive for raw agricultural products, bolstered by recent grain sales to the Soviet Union, rose 3 per cent from June 15 to July 15, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: North Korean Move for U.S. Talks Is Reported
description: TOKYO, July 31A special envoy of the Japanese Premier has reported after a visit to Pyongyang that the North Korean Government would like to open talks with the United States about an agreement that would replace the existing Korean armistice accord.

title: U.S. Releases Copies Of Pampkin Papers
description: Copies of the pumpkin papers, a set of five microfilms used to implicate Alger Hiss as a Soviet spy, were released by the Justice Department yesterday.

title: REAR ADM. JULIAN BOIT
description: Rear Adm. Julian M. Boit, U.S.N.R., retired, died Wedgesday in Amherst, Mass. His age was 75.

title: Protests Over Censorship Avoided by India's Press
description: NEW DELHI, July 31 (UPI)The Indian press did not carry reports today of statements by the West German Government and the International Press Institute deploring the country']s rigid censorship. Both statements reached. Indian news agencies through foreign news agencies yesterday, but were not published today.

title: George, Wash., Is on the Market
description: GEORGE, Wash.George, Washington, will not be sold to the Arabs.

title: People and Business
description: Max M. Fisher, acting chairman of the United Brands Company since May 12, was elected chairman of the diversified foodprocessing corporation at a board meeting in Boston yesterday. Seymour Milstein, who was elected to the board in April, was named vice chairman.

title: July Sales Were Mixed at Retail Chains
description: July sales of the nation's largest retailers were mixed, with several chains reporting yesterday that they had gains that fell substantially below the inflation rate.

title: GEORGE R. MEYERS
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 31George Roberts Meyers, former superintendent of grounds and buildings at Princeton University, died today at the Princeton Medical Center. His age was 76.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Rangers and the Islanders will hold their threeweek training camps on Long Island for the coming season instead of at their customary Canadian bases. The Rangers will begin preparation for the 197576 season on Sept. 14 at the Nassau County Rink in Long Beach. The Islanders will open camp the next day at the Racquet and Rink in Farmingdale. Rising costs are the chief reasons for the changes.

title: Stratford Winter's Tale a Model of Style
description: STRATFORD, Conn.There is a pure magic to Shakespeare's last plays, an autumnal glory, that has never really been matched, except perhaps in the final quartets of Beethoven, where all pi'sson seems spent and the artist is speaking out with the simplicty of crystal purity.

title: Judge Rules Woman Has Right To Sue Zabar's in Assault Case
description: In denying a move to dismiss a complaint against Zabar's, the West Side delicatessen, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a shopkeeper must summon the police to protect a woman customer from an attempted sexual assault and not subject her to titters and giggles and jokes.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, had only a small downtown otfice and no functioning headquarters in Washington. Mr. Sanford has a headquarters with a fulltime staff headed by Jean Westwood, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. It is housed in a suite of rooms in an office building at 1028 Connecticut Avenue.

title: Carey and A ides Wind Up Trip To Buffalo With a Good Score
description: BUFFALO, July 31Governor Carey corrcluded his near saturation visit of to Buffalo area today with an inspection of roadways around Niagra Falls, a session with local government officials, and a town meeting here of the sort popularized by former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller.

description: BASEBALL

description: TRENTON, July 31  The State Senate passed bills today that would establish a medical malpractice insurance pool and place a $100million housing bond issue on the November ballot.

Theater Workshop of the Theater for the New City begins its fifth annual summer tour of the town with Mama Liberty's Bicentennial Party. It is described as a riproaring rock musical about a little kid named Alvin who gets left behind by the Fresh Air Fund bus arid gets involved with Boss Tweed, Richard Nixon, Jimmy Walker, Abe Beame, Henry Kissinger, Batman, Robin and Muhammad Ali.

description: BUENA PARK, Calif., July 31 (UPI)Gary Sanders, a 25yearold professional golter who was an amateur star at the University of Southern California, was in critics. condition today from the effects of a massive cerebral hemorrhage.

description: DINGMAN'S FERRY. Pa., July 31 (AP)For 13 years, Harold Dickinson has patiently waited for his idyllic riverside village to disappear under eight feet of water into the Delaware River.

description: All right, officer, having been duly informed of my constitutional rights, I make the following confession of my own free will and with full knowledge that anything say may be used against me:

title: Robert P. Heller, 60, Dies; ExCBS Radio Executive
description: Robert P. Heller, head of documentary and factual programing for the Associated Television Corporation of Britain, died Tuesday in London, where he lived. His age was 60.

title: About New York
description: On Monday, Lieut. David Durk began his new assignment, keeping an eye on a halfdozen clerical workers in the office of the Queens detective commander.

description: The jobs of 750 sanitationmen were saved only hours before they were scheduled to be laid off yesterday after Mayor Beame said that new calculations would make it possible to retain them at least for a couple of months without allocating more money to the Sanitation Department's budget.

title: LSD CREATOR SAYS ARMY SOUGHT DRUG
description: STORRS, Conn., July 31Dr. Albert Homann,the Swiss chemist who invented LSD 32 years ago, said here today that he was repeatedly approached during the late nineteenfifties by United States Army re searchers looking for a way to massproduce large quantities of the mindaltering drug.

title: The Pop Life
description: Rod Stewart seems the archetypal British rock superstarespecially as he was the other day in the Hotel St. Regis's overstuffed Presidential Suite, decked out in a vertically striped silk lounging suit open to the waist and necking with Britt Eldand, his current companion.

title: Maharani Critical of Mrs. Gandhi Jailed
description: NEW DELHI, July 31The Maharani of Jaipur, one of India's most glamorous and wealthiest aristocrats, has been arrested, the Government announced today.

title: Laos Denies Visas to A.P. And Times Correspondents
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 (AP)The Government of Laos has refused entry of two American newsmen, Dennis D. Gray of The Associated Press and David A. Andelman of The New York Times, the Laotian Embassy said today.

title: CONOCO REVAMPING CORPORATE SETUP
description: The Continental Oil Company, the nation's 9th largest petroleum products company, announced yesterday a major corporate restructuring that the company's chairman, Howard W. Blauvelt, said will place Continental Oil's operations on a worldwide functional basis, a shift from its current geographical structure.

title: Cosmic Rays Are Traced To Center of This Galaxy
description: For decades, astrophysicists have debated whether the cosmic rays raining down on the earth from the universe came from within the galaxy that includes the sun among its 100 billion stars, or from the billions of galaxies outside.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Reuters Bids Soviet Halt Harassment of Newsmen
description: LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) Gerald Long, managing director of Reuters, today asked Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to intervene to stop what he called harassment of foreign correspondents.

title: Outpatients Exceeded Inpatients In State Mental Centers in 1974
description: Last year for the first time, state psychiatric centers served more people in outpatient programs than in inpatient settings, the 1974 annual report of the State, Department of Mental Hygiene disclosed yesterday.

title: House Resolution Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the House majority leader, has circulated a letter to other House members calling on them to join in a sense of the Congress resolution urging the Administration to consider withdrawing from the United Nations General Assembly if Israel is expelled or suspended from that body.

title: For City Construction, Effect of Cuts Will Be Spotty
description: Construction of schools, libraries and park facilities are likely to suffer the heaviest cuts as a result of Mayor Betune's announcement yesterday that the city's capital budget would have to be cut by $375million, sources in the administration said after the Mayor made his statement.

title: The Screen: 'Hennessy':Rod Steiger Stars as an Irish Assassin
description: A lot of us may have wanted to throw a bomb on occasion but only a few of us have ever set about the task seriously. A bomb thrower is thus different from you and me. Some aspect of his feeling must remain forever mysterious to us, as if he were the sole survivor of an airplane crash. We can speculate on how the wires inside his head are crossed, yet we'll never know for sure."Hennessy," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, may be aware of that and doesn't speculate much at all about the emotional state of its hero, Hennessy Rod Steiger), who sets off from Belfast to London to blow up the Queen, the royal family, the members of the British Cabinet, the House of Lords and the House of Commons at the state opening of Parliament.The movie does give Hennessy a reason to be angry with Britain. He has just seen his wife and daughter accidentally machine-gunned to death by a British soldier during a demonstration against the continued British presence in Northern Ireland. Hennessy has a reason, all right, but reasons and feelings are not what "Hennessy" is all about. It is, instead, a sometimes clever, mostly mechanical suspense melodrama about how Hennessy fails in the nick of time.The film was directed by Don Sharp "The Face of Fu Manchu") and written for the screen by John Gay, who did the screenplay for "Sometimes a Great Notion."Although it is about a political act, it is as carefully apolitical as an aspirin commercial. Hennessy, who, for the convenience of the story, is a demolitions expert, once had connections with the Irish Republican Army, but his plan to fragment Britain's power structure belongs to no one but himself.Indeed, the movie makes a great point of the fact that as soon as word of the plan gets out, his former I.R.A. associates are no less intent on stopping him than Scotland Yard. "If he should succeed," says one I.R.A. fellow with no irony whatsoever, "it would set us back 50 years."Hennessy's assassination plans go along with remarkable ease almost up to the moment of the would-be fatal impact, when he has dressed himself up in the clothes and the identity of a kidnapped M.P. and wired himself with enough explosives to demolish everyone in the Lords chamber.The suspense of the film until this moment has been fairly routine. The concluding sequence, however, is fascinating for the shrewd way in which the fictional footage has been intercut with the newsreel footage, which it perfectly matches. Unless you pay close attention, it does seem as if Elizabeth II looks up from the prepared text of her speech to glower benignly at the interruption caused by the two-footed bomb.This is the only unique aspect of a movie that is otherwise a harmless time-waster. In addition to Mr. Steiger, who seems to be getting rounder with age, "Hennessy" featureswithout demonstrating  the talents of Lee Remick, as an I.R.A. widow, and Trevor Howard and Richard Johnson, as Scotland Yard fellows.

title: Harlem Valley Activist Gets Rail Service Back
description: MILLERTON, N. Y., July 30Lettie Gay Carson, who is seeking to save railroads in the Northeast, has won restoration of passenger rail service on the Harlem Division north to Millerton in Dutchess County.

title: Vilas Gains, Solomon Beaten in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31 (AP)Topseeded Guillermo Vilas struggled to a threeset victory today in the second round of the Louisville pro tennis tournament. He defeated Jeff Borowiak, 46, 63. 76.

title: Reds Teach Brash Giant 116 Lesson
description: John Montefusco, a rookie righthander with the San Francisco Giants, is known as The Count. Perhaps his aristocratic nickname is responsible for his confidence, which borders on brashness.

title: MISS MATHIS STERN AS QUEEN OF WILIS
description: Myrta, Queen of the Wilis, is a reminder of what Giselle could have, indeed should have, become when she found herself in their midst. The entire force of the second act derives from the buffeting that Albrecht endures from their otherworldly fury and Giselle's compassion for him. Eleanor D'Antuono and Ted Kivitt were the maid and the count, and Bonnie Mathis danced a stern Myrta for the first time Wednesday evening at the State Theater in American Ballet Theater's production of Giselle.

title: Chrysler Omitting Dividend
description: The financially troubled Chrysler Corporation, which this week reported an operating loss of $58.7million on its 1975 secondquarter operations, announced yesterday that it would omit payment of a third quarter dividend. The company last paid a dividend in December, 1974, of 35 cents.

title: SOME UNIONS BALK
description: Mayor Beame asked the City Council yesterday to give him the emergency power to freeze the wages of all city union workers as part of a broad austerity package.

title: Brezhnev, at Parley, Sees Bar to Dictating to Others
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31  Leonid I. Brezhnev said at the European security conference today that its important conclusions for Europe's future would discourage any nation from telling another how to run its internal affairs.

title: Microwave Ovens Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration announced today a recall of 168 microwave ovens that it said might be leaking radiation. The ovens are called Bomar builtin electricmicrowave ovens, Models Bx10 and Bx20. They were manufactured by BomarTic Inc., New bury Park, Calif.

title: James Jones. After Paris, a Farm
description: SAGAPONACK, L. I. James Jones, who writes mostly about wars, has established a beachhead in the United States.

title: Does Deterrence Deter?
description: BUFFALO  I do not doubt that strong armies and navies help to win wars, but I doubt that they help avoid them. The $104billion Defense Department budget that President Ford wants for fiscal 1976 may buy us a $104billion triumph in the next world war; I doubt if it can buy us a nickel's worth of peace.

title: McDonnell Douglas Wins $424.3Million Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reuters)The McDonnell Douglas Corporation was awarded three defense contracts totaling $424.3million today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Despite 1975 Lag, Oil Profits Still Gush
description: One year Croesus, the next year Jabthis is the richestorags story told by the oilindustry earnings figures released in the last few days.

title: Seattle Bearing Up Well Despite Boeing's Cutbacks
description: SEATTLEIn the Boeing Company's hangars, assembly plants and lowslung office buildings, which dominate the Seattle industrial scene, workers are haunted again by fears that their jobs may be the next to be abolished. Boeing has slashed its employment from 54,700 to 49,000 so far this year, and company executives say the number will drop to 46,000 by yearend.

title: Taxi Agency Is Said to Fill U.S Jobs Through Politics
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission, depicted recently by industry critics as patronageridden, went through political channels in recruiting workers for a Federal jobtraining program in which patronage hiring is prohibited, those involved with the program have reported.

title: Time to Take Charge
description: Whether he is justified in feeling personally humiliated or not, Mayor Beame is in no position to resist pressure for genuine reforms in the city's archaic management that has brought New York to the brink of financial collapse. Everyone would come out the loser if the initiatives finally forced upon City Hall this week were allowed to be frittered away in a return to mismanagement as usual.

title: Policemen and Manager Injured In Foiled Peekskill Bank Holdup
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1Two policemen were shot here after a bank holdup this morning by three masked gunmen who also pistolwhipped the bank manager and another policeman and briefly held a teller and a customer hostage.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Yank Shift Reported
description: The New York Yankees were reported last night to have hired Billy Martin to replace Bill Virdon as manager. The announcement is expected today. Page 15.

title: Helsinki, a Young City, Is Basking in Limelight
description: For Finnish leaders who have sought to make of Helsinki, their capital, a place where East and West could meet, these have been heady days.

title: Last Chevrolet Convertible, A Corvet, Rolls off the Line
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP)The ragtop era of Chevrolet's popular sports car ended this week when the last convertible model rolled out of the assembly plant here.

title: Dance: Kirkland Giselle
description: Somewhere lurking inside Gelsey Kirkland was a true Romantic dancer, and her local debut Thursday night, at the New York State Theater in the title role of American Ballet Theater's Giselle was confirmation that this is the style that suits her best.

title: Senate RollCall Vote Rejecting Defense Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate refused today to accept a compromise $31.2billion military procurement bill.

title: Sugar Prices Are Reduced
description: Sugar prices, which had been rising steadily since the beginning of July, were rolled back yesterday to a point below those prevailing in the middle of last month. The Amstar Corporation and CPC International, Inc., announced a wholesale price cut orr their industrial sugars. Amstar cut the price of its industrial sugars $3.50 a hundred pounds to $27.70 for extra fine granulated sugar and to $27.30 for bulk granulated sugar and No. 2 liquid sugar.

title: 5 SUGAR CONCERNS ARE FINED 300,000
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (AP)Five of six sugar companies charged with illegal pricefixing have pleaded no contest and have been fined the maximum $300.000.

title: Notes on People.
description: The resignation of Arthur F. Sampson, who had said he planned to remain as head of the General Services Administration until late 1976, has been accepted by President Ford effective Oct. 15. In his letter to the President, the controversial administrator of the Federal Government's housekeeping agency wrote that circumstances are such that he would set the earlier date.

title: Concert
description: Ideally, the word festival (as in Mostly Mozart Festival) should refer to an artistic event of quite limited duration in which every performance is something special, something not to be encountered in the normal run of concerts. That, of course, is the hope; in practice, there is often nothing much festive about performances that have to be rehearsed and put on as summarily as those at the Mostly Mozart Festival, which offers six concerts a week. in addition to prelude recitals.

title: Steelers Top Stars, 2114, On Late Pass
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP)Joe Gilliam came off the bench in the final quarter and threw two touchdown passes to lead the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 2114 victory over football's College AllStars tonight before a nearcapacity crowd of 54,562.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose 4.8 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 201.3 from 196.5 last week.

title: FORD BIDS NATIONS LIVE UP TO SPIRIT OF HELSINKI PACT
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1President Ford, declaring that the summit meeting here will be judged not by the promises we make but by the promises we keep, joined leaders of the Soviet Union and 33 other nations today in affirming a broad charter for peace and human progress throughout Europe.

title: Temblor in South
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Aug. 1 (UPI)A moderate earthquake, centered in this desert resort area, jarred Southern California and was felt in Los Angeles today on the heels of a bigger temblor in the northern part of the state.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Machine to Identify Criminals Among Week's Patented Ideas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1A New Jersey police consultant who supplies guns and other equipment to lawenforcement agencies has invented an apparatus to help witnesses recall and reconstruct the facial appearance of criminal suspects. Standardized features and other components, made of magnetic tape, are collected on flat sheets of metal and held temporarily in place while a portrait is produced.

title: Sinai's Passes Vital, Israeli Generals Say
description: JERUSALEMAir superiority is the key to success in any battle in Sinai.

title: Africans Rebuff Arab Call For U.N. to Expel Israel
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 1The Organization of African Unity, refused today to adopt a resolution calling for the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations.

title: Cuba Is Rapidly Emerging From a Decade of Isolation
description: HAVANA, Aug. 1 Reuters) More than a decade of isolation formally ended for Cuba this week when the Organization of American States voted to lift sanctions against the Island.

title: Lauda Sets Record
description: NUERBURGRING, Germany, Aug. 1 (UPI)  Niki Lauda of Austria, the leader in the world driving championship standing, broke the track record in practice today and became the favorite for Sunday's German Grand Prix auto race. He drove a Ferrari 312T round the 14.1mile Nuerburgring circuit in 7 minutes 6 seconds for an average speed of 121.15 miles an hour.

title: MASSEUSE IS SLAIN IN 56TH ST. PARLOR
description: A 31yearold woman was found stabbed to death yesterday in a midtown massage parfor where she was employed as a masseuse.

title: PROP ANE OUTLOOK PONDERED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Ford Administration, already planning for complete decontrol of oil prices a month from now, pondered today how to deal with one difficult problem if controls expirethe problem of propane.

title: Pate Shuns Deals With Sponsors
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 1Jerry Pate would have no trouble finding a sponsor to back hint on the professional golf tour if he wanted one.

title: Kibbee Bid to Oust Draper Rejected by Education Unit
description: The Board of Higher Education has rebuffed the chancellor of the City University, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, by refusing to accede to his request that Dr. Edgar D. Draper be ousted as president of the troubled Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: PRICE RISE SHOWN IN GRAIN FUTURES
description: In quiet trading yesterday wheat, corn and soybeans moved up a few cents a bushel. Some traders cited concern over sufficient rain for Iowa, where the corn crop needs moisture.

title: SENATE REJECTS ARMS BILL, 4842
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Senate, by a surprise vote of 48 to 42, rejected today a compromise military procurement's bill after the newly created Senate Budget Committee) warned that the legislation would push the defense program over the new budgetary guidelines adopted by Congress.

title: Mansfield Wins Dolls Suit
description: In a suit over the movie Beyond the Valley of the Dolls. Irving Mansfield, widower of Jacqueline Susann, was awarded $2millio damages from 20th CenturyFox by a Los Angeles jury yesterday. The suit for $10million was filed by the couple before the novelist died of cancer last year. It alleged that, since Miss Susann had nothing to do with the film, the studio had exploited the success of The Valley of the Dolls, an earlier movie based on a novel by Miss Susann.

title: Lockheed Says $22Million Went to Officials Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Reversing earlier denials, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today that since 1970 it had paid at least $22million that it knows or believes went to officials and political organizations in a number of foreign countries.

title: Public Defender's Office Is a Subdued Enterprise
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1, (UPI)Roger Lowenstein's Public Defender's office works outside the limelight of New Jersey's Federal courts.

title: July 3dWettest Month In Trenton Since 1865
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)July was the thirdwettest month in Trenton since the National Weather Service began keeping rainfall records in 1865, the service reported today.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: New Jersey Bell Obtains $48Million Rate Increase
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1, (UPI)The New Jersey Public Utilities Commission tenattively approved a $48million rate increase for the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today, plus extra charges for callers who use information operators frequently.

title: DAVID LICHT, 71, OF YIDDISH STAGE
description: David Licht, a wellknown director and former actor on the Yiddish stage, died Thursday of a heart attack in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived here and in Buenos Aires.

title: Old New Orleans Weighing Future
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug 1A man here tells of a cousin, an educated, welltodo woman now approaching middle age, who had never seen any part of the United States beyond a 40mile radius of New Orleans until she was grown and married.

title: Grain Sale Is Seen Possible Catalyst To U.S. Food Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) An agriculture expert testified today that the latest big sale of grain to the Soviet Union could be the catalyst for a 10 per cent rise in United States food prices in 1976.

title: Yunich No Longer Rides Penn Central to Work
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 1 David L. Yunich apparently quit riding Penn Central trains on a regular basis when he took over its operation as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Lockheed Says $22Million Went to Officials Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Reversing earlier denials, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today that since 1970 it had paid at least $22million that it knows or believes went to officials and political organizations in a number of foreign countries.

title: DANE CHANASE
description: Richard Dane Chanase, a painter, printmaker and sculptor, was found dead Wednesday at his home, 3844 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 80 years old.

title: Jobless Rate Off to 8.4%, Hinting Economic Upturn
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The unemployment rate dropped to 8.4 per cent In July as the total number of persons employed rose by 630,000, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Berle Set In New Comedy
description: Milton Berle, whose stage and film career spans 62 years, is returning to Broadway in The Best of Everybody. by Bernard M. Kahn on Oct. 28 at a theater to be announced. The comedian last appeared on Broadway in Herb. Gardner's The Goodbye People in 1968. Mike Merrick and Don Gregory are presenting the comedy in association with Bryon Lasky. The director will be Mel Shapiro.

title: M.A.C BONDS DIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: The bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation slipped downward yesterday in slow trading as banking and investment leaders held meetings to discuss the city's continuing financial requirements.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Cleveland at New York (2 P.M.)  Peterson (57) vs. Dobson (911).

title: City Fails to Clear Backlog of Refuse; Citizen Aid Sought
description: The city announced plans yesterday for 51 neighborhood councils to try to slow the accumulation of garbage, as the Sanitation Department said it was making no progress in reducing the backlog of refuse on the city's streets.

title: Old Rights Units Thrive
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 1In her address at the closing banquet; of the National Urban League's convention here Wednesday night, Eleanor Holmes Norton was interrupted by applause only three times. Yet the speech by New York City's Commissioner on Human Rights, on the pressures on black families, was substantive, her points presented logically with carefully selected and utilized supported data. But it was devoid of hot rhetoric designed to appeal to footstomping and bandclapping audiences.

title: DR. GEORGE N. HAYNAL
description: Dr. George N. Haynal of North Manursing Island, Rye, N.Y., staff surgeon at the DunlapManhattan Psychiatric Center and earlier attending surgeon at the ColumbiaPresbyterian and Downstate Medical centers, died Wednesday of a heart attack at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. His age was 61.

title: NEW U.S. SCHOOL SET FOR CLASSES
description: FT. MONMOUTH, Aug. 1 (UPI)The first arrivals began streaming into Fort Monmouth today to begin classes at the United States Military Academy Preparatory School, which has been moved here from Virginia.

title: Daylight Time Plan Backed
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 1 (AP)  Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman says the experimental eightmonth daylight time period may have been modestly helpful in cutting energy use, traffic deaths and violent crime. In a report to Congress yesterday, he suggested that it be extended through 1977.

title: NORTH CALIFORNIA ROCKED BY QUAKES
description: OROVILLE. Calif., Aug. 1 (UPI)A series of earthquakes, centered only five miles from the nation's tallest earthfilled dam, rolled across a section of Northern and Central California today.

title: Auction of Schooner Is a Lovers' Tryst
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 1She was mistress to surprisingly few masters in her 47 years, but the last three years of service had taken their toll on Nina, once a greatly admired and respected grand dame.

title: Year of Rabbit for Giants?
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. Aug. 1It is the Year of The Rabbit on the Chinese calendar, and it may become the year of the rabbit in professional football.

title: City and Suburban Riders Angered by Fare Increase
description: The prospect of higher transit and commuter fares drew expressions of angry resentment and steamy resignation from New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors yesterday, and Mayor Beame heard some of the reactions firsthand from an unfriendly crowd in Wall Street.

title: Business Briefs
