description: PARIS, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Plans to regroup the activities of France's statebacked computer venture, Cie Internationale de L'intormatique, with the American controlled Honeywell Bull threaten to collapse on the question of control of the new entity, informed sources said today.

title: 6 Convicted by South Yemen As Spies for 2 Companies
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1 (UPI)The high court of South Yemen has sentenced six persons to prison terms ranging from five to 15 years on coniviction of spying for the International Telephone and Telegraph Company and the West GermanBelgian Company AGFA Gavaert, the Iraqi news agency reported from Aden.

title: To the Finland Station
description: HELSINKI, FinlandLenin's arrival at the Finland railway station of Petrograd, a city that would soon bear his name, marked the start of a final phase in the revolution that created the Soviet Union out of Russia and provided an increasingly powerful base for Communist doctrine's international spread.

title: Books of The Times
description: The rise of women's consciousness in the nineteensixties added a burden to the reader of contemporary poetry. Every observant reader in the past has been aware of the special sensibility in the poetry of women, but the tendency has been to assimilate the work into the larger body of American verse. Though it was evident, for example, that Emily Dickinson and Edna St. Vincent Millay (to take two disparate cases) expressed themselves in ways uniquely feminine, their poetry was read, by and large, as part of a tradition that extended not just from Anne Bradstreet and Phillis Wheatley to Anne Sexton and Nikki Giovanni but as one that was part of the wider stream that ran from Edward Taylor to Robert Lowell.

title: 5 Die in Vermont Crash
description: BERKSHIRE, Vt., Aug. 1 (AP)Five young persons were killed tonight when the car in which they were riding crashed into a tree, the authorities said. The accident occurred about five miles south of the Canadian border, the state police said. The victims were not immediately identified.

title: Buying by Computer at a Supermarket in TokyoIt's a Shoplifter's Nightmare
description: TOKYOA computerized supermarket, which opened here recently, has ended shoplifting, mistakes by cashiers, and the long line of customers waiting at cash registers.

title: Opera: Staging Rigoletto in Bandshell
description: Vincent La Selva is a very fine opera conductor. He is also a totally committed man. Last summer he and his New York Grand Opera put on a free performance of Puccini's La Boheme in the bandshell on Central Park's Mall, and it was the first fully staged fulllength opera presented in the city's parks. Encouraged by its success, he scheduled four productions this summer.

title: Lost Evidence at Slaying Scene Is Conceded at Joan Little Trial
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 1The Joan Little defense extracted from a key prosecution witness today a picture of confusion and disorganization, as well as lost, overlooked and destroyed evidence and failure to take notes or photographs or to search thoroughly for fingerprints, in the investigation of the slaying of Clarence T. Alligood.

title: FARE RISE TO COST CITY $16.8 MILLION
description: Because of the 50cent transit fare that goes into effect Sept. 1, the city is expected to increase its payments to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by $16.8million.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Eleanor Uris, 65, Who Headed Election Frauds Bureau, Dead
description: Eleanor Uris, who as an assistant State Attorney General directed the Election Frauds Bureau, died of a stroke Monday at Lake Louise, Alberta, on a trip through Canada. She was 65 years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.

title: Basic Soviet Grain Policy Change Seen
description: Recent Soviet grain purchases abroad are being interpreted by American specialists as further evidence of a basic decision by the Kremlin to move more aggiessively into world grain markets whenever domestic crops fall even marginally short.

title: E. T . Tyler, Gynecologist, Dies; Researched Oral Contraceptives
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP) Dr. Edward T. Tyler, a gynecologist and one of the first research scientists to work on oral contraceptives, died of a heart attack Wednesday. He was 62 years old. Dr. Tyler was considered one of the world's foremost authorities on human fertility.

title: The Dance: Tin Soldier
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.New York City Ballet is playing the horses for the first timerather it is playing with the horses, or even more accurately it is playing at the same time as the horses. The Saratoga flat racing season (that brief sunburst of society and equestrianism) has not previously coincided with the regular City Ballet season at Saratoga. This year it has, and it may be partly the reason why the company is setting boxoffice records. Certainly it means now there are two good reasons for getting out the old Saratoga trunk.

title: M.A.C. AND BANKS SEKING A BILLION FOR AUGUST NEEDS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation and three of the city's largest banksChase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty Trust and First National Citybegan constructing a money package of nearly $1billion yesterday to take care of the city's August cashflow needs.

title: Old New Orleans Weighing Future
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug 1A man here tells of a cousin, an educated, welltodo woman now approaching middle age, who had never seen any part of the United States beyond a 40mile radius of New Orleans until she was grown and married.

title: Shift in China's Military Displayed at a Banquet
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 1Far the first time since the Chinese army was shaken by the death in 1971 of Lin Piao, the former Defense Minister, the entire high command appeared Publicly at a banquet last night to commenmorate the founding of the Chinese Communist armed forces.

title: Baltic Americans Saddened by Pact
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1Standing near the busy cash register in his bustling grocery here today, his English nearly smothered by his accent, Jurgis Janusaitis had reached 1949 in the story of his life.

title: Colby Says Other Bases Cannot Replace Turkey's
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, said in a letter made public today that if the United States permanent. ly lost its intelligencegathering stations in Turkey, deficiencies from such a loss could not be completely made up by any otoher means of relocation.

title: Fiscal Brinkmanship
description: A few weeks ago. Mayor Beame held one of the informal Saturday morning staff meetings at Gracie Mansion that have become a recent but regular fixture in his administration as he and his closest advisors have struggled to detach themselves from the chaos of each week's events, sort out their options and formulate longrange policy.

title: Rozelle: Rams Keep Bryant
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League, facing yet another legal battle on league policies binding a player to a single team, announced yesterday he had canceled the disputed order that sought to send Cullen Bryant to the Detroit Lions.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: STOCKTON, Calif.  Jessie Burnett, Los Angeles, outpointed Alvaro (Indian Yaqui) Lopez, Stockton, 12 lightheavyweights. Weights not available.

title: Hunt for Missing Hoffa Focuses On Figures in Organized Crime
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1State and local policemen, apparently unable to find clues regarding the whereabouts of James R. Hoffa, said today that they had begun to concentrate their investigation on organized crime figures, some of whom have been associated with Mr. Hoffa.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 2, 1975

title: The Green in the Green Pastures Is Brown
description: Each day 4,100 men and women become senior citizens. And for almost half of them, their 65th birthdays close the door to their jobs. They are mandatorily retired, a cornmonplace of work in America.

title: Surefire Favorite In Dexter
description: WESTBURY, L. L, Aug. 1Two weeks after having scored an impressive triumph in the Yonkers Trot, Surefire Hanover will take aim tomorrow night on the second leg of the Big Five for 3yearold trotters, the onemile $122,525 Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: F.C.C. Bars a Settlement Plan On WPIX Rights to Channel 11
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission rejected today, 5 to 2, a proposed settlement that would allow WPIX to maintain control of TV Channel 11 in New York.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: HORACE JAYNE, 77, ART CURATOR, DIES
description: Horace H. F. Jayne, curator of Oriental art at the Norton. Gallery of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., and former vice director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art here, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack in West Palm Beach. He was 77 years old.

title: DRUGGISTS WARN ON MEDICAID CUTS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1New Jersey pharmacists, described today as very unhappy with newlyreduced Medicaid payments for prescriptions, threatened to withdraw from the state Medicaid program.

title: Backward Reels Time
description: Republican conservatives are still uneasy about President Ford. He is racing full tilt toward the nineteenth century, but they suspect his heart is still with the twentieth.

title: Judge Dismisses Changes Against a Lawyer Upstate
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 1 (AP)Judge Ormand N. Gale today dismissed charges against Frrancis Beige, a lawyer for Robert Garrow, who was convicted of murder. Mr. Beige was indicted for failing to report, the location of a murder victim's body.

title: No Excitement in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 1The average Czechoslovak citizen, in common with most East Europeans, seems to regard the Helsinki conference as good in an abstract way but having no perceptible bearing on private life.

title: Lockheed Net Increases; L1011 Losses Up in Half
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that its net income for the second quarter had come to $14.9million, compared with $8.5million for the same period in 1974.

title: People and Business
description: Glen W. Turner, the millionaire Florida franchiser with a taste in estates modeled after medieval castles, said yesterday that Federal authorities have kept pressing fraud charges against him because he refused to contribute $200,000 to former President Nixon's campaign in 1971.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TEEN TROT Two free walking tours open to young people of 12 years and older and guided by student teachers from local colleges are being offered tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday in connection with the Bicentennial celebration as sightseeing footnotes to history. Sponsored by G. H. Bass & Co., the shoe manu facturers. The excursions, are planned to interest vacationing youngsters and also provide interim employment for teachers. The tours, with two separate routes, will begin at 10 A.M., noon and 2 P.M. ?? Bass Walking Tour ??anners at Avenue of the Americas and 59th Street.

title: Art: Small Hepworth Sculpture
description: After July 31, most dealers don't even pretend to mind the store. Shutters come down; iron gates are drawn tight; dogs withdraw, panting, to the country.

title: Sets Subdue Triangles, 31 to 19
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 1 The women of the New York Sets gave their team a big lead against the Pittsburgh Triangles in a World Team Tennis match tonight, and then the men held on to insure a 3119 victory.

title: Choosing Health
description: Early in July, President Ford vowed to use his veto rower as a positive tool to keep the Government from overextending itself at the individual's expense. Last week, Congress overrode his veto of a $2billion health bill. In the debate, the issues which divide the President and the majority of this Congress were clearly exposed.

title: Market Place
description: Memos prepared by Lord, Abbett & Co. in connection with its recent successful bid to assume the management of Bayrock Utility Securities argue that electrical utilities are about to come out of their extended slump.

title: In the Hamptons, Only the Lifeguard Remains the Same
description: EAST HAMPTON. L.I., Aug 1John Cavagnaro has been staring at the ocean for 14 summers in the Hamptons. Some things have changed immensely, but the most important thing has remained the same.

title: Tiny States Mingle With the Mighty
description: HELSINKI, Finland Aug. 1 While the mightiest men of Europe and North America hurried endlessly from big to little summit meetings, the delegates of Europe's tiniest, states, earnestly followed the security conference here and pressed their own diplomacy.

title: Bridge:
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 1A New York team clashed with one from Tennessee in the semifinal of the grand national team championship here this afternoon, while a Los Angeles team met one from Dallas in the other match.

title: Red Sox Win, 87, With 2 Runs in 9th
description: Ten o'clock lightning struck in Fenway Park last night when Detroit scored four runs in the top of the ninth inning on homers by Willie Horton and Bill Freehan.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 2, 1975

title: Soviet Grain Purchases
description: A few weeks ago, Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz was predicting that the Soviet Union would buy about ten million tons of American grain this year. He emphasized at the time that this would only be about half the size of the notorious grain sales of 1972, and he predicted confidently that this year's purchases would have only a minimal impact on domestic prices, a prediction based upon forecasts of record grain crops in this country this year.

title: L.I. Police Officer Gets Leave to Care For Two Orphans
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 1A Nassau County police officer, who had been denied permission for maternity leave to care for two Korean children because she was not their natural mother, today was granted the leave in a reversal of Police Commissioner Louis Frank's original decision.

title: Fiscal Brinkmanship
description: A few weeks ago. Mayor Beame held one of the informal Saturday morning staff meetings at Gracie Mansion that have become a recent but regular fixture in his administration as he and his closest advisors have struggled to detach themselves from the chaos of each week's events, sort out their options and formulate longrange policy.

title: Rockwell Holding Talks On Sale of 11 of Its Units
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, a major diversified manufacturer with sales last year of over $4.4billion, is discussing the sale of 11 of its divisions with annual volume estimated at around $160million.

title: Cautious Approach By Miss Harwood Marks Swan Lake
description: Vanessa Harwood's careful, clean approach to her Swan Lake leads her to give an accurate reading of her role, if not a specially illuminated one. She was joined by Rudolf Nureyev Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House in the odd production staged by Erik Bruhn for the National Ballet of Canada.

title: FARE RISE TO COST CITY $16.8 MILLION
description: Because of the 50cent transit fare that goes into effect Sept. 1, the city is expected to increase its payments to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by $16.8million.

title: Judge Orders Integration Plan For Indianapolis School System
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 1A Federal judge today ordered the transfer next month of 6,533 black pupils from the Indianapolis school system to eight suburban school systems that he held have consistently resisted the movement of black citizeris or black pupils into their territory.

title: Stone Rescued Amid Pirates' Rally in 7th
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1Dave Kingman did not hit a home run tonight, but he did bunt for a runscoring single. This is August, not July.

title: POLICE FACE SUIT IN KENNEDY CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1Two men and CBSTV announced today that they would sue to force disclosure of police evidence in the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Man Found Guilty Of Slaying a Priest In School Shooting
description: SALEM, Aug. 1 (UPI)David Gary, who went on a shooting spree in a Penns Grove school last February, was found guilty of firstdegree murder tonight in the killing of the Rev. Thomas J. Quinlan.

title: Miss Conley Gains Women's Golf Final
description: CLEMMONS, N. C., Aug. 1 (UPI)  Peggy Conley of Spokane, Wash., defeated Cindy Hill, the current United States Amateur champion, 3 and 1, and Debbie Massey of Bethlehem, Pa., beat Nancy Lopez of oRswell, N. M., 3 and 2, today as they gained the final tomorrow of the women's Western amateur golf championship.

title: Average Rise of $200 Set on New A.M.C. Cars
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1The American Motors Corporation has set tentative prices showing an average rise of $200, or 5.8 per cent on its 1976 models.

title: Agnew Denies Campaign Gift Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew said today that the wanted to tell the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence that he knows of no contributions to the NixonAgnew campaign from rulers of the Greek military junta.

title: Japan and Korea
description: Japan deserves the fullest encouragement from the United States in its tentative beginnings toward an independent diplomatic role on the Korean peninsula. Prime Minister Miki, arriving this weekend for his first official visit to Washington, has placed the Korean question high on his agenda for talks with President Ford and top American policymakers.

title: Jumpers Get Day At Saratoga Meet
Synagogues Scored for Failing to Influence Youth
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1  The American synagogue was criticized today by the head of the nation's largest Jewish teenage movement for not having a more pervasive influenceamong youth.

title: COLEMAN REJECTS ROAD TO CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. ruled today against completion of the Northern Virginia leg of Interstate Highway 66 into Washington, and in his written opinion indicated his preference for mass transportation instead of highways for environmental reasons.

title: M.A.C. AND BANKS SEEKING A BILLION FOR AUGUST NEEDS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation and three of the city's largest banksChase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty Trust and First National Citybegan constructing a money package of nearly $1billion yesterday to take care of the city's August cashflow needs.

title: Consumer Agency Approves Swimming Pool Safety Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The Consumer Product Safety Commission tentatively approved today a proposed safety standard for swimming pool slides to reduce the estimated 50,000 injuries that occur annually in four million swimming pool.

title: Police Kill a Man In Boat Near HelsinkiTalks Party
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1An unidentified, man was killed by Finnish security men last night after his boat ventured near the site of a party for delegates of the European security conference.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower in the slowest volume of trading for any day so far this year. Only 1.3 million shares changed hands compared with 1.7 million the previous day. The Amex index dropped 0.73 to 89.23.

title: After Parley, a Long Way to Go
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1Many leaders at the Conference on European Security and Cooperation, which ended here today, called it a milestone, and it was. It marked how far EastWest relations had evolved since the depth of the cold war, one how much further they had to go.

title: Lisbon Truce Mission Flies to Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  A toplevel Portuguese military mission flew into Angola today as fighting spread through more of the territory and thousands of refugees packed two major cities.

title: Shaky Thai Coalition Bolstered As It Wins Key Confidence Vote
description: BANGKOK, Thailand Aug. 1 The fragile coalition Government won a key vote of confidence in the National Assembly early today with a preliminary approval of a record $3.13billion 1976 annua budget.

title: M.A.C. BONDS DIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: The bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation slipped downward yesterday in slow trading as banking and investment leaders held meetings to discuss the city's continuing financial requirements.

title: Blacks in the Military
description: WASHINGTONThe richest, most powerful agency of the Government has been caught stealthily in pursuit of an unauthorized policy that is as threatening to the nation's moral fiber as a runaway Central Intelligence Agency and an undisciplined Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: FORD BIDS NATIONS LIVE UP TO SPIRIT OF HELSINKI PACT
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1President Ford, declaring that the summit meeting here will be judged not by the promises we make but by the promises we keep, joined leaders of the Soviet Union and 33 other nations today in affirming a broad charter for peace and human progress throughout Europe.

title: Anne Farr Is Wed to R. Parker Kuhn Jr.
description: Anne Witherspoon Farr, a fashion consultant here, was married yesterday afternoon to R. Parker Kuhn Jr. of Bedford, N. Y., manager of export for, the Otto H. York Co., Inc., of Parsippany, N. J. The Rev. Arthur W. Hargate performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: PHILHARMONIA SETS SIX PARKS CONCERTS
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia, which gave three concerts in its first series in the parks last summer, will give six this year.

title: I.B.M. Canada Acts On Contribution's In Political Area
description: Machines Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, IBM Canada, Ltd., will The International Business forego its customary and legal practice of making political contributions.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FORCE QUITTING RHODESIA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 1South Africa is withdrawing her paramilitary police force from Rhodesia and leaving the Salisbury Government to face guerrilla infiltrators alone.

title: Connally Raising Funds and Issues
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1  John Bowden Connally played host to a fundraising dinner for himself here last night, raised $300,000 to $400,000 from both Republicans. and Democrats, and showed that he bad retained much of his old political power in Texas.

title: Jersey's Assembly Votes Budget Bills To Ease Cutbacks
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1The State Assembly completed passage tonight of the revenue measures designed to help restore $267million in state programs that were cut from the state budget for economy reasons.

title: APARTMENT FIRE KILLS 7 UPSTATE
description: HIGHLAND FALLS; N.Y., Aug. 1A young mother and six children, five of them her own, died today when fire swept through their attic apartment in this village adjacent to the United States Military Academy.

title: Dolly Parton, a Country Girl, Is Widening Her Scope
description: Country music is a lot more open than it used to be Singers who don't revolve in Nashville's orbit can stall top the country chartsOlivia NewtonJohn and Linda Ronstadt, for instance.

title: Things That Glow Bright in the Night
description: The city has taken on an eerie glow. Phosphorescent bands of green light are glimmering in dark cafes, at concerts in Central Park and on street corners at night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Helen Markel, Robert Clurman Wed
description: Helen Markel, an editor of McCall's magazine, was married yesterday noon to Robert Clurman, former editor of the Week in Review section of The New York Times, where he also was deputy foreign editor. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 52yearold woman who had spent more than 18 months in Rikers Island Prison for civil contempt arising from a custody case was granted an interim parole yesterday by a Supreme Court Justice. The case involves Teddy Feldman, who was originally imprisoned for refusing to reveal the whereabouts of her foster son, David Rosoff, who was born to Miss Feldman's commonlaw husband, Dolph Rosoff, when they all lived together in the East Village.

title: Rehabilitation Astonishes
description: PEKING, Aug. 1The rehabilitation of Lo Juiching has astonished foreign observers in Peking.

title: Coast Court Drops Old Rule on Rape
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 (UPI)The California State Supreme Court, in a ruling hailed as a victory by the National Organization for Women, yesterday ended a 300yearold Jaw requiring judges to tell juries rape was easily charged and difficult to defend.

title: Jobless Rate Off to 8.4%, Hinting Economic Upturn
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The unemployment rat dropped to 8.4 per cent in July as the total number of persons employed rose by 630,000, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SENATE REJECTS ARMS BILL, 4842
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Senate, by a surprise vote of 48 to 42, rejected today a compromise military procurement bill after the newly created Senate Budget Committee warned that the legislation would push the defense program over the new budgetary guidelines adopted by Congress.

title: N.M.U. ATTORNEY IS ASKED FOR FILES
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1A Federal judge here today ordered the attorney for the National Maritime Union to produce extensive financial records of his law firm for a grand jury investigating alleged corruption among present and former leaders of the union.

title: ALFRED KASTNER, 74, ARCHITECT, IS DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Alfred Kastner, an architect of the country's first public housing project, died of cancer Tuesday in the Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Bishop in Honduras Asserts Ranchers Want to Kill Him
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Aug. 1 (AP)The Roman Catholic bishop of Olancho, a Honduran province where two priests were killed, says land reform opponents there have put a $10,000 price on my head.

title: Curtain Falls Softly at Helsinki Parley
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe ended today with a whisper of pens as the ranking representatives of 35 assembled states, from superpowers to pocket nations, signed the pages of a huge document worked out over the last two years.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Riddick Captures British 100Meter
description: LONDON, Aug. 1 (UPI)Steve Riddick of the United States won the 100meter dash today at the twoday British Amateur Athletic Association track and field meet.

title: Rottweiler Chosen Best of 1,266 Dogs
description: LANSDALE, Pa., Aug. 1The Rottweiler is a dog long on historical backgroundancient Romebut relatively short when it comes to taking home bestinshow awards. So there was a stir around the ring at the Perkiomen Valley Club's fixture on the grounds of North Penn High School today when Charles Hill's Ch. Erno vom Ingenhof was chosen for the top award in a field of 1,266.

title: Psychiatric Test Ordered Before Sentencing in Fraud
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP) A 52yearold accountant from Yonkers, N.Y. who pleaded guilty to his part in a scheme to bilk the city out of $3.5million has been ordered to undergo a 90day psychiatric study prior to his sentencing.

title: The Memphis 3 Go to Work Tonight
description: Almost as if they were three men who had descended from the moon over Miami, the most celebrated players in the history, and finance of the World Football League will begin perspiring under a microscope tonight. Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield and Jim Kiick of the Memphis Southmen will open their W.F.L. season against the Jacksonville Express, with Csonka joking about his role. I am, Zonk says with a grin that linebackers never see, just a blocking back now. Not really. Once the body and soul of the Miami Dolphins' offense on two Super Bowl champions, Larry Csonka is the personification of the Southmen's unofficial nickname, the Grizzlies, as W.F.L. tacklers will learn. But the 240pound fullback is enjoying the reincarnation of Jim Kiick as a running back. In the Southmen's final exhibition game last week, Kiick ran for 115 yards in 33 carries.

title: Segregationist Gets 5 Years For Transporting a Bomb
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 1 (UPI)Byron de la Beckwith, Mississippi segregationist, today was sentenced to five years in prison for illegally bringing a ticking time bomb into Louisiana.

title: Railroad Clarifies Earnings
description: The Union Pacific Company in the second quarter of 1975 made provision in its income acounts for a $31.6million ??tax reserve for possible losses on a subsidiary's lease acquisition costs. There was no corresponding reserve in the second quarter of 1974, as was indicated in these columns yesterday. A 1974 reserve of $31.2million was taken by the company in the fourth quarter of that year.

title: Hunt for Missing Hoffa Focuses On Figures in Organized Crime
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1State and local policemen, apparently unable to find clues regarding the whereabouts of James R. Hoffa, said today that they had begun to concentrate their investigation on organized crime figures, some of whom have been associated with Mr. Haifa.

title: Hearing for Capital Paper
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission ordered an expedited hearing on Aug. 8 today on whether the parent company of The Washington Star should be allowed to retain its profitable broadcast properties. The paper is in danger of going out of business if it is forced to dispose of its television and radio stations.

title: City Fails to Clear Refuse Backlog
description: The city announced plans yesterday for 51 neighborhood councils to try to slow the accumulation of garbage, as the Sanitation Department said it was making no progress in reducing the backlog of refuse on the city's streets.

title: A Nationalist Group in Cabinda Declares Area Free of Portugal
description: LONDON, Aug, 1The disputed exclave of Cabinda was declared independent today by the president of that Portuguese territory's nationalist movement, based in Kinshasa, Zaire.

title: Crater Park Reopens After Sewer Repairs
description: CRATER LAKE, Ore., Aug. 1Crater Lake National Park, a scenic 250square mile area of pines, deer and bears surrounding an ancient collapsed volcano and the world's seventh depest lake, reopened today three weeks after a mysterious malady struck more than 1,000 visitors and workers and closed the facility.

title: 100 Are Injured in Boston as 3 Subway Trains Collide in the Rush Hour
description: BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) Three rapid transit trains all going in the same direction collided today in a chain reaction in the evening rush hour, injuring more than 100 persons.

title: Soviet Wary of the Internal Effects of Detente Abroad
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1While hopes are expressed in the West that the European security agreement will liberalize some aspects of life in the Soviet Union, there is no evidence here that the leadership intends any relaxation of its tight and pervasive control.

title: A Black Market Is Uncovered In Muncie in Canning Jar Lids
description: MUNCIE, Ind., Aug. 1This country's big demand for lids for home canning jars has resuited in the first case of theft and blackmarketeering of this now precious commodity.

title: HOWARD J. M'AULIFFE
description: Howard J. McAuliffe, director of domestic terminals of American Export Lines, Inc., died Thursday of cancer at the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, N. J. He was 52 years old land lived in Spring Lake Heights, N. J.

title: MEDICAID LIMITS PUT ON ABORTIONS
description: An appeals court has decided that a Federal law does not require Connecticut to make Medicaid payments for abortions unless they are medically necessary.

title: Dow Index Off 5.01; Volume at '75 Low
description: Shrugging off the Government report that the nation's jobless rate dropped to 8.4 per cent in July from 8.6 per cent the previous month, the stock market closed lower yesterday in the lightest trading of the year.

title: Income Inequality in Britain Found to Change Little in Decade
description: LONDON, Aug. 1The last decade of welfare economics in Britain appears to have done little to change the inequality of incomes between rich and poor. But the gap since before World War II has narrowed dramatically.

title: Ford's Son Has Trouble Keeping Up With Father
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 (AP)Showing more effects from jet lag than his parents, Jack. Ford wondered how father can do it as he toured two technical installations here today.

title: Germany's Payment Surplus Showed a Decline in June
description: FRANKFURT, Aug. 1 (Reuters)West Germany's balance of payments on current account showed a provisional surplus of 723 million marks in June, against a revised surplus of 1,053 billion marks in May, and a surplus of 460 million marks in June, 1974, the Bundesbank said today. The recent surplus is equivalent to $282million at current exchange rates.

title: Calm After Coup, Nigeria Acts to End Emergency Curbs
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 1 (Reuers)Nigeria's new military tillers announced today that all emergency measures imposed since the removal of Gen. Yakubu Gowon, from power on uesday would be lifted tomorrow.

title: 3 JAILED FOR AIDING DOMINICAN REBELS
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 1 (AP)A Dominican court has convicted three Puerto Rican Socialists of violating this nation's internal security laws and has sentenced each to 30 years in prison.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Aug. 1, 1975

title: U.S. Reported Refusing Entry to ExSaigon Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Reuters)The United States is advising Dang Van Quang, the refugee South Vietnamese general accused of heroin smuggling, that he has Virtually no hope of being ad mitted to this country, American officials said today.

title: Baltic Americans Saddened by Pact
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1Standing near the busy cash register in his bustling grocery here today, his English nearly smothered by his accent, Jurgis Janusaitis had reached 1949 in the story of his life.

title: CYPRIOTES AGREE ON TRANSFER PLAN
description: VIENNA, Aug. 1Leaders of the opposing communities on Cyprus reached agreement here today on the transfer of minorities, and Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations called it an important step forward.

title: VINCENT LACAPRIA OF CLOTHING UNION
description: Vincent Lacapria, a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and comanager of the union's New York Joint Board, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his sleep. He was 76 years old and lived in Hempstead. L.I.

title: Delafield Hospital Shuts Doors After 24 Years' Service
description: The last nurse closed her locker gently. The last patient, alive for 12 years after cancer diagnosis, saw a doctor at the hospital for the final time. And a director fought back tears for the peoplesome who will suffer and others who will dipbecause of its demise.

title: Jersey's Assembly Passes Revenue Bills
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1The State Assembly completed passage tonight of the revenue measures designed to help restore $267million in state programs that were cut from the state budget for economy reasons.

title: WILLIAM M. SHORT
description: William M. Short, a retired real estate broker, formerly with Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., of New York, died Tuesday at his home in Allendale. N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: POUND AT NEW LOW; GOLD DROPS BY 15c
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 1 (UPI)The British pound, despite bouts of resistance throughout the day, closed today at a new low against the dollar. The dollar, which has risen steadily throughout the week on foreign exchanges, leveled off in quiet weekend trading. quiet areweekend trading.

title: Cosmos Beaten; Playoff Unlikely
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 1The Hartford Bicentennials defeated the New York Cosmos, 31, tonight and virtually wiped out all chances Pel's team had for a playoff berth in the North American Soccer League.

title: Pace Slackens as Mercury Soars to a Hazy 93 in City
description: The tropical city of New York looked like something out of a slowmotiion movie yesterday, as the temperature rose once again into the nineties, wilting everything in sight.

title: Freight Traffic Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.3 billion tonmiles. 14.4 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 431,253 cars, 17.2 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 17.0 per cent below last year.

title: Card of Thanks
description: SLUTSKYBen J. The Family of the late Ben J. Slutsky of The Nevele, Ellenville, N.Y., expresses its deep gratitude for the many messages of sympathy and condolence on our recent bereavement.

title: 1798 Washington, a Bleffed Paradife
description: Publiclz notice. To our fair readerf of the OpEd Page of The New York Timef: The following article if excerpted from the February, 1799, iffue of The Lady? Magazine; or, Entertaining Companion for the FAIR SEX, appropriated folely to their Ufe and Amufement. It was first publifned in England.

title: Oona O'Neil Chaplin Gives 1,000 To Museum for Father
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 1  Oona O'Neill Chaplin, daughter of the late playwright Eugene O'Neill,. has made a $1,000 donation toward restoration of the Monte Cristo cottage here where her father spent summers as a boy.

title: No Assurances Given on C.I.A. Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 James T. Lynn, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, told Congress today that he could not provide assurances that none of the funds currently appropriated to the Central Intelligence Agency were being spent for illegal covert activities or for domestic surveillance of American citizens.

title: CYPRIOTES AGREE ON TRANSFER PLAN
description: VIENNA, Aug. 1Leaders of the opposing communities on Cyprus reached agreement here today on the transfer of minorities, and Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations called it an important step forward.

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, it was incorrectly stated in the New Jersey editions on Wednesday that New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner, Alan Sagner, was not concerned with the possible elimination of rail lines in the state under a proposed Federal plan. Mr. Sagner said he was most concerned over the possible elimination of the lines.

title: Text of President Ford's Address to Final Helsinki Session
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug: 1 (Reuters)Following is the text of President Ford's speech to the European security summit meeting today:

title: City and Suburban Riders Angered by Fare Increase
description: The prospect of higher transit and commuter fares drew expressions of angry resentment and steamy resignation from New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors yesterday, and Mayor Beame heard some of the reactions firsthand from an unfriendly crowd in Wall Street.

title: F18 FIGHTER CHOSEN IN SHIFT BY MARINES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Reuters)The Marine Corps commandant general, Louis Wilson, today reversed a decision of his predecessor and said that the Marines would buy the F18 fighter instead of the more expensive Grumman F14.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Four New Jersey residents were killed when their car skidded across a highway and was struck broadside by a truck near Rock Hill, S.C. Cpl. J. E. Vargos of the South Carolina Highway Patrol identified the dead as Samuel Shivers, 68 years old; Mabel Shivers, 27; Alonzo Shivers, 33, and Cynthia Burns, 17. The Shivers were from East Orange; Miss Burns was from Dauxhall.

title: Congress Starts Recess; Conflict With Ford Holds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The 94th Congress, which began last January with a renewed pledge from President Fold of communication, conciliation, compromise and cooperation, began a monthlong recess today in a conflict with the President over energy policy.

title: Costs Up for the Retired
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) The average annual cost for retired couples living in urban areas rose about 11 per cent between autumn, 1973, and autumn, 1974, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Japanese Securities Groups Consider Overseas Offices
description: TOKYO, Aug 1 (Reuters)The Japanese Ministry of Finance said it was considering plans by seven Japanese securities concerns to set up overseas offices. They include the Nikko Securities Company, Ltd., opening a representative office in Beirut, Lebanon, end the Daiwa Securities Company, Ltd., setting up a similar office in Cairo this year, it said.

title: The Paris Couture: Serenely Relevant Most of the Time
description: PARIS, Aug. 1The couture is pulling in its horns, retrenching. It's recovering from the culture shock of the hippie movement and the antifashion attitudes of the last few years.

title: UNCTAD to Study Way of Stabilizing Price of Tungsten
description: GENEVA, Aug. 1The prospects for achieving a workable international agreement to stabilize tungsten prices are to be examined under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

title: Mr. Shanker's Blinders
description: The notion persists in some quarters that New York is in its deep fiscal crisis because of a mysterious conspiracy that has arbitrarily cut off the city's credit. The theory suggests that, except for some subterranean villainy, the city's mode of operation need never have been disturbed and no sacrifices would now be necessary to terminate an artificially created emergency.

title: MITCHELL BRIEF SAYS TRIAL WAS TAINTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell charged today that the juors who convicted him in the Watergate coverup trial were drawn froth a poisoned well because they held preconceived opinions about the case.

title: 3d World Deficits Forecast
description: GENEVA, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Continuing low demand for third world exports mean the combined commercial deficit of nonpetroleum exporting developing countries could be at least $33billion this year against $26billion in 1974, a report from the United Nations Conferences on Trade and Development said.

title: GARY SANDERS DIES; GOLF PLAYER WAS 25
description: BUENA PARK, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP)Gary Sanders, a professional golf player and a former amateur star at the University of Southern California, died today, two days after having suffered a massive cerebral hemorrhage. He was 25 years old.

title: Threat of Suburbanization Tied To Rejection of Tocks Dam Plan
description: TRENTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)The New Jersey Environmental Commissioner, David J. Bardin, indicated today that the threat of suburbanization had contributed to the death of the Army's 15yearold plan for a dam on Tocks Island in the Delaware River.

title: SOVIET WEIGHING NEW GRAIN DEALS
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 1 (AP)The Soviet Union is talking to a French company and a West German concern about buying one million tons of grain for quick delivery, Common Market Agriculture Commissioner Pierre Lardinois said today.

title: Harvard Club Is Struck
description: The darkwalled serenity of the Harvard Club, only three months recovered from a contretemps over the ratio of spirits in its martinis, was marred yesterday by a strike by dining room and bar workers protesting the dismissal of a longtime employe.

title: Life Moves at Petty's Pace, From One Million to the Next
description: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 2The modest roadside motel looked almost deserted. A young woman swam lazily in the small pool and only one car, a bright blue and red van, was parked in front of the room units. Its owner was either sleeping off a 10hour drive or counting his millions.

title: One year of San Clemente
description: SAN CLEMENTE. He is no longer in power, but still the tourists come, seeking a glimpse of him in disgrace. At just about any time on most afternoons, a halfdozen vehicles will be parked along Avenida del Presidente (some vandalized street signs read Avenida del exPresidente). The tourists stretch their legs beside the high wall around La Casa Pacifica and nod sheepishly at one another: families in outofstate campers full of kids, elderly Californians out for Sunday drives, young longhairs in customized vans. They don't see muchthe wall and, above it, the tops of palms. Soon they are impatient and leave.

title: Changing L.I. Viewed Aloft
description: WESTBURY  When William Fried quit accounting nearly 30 years ago, he started moving upup as high as his aerial photography could take him.

title: Columbia Encyclopedia: Instant Universe Again
description: Making a onevolume encyclopedia is like taking the broth of the universe and condensing it into a bouillon cube.

title: Ugly Lots Blossom Into Parks For a While
description: NEWARKA plan to turn ugly vacant lots into attractive portable parks has taken root across from City Hall.

title: Edith Ware Bridgman Bride of Minister
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Jefferson, N.H., yesterday afternoon, Edith Ware Bridgman of Boston, daughter of Mrs. Robert Ware Bridgman of Wilton, Conn., and Jefferson, and the late Mr. Bridgman, became the bride of the Rev. Dr. William Joseph Ventimiglia of Haverhill, Mass.

title: Rockefeller Picks Steel Aide
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 (AP)R. Heath Larry, the United States Steel Corporation vice chairman, has been named a counselor to Vice President Rockefeller on productivity matters.

title: Southmen Win, 2726, on Kiick's Tally
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 2 (UPI)Jim Kiick ran a yard for a touchdown with 38 seconds to play tonight and Jacksonville missed an action point with 2 seconds left as the Memphis Southmen won, 2726, from the Express in a World Football League season opener.

title: AliForeman: The Eighth and Final Round
description: The bell rang for the eighth round. Working slowly, deliberately, backing up still one more time, Muhammad All hit George Foreman carefully, spacing the punches, taking aim, six good punches, lefts and rights. It was as if he had a reserve of good punches, a numbered amount like a soldier in a siege who counts his bullets, and so each punch had to carry a predetermined portion of the work.

title: G.O.P. Urged to Pick State Backing Rights Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) The League of Women Voters asked the Republican party today to hold its 1976 national convention in a state that has ratified the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: Cones and Stones and Spider Webs Can Become Creative Whimsies
description: Collectors of such apparently worthless items as spider webs, ordinary rocks, cornhusks, fungi, seashells, pine cones, tree burls, driftwood, berries, bones, and innumerable other odds and ends of nature comprise large and varied group of hobbyists generally known as naturecrafters.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the article on the marriage of Nancy Ruth Finn to Arthur William Kuper Jr., published in last Sunday's New York Times, the educational background of the bridegroom was erroneously attributed to the bride's father.

title: The Equipment Dilemma
description: EVEN a streamlined camping trip requires some initial investment. The current issue of Ms. estimates in its cover piece on backpacking that the welloutfitted feminist bushwhacker will spend between $200 and $500. My family was anxious to spend a total of no more than $500 on new equipment. And we looked squintily at such helpful sources as Colin Fletcher's The New Complete Walker (Knopf, $8.95) and the catalogue of L. L. Bean, the mailorder outfitter in Freeport, Me.

title: Litvinov Granddaughter Denied Visa to Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (AP) Tatyana Litvinov, daughter of the late Maxim Litvinov, the Soviet Foreign Minister in the nineteenthirties said today she had protested to the European security conference in Helsinki because Soviet authorities had refused to let her daughter return to Moscow from the United States for a visit.

title: POLICE IN CLEVELAND CURB MELEE BY 500
description: CLEVELAND Aug. 2 (UPI)A mob of 500 young persons fought the police with bricks and bottles, smashed windows and looted downtown stores early today, after refusing to leave the city's annual All Nations Festival and its 25cent beer at closing time.

title: The Dance
description: Antony Tudor's Shadowplay is a witty, profound ballet that requires care from its dancers if its symbolism is to be understood. Friday night at the State Theater, Fernando Bujones made his debut as the hero, the Boy With the Matted Hair, in the new American Ballet Theater production. The role fitted him like a glove.

title: Cynthia Halsey Has Nuptials
description: Cynthia Everett Halsey and H. William Snyder Jr., son of Audrey J. Snyder and Howard W. Snyder, both of Hamilton, N. Y., were married yesterday afternoon. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Van Rensselaer Halsey of Locust, N. J., and Thendara, N. Y.

title: Food News
description: SOUTH AMBOYThe season is just beginning for good shellfish dinners, ending a period when diners felt something lacking in their ordered repasts.

title: Haman Chain Over U.S. Urged for Bicentennial
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)Marvin J. Rosenblum has a monumental plan for citizen involvement and unifying the United States on its 200th birthday celebration next July 4: a human chain of millions of Americans holding hands from sea to sea.

title: Bay State Nuptials For Miss Dwinnell
description: Joanne Dwinnell and Martin Koon Bovey Jr. of Boston were married yesterday afternoon in Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Craig W. Casey performed the Episcopal ceremony at the summer home of the bride's mother.

title: Explosion in a shingle factory
description: IT WAS the most famous painting of its day. Laughed at and lampooned in the press (the headline above was one of the more polite descriptions of it), it nevertheless was beyond question the great success of New York's famous Armory Show of 1913. Marcel Duchamp's Nude Descending a Staircase was unlike any nude ever seen before in art. She did not lie or stand, motionless, as respectable painted nudes had always done before. She hit the road. Right across the canvas, down a flight of stairs, in a blur of angular nakedness.

title: Check Finds 60% of Beef For Military Substandard
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) A spot check, by its staff, of beef consigned to the military has shown that more than 60 per cent of the meat failed to measure up to standards, a Senate panel says.

title: Susan Murphy Bride of Richard Fahey
description: Susan Catherine Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Vincent Murphy Jr., of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L. I., and Christiansted, St. Croix, V. I. was married yesterday afternoon to Richard James Fahey, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Fahey of Andover and Scituate, Mass.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets play a fivegame series with the Montreal Expos, the lastplace team in the National League East, beginning tomorrow in Shea Stadium. Tomorrow night's game begins at 8:05 o'clock. Tuesday's twilightnight doubleheader starts at 5:30 and the series winds up with single game's. Wednesday at 8:05 and Thursday afternoon at 2:05. The Mets then play three games against the Los Angeles Dodgers starting with a night game Friday. Saturday's game begins at 2:15 P.M. The Yankees are on the road all week.

title: Dr. D. A. Foley Weds Janis Kennard
description: Janis Kennard, a. research assistant at the Cornell University Medical College here, and Dr. David Allen Foley, a research scientist in the department or preventive medicine at the New York University Medical School, were married yesterday afternoon.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Nancy Drew

title: LIVING COSTS CALLED KEY WORRY BY 47%
description: The number of Americans who think that the high cost of living is the nation's biggest problem has dropped from 81 per cent last October to 47 per cent last month, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Is Ford Really Serious?
description: WASHINGTONAt the end of the Helsinki summit conference, which was billed as the most spectacular gathering of world leaders since the Congress of Vienna, the main story in The New York Times was that the New York subway fare was going up to fifty cents, and the top headlines in The Boston Globe were that Turkey and turned down a $50million handout from the United States, and the Boston Red Sox had won a doubleheader.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Overcrowding in State Prisons Again Produces Fear of Unrest
description: The inmate population of the state's 25 prison facilities has swelled to more than 16,000 prisoners, and observers fear that the resulting overcrowded conditions, which have already led to a number of incidents, may spark major disturbances at any time.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONWhen friends of Governor Byrne announced last week their formation of a private organization to finance his nongovernmental traveling and research expenses, the Republicans reacted with cries of foul, and even many Democrats raised their eyebrows.

title: Songflori $9 Victor In Dexter
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 2 Songflori, a 3yearold colt who had leg problems in his first trotting season, scored an upset victory tonight in the $118,525 Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: AN ANGOLAN AIRLIFT OF WHITES PLANNED
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 2 (AP)From 250,000 to 300,000 whites, apparently fearing chaos when factionally troubled Angola becomes independent in the fall, will be airlifted out over the next three months, officials of this Portuguese colony said today.

title: Design
description: The mansion George and Louise Beylerian bought in IrvingtononHudson two years ago has Italianate interiors that were popular at the turn of the century. In theory, the Beylerians should have hated this baronial style. He imports sophisticated, modern plastic furniture from Italy, she was in the interiordesign field before their two children were born. But the spaciousness of the house, its twoacre setting and the architectural flights of fancy in its 25 rooms were appealing. On the main floor, the living room, with fluted columns and beamed ceiling frosted with plaster work, measures 24 by 36 feet. In addition there are a dining room, billiard room, library, powder room and kitchen with two pantries. The Beylerians left these interiors intact but indulged their taste in furniture: sofas and lounge chairs by Cini Boeri, an oval plastic dining table by Anna Castelli Ferrieri and Ignacio Gardella. chairs by Gae Aulenti. The rooms upstairs were enlivened with contemporary furniture and ceilings of red, blue and yellow.

title: Julia Wood Affianced To Dewitt John Strong
description: The engagement of Julia Elizabeth Thayer Wood to Dewitt John Strong has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Thayer Wood of Overland Park, Kan.

title: Chile to Get U.S. Wheat Valued at Over $45Million
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Chile will get 11 million bushels of United States wheat valued at $45.7million under a new agreement, the Agriculture Department has announced.

title: Ancient Title Takes Whitney by a Neck
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2Until today, Keith Stucki's only memory of Saratoga went back 38 years to the days when he galloped Seabiscuit here in morning workouts.

title: FILM VIEW
description: If that alleged Central Intelligence Agency plot to assassinate Castro by sending him a giftwrapped box of cigars had ever been implemented, how would the card have been signed? Simply A Friend? And why send Castro cigars at all when heof all peoplemight reasonably be expected to have as many as he wants? Why not a Playboy calendar that had been treated with toxic ink? What is the C.I.A. thinking of?

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Anglers Find A Number of Dolphin Off Nags Head
The African Organization Endures, and Sometimes Works
description: The 45nation Organization of African Unity has existed in a chronic state of crisis ever since it was born out of a welter of conflicting interests and ideas on May 25, 1963. Having survived 12 years of sometimes bitter political rivalries, it likely to endure even the controversial chairmanship of President Idi Amin of Uganda, who will hold office for a year.

title: Oyster Bay Appealing Decision Calling TwoAcre Zoning in Jericho Confiscatory
description: In an effort to keep a partially wooden parcel of land in Jericho zoned residential twoacre, as it has been since 1929, Oyster Bay is appealing a State Supreme Court decision that found the zoning confiscatory because it denied the property owner a reasonable financial return.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayHunterdon Kills K. C. allbreed and obedience, Fairgrounds, Route 31, Flemington, N. J.; 1,645 dogs; 9 A:M.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: COURT CONDEMNS TWO JAILS HERE
description: Overcrowded conditions at city jails in Brooklyn and Queens have been assailed as unconstitutional by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Malcolm Davidson Weds Renata Leon
description: Renata S. Leon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gonzalo S. Leon of Sudbury, Mass., was harried there yesterday afternoon to Malcolm L. Davidson, son of Mrs. Richard R. Davidson of New York and the late Mr. Davidson.

title: P. L. Shea Weds Nancy W. Sage
description: Nancy Wickes Sage was married yesterday to Peter L. Shea of New York. The Rev. Douglas Morrill performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's father in Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Within hours after Police Lieut. Henry O. Schmiemman was shot and killed by a wouldbe robber in Queens on June 20, 1974, the police had a suspect. The lieutenant, who was in civilian clothes and on his way to work, had managed to fire one shot at his assailant. The suspect was 26yearold John Smith of Brooklyn, who had entered a hospital with a bullet in his chest.

title: Lisa C. Moseley Plans Aug. 30 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clark Moseley of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Cole Moseley, to Saul Robert Chandler. The prospective bridegroom, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin M. Lipschutz of Fairfield, Conn., legally changed his name.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: As two current group shows demonstrate, most photographers pay very little attention to what art critics say. Which is probably just as well. For art critics have traditionally had little use for the higher claims of photography as art. Baudelaire, to take an early example, wanted to confine photography, to reportage and documentation. It will be so much the worse for us, thundered the poet in his celebrated review of the Salon of 1859, if photography is allowed to encroach upon the domain of the unpalpable and the imaginary, upon anything whose value depends solely upon the addition of something of a man's soul.

title: Ens. R. C. Middaugh Weds Miss Foothorap
description: Barbara Jane Foothorap, daughter of Mrs. James Frederick Foothorap of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Foothorap, was married yesterday afternoon to Ens. Richard Carney Middaugh of the Naval Reserve, a helicopter pilot stationed in San Diego. He is the on of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Richard Middaugh of San Jose, Calif.

title: Dublin Sees New Role for Itself in Europe
description: DUBLIN  For the first time in her troubled history, Ireland is firmly convinced that she is emerging from Britain's shadow to fill an independent and somewhat iconoclastic role on the European stage.

title: 100,000 Expected At Flemington Fair
description: FLEMINGTON  Close to 100,000 visitors are expected to attend the Flemington Fair, which opens Aug. 26 for a sevenday run through Labor Day at the 60acre fairgrounds just off Route 31.

title: Barbara A. Cook Plans Marriage
description: Dr. Edward J. Cook, president of the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University, and Mrs. Cook of Brookville, L. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Cook, to George Patrick Conbeer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Conbeer of Shamokin, Pa. A wedding in October is planned.

title: Refuse PileUp Expected To Last at Least a Week
description: The city's Sanitation Commissioner, Robert T. Grob, said yesterday that the city's streets were not likely to look any cleaner for at least a week.

title: Premedical Students Are Working With Doctors in Valley Stream Program
description: VALLEY STREAMTwentyfour premedical students are getting a closer look at what it is like to be a doctor by working side by side with physicians this summer in an unusual program at the Franklin General Hospital here.

title: Moveouts Weaken Prewar Buildings
description: The tremors of the economic crunch are reverberating through the city's prewar office towers, toppling some and threatening others.

title: JOHN OTTO NEES
description: John Otto Nees corporate director of insurance for the American Broadcasting Companies, died yesterday of cancer in Plainview (L.I.) Central Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Huntington, L. I.

title: Effete Snobs Go Camping
description: WE pushed oft for the wilds of western New Jersey at 2:30 P.M. The campsites will all be full, if you don't get here by 5, a twangy female voice had warned me when I had called Worthington State Forest a few days before. And so we were getting an early Friday start, getting the jump on the army of Archie and Edith Bunkers that supposedly jam every campground in America all summer.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Other Wilt
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 2 POLITICAL CHIEFS FACE CHALLENGES
description: Two of the city's longestreigning political leaders, Vincent F. Albano and Frank G. Rossetti, the Republican and Democratic leaders of Manhattan, are being challenged as district leaders in the Sept. 9 primary.

title: Profits Now on the Upswing
description: Earnings in the current quarter will make very poor comparisons with a year ago a period bolstered by huge inventory profits. But pattern of earnings during 1975, a lesspublicized one, is more encouraging.

title: He Admits He'd Lose a National Election Today in Australia
description: MELBOURNEIn the first heady days after he came to office in 1972, Australia's Prime Minister Gough Whitlam moved fast and with style. He changed the country's foreign policy, recognizing Red China, withdrawing Australian troops from Vietnam, demonstrating to the United States that Australia would be an ally but not a subservient one. He changed the national anthem, introduced a new honors system not identified with Britain or the Queen, and moved for equality of opportunity in education, a national health scheme and a better environment.

title: U.S. Door Shut, Hope Dims For Indochina's Refugees
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 2Thousands of refugees from Indochina face an uncertain future in makeshift camps scattered about Southeast Asia because the United States has reached the limit of 130,000 it has authority to admit.

title: Jane D. Penberthy, Law Editor, Is Married to Rawle Deland Jr.
description: Jane Devor Penberthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Penberthy of Rowayton, Conn., was married last evening to Rawle Deland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Deland of Darien, Conn., and New London, N. H.

title: ROBERT P. JUDY
description: Robert P. Judy, a former as sistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and member of the Public Service Commission of the Virgin Islands, died Thursday in St. Croix, V. I. He was 76 years old and also lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: A Summer With Freud
description: The longawaited publication of Otto Krauss's reminiscences of his encounter with the Viennese Analytic Society (Sketches of Psyches: My Summer With Freud and His Group, Bled Press, Yugoslavia, 546 pp.) has aroused the expected tumult. Krauss, a German emigr, owned the resort hotel where the society vacationed during the historic summer of 1906. The book, held back from publication for 60 years, will go a long way towards filling the gaps in the history of the psychoanalytic movement. Krauss, however, has not been without his detractors. Ernest Jones. Freud's biographer. and other analytic historians dismissed much of what Krauss wrote as pure fantasy, arguing that it was no secret in upperclass European circles that he suffered from the fear that he gave the impression of being an eggplant.

title: Fittipaldi Runs Into Roadblock In His Pursuit of Lauda at Ring
description: NUERBUERGRING, West Germany, Aug. 2It will be like having the front line of the old Green Bay Packers blocking for the running backs. And Emerson Fittipaldi will be on the defense.

title: Reflecting Pools Mirror the Calm Of Summer Life
description: WYCKOFFThe recession has turned a hobby into a livelihood for the Joe Dekkers, one in which almost every member of the family has a hand.

title: Ruling on Phones on Boats
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) A telephone company cannot refuse radiotelephone service to boat owners because they failed to purchase their telephone equipment from the company, the Federal Communications Commission ruled Wednesday. The F.C.C. said the law requires common carriers en gaged in interstate of foreig?? communications by wire or radio to furnish such communications service on reauest.

title: Matlack Earns 13th Victory on 5Hit Performance
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug, 2One hundred and four pitches. That's all Jon Matlack needed today to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 60, the third victory in a row for the New York Mets, who crept within six games of first place.

title: Headliners
description: A year ago, Charles Lockwood, a Britishborn financier working in Argentina, was happy to be alive. Held for eight weeks by an Argentine leftist group, he was released unharmed after the reported payment of $1million in ransom. He continued to work in Argentina, reassured, he said, because, The guerrillas told me they don't squeeze the same lemon twice. Not true Mr. Lockwood has again been kidnapped. No ransom has yet been asked.

title: Chris Chapman Florida Bride Of R. L. Hilton
description: Chris Ann Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah H. Chapman Jr. of Miami, was married yesterday evening to Robert Lund Hilton.

title: Greenery for Therapy
description: Some poke at tomato plants with their canes, hoping to find them nearly ripe. Others gesture enthusiastically from wheelchairs at young cucumbers on the vine. Still others, confined to their rooms, peer through window screens at colorful balsam and marigolds growing outside.

title: Travel writers Choose
description: Probably my idea of the best vacation would be to go to the south of Francesomewhere between Menton on the Italian border and St. Tropezand sequester myself in a comfortable pad (preferably a villa). I would have access to an intellectual world of arts and letters, the sea, excellent food, a great time at such places as St. Tropez, beautiful views on monokini beaches, and Italy, where one can wallow in the pasta. And if I didn't feel like doing anything, I could sit and vegetate in most pleasant surroundings.

title: Ms. America Goal: Open Doors, Eyes
description: Sitting in the brightly colored living room of her New York East Side apartment, Seena Hamilton was bubbling with optimism as she talked about the future of the new Ms. America tennis circuit. We have 32 of the most promising women tennis players in the world, said Miss Hamilton. the newly appointed copromoter and tournament director of the circuit. These women are only a step below the professional women's tennis circuit and are constantly exciting the crowds with their outstanding tournament play.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on resolution disap. proving military construction projects on the island of Diego Garcia, which was rejected, 53 to 43, July 28.

title: Projects Will Test 2Way Cable TV For Future Uses
description: The National Science Foundation has given grants to three experimental projects that could help determine future uses of twoway cable TV.

title: Sept. 13 Bridal for Karen Blanchard
description: Karen Linda Blanchard and Scott Eliot Martin, graduates of the College of Wooster in Ohio, will be married Sept. 13.

title: Westfield Preparing Guide to Its Homes
description: WESTFIELDAn illustrated guide to Westfield's architectural heritage is being compiled by the community's Bicentennial Committee.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN REGIONAL PARLEYS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2A newly formed group of liberal Democrats, calling themselves the Democratic Conference, announced this week that they would sponsor five regional conferences around the country to allow Presidential candidates to become better known.

title: Play Fashion, 171, Hazel Park Victor
description: HAZEL PARK, Mich., Aug. 2(AP)Play Fashion; a 171 shot, took the lead a the start and stayed there all the way today in capturing the $36.100 Michigan Breeders Stakes at the Hazel Park Race Track.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: A recent photograph has provided visual evidence of the existence of a novel state of matter: liquid electricity.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: We are enclosing a porch which will then be used as a dining area. The floor and serving counter will be covered with quarry tile in light grey. What finish would you recommend to prevent food stains from causing permanent damage? Someone suggested linseed oil. Do you agree?S.H.H., Vineyard, Haven, Mass.

title: Weddings
description: MummBoes

title: Street Muralists Find New Canvases
description: Find a wall that is highly visible and has a fine surface. Repair the cracks. Scrape off the dirt and loose particles. Add masonry conditioner to seal the bricks. Waterproof the wall.

title: Guest Observer
description: If my telephone rings at 11:05 P.M., Pacific standard time, I know who it is. It is somebody asking me if I know that I am on the Groucho Marx show. No, say, but if we get off the telephone I can go watch.

title: Pentagon Sees Threat in a Red Portugal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2, (Reuter)sDefense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the ability of the United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean to survive in wartime would be endangered if Portugal became Communist.

title: Meet a Mummy, Grapple With a Ghost.
description: I have felt the cutting edge of the blade graze my throat in the dark as the pendulum swung downward, ever closer. I have conversed with ghosts and mummies, grappled with invisible, murderous beings, watched corpses rise in their cerements from lonely graves. I have stared into the red eyes of slithering rats, willed lovers back to life, fended off vampires, fought down evil alteregos trying to take over my personality. In other words, I have just emerged, pale and shaken, from a season of exposure to horror stories on disks.

title: G.A.O. BACKS PROJECT ON BREEDER REACTOR
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 2 (UPI) The General Accounting Office has recommended that the Government proceed with the $10.7billion effort to develop the nuclear breeder reactor as a possible energy source by the end of the century.

title: An Art Competition For Morris Elderly
description: RANDOLPH TownshipMorris County's elderly citizens compete for the right to participate in the Capitol Art Juried Exhibition in Trenton in September.

title: CYPRUS CONFEREES REPORT PROGRESS
description: VIENNA, Aug. 2 (UPI)Greek and. Turkish negotiators reported today that they have made unexpected progress in the third round of the Cyprus peace talks and said they would meet again next month in New York.

title: Chile's Version of Leftists' Fate Doubted
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2The Governmentcontrolled Chilean press lists more than 100 leftist extremists as killed in fighting among themselves or against security forces in Argentina. But there is substantial evidence that they have actually been detained in Chile.

title: Democracy and Poetry
description: Robert Penn Warren was among the writercritics in the forties and fifties, often in Partisan Review, who brought a social conscience to literature and a literary sensibility to society. Then literary discourse was still the provhice of intellectualsof tough idealists. Poems, plays and novels had not yet been refrigerated into texts. Criticism was essentially a moral act; literature made militant. It had possessed an exigencyone of their wordsof a humanly consequential pursuit.

title: Miss White Fiancee Of Gregory Mercer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence White of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca White, to Gregory Mercer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mercer of Nashua. N.H.

title: B'NAI B'RITH GAINS WITH COED UNITS
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2  Unobtrusively, but with unusually positive results, the 131yearold B'nai B'rith, largest among Jewish organizations, is loosening a long tradition of sexsegregated membership by enrolling men and women into integrated local units scattered throughout the country.

title: FIVE BYSTANDERS HURT IN SHOOTOUT
description: Five bystanders were wounded yesterday after a shootout between two men involved in an argument near the south campus of City College.

title: Dance: Nureyev Absent
description: Well, what is Hamlet like without the Prince of Denmark, or what is the National Ballet of Canada like without its customary New York guest star, Rudolf Nureyev? In fact, it is precisely the same as it is with him, an extremely good secondrank company, but it certainly doesn't sell so many tickets.

title: Tax Rebates Some Give Them Back
description: Last June, Daniel R. McKee, an 18yearold Capitol Hill page, wrote letters to the editors of several newspapers protesting the tax rebates and saying that, although working his way through school, he was donating the check he had just received to charity because it was uncalled for, ineffective, and no solution to the problem of the nation's halfatrilliondollar deficit.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The opening of the Mostly Mozart Festival the other weekand a happy occasion it wasset this listener off on a series of disconneoted thoughts. It was nice to see a soldout Avery Fisher Hall on a hot summer night. It also was nice to see the accent on youth. (That could apply to the composer himself, who, after all, was about 36 years old when he died.) The audience was composed predominantly of young people, the crack little orchestra was full of youngsters, and the two soloistsPinchas Zukerman, who doubled as conductorand Misha Dichter are among the younger generation of instrumentalists.

title: And in the Middle, Mr. Beane, Pushed, Pulled, Vilified, Praised
description: Elected in 1973 on the promise to restore fiscal peace and sanity to New York City after eight turbulent Lindsay years, Mayor Beame has watched his credibility, and the bity's credit rating, slowly crumble. Within the last several weeks he has:

title: B. B. Denniston Marries Kathleen Foley
description: Kathleen Bowles Foley, assistant director of membership and special projects for the Association of Trial Lawyers of America in Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Brackett Badger Denniston of Cambridge, a lawyer with the Boston firm of Goodwin, Proctor & Hoar. Msgr. Charles M. Murphy performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Yarmouth. Me.

title: Digging gold from the desert
description: One day in 1945, bright, handsome, hardasgunmetal Benjamin (Bugsy) Siegel got the idea of a lifetime: to build a Babylonian gambling casino right in the middle of a desert. He especially liked a dinky Nevada town called Las Vegas, the meadows. The idea was legitimate. The object was to thin down wartime profiteers from the West Coast as they drank, made hogs of themselves and dared the house odds. All would be done in an environment as magic as foreign foods, New York broads, Del Webb and Hollywood superstars could create. Bugsy called his electrified carpet joint The Flamingo.

title: Dog Days
description: Now come the Dog Days, as the old Romans first called them. Once they were a time of mysterious fevers, when mad dogs ran rabid through the streets and when vipers were quick to strike. Canicula, the Dog Star, was in conjunction with the sun, and Canicula, not the mad dogs, gave the name to the late summer interval.

title: NATIONS DEMAND AGRICULTURAL AID
description: A global network of international agricultural research centers, none of them more than 20 years old, is facing an explosion of demands from individual nations for help in increasing food production to meet rapid increases in population.

title: A Child's Theater of Delight
description: The hound, the goose, the flounder and the birds all had a wonderful time last week, but not quite as much fun as the hundreds of youngsters who watched them frolic in the sunlit splendor or a Queens park. To everyone's delight, there is more merriment in store.

title: The World
description: Turkish teams have assumed command at the 25 or so former American bases in Turkey in reprisal for continuance of an embargo on arms shipment imposed by Congress last February. But even if attempts to end the embargonow delayed by the summer Congressional recesssucceed, the relationship between Washington and Ankara will have been greatly changed.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: MITTLEMANRichard E. Memorial services for Richard E. Mittleman, age 28, formerly of Huntington, L.I., will be held Sunday, August 3, 1975 at 7 P.M. at the Community United Methodist Church in Cold Spring Harbor, LI., N.Y. Mr. Mittlemon ran for the Suffolk County Legislature In 1971 and was former Director of Executive of The Human Resources Administration for the City of New York.

title: TV Notes: Networks Awash In NameTag Title Wave
description: NBC recently changed the title of The Metro Man, a new police action series in its fall lineup, to Joe Forrester. A new comedy originally called Sunday Dinner has now been rechristened The Montefuscos. A madeforTV movie entitled The Greatest Gift has become a weekly series as The Family Holvak (starring Glenn Ford and Julie Harris). All A e part of a new title wave at the networks.

title: Food
description: Years ago, a reader sent us a recipe for what was called a brandy Alexander pie. It consisted of a mousse or charlottelike filling flavored with brandy and crme de cacao poured into a grahamcrackercrumb crust before chilling. It proved to be one of the most popular desserts printed in The New York Times over a 10year period. A short while ago we received a detailed compilation of similar pies with various cordial flavors. It was the contribution of an enormously resourceful reader from College Park, Md., Richard C. Taeuber.
