Mr. Taeuber submitted his list with the added information that the pic freezes, or more important, thaws, quite well, which means that it can be made further in advance of use than the night before, as has been the custom in my home. The results of his prolonged kitchen experiments are reprinted here.

title: BACKTALK
description: ICP's Doors Are Wide Open

title: Police Act on Crime in Brooklyn Heights
description: Two more officers will be added tomorrow to the police anticrime patrol in Brooklyn Heights to help cope with an increase in burglaries in that middleclass residential neighborhood.

title: Group Homes Gain Amid Hostility
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  When the Wiltwyck School, a Yorktown home for disturbed boys, tried to open a group home for eight 124015 year olds last spring in nearby Ossining, more than 600 neighbors signed a petition and got an injunction to stop it.

title: The Castro Caper
description: There are some allegations the mind seeks to reject until it is confronted with facts that cannot be ignored. That is the case with the story that a United States Government agency hired a mobster to murder the chief of state of a nation with which the United States was at peace.

title: Krome George: PostRecession Planning at Alcoa
Marvin Kitman's long joke
description: This is a book set in Woody Allen country  that place where cowardice, antiheroes, paranoia, fearfulness and passivity are made acceptable, even lovable. But while Woody Allen is standing still, just one lone person shrinking appealingly into the woodwork as his date walks off with another, Marvin Kitman with The Coward's Almanac is trying to make cowardice safe for everyone.

title: Candy Gill Fiancee of B. C. Stevens
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Gill of Manhasset, L. I., and Scottsdale, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Celeste Nancy Gill, to Bruce Chambers Stevens of Atlanta.

title: Guild Hall Posters Evoke Belle Epoque
description: EAST HAMPTON  The poster exhibition at Guild Hall might for some visitors elicit a mood of the gaite parisienne. Celebrating the saucy belle epoque, these colorful advertisements reopen the curtain of a period marked by its beautiful dancing girls, extravagant costumes and a devilmaycare ??ust for life.

title: Poor Man's Boat Astor Cup Victor
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 2The new era in yacht racing was evident again today when a little boat called Kindred Spirit, whose expense has been syndicated among 10 earnest but somewhat impoverished owners, won the Astor Cup. The cup is one of yachting's most treasured trophies, dating back 65 years, and has on its pedestal the most most distinguished names in the sport, names that one connotates with wealth and skill.

title: Mercury Hits 97 Here; Heat Blankets Northeast
description: Gasping and wilting in the biggest heat wave in years, New Yorkers flocked to parks and beaches and rallied around fire hydrants yesterday in a quest for shade, breezes or cool waters of forgetfulness on what proved to be the hottest day of the year.

title: I Would Have Saved Them If I Could
description: The short story is good for filling up magazines and bibliographies, but volumes of collected stories usually seem disappointingwhy, one keeps wanting to ask, didn't you write a novel? But the publication of Leonard Michaels's second book of stories (the first, Going Places, was a National Book Award nominee in 1969) is a useful reminder that the rich complexity of a successful novel can, in the hands of a master, be achieved within the limitations of smaller forms, and I Would Have Saved Them If I Could Seems to me an important literary event.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: PayFreeze Accord First Made in Secret
description: The wagefreeze agreement between the municipal labor unions and the city had been worked out in secret meetings two days before it was announced, but was held up while all sides tried to get the policemen and firemen to go along.

title: Claudia Smith Wed To R. E. A. Paredes
description: Claudia McBeath Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bishop Frank Smith Jr. of Aiken, S. C., was married there yesterday afternoon to Roberto Edgard Alfonso Paredes, an architect with the firm of Gill Wilkins & Wood in Florence, S. C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis 1. Paredes of Lima, Peru.

title: LSD RESEARCHER IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2A pioneer medical researcher who conducted Air Forcesponsored experiments with LSD at the University of Minnesota and the Missouri Institute of Psychiatry is being investigated by the Department of Justice, a department spokesman said today.

title: Busing an Unknown Factor in Boston Mayoralty Race
description: BOSTON, Aug. 2With his tie loosened and his sleeves rolled up, Mayor Kevin H. White greeted the reception line of campaign workers in the decorated aluminum trailer at the opening of his Brighton neighborhood headquarters.

title: Tuition Rise Due in '76 At Nassau College
description: GARDEN CITYStudents at Nassau Community College, the largest institution of its kind in the state, will have to pay increased tuition costs and higher fees starting with the spring semester next year on the basis of a proposed college budget recommended to the Board of Supervisors.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has acquired the 22story office building at 1180 Avenue of the Americas, at 46th Street, and the eightstory garage property at 3842 West 46th Street for approximately $18million.

title: But Individual Experience Is Hard to Measure
description: Giving credit for experience college students gain outside the classroom has become, if not a commonplace, then at least a common practice, in American education. But now colleges are increasingly willing to give a new kind of credit for another kind of experience: learning that students have acquired before they enroll, in forms that cannot readily be measured by conventional academic standards. In more than 150 colleges, life experiences, ranging from stints in the Peace Corps to community volunteer activities, can qualify as credit toward a degree.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: As International Jaws Year has still some months to run, the Whitney Museum has done well to remind us that there are other sides to the sea. The sea is a killer, admittedly; but it is also a school of proportion. It teaches us that everything changes, that nothing can be counted on, and that what goes out must come in (and vice versa). The imago of the sea as killer may be uppermost this summerto the extent that even Amtrak has felt bound to steady us with the true statistics of the shark/swimmer relationshipbut before long we shall be back with the image of the sea as playmate, the sea as philosopher, the sea as battlefield, the sea as source of nourishment, and the sea as one of the best of all places in which to earn an honest buck.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Bureau of Engraving and Printing has welcome news for paper money collectors or anyone who appreciates fine engraving. It is offering two new issues in an unexpected continuation of a popular series of souvenir cards that display superbly detailed reproductions of famous 19th century U.S. currency designs. The news was unexpectedand especially Welcomebecause the Bureau had indicated last year that it might be required to curtail the tradition in connection with an overall Treasury Department econo

title: Postage Stamps in Spirit Of '76 Bring Protest in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 2 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Laotian postal service has run into trouble over its issue of stamps bearing the pictures of George Washington and Gerald Ford.

title: The Prodigal Son
description: In hiring Billy Martin as their manager, the New York Yankees are attempting to rehabilitate a threetime loser, a prodigal son on parole. But before he was discharged by the Texas Rangers, the Detroit Tigers and the Minnesota Twins for a variety of turbulent transgressions, Billy Martin was a threetime winner. That's all the Yankee owners are thinking about now. They'll worry about the problems later, We've chosen Billy Martin, says Gabe Paul, the Yankees' president, because of the excitement he will bring coupled with the Yankee tradition. It also would have been exciting for Chase Manhattan to have hired Willie Sutton as a bank guard, at least until he robbed the bank. Sooner or later, Billy Martin will rob the bank. He has everywhere else.

title: Now, the DoubleDigital Watch
description: The Longines Wittnauer Watch Company and the Hughes Aircraft Company last week announced that Longines will market the doublethreat digital electronic watch designed to tell the time clearly under all light conditions. Hughes is to supply the digital mechanisms, known as modules, and Longines is to produce the watch. called Gemini II.

title: Robin Randolph Lind, Reporter, Fiance of Kathleen M. Williams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murat Willis Williams of Madison Mills, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Murat Williams, to Robin Randolph Lind, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Udny Lind of Oakville, Ontario.

title: College Lends Hand To Blind in Queens
description: Jacqueline Joseph, an 18year old Haitian, was blinded by disease three years ago and came to New York City for treatment. Although she had to first learn Braille in her native French before she could learn English, Miss Joseph has mastered everything well enough to attend college here in the fall.

title: Anna Dorsett Bride of R. C. Paschal
description: Anna Lee Dorsett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Kye Dorsett Jr. of Raleigh and WinstonSalem. N.C., was married in Raleigh at noon yesterday to Robert Cummings Paschal, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Washington Paschal Jr., also of Raleigh.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Perhaps somewhat more problematical than these movies about the aborted assassinations of the Queen, of General de Gaulle (Jackal) and of former President Nixon (Dolphin), are films like The Parallax View and Executive Action, which solemnly suggest the existence of assassination conspiracies, which is certainly a subject we should all think about, though they only grab our attention by graphically Showing us assassinations successfully carried out. I suspect that they appeal to our blood lust more than they do to our intellect.

title: Wendy Cook Bride of Thomas A. Hickey
description: St. Jude's Roman Catholic Church in Peoria, Ill., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Wendy Ann Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Clement Cook of Dunlap, Ill., to Thomas Aloysius Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William Hickey of partsdale, N.Y.

title: The Hardships Are Real, Particularly in View of New Figures
description: WASHINGTONOne of the major mysteries of the recession has been the lack of visible anger with which it has been endured by the American people. There has been no violent protest and even orderly, peaceful demonstrations have been few and not very large. Yet unemployment, though finally declining now, reached higher levels this year than at any time since World War II put an end to the Great Depression.

title: The Region
description: Unemployment in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey region continues to be significantly worse than in the nation as a whole, and it is too soon to know whether the apparent leveling off in the nation's unemployment rate is occurring In the area.

But whatever the court decides, the scimitarrattling over the region in the last two years has threatened to progress to a shooting war whose consequences could affect the balance of power among the Arabs and in the Western Mediterranean.

description: EAST QUOGUEAccording to Pilar Turner, paella is pickup food, a dish just put together with whatever ingredients are handy. The stunning array that she assembled on a recent sunny Saturday did not contradict that definition.

description: To the Editor:

title: History 200 years apart
description: The case for Jules Archer's Watergate: America in Crisis is quite simply that it is the first attempt at a comprehensive account of Watergate for young citizens. Mr. Archer's basic premise, according to the book jacket, is that if young readers are to make the intelligent judgments essential to a functioning democracy they must be given the whole truth about the society. Surely, we are told, no subject calls for this approach more than the crisis we call Watergate.

title: Uganda Plagued by Shortages Of Many Basic Commodities
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 2Two weeks of African summitry were beginning to take their toll on Uganda's limited resources by the time the Organization of African Unity meeting here drew to a close yesterday.

title: Westchester Grass Is in Heat of Battle
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 2July's heavy rains in the metropolitan area followed by extreme heat and bright sunshine have combined to destroy the grass on fairways and greens at many fine golf courses in the region. Those large brown areas on formerly lush green golf pastures are the result of putting the grass in nature's pressure cooker and boiling it.

The June wade surplus, a record $1.74billion, was the fifth consecutive monthly surplus, scored despite the continued high prices of imported oil. . . . The composite Index of leading Indicators rose 1.9 per cent In June, the fourth consecutive monthly gain, to 98.3 [1967=100], up from a revised 96.5 in May.

title: HARRY W. MILLER
description: Harry W. Miller, a retired chief official in the United States of the Commercial Union Assurance Companies of Britain, died Thursday. He was 77 years old and. lived at 47 Langdon Terrace, Bronxville, N.Y.

description: LONDON, July 30 Huge trenches ringing playing fields, fourfoothigh restraining walls, cattle pens to segregate spectators in the standsthese were some of the suggestions that surfaced today in meetings aimed at reducing the rising level of violence at British professional soccer matches.

description: VIENNA, Aug. 2 (UPI)Greek and Turkish negotiators reported today that they have made unexpected progress in the third round of the Cyprus peace talks and said they would meet again next month in New York.

description: PARISAs a consequence of changes In service conditions, and training programs, the French Army is gradually emerging from a period of dissension and frustration.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Up to now, Owen Sela has concentrated on novels that mix action and espionage. There is something of a departure in his latest book, THE BENGALI INHERITANCE (Pantheon, $6.95). It is a procedural, but a procedural with a difference. Senior Chief Inspector Richard Chan, of the Criminal Investigation Department in Hong Kong, is the cop. ?? is Chinese, honest, tough and ingenious, and he does for the Hong Kong police what H.R.F. Keating's Inspector Ghote does for India. But Chan is a much more dangerous specimen than the cautious, introverted Ghote.

description: RENO, Nev., Aug. 2 (AP)A 5yearold boy who was attacked by seven dogs died during surgery yesterday. The victim, Michael Yount, suffered severe bites on the neck, chest and right leg.

title: Historic Erie and Lackawanna To Chug on Under a New Name
description: Two of the oldest names in American railroadingErie and Lackawannaseem to be highballing into the sunset for the last time.

description: The capital problems of business are pressing and require resolution if a strong and sustainable economic recovery is to materialize. It would be wrong to conclude, as did Joseph Pechman, that our capital needs can be met without distortion of the tax structure (Point of View: Business Doesn't Need More Tax Breaks. July 20).

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2Thousands of homes heated by solar energy by next year?

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar on Wednesday defended the record of the Postal Service saying it had improved productivity without reducing service.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Arnold Wesker and the East End Jews
description: Arnold Wesker is the English Jewish dramatist whose plays, mostly of East End lifeOhicken Soup With Barley, I'm Talking About Jerusalemfitted in with the kitchen plays of lowerclass life by radical English dramatists of the fifties and sixties. Jewish writers of immigrant workingclass vintage do not get a hearing in England as easily as their counterparts do in America. Weskees emergence was clue in part to the radical temper of the postwar British theater, but above all to the fact that he handled abrasive subjects  Jewish Communists, highpitched emotions inside the Jewish familywith a notable lovingness, tact and respect for the workingclass mores in general.

title: Howth: Swooping Cormorants, Heathery Moors and the Irish Sea
description: EVEN the pleasures of what gorgeous Georgian monument of a city, Dublin, can pall. When happens, the cure is close at hand. Just do as Dubliners have been doing for centuriestake the day off and hurry out to Howth.

title: Answers/Questions
description: BINDWEED (July 13)

title: Britons Take Tea To Heart
description: WHOEVER travels the roads of Britain will observe a peculiar social ritual which takes place, with clockwork regularity, at 4 o'clock on summer afternoons. Cars are parked on the roadside, their trunks opened, folding chairs and tables extracted, and an alfresco dining room is set up, usually at a perilous angle, on the grassy shoulder. A small paraffin stove is lit and pumped vigorously; precise measures of a black herb are spooned into a china pot; packets of biscuits and damp sandwiches are unwrapped. When the kettle boils, the pot is brought to it (never vice versa) and, amid clouds of steam, the bubbling contents of the one infuse the dry contents of the other. A rich, sad fragrance climbs in the air and mixes with the blue fumes of passing traffic. With dreamy eyes and contented sucking noises, the English imbibe cup after cup of what P.G. Wodehouse called the good old tissuerestorer.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: For both the beginner and veteran of photography, a camera club can offer a wealth of stimulating experiences within a congenial atmosphere. A club is a learning center, where photo enthusiasts exchange ideas, share techniques, enter competitions and a social center for people who share a love of photography.

title: Last Year Was Fabulous This Year Maybe
description: With New York and other municipalities in the metropolitan region sinking toward insolvency, the giant seaport of New York and New Jersey and other area ports have been particularly influential in keeping the region's economy afloat.

title: When Deal Is Made in Soccer, Players Usually Last to Know
The Nation
description: PHILADELPHIAThis may be one of America's best citiesand one of its worst. But for reasons wholly separate from Philadelphia's virtues and flaws, the city has quite suddenly been thrust forward, center stage. The director in this instance is the Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission, which has filed a proposal for public school integration in Philadelphia with a state court. It calls for a radical realignment of the city's education system, including the busing of more than 50,000 students out of their neighborhoods.

title: AntiNuclear Drive Aided By Scientists' Donations
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 2 (UPI)Scientists and entertainers have contributed sizable sums of money to a campaign to ban nuclear power development until reactors meet stringent safety standards.

description: BECKENSTEINFannie. July 29, 1971, In loving memory of a cherished mother and wonderful soul. Forever In our hearts and thoughts.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The head of the Federal Bureau of Prisons is appealing for Congressional approval of new facilities that he contends are needed to eliminate the grim prisons of the past.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 2 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, seeded first, and Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion, overcame stubborn opponents today in the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Louisville pro tennis tournament. But fourthseeded Manuel Orantes was upset by Jaime Fillol of Chile, 75, 64.

description: CAIRO, Aug. 2 (Reuters)Egypt has concluded a $750million agreement with the European Economic Community to buy meat, wheat, sugar and dairy products over the next three years, the Ministry of Supply announced this week.

title: 3 U.S. Crews Qualify for Finals In Canada as Heat Scratches 32
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Aug. 2Thirtytwo crews scratched today as the heat continued to take its toll in the 93d annual Royal Canadian Henley Regatta. Yesterday's record 101degree temperature was equaled, and coupled with an increased humidity that cut visibility to 1,000 meters, those crews that did show up appeared to be coming out of a fog as they rowed down the 2.000meter course.

description: WASHINGTON  As Congress heads home for recess, enough has occurred under the new Congressional budget procedures and in the battles over spending between the executive and legislative branches of government, for some tentative conclusions to emerge.

title: Red Baron Sets Mark For Lakeland Terriers
description: The topwinning dog of 1974, Ch. JoNi's Red Baron of Crofton, owned by Mrs. Virginia Dickson, showed he had lost none of his prowess when the Lakeland terrier came through with two victories last weekend in CaliforniaVentura and Santa Barbara. A third show, the first ever staged by Chanel City, went to the nation's No. 1 toy dog, Ch. JayMac's Impossible Dream, a miniature pinscher owned by Dorothy De Maria of Downey, Calif.

title: Subway Sam Had Jim Dandy
description: The horses are running at Saratoga, and as the day approaches for the renewal of the elderly Travers Stakes, somebody is sure to recall the Travers of 1939 when Jim Dandy, at 100 to 1 in the books, finished first in a fourhorse field that included the two top 3yearolds in America  the Triple Crown winner, Gallant Fox, and the brilliant Whichone. Among those present on that historic occasion was Phil Bieber, who testifies as follows: When stories of daring gamblers are told, no one should forget Subway Sam Rosoff. He came here as an immigrant in his teens with little formal education, and his climb was phenomenal. He created and operated a heavy construction firm that built some of New York City's subways and tunneled through mountains in Mexico, but his great thrill was gambling. He preferred racing, but wouldn't turn his back on other games. One evening in Saratoga he was trying to ease his way into a crowded crap game when a player said, quit shovin', will ya? I'm trying to get even. How much are you stuck? Sam asked. About $300. O.K., son, Sam said, here's $350. Now go home a winner. The guy took the money and amde room. brilliant Whichone. title: Program Is Offered Legal Technologists

The twoyear legal technology program will feature increased emphasis on family, property and tax law, business practices and legal research.

title: MIAMI SET TO HIRE MORE MINORITIES
description: MIAMI, Aug. 2Trying to avoid a Federal lawsuit and a possible loss of $10million in Federal funds, the city of Miami has taken steps to end discriminatory hiring practices.

title: Encounter: In the Caribbean, an Exploding Emerald on the Horizon
description: ONE February evening along the beach on the Caribbean island of Bequala, I paused for a moment on the opalescent sand to watch the sun set. The second it disappeared I saw a brilliant flash of green light, like an exploding emerald.

title: Epilogue
description: United States District Court Judge Joseph C. Waddy has ruled that the civil rights of participants in every major demonstration, including the large antiwar protests, in Washington, D. C., since 1969 had been violated by the police through the illegal use of massarrest procedures. Judge Waddy said. that the arrests of protesters for crossing a police line were in clear violation of the First Amendment of the Constitution. There was also frequent illegal use of tear gas, clubs and stampede tactics on protesters, he said. Judge Waddy ruled that the arrest records of any person illegally arrested for the last six years be erased. This will affect about 2,000 persons. The decision was in response to a suit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union for the Washington Mobilization Committee.

title: Is It Too Late To Buy Stocks?
description: Marking one of the truly dramatic recoveries in American financial history, stock market indexes by midJuly had posted gains of some 50 per cent from their earlyDecember lows. The actual value of securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange alone increased by almost $250billion. More recently, however, the market has turned dawn.

title: Hamm Chain Over U.S. Urged for Bicentennial
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)Marvin J. Rosenblum has a monumental plain for citizen involvement and unifying the United States on its 200th birthday celebration next July 4: a human chain of millions of Americans holding hands from sea to sea.

While postwar fear was of a repetition of the outrages committed by the Nazis upon Jews and other conquered peoples, the worry today is that more subtle but still serious damage may be done in the name of increased knowledge.

description: MANDEL, EDWARDThe family of the late Eddie Mandel gratefully acknowledges & deeply appreciates the kind expressions of sympathy extended to us In our recent bereavement.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Chicago, the new Bob Fosse musical, has been dismissed by many critics as a visually striking but cold and empty spectacle. Fosse's conception for this bizarre caustic musical vaudeville is certainly open to question, but there is a case to be made for Chicago as an intriguing speculation on the enticements and the limitations of theater.

title: Tocks Island Victory

With the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Delaware now on record against the Tocks Island Dam, Congress is fully expected to deauthorize the appropriation for its construction and move instead toward a national recreation area based on the live river.

title: Morristown Park May Bridge I287
description: MORRISTOWNPlans for a $7million, threeacre park spanning a stretch of Interstate Highway 287 as it slices through this town have been approved by State Transportation Commissioner Alan Saener.

title: Shellfishing Is Reopening
description: Oyster Bay were closed in April, 1974, when it was found that leaks in the outfall pipe were dumping about 9.5 million gallons of sewage into the bay each day.

title: Cape Cod National Seashore: Walks, Talks, Bike Trails, Movies
description: IT is a sparkling summer day. The breeze corning In off the sea and over the dunes carries the scent of pitch pine and bayberries. The ocean visible in the distance  just a few shades darker blue than the sky stretches to the horizon.

title: PRESS UNIT NAMES 2 FOR INQUIRY IN CHILE
description: The appointment of a twoman committee to investigate the status of the press in Chile has been announced by the Inter American Press Association. The committee was appointed in compliance with a resolution of the association's executive committee at a meeting in Miami Beach last week.

title: Giuseppe Dessi's Mediterranean world
description: The marvelous slang title of Fellini's film, Amarcord, suggesting in the Italian an intensely subjective remembrance, exquisitely describes the mood of The Forests of Norbio, a novel by Giuseppe Dessi that overflows with affection for a lost time and dignity. Here is another rich story by a mature, newlytranslated writer from a halfdiscovered corner of the Mediterranean. The little town is utterly different from the usual image of the island or Sardima  yacht chic plus brooding noble savageconveyed by the Aga Khan's pumphouse gang.

title: Miss Luciani Wed To William Hughes
description: Jacqueline Marie Luciani, a member of the faculty of the Turkey Hill School in Orange, Conn., was married yesterday morning to William David Hughes of Wilton, Conn., customers service manager in Manhattan with the Xerox Corporation.

title: SHARP RISE NOTED FIN CITY CRIME RATE
description: All categories of serious crime reported to the police. except for murder, rose sharply in the city during the first six months of the year.

title: PARIS RED'S TALK IN 1972 STIRS RIFT
description: PARIS, Aug. 2The disclosure of a secret speech by the French Communist leader, Georges Marchais, three years ago has revived the quarrel between the Communist and Socialist parties here.

title: New York Team Upset in Bridge Play
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 2 The New York contract bridge team suffered a most unexpected defeat here early this morning, losing in the semifinal of the grand national team championship and thereby forfeiting an excellent chance of international honors.

title: Drew Becomes a Camp for Handicapped
description: MADISONEvery summer weekday at 9 in the morning, 35 children from 4 to 14 years old are left by their parents at the Green Village Road School for a day at camp. Most of themboys and girls, whites and blacks, from poor and rich familiesshare the same kind of summer fun.

title: Can This Man Save Avery Fisher Hall?
description: Late next spring an unprecedented venture in architectural surgery will get under way at Lincoln Center. Workmen in hard hats will smash their way through Avery Fisher Hall, ripping out the seats, tearing down the balconies and demolishing the walls and ceiling. When the destruction is complete, they will build a new and totally different concert hallscheduled to open in time for the 1976 fall seasonthat the Lincoln Center management fervently hopes will pass muster acoustically with the, most exacting critics and musicians.

title: Endpaper
description: In a manner of speaking, each Administration develops a lingo all its own. In the Johnson era, staff aides spoke of the smell of magnolias and pressing the flesh to describe forms of political charm, and the coonskin on the wall became a linguistic symbol of victory.

title: Nuns Work As Equals Of Priests In Brooklyn
description: A team of three priests, a siminarian and three nuns has been working for the last couple of months on a coequal basis to revitalize a Roman Catholic Church in downtown Brooklyn.

title: TV VIEW
description: PARIS There is no good reason on a Sunday night in Paris to be sitting in the lobby of the Htel de Nice et des BeauxArts watching French television, unless you have Just been across the rue for an afterdinner drink at L'Htel. Oscar Wilde is said to have died in the building that is now L'Htel and was then a flophouse. It is a pity he couldn't have hung on longer, for he might have appreciated what Guy Louis DuBoucheron and his American architect have done to fabricate for the yy crowd an amalgam of the Continental Baths and Napoleon's Tomb. In the bar, the red cushions are so plush you are obliged to peer at your companion over your own kneecaps. A parrot in a cage goes on incessantly, like Maude. An unconvincing waterfall feeds a tiny pond on which a pair of equally tiny ducks go paddling, when they haven't hopped out to waddle around on the carpet and quack at your ankles. A snifter containing a minimum of poire and a maximum of crushed ace costs 25 francs or six dollars a throw at the current exchange rate. Compared to L'Htel, French television looks good.

title: Disclosure Law Curb Accepted
description: TRENTON  Democratic legislative leaders disclosed his week that they had no plans to replace a highly controversial section of the New Jersey Campaign Contributions and Expenditures Act that was struck down as unconstitutional last month in State Superior Court.

title: Pamela M. Adams To Be Wed Oct. 4
description: Arlene Pugh Adams of Short Hills, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Pamela Marie Adams, to Kenneth E. Dougherty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Dougherty of Huntington, L. I. Miss Adams also is a daughter of Byron K. Adams of Framingham, Mass., who is a district manager with the Piedmont Capital Corporation in Wellesley, Mass.; a mutual fund concern.

title: Elderly Man Slain, 7 Hurt In Ulster Attack on Minibus
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 2A 78year old man was killed and seven other persons, most of them elderly women, were wounded last night when gunmen fired on minibus returning from a bingo outing.

Shanley, the Republican National Committeeman from the state.

Connally of Annapolis, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Connally of Philadelphia, to Charles Edward Bradford, an officer of the Girard Bank in Philadelphia. He is the son of former Gov. Robert Fiske Bradford of Massachusetts and Mrs. Bradford of Cambridge. The wedding is planned for Oct. 4.

title: Congress Triumphant?
description: Congress has quit for its traditional August recess on a note of institutional triumph, having successfully rebuffed President Ford on several foreign and domestic issues; but its sense of satisfaction is unjustified.

title: Hearing Slated on Proposal to Halve Yonkers Council
description: YONKERSThe City Council here took an unusual step last week, one that could be the first toward legislating at least half of its 12 members out of work.

title: Suspect, 21, Arrested in Murder Of Brooklyn Widow Last Month
description: A 21yearold man with a record of arrests and convictions was taken into custody yesterday and charged with the strangling on July 22 of a 77yearold widow during a burglary in her Brooklyn apartment.

title: Precipitory Victor In Keystone Sprint
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP)  Precipitory charged from off the pace and won the $28,625 Signature Stakes for 2yearold fillies today at Keystone.

title: Hospitals Seeking to Form Insurance Company
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2Texas hospitals, smarting from increases in medical malpractice insurance rates, have decided to form their own insurance company.

title: Cold Peace for Cold War
description: HELSINKIThe primary purpose of the European Security Summit was to sign and seal a document already delivered by negotiators from 35 participating nations after excruciatingly long sessions held in Helsinki and Geneva. The atmospherics were astonishingly cordial and optimistic.

title: Births
description: Edwards

title: Wise Wins No. 14 For Red Sox, 7 to 2
description: BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP)Denny Doyle extended his hitting streak to 20 games with a double and two singles today, scoring two runs and driving in one to help the Boston Red Sox to a 72 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Student Fiance Of Susette Chu
description: Mr and Mrs. Kuanb the Chu of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter. Susette HsinHua Chu. to Winford Caldwell Naylor Jr., son of Cynthia S. Naylor of Augusta, Ga., and the late Captain Naylor of Concord. Mass., a pilot for Eastern Airlines.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, August 3, 1975

title: 3Run 8th Erases 32 Indians' Lead Lyle Excels
description: Alternately pacing the dugout like a man on fire and watching unmoved with his chin cupped in his hand, Billy Martin led the Yankees to comeback 53 victory over the Cleveland Indians yesterday in his managerial debut.

title: Wayne G. Lyster 3d, Miss Crabtree Marry
description: St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret JoAnne Crabtree to Wayne Gray Lyster 3d. Msgr. James McLaughlin performed the ceremony.

title: Ethiopia Executes 20 As Foes of Revolution
description: LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) Ethiopia executed 20 people today for crimes against the 1974 revolution, the Addis Ababa radio reported.

title: Is It Too Late to Buy Stocks?
Dressage Selection Slated
description: Selection trials for the United States Equestrian Team's dressage squad for the PanAmerican Games this fall will be held Aug. 15 through 17 at Gladstone, N.J. Bill Steinkraus the president of the U.S.E.T., announced nounced the News dates, adding that a short list of riders would be named following the trials. Horses selected for the games must have had a VEE inoculation since April of this year. The team has suggested that horses be given the VEE inoculation before the trials. Evidence of the inoculation and of a Coggins test must be presented at Gladstone. No horse will be admitted to the U.S.E.T. stables without a report of a Coggins test within the last six months.

title: Study Says Rise in Coal Mining May Alter Great Plains States
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Coal mining and processing may become the dominant in dustry of the northern Grea Plains states within the next 25 years, an Interior Department study says.

title: A British Test Of the Right To Publish
description: Over the last two weeks, a legal drama that Americans would in many ways find familiar has been tried out before the Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Widgery. It is the case of the Crossman Diaries, a great test of freedom to publish in Britain.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relations to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb. Routes 34 and 537, Colts Neck. (201) 4620383.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: To a young man growing up 30 years ago with British theater and ballet, Antony Tudor was always a remote, elusive and mysterious figure. Even his assumed name, with its regal connotations, seemed strange, although at least it was English, in contrast to that other regalsounding nom de guerre, Ninette de Valois. Strangest of all about Tudor was his selfimposed exile; he had left his homeland and clearly evidenced no special desire to return to it. (At the time, I could hardly have guessed that in the years to come I too would be destined to buy the same oneway ticket.)

title: The Rev. Albert E. Couch, A Pastor in Manhasset, 74
description: The Rev. Albert E. Couch, who retired in 1968 as associate pastor of the Manhasset (L.I.) Congregational Church, died Friday in the Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn.

title: A U.S. AIDE DENIES FITZSIMMONS DEAL
description: William S. Lynch, chief of the Organized Crime and Racketeering Section of the Justice Department's Criminal Division, has denied accusations made against him by a selfdescribed longtime Government informer.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 2 (Reuters)About 4,000 leftists demonstrated around the heavily policed Tokyo international airport here today when Premiei Takeo Miki left on a 10day visit to the United States.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Beame Uses Phone as Weapon
description: Mayor Beame's last two weeks have been a series of postmidnight and prebreakfast meetings, hidden pressures and public testiness, dozens of halfeaten and discarded tuna fish sandwiches and bitter personal confrontations with the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which he always calls Big Mac.

title: City to Shut incinerator
description: BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP)Lowell has agreed to shut down its municipal incinerator by Sept. 11 because of excessive air pollution. The Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday that it had agreed to the date to give the city time to find alternative means of rubbish disposal.

title: Miss Gossett Wed to John Dowdall
description: Susanne Gossett, a summa cum laude graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., and John Patrick Dowdall, a summa cum laude graduate of the University of Notre Dame, were married yesterday at the Jesse Lee Methodist Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Seniormobile Plans 8 Days at Beache
description: CARLE PLACEIn an effort to bring needed services to the elderly during the summer, the Nassau County Department of Senior Citizens Affairs' Seniormobile will spend eight days at two county beaches.

title: European Socialists Back Democracy for Portugal
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 2 (UPI)Heads of government from eight Socialist nations unanimously agreed rtoday ta actively work for the return of democracy in Portugal.

title: CocaCola Disappears From Saigon Markets
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (UPI) The first Western product to disappear from the markets in South Vietnam is CocaCola, one of the symbols of things American.

title: 4 Women Show Photos in Trenton Exhibition
description: TRENTON  Women Vision is the title of an exhibition of work by four of New Jersey's women photographers at the State Museum.

title: Airmail to South Vietnam Is Being Resumed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Regular airmail service to South Vietnam will be resumed Monday, the Postal Service has announced.

title: In View of a Scholar, The Giants Are Wiser
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 2In between researching Franz Kafka and preparing game plans for the next semester of linguistics, Prof. Howard Livingston has made his trainingcamp cuts on the New York Giants' roster.

title: Ford's Economics, One Year Along the Way
description: It will be one year ago next Friday that Gerald R. Ford, the only man in the bullpen, was suddenly summoned to the mound to assume control of the nation's deteriorating political and economic situation.

title: ZEAL OF CENSORS ASSAILED IN INDIA
description: The chairman of the leading news agency in India has assailed what he called a new climate of excessive zeal in the enforcement of press censorship imposed by the Government last month in a crackdown on opponents of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: THE HEAT SPARKS GOODMAN CONCERT
description: Heat does things to jazz musicians, according to a sage who was at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Friday evening to hear Benny Goodman. This could be.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: General From Old Regime Is Named to Saigon Council
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (UPI)The general who ordered army troops of the old ?South Vietnamese Government Ito surrender to the Commutnists has been named to a special Government council.

title: Britain's Hits Are Bad for Broadway's Health
description: Americans have welcomed the British invasion of our theatrical shores almost as passionately as, 200 years earlier, we greeted our freedom from British rule The triumph on the New York stage in recent years of English plays and players has been followed by audience satisfaction, critical celebration and a variety of awards. Broadway  rescued from nearextinction by a succession of hits imported from Londonhas expressed its gratitude with a number of Tonys; the Critics Circle has voted additional prizes; the National Endowment for the Humanities, a Government funding agency, has made a generous grant to the Royal Shakespeare Company in support of its educational tour of our hinterlands; and, in a reverse development, Clive Barnes, theater critic for The New York Times, was recently honored by Queen Elizabeth for his services to British cultural interests in New York.

title: WeekLong Sailing Course A Success in Nassau County
description: The tanned, blond mother of two stepped aboard the Sunfish and was pushed away from the dock. It was Tuesday, dunk day, the day when the 75 new sailors in Nassau county unusual weeklong sailing course learned how to capsize. O.K., Just lean to leeward, explained the instructor.

title: Modern Intelligence: Myth and Reality
description: WASHINGTONThe Aztecs thought the Sun God had to be strengthened each day by the sacrifice of a young man or woman. Without the sacrifice the sun could not rise.

title: After Helsinki
description: The speeches at Helsinki emphasized what had been evident long before the 35 leaders of different countries had come to Finland's capital. This was the simple fact that agreement on a declaration of European security could be attained only by giving something to everybody.

title: As Nehru Saw It
description: Civil Liberty is not merely for us an airy doctrine or a pious wish, but something which we consider essential for the orderly development and progress of a nation. It is the civilized approach to a problem about which people differ, the nonviolent way of dealing with it.

title: THE RISING OF LOWERED EXPECTATIONS
description: WASHINGTON. In a conversation the other day, I asked President Ford to draw the balance sheet on his first year in the White House. What, in his view, were the major achievements? What were the big disappointments?

title: African Violets Are Tops
description: African violets well deserve their great popularity. A recent survey by Plants Alive magazine asked readers to name their five favorite house plants and African violets headed the list.

title: Engagements
description: SteinbergJurist

title: The happy hacker
description: Some 30 million Americans now play tennis20 million more than played it a decade ago. The newcomers and not a few of the veterans need all the help they can get in mastering the sport: hence a new American institutionthe tennis camp. An authoritative guide published this spring listed some 35 of them, and there must be an equal number that didn't make the list. Some are permanent features of the sun belt; some set up shop on prepschool campuses or ski resorts deserted for the summer. Prices range from around $200 a week to $750 (not counting transportation to and from). And, recession or no, they are boominga growth branch of a growth industry.

title: The Nation
description: Administration officials responded with caution last week to economic developments: first, to the latest United States trade figures, then to the Government's most recent statistics on July unemployment.

title: Florida Panhandle Still Wallace's, but Slippage Is Seen
description: DESTIN, Fla., Aug. 1Most of the Florida Panhandle is pineywoods country  flat, rural, poor and inwardlooking, with little county seats that have not grown much in the last 50 years.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: There are, of course, 10 pins in the bowling rack and the idea is to get all of them down with as few shots as possible. You get a strike if you fell all of them on the first roll, a spare if you fell all of them after the second roll.

title: 400 Prisoners Are Transferred To New U.S. Jail on Foley Sq.
description: Under heavy security, 400 inmates of the 60yearold Federal Detention Headquarters on West Street were moved over the weekend into the new Metropolitan Correctional Center on Foley Square.

title: ...And Italy Loses Guido Carli
description: PARISAlmost as predictably as the Pope gives his Easter benediction, Guido Carli, governor of the Bank of Italy, had submitted his resignation. Just as predictably, the Government had rejected it.

title: LISBON'S LEADERS TRY TO END UNREST
description: LISBON, Aug. 2Portugal's three top military leaders attempted today to find an effective government for a country rent by divisions within the armed forces and among civilian political groups.

title: Lexington and Concord 1775
description: The idea for this book, according to the jacket, was conceived during a series of lunches at a Concord inn halfway between the homes of author Jean Poindexter Colby and artist Barbara Cooney (1959 Caldecott Medal winner). The collaboration has been a happy one. The book, slender and handsometwo important requisites for young researchers gives not only an account of what really happened at Lexington and Concord in 1775 but also a record of the sources behind the accountan interesting story in itself. In addition, the book includes a summary of events leading to the war, an annotated list of prominent men on both sides, a tour of Lexington and Concord and a scholarly bibliography. It's a mixed and rather unusual approach but on the whole a good one which should both answer questions and motivate readers to further research.

title: Threat to Dogs Cited
description: Predictions of a mosquito plague in New Jersey brought warnings from health officers about the mosquitocarried disease of dog heartworm, which often infects dogs fatally.

title: About the Jets . . .
description: Steve Tannen fell and reinjured an old shoulder ailment when he attempted to break up a pass play during yesterday's workout, The safety will be out from two to three weeks..... The heat also knocked Roscoe Word, a cornerback, out of the scrimmage. . . . Bobby Howfield is back and kicking. He made four fieldgoal attempts, from 15 to 37 yards. They were his first kicking efforts for the New Yorkers since he was injured last season.

title: F. B. I. Reported to Have Listed Citizens to Detain During Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Federal Bureau of Investigation began in the early nineteenfifties to compile a secret list, known as the Security Index, of American citizens who were targeted for detention in a national emergency under the Subversive Activities Control Act, according to two sources who claim direct knowledge of the operation.

title: Mental Illness Is Reported Main U.S. Health Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Mental illness is America's primary health problem, afflicting at least 10 per cent of the population, according to the National Institute of Mental Health.

title: Shinn Fits Description By Beame for Appointee
description: When Mayor Beame announced last week that he would set up a council to reform municipal management and productivity, he said he would select as its chairman one of the most outstanding people in our city in the business world.

title: Tour Package Offered Cruise Travelers Here
description: To drum up more business for its eightmonth old, $40million passenger steamship terminal, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey last week began a campaign in Cleveland offering a special weekend cruise holiday to New York.

title: 4 Pros Inducted By Hall
description: CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 2The emotion of joining the Pro Football Hall a Fame overwhelmed Lenny Moore, Roosevelt Brown and Dante Lavelli today.

title: Degas
description: The reputation of Edgar Degas was stabilized once and for all in the winter of 191819, within a year and a half of his death. After the contents of his studio in Paris were dispersed at auction, he took rank as one of the greatest of all European artists. Initially as painter and draftsman. later as a pastellist, and finally as a sculptor his place became secure beyond question.

title: Europeans Must Also Weigh Congress's Foreign Policy
description: HELSINKIFor the first time since the early postwar years, the influence of the United States Congress was very much on the minds of leaders of the governments of Europe, as they gathered for the finale of the European Security Conference.

title: Man, 2 Children and Friend Drown in Bridgeport Lake
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. Aug. 2 (UPI)A father, his two young daughters and one of their girlfriends drowned today while bathing in an offlimits lake in Beardsley Park. The victims included Joseph Nunes, 46 years old, and his daughters, Maria, 9 and Laura 7. The fourth victim, whose body was not recovered, was hot immediately identified.

title: Weiskopf's Lead Is Cutto 2 Stroks
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 2It happens sometimes. A leader, even if he is on a hot streak, can have at least one poor round in a tournament, and today was Tom Weiskopf's turn. The sweltering 104degree heat not only wilted thousands of spectators, but it also melted Weiskopf's lead in the Westchester Classic from seven strokes to two.

title: Utah Eager for Big Power Plant
description: BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK, UtahA family of tourists was posing for photographs at the edge of Paria View, overlooking the vast Bryce landscape of bronze, vermilion and ochre forms that look like giant chess pieces.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: An American business executive who is troubled about whether to cross the palm of a foreign gobetween in order to smooth a multimilliondollar deal is unlikely to receive many clear signals from the nation's moral shepherds.

title: INVESTING
description: There are relatively few people in the vast universe of securities holders who have lost money because they failed to submit debentures or preferred shares in time to meet a conversion deadline.

title: What's Doing Around SANTA FE
description: THE ADOBE CITY  Santa Fe, capital of New Mexico, is a small (about 45,000 people) city that wears its tourist attractions well. The city is one of the oldest settlements in the country (it was founded in 1610) and has retained its distinctive Hispanic aura despite the proliferation of motels, neonlined highways and curio shops on its outskirts. The Indians, of course, came first, then the Spanish conquittadores, then the Mexicans, then the Americans.

title: Skirting the Precipice
description: Once again, New York City officials have taken painful measures to end their seemingly endless financial crisis. And again, although the enormous cost in the latest solution will fall on almost every city resident and worker, there is no assurance that the actions taken will be sufficient.

title: U.S. Archives Enjoying Bicentennial Boom
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The National Archives is the repository for, among other things, the Declaration of Independence, a treaty with the signature Bonaparte, 72,000 sound recordings including Tokyo Rose's radio propaganda of World War II, the official proceedings of all Government agencies and a driedup finger in a pickle jar.

title: Alfred Hayes, of the Fed, Retires...
description: A tall, thin man in a gray pinstriped suit climbed into a gray Cadillac limousine on Maiden Lane in New York's financial district Thursday evening and was driven out to his summer home near Bridgehampton on Long Island.

title: BEAME SELECTING ATOP EXECUTIVE TO HEAD OVERHAUL
description: Mayor Beame has selected the president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to direct a citywide management overhaul that would include the possible elimination of programs, reassignment of personnel and introduction of new productivity reforms.

title: Cordless Tools Make Life Easier
description: Cordless electric shop and garden tools that are powered by builtin rechargeable batteries and can be used anywhere without need for long extension cordsor in remote locations where no source of regular electric power is available at allare becoming increasingly popular with home gardeners and doityourself enthusiasts.

title: Soviet Publishes in Full The Helsinki Document
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (Reuters) The Soviet Union fulfilled today one of the basic conditions of the European security conference document in Helsinki yesterday that the entire 30,000word declaration be published in full in each of the 35 signing nations.

title: Notes: Europe Offers Tips to Beat Prices
description: HIGH air fares, runaway prices and fluctuating exchange rates in Europe have discouraged thousands of Americans from crossing the Atlantic. But the European nations are not taking that setback lying down. For one thing, they are sending forth rafts of free booklets boosting discounts and other bargains to help visitors cut costs. And some of the countries are advertising their own economic advantages by way of comparisons bound to be odious to their European neighbors.

title: Hotel Monmouth Site Split Into 23 Lots
description: SPRING LAKEWhen the cupola that graced the dome of the Hotel Monmouth shuddered to the impact of the wrecker's ball and toppled into the structure's ruins here last spring, it marked the end of an era.

title: Is there a sceret police of American capitalism?
description: It almost takes the stamina and interest of a Soviet spy to get through Philip Agee's attempt to relate everything he knew and did during his 12 years as a Central Intelligence Agency operations officerhis selection, training and assignments in Ecuador, Uruguay and Mexico in the 1960's, and his final disillusionment and resignation at the end of 1969. Too bad Inside the Company is such a task to read, because there is important information buried in its 600 or so pages that the general American public should understand, particularly with today's debate over the past and future roles of the C.I.A.

title: U.S. INQUIRY PLANNED ON SPYING BY POLICE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UPI) Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, has announced that the General Accounting Office will investigate the use of Federal monies in the nation's 10 largest cities to fund illegal police spying activities.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor.

title: Sophie Bell Is Bride of S. P. Kelley
description: The marriage of Sophie Harris Bell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. L. Loomis Bell Jr. of Tenafly, N. J., to Stephen Paul Kelley took place yesterday afternoon in Prout's Neck, Me. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Kelley of Eden Prairie, Minn.

title: Taconite Rejuvenates the Iron Range
description: DULUTH. Minn.  For much of the last two decades, the Mesabi iron range in northern Minnesota has seemed destined to become another example of the boom  town  to ghosttown syndrome. But, as Richard Paull, president of the Hibbing, Minn. Chamber of Commerce, says of the present situation, I believe we have the biggest construction boom in the entire country.

title: Accusations Against Two Canadian Legislators Cause a Sensation
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 2Two accusations against Members of Parliament, one to be investigated by a Parliamentary committee, and the other to be aired in court, have caused a sensation in Canada.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A telephone hot line to help state and local officials in New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands find their way through the maze of Federal assistance programs has gone into operation here under the supervision of the Federal Regional Council, 26 Federal Plaza. S. William Green, council chairman here, said that there are 1,000 Federal assistance programs. The phone number is (212) 2645900.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Back to back at the top of the popmusic popularity charts this summer are new albums by Elton John and Paul McCartney. Both disks are huge sellers, tributes to the popularity of these gentlemen. Their music also reflects the wide appeal rock can still exert when it is given the pop treatment by musicians who view themselves primarily as entertainers and their albums as entertainments designed to make rock palatable to the multitudesan approach Elton John has been employing with enormous success for the past five years.

title: Fashion
description: Leave it to the French. They've turned classic American blue jeans into a style called la cigarette, or jeans  la franaise. French jeans are tight, as if sewn on. In Paris, they're rolled up over highheeled boots or down over work boots, and they're de rigueur. So, American manufacturers are busy turning out French jeans.

title: Foul Air Poses Health Threat to East
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Air pollution plagued several large and populous areas along the Eastern seaboard today, causing serious potential hazards for people with respiratory or other health problems and at least some discomfort for countless others.

title: Alaska Sues Over Oil Spill
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 2 (AP)The state of Alaska has filed suit against Alyeska Pipeline Service Company for damage resulting from a fuel oil spill discovered at Galbraith Lake pipeline camp a month ago.. The suit also names Bechtel, Inc., and Arctic Constructors, Inc., as defendants. It asks $5,000 to $100,000 in damages from each of the defendants.

title: Move for Secession Ends in Bass River
description: BASS RIVER TOWNSHIPA movement for the secession of this township from Burlington County so that it could become a part of Ocean County reached the point of approval by the Burlington Freeholders, and then suddenly collapsed.

title: Not what they seem
description: Books about America's selfimage in the movies are among the small and wholly avoidable pains of life. Conceived in a bright moment by a social historian or movie enthusiast on the make, they are likely to suffer from the absence of two things: a sense of America and a sense of the movies. In this overcultivated but not markedly cultured field, Michael Wood strikes the unfamiliar note of the man able to cross boundaries without wrecking the land on both sides. America in the Movies has an almost unheardof combination of virtues for a movie booklucid, wellinformed, and obviously written in high spiritsand anyone interested in the subject will want to look at it for himself.

title: Hypnosis Produces Clue in Hoffa Case
description: DETROIT, Aug. 2A source close to James R. Hoffa's family said today that members of the family and the police had been told the names of two men whom Mr. Hoffa was supposed to have met, along with Anthony Giacalone, a reputed Detroit Mafia figure, last Wednesday, the day he disappeared.

title: Victory Goes to Steelers, Pride Goes to AllStars
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)The Pittsburgh Steelers won the College AllStar football game last night, hut they aren't proud of the way they did it.

title: State Acts to Thwart Mosquitoes
description: JERSEY CITYMosquitoes threaten to become a major state problem this year.

title: A U.N. REPORT CITES USE OF COAST AREAS
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 2 (Reuters)  Twothirds of the world's nearly four billion people lives along its 280,000 miles of coastline, and 39 of the 66 largest cities are in coastal areas, according to a report compiled by the United Nations Ocean Economics and Technology Office.

title: Deborah C. Murray To Be Wed Sept. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. P. Walter Murray of Lancaster, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Carroll Murray, to Frederick Thorne Warner 3d of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warner of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Pompidou was introduced to King Timahoe but not to the author
description: This is a book about the servant mentality in a large American household. The servant in question is one Traphes Bryant, a nightshift electrician at the White House, who through his affection for dogs and his unremitting sycophancy, became the White House dogkeeper under Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon. Early on, when seamstress Lillian Rogers Parks published her best seller, My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House, Bryant was inspired. As he writes, Hell, I thought, where there's smoke there's fire. I kept my ears and eyes open and my mouth shut and almost every day while the stuff was fresh in my mind I'd make a few notes. Nothing fancy. Just plain talk.

title: Remembrances of 'B' Movies Past:Remembrances of 'B' Movies Past
description: Outcast gunfighters, Hamlet-like shamuses, father-loved boxers and housewives in heat were the key creations of those fine, mean, muscular movies that studio bosses used to lump under the designation of "B" (for Budget). Most critics treated B-movies with freezing contempt, cinastes rarely gave them a second thought and, to this day, only a few maverick film historians have bothered to discuss these quickie classics, which from the early forties through the late fifties could always be caught in derelict metropolitan theaters located between penny arcades and tattoo parlors.The very best of the B's were made on workhouse budgets under coolie conditions by the likes of Val Lewton, Andr de Toth, Rudolph Mate and Roy Rowlandmodest, movie-wise, endlessly inventive craftsmen who would take a hopelessly hack assignment and turn it into 95 fast minutes of sharp detailing, understated performing and hard-nosed truth. They went after action, atmosphere and nervy, offbeat characterization, using their junk material, as the film critic Manny Farber has said, "to capture the unworked-over immediacy of life before it's been cooled down by art."Right now, as for the last 20-odd years, hundreds of these shoestring miracles continue to show up on television and continue to be put down by daily and weekly guides as "quaint archaisms" or "just so much celluloid." To give readers a fair idea of what they're like and how well they've survived the small screen, I offer here, from TV's inventory of canned goods, 10 of my favorite forgotten B-jobs and a moment or two from each of the ten that has stayed with me for years.1. "D.O.A." (directed by Rudolph Mate) gives Edmond O'Brien his one right role as a loner-loser dying with each breath from a slow-acting poison meant for somebody else. He spends his last hours and energies hunting his not-quite murderer, encountering the bad, the worse and the implacably malign in a San Francisco whose benign, placid backgrounds vindictively counterpoint his mounting grief and rage. But "D.O.A." is no "Odd Man Out," no metaphor for the modern world; its power is derived from the central image of one chunky, sweating, absolutely desolated human and from the way it puts the spectator inside that human's skin and nerves. Case in point: the superb three-minute sequence when O'Brien, crazed by the doomful diagnosis he's just received, pounds down the steps of a hospital, yowls like a primate, then cuts and runs and keeps running till he blunders against a newspaper kiosk; along the front of this kiosk and in fat bunches on the counter are copies of Life magazine.2. "Ramrod" (Andr de-Toth). In essence, the Western is a ballet with three basic choreographies: The Call-out, the Walk-out and the Shoot-out, "Ramrod," which pits an amiable, unscrupulous cattle baron against an amiable, unscrupulous saddletramp, works exquisite combinations and permutations with all three. Watch, above all, what may be the most quietly, ominous and austere gunfight ever filmed: a shot of a man squatting awkwardly by a stream; a shot of Joel McCrea taking small, stiff-legged steps to come up behind him; a shot of the man glimpsing McCrea's reflection in the stream and realizing death is inescapable; a shot of him trying to grin amiably; a shot of McCrea grinning cruelly back.3. "The Prowler" (Joseph Losey). Van Heflin is a rogue cop, Evelyn Keyes a prurient, slightly pathetic housewife who makes faces at lawn-loving neighbors. Soon after doing what they like to do, they do what they have to domurder her husband. But if "The Prowler" is discount "Double Indemnity," it's also a lot more comfortable with American places and objects, with the kind of sneaky, dangerous eroticism good tabloid melodrama needs. (Even in separate cars parked at a jammed freeway rest-stop Keyes and Heflin forge chains of intimate knowledge.) And the finaleKeyes in a $4-motel box suffering labor pains silently while Heflin moansis as graphic and grueling as a battlefield amputation.4. "The Gangster" (Gordon Wiles). Daniel Fuchs adapted his own novel, "Low Company," loading the script with lines that turn soda-jerks into small-time Falstaffs. ("Go wash your teeth and take care of your family.") It's a darkly-shot, bitter, poetic movie about people who measure out their lives with coffee spoons in a Coney Island luncheonette. One of these people is the gangster, Shebunka (Barry Sullivan). He has never used or wanted to use guns; as a result, ruthless outsiders can push him easily, disdainfully out of his little empire of bungalow bordellos. ("Who do you know, Shebunka, and what have you got?") At the end he has nothing, not even his insistent self-pity; when gunmen wait off-camera to kill him, he holds out his arms and receives their bullets like a benediction. An immense compassion moves beyond clich or campiness. I admire and honor as well the funny, forlorn humanity of Akim Tamiroff crooning to his new ice-cream machine and John Ireland looking and looking at his wife in her rump-sprung bathrobe and saying suddenly and mildly, "You know, I never had a good day with you."5. "He Walked by Night" (Alfred Werker). Using the drainpipes of Los Angeles, Richard Basehart scuttles under the city to steal electronic gear; the stealing is precise and passionless, the thief as colorless as a glass of water. He has no traits, no idiosyncracies and, though we catch his name once, virtually no identity. We never know or care to know what he does and whom he sees when he's not in the drainpipes, for the real achievement of this movie is in its acute presentation of someone who's managed to make society altogether irrelevant. Forget, therefore, the occasionally intrusive civic-minded narration and concentrate instead on those five minutes of brilliantly visual storytelling as Basehart, wounded, goes, not to a doctor, but to his own roomusing his own surgical instruments and magnifying mirrors to remove the bullet himself.6. "The Leopard Man" (Jacques Tourneur). Thirty-four years after its release, this thriller, about a psychopath who terrorizes a Mexican border town, may still be a bit ahead of its time. There's not a cheap trick in it, not an excessive shot or a single piece of cinematic rhetoric. The camera is logical and lucid, linking an image, an idea, to a character's perceptions, pulse rate, wave length. Thus, in a candlelight procession of hooded, keening penitents, it draws you moment by moment deeper into the guilt-ridden mind of the still-unknown killer who walks among them. Various directors over the decades have tried aping this effect without even coming close; none, to my knowledge, has had the skill or nerve to take on the nightwalk: A tipsy seorita-swinger leaves the local hangout, heads home through back streets clicking castanets, wobbling on much-too-high heels. She fears her mother's wrath; the fear is magnified, resonated by sight and sound so that every pebble, bird, cloud partakes of abiding evil. Just as she reaches her door, a branch shakes, bends and, as her mother bolts the door against her, springs up. She screams, and her mother, mockingly, screams louder. At the height of her mother's screams, blood leaks under the door.7. "Killer McCoy" (Roy Rowland). The story veers between ludicrous and lamentable. (Street-kid with sweet left hook; father with bottle problem; mobsters with big bet riding against the kid; trainer saying things like, "Kid, I'm throwing in the towel, the sponge, the stool.") But for once and for the last time, Mickey Rooney gets the chance to use a body as eloquent as Cagney's. You're best off, then, simply feeding on Rooney as he deals his drunken father the most poignant movie-slap ever put on film or parodies a flamenco dancer or relishes a rubdown, a shower, a frankfurter, a kiss. Try, especially, to catch him stroking his girl's hair with 8-ounce boxing gloves and see how long it is before you find yourself forgetting about the gloves.8. "Gun Crazy" (Joseph H. Lewis). A carnival marks-person (Peggy Cummins) and a deadeye hick (John Dall) turn Middle America into a pistol range. And while the round-faced apple-cheeked kill-happy kids chase around, we get a looney look at the country entering the fattening fifties. There's no message, really, or if there is one it's delivered by Cummins in a jolting line spoken while she's wandering around a treeless sun-drenched shopping center: "Hey, it hurts me here! Everything in these forty-eight states hurts me!" Yet the line is nearly lost under the blasting of horns, the idiot yells from a nearby fun house. Scene after scene abounds in similar tiny, tossed-away triumphs that are never underscored or overworked. Among these triumphs: a pump-jockey deliberately and with utmost delicacy cutting through the fan-belt of an out-of-state Cadillac; an expensively-dressed matron unloading the contents of a supermarket shopping cart, then the shopping cart, into her car; a pair of object-hungry young marrieds fondling pressure cookers in a department store and shivering orgiastically while a hold-up goes on.9. "Jeopardy" (John Sturges). For its first 10 or 15 minutes, this one has the look of a low to medium-grade nail-biter. (Barbara Stanwyck and Barry Sullivan make camp between nothing and nowhere; Sullivan is pinned under the pilings of a jetty; and in hours the tide will cover his head.) Director Sturges loves, as a five-year-old cave dweller would and a Hitchcock sometimes does, the banal, beautiful reality of bumper jacks, tow ropes, lug wrenches, crowbars, joists, grapples. He loves, too, exploiting the plain, pure physicality of hard, marred men doing difficult jobs. Ralph Meeker is just such a man, the rescue operation just such a job, and both together wind the movie up like a tight spring; a rough equivalent to the last half hour might be watching the invention of the wheel.10. "The Incredible Shrinking Man" (Jack Arnold) "reduces, by means of special effects that are stamped on the retina, a good-sized, middle-class male into something a little less than the least of earth's creatures. In a way, this might be considered as a merely superb piece of science fiction; in the same way, Kafka's "Penal Colony" might be read as a plea for prison reform. I mean that for me, at least, the movie's singularity and strength come from its quiet integrity, its stubborn refusal to rely on gimmickry  though just the battle against the spider or the scaling of the cellar steps or the whiney, peevish voice issuing out of a doll house could have easily carried the highest-priced sci-fi. While I don't know how to overpraise these sequences, I respect even more that quiet closeup of Grant Williams studying his bed, registering thereby an eternity of sexless nights; that icey complaisance of his brother drawling, "Well, there must be certain . . . domestic problems"; that cheery masochistic mask of his wife's face while she sews and sizes the smallest of coverlets. As for the closing speech, I'll say only that it's worth committing to memory.Just in case I come across as a cranky atavist or, worse, a nostalgia addict, I hasten to recommend "Murph the Surf" (Marvin Chomsky), a fairly recent release that seems to me to have something very much like the zest and velocity of my old B's. Though "Murph" was generally assigned to second-string critics and allocated two sticks of type at the foot of most movie pages, I'll probably see it five times more for the sake of watching Don Stroud ignore the unbelievable cleavage of a blue-haired Miami Beach matron in favor of the believable seeded onion roll he is ravening.Wallace Markfield is a novelist who writes about popular culture.

title: Rep.Edward Mezvinsky to Wed Marjorie S. Margolies of NBC
description: Marjorie Sue Margolies, reporter with NBC News here, and United States Representative Edward Mezvinsky of Iowa City plan to be married Oct. 5. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Margolies of Philadelphia have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Mezvinsky of Ames, Iowa.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Miss Gaynor, Thomas Lynch Plan to Marry
description: Col. Peter F. Gaynor Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gaynor of Mamaroneck, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Elizabeth Anne Gaynor, to Thomas Goffe Lynch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Lynch Jr., also of Mamaroneck.

title: HUSSEIN IS FIRM ON GUERRILLA BAN
description: AMMAN, JordanThough recently he has cemented ties with neighboring Syria and spoken of opening a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, King Hussein of Jordan appears to have no intention of permitting the return of Palestinian commandos.

title: The Federal Reserve and the Reserve Clause
description: With an article questioning the economic effects of major league baseball's restrictive labor practices, Business Review, the scholarly publication of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, has entered the world of sports.

title: The World
description: Gen. Yakubu Gowon has suddenly, and without violence, been deposed as Nigeria's head of state. For nine years Nigeria's national unity and identity, relative political calm, economic growth and nominal leadership in West Africa have depended on his deliberate, nonautocratic style of governing. Outsiders, although on occasion patronizing; liked to describe General Gowon's rule as stable.

title: Wajima First by A Neck
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 EastWest Stable's Wajima turned in another of his fast finishes today and won the $100,000 Monmouth Invitational in stifling heat.

title: His Overthrow Means the Loss to Black Africa of a Guardian
description: KAMPALA, UGANDAA Frenchspeaking African diplomat, worried about the effects on this continent of last week's apparently bloodless coup in Nigeria, asked rhetorically:

title: IRVING KREITZBERG
description: Irving Kreitzberg, for the last 17 years principal of the Greenwich Village School, Public School 41 on West, 11th Street, died of an aortic aneurysm at Montefiore Hospital Friday evening. He was 60 years old and, lived at 2711 Henry Hudson Parkway in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: A Mozart Stylist
description: The Mozart  and it was mostly  section of the Mostly Mozart Festival program in Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night was a mixed bag. There was the E flat Piano Concerto (K. 271), an early if superb work. There were two soprano arias, Ch' io me scordi di te, featuring a piano as well as the orchestra, and Parto, panto from La Clemenza di Tito, which involves a clarinet obligato besides the orchestra. Finally, there was the familiar G minor Symphony (K. 550).

title: Bid by Illinois to Muffle Tracks Stirs a Storm
description: Next Sunday could mark the beginning of the end of motor racing in the state of Illinois, and it could establish a trend for other states regarding noise regulations.

title: Youth Is Testing Search Law
description: OCEAN CITYWithin the next several weeks, there may be a court battle to test the legality of laws designed to keep a tight rein on youthful vacationers.

title: LE FIGARO OF PARIS HAS NEW OWNERSHIP
description: PARIS, Aug. 2 The Paris daily Le Figaro, one of France's largest, passed quietly this week to a new ownera month after employes of the paper staged a brief walkout to opnose the sale.

title: To tell the truth, the price is right
description: To critics, game shows are a vulgar expression of American materialism. To an enthusiast, they are a passion that drives someone in its throes to appear on national television dressed as a baked Alaska in hopes of winning a Vega Hatchback or a color TV or, at least, a nuclearpowered potato masher by AEC, Inc., and a week's supply of Blue Luster Carpet Shampoo. To broadcasters, this lowbudget format is such an inexpensive schedule filler that, during daytime and early evening hours, they have given viewers little else to choose from. And the game shows' ratings are more than healthy enough to indicate that millions of viewers seem to find them an entertaining way to pass the time.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Casey Stengel talks about Billy Martin: He's a damn good manager. He might be a little selfish about some of the things he does and he may think he knows more about baseball than anybody else, but it wouldn't surprise me if he wuz right.

title: Housing And the Money Market
