description: Roger Starr, critic, writer and lately head of New York City's Housing and Development Administration, has written a book about the production, costs and financing of housing. The book's publication coincides with the near collapse of portions of the industry, a situation which doubtless depresses Starr as a critic and housing official but should encourage him as a writer. Interest in the housing money market, the major focus of his book, is at a peak. Housing exceeds all other demands for investment funds in the United States because it requires enormous loans to build and finance. Interest charges, as every builder and owner knows, are the largest component of housing cost. The lending institutions, therefore, play a major role in where housing is built, how much it costs, and Whom it will serve American residential development patterns, whether suburban growth or the erosion of older city neighborhoods, represent a fairly accurate picture of how and where the investors place or withhold their mortmoney.

title: Minneapolis School Board To Test Open Meeting Law
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 (AP) The Minneapolis school board has voted unanimously to test Minnesota's open meeting law, in a suit against The Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company.

title: Lethargic Attitude Blamed By Some for Yank Decline
description: Bill Virdon, who played for the Pittsburgh Pirates against the Yankees in the 1960 World Series, had planned to play against New York's oldtimers at Shea Stadium yesterday. Billy Martin, who played for the Yankees in five World Series in the nineteenfifties, had received a belated invitation to participate in the festivities, but he hadn't planned on attending.

title: Pennsylvania Law Upheld in Challenge on Tax Refund
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (UPI) The constitutionality of a state law denying property tax refunds to about 92,500 elderly persons on public assistance ??to rent their residences has been upheld by a Federal court.

title: BRIDGE
description: Exactly why it is that men dominate the upper echelons of tournament bridge is a question that is often asked but never satisfactorily answered. But the facts are Clear and can be illustrated by some statistics.

title: Key Road Opening In Paterson Soon
description: PATERSONA key section of the city's Inner Loop Road, a fivelane highway planned to bring shoppers and business back into the troubled downtown commercial district, is scheduled to open by Labor Day, according to the Paterson Redevelopment Agency, which is in charge of the project.

title: Man Dates After Wife Dies and Loses His Job
description: ROCK HILL, S. C. Aug. 2 (UPI)A former employe of the Rock Hill Telephone Company who says that he was dismisesd because he dated too soon after his wife's death is seeking aid from the South Carolina Labor Department.

title: Amin Says Inquiry Clears Him of Killing in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda (Reuters) President Idi Amin of Uganda, the new chairman of the Organization of African Unity, said today he would submit a report to the O.A.U. clearing him of charges of mass killings.

title: German System Is Chosen For Italian Color Television
description: ROME, Aug. 2The Government has opened the way for the introduction of color television in Italy by choosing the West German PAL system over its French rival. SECAM.

title: Edward O'Brien Weds Miss Czyszczon
description: At noon yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church In Schenectady, N.Y., Constance Stephanie Czyszczon and Edward Patrick O'Brien were married by the Rev. Michael Zakens, pastor of the church.

title: Book Ends
description: August. A month in which a new Saul Bellow novel appears can't be dismissed out of hand, so let us mop our brow and press ahead with August's tentativelyscheduled offerings.

title: Bond Indicator
description: Investors naturally tend to look to the stock market for a guide to the future of the economy. Stocks, after all, are an established leading indicator  one of several that usually move well before changes in business conditions.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Sometime ago we printed an interview with Paul Bocuse, chefproprietor of his threestar restaurant in Lyons, and, as we have noted several times, perhaps the most famous chef in the world. In the article we indicated that Mr. Bocuse was the only chef to have been received in the French Legion of Honor. We had a note from, among other readers who questioned the authenticity of that statement, Richard de Rochemont of Manhattan.

title: Modern Masters Is a Must Display
description: For just four weeksfrom today through Labor Daythe Museum of Modern Art has on offer a New York showing of one of the most conspicuous of its evangelical successes. This is the exhibition entitled Modern Masters: Manet to Matisse that was sent to two major museums in Australia and racked up close to a halfmillion visitors. It was directed by William S. Lieberman and sponsored by the Alcoa Foundation; and it is by any standard a marvelous display.

title: Lockheed's Payments Abroad To Be Studied by Loan Board
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Federal Board set up to Supervise the Government backing of loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is investigating whether Lockheed has violated its contractual obligations to the Government by not disclosing to the board the $22million it paid foreign officials and political organizations.

title: Astor Cup
description: THE LEADING FINISHERS

title: F.B.I. Enters Hoffa Case; Extortion Statute Cited
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was entering the investigation of the disappearance of James R. Hoffa in Michigan.

title: 4th Day in the 90's Here, And No Relief Is in Sight
description: A stagnant equatorial heat wave subjected the city to merciless record temperatures yesterday and showed no signs of going away.

title: Lockheed Investigated
description: The Federal board set up to supervise the Government backing of loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is investigating whether Lockheed violated its contractual obligations to the Government by not disclosing to the board that it had paid $22million to foreign officials and political organizations. Page 29.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports News Briefs
description: U.S. Leads in Admiral's Cup

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BODY AND SOUL Showtime is 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. at Thyme & Motion (6845710), 405 Third Avenue (between 28th and 29th Streets), and Queen Yahna returns tomorrow night through Saturday. With a policy of rotating talent, this bar showcase opened several months ago and the entertainer, whose appearance is as unorthodox as her name, was an early, brief booking.

title: Why They Run
description: WASHINGTON Compared to the number of citizens who seek the services of government daily and confidently expect it to be ready to meet their needs, the number who offer their services to keep the wheels of government turning is pathetically small. Yet those who do offer their services are eyed warily by the press, the voters, and those who never bother to vote. The higher the office, the more careful the scrutiny.

title: Defense Rebuff
description: The Senate's surprise defeat of the $25.7billion military procurement bill last week, an act unprecedented in recent memory, was a welcome response to a not unprecedented abuse of power by the militaryindustrial complex in Congress. The majority of 48 to 42 was achieved with the help of fiscal conservatives and others concerned as a matter of principle about even small disregard of Congress' new budgetcontrol guidelines, a principle which dominated the debate. But what triggered the definitive assault was anger over the way the conference committee of the two houses resolved controversial issues almost Invariably in favor of the military.

title: On The Hustle
description: WASHINGTONIf a man were permitted to make all the ballads, wrote Scottish rebel Andrew Fletcher in 1704. he need not care who should make the laws of a nation. This sentiment was echoed by Artemus Ward in 1863: Let me write the songs of a nashun and I don't care a cuss who goes to the legislater.

title: Pay 'N Pak Victor In Hydroplaning
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 3 (AP)George Henley piloted the Seattlebased Pay 'N Pak to its fourth straight unlimited hydroplane victory today in a Seafair Regatta with many boats plagued by mechanical problems.

title: U.S. Consul in Malaysia Held By Three Japanese Guerrillas
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Monday, Aug 4 (Reuters)Gunmen said to be members of the Japanese Red Army guerrilla group shot their way into the United States consulate here today and took the consul and three women employes as hostages, a spokesman for the embassy said.

title: Miss Doerner Wins Tennis Title
description: With an answer for every deep, low shot dealt her yesterday by 17yearold Jeanne Evert, 24yearold Cynthia Doerner of Australia won the championship of the Ms. America tennis circuit, 61. 36, 61. Her prize was $3,500. Miss Evert, who had been seeded first, won $1,900 as the runnerup.

title: Bradford Quits Presidency Of Allied Chemical Corp.
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that David H. Bradford Jr. had resigned the presidency of the, company. No reason was given for the resignation, although Allied stated that Mr. Bradford would continue to serve on the board and handle specific projects and assignments for the chairman.

title: Littler Takes Westchester Golf By Defeating Boros in Playoff
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 3  Gene Littler, a 45yearold golf pro whose distinguished career has scarcely been affected by my little setback  a cancer operation in 1972  made up a fourstroke defkit today by shooting two eagles, one of them a holeinone, to win the Westchester Classic.

title: 5Cent Staten Island Fare Sails Into History
description: Sam Marino stood at the entrance to the Staten Island Ferry terminal at the Battery yesterday with a light meter poised over a big, bold, new sign. Effective 12:01 A.M., Monday, Aug, 4, 1975, Fare 25c, the sign said and Mr. Marino, camera in hand, recorded the date of the death of the famed nickel fare.

title: Las Vegas Night Was the Real Thing, Police Raiders Say
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 3Suspecting that professional gamblers were becoming involved in purportedly charitable Las Vegas Nights in Connecticut, a joint organized crime task force raided one such event last night in this affluent summer resort.

title: 188 on Charter Jet Killed In Moroccan Crash in Fog
description: AGADIR, Morocco, Aug. 3A chartered jetliner carrying Moroccan workers from France to their homeland for summer vacations crashed into a mountainside in heavy fog early today, killing all 188 people aboard, authorities said.

title: Money Market Is Showing A Decided Upward Trend
description: The pendulum finally has begun to swing toward higher interest rates, some money. market analysts believe. There may be aberrations from week to week, they say, but the basic trend now points upward. That means, in general terms, lower prices and more generous yields for Treasury securities and corporate bonds during the next couple of monthsand perhaps for a much longer period.

title: World Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAME

title: Don't Call It a Fat Camp
description: POULTNEY, V.t.It's not a fat camp. It's not a milk farm. It's not a beauty spa. It's a weight control community, where women between the ages of 16 and 45 can spend their summer vacations and, they hope, take it off, take it all off.

title: Fanfani, ExParty Chief In Italy, Is Married
description: ROME, Aug 3 (Reuter) Amintore Fanfani, recently ousted as leader of Italy's Christian Democratic party, was married today in a private church ceremony.

title: Instant Lottery Will Halt Earlier as Sales Go Down
description: Though sales are still running at a reasonably brisk pace, New Jersey's Instant Lottery is beginning to lose its novelty and will probably be discontinued a week to 10 days before originally anticipated.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Bouvier Is Best at Hunterdon
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 3  Champion Taquin du Posty Arlequin, a Bouvier des Flandres, owned by Chet Collier of IrvingtononHudson, N.Y., and chairman of the board of Westinghouse TV, won his 19th top award today at the Hunterdon Hills Kennel Club show on the county fairgrounds.

title: Papers Show U. S. Considered Ousting Rhee in Korean War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Newly declassified documents show that the United States gave highlevel consideration during the Korean war to staging a coup against President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

title: DEAL OF $1BILLION TAKES SHAPE HERE TO GIVE CITY CASH
description: An intricate $1billion package of bond sales, bank loans and a cash advance by the state moved toward final shape yesterday as bankers and financial officials worked vigorously to try to raise the cash to avert a city default this month.

title: Reutemann Wins; Lauda 3d at Ring
description: NUERBURGRING, West Germany, Aug. 3Carlos Reutemann and Niki Lauda made sacrifices today and their unusual rituals led to blessines.

title: Nigerians Shrug at Coup; Bus Fare a Bigger Topic
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug 3I am waiting to see what it all means to the price of gari.

title: Kibbee Hopes City U. Can Regain Some Funds
description: The City University Chancellor, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, voiced the hope yesterday that the university might recover part of the cityordered budget cuts. This could be done, he said, by persuading the state to disburse already budgeted matching funds it stands to save because of the cuts.

title: Steel Industry Expects Price Rise After Labor Day
description: Most steel executives are now saying privately that it's only a matter of time before their industry breaks out with a rash of price increases. Most of them feel the timing will come after Labor Day, because most expect the third quarter to prove weaker than the second.

title: To Save a Newspaper
description: The tendency of bureaucratic government regulations to produce exactly the opposite effect from the goal avowedly sought has often been remarked upon but has rarely been so glaringly evident as in the current crisis threatening the survival of The Washington Star. There a Federal Communications Commission regulation nominally aimed at increasing the diversity of the marketplace of opinion threatens to make Washington a onenewspaper city and to abort the promise offered by the recent infusion of new capital and new talent into The Washington Star.

title: Josie Johnson Married To Dr. Leo Winter Jr.
description: Josephine Lynne Johnson, an actress known as Josie Johnson, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Leo Winter Jr., an oral surgeon, and president of Leo Winter Associates, a drug and cosmetics: research concern here. The ceremony was performed at the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Hotel by Judge John Harris of the West Los Angeles Municipal Court.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India has drafted retroactive legislation that would end her personal entanglement with the courts by changing the election laws under which she was convicted in June of improper practices. The amendments, which were written to fit the particular circumstances of the case against Mrs. Gandhi, are expected to be presented today to Parliament. They will probably be enacted quickly. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 4, 1975

title: F.T.C. Probe Asked Of 8 Directorates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission was asked today to investigate eight industrialists who serve on the boards of two competing companies.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices as which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: DEAL OF $1BILLION TAKES SHAPE HERE TO GIVE CITY CASH
description: An intricate $1billion package of bond sales, bank loans and a cash advance by the state moved toward final shape yesterday as bankers and financial officials, worked vigorously to try to raise the cash to avert a city default this month.

title: PROFITS CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND
description: Corporate profits to the second quarter continued to slide despite the huge selloff of inventories during the period. The 3.7 per cent decline from this year's firstquarter profits may seem minor, but it is part of a total drop of 36.2 per cent from the peak of last year's third quarter.

title: ANTICOMMUNISTS DEFY LISBON EDICT
description: LISBON, Aug. 3  Despite official warnings against disorder, antiCommunist demonstrators again went into the streets of various towns last night and today.

title: Butz Expects Food Prices To Rise and Beef to Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)  Food prices will rise slightly later this year, but the price of beef probably will decline somewhat, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today.

title: ROSENBERG PAPERS ORDERED PRESERVED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) A Federal judge has issued an order barring the destruction of documents sought in a suit by the two sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were executed as spies in 1953.

title: Centennial of Hans Andersen's Death Is Observed
description: Once upon a time in the Danish town of Odense, there lived a tall, awkward, ragged boy named Hans, the son of a shoemaker and an illiterate washerwoman.

title: Phyllis Cohen Is Bride Of Sanford F. Seplow
description: Phyllis Ann Cohen, a management analyst with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was married yesterday afternoon, to Sanford Freeman Seplow, a stockbroker with Doft & Co., Inc.

title: Keeping Cool Turns Upper East Side Into a Land of Fountains
description: All along the East Side avenues north of 96th Street yesterday the little boys were kings, commanding magnificent legions of water.

title: Gov. Brown Urges a Delay in Offshore Oil Leasing
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has sugBested that the Federal Government's headlong rush to sell offshore oil rights was simply a foreign policy maneuver designed as psychological pressure on the foreign oilexporting nations.

title: City's Fiscal Woes Hurt Suburbs, Too
description: Like the neighbors of a home where the grass is growing shaggy and the paint is beginning to peel, the suburbs are feeling some unhappy impact from New York City's highly visible fiscal tribulations.

title: A Letter to Sihanouk By FOX BUTTERFIELD
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 3The senior Cambodian Communist leader has sent a letter to Prince Norodom Sihanouk in North Korea wishing him good health but not mentioning a possible return by the Prince to Phnom Penh, the official North Korean press agency disclosed today.

title: Rostropovich Sets Verdi Requiem Afire
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3Verdi's Requiem, almost alone among the great funerary choral pieces, can leave you feeling that entry into the next life may be a rather lively experience, one that you would not want to miss if at all possible. In a truly inspired performance such as Mstislav Rostropovich conducted here at Tanglewood last night, the operatic gestures in this mass, which were once condemned as inappropriate for a liturgical work, are transmuted. Under the selfexiled Soviet artist's baton, Verdi's score became a devastating statement in which the apocalypse could be felt not only as the ultimate theatrical event that it no doubt will be but also as a hopeful, even joyful, moment.

title: Ronnie Yellin Bride of Stephen Charme
description: Ronnie Yellin, daughter of Mrs. William F. Pierce of East Meadow, L. I., and West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Bernard P. Yellin, was married yesterday evening to Stephen M. Charme, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Charme of Westfield. N. J.

title: B'nai B'rith Seeks Visit to Soviet Union
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3  B'nai B'rith's board of governors, ruling body of the 500,000member Jewish service organization, voted today to seek early agreement from the Soviet Union for an official delegation to meet and establish closer religious and cultural ties with the Jews of that country.

title: ProFrench Group Gains Control Of the Comoro Islands in a Coup
description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, Aug. 3 (Reuters)An opposition group seeking to retain links with France took control of this Indian Ocean archipelago today in a bloodless coup, just four weeks after the parliament of the islands unilaterally declared independence from France.

title: Shadows of City's Fiscal Ills Darken Bond Market for Other Municipalities
description: When municipal officials met at Buffalo's City Hall one day last week to open bids for a $35million issue of sewer bonds, a strange thing happened. For the first time in the city's history, the local sewer authority failed to receive any bids from underwriters.

title: Michael Carr Marries Barbara Ann Freeman
description: Barbara Ann Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Freeman of Franklin Lakes, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Bryan Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Carr of Cherry Hill, N. J. The Rev. Robert Davidson performed the ceremony in the Mount Cannel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N. J.

title: Beverly Schreiber Bride of Dr. Jacoby
description: Beverly Edith Schreiber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schreiber of Cincinnati, was married yesterday morning to Dr. John Eric Jacoby, son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Jacoby of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Andrea J. Osur Married in Jersey
description: Andrea Judith Osur, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Osur of Elmwood Park, N.J., was married last evening to Allen Susser, son of Presiding Judge Herbert Susser of the Passaic County District Court and Mrs. Susser of Paterson, N.J. Rabbi Harry A. Bornstein performed the ceremony at the Short Hills in Millburn, N.J.

title: PANEL SAID TO FIND C.I.A. ACTS ILLEGAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Justice Department lawyers looking into possible wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency have concluded that agency employes acted illegally in opening and photographing mail in transit between the United States and Communist countries, according to wellplaced department officials.

title: Fourth Day of 90Plus Readings in City
description: Heights and Brownsville Brooklyn, as well as Harlem and the South Bronxhad water pressures reduced to a point that might hinder firefighting efforts. In addition, some buildings were said to be losing some or all of their water pressure. The alert was canceled overnight.

title: PANEL SAID TO FIND C.I.A. ACTS ILLEGAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Justice Department lawyers looking into possible wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency have concluded that agency employes acted illegally in opening and photographing mail in transit between the United States and Communist countries, according to wellplaced department officials.

title: Bold Forbes Wins, Sets Spa Record
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3Anybody in his right mind would have stayed in the motel pool today instead of sweltering in 95degree heat at a race track.

title: Tocks Dam: Story Of 13Year Failure
description: The final chapter of the story of a dam that was never built is to be written soon by Congress. It will be anticlimactic, however, because after 13 years of controversy three Governors have told the Congress what to say.

title: Schlesinger: C.I.A. Role Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger has said that the Central Intelligence Agency's sources of information abroad have been dramatically reduced as a result of leaks from Congressional investigating committees.

title: Betty Ford, Tired, Rests as President Sees Transylvania
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 3 (AP)Betty Ford excused herself from an excursion to Transylvania today because of a recurrence of a fatigue that had forced her to curtail her program earlier in the Presidential tour of Europe.

title: Purchasing Executives Find Prices Increasing
description: Inflation reappeared in July after five months of containment, the National Association of Purchasing Management said over the weekend. In its monthly report on business conditions, the association pointed out that suppliers were beginning to test the market as the business recovery moved along.

title: Red Smith
description: A fellow can't help wondering how George Steinbrenner will react when he comes back to the Yankees and discovers that Gabe Paul has fired his manager of the year behind his back and hired somebody else's manager of the year. We know Bill Virdon was dismissed and Billy Martin signed without Steinbrenner's knowledge and consent because Bowie Kuhn himself has assured us that Steinbrenner has no connection with baseball, not even when he watches games from the club box or tapes pep talks for delivery in the locker room. The commissioner gave the assurance when he decided there was no place in baseball for an admitted felon, and wouldn't be for two years. That is the term of the suspension he imposed last fall after Steinbrenner was fined for violating the laws an political campaign contributions.

title: RABIN AND WALDHEIM MEET IN STOCKHOLM
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 3 (Reuters)Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Secretary General Waldheim met for 90 minutes here today to discuss Middle East peace moves and Arab efforts to oust Israel from the United Nations.

title: U.S. Oarsmen Dominate Canadian Henley Regatta
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Aug. 3  American entries won 13 of the 18 finals contested on this concluding day of the 93d Royal Canadian Henley Regatta. The most notable American achievement came in the senior eights, won by the American men's and women's national teams.

title: Abraham I. Kalina, 69, Is Dead; A State Supreme Court Justice
description: State Supreme Court Justice Abraham I. Kalina died yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Queens. He was 69 years old and lived at 4811 Beach 48th Street. Brooklyn.

title: LOUIS D. FLETCHER
description: Louis Dubois Fletcher, a retired senior partner in the New York law firm of Darby & Darby, specializing in patent and trademark law, died Saturday in White Plains Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 12 Rutland Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Sun Scores, 2115, In W.F.L. Opener
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP)Mike Ernst threw touchdown passes of 65 and 25 yards and led the Southern California Sun to a 2115 victory today over the Portland Thunder in a World Football League opener.

title: Eleanore Grosz Wed
description: The Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Eleanore Grosz, daughter of Mrs. Jack Weiss of Yonkers and the late Stephen Grosz, to Cary Hirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Hirsch of Kings Point L. I. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony.

title: Personal Finance: On Social Security
description: The direct depositing of Social Security checks in financial institutionslong in the planning state and in a pilot stage for the last yearbegan to go into effect last Friday.

title: Doyle Lifts Bat Streak to 21 as Red Sox Win, 64
description: After spending five uninspired seasons with the Philadelphia Phillies and the Califorrnia Angels, Denny Doyle seems to have found pleasant surroundings with the Boston Red Sox.

title: Babashoffs Take FreeStyle Events
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP)Shirley Babashoff and her brother, Jack, scored victories in the women's and men's 100meter freestyles today in the final day of the Mission Viejo Invitational swim meet.

title: Frost in Brazil Sending Coffee Prices Up
description: Reports that almost half the coffee trees in Brazil were destroyed by a severe frost last month were received here at the time with some skepticism. But by last week one thing was clearcoffee prices are going up sharply.

title: TITO WARNS FORD ON ISRAELI STANCE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3  President Tito declared bluntly tonight at a diner for President Ford that to avoid a dangerous crisis in the Middle East, Israel must give up occupied Arab lands and recognize Palestinian independence.

title: SEWAGE DELAYS SCORED BY LEVITT
description: Unnecessary delays in carrying out a $624million program to improve nine major sewage treatment plants here have cost taxpayers an additional $15million and resulted in continuing excessive pollution of the city's waters, Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday.

title: Diane Rotter, Richard Kelmenson Wed
description: Diane Rotter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Rotter of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Kelmenson, son of Dr. Harry Kelmenson and Mrs. Florence Siegel, both of Baltimore.

title: F.B.I. Enters Hoffa Case; Extortion Statute Cited
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was entering the investigation of the disappearance of James R. Hoffa in Michigan.

title: Times Have Changed
description: Mayor Beame has made a credible start on the longdelayed task of restoring New York City to solvency. Facing the need for nearly a billion dollars of borrowed funds to meet August's heavy cash demands, the challenge now is to overcome a widespread habit of skepticism about the city's efforts to balance the budget.

title: About New York
description: A pothole in the southern Verpont hamlet of Grafton, beautifully situated a half hour from nowhere, aroused an the inferiorities that New Yorkers often unwittingly throw into the trunk when they drive off on New EngIand vacations.

title: Cosmos Lose, 50, and Miss Playoff Berth
description: The New York Cosmos lost to the Minutemen, 50, in Boston yesterday in a nationally televised game that eliminated them from a possible playoff berth in the North American Soccer League.

title: San Francisco Tops 13 Cities in Survey Of Violent Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Residents of San Francisco and Minneapolis reported the highest level of violent crime in 1973 among 13 large cities included in a new Government victimization survey.

title: Burma Cooperating With U.S. to Stem Opium Flow
description: RANGOON, Burma  Burma, Southeast Asia's principal producer of opium, has quietly begun cooperating with the United States in fighting the traffic that begins with the gum of the poppies grown in the Burmese mountains, and ends with heroin in the streets of American cities.

title: Comeback Star of Pro Golf Tour
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 3Gene Alec Littler, who made a spectacular comeback after cancer surgery in the spring of 1972, has said, If I perform well out there on the golf course I feel I'm doing something for those people who have the same problem I had.

title: Susan Feder Bride of Richard Gibralter
description: Susan Janet Feder, who is starting her third year at the Brooklyn Law School, was married yesterday at noon to Richard Paul Gibralter, a fourthyear student at the Mount Sinai Medical School. Justice Aaron E. Koota of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A fashion show at Azuma? Well, why not? The sevenstore chain that specializes in Eastern imports has always .been a trove of goodlooking ideas for little money, and bright young things scout for bargains there regularly.

title: Bridge; Victory in Grand National ?? HammanWolff Plans
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 3The victory of the Dallas team in the Grand National team championship here last night had one strange result: two members of the winning team, Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff, became the first players to regret that they had won a major national team title.

title: Life Without Dreams
description: In his speech to the Helsinki Conference, President Ford emphasized its pledges of freer movement for people and ideas. It is important, he told the leaders of thirtyfour other countries there, that you recognize the deep devotion of the American people and their Government to human rights and fundamental freedom.

title: Banker Voted Tribal Chief
description: TAHLEQUAH, Okla., Aug. 3 (UPI)  Ross Swimmer, a banker and former Cherokee tribal attorney who was endorsed by the outgoing chief, won the tribal chief election yesterday.

title: DR. WOLDEMAR WEYL, AUTHORITY ON GLASS
description: Dr. Woldemar A. Weyl, an authority on the technology of glass, died Wednesday of cancer in State College, Pa. He was 74 years old.

title: Lockheed Investigated
description: The Federal board set up to supervise the Government backing of loans to the Lockheed Aircraft corporation is investigating whether Lockheed violated its contractual obligations to the Government by not disclosing to the board that it had paid $22million to foreign officials and political organizations. Page 29.

title: Books of The Times
description: Peter Dickinson's baroque portrait of international intrigue differs from our present political climate only in the high style of some of its characters. It makes me blush for the inelegance of our own Government's brand of iniquity. With all the classy spy stories Americans read and see in films, I would expect that our elected representatives and their minions might be more graceful in their egregiousness.

title: A Beguiling Dolly Parton Sings at Jersey Festival
description: STANHOPE, N. J., Aug. 3Dolly Parton on records is a country singer and song writer of enormous individuality and charm. She retains all of that in concert, but seems even more quintessentially country than ever.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Aug. 3 (UPI)Andy Bean shot a par 3 on the 17th hole today to go 1 up over Randy Simmons and win the 73d annual Western amateur golf championship. In the semifinals earlier today, Simmons, of Shreveport, La., had won 3 and 2 from Bob Byman of Raleigh, N.C. and Bean of Lakeland, Fla., had won, 1 up, from the champion, Curtis Strange of Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Souvenirs Sold in Alaska Spur F.T.C. Fight on Product Labels
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 3Somel 1,000 miles from Alaska's crowded souvenir stands, the Federal Trade Commission is engaged in a court battle in Seattle that could force manufacturers to label exactly where, and from what materials, totem poles, ivory and soapstone carvings, bead work and other native type gifts are made.

title: ENQUIRER TO YIELD DATA ON KISSINGER
description: LANTANA, Fla., Aug 3 (UPI) The Weekly National Enquirer anounced today that It would, comply with a Secret Service request to return documents it found in Secretary of State Kissinger's trash.

title: Advertising
description: In these days of promotion budget trimming. David L. Brown 3d and Allan F. Pam of the Marriott Corporation are on the road seeking major corporate commitments for their three new Great America theme parks. You think that's easy?

title: Better News on Jobs
description: The latest data on employment and unemployment provide confirming evidence that the long recession that began in November of 1973 has touched bottom and that recovery has begun. But the figures also give reason for caution about the strength of the recovery.

title: MUIR MATHIESON, 64, A FILM CONDUCTOR
description: OXFORD, England, Aug. 3 (AP)Muir Mathieson, who directed the music for many of Britain's bestknown films, died yesterday at the age of 64.

title: Music: Antonia Brico Conducts Here
description: Antonia Brico came back to conduct in New York last night after an absence of some 40 years and the concert, at the Mostly Mozart Festival, had all the makings of an irresistibly sentimental occasion. Dr. Brico, whose career flourished during the nineteenthirties but lost momentum, possibly because as a woman conductor she was far ahead of her time, came onstage at Avery Fisher Hall after a showing of the documentary film about her career, Antonia: A Portrait of a Woman, and received an aptly delirious reception from an audience of Brico idolators. The film, directed by Judy Collins and Jill Godmilow, has won a dozen prizes, and deserves them all.

title: Ford Picks Humphrey
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) President Ford says he thinks Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota is his most likely Democratic opponent in the 1976 election. When the Democrats get all through, Senator Hubert Humphrey probably is as good a guess as any, he told U.S. News and World Report.

title: Centennial of Hans Christian Andersen Is Observed
description: Once upon a time in the Danish town of Odense, there lived a tall, awkward, ragged boy named Hans, the son of a shoemaker and an illiterate washerwoman.

title: Pearson Triumphs in Smoking Mercury
description: LONG POND, Pa., Aug. 3David Pearson ignored a black flag, official orders to pull into the pits, and two laps later took the checkered flag in his smoking Mercury as the winner of one of the finest stock car races in history today.

title: INK GANDHI PLANS RETROACTIVE LAW TO CLEAR HER CASE
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 3  The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has drafted retroactive legislation that would lend her personal entanglement with the courts by changing the election laws under which she was convicted in June of improper practices.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: 5 Hurt as Hail Hits Plane
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 3 (UPI)Five persons suffered minor injuries tonight when a Delta Airlines DC9 was hit at 27,000 feet by turbulence and hail that cracked its windshield, authorities said. The Federal Aviation Administration said the plane, flight 548 from Cleveland to Burlington, Vt., made an emergency landing at Hancock Airport without further incident.

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at MilwaukeeMay (106) vs. Travers (45).

title: DR. EDWIN GRACE, SURGEON, 81, DEAD
description: Dr. Edwin J. Grace, a former thoracic surgeon and research scientist, who was an authority on the clinical administration of antibiotics, died yesterday in Huntington (L. I.) Hospital. He lived in Greenlawn, L. I., and would have been 81 years old next Sunday.

title: For the Mideast, a Real Peace Is as Elusive as Ever
description: The Middle East is as close to peace as it ever comes, and all the surface signposts indicate that it will remain in that uneasy situation for at least six months. Nonetheless, the roots or war the visceral Egyptian and Syrian desire for the return of lost lands, Israeli resistance to a Palestinian state, the ambitions of politicians on both sides responsive to extremist demands  remain untouched after 22 months of intensive diplomatic activity. Land mines are strewn across every path to permanent peace.

title: Vilas Gains Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3(AP)  Topseeded Guillermo Vilas reached the final of the $100,000 Louisville pro tennis tournament with a 62, 6.2 victory over Jaime Fillol today.

title: Senate Expected to Pass Assembly Tax Plan Today
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3 (AP)The job of restoring $267.8million to New Jersey's state budget is expected to be completed tomorrow.

title: Susie Berning Wins on Birdie
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. (AP)Susie Berning of Lake Tahoe, Calif., birdied the final hole today and won the Lady Keystone open, a satellite tournament on the women's progolf tour. She won $4,000.

title: GALAXIES' SIGNALS BEING RECORDED
description: Radio signals emitted by clouds of carbon monoxide gas in two dusty, exploding galaxies more than 10 million lightyears away from earth have been recorded by a specially designed telescope In Arizona.

title: Four Yachts Bidding for Top Award
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 3The New York Yacht Club squadron dispersed today following yesterday's Astor Cup race, won by Kindred Spirit, which concluded the sevenday annual summer cruise. The remaining piece of business for the club's race committee was to select the yacht which had the most outstanding performance during the week, a citation which brings to its skipper the Cygnet Cup. It is awarded at the club's annual dinner in November.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
NAVAL FACILITIES BAR A RESERVIST
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3Growing resentment over the Navy's attitude toward its reservists erupted into open conflict last week when a regional president of the Naval Reserve Association was barred from all Reserve armories and other facilities in four Western states.

title: River Lovers Begin Hike In Drive to Save Potomac
description: THOMAS, W. Va., Aug. 3Ten years ago, in one of his flamboyant visions of the future, the late Lyndon B. Johnson made a Presidential pledge that by 1975 we are going to reopen the Potomac River for swimming.

title: TITO WARNS FORD ON ISRAELI STANCE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3  President Tito declared bluntly tonight at a dinner for President Ford that to avoid a dangerous crisis in the Middle East, Israel must give up occupied Arab lands and recognize Palestinian independence.

title: ROBERT FEINBERG, LABOR LAWYER, 63
description: I. Robert Feinberg, a leading labor lawyer and arbitrator, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 10 West 66th Street

title: Janet Polivy Has Nuptials
description: Dr. Janet Polivy, assistant professor of psychology at Loyola University, was married yesterday to Dr. C. Peter Herman, assistant professor of psychology at Northwestern University. The ceremony was performed in Congregation Beth Sholom, Lawrence, L. I., by Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman.

title: El Salvador Plane Crash Kills 17 in Dance Troupe
description: SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 3 (AP)A Nicaraguan Air Force C47 crashed into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of El Salvador last night, killing all 20 persons aboard, a Salvadorean Air Force spokesman said today.

title: The New F.B.I. Man Does Not Quite Fit the Old Image
description: He planted one foot against the dashboard, braced himself, and looked up and down the sidestreets. You got it, he said. Now go, go, go.

title: Ballet: Noella Pontois Dances Giselle
description: During the last few days New York has had the opportunity to see the Paris Opra ballerina Noella Pontois in three modestly contrasted roles. At the gala just a week ago she made her American debut dancing in the Don Quixote pas de deux with Mikhail Baryshnikov. The following night, also with Mr. Baryshnikov, she danced in La Bayadre, and finally, on Saturday night, she made her local debut in Giselle, once more with Mr. Baryshnikov, who first danced with her in Paris and has reportedly found her most sympathetic work with.

title: East Germans With Kin in West Await Proof of Helsinki Accord
description: WILTHEN, East GermanyNorbert Dietrich, like members of thousands of families in East Germany, has relatives in the Westtwo brothers who left before the Berlin wall sealed off the country in 1961.

title: Beame Court Plan Seen Saving City $200Million
description: Were the state to absorb the cost of the city's court, correction and probation systems as proposed by Mayor Beame last weekthe city would save as much as $200million annually.

title: Hanoi Delegation Confers With Cambodian Leaders
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 3 For the first time since the end of the warfare in Indochina earlier this year, toplevel discussions have taken place between officials of North Vietnam and the new Communist regime in Cambodia.

title: On Involuntary Psychiatry
description: SYRACUSEIn its recent decision in O'Connor v. Donaldson, the United States Supreme Court held for the respondent on the ground that he was compulsorily confined in a mental hospital even though he was not dangerous and was not given treatment. Was this a good decision?

title: Robbers Take $8,000 From Two Restaurants
description: The Burger King restaurant at 427 Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn was robbed of $5,000 by two gunmen before it opened yesterday,

title: The New F.B.I. Man Does Not Quite Fit the Old Image
description: He planted one foot against the dashboard, braced himself, and looked up and down the sidestreets. You got it, he said. Now go, go, go.

title: Blue Cross Called Lax On Curbing Health Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The cost of medical care in the United States is rising more rapidly than the cost of living, partly because Blue Cross and Blue Shield hesitate to impose cost controls on doctors and hospitals.

title: Instant Lottery Ends In Jersey This Month
description: Though sales are still running at a reasonably brisk pace, New Jersey's Instant Lottery is beginning to lose the charm of novelty and will probably be discontinued a week to 10 days before originally anticipated.

title: 4th Day in the 90's Here, And No Relief Is in Sight
description: A stagnant equatorial heat wave subjected the city to merciless record temperatures yesterday and showed no signs of going away.

title: Hughes C.I.A. Pact Is Put Month After Gift to Nixon
description: LOS ANGELES. Aug. 3Howard R. Hughes got his secret contract with the Central Intelligence Agency for the ship Glomar Explorer five weeks after making an emergency contribution of $100,000 to President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign, according to sources familiar with a tax investigation of the ship here.

title: Ford Says Soviet Aids Portuguese Reds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)In an interview published today, President Ford accused the Soviet Union of quietly helping the Communists in Portugal and called it tragic that the United States was unable to helo the situation there.

title: Chick Called Sue Wins
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N.M., Aug. 3 (AP)  Chick Called Sue upset Bugs Alive in 75 and Chick's Deck today at Ruidoso Downs race track to win the $315,140 Rainbow Futurity, the second leg in the triple crown of quarter horse racing.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne announced plans yesterday for the construction of a new exit on the New Jersey Turnpike that will ease access to Newark International Airport. Mr. Byrne said the new exit, 13A, which will cost $50million, would be situated in Elizabeth and would save 15 minutes in driving time for vehicles approaching the airport from the south.

title: 18 of World's 50 Biggest Companies Are in Oil Industry
description: Oil companies dominate the list of the 50 largest industrial corporations in the world last year, according to a ranking compiled by Fortune magazine and released today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NAMING OF SHINN PRAISED BY M.A.C.
description: Officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday viewed as positive and hopeful the expected appointment of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company president, Richard R. Shinn, to head a management overhaul of the city, but they said this move by Mayor Beame would not deter them from initiating their own management review of city government.

title: Authors Call on Byrne To Bar Royalties Tax
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)A group of New Jersey authors called on Governor Byrne today to reject a tax package that would tax royalties from their publications.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two tractor trailers loaded with color TV sets, electrical appliances and drygoods valued at $110,000 were stolen from the Pilot Freight Carriers, Inc., terminal 4940 New Maspeth Avenue in Maspeth, Queens, by three men, two of whom were armed with revolvers. They kicked and handcuffed the security guard, Vincent Scuderi, 46 years old, stole his car and ransacked the freight offices. Several hours later the trailers were found in different sections of Brooklyn with their cargoes intact. The police found the guard handcuffed to a pipe in the bathroom. His car was recovered nearby.

title: Maureen O'Neill, Cornell '75, Is Married to Floyd Weinstock
description: Maureen ONeill, daughter of Michael J. O'Neill, editor of The Daily News, and Mrs. O'Neill of Scrasdale, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to Floyd Weinstock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Weinstock of White Plains.

title: Lawyer Weds Diane B. Cohn
description: Diane Beth Cohn and David Franklin Zorensky, graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married yesterday afternoon at the Pierce House in Lincoln, Mass. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Zev Nelson.

title: NEW SPONSOR SET FOR BOOK AWARDS
description: The National Institute of Arts and Letters has taken over the sponsorship of two major literary rrogramsthe National Book Awards and the National Medal for Literature, which carries a cash prize of $10,000.

title: Papers Show U.S. Considered Ousting Rhee in Korean War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Newly declassified documents show that the United States gave highlevel consideration during the Korean war to staging a coup against President Syngman Rhee of South Korea.

title: Minnesota Six Wins
description: ALLEGHE, Italy, Aug. 3 (AP)The University of Minnesota hockey team defeated a local Italian squad, 72, last night in the first of a series of games in Italy.

title: MRS. GANDHI PLANS RETROACTIVE LAW TO CLEAR HER CASE
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 3  The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has drafted retroactive legislation that would end her personal entanglement with the courts by changing the election laws under which she was convicted in June of improper practices.

title: HorseShow Awards
description: AT DARIEN, CONN,

title: No Sunday Dent Made In PiledUp Garbage
description: Because sanitation employes do no work on Sunday, none of the 3,500 tons of garbage that has gone uncollected on the city's streets was picked up yesterday.

title: 188 on Charter Jet Killed In Moroccan Crash in Fog
description: AGADIR, Morocco, Aug. 3A chartered jetliner carrying Moroccan workers from France to their homeland for summer vacations crashed into a mountainside in heavy fog early today, killing all 188 people aboard, authorities said.

title: Polls and Pressures
description: Not since General Sherman's famous repudiation has a politician renounced a Presidential candidacy in such flat, forthright, unequivocal terms as Senator Edward M. Kennedy did nearly a year ago: I will not accept the nomination. I will not accept a draft. I will oppose any effort to place my name in nomination. . . . And I will oppose any effort to promote my candidacy any other way. That statement, clear enough to have won the acceptance of the most cynical, has since been reinforced, most recently again last week.

title: R. O. BLOOD, 87, DIES IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 3 (AP)Dr. Robert O. Blood, a family doctor and dairy farmer who was twice elected Governor of New Hampshire, died this morning in a nursing home here. He was 87 years old.

title: Caramoor
description: Perhaps inspired by the past success of Benjamin Britten's parable operas staged outdoors in the Spanish Courtyard, the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N.Y., presented a somewhat similar entertainment Saturday night, the world premiere of The Last Lover with music by Robert Starer and a text by Gail Godwin.

title: Most Wall Streeters Optimistic on Market
description: The recent decline in the stock market is viewed as a temporary correction by most Wall Street analysts, who expect prices mostly to advance during the next two months.

title: 5 Cent Staten Island Fare Sails Into History
description: Sam Marino stood at the entrance to the Staten Island Ferry terminal at the Battery yesterday with a light meter poised over a big, bold, new sign. Effective 12:01 A.M., Monday, Aug. 4, 1975, Fare 25c, the sign said and Mr. Marino, camera in hand, recorded the date of the death of the famed nickel fare.

title: Superdom e Dedicated Amid Superlatives
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 3 The Louisiana Superdome, newest and grandest of the nation's sports palaces, was opened to the public today 10 years after it first gleamed in a New Orleans promoter's eye.

title: Jury at Gurney Trial Returns Some Verdicts but Not Others
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 4On the eighth day of deliberations, a Federal Court jury at the trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney and three codefendants returned some verdicts today and declared itself unable to reach others. The verdicts were not made pnblic.

title: G.M.'s Korea Unit Linked To $250,000 Political Gift
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The General Motors Corporation's joint ventures in South Korea made a political contribution in 1972 of $250,000, which they say was made on behalf of General Motors Korea, it was disclosed today.

title: Statue of Hadrian Is Found in Israel By a N. Y. Broker
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 A New York stockbroker armed with an electronic mine detector and a Boy Scout knife recently stumbled upon one of the rarest and most valuable finds of the archeological season here: a lifesize, magnificently carved bronze statue, of Emperor Hadrian, dating from the second century.

title: A LIQUOR LICENSE FOR POLICE VETOED
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that Would have permitted the issuance of a liquor license to a club whose members are active police officers.

title: 21 Triumph Is 11th for Yank Pitcher
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 Billy Martin, shirtless, looked up from the stool in front of his locker, a dreamy look in his eve.

title: Banks With Officers on Blue Cross and Blue Shield Boards Use Their Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Mill?? of dollars in Federal ?? private funds entrusted to Blue Cross and Blue Shield are being channeled through banks with officers who sit on the health organizations' boards.

title: An Executive Is Appointed By Times News Service
description: Sam Summerlin, an editor for the Associated Press, has been appointed to the new position of assistant editor and assistant general manager of The New York Times News Service.

title: TRANSIT AIDE ASKS TAX ON EMPLOYERS
description: John G. de Roos chief operating officer of the Transit Authority, suggested yesterday that a transportation tax paid by employers could go far toward ending the persistent threat of everhigher transit fares.

title: Paul Says Key to Signing Is Bonus Issue
description: Cleon Jones, the rebel outfielder of the New York Mets, became a free agent officially yesterday and said it looks pretty good that he might soon surface again in Shea. Stadiumthis time in the uniform of the Yankees.

title: HangGliders Taking Exhilarating Flights at Yosemite
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 3Dawn In Yosemite Valley. Sunlight spills into the misty chasm of rock ledges. The dark granite faces of El Capitan and Half Dome brighten to a smooth metallic finish.

title: Illegal Intelligence
description: Viewed separately as isolated incidents, each violation of the laws and every incursion into a citizen's privacy by this country's foreign and domestic intelligence agencies may seem of limited importance and perhaps even excusable. As a longdeveloping pattern, these actions are highly disconcerting. The cumulative impact, and the difficulty of stopping them and preventing their recurrence, threatens to distort the relationship between ordinary Americans and their government.

title: Destroyer Costs Increased
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 4 (AP)  The Navy announced today a $280.2million increase in the target price for 30 new destroyers. This will increase the cost of each ship by $9.3million to a new level of about $69million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor

title: 1.09 Million Shares of Apco Tendered to Northwest
description: The Northwest Energy Company of Salt Lake City announced yesterday that at the close of business Friday, a total of 1.09 million shares of the Apco Oil Corporation had been tendered to the company. Both Northwest Energy and the Alaska Interstate Company of Houston are competing to buy Apco Oil. Each, is looking to buy 1.5 million shares. Northwest Energy is offering $25 a share and Alaska Interstate $23.50 a share.

title: Kunstler Jailed for Two Hours For Contempt at Little Trial
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug 4William M. Kunstler, the activist lawyer, spent two hours behind the bars of the Wade County jail here today after he appeared at the Joan Little trial lust long enoughabout five minutesto provoke the presiding judge by questioning the quality of North Carolina justice.

title: People in Sports
description: Although they have not approached him yet, the Texas Rangers are considering Bill Virdon for a spot in their organization, but not as field manager. Virdon, who was dropped by the New York Yankees on Saturday with more than a year left on his contract as manager, is being considered by Brad Corbett, the majority owner of the Rangers, as director of player development. He would work with Dan O'Brien, the general manager, in assessingyoung talent and making trades.

title: U.S. ISSUE PRICES SAG TO NEW LOWS
description: The prospect of higher interest rates, coupled with a lack of buying demand, pushed down prices of fixedincome securities yesterday. The three issues sold in last week's Treasury auctions amounting to $5.8billion all marked new lows in price. Corporate bonds, acting in sympathy to the pressure in the Government market, moved lower. Declines of onehalf point, or $5 per $1,000 bond, were commonplace.

title: FLIP PHILLIPS PLAYS WITH MELLOW TONES
description: Eighteen years ago Flip Phillips, the tenor saxophonist who was a star in Woody Herman's powerhouse band of the midnineteenforties and later spent nine years locked in musical combat with other saxophonists on Jazz at the Philharmonic concert tours, settled in Pompan Beach, Fla., where he has done most of his playing ever since. He appeared here at the Newport Jazz Festival three years ago, but his current engagement at Michael's Pub is the first time since he left for Florida that he has been here for more than one night.

title: BEAME DISCOUNTS NEED FOR REVIEW OF CITY BY M.A.C.
description: Mayor Beame indicated yesterday that he felt his soontobeformed management council, intended to make economies in city government, would remove the need for a similar panel to be set up by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: TRAFFIC LIMITED IN GARMENT AREA
description: New traffic and parking regulations, aimed at speeding deliveries by reducing congestion, went into effect in the garment center yesterday.

title: Jersey Woman Dies of Heat On Chair Covered With Foil
description: A 26yearold South Platia, field, N. J., woman apparentlydied of heat exhaustion Saturday after having fallen asleep in 96degree temperature on a lounge chair covered with aluminum foil.

title: HangGliders Talking Exhilarating Flights at Yosemite
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 3Dawn in Yosemite Valley. Sunlight spills into the misty chasm of rock ledges. The dark granite faces of El Capitan and Half Dome brighten to a smooth metallic finish.

title: KICKBACK CHARGES MADE AGAINST LENT
description: MINEOLA, Aug. 4Matthew Bonora, Democratic candidate for Presiding Supervisor in the Town of Hempstead, today charged Representative Norman F. Lent, a Republican, with telling a town employe that he would lose his job unless he paid I per cent of his salary to the Republican party.

title: Plan for Convention Center Here Jeopardized by City's Fiscal Ills
description: After six years of planning and controversy, and despite the commitment of two city administrations, proposals to build a major convention and exhibition center on Manhattan's Hudson River waterfront have been plunged into jeopardy by the city's fiscal crisis.

title: JOHN CLOUGH, LED FAIRCHILD CAMERA
description: John H. Clough, president or the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation frorri 1950 to 1957 and of the General Electric Xray Corporation from 1933 to 1950, died Friday in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Legislative Panel Renews Plea To Ease Marijuana Penalties
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 (AP)A legislative commission recommended again today that possession of small amounts of marijuana be decriminalized.

title: Ailing Bold Forbes Out for Six Weeks
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4Bucked shins, a common ailment that temporarily sidelines most young thoroughbreds at one time or another, will keep undefeated Bold Forbes out of action for about six weeks. According to his trainer, Laz Barrera, the Puerto Ricanowned 2yearold colt suffered the injury during his easy eightlength victory in yesterday's 73d running of the Saratoga Special. Bold Forbes ran the six furlongs in 1:09 4/5, a stakes record for the Special at Saratoga.

title: MISSISSIPPI VOTING IS SET FOR TODAY
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 4 Mississippi's voters will go to the polls tomorrow to choose among six Democratic contenders for Governor, one of whom Will meet a strong Republican candidate in November. The state is one of only two that will elect Governors this year, the other being Kentucky.

title: Heats
description: Little did Victor Gosworth suspect, as he knotted his necktie for a refreshing postconjugal stroll along Central Park West that he was about to become the first victim of a savagery that would gross more than $19 million in a mere five weeks at the box office.

title: HELEN M. GERSON
description: Helen Movshovitz Gerson, a dentist in the Bronx for 25 years and a leader in the county dental society, died Saturday. Mrs. Gerson, who practiced under her maiden name, was 91 years old and lived at 8860 18th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Machine Age At Jet Camp
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 4 Besides liniment and shoulder pads and size15 shoes, the Jets' training camp offers a magical assortment of Tinker Toys for grownup children.

title: '51 Shot Is Heard Round '75 Clubhouses
description: Although it is almost 24 years since Bobby Thomson hit a home, run in the Polo Grounds to give the New York Giants themost dramatic pennant in baseball history, the memory of the 1951 season is being consciously kept alive in several major league clubhouses these days.

title: A Canadian Cold Front Breaks Heat Wave Here With Storms,
description: A Canadian cold front carrying thunderstorms and gusty winds veered over the metropolitan area before dawn yesteriday and broke the grip of a sweltering heat wave that had oppressed the region with 90degree temperatures for four days.

title: PHYSICIANS DRAFT ARBITRATION PLAN
description: The Medical Society of the State of New York said yesterday that it planned to begin a system of arbitration between physicians and patients undergoing operations, in an effort to avert a new series of malpractice rate increases.

title: Brief Says Mitchell Got Silbert Warning Of Indictment in '73
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell was told by Earl J. Silbert as early as April, 1973, that he would be indicted, according to Mr. Mitchell's appeal brief in the Watergate coverup conviction. Mr. Silbert was then principal Assistant United States Attorney here and leader of the threeman Watergate investigation team.

title: General Motors Keeps Its Reduced Dividend
description: DETROIT, Aug. 4 (UPI)Despite an almost 9 per cent jump in secondquarter profits, directors of the General Motors Corporation voted today to pay a third straight reduced quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share.

title: Clam Broth House Sold For 2d Time Since '99
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 4For the second time since it opened in 1899, the Clam Broth House, famous for its steamers and suds, is changing hands. The new owner of the venerable waterfront restaurant on the corner of Newark and River Streets is Arthur Palaez., a 6foot 3inch Cuban who began working as a waiter there 20 years ago, rose to become manager and already is referred to locally as Mr. Clam Broth.

title: THREAT TO HOFFA IN '74 IS REPORTD
description: DETROIT, Aug. 4A former teamster rebel said today that James R. Hoffa told him last year that Anthony Provenzano had threatened the safety of Mr. Hoffa and his family in connection with Mr. Hoffa's drive to regain the presidency of the teamsters' union.

title: McGovern Won't Run; Key Advisers Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, says he will not make another bid for the Presidency but would accept the nomination if it were offered to him.

title: John Baragrey, Actor, Is Dead; Star in Broadway Enchanted
description: John Baragrey, an actor on Broadway and in many television dramas, died yesterday at his home, 21 West 16th Street. He was 57 years old.

title: POWER CUTBACKS CALLED UNLIKELY
description: So far this summer, the Consolidated Edison Company has not been forced to imposevoltage reductions on its custorriers and the utility's officials believe that there is a reasonably good chance that It will not have to.

title: You've Got the Swaps Filly
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4If I had about eight more like Bobby, a prominent horse trainer was saying here yesterday, life would be easy.

title: Recent Mexican Oil Finds Put Pemex in the Black
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4 (AP)Two new fields discovered last year in Chiapas and Tabasco in southern Mexico, have produced a total of 100 million barrels of crude oil in the past 12 months, an official report said today.

title: Major Trouble Shooter
description: Five years ago this month, telephone service in New York City was poor and getting worse. The New York Telephone Company had badly misjudged the city's rate of growth. Thousands of customers and wouldbe customers were demanding help. Telephone men knew they were on the spot and had to do something fast. So they named William Maurice Ellinghaus, a 48yearold executive vice president of the parent American Telephone & Telegraph Company to be president of New York Telephone Company.

title: An Uneasy Racial Peace Prevails Amid Recession
description: Depressed economic condi tions in the central cities, believed to have been among the major causes of riots and mass demonstrations in the nineteensixtids and early nineteenseventies, have been described by some authorities this summer as worse than at any time in the last decade.

title: Court Limits Committing Of the Criminally Insane
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the criminally insane could not be confined to mental institutions against their will unless they had been judged dangerous to themselves or others.

title: . . . Action Is Needed
description: To achieve these and other persuasive objectives, the commission favors an agency that would function within the two states' coastal zone programs, composed of Federal, state, local and regional representatives along with those of private citizens; groups. The report argues that this is preferable to a new bistate authority, which would take years to set up and be funded and which would then be dependent on legislatures rather than the affected communities. Two separate state agencies would be even less satisfactory; and to leave the whole program to the individual local governments, each moved by its own interests, would be to invite paralysis.

title: U.S Court Finds Bar's Gag Rule On News Invalid
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today ruled unconstitutional the American Bar Association's (code of professional responsibility, which prohibits lawyers from discussing some aspects of legal cases with newsmen.

title: JOSEPH L. RODGERS
description: Joseph L. Rodgers, general manager of the packaging division of the Union Carbide Corporation, died of cancer yesterday in Somerset Hospital, Somerville, N. J. He was 60 years old and lived at 795 Ross Lane, Bound Brook, N. J.

title: Being First Lady Is Practically a 24HouraDay Job
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 4 (AP) Betty Ford says that her first year in the White House has been exciting, even though it was marked by illness and occasional loneliness, and that she has gained confidence in her ability to meet the demands of being the President's wife.

title: Flight Recorder Is Sought In Moroccan Plane Crash
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco, Aug. 4 (Reuters)  A commission of inquiry today began searching the wreckage of a chartered Jordanian Boeing 707 that crashed near Agadir yesterday, killing all 188 people on board.

title: Rep. Pike Angry as C.I.A. Bars Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence complained angrily today that the Central Intelligence Agency and other units of the executive branch were withholding information that his panel needed to advance its inquiry into the Federal intelligence community.

title: Nadia Potts Is a Stylish and Distinctive OdetteOdile
description: Three of the ballerinas of the National Ballet of Canada are dancing OdetteOdile in Erik Bruhn's staging of Swan Lake at the Metropolitan Opera House this summerKaren Kain, Vanessa Harwood and lastly Nadia Potts, who appeared in the ballet for the first time this season Sunday night, partnered, like her two sister swans, by Rudolf Nureyev.

title: Northwest Airlines Shut Down  By a Walkout of 1,550 Pilots
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 4 (AP) The Air Line Pilots Association struck Northwest Airlines in a contract dispute today despite 11thhour efforts by the Federal Government's top labor troubleshooter.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: An Uneasy Racial Peace Prevails Amid Recession
description: Depressed economic conditions in the central cities, believed to have been among the major causes of riots and mass demonstrations in the nineteensixties and early nineteenseventies, have been described by some authorities this summer as worse than at any time in the last decade.

title: Ford Nettles Beame In Telling Yugoslavs City Is Fiscally Inept
description: President Ford made some critical remarks about New York yesterday during a meeting with the city fathers of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, but before the day was out, Mayor Beame and City Council President Paul O'Dwyer got in a few licks of their own.

title: State Moves to Foreclose Mortgage on Coop City
description: State housing officials began court action yesterday to foreclose the $436million mortgage of Coop City in the Bronx, the nation's largest apartment development, where most of the tenant  cooperators have been refusing to pay a 25 per cent increase in monthly maintenance charges.

title: Heat Wave Parching Vast Areas of Europe
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Northern Europe is experiencing its hottest and driest summer in years.

title: The Khrushchev/ Brezhnev Doctrine at Helsinki
description: No less a politician and statesman than British Prime Minister Harold Wilson seemed to take seriously Leonid I. Brezhnev's talk about noninterference in other country's affairs at last week's Helsinki conference.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 4 (AP)A settlement of all claims and counterclaims involving Jane Blalock and her legal fight with the Ladies Professional Golf Association was announced today. The L.P.G.A. had appealed the case a year ago after Miss Blalock had been awarded damages of $4,500. She contended she might have won that amount had she been allowed to play in the Lady Carling tournament in Baltimore in 1972. She had been suspended by the L.P.G.A., which alleged she cheated in a tournament.

title: MRS. PERON BACK AT WORK IN OFFICE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4President Isabel Martinez de Perlin returned to her office today after two weeks.

title: PRESCRIPTIONS CUT BY MEDICAID TRIMS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 (AP)It has become nearly impossible to have a prescription filled under Medicaid in many New Jersey cities as pharmacies, protesting cutbacks in fee schedules, have dropped out of the program.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: DETAINED IN INDIA ARE PUT AT 55,000
description: LONDON, Aug. 4At least 50,000 to 60,000 people have been seized in India since Prime Minister Indira Gandhi imposed a state of emergency five weeks ago, according to opponents of Mrs. Gandhi and Indians who have recently left New Delhi.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In yesterday's Going Out Guide column, the address of the St. Agnes Branch of the New York Public Library was listed incorrectly. The branch, where a performance of Joan of Lorraine will be given on Aug. 18 at 7 P.M., is at 444 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CRIME RATE STIRS HONG KONG ANGER
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 4To New Yorkers, hardened by years of rising crime rates, the incidents might not have seemed unusual:

title: 3 at Helm in Comoros
description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, Aug. 4 (Reuters)A triumvirate headed by a former member of the French Senate took over control today of the Comoro archipelago, in the Indian ocean off southern Africa, following a bloodless coup yesterday. The three are expected to seek uni ty in the islands and close ties with France, which ruled them until four weeks ago when the parliament of the islands unilaterally declared independence.

title: Blimp Buffeted by Storm
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 4 (AP)  One of the Goodyear blimps ran, into trouble this evening when it encountered an unexpectedly severe thunderstorm blowing through upstate New York. The blimp, America, was caught by high winds and heavy rain in its trip froth Windsor, Vt., to Syracuse.

title: INDIA INTRODUCES ELECTORAL BILL
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 4Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government today introduced legislation that would nullify the court action pending against her and prevented the Indian press from publishing full accounts of the move.

title: Giants' Rookie End Plays Name Game
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 4Ed O'Bradovich to the lobby, a voice piped over the intercom today in the New York Giants' dormitory at Pace University.

title: Jackson, in City, Invites 1976 Support
description: Senator Henry Jackson of Washington made what he called a political reconnaissance through New York yesterday, bringing to politicians and the press a softsell message that the man with the money up front was the man to watch for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: KAREL BOSSART, 71, CONVAIR ENGINEER
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 4 (AP)Karel J. Bossart, retired technical director of the Convair division of the General Dynamics Corporation, who was project engineer in the program that produced the Atlas rocket, died yesterday at his home here. He was 71 years old.

title: Bayh Forms a Committee To Study Nomination Race
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana has formed a committee to determine whether he should seek the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination, it was disclosed today.

title: Fed Is Urged to Allow Faster Money Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The chairman of the House Banking Committee called on the Federal Reserve Board today to allow the nation's money supply to grow somewhat more rapidly than its targeted upper limit of 7.5 per cent.

title: Americans at Peking Dinner
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 4 (UPI)Chou Chiuyeh, vice president of China's Institute of Foreign Affairs, held a dinner in Peking today for a visiting United States Congressional delegation, Hsinhua the Chinese press agency, reported. The delegation, which arrived in Peking today, includes Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York and Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EASY DOES IT You might wonder what's behind the door of a place calling itself the Pink Poodle. The answer is Travis Washington, a pianist who sings old favorites with smiling relish, to his own unfrilly accompaniment. Does any other entertainer in town do Sally of My Dreams, a ballad that vanished decades ago?

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Bluechip and glamour issues led another decline in the stock market yesterday in the lightest trading of the year. Investors remained uncertain over the prospects for another upturn in the rate of inflation.

title: Dollar Moves Down In Trading Abroad; Gold Also Declines
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 4 (UPI)The dollar lost today some of its recently gained strength on European money markets. At the same time the British pound began another bad week, hitting a third record low in as many trading days.

title: Ford Returns Optimistic
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) President Ford returned from a 10day, fivenation trip to Europe tonight encouraged and optimistic after discussions on arms limitation with the Soviet Union and talks seeking peace in the Middle East.

title: Solomon Is Upset By Plotz in 3 Sets
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP)HansJoachim Plotz of West Germany upset sixthseeded Harold Solomon of Silver Spring. Md., today, 62, 46, 64, in the first round of the $100,000 New Hampshire international tennis tournament.

title: CALIFORNIA TRIMS HIGHWAY BUILDING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4A 20 per cent reduction in highway construction and maintenance staff was announced today by the California Department of Transportation.

title: INSURERS MOVING TO INCREASE RATES ON CARS AND HOMES
description: The nation's fire and casualty insurance companies, their profits whittled last year by inflation and losses on their investments, raised their rates substantially during the first half of the year on millions of home and automoblie insurance policies. And company executives, citing a worsening profit trend this year, say that steeper rate increases are in prospect.

title: In Memoriam
description: FELSHMANClaudia, October 21, 1966August 4, 1974. Happy Anniversary in Heaven. So young and so beautiful. Only God knows why. Through the tears and heartache our hearts are filled with such precious memories. Though we are heaven and earth apart you shall live In our hearts until the day we will be together again.

title: Paper in Cairo Reports A Coup in Libya Foiled
description: CAIRO, Aug. 4 (AP)An attempted coup against the Libyan strongman, Col. Muammar elQaddafi was crushed last week and its leader arrested, the Cairo daily alGomhouriya said today.

title: Statue of Hadrian Is Found in Israel By a N. Y. Broker
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4  A New York stockbroker armed with an electronic mine detector and a Boy Scout knife recently stumbled upon one of the rarest and most valuable finds of the archeological season here: a lifesize, magnificently carved bronze statue of Emperor Hadrian, dating from the second century.

title: Fiat 500 Production Ends
description: TURIN, Italy, Aug. 4 (UPI)Fiat announced today the demise at age 18 of Italy's smallest automobile, the Fiat 500. A Fiat spokesman said the last of the more than four million cinquecentos produced since 1957 rolled off the assembly line Friday.
