The 500 is being replaced by the Flat 126, a slightly bigger minicar introduced in 1972.

title: Shell Geothermal Well Holds Commercial Outlook
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) The Shell Oil Company said today an exploratory well in the Geysers area of northern California indicated commercial guantities of steam.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1975

title: INSANE CRIMINALS WIN NEW RIGHTS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the criminally insane could not be confined to mental institutions against their will unless they had been judged dangerous to themselves or others.

title: 2 Indicted in Inquiry Into Police Sergeants Club
description: A lieutenant and a retired sergeant, both 20year veterans of the Police Department, were indicted yesterday on charges they had lied to a special grand jury investigating graft in a Queens precinct.

title: Hughes Spruce Goose Safe for Another Year
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 4 (AP)Howard R. Hughes's giant wooden seaplane, known as the Spruce Goose, was saved from the wreckers today when the harbor commission voted to extend its hangar leas efor another year.

title: TRANSIT AIDE ASKS TAX ON EMPLOYERS
description: John G. de Roos chief operating officer of the Transit Authority, suggested yesterday that a transportation tax paid by employers could go far toward ending the persistent threat of everhigher transit fares.

title: NuisanceTax Bills Are Signed By Byrne, Ending Fiscal Crisis
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4Governor Byrne today privately signed the last portion of a $257million package of nuisance taxes that he once said he would never accept, thus apparently signaling the end of the state's budget crisis and the Governor's drive for tax reform, at least until late next fall.

title: Books of The Times
description: Because Robert Nozick's Anarchy, State, and Utopia was published late last year, won the 1975 National Book Award in the category of Religion and Philosophy and has been attended to respectfully in such politically diverse publications as Forbes magazine and The New York Review of Books, something should be known by now of the book and its author. It should be known that Mr. Nozick is a 36year  old philoso phy professor at Harvard, and that he got there by way of Columbia, where he founded the local chapter of the Student League for Industrial Democracy (the socialist organization that in 1962 became Students for a Demcratic Society). It should be known that, surprisingly, his study mounts a major philosophic challenge to any form of paternalistic government that forbids capitalist acts between consenting adults. (In fact, it tries to show that although the protective nightwatchman state conceived by classical liberal philosophy can be evolved from a theoretical state of nature without anyone's natural rights being violated, no more extensive a state than that minimal one can possibly be justified.) It should be known, in short, that 19thcentury liberalism lives again, and that even Washingtonwhere liberalism is deader than deadis reading all about it (the book, I am told, is being devoured by speechwriters in the Ford Administration).

title: Monetary Summit: U.S.European Split
description: PARIS, Aug. 4A year after President Ford organized his domestic summit conference to bring bold ideas into play for reviving the American economy. France, supported by West Germany, is trying to promote an international summit to get the world monetary system working better. While the United States has not ruled out such a new meeting, it sees less value in it than its European partners.

title: People and Business
description: Baxter Freese, chairman of the Agricultural Council of America, which is made up of farmer and agribusiness groups, charged yesterday that critics of the recent large Soviet grain purchases were using them as a trumped up excuse for raising consumer prices.

title: Bridge
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 4Two littleknown young experts from the Middle West made a strong bid for national honors in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today.

title: State Moves to Foreclose Mortgage on Coop City
description: State housing officials began court action yesterday to foreclose the $436million mortgage of Coop City in the Bronx, the nation's largest apartment development, where most of the tenant  cooperators have been refusing to pay a 25 per cent increase in monthly maintenance charges.

title: Living in New York: 2 Single Women Find Opportunityand Fear
description: Janet Kole and Susan Ball reside a few blocks from the Bowery. That fact has made anxiety slip around their lives like a back brace and reminds them constantly that the line between making it and not making it, between living and dying, is very thin indeed.

title: Benoit Frachon, French Leader In Communist Party, 82, Dead
description: Benoit Frachon, once a pow erful figure in the French trade union movement and a member of the Communist party's Central Committee for almost 50 years, died yesterday in Paris at the age of 82. He had been secretary general of the Confederation Generale du Travail (C.G.T.), the largest national union in the country, from 1945 to 1967.

title: U.S. SAFETY RULES ATTACKED BY ABEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4I. W. Abel, president of the United Steel Workers of America, acbused the Ford Administration of playing politics with the lives of cokeoven workers in the nation's steel plants.

title: Ford to Use Catalytic Converters on All Its Models
description: DETROIT, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company, whose decision a year ago largely to avoid catalytic converters cost it heaviy in the competition over mileage claims, is changing over all its models to catalytic converters for 1976.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In yesterday's Going Out Guide column, the address of the St. Agnes Branch of the New York Public Library was listed incorrectly. The branch, where a performance of Joan of Lorraine will be given on Aug. 18 at 7 P.M., is at 444 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: City Hospitals to Get Delafield's Equipment
description: Seymour Kleinberg, supervisor of the chemistry laboratory at Fordham Hospital in the Bronx, wandered eagerly through Francis Delafield Hospital in Washington Heights yesterday with a thick roll of gummed labels unfurling about his legs.

title: NUISANCE TAXES SIGNED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4Governor Byrne today privately signed the last portion of a $257million package of nuisance taxes that he once said he would never accept, thus apparently signaling the end of the state's budget crisis and the Governor's drive for tax reform, at least until late next fall.

title: City to Oust New Workers Hired Under U.S. Program
description: City officials last night prepared letters of dismissal to 1,160 recently hired employes in a federally financed publicservice job program who had performed work similar to that of dismissed civil servants.

title: EXPERT TESTIFIES ON KENT STATE FILM
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 (UPI)Three students at Kent State University were within 85 feet of Ohio National Guardsmen when the troops opened fire in a May 4, 1970, campus antiwar disturbance, according to Robert A. Johnson, a film expert.

title: Lisbon's Left Wing Feels Impaled on Satiric Barbs
description: LISBON, Aug. 4Every night Portuguese crowd into Lisbon's main theater to hear nostalgic music, racy bourgeois jokes and sharp satire against the Communist party.

title: School Spending Law Is Signed by Byrne
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 (AP)A bill designed to assure the state value for its dollar in Newark's public schools was signed today by Governor Byrne.

title: Boeing Reports Profit and Sates Gains
A BATTLE LOOMING OVER TACKS VOTE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4A major battle appears to be shaping up among the Delaware River Valley states over whether to deauthorize or defer the $400million Tocks Island darn project.

title: BEAME DISCOUNTS NEED FOR REVIEW OF CITY BY M.A.C.
description: Mayor Beame indicated yesterday that he felt his soontobeformed management council, intended to make economies in city government, would remove the need for a similar panel to be set up by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: STEEL OUTPUT ROSE 0.2% FROM WEEK AGO
description: Steel production for the week ended Aug. 2 moved upward following a oneweek decline the American Iron and Stec?? Institute reported in Washington yesterday.

title: Belgian Cost Index Is Called Inflation Spur
description: BRUSSELSIn Belgium, where a lot of importance is placed on keeping economic and social life running smoothly despite the frequent political breakdowns, nothing works more smoothly than the costofliving compensation system.

title: Bentsen Asks U. S. To Grant Priority To Israel on Trade
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 4Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, last night called onl the United States to grant Israel preferential treatment in trade agreements to counteract the Arab boycott.

title: Where Craftsmen Pursue Philosophy and an Almost Monastic Life
description: MIDDLESEX, N.Y.Scott Goewey, who once made 15cent hamburgers at his own highway stand, now makes $300 porcelain vases for the Rochester Folk Art Guildelegant vases, sometimes carved, sometimes richly glazed, but never signed with his own name.

title: Henry L. Reese, 65, Dies; Played Football for Giants
description: OCEAN CITY, N.J. Aug. 4 (AP)Henry L. (Hank) Reese, a football player with the Philadelphia Eagles and New York Giants, died yesterday of a heart attack while on vacation here. He was 65 years old.

title: DR. YUDEL MARK DIES; 4 LEXICOGRAPHER, 77
description: Dr. Yudel Mark, a leading Yiddish lexicographer and editor in chief of The Great Dictionary of the Yiddish Language since 1953, died Friday of a stroke on a visit to Wilmington, Del. He was 77 years old and lived in Jerusalem and formerly in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Ilya Salkind, coproducer with his father, Alexander Salkind, of The Three Musketeers and its sequel, The Four Musketeers, said that Mario Puzo had completed rough draft of the script of Superman, which will be made by the Salkinds' independent company, Film Trust, starting in Hollywood and New York early next year. The script, Mr. Salkind said, is a straight, not campy, story and one in which Superman will be romantically involved with Lois Lane, his reportercolleague.

title: Living in New York: 2 Single Women Find Opportunityand Fear
description: Janet Kole and Susan Ball reside a few blocks from the Bowery. That fact has made anxiety slip around their lives like a back brace and reminds them constantly that the line between making it and not making it, between living and dying, is very thin indeed.

title: Ford Nettles Beame In Telling Yugoslays City Is Fiscally Inept
description: President Ford made some critical remarks about New York yesterday during a meeting with the city fathers of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, but before the day was out, Mayor Beame and City Council President Paul O'Dwyer got in a few licks of their own.

title: Connecticut Poultry Losses
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 4 (AP) Poultry farmers in eastern Connecticut lost 85,000 birds worth $300,000 because of last weekend's extreme heat and the Federal government should declare that part of the state a disaster area, Gov. Ella T. Grasso said Monday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Credit Card Money By Telephone Is Set
description: The Western Union Corporation announced yesterday that sending money orders by telephone was now possible through an arrangement with Master Charge, the credit card concern.

title: Expos Win, 43Tate NoHit Bid Fails
description: Randy Tate, the 22yearold rookie righthander for the New York Mets, pitched a nohitter against the Montreal Expos last night for 7 1/3 innings. Then in the space of 10 maddening minutes, he lost the nohitter and the game when the Expos exploded with four runs for 4.3 victory.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
INSURERS MOVING TO INCREASE RATES ON CARS AND HOMES
description: The nation's fire and casualty insurance companies, their profits whittled last year by inflation and losses on their investments, raised their rates substantially during the first half of the year on millions of home and automobile insurance policies. And company executives, citing a worsening profit trend this year, say that steeper rate increases are in prospect.

title: It's Always Rodgers & Musical Time
description: Wherever he turns, Richard Rodgers can hear the sound of his music.

title: Bolivian Miners in Walkosut
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 4 (Reuters)Five thousand tin miners in Catavi and Siglo Veinte, 210 miles southeast of here, staged a 24hour strike today to demand an amnesty for political prisoners to mark Bolivia's 150th anniversary on Wednesday.

title: To Save the Sound...
description: Five years after Congress asked the New England River Basins Commission to study the problems of Long Island Sound and make recommendations for its environmental improvement, that agency has issued its report. It is admirable for its analysis of the haphazard development that has polluted the waters of the sound and marred its beaches. Its proposals for undoing the damage and enhancing the quality of life on northern Long Island and southern Connecticut are eminently sensible. Only its scheme for implementing those proposals leaves one with a feeling of doubt.

title: U.S. Camps Have Sent Out Nearly Half of Refugee
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., Aug. 4 (AP)Nearly half the Indochinese refugees who fled to the United States during the fall of South Vietnam and Cambodia have been processed out of the four domestic relocation camps, according to the United States Army.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DRIFT DOWNWARD
description: In a dull trading session, prices drifted lower on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The index closed at 88.68, off 0.55, as the volume totaled 1.3 million shares, little changed from Friday's pace.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Sharon Bovaird at Madison Avenue and 83d Street is the kind of neighborhood shop where a woman can assemble and accessorize an outfit between visits to the supermarket and cleaner. We try to do a look rather than a price, rays Miss Bovaird, coowner of the shop with her husband, Allen Klein.

title: Garbage Trucks Will Be Given Quotas; City Says Penalties Could Be Financial
description: Concerned over the continued backlog of uncollected garbage, Mayor Beane announced yesterday that productivity quotas would be assigned to each sanitation truck and that there will be penalties if the crews did not meet the quotas.

title: ADMIRAL SAID TO USE PLANE FOR ERRANDS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 4 (UPI)Vice Adm. Malcolm W. Cagle, retired, former commander of the Pensacola Naval Air Sation, used a Navy transport plane as his personal shuttle service, the St. Petersburg Times reported today.

title: London Observer Plans Cut In Its Staff to Stem Losses
description: LONDON, Aug. 4One of Britain's prestigious Sunday newspapers, The Observer, announced tonight that it would dismiss nearly a third of its staff this week in an effort to halt its mounting financial losses.

title: Bielfuss Wins at Billiards
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)Mark Bielfuss, a 16yearold player from. Grand Rapids, Mich., defeated Brian Asch, 15, of Hillside N.J., 15089, in 33 innings today to win the United States junior pocket billiards championship.

title: Jackson, in City, Invites Support for Presidency
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington made what he called a political reconnaissance through New York yesterday, bringing to politicians and the press a softsell message that the man with the money up front was the man to watch for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Crackdown Hits Calcutta, but the Poor Find Things the Same
description: CALCUTTA, India  City employes are corning to work on time. Streetcar fares are to he raised. But houses still collapse, cholera lingers, beggars swarm.

title: POLITICS CHARGED IN HIRING BY S.B.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Top officials of the Small Business Administration were illegally hired on the basis of political influence employed by Congressmen and the Nixon Administration, according to a Civil Service Commission report released today by a Congressional committee.

title: FORD OFFERS TITO VIEW ON MIDEAST
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 4President Ford, calling a Middle East stalemate nnacceptable, today urged moderation on President Tito of Yugoslavia and then flew home for apparently intensified efforts to obtain a new Sinai agreement.

title: Advertising
description: Twentyfour college students, all members of minority groups, are working this summer as interns at New York and Chicago advertising agencies.

title: PalestinianEgyptian Rift Opens Over Ousting Israel From U.N.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Aug. 4A rift has been opened between Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization over Egypt's unwillingness to back a resolution at the African leaders' conference in Kampala. Uganda, calling for the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations.

title: Market Place
description: The great bear market of the last five years was so devastating, so prolonged that all but the most patient investors gave up hope.

title: Medical Society Plans a System To Arbitrate Malpractice Claims
description: The Medical Society of the State of New York said yesterday that it planned to begin a system of arbitration between physicians and patients undergoing operations, in an effort to avert a new series of malpractice rate increases.

title: Incendiary Device Set Off At Venezualan Consulate
description: The Venezuelan Consulate was bombed shortly before midnight yesterday by a small incendiary device that shattered a plateglass window, according Ito the police.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two taxi drivers were shot and wounded last night in two separate incidents in which their passengers attempted to rob them. Kennedy Robinson, a 30yearold gypsy cab operator, was shot in the neck by one of two, passengers who fled from the cab at Evergreen Avenue and Covert Street in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. Mr. Robinson was in serious condition at Wyckoff Hospital.

title: U.S. Estimates Are Lower
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Administration officials estimated today that Mrs. Gandhi's Government has placed 20,000 to 30,000 citizens in detention during the last five weeks.

title: A Key Basque Rebel And 3 Spanish Nuns Reported Arrested
description: MADRID, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Spanish police arrested the nation's most wanted guerrilla and several accomplices last week in an abortive plot to free 40 political prisoners, the Governmentcontrolled Spanish television network reported today.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 1.5 million new common shares of Crocker National Corporation, at $22.50 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters, headed by Lehman Brothers.

title: ALABAMA SCORED ON WELFARE PLAN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 4A threejudge Federal Court has ordered a major revision of the Alabama welfare payment system to eliminate what it termed racially based unconstitutional disparities between aid to oldage pensioners and to families with dependent children.

title: POLITICS CHARGED IN HIRING BY S.B.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Top officials of the Small Business Administration were illegally hired on the basis of political influence employed by Congressmen and and the Nixon Administration, according to a Civil Service Commission report released today by a Congressional committee.

title: Notes on People
description: George S. Patton 3d was a West Point cadet when his father, the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr., led the Second Armored Division in North Africa in World War II. Yesterday the general's 51yearold only son, himself a major general, took command of the same division at Fort Hood, Texas. He succeeds Mai. Gen. Robert Leahy Fair.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Indians' Eckersley Defeats Tigers, 64
description: Dennis Lee Eckersley ?? ?? seasons with Reno in the California League. Last season he pitched for San Antonio in the Texas League where he won 14 games and lost three in 23 appearances.

title: THREAT TO HOFFA IN '74 IS REPORTED
description: DETROIT, Aug. 4A former teamster rebel said today that James R. Hoffa told him last year that Anthony Provenzano had threatened the safety of Mr. Hoffa and his family in connection with Mr. Hoffa's drive to regain the presidency of the teamsters' union.

title: Shark Scare Closes L.I. Beach 45 Minutes
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.T., Aug. 4As a result of a shark alert, some of the beaches here were temporarily closed to swimmers this past weekend for the first time in 10 years.

title: Beirut Reports Naval Fire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Aug. 5 (Agence FrancePresse) Four Lebanese officers were killed by fire from Israeli ships before dawn today, Beirut Radio said, giving a military spokesman as the source of the information. A fifth officer was wounded. The radio said Israeli launches bombarded a barracks at Tyre and a Palestian camp.

title: Chess
description: In the early days of queenpawn openings, it was feared that quick development of White's QB would leave the queenside unguarded, and that what we now know as the standard Queen's Gambit, 1 PQ4, PQ4; 2 PQB4, PK3; 3 NQB3, NKB3; 4 BN5, was thus too risky. Yet without that 4 BN5, White loses the opportunity for aggressive play and, consequently, the queenside openings took a back seat to 1 PK4.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCH

title: Convention Center Jeopardized
description: After six years of planning and controversy, and despite the commitment of two city administrations, efforts to build a major convention and ??hibition center on Manhattan's Hudson River vaterfront have been plunged into jeopardy by the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Impasse in Portugal
description: The ruling troika formed in Lisbon last month for the stated purpose of normalizing Portugal's political situation is proving a failure thus far. It has still been unable to produce a new cabinet to govern the country. Despite increasing resort to repressive action by the regime, activist antiCommunism at the grassroots level is underlining the determination of the vast majority of Portuguese not to become slaves of a Communist dictatorship.

title: Spectators Told to Testify On Court Escape Attempt
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered 12 spectators, including three lawyers, to testify before a grand jury that, is investigating how three selfdescribed members of the Black Liberation Army received weapons and explosives with which to escape from the Criminal Courts Building.

title: Cleon Jones Is Hopeful Of Becoming a Yankee
Portuguese of New Bedford Keep Identity
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 4The embroidered, tassled skull cap of the island of Madeira perched on her dark hair, a CocaCola in her hand, 13yearold Linda Barreto tapped her feet to the rhythm of the Princo, whose carved wooden dancing figures, mounted on a pole, make the sounds of castanets and tambourines.

title: Subway in Washington Won't Be Ready in '76
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Washington area subway system will not be ready for the millions of tourists expected in the nation's capital during the Bicentennial celebration because of an extended construction strike.

title: 2 Killed as Anti  Communist Violence Grows in Portugal
description: LISBON, Aug. 4Two persons died early today in a new flareup of antiCommunist violence while Portugal's armed forces continued to be beset by political paralysis.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Gaspe Salmon
description: MATANE, QuebecHeavy fog and intermittent rain greeted us as we drove East from Matane, allowing only intermittent glimpses of the Gaspe Peninsula's magnificent scenery, but there were compensations.

title: GOLD
description: Salaried world gold prices Monday. London: Morning fixing $166.35, down $0.40; afternoon fixing $166.50, down $0.25.

title: Futures Prices of Corn and Soybeans Show Sharp Increases
description: Rain came to Iowa, Illinois and some other Midwestern growing states over the weekend, but traders were not convinced the moisture was enough, especially in Iowa. As a result speculators yesterday pushed prices for corn ahead by as much as the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel.

title: RAIDERS HOLD 50 IN U.S. CONSULATE IN KUALA LUMPUR
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Tuesday, Aug. 5Japanese Red Army guerrillas who seized the American consulate here held about 50 hostages today while they awaited the arrival of comrades the Tokyo Government had agreed to free.

title: Heart Recipient Improving
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 4 (UPI)Glen Allen Wyatt, Medical College of Virginia's 11th heart transplant recipient, was in serious condition today but improving steadily, a hospital spokesman said. Mr. Wyatt, 20 years old, received his new heart in a fivehour operation last Thursday. Dr. Richard Lower, chief of thoracic and cardiovascular surgery at the hospital, headed the team of transplant surgeons.

title: New Lying Charge Denied By Tax Lawyer for Nixon
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon's tax lawyer pleaded not guilty today to an additional charge of lying to investigators about Mr. Nixon's 1970 gift of public papers to the United States Government.

title: President Is Named By B. Altman & Co.
description: B. Altman & Co. which had been looking for an executive vice president, has apparently decided to appoint a president instead. Yesterday it announced that John W. Christian currently president of the M. O'Neil Company of Akron, Ohio, will become president of Altman's on Sept. 8.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Political Fight Is Expected in the Capital Over New U.S.Soviet Arms Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Administration officials said today that they expected a political fight to develop here when a new accord with the Soviet Union on the limitation of strategic weapons is submitted to the Senate for approval.

title: Business Briefs
description: ARMONK, N.Y., Aug. 4 (UPI)MiraPak, Inc., and the International Business Machines Corporation jointly announced today the settlement of an antitrust suit brought by MiraPak against I.B.M. and two actions filed by I.B.M. against MiraPak.

title: ExBasketball Fixer Killed In a GangStyle Slaying
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 4 (UPI) The police said today that the fatal shooting of Jacob Molinas, former basketball player, once accused of being the master fixer of basketball games, may have been a gangstyle slaying.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1975

title: Plate and Bars Cut To Industry Prices At Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's No. 2 steel producer behind the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it had reduced as of last Friday its base price on plate by $5 a ton and on specialty bars by $4 a ton. The action means that Bethlehem is now charging $242 a ton for plate and $242 a ton for specialquality bars.

title: DANNY'S HIDEAWAY CLOSES IN A DISPUTE
description: Danny's HideAWay, the financially ailing steak house at 151 East 45th Street, closed its doors yesterday afternoon after 30 years. According to spokesman for the restaurant's owner, Danny Stradella, it was a victim of a labor dispute.

title: STATE SENATE VOTES AGENCY NOMINATIONS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)The New Jersey Senate confirmed the following nominations today:

title: Michel Foucault, on the Role of Prisons
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Michel Foucault, French philosopher, psychiatrist and historian, and author of The Order of Things and Madness and Civilization. It first appeared in the Paris newspaper Le Monde, preceded by a commentary by the interviewer RogerPol Droit. This was translated by Leonard Mayhew.

title: Study of JapaneseAmericans Indicates Stress Can Be a Major Factor in Heart Disease
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 4A new study indicates that stress, American style, is a major contributing factor in heart disease, a group of epidemiologists announced last week.

title: Help From. Mr. Levitt?
description: The difficulties still being encountered by the Municipal Assistance Corporation in trying to assure a strong market for a second $1billion package of bonds to help New York City meet its August obligations underscores the persisting desperation of the city's fiscal plight.

title: GROWTH IS EASING IN GAS DEMANDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 4The demand for gasoline, though it has rebounded this year from the low levels of 1974, is moving on an upward trend much more slowly than before the big increase in prices, new Federal Energy Administration figures indicated today.

title: New Clash Reported at Lebanese Border
description: TEL AVIV, Tuesday, Aug. 5Israeli commandos struck across the Lebanese border early this morning 10 miles up the coast near Tyre in the second reported clash between Israeli and Palestinian guerrilla forces in 24 hours.

title: Oppositionist Turk Calls for Removal Of the U.S. Military
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4The leader of the Turkish opposition called on the Government today to close immediately all United States military bases and send American military personnel home.

title: Whitney Museum Halts Architectural Displays
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, which has sponsored the first New York exhibitions of the work of such innovative architects as Robert Venturi and Paolo Soleri, has canceled all architecture exhibitions until at least 1977, according to the museum's director, Thomas Armstrong.

title: 2 Killed as AntiCommunist Violence Grows in Portugal
description: LISBON, Aug. 4Two per sons died early today in a new flareup of antiCommunist violence while Portugal's armed forces continued to be beset by political paralysis.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Los Angeles  Willie Jenson, 109 pounds. Las Vegas, outpointed Rollo Galindo, 112, Mexico. 10 rounds.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dr. Joseph P. Donnelly, the head of Blue Shield of New Jersey, has said the medical insurance plan will apply for another rate increase because the 14.5 per cent increase granted last Thursday is too small. Blue Shield had sought a 34.4 per cent increase.

title: General Haig Is Altering NATO Deployment
description: CASTEAU, BelgiumGen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. has begun to alter the deploy ment of United States forces on the central European front to correct a longstanding strategic weakness of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: U.S. Courthouse Bombed Despite Security Order
description: TACOMA, Wash. Aug. 5 (AP)A bomb exploded this afternoon in the Federal Courthouse, causing extensive damage but no injuries. Last week a judge had ordered security, tightened there because of a California group's interest in a trial.

title: TAX CREDIT ALLOWED FOR WELFARE HIRING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Private employers can now claim tax credit for employing recipients or family welfare aid, the Department of Health, Edudation and Welfare said today.

title: Charter Change Would Be City's 5th
description: If accepted, the final recommendations of the Charter Revision Commission made public yesterday would mark the fifth charter revision in the city's history.

title: Lisbon Is Fearful as Violence Spreads
description: LISBON, Aug. 5As violence continued in northern Portugal and spread to Lisbon, concern was felt among political groups here today that growing political and economic disorder would lead to full dictatorship.

title: Canada's Jury Reserves Off
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 5 (Reuters)Canada's official foreign reserves fell by $104.3million of United States currency to $5.23billion in July from $5.33billion in June, the Federal Finance Department reported today. Most of the change was a gross decline of $81.2million in the Special Drawing Rights component, reflecting in part depreciation of the United States dollar value of S.D.R.'s, the department said.

title: SHELLY GROSSMAN, PHOTOGRAPHER, DIES
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 5 (AP)  Shelly Grossman, photographer and conservationist, died July 30 in Switzerland after suffering a massive coronary thrombosis, his family reported. He was 47 years old and moved here from New York three years ago.

title: Charter for Reform
description: One way New York City can speed its return to solvency and control over its own affairs is through adoption of six propositions submitted unanimously yesterday by the State Charter Revision Commission for a November referendum. Most crucial are Propositions One and Two dealing with fiscal and management reforms.

title: KENT STATE FIRINGS TERMED IMPROPER
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (UPI)Ohio National Guardsmen who fired at Kent State University students in a campus antiwar disturbance May 4, 1970, were in conflict with Regular Army guidelines according to Lieut. Col. Edward L. King, retired.

title: 4 A.M.A. EMPLOYES QUIZZED ON LEAK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The American Medical Association said today that liedetector tests had been given to four, employes in an effort to discover the official or former official responsible for giving reporters sensitive A.M.A. documents.

title: CATTLEMEN'S AWARD IS SETTLED BY A.&P.
description: The Great Atlantic and Pactific Tea Company, the naion's second largest supermarket chain, announced yesterday it had settled for $9million a $35.8million antitrust judgment that was handed idown against it last year by Federal court in San Francisco.

title: India's Lower House Approves Bill to Clear Mrs: Gandhi's Case
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 5The lower house of Parliament, voting by acclamation, today approved legislation designed to end Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's entanglement with the courts by changing the law under which she was convicted eight weeks ago.

title: St. Joe in an Accord To Acquire Austral; Superior Backs Bid
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation and the Austral Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle for St. Joe to acquire Austral through an exchange of com mon stock. The agreement provides for St. Joe to exchange 0.62 share of its common stock for each of Austral's approximately 4.2 million common shares outstanding. St. Joe would issue about 2.6 million shares to complete the deal.

title: Oil Shale Tracts Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Interior Department said today that five companies had nominated tracts for next year's proposed Federal leasing for oil shale development.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Norwegian Rye and Wheat Bread
description: 3 cups unsifted, unbleached, white flour, approximately

title: Judge in Little Trial Sees Victim's Shirts
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 5The prosecution in the Joan Little murder case hung Clarence T. Alligood's bloody undershirt on a blackboard in Wake County Superior Court today in what appeared to be the beginning of a latehour attempt to show that, the jailer's outer shirt was rearranged while he was being stabbed to death.

title: YEAR AFTER WAR, TURKS UNYIELDING
description: ANKARA. Turkey, Aug. 1One year after Turkish troops invaded Cyprus and occupied 40 per cent of its territory Ankara shows little willingness or ability, to negotiate a political solution for the island's future.

title: 11 Indicted on Tax Charges in Fraudulent Grain Sales
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5A Federal grand jury indicted 11 men today, including junior officials and former officials of three large grain elevators here, for evading taxes on $713,840 in income from sales of stolen grain and fraudulent sales that involved no exchange of grain.

title: Memorial Services
description: BARAGREYJohn. Memorial services for John Baragrey, actor, to be held Thurs., Aug. 7th, 12 noon at St. Malachy, 239 49th St.

title: REFUGEES ARRIVE TO SETTLE IN MAINE
description: STANDISH, Me., Aug. 5A group of 310 Vietnamese is coming to Maine in a program making the state the second to start a governmentsponsored refugee resettlement and job placement program.

title: Suspect Questioned in Blast in Allendale
description: The pipebombing of a liquor store at 11:30 P.M. Monday and the subsequent burning of a nearby hotel in Allendale, N.J., led yesterday to questioning by the police of one of four youths described as suspects in the two incidents.

title: A Portuguese Town Wars on Communism
description: VILA NOVA DE FAMALICAO, Portugal, Aug. 5  This sleepy northern textile town with its horse carts, cobbled streets and red  tiled roofs set in a gentle landscape of radiant vineyards and hills has become the focus of a bitter antiCommunist battle.

title: Campus Security Is College Seminar Topic
description: EDISON, Aug. 5  The problems of campus security personnel in the realm of human relations are the focus of the final weeks of a nineweek training course at Middlesex County College here.

title: Monday's Fights
description: Brisbane, Australia  Hector Thompson, 141 pounds, Australia, knocked out Shinichi Kadota, 141, Japan, 5 rounds.

title: HEARING SET HERE ON TRANSIT FUNDS
description: A joint legislative hearing will be held here Sept. 10 to take testimony on a proposed regional tax to subsidize masstransit operations.

title: OPENING OF MAIL IS TRACED TO F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened and photographed foreign and domestic mail at several sites in the United States beginning in 1958 and continuing until possibly 1970, according to a source with direct knowledge of the secret operation.

title: For TeenAlters in California, Counseling Precedes Marriage
description: LOS ANGELESSixteenyearold Barbara and 17yearold Joe are in love and want to get married. Their parents approve although she has not finished high school and he is unemployed.

title: Big Crop Loss in Honduras
description: MIAMI, Aug. 5 (UPI)Drought has destroyed as much as 80 per cent of the corn crop in Honduras, which lost most of its 1,974 crop in a hurricane, and as many as 700,000 persons face possible famine, The Miami Herald deported today in a dispatch from Tegucicalpa, the Honduran capital.

title: Peers Win a Point; Justice Comes Out Ahead of Politics
description: LONDON, Aug, 5  The House of Lords won one last night. It was not a great victory, just enough to remind the House of Commons that the 1,074 lords and ladies of the realm can on occasion rise above constitutional disability, pageantry and eccentricity to teach a moral lesson.

title: Utility's Message Gains Awards and Brickbats
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 5 (AP)The Atlantic Electric Company has jettisoned an awardwinning program of letting customers know if they are conserving energy. The utility deleted a conservation message from its bills this month because of complaints from consumers who were using electricity but paying more because of higher fuel costs, a spokesman said today.

title: Dancer Who Shares Raymonda Dream
description: Quite obviously the Glazunov/Petipa Raymonda, first given in St. Petersburg in 1898, is never going to be a Swan Lake or a Sleeping Beauty. What is? But equally obviously, it is going to be a great hit, and a really substantial addition to the repertory, of American Ballet Theater. For one thing, in Ballet Theater's new and handsomely styled production by Nicholas Georgiadis, the British designer, it looks somberly gorgeous, and Rudolf Nureyev has given the production a certain choreographic sumptuousness that is going to delight the true fans for years and years to come. And come they will.

title: BERGMAN AND SON ARE INDICTED HERE IN MEDICAID FRAUD
description: Bernard Bergman, the central figure in nursinghome investigations since last October, was indicted by Federal and state grand juries yesterday on charges of stealing $1.2million from Medicaid.

title: Palmer Halts Red Sox, 30
description: Cornelius McGillicuddy (a/k/a Connie Mack) said pitching was 90 per cent of baseball. The former ownermanager of the Philadelphia Athletics has been proved right many, many times in his estimate of the game's most basic factor.

title: AntiPollution Delay
description: President Ford recently formalized the unofficial request he had earlier made to Congress to ease its schedule for reducing automobile emissions. Both the Senate Subcommittee on Environmental Pollution and the Environmental Protection Agency also favor a modification of the timetable.

title: Hong Kong Gang Seizes $1.5Million in Robbery
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 5 (Reuters)Ten robbers ambushed two cars carrying money to a bank here today and stole nearly $11.5million in foreign currency, most of it United States funds, police officials said.

title: Banks Misses Court Date; F.B.I. Is Asked to Find Him
description: CUSTER, S.D., Aug. 5 (UPI) Dennis Banks, the American Indian Movement leader, failed today to appear in Custer County Circuit Court for sentencing and state officials asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to enter the case.

title: Berkeley, Changed by the Movement, Is Still Center of Ferment
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 5 The hair was shoulderlength on the policeman on Telegraph Avenue, where he arbitrated a dispute over merchant sales space. The jogger leaving City Hall wore gym shorts and was barefoot, but carried a receipt for a traffic fine he'd paid. The old man on University Avenue blew his nose in his hand and glared defiantly as he wiped palm on the seat of his pants.

title: Alger Hiss Is Readmitted To the Massachusetts Bar
description: Alger Hiss was ordered reinstated to the Massachusetts bar yesterday by that state's highest court.

title: Ford Signs Bill Giving Citizenship Back to Lee
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)President Ford today signed legislation restoring full citizenship to Gen. Robert E. Lee and said that Congress, in passing the bill, corrects a 110year oversight of American history.

title: Navajo Girl in New Mexico Victim of Bubonic Plague
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 5. (AP) A 3yearold Navajo Indian girl, Charlene Brown, died yesterday in a Gallup hospital of bubonic plague, the New Mexico Health and Social Services Agency said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A New Jersey man, Richard Feinberg, 47 years old, of Somerset, was indicted for allegedly selling $850,000 worth of property in Pocono Township, Pa., by making false promises to build lakes, a swimming pool and tennis courts. Also indicted were the Pocono Haven Corporation, which promoted the 132 acres of land; Sea and Ski Homes, Inc., and Paul Bunyan Distributors, two companies that built homes on the land.

title: Second Body Is Discovered In Helsinki Boat Incident
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 5 (UPI)Policemen today found the body of a second man who was killed July 31 when coastal patrolmen fired a flare at a speedboat in restricted waters near a hotel for delegates to the European security conference.

title: Oil Wealth Building a Favored Class in Socialist Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, IraqThe oil wealth that Iraq is putting into development of a modern high  consumption economy is producing a new class of rich bureaucrats and property owners in a society that is supposed to be dedicated to revolutionary socialsim.

title: Greek Dance: Rich Link to Golden Abe
description: ATHENS  Shortly after World War II Dora Stratou read an article in Reader's Digest suggesting that the modern Greeks bore little relation to the classical Greeks and that only the stones of Athens were authentic.

title: U. S. Newsmen in Moscow Eager To Obtain MultipleEntry Visas
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (UP) The Soviet Government declined today to issue multipleuse exit and entry visas to foreign correspondents as agreed at the European security conference in Helsinki, Finland.

title: Standard Brand Switches Agency
description: Standard Brands Foods, a division of Standard Brands, Inc., announced yesterday a realignment of its advertising agency assignments, because, in the words of a company spokesman, we felt it was time for a change.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Charter Panel Members
description: Following is a list of members of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City:

title: It Was 90, but Breeze And Less Humidity Help
description: The temperature in Central Park shot up to 90 degrees at 4:35 P.M. yesterday, but gentle breezes and a sharp drop in the humidity spared the city a recurrence of last weekend's sweltering agony.

title: Burger Calls on Chief Justices To Lobby on State Court Needs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger exhorted the chief justices of the 50 states today to lobby in the state legislatures for the courts' needs. The courts must be heard, he told them, on every piece of legislation that will have an impact on their work.

title: Fans Stay Till End
description: Few fans leave Northeast Louisiana basketball games early, reports the aNtional Collegiate Sports services. Four recent games were decided in the final five seconds, one in the last 54 seconds and one in overtime.

title: Risk at Marco Island
description: In a recent letter to this newspaper, a reader took issue with our earlier condemnation of a housing development on Marco Island, Fla., that would destroy 2,200 acres of mangrove wetlands. The Army Corps Engineers has yet to hold hearings on the required applications for dredging and filling; but whichever way it decides, the issue raised by our correspondent, Robert E. Kennedy, is worth examining for implications that go beyond this particular project.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Organized labor has mounted a campaign to urge Governor Carey to veto four bills that would set aside 25 per cent of certain construction work and services at state construction projects for minority contractors.

title: People and Business
description: A former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Secor D. Browne, criticized strongly yesterday proposals to deregulate the airline industry and warned that the industry urgently needed Government economic aid to avert nationalization.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  United States exports to the countries of North Africa and the Near East, most of them oil producers, have continued to soar this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The number of shares of the Apco Oil Corporation tendered to the Northwest Energy Company was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday. A total of 2.09 million shares were tendered as of the close of business last Friday.

title: Larchmont Club Wins Sailing Title
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 5  The Larchmont Yacht Club, represented by Richard Ronan as slepper, won the William H. Taylor Trophy today by defeating the Norton (Conn.) Y.C., with Robert N. Bavier Jr. skipper. Larchmont, the host club, won the final, three races to one for 10th annual interclub matchrace championship.

title: Music by Brasil Gives 2 Singers Endurance Test
description: Sergio Mendes, the Brazilian pianist and singer, may update the name of his group 10 years ago it was Brasil '65, the next year, Brasil '66 and, since 1971, Brasil '77but the basic idea has remained essentially the same: a company of four or five instrumentalists and two women singers focusing primarily on Brazilian tunes, rhythms and percussion.

title: FORD WILL VISIT REFUGEES' CAMP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 President Ford, who returned late last night from a fivenation trip to Europe, will visit a Vietnamese refugee camp in Arkansas on his way to a working vacation in Vail, Colo., Sunday, the White House announced today.

title: Mexican Chief in Egypt
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 5 (Reuters)President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico discussed the Middle East situation in separate talks today with President Anwar elSadat and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat.

title: BOND MOVE WEIGHED BY MORGAN STANLEY
description: Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., questioned about Wall Street reports that it was inspecting real estate in Jersey City, said yesterday that it was deeply concerned about New York City's newly enacted bond transfer tax and was seriously considering moving its bond trading operations out of the city.

title: Pope Names Two Bishops In Bulgaria to Foster Ties
description: ROME, Aug. 5 (AP)  Pope Paul VI named two bishops for Bulgaria today in another move by the Vatican to improve relations with a Communist regime.

title: More Smuggling Arrests
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 5 (AP) The police arrested eight more men today as they investighted a marijuana smuggling operation linked with a carge plane that made a midnight landing near a mountain in west. Georgia. A DC4 had landed on an airstrip, several hundred feet long, that had been bulldozed out of a field.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The original version of Tennessee. Williams's twocharacter play, Outcry, which has never been seen in New York, will be presented starting Aug. 19 at the Quaigh Theater, 808 Lexington Avenue at 62d Street, for 12 performances. Mary Ellen Flynn and Robert Stattel will play the two roles.

title: British Abortion Dispute
description: LONDON, Aug. 5 (Reuters)A committee of Parliament today urged restrictions on abortion clinics here, which attract nearly 60,000 foreign women a year to Britain. The move was a reaction against Britain's 1967 laws legalizing abortion on medical and social grounds.

title: Age Is No Drawback for This L.I. Science Columnist
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.Every fortnight since the middle of June, readers of The East Hampton Star have been instructed and entertained by an erudite and witty science column.

title: Malaysia Terrorists Free Most Hostages in Embassy
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Wednesday, Aug. 6Five Japanese Red Army terrorists who had occupied the consular section of the United States Embassy here for two days released nine of their hostages today, then herded 15 more aboard a bus and headed for the airport.

title: Dodgers Pass 2 Million
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 (UPI)For the 11th time in the 18 seasons that the Dodgers have played here, the club has hit the 2 million mark in attendance. A crowd of 25,036 turned out to watch Los Angeles beat Atlanta, 91, last night, swelling the 1975 home crowd total to 2,000,184. The Dodgers hold the major league attendance record of 2,755,184 set in 1962.

title: No Fund Misuse Found in Odyssey House Inquiry
description: Odyssey House, a private narcotics rehabilitation program, has been cleared by the city of charges it misused public funds.

title: Youngsters Are Using Harlem Landmark for a Gym
description: One of Harlem's few designated historic landmarks, a 120yearold castiron lookout fire tower in Marcus Garvey Park, has become a jungle gym for neighborhood youngsters.

title: Cottage Cheese: It's a Very Quiet Issue
description: The question of cottage cheese hasn't come up, and maybeit shouldn't. After all, nobody who's anybody talks about it, presumably because it's hardly in a league with detente or salmon mousse. Yet nearly everybody eats it at one time or another, especially in summer.

title: 8 AGENCIES TOLD TO WITHHOLD DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The principal architect of the Freedom of Information Act has had subpoenas sent to eight Federal regulatory agencies to prevent them from publicly disclosing a mass of material compiled at his request.

title: Advertising
description: The tennis boom has long been recognized and accepted by marketers throughout the United States. With about 30 million Americans now playing the game and more than a halfbillion dollars spent annually on products related to the sport, the number of corporations identifying themselves with tennis continues to grow.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Knicks, foiled in their recent attempts so far to get a good big man, lost out on a good little man yesterday, 6foot2inch Luther (Ticky) Burden. The allAmerican guard from Utah and the Knicks' second  round draft choice in the National Basketball Association draft, signed a multiyear pact with the Virginia Squires. The Squires selected him in the fourth round of the American Basketball Association draft. He averaged 28.7 points a game, fourth best in the country, while making 51 per cent from the foul line, as a junior at Utah last season. Burden, who had a year's eligibility remaining in college, applied for the hardship draft.

title: Lie Tests Given 8 at Roosevelt
description: Were you helped in the race? Did you bet on the race? Did anyone help you? Did you try?

title: 8 Argentine Guerrillas Slain
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 (UPI)  Argentine soldiers stormed a guerrilla mountain hideout today and killed eight leftwing terrorists, an army communique said. Several guerrillas in the clash, in northern Tucuman Province, managed to escape.

title: About the Giants . .
description: Tony Roberts, the business partner of Ted Hendricks, has informed the Giants that he will fly to Oakland, Calif., for further negotiations with the Raiders. . . . Brad Van Pelt, his knee healed from a summer boating accident, has begun workouts this week at linebacker. . . . With Joe Dawkins still recovering from bruised ribs suffered last week, Larry Watkins has been seeing considerable action as No. 1 fullback. . . . Terry McClowry on his pro debut against the Steelers: I thought it was easy. Before the game, I was nervous because it was my first game against the professional champions. But they didn't seem as good as I expected.

title: U.S. Car Makers' July Sales Fell 7.9% But Annual Selling Rate Is Year's Best
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5Domestic auto makers reported sales of 636,666 new cars in July, off 7.9 per cent from the same month in 1974 but the annual selling rate climbed to a yearly high.

title: PRESIDENT URGED TO KEEP OIL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Nine members of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, one of them a Republican, appealed to President Ford today to allow oil price controls to continue for a while so that a final effort could be nade to reach a compromise on the issue

title: BRITISH SET SUBSIDY TO PRESERVE JOBS
description: LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP)The Government, battling Britain's worst unemployment in 35 years, today announced a subsidy of $22 a week per worker to help private concerns save threatened jobs.

title: 31Day Potato May Aid Hungry Lands
description: Prospects for an additional large food supply for tropical nations have been increased by a South American research center's success this year in growing mature potatoes in a warm, humid area in only 31 days.

title: Hercule Poirot Is Dead; Famed Belgian Detective
description: Hercule Poirot, a Belgian detective who became internationally famous, has died in England. His age was unknown.

title: Terrorists Release 9 of 50 Heldin U.S. Embassy Raid
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia. Wednesday, Aug. 6Japanese terrorists today released nine of about 50 people they have held hostage for nearly two days but continued their occupation of the consular section of the United States Embassy here.

title: Mets, on Banner Night at Shea, Shut Out Twice, 70, by Expos
description: For the sixth time this season, the New York Mets dropped both ends of a doubleheader when the Montreal Expos tripped them twice last night by identical scores of 70.

title: Lawyer Hiss
description: In deciding that Alger Hiss could be readmitted to the Massachusetts Bar, the state's Supreme Judicial. Court acted on broad humane principles which do credit both to the court and to the law.

title: NEW JERSEY BELL POSTPONES BONDS
description: The current weakness in the corporate bond market was underscored yesterday when New Jersey Bell Telephone postponed its toprated $75million offering because of disappointing market conditions resulting from the sudden rise in longterm interest r ate s. Bond analysts estimated that the Bell System unit would have had to provide a yield to investors of about 9.25 per cent in order to merchandise successfully its proposed 40year debenture issue that is rated tripleA.

title: 9% PRICE RISE SET BY ARMCO STEEL; AUTOS AFFECTED
description: The Armco Steel Corporation plans to raise prices of flatrolled and sheet steel an average of 9 per cent next Sunday, it announced yesterday. Armco is the nation's fourth largest steel producer.

title: Susan Ford Finds A Superneat Job
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4At 8:57 A.M. on a recent day, Dick King, the city editor of The Topeka State Journal, handed a slip of paper bearing a picture assignment to the young blond woman with a camera bag.

title: New Books
description: Adolescent Prejudice, by Charles Y. Glock, Robert Wuthnow, Jane Allyn Piliavin, Metta Spencer (Harper & Row, $12.50). A study in the Patterns of American Prejudice Series.

title: H.E.W. CAUTIONS ON SEX DISEASES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Department of Health, Education and Welfare, in a report on the nation's health problems, says more public attention should be paid to three groups of sexually transmitted diseases, other than syphilis. and gonorrhea, that are rapidly increasing.

title: 2 VIETNAMS PRESS ADMISSION INTO U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5The permanent observers of North and South Vietnam held a news conference here today to press for separate memberships in the world organizations while maintaining that Vietnam was a united country.

title: PHILADELPHIA TIED TO U.S. FUND WASTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Federil Government presented Philadelphia's redevelopment authority today with an Audit challenging nearly $14million in spending by the authority as either unjustified or questionable.

title: Over 61 Pounds of Cocaine Seized on 2 Ships at Miami
description: MIAMI, Aug. 5 (UPI)Customs agents found 40 pounds of cocaine today aboard a banana boat that had docked in the Miami River net to, the vesse Frigora, Which Yielded $4,5million worth of  cocaine to inspectors yesterday.

title: Colts Bring Top Prices At Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP)Corbet Robertson of Houston, owner of the 3yearold West Coast star, Foreten, was the first buyer tonight at the opening of the FasigTipton yearling sales.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Corn Declines in Slow Trading As Some Rain Falls in Midwest
description: As more rain came to the Midwest growing areas, prices of corn and soybeans drifted lower on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Trading was described by one analyst as lethargic.

title: McDonnell Douglas Unveils New Cargo Jet
description: A radically designed cargo plane that will compete for what could be billions in Air Force orders was shown to the public yesterday at a traditional rollout ceremony in Long Beach, Calif. The plane, the McDonnell Douglas YC15, is due to make its first flight in a few weeks.

title: WILLIAM N. THOMSON
description: William N. (Tommy) Thomson, a Hearst newspaper executive, died yesterday of lung cancer at his home in Whiting, N. J. He was 71 years old.

title: Israelis Aid Egyptian Ship
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 5 (Reuters)  Israeli sailors recently assisted an Egyptian cargo ship in distress, an army spokesman said here today. He said a naval patrol vessel had met the ship, the Karim, drifting with engine trouble near the Sinai coast on July 26. After trying vainly to repair the engine, the Israelis towed the ship to a spot where a favorable wind enabled it to continue to Port Said under sail.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Representatives of state employe groups met with State Treasurer Richard Leone in Trenton to seek raises and stave off layoffs. They emerged from the hourlong meeting to say they expected to meet within a week with Governor Byrne to present their case.

title: Amex Stocks Fall As Volume Grows; OTC Sector Oft
description: Prices continued to decline on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with the index dropping 1.35 points to 87.33. Volume totaled 1.7 million shares, up from 1.3 million on Monday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Charter Change Proposed To Curb Mayor's Powers
description: In the midst of the city's fiscal crisis, a state commission yesterday proposed a revision of the City Charter that would curb some of the Mayor's budgetary powers and strengthen those of the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
WINE TALK
description: Sometime early in the fall, the Federal Government will release the findings of hearfigs held last spring on wine labeling. The Governmentspecifically the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms of the Treasury Departmentthinks the public is entitled to know more about what goes into every bottle of wine.

title: Consumer Credit in Climb
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board reported today, that Americans increased their indebtedness during June by the largest amount in nine months.

title: House Panel Demands Security Charter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The House Select Committee on In telligence appeared today to be headed for a confrontation with the Ford Administration and the Department of Defense over its attempts to obtain top secret national security documents.

title: Brige:
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 5  A totally unknown partnership held a commanding lead into the final section of the Life Master Pair Championships at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer. Nationals here tonight.

title: Marguerite Steen Is Dead at 81; A Popular Novelist in England
description: LONDON, Aug. 5Marguerite Steen, the novelist, died yesterday in a private hospital near her home at Blewsbury, Oxfordshire. She was 81 years old.

title: Pesticide Ban Spurs Suit
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 5 (AP)  A major manufacturer of two insecticides tentatively banned as potential causes of cancer challenged the decision today in Federal District Court. The suit by the Velsicol Chemical Corporation contends that the Environmental Protection Agency's move to end most uses of the powerful insecticides, chlordane and heptaclor, is illegal??

title: Alger Hiss Is Readmitted To the Massachusetts Bar
description: Alger Hiss was ordered reinstated to to the Massachusetts bar yesterday by that state's highest court.

title: School Boycott Urged
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5 (AP)  Opponents of busing who claim to represent groups; in at least five states have called for a nationwide boycott of schools Sept. 4.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, August 5, 1975

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 1975

title: 4 AIRLINES BLOCK NEW RISE IN FARES
description: Airlines serving the North Atlantic have voted overwhelmingly in favor of a 4 per cent fare increase beginning Nov. 1 Wit the action remained blocked by the opposition of four carriers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Small Amount of Bran Meets Most of Body's Fiber Needs
description: Dried fruits, nuts, seeds, whole grains and cereals have always figured prominently in healthful diets and now there is evidence to suggest that the higher proportion of fiber in all these foods is not only essential for good health in a general sense, but also beneficial specifically in preventing diseases of the gastrointestinal tract and circulatory system and in treating obesity.

title: Missing Patient, 83, Found Dead on Roof
description: The pajamaclad body of an 83yearold patient missing for three days from the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home on the Upper East Side was found on the roof of the home Monday, the police reported yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BOROUGHING IN Tonight begins the second season of free park concerts by the Brooklyn Philharmonia, with three programs under different guest conductors repeated in a second locale.

title: OPENING OF MAIL IS TRACED TO F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Agents of the Federal Bureau of investigation opened and photographed foreign and domestic mail at several sites in the United States beginning in 1958 and continuing until possibly 1970, according to source with direct knowledge of the secret operation.

title: BERGMAN AND SON ARE INDICTED HERE IN MEDICAID FRAUD
description: Bernard Bergman, the central figure in nursinghome investigations since last October, was indicted by Federal and state grand juries yesterday on charges of stealing $1.2million from Medicaid.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: 3 Die in Rushmore Air Crash
description: KEYSTONE, S. D., Aug. 5 (UPI)A helicopter flying near Mount Rushmore crashed today, killing the three persons aboard. Arnold Simmons, chief ranger of the Mount Rushmore national memorial, said the helicopter crashed in an area of ponderosa pines and rocky ridges about one, and a half miles from the monument. The names of the victim, including the pilot, were not released pending notification of kin.

title: Salesman Ford
description: New York City is fortunate in not having to depend on President Ford to sell its Wilds. It is even more fortunate that the Market for those securities in Yugoslavia is minimal. After appreciating these minor blessings, the city can only feel provoked by the President's singularly callous discussion of its affairs with the Mayor and Council of Belgrade.

title: CHURCH CANCELS PROPERTY SALE
description: Trinity Church has decided to take off the market 10 Lower Manhattan properties that it had been offering for sale since last December for $14.665million.

title: U. S. Looks to Talks Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5A State Department spokesman said today that the United States hoped governmental arrangements with the Soviet Union could be worked out soon to improve conditions for journalists under the provisions of the Helsinki declaration. This would include multipleentry visas.

title: DeLury to Meet Mayor Today on Refuse Backlog
description: Charging that the Sanitation Department is in chaos, John J. DeLury, the head of the sanitation's union, arranged yesterday to meet with Mayor Beame today to offer suggestions on how the city might cope better with the piles of garbage that have clogged its streets and sidewalks for the last 15 days.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the most urbanand urbaneof Congressmen, Representative Fred W. Richmond of Brooklyn, has promised to help with beforebreakfast farm chores three mornings this month during a fourday exploration of farm life and farm problems in Iowa and Minnesota. The 51yearold freshman Democrat from Brooklyn Heights, a selfmade business millionaire whose multiethnic district runs from Newtown Creek to the Gowanus Canal, will visit farms in the districts of three fellow members, also freshmen Democrats, on the House Agriculture Committee. Representatives Berkley Bedell and Tom Harkin of Iowa and Richard Nolan of Minnesota.

title: Carey Pressured on Four MinorityContracting Bills
description: Four bills that would give minority contractors at least 25 per cent of certain construction work and services at designated state public works projects have pitted organized labor against minority groups seeking a share of the more than $100million in construcLion work.

title: Birth Control Zealot Ends Pacific Raft Trip
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 8 (AP)A 58yearold Japanese building contractor, ttempting to cross the Pacific alone on a raft to promote birth control, has been res, cued by a fishing boat, the Maritime Safety Agency reported today.

title: MRS. BENJAMIN SATTLER
description: Josephine Armstrong Sattler, a longtime Queens resident whose husband, the late Benjamin Sattler, was a member of the International Typographical Union for more than 50 years, died on Monday at a nursing home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: SCIENTIFIC BALLOON LAUNCHED IN SICILY
description: TRAPANI, Sicily, Aug. 5 (AP)An Americanmade scientific research balloon was launched early today from Italy's Milo air base for an expected eightday voyage to Palestine, Tex.

title: JACK SCOTTS BAR HEARSTCASE AID
description: Jack Scott, the radical critic of organized sports, and his wife, Micki McGee Scott, a writer, said yesterday that they would refuse to collaborate with a Federal grand jury that has subpoenaed them to testify about their knowledge of Patricia Hearst.

title: Road Allowed Near Cranes
description: BILOXI, Miss. Aug. 5 (UPI)A Federal judge has refused to ban the construction of an interstate highway through the habitat of the Mississippi sandhill crane, an endagered species living in a swampy marshland of Jackson County. In rejecting a suit by the National and Mississipi Wildlife Federations, Federal District Judge Walter Nixon said yesterday that testimony failed to demonstrate that construction of Interstate 10 through the home of the remaining 40 cranes would pose a serious threat to the species.

title: Gardening Groupers: Summer Amid the Tomatoes
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. Groupers, those young, usually unmarried people who rent shares in summer houses, aren't always well thought of in these fashionable parts.

title: Ice Water After the Sauna
description: STOCKHOLMThe pleasant Finnish custom of a hot sauna followed by a freezing dip serves as a healthy stimulus and dousing the head in ice water after the radiant smiles of Helsinki's European security summit is an exercise much to be commended.

title: Excerpts From Summary of Major Proposals by State Panel to Revise City Charter
description: The budget shall be balanced using the State Controller's accounting principles for municipalities.

title: Molinas's Past Sifted For Clues
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5The police said today they were looking into a possible link between the fatal shooting Sunday morning of Jacob (Jack) Molinas, the former Columbia University basketball star, and the 1974 murder of his former business partner, Bernard Gusoff.

title: Zebra Case Prosecution
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 (AP)The prosecution rested today in the trial of four black men accused of three murders and four assaults in a wave of street shootings of whites that the police call the Zebra case. On trial are Manuel Moore, 30 years old, Larry Craig Green, 23, S. C. X. Simon. 28, and Jessie Lee Cooks 30. They were indicted on 12 counts in three murders and four assaults between October 1973 and April 1974.

title: L.I. Surgeon Indicted as Wife's Slayer
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 5Dr. Charles E. Friedgood was indicted by a Nassau County grand jury today on charges of having murdered his wife, Sophie, and stolen more than $569,000 of her property.

title: FreeAgent Shift Asked By Players
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5In an attempt to modify but not eliminate baseball's reserve system, the Major League Baseball Players Association has proposed giving players with at least five years service in the minor or major leagues an opportunity to become free agents.

title: A Portuguese Town Wars on Communism
description: VILA NOVA DE FAMALICAO, Portugal, Aug. 5  This sleepy northern textile town with its horse carts, cobbled streets and red  tiled roofs set in a gentle landscape of radiant vineyards and hills has become the focus of a bitter antiCommunist battle.

title: 15Member Legislature Urged For Nassau by Judicial Panel
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 5A judicial commission appointed by a State Supreme Court justice to develop an interim form of government for Nassau County today recommended a 15member County Legislature of equal population districts.

title: Ousters From U.S.Paid Jobs Scored
description: There were angry reactions yesterday to the cityordered dismissal of 1,466 workers from a Federal publicservice jobs program.

title: CONVERT FILES SUIT IN SECT KIDNAPPING
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5 (AP)A recent convert to a fundamentalist sect has filed a $350,000 suit against his wife and brother, the selfstyled cult deprogramer Ted Patrick and seven others for an incident he described as a kidnapping.

title: Red Smith
description: This is about Cullen Bryant, a running back whose employers, the Los Angeles Rams, permitted him to run from scrimmage 10 times in 14 professional football games last season. It is about Ron Jessie, a wide receiver who played out his option with the Detroit Lions and now has found happiness in Los Angeles. And it is about Pete Rozelle, the supreme being of football, whose sovereign authority was successfully challenged by Bryant recently Cullen Bryant is no relation to and should not be confused with the author of Thanatopsis. Nevertheless, when Rozelle ordered him to deliver his muscular body and mortal soul into the service of the Lions, he replied: I goest not like the quarry slaves at night, scourged to his dungeon, or words to that effect. Instead he went to court and got a temporary injunction restraining the commissioner from enforcing his transfer under the Rozelle Rule. It was confidently expected that for this appalling piece of lese majesty Rozelle would call down a thunderbolt to smite him but Pete did no such thing.

title: White House Clarifies Tito's Mideast Remark
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)  Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said today that a translation error had left the impression that President Ford and President Tito of Yugoslavia shared identical views on the Middle East.

title: About New York
description: A seat is one of those commonplaces of life that rarely comes easily in New York.

title: The Mayor Resists
description: Mayor Beame, who should be doing everything in his power to help the Municipal Assistance Corporation in its uphill battle to save this city from fiscal ruin, is doing just the opposite with his testy resistance to fiscal and management reforms proposed by the M.A.C. board.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: By the time she is 70 years old, the average woman in the United States has nearly a 50 per cent chance of undergoing a hysterectomy, according to testimony presented recently to a House of Representatives subcommittee investigating the incidence of unnecessary surgery in this country.

title: Ordination of Women
description: A year after 11 Episcopal women took ordination vows in Philadelphia and created A bitter controversy, the issue remains far from resolved and continues to generate new problems. A worsening or tensions was evident last week when William A. Stringfellow, the chief lawyer for the women, told them in a letter dated July 29 that ecclesiastical remedies are exhausted and that civil proceedings were about to begin.

title: Judge Denies Plea to Void Curb on Publishing Names
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 (AP)A Federal judge has refused to issue an order declaring unconstitutional a section of Tennessee law dealing with publication of juveniles' names.

title: NIGERIA INSTALLS MILITARY RULERS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 5A new Supreme Military Council, the highest ruling body in Nigeria, was sworn in today, one week after the country's apparently bloodless coup d'tat.

title: Wingless Aircraft Lands At 200 M.P.H. at Edwards
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 5 (UPI)A wingless X24B experimental aircraft made a 200mileperhour landing on the main concrete runway at Edwards Air Force Base today in a forerunner of future manned spacecraft missions that will land on the ground.

title: Raiders Are Part of a Loose Alliance of Japanese Extremists
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5The five Japanese radicals flown from here to Kuala Lumpur today and their comrades who took hostages there are members of a small, loose alliance of extremists who have for five years spread terror across Japan, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Europe.

title: STOCKS DECLINE: DOW OFF BY 7.90
description: A midsession rally wilted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and prices again closed lower in an extension of a threeweek correction.

title: Penn Central Is Recalling Some Furloughed Employe
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (UPI)  The Penn Central Transportation Company began today recalling furloughed employes at its Altoona Works and said it would hire new employes there to increase the force to 3,500.

title: ROBERT F. NEWMAN
description: Robert F. Newman, president of Eye Gate, Inc., a maker of audiovisual aids, and vice president of its parent concern, Cenco, Inc., died of a lung infection yesterday in Flushing (Queens) Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Glen Head, L. I., and formerly lived in Beechurst, Queens.

title: Israeli Units Raid Tyre Area in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 5A predawn Israeli commando raid accompanied by artillery fire, and a midday fighterbomber attack on Palestinian refugee areas near Tyre, took 16 lives today, according to reports from the southern Lebanese city. TwentyEight persons were wounded.

title: 9% PRICE RISE SET BY ARMCO STEEL; AUTOS AFFECTED
description: The Armco Steel Corporation plans to raise prices of flatrolled and sheet steel an average of 9 per cent next Sunday, it announced yesterday. Armco is the nation's fourth largest steel producer.

title: Newest Comet Is Visible
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) The newest comet to visit the solar system can be viewed for the next two weeks as a faint light in the sky without, the aid of binoculars. The comet KobayashiBergerMilon will continue to grow in brightness, said Marvin Mayo, a Los Angeles astronomer. The faint glow of the comet appears just west of the second star in the handle of the Big Dipper.

title: Nuisance Taxes Gain Quiet Acceptance
description: New Jersey's new package of nuisance taxes, signed into law last Monday was greeted yesterday by few cheers or groans.

title: Susan Ford Finds A Superneat Job
description: TOPEKA. Kan., Aug. 4At 8:57 A.M. on a recent day, Dick King, the city editor of The Topeka State Journal. handed a slip of paper bearing a picture assignment to the young blood woman with a camera bag.

title: Public's Role on Health Plans' Boards Found Limited
description: Millions of Americans whose monthly payments finance Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance plans have no say in choosing the directors who run the nonprofit, public service organizations.

title: Cambodia for Nonalignment
description: BANGOK, Thailand, Aug. 5 (UPI)Cambodia wants to be considered a nonaligned nation, radio Phnom Penh said today. The broadcast, monitored here, said Cambodia would request official membership among the nonaligned nations when the group meets at Lima, Peru, on Aug. 2428.

title: New York Glovemaker's Claims Keep U.S.Czech Relations Cool
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 5The United States' relations with Czechoslovakia have scarcely moved beyond the cold war, because of a dispute between the Prague Government and an American glove manufacturer.

title: The Highway Almost Nobody Wants
