description: From our tenthfloor terrace I have an unimpeded, dramatic view of what has become probably the world's most unused highwaythe Hudson River, which once gloried in such clich descriptives as Majestic and Mighty, but which now could more appropriately be described as Deserted, perhaps even Unwanted.

title: Giants Quit On Rookie; Glass Goes
description: To no one's surprise, Coach Bill Arnsparger said he was inclined to start Craig Morton at quarterback for the New York Giants in Sunday night's exhibition opener against the New England Patriots.

title: Investigators in Hoff a Case Trying to Find Foster Son
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5James R. Hoffa's foster son, who had been his bodyguard, emerged today as a potentially important figure in determining the whereabouts of the former president of the teamsters' union, missing since last Wednesday.

title: How Trenton Came Up With Its Tax Package
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6A former Senate aide from the days when the upper house had one representative from each county and was called the 21 club shook his head in disbelief yesterday after Governor Byrne and the State Legislature completed enactment of a package of stopgap taxes to balance the state budget.

title: 8 ASIAN NATIONS IN TARIFF ACCORD
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 5Representatives of eight underdeveloped and developing Asian countries have reached agreement on the first series of broad, multilateral tariff concessions among themselves an agreement they hoped would pave the way for the development of an Asian free trade zone.

title: City Discloses 3 Programs Under Study to Cut Costs
description: A proposal for the use of large metal containers to hold garbage until it can be picked up by the Sanitation Department, the replacement of policemen in the automobile tow away program with civilians and the hiring of private contractors to resurface some highways are among the economy measures now being studied by the city.

title: Capt. James Lewis, 86, Dies; Commanded Destroyer Fleet
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 5Capt. James A. Lewis, U.S.N., retired, who commanded the Atlantic destroyer fleet headquarters here in World War II, died Monday in Veterans Administration Hospital in Manchester, N.H. He was 36 years old.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 910,000 common shares of the Harnischeger Corporation, at $25.75 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation. Harnischfeger, which has its headquarter in Brookfield. Wis., is a diversified supplier of construction, mining and industrial material handling equipment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The number of shares of the Apco Oil Corporation tendered to the Northwest Energy Company was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday. A total of 2.09 million shares were tendered as of the close of business last Friday.

title: Investigators in Hoff a Case Trying to Find Foster Son
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5James R. Hoffa's foster son, who had been his bodyguard, emerged today as a potentially important figure in determining the whereabouts of the former president of the teamsters' union, missing since last Wednesday.

title: S.B.A. WRONGDOING IS DENIED BY WYMAN
description: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 5 (UPI)Louis C. Wyman, the Republican candidate in the New Hampshire race for a United States Senate seat, has denied any wrongdoing in the appointment of a Republican official to a Small Business Administration post.

title: Moret, Hurt in Car, Faces Boston Fine
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP)Roger Moret, the Red Sox lefthander, was sent tonight to a hospital here for observation after being injured in an early morning highway accident in Connecticut Moret suffered cuts requiring stitches on the head, some above an eye, when his car ran into a parked trailer on Interstate 95 in North Stonington, Conn. The police reported the accident occurred in fog at about 4:30 A. M.

title: About Education
description: Brothers, we thank you for educating our children in your schools, a member of the Onondoga Indian tribe told a community of English colonizers in 1760, but we have observed that for a long time after our children return home they are not good for anything.

title: Getting on Top of the Problem
description: New York City's budget crisis poses a standard management problem: balancing revenues and expenditures. Two broad strategies can be followed: increasing revenues and decreasing expenditures. Practically speaking, however, revenues cannot be increased. Local taxpayers cannot be charged more without further damaging the city's economy, and taxpayers elsewhere will not contribute, however reasonable commuter taxes and national welfare reform may be.

title: Moderate Takes a Solid Lead In Mississippi Governor's Race
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 5 Lieut. Gov. William Winter, who lost a runoff for the governorship of Mississippi eight years ago because of his moderate racial stance, took a solid lead tonight over five other candidates for the state's Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Comparative Riches
description: For years Americans have thought of themselves as the richest people in the world. Are they still? Confidence that the United States is still far out in front of other countries in per capita income has taken a jolt in the last couple of yearsparticularly as a result of the devaluation of the dollar, starting with the Smithsonian agreement at the end of 1971.

title: Jones: New Snag
description: The New York Yankees said yesterday that their attempts to sign Cleon Jones were being stalemated by the former Met outfielder's insistence on a cash bonus. As a matter of principle, said Gabe Paul, president of the Yankees, we don't give bonuses to released players. He wants a bonus for signing; we don't want to give him one. I told him that and he said, I guess we can't get together. So I gave Cleon my telephone number, and it's up to him.

title: Charter Change Proposed To Curb Mayor's Powers
description: In the midst of the city's fiscal crisis, a state commission yesterday proposed a revision of the City Charter that would curb some of the Mayor's budgetary powers and strengthen those of the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

title: Refugee Eligibility Expanded
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Attorney General Edward H. Levi today expanded the categories of Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees eligible to stay in the United States and also agreed to accept Laotians who have fled their country. A spokesman said, however, that the steps were expected to have only little effect on the total number of refugees permanently resttled in United States.

title: About New York
description: A seat is one of those commonplaces of life that rarely comes easily in New York.

title: Baker's Home Ransacked; Valuable Articles Ignored
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The house of Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., a member of the Senate intelligence committee, was broken into and ransacked last night, but the burglars apparently ignored jewelry, gold coins, camera equipment and other valuables, according to members of the Senator's staff.

title: LEVITT REPORTED LEANING TO M.A.C.
description: The effort to piece together a complex, $1billion package for the city brightened yesterday as State Controller Arthur Levitt, in a change of position, was reported to be considering investing state pension funds in Municipal Assistance Corporation securities.

title: National League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Ford's Appraisal of City Is Termed Consistent
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said today that President Ford's disparaging remarks in Yugoslavia yesterday about New York City's inability to manage its money was no departure from Mr. Ford's previous, and publicly expressed, feelings.

title: LEVITT REPORTED LEANING TO M.A.C.
description: The effort to piece together a complex, $1billion package for the city brightened yesterday as State Controller Arthur Levitt, in a change of position, was reported to be considering investing state pension funds in Municipal Assistance Corporation securities.

title: Hercule Poirot Is Dead; Famed Belgian Detective
description: Hercule Poirot, a Belgian detective who became internationally famous, has died in England. His age was unknown.

title: Ford's First Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5At the end of his first year in the White House, and the beginning of his campaign for four more years beyond 1976, President Ford must know that, even among the vast majority of his fellowcountrymen who wish him well, there is a strain of doubt.

title: Books of The Times
description: CATCH RIDES. By Sara McAulay. 256 pages. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Gulf Oil Is Indicted Over F.E.A. Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Gulf Oil Corporation, one of its subsidiaries and one of its top officers were indicted today for willful violation of Government regulations that were aimed at making sure that all domestic oil refiners received a fair share of relatively lowerpriced domestic crude oil.

title: Market Place
description: When the St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced plans to acquire the Austral Oil Company at noon yesterday, investors with long memories recalled that the Superior Oil Company had previously purchased a 20 per cent interest in Austral, and had an option to buy additional Austral shares. They thus wondered if there was to be a proxy fight.

title: 3d Angola Faction Now Set To Join Fighting if Provoked
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 5 (UPI)An Angolan nationalist movement that had remained aloof from the fighting between two other nationalist forces mobilized its troops today and ordered them to shoot back if provoked. Clashes have increased as this African territory approaches independence from Portugal.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 1975

title: BRITISH CURRENCY SAGS TO NEW LOW
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 5 (UPI)The beleaguered British pound fell today to another record low close. The dollar, which has been riding high, also showed losses for the second straight day.

title: Louisville Net Final To Vilas
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5 (UN)  Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, extending his unbeaten streak to 17 matches, defeated Rumania's Me Nastase, 64, 63, tonight in the final of the $100,000 Louisville Classic.

title: GLOUCESTER FAILS TO GAIN U.S. AID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Federal Government refused today to declare New Jersey's Gloucester County, which was hard hit by recent floods, a disaster area.

title: Catherine Bradley Married on Coast
description: Catherine Bradley and Ludlow Shonnard 3d, graduates of Colorado College, class of '73, were married yesterday in Monterey, Calif., where the Rev. Jerome Pulitzer performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Chapel.

title: Music: Herseth Sparkles on Trumpet
description: Johann Nepomuk Hummel and Adolph Herseth are not exactly household words, but they made a combination potent enough to turn the house upside down at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday, night. Mr. Herseth, who is the principal trumpet of the Chicago Symphony and quite possibly the most dazzling player on his instrument in the world today, created a happy commotion with his performance of the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in E at the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Ontario Paper to Close Its Plant for Eight Days
description: THOROLD, Ontario, Aug. 5 (AP)The Ontario Paper Company, Ltd., a unit of the Tribune Company, Chicago, said it would close its 670tonaday newsprint mill here from Aug. 30 to Sept. 8 because of the continuing weak newsprint markets.

title: In Memoriam
description: FABRICANTEsther and Hyman, Cherished memories of our dearly beloved Mother And Father. You live in our hearts always.

title: COST OF FOOD FOR 4 DOWN 0.6% IN WEEK
description: The cost of feeding a typical family of four here declined 0.6 per cent last week as measured by the 38item market basket of the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 5 (UPI)Jessie Philips gave a thumbsup signal today for the United States team's chances of winning the 10th Admiral's Cup, the world's premier ocean yacht racing series. Just watch us go if keeps windy tomorrow, said Philips, the owner of the yacht Charisma, as boats from 19 countries were prepared for tomorrow's inshore race. There was no racing today, but with two of the four races completed, the competition already has shaped into a battle among the only four nations that have won the titleAustralia, Britain, the United States and West Germany. West Germany was the halfway leader with 433 points, just 4 ahead of the United States with fivetime winner Britain third with 403 followed by Australia with 370.

title: Vikings' Exhibition Opener To Be Fiery Start for Jets
PIER L. CHERICI
description: Pier L. Cherici, an architect and a principal of Bernard M. Deschler Associates, died of a heart attack July 28. He was 62 years old and lived at 271 Cold Spring Road, Syosset, L. I.

title: Peers Win a Point; Justice Comes Out Ahead of Politics
description: LONDON, Aug. 5  The House of Lords won one last night. It was not a great victory, just enough to remind the House of Commons that the 1,074 lords and ladies of the realm can on occasion rise above constitutional disability, pageantry and eccentricity to teach a moral lesson.

title: Ranks of Nicaraguan Guerrillas Appear to Grow
description: MATAGALPA, Nicaragua, Aug. 2The rural guerrillas of Nicaragua appear to be gaining strength slowly despite a deter?? effort by the 40yearold Somoza family regime to flush them out of the mountains and cut them off from their peasant supporters.

title: RULING ON CONTEMPT IN SAXE CASE UPHELD
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has held a Lexington, Ky., student in contempt of court for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the whereabouts of Susan Saxe and Katherine Powers.

title: Wrongful Use by Boston Of U.S. Funds Indicated
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) About $25million in public funds may have been improperly spent in Boston's Model Cities program from 1969 to 1973. Federal auditors say.

title: Symmetry Is One of the Goals of the Revision
description: The architectural symmetry of New York's handsomely columned City Halla wing for the Mayor on the west, an equal wing for the City Council on the eastwould be more accurately match ed by the structural symmetry of the government that it houses under the package of revisions that the charter study commission proposed yesterday for the November ballot.

title: U.S. REPORTS GAIN IN SINAI EFFORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The State Department said today that some progress has been made but that substantial differences remained between Egypt and Israel on the terms for a new agreement on the Sinar Peninsula.

title: P.S.C. Staff Urges Denial of Increase In Con Ed Gas Fee
description: The staff of the State Public Service Commission yesterday urged that an application by the. Consolidated Edison Company for an interim annual increase in gas revenues of $39.2million be denied. The reason given was figures offered by the utility in support of the request were inadequate, inaccurate and insufficient to warrant the rise in rates.

title: Montreal Transit Strike
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 5 (UPI)One million commuters jammed major expressways and packed into commuter trains today during a oneday walkout by bus and subway drivers. The Brotherhood of Bus and Metro Drivers voted to limit their walkout to one day and authorized their union to return to the bargaining table in an effort to solve a deadlocked wage dispute.

title: Towers Was a Target Of Frequent Inquiries
description: The Towers Nursing Home has been the target of investigations and allegations of scandal involving neglect of patients and misuse of welfare and Medicaid funds for years, and has long been condemned as unsafe. Nevertheless, the home, at 2 West 106th Street, remained in operation for 15 years, until last December.

title: Carey Signs Bill Meant to End The Doctrine of Caveat Lessee
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5  This moves the law of landlord and tenant into the 20th century, Governor Carey said today, signing a bill that requires a landlord to keep leased premises in proper repairs.

title: Regional Tax Plan Hearing Set To Aid MassTransit Operation
description: A joint legislative hearing will be held here Sept. 10 to take testimony on a proposed regional tax to subsidize masstransit operations.

title: Reinstatement Barred
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused today to reinstate a defense attorney charged with attempting to get a witness to tell a lie in the Joan little trial.

title: Whole Wheat Sesame Parmesan Loaf
description: 3 cups unsifted whole wheat flour

title: Yanks and Hunter Win, 43, On Bonds's Homer in Ninth
GOING OUT Guide
description: ISN'T IT ROMANTIC? Couples who haven't yet basked in the love ballads, among other tunes, of Rogers & Hart can get in free tonight if they queue up in time for the ticket giveaway that begins at 7 P.M. at the box office of the Helen Hayes Theater, 46th Street west of Broadway. However, it's not open house. One pair of free tickets will go to the first 500 couples in line for the 7 o'clock handouts. Curtain time is 8.

title: 2 U.S. Buildings Damaged By Bombs in Seattle Area
description: EVERETT, Wash., Aug. 6 (AP)A bomb exploded early today in the Federal Office Building here, less than eight hours after another bomb exploded at the Federal Courthouse in Tacoma, the police said.

title: DRUGGISTS DEFEND VIEW ON MEDICAID
description: NEWARK, Aug. 6 CAP)Pharmacists who have stopped filling prescriptions under Medicaid are reacting with utter defiance to a state official's threat to revoke their licenses, a spokesman for the druggists said today.

title: Divorced Woman Charges Bias In Bid to Evict Her From Coop
description: A fashion designer who got a cooperative apartment in an alimony settlement faces eviction because she was not approved as a new owner by the cooperative's board of directors. She says the hoard had refused her because she was a divorced woman, and she has filed a sex bias charge.

title: Notes on People
description: After 20 years in the Senate, Norris Cotton of New Hampshire has wound up 100th in seniority. The 75yearold Republican, who retired Jan. 1, was sworn in yesterday to serve as his state's junior Senator by appointment of Gov. Meldrim Thomson. The seat, to be filled by a special election Sept. 16, has been in question because of the Senate's inability to decide who won last November's close election between John A. Durkin, the Democratic candidate, and Louis C. Wyman, the Republican.

title: Hoffa's Foster Son Turns Up in Detroit And Is Questioned
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6  Charles L. O'Brien, the foster son of James R. Hoffa, was questioned by Federal agents here today as the key figure in the investigation of the disappearance a week ago of the former teamsters' union president, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Steel Raises ...
description: Armco Steel's plan to raise the prices of its flatrolled products by 9 per cent is one more piece of evidence that the economy faces a resurgence of inflation before it is fairly out of the slump and the heavy unemployment.

title: American Motors Shows Quarter Profit
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6Following three consecutive quarters of losses, the American Motors Corporation had a $10.1million profit in the quarter ended June 30, the company reported today. The earnings, nevertheless, were off 47.4 per cent from the yearearlier level.

title: New Israeli Consul on Coast
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 6 (AP)Hanoch Givton, a broadcaster for Hagana, the underground Jewish Army before Israeli independence and former Israeli spokesman at the United Nations, will be the new consulgeneral in Los Angeles, officials said today. The 58yearold Mr. Givton will have the rank of ambassador. The official announcement was expected shortly.

title: STATE WILL AUDIT CITY'S HOSPITALS
description: The city's hospital systemalready embroiled with the Beame administration over the acceptable level of budget cuts as part of the current municipal belttightening  will undergo an extensive state audit of its efficiency and costs.

title: Heat Wave Killed Many Hens; Egg and Chicken Prices to Rise
description: Record temperatures in New. England during the recent heat wave killed more than 125,000 chickens, mostly laying hens, in Connecticut; 50,000 in Massachusetts and 1.5 million in Maine.

title: Guessing Game for Carpet Shoppers
description: A handsome collection of rugs at a New Jersey carpet chain may start something of a guessing game among customers. Some people may decide they're American Indian rugs; others may be convinced they're from North Africa, and quite a few may opt for Western Asia as the provenance.

title: Working Man's Candidate Gets Runoff Spot in Mississippi Race
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 6An Aug. 26 runoff for the Democratic nomination for Governor in Mississippi was assured today between Lieut. Gov. William Winter, 52yearsold, a veteran of state politics, and Cliff Finch, 47, a Batesville attorney and selfstyled working man's candidate.

title: In Watts a Decade Later: Poverty in Ashes of Riots
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6Ten years after the fires of the era of the long hot summer were kindled in Watts, the black ghetto on the south side of Los Angeles has lapsed into a cold autumn of desperation.

title: Concerts Alfresco Acoustically Sound
description: When the New York Philharmonic plays at Avery Fisher Hall. 2,832 people hear the concerts, the farthest some 130 feet from the stage.

title: Jones Mersereau, 88, Dies; Davis Cup Selection Official
description: Jones W. Mersereau, a realestate executive and tennis official, died Tuesday at the Whitehall Manor Nursing Home in Hyannis, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in South Yarmouth, Mass.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Con Edison reported that its customers used more electricity, about 255 million kilowatt hours, during the heat wave last weekend than on any other weekend in the history of the utility. The previous weekend record, 234 million kilowatt hours, was set on Sept. 1 and 2, 1973, the first two days of a Labor Day weekend.

title: Refining and Inventories Of Gasoline Rose in Week
KENT PLAINTIFFS REST THEIR CASE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 6Attorneys for the victims of the 1970 Kent State shootings rested their case today. In 12 weeks, 76 witnesses appeared and the transcript is more than, 10,000 pages long.

title: Millar Northrop Chairman; Jones Still Chief Executive
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6The Northrop Corporation announced today that directors of the scandalwracked aerospace company had elected Richard W. Millar, 76 years old, as charman of the board.

title: I66: End of the Road
description: The veto of a longfought sixlane highway across Virginia's northern counties into Washington is more than good news in its own right. It is heartening promise of a new attitude in the Department of Transportation, where Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. has just taken charge.

title: Suits on Offshore Oil Being Prepared by Some States
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6Several states are preparing to lob obtructive lawsuits a?? the Interior Department if ?? proceeds with its schedule of auctioning offshore oil extraction rights to oil companies, authoritative sources say.

title: Ford Seeks $20Million Aid in Crime Control
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)President Ford asked Congress today to appropriate an additional $20.4million to reinforce Federal anticrime operations in big cities.

title: Dow Average Rises 3.52, But Declines Top Gains
description: The stock market, still wary over signs of an inflationary upsurge in the economy, turned mixed yesterday. Declines again topped advances on the day, but the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed modestly higher.

title: Inquiry Asked by M.P.
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 6 (UPI)John Fraser, a member of the Canadian Parliament from Vancouver, asked today for a full study of the Transport Ministry's policy of allowing some airtraffic control to be conducted in French.

title: Expecting Humor, Jews Get Feminism Lecture
description: One hundred young Jewish leaders of the future met in Howard Samuels' West Side apartment the other night, expecting to hear titillating things about the socalled Jewish American Princess. Instead, theygot a lecture on feminism.

title: Subway Graffiti Campaign Given Lower Priority
description: A youthful army of spraygun commandos estimated at no more than 400 has not only painted Scrawls on nearly all of the 6,700 subway cars; it has also painted the Transit Authority into a corner.

title: Bridge
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 6The Life Master Pairs championship ended in a photofinish in the early hours of this morning, with two official decisions playing a substantial part in the final standings.

title: FORD INTERVIEW ON FIRING LINE
description: Jack Anderson's filmed interview with President Ford on the subject of the American Bicentennial, which all the networks had declined to televise, will be aired on William F. Buckley Jr.'s weekly publictelevision series, Firing Line, in conjunction with a discussion on network policies that bar the use of freelance journalism.

title: Chess:
description: Having a queenside pawn majority is a strategic weapon that was heavily touted by Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894. A pawn majority of whatever size, 43, 32, or 21, can be made to yield a passed pawn. which in turn produces an incipient threat to make new queen.

title: Brazil Raising Prices Sharply On Exports of Instant Coffee
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 6 (UPI)Brazil, whose coffee crop was 70 per cent destroyed by frost two weeks ago, announced huge increases today, in the export prices of instant coffee.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Notes on People column in some editions of The New York Times on Tuesday stated that Eric M. Javits practiced law with his father, Benjamin A. Javits. The elder Mr. Javits died May 18, 1973, and his son is now the senior partner in the law firm of Javits & Javits.

title: CocaCola Raises Quarter's Net 16.2% to a Record
Free Meals Ending For 2,000 Employes At a State Hospital
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., Aug 6In what may be a sign of the times, the free lunch has ended in Valhalla.

title: Gunman Slain, 3 Hostages, Suspect Hurt in ShootOut
description: A holdup man was killed and an alleged accomplice was injured last night after they took three persons hostage, from a lower Manhattan printing office and tried to escape with a $20,000 cash payroll.

title: Moscow Accuses China on Asian Role
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6The Soviet Union, in a new burst of press criticism, has accused China of plotting to extend her hegemony over Southeast Asia.

title: Ford Signs Bill on Voting Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)President Ford signed a sevenyear extension today of the Voting Rights Act, which in the last decade has enfranchised more than a million blacks in Southern states.

title: PETER DAUBENY, LONDON PRODUCER
description: LONDON, Aug. 6Sir Peter Daubeny, the London impresario who spent the last quarter of a century bringing foreign theater companies and performers to the West End, died today of a brain tumor. He was 54 years old.

title: Miss New York (Boat) Is Sold for $50,000
description: Miss New York, a ferryboat that plied the waters between Staten Island and Manhattan for 37 years, is about to embark for unknown waters.

title: PANEL TO STUDY RIGHTS OF PRIVACY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Should an individual be able to sue the Federal Government for damages for violations of his right to privacy?

title: Jail for 20 Greek ExOfficers Asked at Conspiracy Trial
description: ATHENS, Aug. 6 (UPI)The prosecutor of the Athens military tribunal called today for the conviction and imprisonment of 20 former officers on trial for conspiring to overthrow the Government of Premier Constantine Caramanlis.

title: Elderly Will Still Pay Half Fare on Transit
description: When the 50cent transit fare goes into effect Sept. 1, the elderly will continue to pay halffare during nonpeak hours, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: SEOUL LOSES IN U.N., SO U.S. WILL VETO SAW AND HANOI
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The United Nations Security Council refused today to consider South Korea's application for membership in the United Nations. The United States retaliated by announcing that it would veto membership for South Vietnam and North Vietnam.

title: FORD INTERVIEW ON FIRING LINE
description: Jack Anderson's filmed interview with President Ford on the subject of the American Bicentennial, which all the networks had declined to televise, will be aired on William F. Buckley Jr.'s weekly publictelevision series, Firing Line, in conjunction with a discussion on network policies that bar the use of freelance journalism.

title: DOWNTOWN THUG DIES IN SHOOTOUT
description: One gunman was killed, his alleged partner captured and three hostages they had seized were wounded during a shootout with the police last evening after a holdup at the office of a financial printing plant in lower Manhattan.

title: OilExploration Bids Welcomed by Saigon
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 6 (UPI) The South Vietnamese Government extended a welcome today to any government or oil company desiring to explore for oil off the nation's coastline. However, a Saigon Government spokesman said that all deals [for exploration rights] made by the puppet regime of Nguyen Van Thieu are hereby declared invalid.

title: Hanoi Reports Naval Gains
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 6 (Agence FrancePresse) North Vietnamese forces hit set on fire or sank 125 American ships during 1972, Nhan Dan, the Communist party newspaper, said today on the 20th anniversary of North Vietnam's Navy.

title: Figure in Connally Case Charged With Texas Theft
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 6 (AP) A former dairy cooperative lobbyist, Jake Jacobsen, was arrested today on theft charges stemming from a loan he made when he was an officer of a savings and loan company.

title: ... and a Civic Response
description: Even if reasonable levels of productivity can be achieved in refuse collection and other municipal departments, New Yorkers face drastic and potentially damaging cutbacks in civic services unless they revive an old and honorable American traditionthe tradition of selfhelp.

title: Ford Held Still Resolved To Veto Oil Price Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) President Ford remains determined to veto the oil price control extension bill, his press secretary said today.

title: JULIA B. FEE
description: Julia B. Fee, who for 46 years operated a Westchester realestate company bearing her name, died Tuesday at the White Plains Hospital. She was 70 and lived at 2 Fenimore Road in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Dollar in Gains Abroad as Pound Continues to Slip
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 6 (UPI)The dollar rebounded today after two days of losses to close stronger on all European mon?? markets. The pound, however, continued to slide, hitting another record, low against the dollar.

title: Eastern Wants Fare Rise
description: MIAMI, Aug. 6 (UPI)  Eastern Airlines, citing the higher cost of jet fuel, asked the Civil Aeronautic Board today for approval of fare increases on all doniestic flights and to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

title: City May Curtail Use of Central Park
description: The New York City Parks Department is considering not allowing any more rallies, ethnic festivals or similar mass events in Central Park, Edwin L. Weisl, Jr., Parks, Recreational and Cultural Affairs Administrator said yesterday.

title: Book to Help While Away Summer Hours, and Other Fun for Children
GUSTAVO VIDAL, 75; A PANAGRA FOUNDER
description: Gustavo Vidal, one of the founders of Pan AmericanGrace Airways (Panagra), died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: 30th Year of Bombing Marked by Hiroshima
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 6 (UPI)With prayers and the symbolic release of birds of peace, Japan marked the 30th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima today.

title: Aleksandr Lapauri, 49, Dancer, Choreographer at Bolshoi, Dead
description: Aleksandr Lapauri, formerly one of the Bolshoi Ballet's leading dramatic dancers and best partners, died in a car crash Tuesday, according to a report from Moscow by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: LOANS TO LEVITT BY I.T.T. DISCLOSED
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has lent $10.7million during the first half of the year to Levitt & Sons, Inc., a homebuilding company it once owned, a Governmentappointed trustee for Levitt reported yesterday.

title: Where Are They Now?
description: WASHINGTONA feature story of the week on television and in newsmagazines has been the whereabouts of the former Nixon men, one year after the fall. Since most stories are limited to a look at San Clemente and a recap of the careers of those involved in Watergate, here is wherearetheynow on the rest of the Nixon appointees.

title: A Separate Bill on Economic Aid Gains in House in New Approach
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6For the first time since the Marshall Plan for the postwar reconstruction of Western Europe, more than 25 years ago, the International Relations Committee of the House of Representatives has approved an economic aid bill separate from military aid.

title: Smith and Vorster Plan Consultations in Pretoria
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 6 (AP)  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia will hold talks here Friday with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa.

title: Freeing of Last Hostages Is Delayed in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Thursday, Aug. 7Five Japanese terrorists agreed early today to end their threeday siege here, free the 15 remaining hostages held since Monday morning and, together with four Government officials as substitutes, fly to Libya aboard a Japanese jetliner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: In Memoriam
description: BELOVEPhilip M. Aug. 7, 1972. In loving memory of our beloved husbandfather grandfather.

title: EDWARD L. TRAUBNER
description: Edward L. Traubner, vice president of Hirtz & Traubner, Inc., a diamondimporting concern of 608 Fifth Avenue, died of a heart ailment Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Great Nick, L.I.

title: Five Indicted on Charges Of Fixing Jersey Races
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6A special state grand jury indicted today five persons, including three thoroughbred horsemen, on bribery charges stemming from attempts to fix trifecta races at the recently concluded Atlantic City Race Course meeting.

title: Free Meals Ending For 2,000 Employes At Grasslands Units
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., Aug 6In what may be a sign of the times, the free lunch has ended in Valhalla.

title: BEAME TO ORDER SPENDING LIMITS AT M.A.C. URGING
description: Bowing to pressure from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he was imposing stringent ceilings over the next three years on city expenditures under his control.

title: ATOM CURB URGED BY FORD AND MIKI
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Premier Takeo Miki of Japan and President Ford agreed today to cooperate in international efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: British Crusaders Fight for Real Beer'
description: AMWELL, England  The Blue Lion. The Rose and Crown. The Bricklayer's Arms. Farmer's Boy Sportsman. Old Greyhound.

title: Bergen Defendant Cleared Of ContractRigging Plot
description: NEWARK, Aug. 6 (AP) Superior Court Judge John A. Ackerman here has dismissed conspiracy charges against a Bergen County businessman and Democratic fundraiser, George Katz.

title: School in South Carolina To Admit Single Blacks
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.. Aug. 6 (UPI)Bob Jones University, will admit, unmarried black students for the first time Sept. 3.

title: People and Business
description: Cenco, Inc., a company that manufactures laboratory equipment and healthcare products and has branched into convalescent home management and pollution control, ran into trouble earlier this year when its auditors withdrew their opinions on its financial statements and the New York Stock Exchange suspended trading on June 23. Yesterday, Ralph C. Read resigned his post as president and quit as a director, too.

title: Colby Says N.S.A. Tapped Phone Calls of Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6William E. Colby, director of Central Intelligence, told a House committee today that the National Security Agency eavesdropped on telephone calls made by Americans in this country.

title: Market Place
description: It has been well over a year since Consolidated Edison omitted its dividend and sent the entire list of utility stocks into a tailspin.

title: Amin Says He'll Return 6 Jet Fighters to Israel
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 6 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda today dismissed his air force commander and said he would return to Israel several jet fighters whose presence has brought criticism from some of his Arab supporters.

title: Biggest Burn Center in U.S. Is Planned At New York Hospital With Private Aid
description: A major center for the treat ment of severe burn cases, recognized as a badly needed facility in the city, will be built with private funds at the New York HospitalCornell Me dical Center, Mayor Beame an nounced yesterday at City Hall.

title: Labor Peace Sought at Racquet Factory
description: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 6In an attempt to end a bitter, 12week strike against the Head ski plant here, which manufactures the Arthur Ashe model tennis racquet as well as one of the country's most popular lines of skis, a Federal mediator in Washington, D. C., has brought labor and management together for new negotiations.

title: Apollo Crew Plans Departure Today For Ford Meeting
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 6  The three Apollo astronauts, who have been under treatment here since July 25, will leave tomorrow for Washington, where they and their families will meet President Ford, but it may take another month to determine whether they have lung complications.

title: SUNOCO IS PLANNING TO DIFFUSE 4 UNITS
description: The Sun Oil Company of Philadelphia announced yesterday that it intended to decentralize its operations and might sell stock to the public in some of its subsidiaries.

title: 2,300 Scientists Petition U.S. to Reduce Construction of Nuclear Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 It a petition presented to the White House and Congress more than 2,300 scientists warned today that the danger of nuclear power were so grave that the United States should make a drastic reduction in the construction of new reactors.

title: Boston Players Triumph In Lucid Mostly Mozart
description: Chamber music performances by ad hoc ensembles that have not had time to develop either individuality or technical cohesion are, unfortunately, among any music season's common events, Such playing, which may he accurate and even fitfully brilliant, generally gives only the palest hint of what chamber music is supposed to be all about.

title: Indiana Stars Lose
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (UPI)The Indiana AllStars lost their second consecutive basketball game to a Moscow junior team, 8674, today, and now have dropped three of four games against two Soviet teams.

title: SEOUL LOSES IN U.N., SO U.S. WILL VETO SAIGON AND HANOI
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The United Nations Security Council refused today to consider South Korea's application for membership in the United Nations. The United States retaliated by announcing that it would veto membership for South Vietnam and North Vietnam.

title: C.I.A. SOUGHT GUARDS DURING '71 PROTESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  The Central Intelligence Agency asked that 500 Federal troops be stationed at its headquarters to protect the building during a 1971 antiwar demonstration, according to documents filed today in Federal District Court.

title: Lucchesi Pact Extended
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 6 (UPI)Frank Lucchesi, hired last month to replace the dismissed Billy Martin, was given today a oneyear extension on his contract to manage the Texas Rangers. Lucchesi signed originally only to finish the 1975 season.

title: Twelve Months On
description: It will be a year on Saturday. The long drama ended in a rush: The last wounded speech to the White House staff, the flight west, then the new President saying, The Constitution works. We were exhausted, relieved, amazed to be free at last of Richard Nixon.

title: U.S. Energy Unit Asks New Octane Code
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Federal Energy Administration proposed a step today aimed at clearing up consumer confusion over octane ratings for gasoline.

title: APPOINTEE MAY GET POST AS S.C.I. HEAD
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6 (AP)A spokesman for Governor Byrne said today that there was a strong likelihood Mr. gbyrne nor would eventually seek to name his own appointed to head the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's impossible to deny what Michael J. Arlen has accomplished in Passage to Ararat, a sequel to the portrait of his family he presented in his earlier book, Exiles. It's hard to resist its impact as autobiography. For he begins by reminding us of the confused upbringing he described so effectively in Exileshow his father, a successful novelist of the nineteentwenties, changed his name from Dikran Kouyoumdjian to Michael Arlen, and forever after sought to mask his Armenian heritage behind a veneer of English urbanity; and how he himself grew up puzzled and slightly shamed by his background. Yet at the climax of the book we find Mr. Arlen in Soviet Armenia, standing in the shadow of Mount Ararat before a Monument to Armenian Martyrs, moved to the point of tears by a sense of reconciliation with his cultural past. And what takes place in between is recounted touchingly enough to make us weep with him.

title: NEW GUIDES SET UP BY ACTORS EQUITY
description: Actors Equity Association, in a move to protect its members from possible exploitation, has established new guidelines for showcase productions.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced another postponement yesterday in its annual stockholders' meeting because of continuing discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission on commissions and other payments made by Lockheed in connection with sales abroad.

title: Mrs. Young Leads on 68 In England
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 6 (AP)Donna Young, carding an, eagle and nine birdies, posted a sixunderpar 68 today and gained a twostroke lead after the first round of the European open at Sunningdale.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Notes on People column in some editions of The New York Times on Tuesday stated that Eric M. Javits practiced law with his father, Benjamin A. Javits. The elder Mr. Javits died May 18, 1973, and his son is now the senior partner in the law firm of Javits & Javits.

title: Fighting in Jail Put Down
description: BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  One hundred fifty policemen put down racial fighting by 75 to 100 inmates of the Charles Street jail that broke out at lunch time today.

title: Sets, Down by 1510, Gain 2220 Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 6 The New York Sets rallied in the last two events tonight, to defeat the Hawaii Leis, 2220, in World Team Tennis before 5,554 fans in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Vincent Sardi's dinnertheater in Franklin Square, L. L, which since last September had brought a bit of Broadway to Nassau County, has closed its doors for lack of working capital.

title: The Ballet: La Sylphide
description: The National Ballet of Canada offered two faces of Romanticism, as well as two views of Rudolf Nureyev at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night. The ballets were Bournonville's 1836 Danish classic, La Sylphide, in a production by Erik Bruhn, and John Neumeier's Don Juan, a work originally created in Germany and restaged a couple of seasons ago for Mr. Nureyev and the Canadians.

title: Yogi Berra
description: On his way to the baseball Hall of Fame, Yogi Berra spent 17 summers observing the methods of managers named Bucky Harris, Casey Stengel and Ralph Houk. You can see a lot by observing, he said. Then he tried his hand and brain at the job, and steered the Yankees to a pennant in his first year. In that autumn of 1964 the Yankees lost the seventh game of the World Series to Bob Gibson and the St. Louis Cardinals. The next day Berra was out of a job.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY COOL TO RECALL
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6Governor Byrne has asked the leaders of the taxweary State Assembly to consider a quick return here to the State House to draft legislation that would place a number of bond referendums on the November ballot. However, a check today with state legislators indicated that the lawmakers were sticking to their plan to take a month's vacation.

title: Reporter's Notebook: In Paris, Beating the Heat and the Pavement
description: PARISThe weather supplanted hemlines as the prime topic of conversation during the couture shows here. Some didn't recall such a prolonged hot spell in 10 or 15 years, but Stella Hanania, the veteran couture buyer at I. Magnin, had the last word. Paris hadn't been so hot since Christian Dior's New Look show in 1947, she insisted, and nobody disagreed.

title: Hoffa's Foster Son Turns Up in Detroit And Is Questioned
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6  Charles L. O'Brien, the foster son of James R. Hoffa, was questioned by Federal agents here today as the key figure in the investigation of the disappearance a week ago of the former teamsters' union president, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Felony Charge Dropped
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 6 (UPI) A felony charge against Morris Dees, a lawyer, was dropped today, and he withdrew his legal efforts to rejoin the Joan Little defense team.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A selfstyled consumer research organization asked the state to adopt regulations requiring public notice of safety precautions in connection with the operation of nuclear power plants in New Jersey. The New Jersey Public Interest Research Group asked the Board of Public Utility Commissioners to adopt the regulation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP)Darrell Pace of Reading, Ohio, became the first person ever to surpass 1,300 points in a registered archery meet with a 1,316 score today in the National Archery Association target tournament at Miami University. The feat represented 144 arrows fired from four distances over a twoday period. Pace, the defending champion, also snapped his national record of 1,291. He also set records with a 309 from 90 meters, 331 from 70 meters and 326 from 50 meters and was 3 points shy of the national mark with a 347 from 30 meters. The scores were out of possible 360's.

title: Kent Recalled
description: We are men and women now, but we still do not fully understand the events that swept us up in emotions when we were students at Kent State Universiy in 1970. Our lives were touched then by the last tragic chapter of domestic strife in the Vietnam era: The real tragedy, of course, that the epilogue has still been left unresolved.

title: The Astaires' Mother Dies
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 6 (AP)Ann Geilus Astaire, mother of Fred Astaire and his former dancing partner Adele Astaire Douglass died July 29 of a stroke at her son's home here, a family spokesman said today. Her age was 96. Besides her son and daughter, who lives in Phoenix, Ariz., and Ireland, she is survived by three grandchildren.

title: ATOM CURB URGED BY FORD AND MIKI
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Premier Takeo Miki of Japan and President Ford agreed today to cooperate in international efforts to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Machinery Orders Are Up
description: The dollar value of new orders for nonelectrical machinery in June edged up 2 per cent from the May figures, but was still 13 per cent below the value in June, 1974, according to McGrawHill's department of economics. The cornpany said machinery orders had now risen on a monthtomonth basis for the fourth consecutive month.

title: Lawmaker Assails Programs to Alter Convicts' Behavior
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Representative Ralph Met calfe, Democrat of Illinois, says behavior modification techniques used on some Federal prisoners is barbaric and should be stopped.

title: ProCommunist Units Rally in Portugal
description: OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 6  About 4,000 representatives of proCommunist trade unions, neighborhood commissions, municipal councils and other leftwing associations cheered Portugal's military triumvirate here today and demanded the immediate imprisonment of the fascist terrorists.

title: Canadian Pilots See Disaster From Traffic Control in French
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 6 (UPI)The leader of Canada's airline pilots warned yesterday that a disaster of major proportions would result from the introduction of French as a second language in airtraffic communications.

title: Department Stores Lifted Sales in July, But Rain Cut Gains
description: An overabundance of rain and lowerthannormal temperatures tended to hold down the volume of retail sales in New York department stores last month.

title: Pact on Oil Compensation In Venezuela Called Near
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 6An agreement for compensating foreignowned oil companies that will be nationalized sometime this year has almost been reached, according to former Venezuelan President Romulo Betancourt.

title: Advertising
description: The marketing of food products took on an additional requirement on July 1 when a new ruling by the Food and Drug Administration took effect. This ruling, requiring that food products that advertise and promote nutritional value clearly list nutrition information on their labels, is expected to lead to a further emphasis on this aspect in the years ahead.

title: Amex Prices Drift Down as OTC Issues Advance
description: American Stock Exchange prices drifted lower again yesterday in light trading, with the index down 0.20 to 87.13 Volume rose to 1.8 million shares from 1.7 million the previous day.

title: U.S. Denial of Flood Aid Jolts Gloucester Farmers
description: GLASSBORO, Aug. 6 Gloucester County farmers and officials expressed astonishment today that Federal authorities once again had rejected the county for quick flood disaster relief.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The rate of increase in straighttime wages and salaries of whitecollar and workers in New York City's private sector accelerated between April, 1973, and April, 1974. But it failed to keep pace with the rise in consumer prices in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: GRAIN SHIP PARLEY WITH RUSSIANS SET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reuters)The Maritime Administration said today it had invited Soviet officials to Washington on Aug. 18 to discuss substantially increased rates for the Russians to move grain purchased in the United States.

title: New Lisbon Press Proposals Threaten the Few Free Papers
description: LISBON, Aug. 6The Ministry of Information has proposed stringent regulations for the news media, provoking fear among journalists here for what remains of a free and independent press in Portugal

title: Morry Weiss, Controller Of Graphic Arts Union, 63
description: Morry Weiss, controller of the Graphic Arts International Union and financial adviser for the 130,000member organization for 19 years, died Tuesday in Cleveland. He was 63 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: THOMAS KARSELL 3D
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (UPI) Thomas G. Karsell 3d, managing editor of the Greenville (Miss.) Delta DemocratTimes at the time it won a Pulitzer Prize in the late nineteenforties for a series on Mississippi race relations, died today at the age of 55.

title: Air Pilots Willing to Talk
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP) An Air Line Pilots. Association spokesman said today that the pilots' union was prepared to sit at the bargaining table with Northwest Airlines and the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. However, he said that no talks had been scheduled between the 1,500 pilots and the Minneapolisbased airline.

title: Concerts Alfresco Acoustically Sound
description: When the New York Philharmonic plays at Avery Fisher Hall, 2,832 people hear the concerts, the farthest some 130 feet from the stage.

title: Joan Little Death Sentence Is Barred, But Judge Lets Lesser Charges Stand
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 6Judge Hamilton H. Hobgood barred today the possibility of a death sentence for pan Little by ruling that the state's case against her was insufficient to support a charge of firstdegree murder.

title: California Court Fight Involves Control of The Berkeley Barb
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 6Control of The Berkeley Barb, the underground newspaper that emerged with the radical movement here, is involved in a bitter court battle between Max Scherr, the paper's 59earold founder, and Beatrice Jane Peters, 37, who was the paper's business manager for years.

title: About the Giants . . .
description: Ricky Townsend is kicking barefoot again. I feel 100 per cent better with the shoe off, the 6foot2inch rookie said yesterday, after 14 successful kicks in a row, including a 47yarder, in practice. Townsend had been wearing a shoe on his right foot. Coach Bill Arnsparger, who is trying to decide among Townsend, Pete Gogolak, Jim O'Brien and George Hunt, said we'll have two charts on himwith shoe and without shoe. . . An allveteran starting lineup was listed by Arnsparger for Sunday night's exhibition opener against the Patriots in Foxboro, Mass. On offense, Bob Hyland, center; John Hicks and Tom Mullen, guards; Doug Van Horn and Willie Young, tackles; Bob Tucker, tight end; Walker Gillette and Ray Rhodes, wide receivers; Craig Morton, quarterback; Ron Johnson and Larry Watkins, running backs. On defense, Roy Hilton and Jack Gregory, ends; John Mendenhall and Jim Pietizak, tackles; Brian Kelley, Pat Hughes and Andy Selfridge, linebackers; Bobby Brooks and Henry Stuckey, cornerbacks; Clyde Powers, strong safety; Pete Athas or Spider Lockhart, free safety.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: U.S. Store Executive Kidnapped From His Home by 6 in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia Aug. 6 (UPI)Five men and a woman kidnapped an American business executive from his Bogota home yesterday, striking his maid and firing a shot that narrowly missed his chauffeur.

title: Company Reduces Dividend
description: Directors of the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company voted yesterday to reduce the dividend to 30 cents from 50 cents quarterly, payable Sept. 8 to shareholders of record Aug. 20.

title: Mets Dismiss Berra and Name McMillan
description: New York baseball was struck by its second blockbuster of the week yesterday when Yogi Berra was dismissed as manager of the Mets and replaced by one of his coaches, Roy McMillan.

title: SOVIET ENDORSES HELSINKI ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6The Soviet Union formally endorsed today the declaration signed last Friday at the European security conference in Finland and it said that Moscow would act precisely to live up to the agreements.

title: CITY MAY TRIM USE OF CENTRAL PARK
description: The Parks Department is considering not allowing any more rallies, ethnic festivals or similar mass events in Central Park, Edwin L. Weisl, Jr., Parks, Recreational and Cultural Affairs Administrator, said yesterday.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Vincent Sardi's dinnertheater in Franklin Square, L.I., which since last September had brought a bit of Broadway to Nassau County, has closed its doors for lack of working capital.

title: Jersey Assembly Is Cool To Plea for Extra Session
description: TRENTON, Aug. 6Governor Byrne has asked the leaders of the taxweary State Assembly to consider a quick return here to the State House to draft legislation that would place a number of bond referendums on the November ballot. However, a check today with state legislators indicated that they were sticking to their plan to take a month's vacation.

title: METHADONE USERS WIN WORK RULING
description: A policy that prevented all methadone users from working for the Transit Authority was declared unconstitutional yes terday by Judge Thomas P. Griesa in Federal District Court here.

title: In Paris There's a Bookstore That Is a Story in Itself
description: PARIS, Aug. 6At 37 Rue de la Bucherie, opposite Notre Dame Cathedral, is one of the most unusual and disarming bookstores in the world where, if you're so inclined, you may spend the day without buying, and if you're tired and broke and if it's O.K. with George, the ownerwhich it usually is if there are not too many guests already  you may have tea, stay for dinner, help with the washing up and bunk down for the night.

title: FOOD STAMP DATA NEED SUPPESSED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Ford Administration suppressed portions of a food stamp report by the Department of Agriculture that did not support the Administration's attempt to cut back the program, Senator George McGovern charged today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mets Dismiss Berra and Name McMillan
description: New York baseball was struck by its second blockbuster of the week yesterday when Yogi Berra was dismissed as manager of the Mets and replaced by one of his coaches, Roy McMilian.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Israel and the Future of the United Nations Ideal
description: JERUSALEMWhat does the United Nations want to bean instrument for solving conflicts or an arena for waging them? For three decades it has been torn between its diplomatic role and its parliamentary fantasies. It cannot have it both ways, for the two principles are contradictory.

title: FordP.L.O. Encounter And How It Came About
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) President Ford met briefly with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Bucharest over the weekend, the State Department said today.

title: The Garbage Mess ...
description: The persisting pileup of garbage and trash on city streets is a noisome symbol of the city's fiscal crisis and glaringly symptomatic of the shortcomings that helped precipitate itnotably, municipal mismanagement and union greed.

title: Japanese Rebels to Free 15 and Take Off for Libya
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Thursday, Aug. 7Five Japanese terrorists agreed early today to end their threeday siege here, free the 15 remaining hostages held since Monday morning and, together with four Government officials as substitines, fly to Libya aboard a Japanese jetliner.

title: Dismissals Confuse U.S.Aided Workers
description: Many of the 1,466 employes to be dismissed from a federally financed public service jobs program were confused and angry yesterday when they received word that they would lose their jobs by tomorrow.

title: Grass Seed Farms Fight Curb on Burning
description: SUBLIMITY, Ore.It starts with a tiny puff of smoke in a field. But within seconds it becomes a giant column of dirty gray smoke billowing upwards thousands of feet. The 15foottall bright orange flames sound like waterfalls as they race across the fields consuming in their intense heat tons of dried grasses, insects, weeds and rodents.

title: BERNARD R. GOODMAN
description: Bernard R. Goodman, a vice president of Warner Bros., died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: Employment Uncertainties Haunting French Workers
description: VALENCAY, FranceRobert Baumard, a foreman at a metal finishing factory near here, used to go to Spain on his August vacation, but this year, he said, I am not going that far away.

title: C.B.O.E. Trading Is Up
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP)Trading activity in July on the Chicago Board Options Exchange rose 23 per cent over last year and marked the fifth straight month that total volume exceeded one million contracts traded. The July volume was a record of 1.407,453 call option contracts traded. The previous month, volume totaled 1,114,353 contracts. The July dollar volume, based on the price paid for an option, was a record $16million.

title: Torrid Orioles Win, 42, 82
description: A few days ago, baseball observers virtually conceded the American League's Eastern Division title to the Boston Red Sox. They had a 9game lead over their closest pursuers, the Baltimore Orioles, as late as last Monday.

title: F.T. C. Lays Deceit to Big Loan Company
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that one of the country's biggest loan companies, Beneficial Corporation, had been deceiving consumers by offering instant tax refunds that were really loans.

title: GRUMMAN'S F14 NOW PROFITABLE
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday it had turned the tide on its F14 fighter planes and since May began making profitable deliveries on the aircraft.

title: More White Settlers Fleeing Fighting in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  Heavy firing broke out today near an old Portuguese fort here where some 600 men of one of the two warring independence movements retreated last month.

title: CITY FISCAL NEEDS GROW NEXT MONTH
description: Even as they worked feverishly yesterday to find sources for the $950million the city needs for August, officials of the city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation were projecting $885million in borrowing needs by the end of September that would probably be much more difficult to raise.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Notes on People
description: After 20 years in the Sentte, Norris Cotton of New Hampshire has wound up 100the in seniority. The 75yearold Republcan who retired Jan. 1, was sworn in yesterday to serve as his state's junior Senator by appointment of Gov. Meldrim Thomson. The seat, to be filled by a special election Sept. 16, has been in question because of the Senate's inability to decide who won last November's close election between John A. Durkin, the Democratic candidate, and Louis C. Wyman, the Republican.

title: Pulliam's Son Is Publisher
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP) Eugene S. Pulliam has succeeded his late father, Eugene C. Pulliam, as publisher of The Indianapolis Star and News. Mrs. Pulliam, widow of Eugene C. Pulliam, was named publisher of The Arizona Republic and Phoenix Gazette.

title: Wilmington Sunday Paper
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 6 (UPI)The News Journal Company, publisher of The Morning News and The Evening Journal, today announced plans for publishing a Sunday newspaper in Wilmington. Norman E. Isaacs, president and publisher, said, The Philadelphia papers have been treating this as a colony for years. The News Journal is simply declaring its independence and moving to recapture its own ground.

title: Soviet Names Statistics Chief
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (AP)The head of the Central Statistical Administration has retired, Tass reported today. Vladimir N. Starovsky, 70 years old, who tips held the post since 1948, was replaced by Lev M. Volodarsky, his first deputy chief since 1967.

title: PAY RISES LAGGED IN PRIVATE SECTOR
description: The rate of wage and salary increases for whitecollar and nonproduction blue  collar workers in New York City's private sector accelerated between April, 1973, and April, 1974, but failed to keep pace with the rise in consumer prices.

title: NEW GAINS REPORTED IN JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UN) A record high of more than 6.6 million persons were receiving unemployment insurance benefits during the week ended July 19, the Labor Department announced today.

title: As Fighting on Border Grows, So Does Burma's Fear of China
description: RANGOON, BurmaThe specter of China, which shares a 1,300mile, frontier with Burma and has been a source of fear since Burmese independence in 1948, looms even larger after the Communist victory in Indochina, officials sources and other Burmese report.

title: 18Day Bill Planned to Help Keep Pace With Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Treasury Department disclosed today that it would have to borrow more in the markets in the next few weeks than it had originally planned.

title: Officials of Civic Groups Cool To Some Charter Revision Plans
description: Officials of three politically potent civic organizations expressed reservations yesterday about various proposals to revise the City Charter as the state commission that proposed the revisions prepared to spend at least $200,000 to promote the suggestions.

title: GURNEY CLEARED OF FIVE CHARGES AT FLORIDA TRIAL
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 6Former Senator Edward J. Gurney, a Florida Republican who was a member of the Senate Watergate committee, was acquitted by a Federal District Court jury today of five felony charges stemming from an election campaign fundraising operation.

title: In Watts a Decade Later: Poverty in Ashes of Riots
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6Ten years after the fires of the era of the long hot summer were kindled in Watts, the black ghetto on the south side of Los Angeles has lapsed into a cold autumn of desperation.

title: Two Others Fallow Suit in Unsettled Bond Market
description: An $80million bond issue planned by Con Edison and two other scheduled offerings were postponed yesterday because of unsettled conditions in the bond market. This brought to five an unprecedented figure, underwriting executives said the number of postponed issues within the last two days. The capital market has the jitters, one dealer declared. Fears of rekindled inflation, combined with recent credittightening moves by the Federal Reserve, have depressed prices of Treasury securities and concurrently sent yields to their highest levels of 1975.

title: Field at Firestone Worries Trevino
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 6It may be part of that legendary hustling of his, but Lee Trevino says he is not playing well enough for a successful defense of his title in the 57th Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: Moderate Quake on Coast
description: OROVILLE, Calif., Aug. 6 (UPI)A moderate earthquake, Jarred the Sacramento Valley last night, but no injuries were, reported. A University of California seismologist at Berkeley said that the temblor, which registered 4.9 on the Richter scale, was centered near this rural community, which was shaken by a series of tremors beginning last Friday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Salmon Thrill
description: GASPE, QuebecIt was 10 o'clock in the morning when he stood on the high bank overlooking the home pool at Earle R. MacAusland's' salmon lease on the York River.

title: Movie: Another Disney:One of Our Dinosaurs' Is Stranded Fossil
description: Near the start of "One of Our Dinosaurs Is Missing" Derek Nimmo, an Englishman smuggling a secret formula out of China, is carried to the Tibetan border by an Abominable Snowman and dumped. "Thanks for the lift, old boy," he says.It is hard to say whether this is funny in some absolute sense or only seems so because the rest of this Walt Disney picturethe fifth new one since the beginning of July, givng new meaning to the notion of a long hot summeris so bleak.Mr. Nimmo arrives in London and is pursued and captured by a Chinese agent, played by Peter Ustinov, and his gang. They are made up to look like men made up to look Chinese. Against this crew is ranged Mr. Nimmo's old NannyHelen Hayeswho recognizes him when he is hiding the formula in the neckbone of a dinosaur in the Natural History Museum.Miss Hayes enlists the entire South Kensington nanny squad to help her, and the picture is full of stratagems, chases and battles as nannies and Chinese struggle for the formula and for Mr. Nimmo. At one point the nannies wrest the dinosaur from Mr. Ustinov's men and race it around the countryside in bored steam truck.The plot is neither particularly good nor particularly bad. What makes the picture so bad is the mechanical and unbelieving way in which Mr. Ustinov, Miss Hayes and their troops grind it out. Slapstick whimsey demands real belief by its performers. The swindle this picture inflicts on the children who will go to see it is precisely that of some bored magician at a birthday party who doesn't bother to wear a clean shirt or prevent the cards from showing up his sleeve.There was a time when the name Walt Disney promised much more and fulfilled at least some of the promise. So did the names Helen Hayes and Peter Ustinov.The substance described in the formula, incidentally, is Won-Ton soup. As is the movie.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILLS ON ENVIRONMENT
description: ALBANY, Aug. 6Governor Carey today signed into law a bill requiring state agencies, public authorities, counties and all other units of local government to prepare environmental impact statements before undertaking construction programs.

title: TRANSIT WORKERS GET INTERIM RAISE
description: Bus and subway workers will receive a 4centanhour increase next week because of the rising consumer price index.

title: Man Held in April Slaying Of U.S. Employe in Bronx
description: A 23yearold Bronx man was arrested last night and charged with the murder of a 21yearold. Federal employe whose nude body was found in a vacant apartment in the suspect's building last April 17.

title: U.S. VISITORS BID CHINA CURB KOREA
description: PEKING, Thursday, Aug. 7Members of a United States Congressional delegation visiting China told Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping yesterday that the United States is committed to defending South Korea against any attack by North Korea.

title: At Met Museum, a Show for the Blind
description: It is not every day that an exhibition covers the whole gamut of human communication, from the most primitive thumps and grunts to systems as sophisticated as any devised. Such as the scope, however, of To Touch and Hear, which opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show will be there through Aug. 29, before beginning an extended outoftown tour.

title: Satellite Launching Delayed
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 6 (AP)The launching of an international scientific satellite designed to study extraterrestrial gamma radiation was postponed today by a mechanical malfunction in a tracking aircraft. The European Space Agency's CosmicB spacecraft was tentatively rescheduled for launcing Aug. 8 at 6:40 P.M.

title: Beame Considers Rehiring of Some Sanitationmen
description: Less than a week after rescinding the threatened layoff of 750 sanitationmen, Mayor Beame promised yesterday to consider rehiring men to cornpensate for the loss of 195 who retired in July.

title: ...Need for a Policy
description: Before this drearyand dangerousscenario is allowed to play itself out, the Administration and Congress should reexamine the need for a broad system of industrial price and wage restraints.

title: Rested Connors and Laver Win
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 6 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors, playing in his first tournament, since he lost the Wimbledon final early last month, and Rod Laver, playing in his first event in nine weeks, won today in a $100,000 international tennis tournament.

title: W .78 St. Residents Protest Plan For a Community Health Center
description: Charging that the West Side has become a dumping ground for welfare, medical and drug rehabilitation programs, the West 78th Street Block Association said yesterday that it would seek to bar an attempt to relocate a community health center on the street.

title: Cosmos Win Finale, 10
description: Playing with zeal but ineffectively, the New York Cosmos closed their North American Soccer League season last night with a 10 victory over the Boston Minutemen, the team that humiliated them on national television last Sunday.

title: Soviet Astronauts Released
description: The Soyuz astronauts, Lieut. Col. Aleksei A. Leonov and Valery N. Kubasov, were released from medical supervision yesterday. The Associated Press quoted Tass, the official Soivet press agency, as saying that the crewmen were in preflight form two days after their July 21 landing, but had been keptu nder supervision because of an agreement with U.S. space officials.

title: L.I. Physician Asks Lowering of Bail
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 6Dr. Charles E. Friedgood, who was indicted yesterday on charges of having murdered his wife and stolen more than $569,000, of her property, had the opportunity the motive and the means to commit the crime, a Nassau County assistant district attorney said today.

title: POLITICS STUDIED IN NURSING HOMES
description: Federal and state criminal instigations of the nursing home industry are turning their attention to alleged political influence exerted on behalf of Bernard Bergman, whose indictment for stealing $1.2million from Medicaid was announced Tuesday.

title: Veto of Pay Rise Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP)  Senator Dewey F. Bartlett. Republican of Oklahoma, urged President Ford today to veto a bill giving annual costofliving raises to members of Congress, Federal judges, the President's Cabinet and other top Federal executives. The hill was passed by the Senate July 29 by a vote of 58 to 29 and by the House last Wednesday by a 214to213 margin.

title: Canada and U.S. End Meat Import Quotas
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 6Canada and the United States abolished today their mutual import quotas on livestock, thereby easing much of the tension that has marred trade relations between the two countries.

title: Health Plans' Elective Surgery Rules Questioned
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 6 (AP) A 6yearold. Maryland boy had a painful problem: a shoulder that repeatedly popped out of the socket.

title: CURBS ON COURTS PRESSED IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 6Parliament today completed ratification of special legislation to clear a court case pending against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, and one of her senior Cabinet ministers said further steps should he taken to make her office immune from judicial scrutiny.

title: 2 Inmates Killed in Fire
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 6 (UPI)Two inmates died today in a fire at the Kirkland Correctional Institution. The victims were identified as Ed Fowler, 30 years old, and James D. Belcher, 28.

title: The Mayor Acts
description: Mayor Beame's announcement that he is imposing stringent ceilings over the next three years on city expenditures under his control and forming a Management Advisory Board headed by Richard R. Shinn, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, should give a substantial boost to efforts by the Municipal Assistance Corporation to save this city from bankruptcy.

title: Rangers List 10 Preseason Games
description: The Rangers will play 10 preseason games, including Madison Square Garden appearances on Sept. 29 against the Philadelphia Flyers, the Stanley Cup champions, and against the Boston Bruins two nights later. Additionally, the Rangers will oppose the Islanders on Sunday, Oct. 5, at the Nassau Coliseum. The complete preseason schedule:

title: Mets Feel McMillan Can Turn It Around
description: At the table in the middle of the Mets' carpeted clubhouse at Shea Stadium, the daily bridge game began as it always does with Jerry Koosman and Tom Seaver trying to finesse their way past the stolid tandem of Jerry Grote and Del Unser.

title: BEAMS TO ORDER SPENDING LIMITS AT M.A.C. URGING
description: Bowing to pressure from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he was imposing stringent ceilings over the next three years on city expenditures under his control.

title: Heat Killed Hens, Putting Pressure on Price of Eggs
description: Record temperatures in New England during the recent heat wave killed more than 125,000 chickens, mostly laying hens, in Connecticut; 50,000 in Massachusetts and 1.5 million in Maine.

title: MARKET OPERATOR CHALLENGED BY SUIT
description: A Bronx market merchant filed a taxpayer's suit in State Supreme Court yesterday against the city, the Board of Estimate and the city's Economic Development Administation, seeking to nullify a 39year lease of the Arol Development Corporation, which has operated the entire market since May 1. 1972.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Security Council refused to consider South Korea's application for United Nations membership, when the vote to place it on the agenda fell two short of the required nine. The United States retaliated by announcing that it would veto the membership applications of South Vietnam and North Vietnam. These were placed on the agenda 14 to 9, with the United States abstaining. A State Department spokesman had said earlier that a package proposal to admit all three would be supported but that this country would reject a selective program of universality. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Personal Finance: Testimony by Former Wives
description: Can a wife testily against her husband? No, say more than 300 years of common law.

title: HEELING STEEL IS RAISING PRICES
description: The Wheeling  Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would raise prices on all flatrolled steel products.

title: Chicago Edison Planning To Raise $350Million
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company, the Chicagobased electric utility, reported yesterday that it would need to raise $350million by the end of the year to meet its financing requirements, which include $100million bond issue that matures in October.

title: Farmer Gets Stuck in Hot Honey Deal
description: Farmer Jones traded two plump piglets for two beehivesand got stung. It seemed like a sweet deal, all that honey for himself. The beehives were worth $125 apiece and the pigs $30 apiece.

title: Prince Alfonso de Orleans
description: SANLUCAR DE BARRAMEDA, Spain, Aug. 6 (AP)Prince Alfonso de Orleans y Borbon, a cousin of the late King Afonso XIII of Spain, died today after a heart attack in his palace in this southern Spanish town. He was 88 years old. He is survived by his widow, Princess Beatriz de Orleans of Saxe Coburgo Gotha, and two sons.

title: British Crusaders Fight for Real Beer'
description: AMWELL, England  The Blue Lion. The Rose and Crown. The Bricklayer's Arms. Farmer's Boy Sportsman. Old Greyhound.

title: A Tight End Stays Loose
description: Now that Russ Francis has convinced the New England Patriots that he can be a standout tight end in the National Football League with his size and speed, Francis is wondering how the Patriots will react to his other athletic pursuitslike flying, motorcycle races, bareback riding, scuba diving and surfing.

title: CORN FUTURES UP; SOYBEANS IN RISE
