description: Traders, still worried about insufficient rain over Iowa growing areas, pushed corn prices ahead yesterday. Soybean and wheat prices also moved up on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Simple Test Shows Fingertip Nerves Can Be Confused
description: Human fingertips, long known to contain such a density of nerve endings that they are the body's most sensitive organs of touch, may actually contain so many nerves that the signals from one type can interfere with those of another, two British researchers have found.

title: People in Sports
description: The Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association signed Bill Willoughby, a 6foot8 inch, 205pound star from Dwight Morrow High in Englewood, N. J., to a multiyear pact at more than $100,000 per year yesterday and won a signing battle with the Denver. Nuggets of the American Basketball Association. However, the victory in signing the 18yearold Willoughby, Atlanta's secondround pick, was largely by default.

title: Force ten, Crowd Set Spa Records
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6Forceten, the colt who beat Avatar and Diabolo on the West Coast, warmed up here today for the Travers by winning the $42,875 Jim Dandy Stakes. It wasn't an easy warmup. Favored at 9 10 by the largest weekday crowd in Saratoga's 113year history, the California colt had to stave off a late charge by Prince Thou Art to take the 12th running of the 1mile stakes. His winning margin was a head, his payoff $3.80 for $2. Northerly was third in the race run at a distance of more than a mile for only the fourth time.

title: GURNEY CLEARED OF FIVE CHARGES Al FLORIDA TRIAL
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 6Former Senator Edward J. Gurney, a Florida Republican who was a member of the Senate Watergate committee, was acquitted by a Federal District Court jury today of five felony charges stemming from an election campaign fundraising operation.

title: Exploration Rights Offered By Lebanon to Oil Concerns
description: BEIRUT. Aug. 6 (Reuters)Lebanon offered today international oil companies exploration rights off its coastline on a production sharing basis if oil is found. Petroleum Minister Ghassan Tweini said applications should be submitted before Sept. 10.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 7, 1975

title: PENN STATE TRUSTEE REPORTS SHAPP GIFT
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug 6 (AP)Michael Baker Jr., a millionaire who made his fortune in engineering, said today that he had personally given Gov. Milton Shapp a $20,000 cast political contribution in 1970.

title: Hussein Says He May Buy Soviet Arms
description: AMMAN, Jordon, Aug. 7King Hussein said today that if the United States Congress refused to allow Jordan to purchase 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles, he would probably turn to the Soviet Union for an airdefense system.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Galanos and Norell. For a long time, they've been in tandem, though they are different companies, on opposite sides of the country. Somehow Galanos in Los Angeles and Norell in New York have managed to capture the fancy of the richest women in the country. They know what the industrialists' wives in places such as Detroit and Chicago delight to wear.

title: Hechler Becomes Waiter To Learn Public's Tastes
description: WILLIAMSON, W. Va., Aug. 7Some coffee, sir? the new waiter asked the day's first customer at the Lock, Stock and Barrel restaurant.

title: Ford Sees Risk of Confrontation With Soviet in a Mideast War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) President Ford said today that there was a possibility of a confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union if war broke out again in the Middle East.

title: Bronx Man Pleads Guilty In 25Million Cocaine Ring
description: A ?? man described by authorities as the leader of a ring that smuggled $25million in cocaine yearly into the city from Latin America has pleaded guilty to a drugselling charge and faces a mandatory minimum sentence of six years in prison.

title: JAMES GRIFFITHS, LABOR PARTY AIDE
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  James Griffiths, one of the Labor party's most respected leaders, died today at his home at Teddington, on the outskirts of London. He was 84 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that the United Nations Security Council had voted 14 to 0, with the United States abstaining, to put on the agenda the application of South Vietnam and North Vietnam for United Nations membership. Actually, that was a preliminary vote; the final vote on the agenda was 12 nations in favor, with the United States opposed and Britain and Costa Rica abstaining.

title: INROADS REPORTED ON GARBAGE HERE
description: Either it's getting better or people are getting used to it.

title: Ford Denies He Plans To Dump Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7President Ford dismissed today as a tempest in a teapot the speculation that he is planning to dump Vice President Rockefeller from his ticket next year.

title: Carey Signs 13 NursingHome Bills
description: ALBANY, Aug. 7Governor Carey today signed 13 bills intended to curb the abuse of patients and end influence peddling in the state's nursinghome industry.

title: Public Drills Urged to Prepare For Possible APlant Disasters
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Federal Government was asked today to require office and home evacuation drills to prepare the public for possible catastrophic accidents at the nation's nuclear power plants.

title: ASBESTOS CALLED A PERIL IN HOMES
description: Residents of an entire household and neighbors in the same building where repair workers use commercial spackling, patching and jointing materials can inhale or otherwise be exposed to diseaseproducing levels of asbestos, according to resuits of a study that doctors at Mount Sinai School of Medicine published today.

title: The Hostages Relive Malaysia Nightmare
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Friday, Aug. 8The 53 hostages who were herded into little celllike rooms in the United States Embassy here Monday lived with a constant threat of violence that underlay a veneer of quiet courtesy shown them by the five Japanese terrorists who were their captors.

title: Bath Mat Company Carries King Solomon Idea a Bit Far
description: Wanted: Half a bathtub. Why? What else can I do with half a bath mat? Actually, I have two halves of a bath mat. It was once whole, but that was before it was neatly sliced in two by the Rubbermaid Company and returned to me, first class, from Wooster, Ohio.

title: Legal Aid Society Cuts Its Criminal Staff Here
description: The Legal Aid Society yesterday dismissed 25 of the 450 lawyers in its criminal defense division and 45 nonlawyers. It also notified 15 June lawschool graduates to whom it had promised jobs that they could not be hired.

title: U.S. ISSUE PRICES DROP FOR 6TH DAY
description: Government security prices declined yesterday for the sixth day in a row. The latest pullback resulted from Wall Street's surprise at the timing and the size of Treasury cash needs for the next two weeks. The Treasury's announcement, issued late Wednesday, produced an immediate markdown in prices yesterday morning by Government dealers. At the end of the session, coupon securities showed declines of  to  of a point. Trading continued extremely light in the corporate bond sector, where prices were mixed.

title: Film: 'The Devil's Rain'
description: At the start of "The Devil's Rain," which opened yesterday at the Loews State II, Tower East and neighborhood theaters, the titles flash against a Hieronymus Bosch backdrop, and a muffled wailing is heard. "Let me out," voices cry. "Let me out."By the time this latest satanism epic ends, it is clear that the wailing is a bit of auditory ectoplasm. It is the accumulated sufferings of the audience at the previous showing that are giving tongue. "The Devil's Rain" is ostensibly a horror film, but it barely manages to be a horror.The quality of writing, acting and direction give a general and routine witlessness to this movie about a devil-priest and his congregation of eyeless zombies taking revenge against a family whose forebears did them wrong some 300 years earlier.In addition, though, it has a particular and specialized witlessness that, because it occurs in various other fright pictures around, deserves mention. The film is built uponand collapses fromthe contradiction between two crafts: camera work and special effects.The special gimmick of "The Devil's Rain," its main attempted horror, is the physical transformation of the victim family as its members are captured and turned one by one into zombies. Their eyes are replaced by black holes, their flesh melts and runs at the slightest irritation, and when they are shot, orange and blue glue spurts out.But the photography  its sharp, precise color, meticulous focus, fine grain and zooming close-ups  sabotages the effects. The weave of the black cloth used to blot out the eyes shows up clearly. The stuff leaking from the bodies is foamily chemical. And when the coven is destroyed and the zombies and their master melt away, the interminable lingering of the camera on their dissolving faces only manages to make it evident that we are seeing wax or latex. It is as horrible as watching an egg fry.If we are returning to the catchup school of scary movies, we would be better off with the grainy, black-and white, underlit movies they used to make. That way we could imagine that the catchup was blood and the exposed brain something more than putty. The camera's lint-picking would not undermine things.There isn't much else to say about "The Devil's Rain." Evil, as usual in Satan films, wins. Ernest Borgnine, whose mugging seems to have developed a minor camp cultto judge from the authoritative giggling among part of the audienceplays the devil-priest. When his face is whooshed into the features of a satan-ram, you can hardly tell the difference.Keenan Wynn, Eddie Albert and Ida Lupino also appear, with and without eyes. At several of the same neighborhood theaters, a second film, "Dark Star," is beshown. The Bryanston Film people, who are releasing it, had some trouble discovering just where but finally reported that it could be found as far south as 125th Street and as far north as Delancey Street. It will be seen and noted shortly.

title: Northwest Airlines Strike Ends As Pilots Agree on 3Year Pact
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7 (UPI) Representatives of the Air Lines Pilots Association and Northwest Airlines reached tentative agreement on a new threeyear contract today, ending a threeday strike that had grounded the nation's seventh largest carrier.

title: CODD ON LAYOFFS: EFFICIENCY REMAINS
description: Despite a loss of 3,000 officers in budget cuts, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday, there has been no discernible loss in patrol and emergency services so far in the city.

title: 1,593 in City Hospitals Being Laid Off
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that it would close major sections of two hospitalsone on Staten Island and one in the Bronxand lay off a total of 1,593 employes to comply with budget cutbacks ordered by Mayor Beanie.

title: Jackie and Roy on Same Bill With Getz
description: It was 1948 when Stan Getz became a star with Woody Herman's orchestra playing Four Brothers and Early Autumn. It was also in 1948 that Jackie. Cain and Roy Kral first drew attention singing jazz duets with Charlie Ventura's orchestra. Now Mr. Getz and the team of Jackie and Roy are sharing the bill at Buddy's Place, where, just a month ago, Mr. Herman's current band appeared.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 8, 1975

title: Top Lisbon Aide Seeks To End Strife in North
description: OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 7Maj. Gen. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, chief of Portugal's security forces, flew here today to try to put an end to a wave of antiCommunist violence in the region and restore military discipline.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.03billion, up 6 per cent from the yearearlier $975million. Total retail store sales were about $11.48billion, up 6 per cent from last year's 10.798billion.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: KINGSTON, Pa.  Lee Glassman seemed calm the other day. He wasn't pacing the floor. He smiled easily.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: BLUE CROSS LAGS ON COST CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Americans who have Blue Cross health insurance are apparently paying millions of dollars extra each year because, most of the Blue Cross organizations are not imposing strict cost controls on hospitals.

title: Books of The Times
description: Iris Murdoch used to sacrifice her characters on altars of incredibility just to see the brightness of their blood in the sun. Her novels were charnel houses of the improbable. Give me liberty or give me death, her characters cried. She played with the human heart as if it was a yoyo. How many people can sleep together on the head of a pin? Love was a holiday from the humdrum. Sex was surprise.

title: Antitrust Study to Cover 1,000 Big Manufacturers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it would survey the nation's 1,000, biggest manufacturers for the first time in 25 years in a search for possible antitrust violations and other corporate wrongdoing.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Ontario Scored on U.S. Car Rebates
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 7A 5 per cent tax rebate for buyers of North American automobile in Ontario has brought that province into sharp conflict with the Federal Government, the European Economic Communty, the Japanese Government and a host of British and European automakers, who call the provincial action discriminatory.

title: JOHN ROSS HAAS, 69, SECURITIES LEADER
description: John Ross Haas, vice chairman of the Haas Securities Corporation, member of the New York and American Stock Exchanges, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a stroke, at Nantucket, (Mass.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on Nantucket Island and at 433 East 51st Street.

title: Alternatives to a Project At Tocks Island Pushed
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7With the Federal Tocks Island Dam Project apparently shelved, New Jersey is accelerating state plans to provide the water supplies and flood control that a $400million dam on the Delaware River at Tocks would have given New Jersey.

title: A BUDGET FREEZE IMPOSED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday told the heads of state agencies and departments that their budgets for the next fiscal year would, in effect, be frozen at this year's levels except for increases attributable to inflation or to the completion of new facilities.

title: State Says Some Striped Bass And Salmon Pose a Toxic Peril
description: State officials warned consumers yesterday not to eat striped bass from the Hudson River or salmon from Lake Ontario because Federal and state researchers have found that the fish contain dangerously high amounts of PCB, a toxic chemical used in a wide range of manufacturing processes.

title: Graustark Colt Sold for $200,000
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP)A colt by GraustarkFictitious sold for $200,000 today, highlighting the third night of the 55th annual FasigTipton yearling sale.

title: Bridge:
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 7The Spingold Knockout Team Championship continued here this afternoon, with 32 teams surviving from an original entry of Ill. The winner of the final, to be played next Monday, will qualify for the International Team Trials next October and become one of four teams with a chance to represent the United States in 1976 world team competition.

title: The First Ford Year: Policy Tide Is Turned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Gerald R. Ford, who came to power at a time of deep national crisis as an unelected president from a minority party, has spent much of his first year in office trying to reverse Federal social and economic policies that stretch back nearly half, a century.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that the United Nations Security Council had voted 14 to 0, with the United States abstaining, to put on the agenda the application of South Vietnam and North Vietnam for United Nations membership. Actually, that was a preliminary vote; the final vote on the agenda was 12 nations in favor, with the United States opposed and Britain and Costa Rica abstaining.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The 53 hostages who were herded into celllike rooms in the United States Embassy in Kuala Lumpur last Monday lived with a constant threat of violence that underlay a veneer of courtesy shown them by the five Japanese terrorists who were their captors. One of the 53 recalled yesterdayafter the last of the hostages had been freed and the plane carrying the terrorists had departed for Libyaa moment of unbearable tension when one terrorist, the most nervous of them all, was fiddling with a grenade he was carrying, and dropped it. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: FANEL WILL MEET ON PHARMACISIS
description: TRENTON Aug. 7 (UPI)Virginia Long Annich, director of the Division of Consumer Affairs, said today the State Pharmacy Board would meet Wednesday to consider whether to act against pharmacists who refused to fill Medicaid prescriptions.

title: JOSEPH T. GRAZIANO
description: Joseph T. Graziano, a vice president in charge of subsidy and administration of American Export Lines, died yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived in Woodbridge, N.J.

title: JOSEPH T. GRAZIANO
description: Joseph T. Graziano, a vice president in charge of subsidy and administration of American Export Lines, died yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived in Woodbridge, N.J.

title: The Happy Traveler
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7A year ago, Richard Nixon made one more maudlin, embarrassing assault on the patience and sensibility of the American people and then flew into exile in California. The old gamester left Gerald Ford behind to fill out the remaining two and onehalf years of his term.

title: ASHLAND PRESSED ON FUND DETAILS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a precedentsetting move, has asked Ashland Oil, Inc., to disclose publicly the names of foreign and domestic individuals who received several hundred thousand dollars in questionable corporate payments over the last eight years.

title: THOMAS P. GIBBS, 70, A BIGBAND PLAYER
description: Thomas Parker Gibbs, bigband musician and radio producer, died yesterday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Tenafly, N. J.

title: Economists Dismayed by Price Rises
description: The sharp rise in July's wholesale prices, reported by the Government yesterday, has lowered the spirits of many of the nation's leading economists.

title: SHELL OIL GROUP SHOWS PROFIT DIP
Computer New Field To Boulez
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 7 For the last week, Pierre Boulez, the composer and conductor, has been at Stanford University learning, learning, learning, as he put it, to use the computer as a new musical instrument and composing device.

title: Indiana Blue Cross and Shield Seek College University Corp.
description: The Indiana Blue Cross and Blue Shield organizations announced yesterday that they had executed a letter of intent with the College University Corporation of Indianapolis for a tender offer by the two organizations to acquire College. The hospital and medical groups are owned respectively by Mutual Hospital Insurance, Inc., and Mutual Medical Insurance, Inc., and are essentially nonprofit organizations.

title: The Pop Life
description: Willie Nelson is a grizzled Texan in his early 40's who never really made it big. But if Charlie Rich made it relatively late in life, so can Mr. Nelson; certainly he deserves whatever success he can get.

title: Smog Widespread In Rural Areas,Too, A U.S. Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) The Government reported today that smog in both rural and urban areas was more widespread than originally thought and that it might be necessary to extend pollution controls into the countryside.

title: F.B.I. Intelligence and Counterespionage Budget Is $82.5Million
description: WASHINGTON Aug 7The Federal Bureau of Investigation is spending a secret $82.5million a year for its intelligence gathering and counterespionage activities, the House Select Committee on Intelligence was told today.

title: Aide Says Ford Bars Calling Special Session
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP)President Ford has no intention of calling Congress back to special session to consider extension of oil price controls, the President's press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

title: POOR NATIONS GET MORE HELP ON OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The International Monetary Fund announced today the establishment of a new account that would be used to subsidize the interest rate on drawings from the Fund by the world's poorest countries to pay for the higher cost of imported oil.

title: Stock Prices Are Mixed As Dow Closes Up by 2.12
description: Stock prices continued mixed yesterday in slow trading, with some bargain hunting in bluechip issues propping up the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials.

title: Archer Daniels Silent
description: A spokesman for the Archer Daniels Midland Company in Decatur said that officials of the company had not had a chance to study the indictment and would have no comment until then. He also said that ADNAC, Inc., was a jointly owned venture of A.D.M. and the Garnac Grain Company, Inc., of New York City but that there was no connection between A.D.M. and Garnac.

title: Pyongyang Begins Effort to Pay Overdue Trade Bills
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 7 North Korea has reportedly begun efforts to repay hundreds of millions of dollars in overdue trade bills. But the tardy action appears to have cost Pyongyang its international credit rating and could jeopardize the country's current six year plan, according to knowledgeable diplomats and businessmen.

title: Airline Route Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7, ReutersThe Civil Aeronautics Board today awarded Allegheny Airlines a nonstop route between Boston and Toronto.

title: Sandra Palmer's 139 Ties Mrs. Young for Golf Lead
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, Aug. 7 (AP)Sandra Palmer, one shoe on and one shoe off, hobbled along the fairways of Sunningdale today and tied Donna Caponi Young at 139 for first place 72hole European women's open golf championship.

title: Music: Outdoor Risks
description: Outdoor performances, with faulty amplification, street and air traffic noises and talkative bystanders, are hard enough on standard music, but at least listeners can correct in their mind's ear the imperfections of what they are hearing. For unfamiliar contemporary works there can be no such compensation, and these run a grave risk when played under difficult outdoor conditions.

title: GOOD HUMOR CITED ON HIGH BACTERIA
description: The Good Humor Corporation and a present and former officer have been indicted by grand jury on charges of knowlingly producing and marketing ice cream with an illegally high bacteria content, District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state announced that almost 250,000 new voters have registered since the state began registration by postcard in August, 1974.

title: Reflections on Year One of Our Deliverance Or, Double Standard in Washington
description: WASHINGTONIt was anticipated that the anniversary celebration would be an unctuous affair. And it was predictable that the first bouquets to Pete Rodino would come out of the typewriters of Mary McGrory and Tony Lewis.

title: Triangles Beat Sets, Hold Lead
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7The Pittsburgh Triangles defeated the New York Sets, 3026, and held first place in the Eastern Division of World Team Tennis tonight. The teams meet again tomorrow night in New York.

title: Connors, Nastase Advance
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 7 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., and thirdseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania advanced to the quarterfinals of the $100,000 international pro tennis tournament today.

title: Principal in Marcus Trial Is a Figure in Coast Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7Herbert Itkin, the informant for the F.B.I. and C.I.A. whose testimony helped send more than a dozen New York City officials and organizedcrime figures to jail, has resurfaced in a Byzantine, highstakes industrialespionage case in southern California.

title: Soviet Showing Prudence In Portuguese Relations
description: LISBON, Aug. 7The Soviet Union and its allies have taken an active interest in Portuguese affairs and this interest is expected to grow as Portugal attempts to diversify her foreign dealings.

title: Oil Price Decontrol Held Likely to Spur A Worse Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (Reuters)A study by the Library of Congress released today warns that decontrol of oil prices will throw up to one million Americans out of work, sharply increase the rate of inflation and deepen the recession.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP BY 1.2% IN JULY; FOOD A BIG FACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Spurred mainly by higher farm and food prices, the Government's Wholesale Price Index rose by 1.2 per cent in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: GIANTSSTEELERS TICKETS

title: About Real Estate
description: Where better to hear the good news than the builder's basement office in threefamily house on Bedford Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, over a cup of diet chocolate soda. After a 20month hiatus, the Gartensteins are starting to build again.

title: East Germany's Chief Bars Easier Travel
description: BERLIN, Aug. 7  Erich Honecker, chief of the East German Communist party, dampened hopes today of any ear??easing of East German trave restrictions as a result of the Helsinki security conference declaration by saying that for his country, security is and remains foremost.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN AMEX SESSION
description: Prices closed lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, with the index at 86.34, off 0.79. Prices also declined in the overthecounter market; the NASDAQ industrial index ended at 83.75, off 0.84.

title: The Israel Lobby in Washington Is Small and Effective
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Once a week, representatives of 14 national organizations that claim to represent four million American Jews meet in a modestly furnished office in downtown Washington to discuss Israel and what they think should be done to help her.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COME ON DOWNTomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4:30 P.M. People here will have a chance to test the cooling air of the Hudson River and their own sea legs aboard a group of North Atlantic Treaty Organization ships moored at Pier 40, at Houston Street. The ships include a United States Navy guidedmissile frigate, three additional frigates from Britain, the Netherlands and Portugal and a Canadian and a German destroyer. The squadron, which will remain here through Thursday, was established in 1968 as part of NATO and participates in exercises and national tactical operations in European and North American waters throught the year.

title: Tarkenton Is Ready for Jets
description: Once it was a clash of lifestyles and playing styles. Now, the fact that Fran Tarkenton will be playing against Joe Namath tomorrow night for the first time since 1969 means nothing to Tarkenton.

title: 12 Horses Perigh in Keystone Fire
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Aug. 7 (AP)Twelve thoroughbred horses were killed today in a fire that swept through a barn at Keystone Race Track. A track spokesman said the fire apparently broke out in the feed room of the barn that housed 48 horses. None of the horses killed was a stakes horse.

title: People in Sports
description: Ted Hendricks, the 6foot7inch, 220pound linebacker, known as the Mad Stork, arrived at the Oakland training camp in Santa Rosa,Calif. yesterday after signing a reported threeyear pact with the Raiders Wednesday. Hendricks, four times an allpro selection, became a free agent after playing out his option with the Green Bay Packers last season. He had been dickering with several clubs, including the New York Giants.

title: Siege Ends in Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 7Five Japan Red Army terrorists who had held 15 hostages captive for 79 hours released them late today, then flew to Libya, ending a struggle that began Monday morning with the seizure of the consular section of the United States Embassy in downtown Kuala Lumpur.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
India Amending Charter To Aid Mrs. Gandhi's Case
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 7The Indian Government, continuing its speedy consolidation of power into the hands of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, moved today to prevent the courts from even considering the matter of her election to office.

title: Panhandler Slain Off Times Sq.; Suspect Is Seized at Subway Stop
description: A thin, bearded panhandler was stabbed to death in A Times Square subway station early yesterday morning after a dispute with a man he had solicited.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Midsummer isn't the best time of the year for visiting New York restaurants, we have decided. Those that don't close down for the hottest weeks tend to wilt, perhaps because substitutes are on duty for members of the staff on vacation, perhaps because of a feeling on the part of the management that there's no point in knocking yourself out for a summer clientele when your regulars have fled the city. The sloppy look of New Yorkers who managed to get as far as a restaurant during last week's heat wave could justify such an attitude.

title: 3 Wounded in Restaurant As Holdup Panics Diners
description: The manager and two employes of an elegant East Side restaurant were shot and wounded last night when three welldressed gunmen, two of them posing as customers, opened fire during a robbery. The restaurant was filled with lateevening supper patrons.

title: Rep. Moss Drops Secrecy Move On Material of Commerce Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7After nearly a week of warnings, threats and subpoenas, the sponsor of the Federal Freedom of Information Act has backed away from his demands that a group of regulatory agencies keep secret a vast amount of material compiled for a subcommittee he heads.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police said they had begun an investigation into the charge that $15,000 belonging to a victim of the June 24 plane crash at Kennedy International Airport had not been returned to the victim's family. Joseph Dispenza, a 40yearold restaurant owner from Baton Rouge, said only $7,680 of the $22,000 his wife, Connie, was carrying in her purse at the time of the crash was returned to him by the police. Mrs. Dispenza was killed in the crash.

title: Arthur Kennedy, 71, Writer On Horse Racing, Is Dead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 7 (AP)Arthur Kennedy, long a thoroughbred  racing reporter and for many years a public relations officer for the New York Racing Associaton, died today of cancer at the Hempstead Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Tomahawks Beat Arrows, 18 to 13
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 7 The Long Island Tomahawks gave up two goals to the Maryland Arrows in the first 49 seconds, then scored six in a row and went on to register an 1813 victory before 5,227 fans tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People
description: After 15 weeks as a physicaltherapy patient here, Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court left yesterday for his summer home in Goose Prairie, Wash. He and his wife, Cathleen, made a quiet, early morning departure from New York University Medical Center, where his doctors said he has completed the first phase of rehabilitation for an arm and leg affected by a paralytic stroke last New Year's Eve.

title: British Pound Falls; Dollar Is Steady; London Gold Is Up
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 7 (UPI)The British pound tumbled to a new low against the dollar today as the dollar's strength on European money markets held steady.

title: 38 Injured as Jet Crashes on TakeOff In Storm at Denver
description: DENVER, Aug. 7 (UPI)A Continental Airlines passenger jet taking off for Wichita, Kan., encountered turbulence from thunderstorm today and crashed in a wheat field 500 feet off the runway at Stapleton International Airport.

title: The Other News
description: International

title: . . . From Old, Source . . .
description: The fuel to power nuclear fusion is nothing more exotic than ordinary sea water, but the technology conversion requires massive reactor complexes. The second ultimate power source is the oldest source of energy known to man, the rays of the sun; the device for converting solar rays into electricity is small and harmless enough to fit into a baby's fist.

title: Moscow Arts Actor Dies
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (Reuters) Aleksandr Komissarov, one of the Soviet Union's bestknown character actors and a player for 50 years at the Moscow Arts Theater, died here Monday at the age of 71, the newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva reported today. He was best known for his performances of Gogol's comic hero Chichikov in Dead Souls and Cherubino in The Marriage of Figaro.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION DECLINES BY 14.5%
description: DETROIT, Aug. 7United States auto production is scheduled to total 93,700 units this week, down 14.5 per cent from 109,631 last week because more plants are closed for model changeover.

title: Yankees Defeat Indians
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 Sandy Alomar has a mustache but no beard, so physically he doesn't really resemble Rip Van Winkle. For a while, though, it seemed as if the Yankee second baseman might challenge the Sleepy Hollow napper for the New York State sleeping title.

title: How the Fiscal Accord Evolved
description: A week ago Mayor Beame and the directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation stood at an impasse that both sides feared would produce an open break this week over Mr. Beanie's authority as a Mayor.

title: JAMES GRIFFITHS, LABOR PARTY AIDE
description: LONDON, Aug. 7  James Griffiths, one of the Labor party's most respected leaders, died today at his home at Teddington, on the outskirts of London. He was 84 years old.

title: Deaf of 30 Nations To Fight Diseases That Harm Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, August 7Deaf people from 30 nations met here this week and agreed to ask their respective countries for better immunization against diseases that cause deafness, such as rubella, mumps and Rh disease.

title: Expos Defeated After Yielding Five in First
description: After yesterday's game with Montreal at Shea Stadium, Tom Seaver was asked what he thought of Roy McMillan's performance as the new Met manager.

title: Record Heat Wave In France Is Blamed For Series of Fires
description: PARIS, Aug. 7In the early hours this morning flames swept through a Shell oil depot near Metz in Lorraine, and it took 300 firemen 11 hours to seal off the fire. Damage was estimated at $1million.

title: See Jersey Month Declared
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Governor Byrne today declared August as See New Jersry Month. The proclamation is part of a program of continuing monthly special themes proposed by the New Jersey Bicentennial Commission to celebrate the history of the state.

title: The First Ford Year: Policy Tide Is Turned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Gerald R. Ford, who came to power at a time of deep national crisis as an unelected President from a minority party, has spent much of his first year in office trying to reverse Federal social and economic policies that stretch back nearly half a century.

title: Angolan Faction Quits Cabinet Until Portuguese Chief Returns
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 7 (UPI)The National Front for the Liberation of Angola pulled out of the transitional government today pending the return of Portugal's High Commissioner, who has acted as a buffer between the warring factions.

title: VENEZUELA DETAILS OIL TAKEOVER PLAN
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 7 (AP)The mechanism for calculating the size of compensation that will be paid to foreign oil concerns upon state takeover of the country's oil industry has been determined, Venezuela's Deputy Mines and Hydrocarbons Minister, Hernan Anzola, said today.

title: O'Brien Placed Near Scene at Time Hoffa Disappeared
description: DETROIT, Aug. 7Federal investigators have, placed James R. Hoffa's foster son near where the former teamster's union president was last known to be at about the time he was last known to be there, according to a highly placed teamster source.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices. Thursday.

title: Representative Elected As Mayor of Nashville
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 7 (AP) Representative Richard Fulton, Democrat of Tennessee, swept to a landslide victory over five opponents today to be elected Mayor of Metropolitan Nashville.

title: Accountants Are in Political Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7From time to time over nearly two centuries of Presidential elections, a pinchfaced man with sleevegarters and an eyeshade bursts into the campaign manager's office and shouts, We've got to cancel next week's tour. The candidate is out of money.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: M.A.C.'S PACKAGE SEALED WITH HELP OF PENSION FUNDS
description: The new board headed by Richard R. Shinn that will review the city's operations will evaluate not only the productivity of municipal workers and the effectiveness of programs, but also the performance of toplevel commissioners of the Beame Administration.

title: Captives of Silence
description: Samuel Johnson once called deafness the most desperate of human calamities. Even with all the subsequent progress of medical science, to be bereft of hearingespecially if the loss has occurred at or near the beginning of liferemains among the most crushing handicaps to which human beings can be subjected.

title: Grain Fraud Jury Indicts Company and 22 Persons
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7A Federal grand jury indicted today a corporate affiliate of two leading grain companies, the manager of its local operation and 21 other individuals on multiple charges including conspiracy to steal grain from foreign shipments.

title: Parents of Handicapped Get More School Rights
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP)The State Board of Education has approved new regulations that expand the rights of parents whose children have been designated handicapped by publicschool officials.

title: Sol Hurok Must Be Grinning
description: In September, 1973, Sol Hurok came back from the Soviet Union with a dream in his hand. It was a contract for the Bolshoi Opera to appear at the Metropolitan Opera House. The terms were all but impossiblefive operas, the chorus, the orchestra, the soloistsa complete package of 450 Russians and those substantial tons of scenery that virtually symbolize the Bolshoi experience. On March 5, 1974, Sol Hurok died  his dream unfulfilled.

title: The Mayor, on TV, Fights Wormy View Of His Big Apple
description: Mayor Beame led a cast of city boosters to the Sheep Meadow in Central Park last night to share their devotion to the city with an estimated five million latenight television viewers across the country.

title: Peak U.S. Corn Crop Forecasted by Leslie
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 7An American corn crop of 5.87 billion bushels was predicted today by Conrad Leslie, one of the nation's leading private crop forecasters.

title: Pet Shops Are Accused At Hearings on Abuses
description: NEWARK, Aug. 7A small group of consumers contended today that they had been victimized by pet shops that sold them sick dogs at high prices and refused to give refunds when the animals illnesses were diagnosed.

title: Top Lisbon Aide Seeks To End Strife in North
description: OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 7Maj. Gen. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, chief of Portugal's security forces, flew here today to try to put an end to a wave of antiCommunist violence in the region and restore military discipline.

title: NBC Terminates Talks For Memoirs of Nixon
description: NBC News announced yesterday that it had terminated negotiations for the exclusive television rights to the written memoirs of Richard M. Nixon, which would have included extensive interviews with the former President.

title: About New York
description: The building boom of the last several years has left an identity crisis behind it, and New Yorkers will be several years finding themselves before it's resolved. The boom has burst, at least for the moment, but squirreled away in the scatter of glassfronted towers of Manhattan are a dozen new locations called plazas.

title: Hayes Leads by 1 With a 67 in P.G.A.
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 7A brisk breeze swept today over the opening round of the Professional Golfers' Association championship to confound established players and to bless a handful of golfers whose names are household words no farther than their own homes. Jack Nicklaus said he had never heard of a few of the leaders, who included:

title: A BUDGET FREEE IMPOSED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday told the heads of state agencies and departments that their budgets for the next fiscal year would, in effect, be frozen at this year's levels except for increases attributable to inflation or to the completion of new facilities.

title: General Mills Plans To Drop Wells, Rich
description: General Mills, Inc., announced yesterday that it was withdrawing all of its product assignments from Wells, Rich, Green and assigning them to two of its other ad agenciesNeedham, Harper & Steers and DancerFitzgeraldSample.

title: State Says Some Striped Bass And Salmon Pose a Toxic Peril
description: State officials warned consumers yesterday not to eat striped bass from the Hudson River or salmon from Lake Ontario because Federal and state researchers have found that the fish contain dangerously high amounts of PCB, a toxic chemical used in a wide range of manufacturing processes.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Argentina: Dazzling Farm Fair as Economy Worsens
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7It was the parade of champions. First came the prize bulls and cows bedecked with ribbons, then the fiery Arab steeds rearing back nervously against the pull of the trainers' reins, and finally the softwooled sheep riding impassively on floats pulled by tractors.

title: About New York
description: The building boom of the last several years has left an ??tity crisis behind it, and New Yorkers will be several years finding themselves before it's resolved. The boom has burst, at least for the moment, but squirreled away in the scatter of glassfronted towers of Manhattan are a dozen new locations called plazas.

title: GOOD HUMOR CITED ON HIGH BACTERIA
description: The Good Humor Corporation and a present and former officer have been indicted by a grand jury on charges of knowtingly producing and marketing ice cream with an illegally high bacteria content, District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at California  Gura (34) vs. Hockenbury (01).

title: Phils Lose on Wrong Move
description: Danny Ozark, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, chose to pitch to Andre Thornton instead of Jerry Morales in the eighth inning last night. It turned out to be the wrong move.

title: People and Business
description: Three group vice presidents of Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., the world's largest slaughterer of grainfed cattle, have resigned over the last several weeks. Several months ago, the company's other two group vice presidents also had resigned.

title: A Village Housing Project Becomes Fiscal Nightmare
description: A new $25million housing development in Greenwich Village has been sitting empty for nearly a year, a dream of urban betterment on a human scale that has become a financial nightmare of giant proportions for the city.

title: GRANT AND BANKS APPROACH ACCORD
description: The W. T. Grant Company the financially troubled retai chain, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with 27 banks to extend its $300million in loans until July 30, 1976, and to subordinate the loans in favor of vendors selling to the Grant chain.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: Case of Encephalitis Traced to Mosquito In Mercer County
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP)Health authorities reported today that a Mercer County woman had contracted St. Louis encephalitis, a rare disease borne by mosquitoes, which can be fatal.

title: Ballet: Sylphide Shift
description: There is a democratic tone to the National Ballet of Canada: All its ballerinas get a chance to dance with Rudolf Nureyev.

title: CHECKS BY POLICE HALT BUSES ON L.I.
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 7This South Shore city's Police Department, expressing grave concern over the safety of people using city buses and other vehicles, for the second day today virtually halted the operation ngof municipal buses by subjecti them to safety checks.

title: Governor Signs a Measure Prohibiting Pay Toilets
description: ALBANY, Aug. 7  A ?? that would prohibit pay toilets in the state after Sept. 1 has been signed into law by Governor Carey, his office announced today.

title: WINSTON L. MAY JR.
description: Winston L. May Jr., a former vice president and director of the Chicopee Mills subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, died Wednesday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn., and in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Indictments Say Bergman Son Was Active in NursingHome Business
description: Stanley Bergman, 33yearold son of the nursinghome operator, Bernard Bergman, reviewed false documents and accountings before they were filed by the Bergman' accountant with health and tax officials, according to indictments naming him and his father here this week.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: PAR 3 GOLF SOR 18 HOLES MINIATURE GOLF DRIVING RANGE OPEN DAY & NIGHT 7 DAYS GREEN VALLEY GOLF CENTER ANDERSON HILL ROAD PURCHASE, N.Y. 9149399897

title: Joan Klonsky Has Nuptials
description: Joan Klonsky and Martin Daniel Ustin of New York were married yesterday by Mayor William S. Hart of East Orange, N. J., who performed the ceremony in his office there. The bridegroom is director of planning and grants administration for East Orange, and his wife is vice president for manpower development at the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation.

title: The Hostages Relive Malaysia Nightmare
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Friday, Aug. 8The 53 hostages who were herded into little celllike rooms in the United States Embassy here Monday lived with a constant threat of violence that underlay a veneer of quiet courtesy shown them by the five Japanese terrorists who were their captors.

title: ASBESTOS CALLED A PERIL IN HOMES
description: Residents of an entire household and neighbors in the same building where repair workers use commercial spackling, patching and jointing materials can inhale or otherwise be exposed to diseaseproducing levels of asbestos, according to resuits of a study that doctors at Mount Sinai School of Medicine published today.

title: Dennis Slochower Weds Amy Lyons
description: Amy Louise Lyons and Dennis Slochower, graduates of George Washington University, were married last evening. Rabbi Eli Pilchik performed the ceremony at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, N. J.

title: Miki, Here, Pledges More Aid for Asians
description: Premier Takeo Miki of Japan called yesterday for a new framework of regional cooperation in Asia and said that his country would expand economic aid to developing nations in Asia.

title: C.B.O.E. Seat Price Up
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP)  A membership on the Chicago Board Options Exchange sold for a record $75,000, or $10,000 above the previous high set June 12. The options exchange, now in its second year of operations, trades in 67 of the most widely held and actively traded securities.

title: Business Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 (AP)The Brazilian Government called today for a $1billion investment to restore coffee plantations destroyed by frost last month.

title: Obstruction Charged In Death of Architect
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 8A 49yearold man from Morris Township was arrested and charged today with four counts of obstructing justice in the investigation into the bizarre slaying of a Chatham Township architect who was shot to death by a stray bullet as he tarred the roof of his home.

title: Wood, Jets' Top Draft Choice, Arrested for Larceny
description: Richard Wood, a threetime allAmerican linebacker who is the No. 1 draft choice in the New York Jets' training camp, was arrested yesterday on charges of using a stolen and forged airline ticket.

title: Cape Cod Paper Renamed
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 7 (UPI)This resort area's only daily newspaper will change its name to The Cape Cod Times on Sept. 2 to end confusion with its former parent publication in New Bedford.

title: New Energy. . .
description: Energy crisesshortages, dislocations and soaring costsmay well dominate public policy onandoff for the next two decades; but, unlike other longrange resource and population pressures which bring today's specialists to the point of despair, the ultimate answers on energy seem to be coming into sight. Though enormous effort and investment will be required, the march of technology does encourage expectation of cheap and safe energy from new and inexhaustible sources by the end of this century.

title: State Unit Accused of Lobbying for a Bill
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP)State Senator Thomas G. Dunn, Democrat of Union County, angered because the State Division on Women was using taxpayers' money to lobby for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, said today the practice should be illegal.

title: ISRAELIS DEMOLISH A HOUSE IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 7 (Reuters)  Israeli troops crossed the border into Lebanon overnight and blew up a house believed to have been used by guerrillas, an army spokesman announced.

title: Obstruction of Justice Charged In Bizarre Slaying of Architect
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 7A 49yearold man from Morris Township was arrested and charged today with four counts of obstructing justice in the investigation into the bizarre slaying of a Chatham Township architect who was shot to death by a stray bullet as he tarred the roof of his home.

title: Briton Wins Jump in Dublin Show
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 7 (UPI)Harvey Smith of Britain captured the top honor today in the international jumping competition at the Dublin Horse Show, winning the Embassy International in a jumpoff with 14 other riders. At the midway point of the sixday event, Britain claimed first and third place in the day's competition, with Ireland salvaging a second. The course included eight fences with a double and triple bar. Fifteen of the competitors cleared the obstacles with no faults, necessitating a jumpoff against the clock.

title: Steve Cady
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug, 7Not long ago, a busy tout service informed its clients that it had been given the green light to release exclusive word on a guaranteed New York winner.

title: N.Y.S.E. Suspends Trading in First Mortgage of Boston
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that had suspended trading on Wednesday in First Mortgage Investors, a Boston real estate investment trust, preparatory to delisting the company's securities.

title: Gulf & Western Dividend Up
description: Directors of Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., raised yesterday the company's quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share, payable Oct. 1 to shareholders of record Sept. 5. It will be paid on the shares outstanding after the 2for1 stock split, already announced, and effective with the 100 per cent stock distribution on Aug. 22. The company paid 27 cents a share on July 1 on a presplit basis.

title: Moscow Arts Actor Dies
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (Reuters)  Aleksandr Komissarov, one of the Soviet Union's bestknown character actors and player for 50 years at the Moscow Arts Theater, died here Monday at the age of 71, the newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva reported today. He was best known for his performances of Gogol's comic hero Chichikov in Dead Souls and Cherubino in The Marriage of Figaro.

title: Hiroshima Plus Thirty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7There has been so little good news around here lately that it almost slips by when it occurs. The visit of the Japanese Premier, Takeo Mild, to Washington and New York illustrates the point.

title: A Village Housing Project Becomes Fiscal Nightmare
description: A new $25million housing development in Greenwich Village has been sitting empty for nearly a year, a dream of urban betterment on a human scale that has become a financial nightmare of giant proportions for the city.

title: Market Place
description: The stock tables today are sprinkled with issues that carry priceearnings ratios of more than 20, which is not surprising in view of the vigorous bull market rally of the first half of 1975.

title: 'Can You Spare a Dime?' Evokes 1930's
description: The evils of the present, so the theory goes, are caused by everything that happened in the past. Everythingnot just the obviously bad thingsis guilty. If the grass hadn't been so green, the sun so bright, the daisies so proud, Genghis Khan's grandmother might have said no.Therefore, the green of the grass was really verdigris. The sun caused cancer. The daisies were hairy bullies of the meeker vegetable forms.This may be a wretched view of history, but it allows for some pretty fashionable movie making. For example, it more or less links up the dizzying, sometimes brilliant disarray of film clips that make up "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?," a documentary about the nineteen-thirties that opened Wednesday at the Plaza.An old clip shows a pyramid of paper securities collapsing, and the great crash is on. The movie continues, drawing on documentaries. Hollywood pictures, stills and even home movies, to show dozens of disparate things as if they were all part of the same thing. There are malefic capitalists, strike-breaker gangs, a Communist orator, the Dust Bowl. Billie Holiday, Hollywood lushness. Dillinger's corpse, bread lines, Roosevelt and jitterbug contests.The message follows in an epilogue. In quick succession we see Hiroshima, lunar landings, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, each displayed for the booing. Then the collapsing Wall Street pyramid reappears, this time in color.Those jitterbuggers  they look pretty good, in factthose skyscrapers, those beauty queens and rich folks' parties, Roosevelt fishing and the Kennedy boys leaving for Britain at the start of World War II: All are precursors of what the film takes for granted is our present rottenness and imminent collapse.There is nothing wrong with asserting both of these sad things. But the movie doesn't assert. It signals, it uses shorthandis 10 seconds of Nixon really equivalent to two chapters of the Book of Jeremiah?it winks and cross-cuts us into belief. A Rolls-Royce, followed by a shot of a woman who can't afford to buy meat, followed by wild dancing. A Hollywood version of a Ku Klux Klan oath-taking followed by a clip of Buffalo Bill having a group of youngsters recite the Oath of Allegiance.Propaganda films are a game that any number can play. The pity is that the techniques used by Philippe Moraa French-born Australian, now living in Britain, who previously did film compilations on the Nazis' Germany  cheapen and sometimes frustrate his material.And much of the material is magnificent. Furthermore, movies being what they are, it is possible to be moved and illuminated by the good things in "Brother" even while wishing that Mr. Mora would go for cofee. It is like touring a first-rate museum with a frequentlynot invariablyinsufferable guide.The best things in "Brother" are the materials taken from documentaries, some not previously shown. Set beside theseand Mr. Mora does so frequentlythe portions of Hollywood movies on the same subject seem farcial and unreal.A fictional scene of hoboes riding the rails, good enough in itself, shrivels when followed by an extraordinary newsreel clip of a state trooper telling a group of hoboes with some pity and shame that they will have to turn back.There is a beautiful long sequence showing armed strike-breakers moving into steel pickets, first gently and tentatively, then with growing violence. There is an extraordinary, previously unshown jail interview with Giuseppe Zangara after his attempt to shoot Roosevelt.There is another precious rarity: Billie Holiday, young and in a plain black dress, singing a shivering version of "Jealousy Blues."Perhaps the best sustained subject in the movie is the periodic reappearace of Roosevelt. The later Roosevelt, old, distinguished and foxy, is familiar enough, perhaps. To many people the clips showing him as a still youthful, still vigorous campaigner for his first term will be a revelation of just how rousing a man he could be, and why many of our fathers and grandfathers loved him in a way no American President has been loved since.

title: Israeli Meets Kissinger On Sinai Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI)  Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel tonight delivered to Secretary of State Kissinger Israel's preliminary reactions to Egypt's latest proposals for a new interim agreement on Sinai.

title: Terrorists Land in Libya And Surrender Peacefully
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Friday, Aug. 8 (Reuters)  Ten Japan Red Army terrorists arrived here today and surrendered peacefully after a 12hour flight from Malaysia with four hostages.

title: Justice vs. Politics
description: By an ironic twist, British democracy has been well served by its House of Lords at almost the same moment that Indian democracy is being undone by its Lok Sabha, or House of the People.

title: STATE AIDE HOPEFUL ON ECONOMIC GAINS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The latest state economic report said today that New Jersey might have turned the corner and be beaded for an economic recovery.

title: Virtually No Rise Shown In Money Supply, Fed Says
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated yesterday that the nation's money supply had shown virtually no growth in July and might actually have declined for the first time since January.

title: Antuofermo, Curto in TV Bout Tonight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 7 (AP)A pair of Italian natives, Vito Antuofermo and Vinnie Curto, meet tomorrow in the third of a series of nationallytelevised boxing matches. Antuofermo, a middleweight who, lives in New York, has a 3111 wonlostdrawn record, including 13 knockouts and 14 victories in a row.

title: Principal in Marcus Trial Is a Figure in Coast Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7Herbert Itkin, the informant for the F.B.I. and C.I.A. whose testimony helped send more than a dozen New York City officials and organizedcrime figures to jail, has resurfaced in a Byzantine, highstakes industrialespionage case in southern California.

title: Norway Approves Pact to Take Over Subsidiary of B.P.
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 7 (AP) The Norwegian Government has approved an agreement to take over Norsk Braendeslolje, a 50 per cent owned subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., it was reported today.

title: City Hall Businessmen
description: In the last two months, businessmen have become more influential in the management of New York City than at any time since the Depression years. Men such as William M. Eninghaus, the president of New York Telephone Company; Richard R. Shinn, the president of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker, have become as familiar to the public as some of the city's top elected officials.

title: E.C.A.C. Keeps Football Officials Hopping
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 7Edgar Stowall is a football field judge, one of those officials in black and white stripes who does not move as fast as zebras or, in most cases, as fast as huge tackles.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Trainer, Jockey Suspended in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7A jockey and a trainer indicted yesterday by a special state grand jury were suspended indefinitely today by the New Jersey Racing Commission for conduct detrimental to racing. The suspensions of James P. Verrone of Cornwells Heights, Pa., a jockey, and John Salvaggio, a trainer from Mount Holly N. J., were the result of an indictment handed up on charges of sports bribery.

title: Doctor and Lawyer Cooperation Urged
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 7The president of the American Medical Association called on doctors and lawyers today to stop the barefaced shouting match over quacks and shysters in which each blamed the other for the medical malpractice insurance crises.

title: Preserving Central Park
description: The gentle hills and grassy areas near the Central Park Mall and the 72d Street transverse were piled high with garbage yesterday morning, and scorched remains of barbecue fires were scattered under the trees.

title: MAC'S PACKAGE SEALED WITH HELP OF PENSION FUNDS
description: The new board headed by Richard R. Shinn that will review the city's operations will evaluate not only the productivity of municipal workers and the effectiveness of programs, but also the performance of toplevel commissioners of the Beame Administration.

title: For Sale: Vermont's Old Prison
description: WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 7Anybody want to buy a used, maximum security prison?

title: FRANCE CUTS BACK ATOM POWER PLAN
description: PARIS, Aug. 7The French Government, concerned about the uncertainties of the outlook for energy supplies and the increasing protests of environ mentalists. has decided to reduce its atomic energy program.

title: JOAN LITTLE JURY HEARS EXINMATES
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 7Lawyers for Joan Little began their defense today with testimony from two black women inmates at the Beaufort County Jail, that Clarence T. Alligood, the night jailer slain by Miss Little, had made sexual advances at them. A third said she had heard him elk Miss Little if she missed her man.

title: Berra Back With Mets  for a Goodby
description: In a remarkable display of personal diplomacy, Yogi Berra returned to Shea Stadium yesterday and spent three hours saying goodby to the players and bosses who had cost him his job as manager of the Mets.

title: Principal in Marcus Trial A Figure in Case on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7Herbert Itkin, the informant for the F.B.I. and C.I.A. whose testimony helped send more than a dozen New York City officials and organizedcrime figures to jail, has resurfaced in a Byzantine, highstakes industrialespionage case in southern California.

title: Diamond Crystal Expanding
description: ST. CLAIR, Mich., Aug. (UPI)  The Diamond Crystal Salt Company announced today it would spend $2.5million to expand and modernize its St. Clair salt refinery. A fifth evaporator will be added. Two months ago, Diamond Crystal announced the St. Clair refinery would be converted to burning coal instead of butane gas because of the high price of butane. The conversion cost of $2.1million will be on top of the expansion and modernization cost.

title: Sucrest Announces Sugar Price Rises
description: The Sucrest Corporation, one of the nation's major sugar companies, and the Corn Products unit of CPC International, Inc., announced yesterday increases in the wholesale prices of their industrial sugars amounting to 83 cents per 100 pounds. The prices are effective today. The price changes bring the price of extra fine granulated sugar to $27.08 per 100 pounds and the price of bulk granulated and liquid No.2 sugar to $26.58 per pound.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP BY 1.2% IN JULY; FOOD A BIG FACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Spurred mainly by higher farm and food prices, the Government's Wholesale Price Index rose by 1.2 per cent in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Cable Over River Strung for Tram To Roosevelt Is.
description: Duck soup. That's what a Swiss tramway expert had said when asked to evaluate the feasibility of providing transportation from Roosevelt Islandnow billed as Manhattan's Other Islandto a point on Second Avenue via aerial cable cars.

title: Advertising
description: New York as a test market? Not a very likely possibility among marketers who generally seek out small and mediumsized cities for their introductory advertising and sales campaigns.

title: FUTURES PRICES CLIMB IN LONDON
description: Weakness in the British pound caused a rush of commodity buying in the London market, which opens earlier than United States commodity exchanges. The result was much higher prices for a variety of basics like sugar, cocoa and silver in markets here.

title: Big Catch by Rawlings
description: The Rawlings Sporting Goods Company announced yesterday that it had contracted to manufacture all of the baseballs used in the major leagues, beginning in 1977.

title: ... and a Sleeper
description: As ERDA's executives were preparing their first broad plan for energy research, development and demonstrationsubmitted to Congress a month agothey seized upon a major source of energy, one that technology might make available both sooner and more cheaply than either fusion or solar conversion.

title: Istomin in Two Roles at Mostly Mozart
description: Eugene Istomin's high repute as a chambermusic expert has tended in recent years to obscure his excellence as a solo pianist. Both aspects of his talent were on display at Thursday night's Mostly Mozart Festival, however, and, perhaps because one may too easily forget how well Mr. Istomin can play, the solo portion of his program struck one's fancy most.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 9, 1975

title: CITY TO GET LESS IN PROPERTY TAX
description: The City Tax Commission had reduced this year's assessed valuations of property by a total of $276million, with about 12,000 properties havimg reeeived the reductions after their owners had protested the original assessments.

title: Tigers Lose 13th Straight, 31
description: Before Detroit's game against the Minnesota Twins in Tiger stadium last night, Mickey Lolich had said, It's just one of those things. You can't believe you're not winning.

title: GRAND JURY LIKELY TO GET HOFFA CASE
description: DETROIT, Aug. 8The investigation into the disappearance of James R. Hoffa appeared tonight to be headed for a Federal grand jury here.

title: Citibank Increases Prime Rate to 7%
description: The First National City Bank of New York raised its prime lending rate to 7 per cent from 7 per cent yesterday in a move that surprised some sectors of the financial community.

title: Rockefeller Questioned 5 Hours In State Inquiry Into Attica Riot
description: Vice President Rockefeller was questioned for five hours yesterday by a special state deputy attorney general about his role in the 1971 uprising at Attica State Correctional Facility.

title: I.M.C. Profits Set Highs; Other Companies Report
Dodgers Triumph, 43 and Send McMillan's Mets to First Loss
description: The magic of Roy McMillan's tenure as the new manager of the Mets ran out after two games last night as New York dropped a 43 decision to the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium.

title: 2 TV Comedies to Treat Women Seriously
description: The dizzy wives of early situation comedies still survive in television commercials. And the unattached woman who makes up so much of the contemporary urban population is stylishly portrayed in the person of Mary, that bright career girl in the Mary Tyler Moore Show.

title: WELFARE FUNDS BARRED IN ORANGE
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 8The Orange County Legislature, aroused by steeply rising welfare costs, refused today to appropriate $5.5million to maintain county welfare services through the end of the year. The denial of funds means that the county may be unable to support many recipients beyond October.

title: Mansfield Visiting Burma
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 8 (AP)Mike Mansfield, Senate majority leader, has begun a fourday visit to Burma during which he is expected to meet the head of state, U Ne Win. The Montana Democrat arrived here yesterday with his wife after visits to Portugal and Saudi Arabia. He leaves Monday for Hong Kong and Manila.

title: NoDuplication Pact Made by Red Cross And Salvation Army
description: The national leaders of the American Red Cross and the Salvation Army, two of the largest volunteer organizations in disaster relief, signed an agreement yesterday to prevent overlapping services in emergency situations.

title: GypsyMoth Damage Up
description: TRENTON, Aug. 8 (AP)The state's Agriculture Department said today that a recent aerial survey showed many forested areas in central and southern areas of the state defoliated by gypsy moths. The department said the insects devoured leaves in 55,430 acres this year compared with 28,102 in 1974, and attributed the increase in part to the incursion of the moth into new forest areas and a decrease in the department's spraying program.

title: Hard Times Taking Toll Among Clubs of London
description: LONDON, Aug. 8One of the better stories reflecting the power and exclusiveness once enjoyed by the gentlemen's clubs of London involves a police raid near the turn of the century on Beefsteak's, a small club in a raffish neighborhood near Leicester Square.

title: National League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: ...And Thwarting a Life of Crime
description: Richard B., a slight 12yearold, stole a car from a midtown parking lot. A policeman arrested him when he was driving it in the wrong direction on a oneway street some miles away. Two months later, he was again before the Family Court in New York City on another juvenile delinquency charge, robbery at knifepoint.

title: ISRAEL SEES PACT ON SINAI NEARING
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 8Israell has submitted to the United States her latest package of proposals for a new interim agreement with Egypt amid a growing mood of optimism here about chances of concluding a new accord sometime in the next several weeks.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Justice Department said a civil suit had been filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn charging five roofing and sheetmetal trade assciations in the New York area with conspiring to violate antitrust laws by offering a common twoyear guarantee on their work. Accused were Composition Roofers & Waterproofers Employers Association, Long Island & Brooklyn Roofing & Sheet Metal Contractors Association, Nassau & Suffolk Roofing and Sheet Metal Employers Association, Sheet Metal & AirConditioning Contractors National Association, New York City chapter, and Sheet Metal & Roofers Employers Association of Southeastern New York.

title: Key Trip for Yankees
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 8Baseball's oldest wonder drug NMH ( New Manager Hypo) was the substance the New York Yankees were counting on to close ground on the Boston Red Sox as the two teams began a sevenday tour of California tonight. The Yankees, having won five of the seven games played under Billy Martin, opened a fourgame series with the California Angels here, while the RedSox were in Oakland facing th A's. On Tuesday, the Eastern teams will switch cities for threegame sets. Since the Angels are tied for last place, and the A's have the incentive of a renewed challenge for first place in their division, this weekend represents a chance for the Yankees to do better than the Red Sox.

title: Trenton's Burned Files Stir Concern!
description: TRENTON, Aug. 8 (UPI)This city lost more than a 73yearold landmark when a a fire leveled the Trenton Civic Center on July 16. Stored in the basement were mountains of city documents, including zoning and tax records, which The city plans to replace were destroyed. the massive onetime armory with a modern cultural center and construction of an annex to City Hall has been proposed to house city offices displaced by the fire.

title: Ashland Oil Gives Data To S.E.C. on Payments
description: Ashland Oil, Inc., announced last night that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission reports on its domestic political contributions and foreign payments following strenuous insistence from the agency.

title: Net Title to Miss Johnson
description: ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 8Cindy Johnson of Spring Lake, N.J., won the Long Island women's tennis championship today by defeating Adria Price of Roslyn, 60, 63, in the final.

title: SOVIET CAUTIONS COMMON MARKET
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8The Communist party newspaper Pravda today invoked the Helsinki declaration of the European security conference to warn the Common Market countries against what it contended was new interference in Portugal.

title: Knick Ticket Renewals Slow
description: Dear Season SubscriberWe are holding your tickets for you. So reads a letter being distributed from the office of the Knicks.

title: Allendale Youths' Tension Rises Over Lack of Recreation Outlets
description: ALLENDALE, Aug. 8Tension is mounting between the young people of this small town and the local police following the arrest of a teen ager on bombing charges, and according to many young people it stems from the boredom of being young and having nothing to do.

title: Five Track Marks Set By Masters
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 8The Amateur Athletic Union Masters track and field meet started its threeday national championships today at Glenn Loucks Memorial Field with five world records broken. There is competition in five age categories for those 40 years and older in 18 events.

title: EDITH H. CRAFTS
description: Edith Honigman Crafts, an early newspaperwoman in New Jersey, died Thursday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N. J. She was 86 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: Inflation Is Worrying Canadians
description: OTTAWA, Aug 8A new round of price rises, plus soaring wage settlements, have caused mounting national concern over erosion in the Canadian economy under the present inflationary conditions.

title: Amtrak Schedules Overnight Trains To Chicago Oct. 31
description: Amtrak, the national rail passenger service, announced yesterday the start of daily overnight train service effective Oct. 31 connecting both New York and Boston with Chicago by way of Albany, Buffalo and Cleveland.

title: StopGap Cabinet Installed By Portuguese President
description: LISBON, Aug. 8President Francisco da Costa Gomes, after three weeks of turmoil and uncertainty following the resignation of two major nonCommunist parties from the Government, today swore in a new Cabinet devoid of any strong political base but leaning toward the Communists.

title: Hurdle Crossed
description: With a big boost from local banks and financial institutions, along with help from the state government and from state and local pension funds, the Municipal Assistance Corporation has patched together a $960 million funding package that should carry the city across one more hurdle in its race away from default.

title: The Arts Dollar
description: The visual arts are feeling the economic pinch in the city more acutely than the performing arts. Obviously, neither should be exempt from some sacrifice when all publicly supported institutions and services are being cut back. The practical problem is to assure that whatever resources are available for the arts be equitably apportioned.

title: U.S. ACTS TO OPEN CHARTER FLIGHTS TO MASS TRAVEL
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday a major liberalization of charter rules that will make ticketplushotel bargains available to anyone at prices that will frequently be less than just the cost of a scheduled airline ticket.

title: The Socialist Way of Life
description: STOCKHOLM  Immediately after the more flamboyant European security summit concluded its business last week, a less advertised but far from insignificant meeting of Socialist leaders took place here. With considerably more gumption than the Helsinki affair, the ideologically unified Stockholm meeting voted to back Democratic Socialism in Portugal, including guarantees of a free press, free parties and free labor unions.

title: French Fishermen Protest
description: MONTPELLIER, France, Aug. 8 (Reuters)Angry fishermen dumped a ton of rotten fish outside the town hall to dramatize their demands that antipollution measures be applied in a local river. Firemen were called to remove the fish.

title: Cahn to Stand Trial on Double Billing
description: MINEOLA, LI., Aug. 8William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, has decided to stand trial on charges stemming from a Federal investigation of alleged double billing, instead of accepting a Government offer to plead guilty to one count of incometax evasion.

title: 400 Reported Dead in China After Collision of 2 Boats,
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Aug. 9Hong Kong newspapers said today that two excursion boats collided and sank in the West River near Canton in southern China, leaving more than 400 persons dead and 100 missing.

title: City Claims Gains In Cutting Backlog Of Leftover Refuse
description: The Sanitation Department has reduced the backlog of uncollected garbage from 3,500 tons to 620 tons in the last seven days, according to Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh.

title: JAMES W. DUNLOP
description: James W. Dunlop, a professor of music at Pennsylvania State University, died Thursday in Salt Lake City. He was 61 years old and lived in University Park, Pa.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: POUND PLUMMETS TO ANOTHER LOW
description: BRUSSEL, Aug. 8 (UPI)The pound plummeted today to new low for the seventh consecutive trading day, ending the worst week on record for the beleaguered British currency.

title: Both Audience and Singers Win in Fort Lee
description: FORT LEE, Aug. 8The Fort Lee Symphony and Opera Association is about to enter its 13th season providing experience for gifted amateurs and musical enjoyment for opera lovers here and in neighboring communities. It also provides an outlet for those who love to sing opera but elect to follow other professions.

title: BANKS HERE AGREE TO HELP CITY CUT ITS INTEREST COSTS
description: Major New York banks have agreed to a plan that will ease the city's borrowing burden in the next 11 months and help to hold down interest costs.

title: ISRAEL, SEES PACT ON SINAI NEARING
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 8Israel has submitted to the United (States her latest package of proposals for a new interim agreement with Egypt amid a growing mood of optimism here about chances of concluding a new accord sometime in the next several weeks.

title: Educator Says Public Colleges Hurt Private Ones Financially
