description: WEST LONG BRANCH, Aug. 8Continued expansion of they state's public twoand fouryear colleges could cause grievous financial problems for Monmouth College and for more than half of New Jersey's 17 other private colleges, Richard J. Stonesifer, Monmouth's president, said here recently

title: Sets Subdue Triangles in W.T.T., 2421
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 8 Sandy Mayer defeated his old friend and doubles partner, Vitas Gerulaitis. 64, tonight and helped the New York Sets beat the Pittsburgh Triangles, 2421 in World Team Tennis. The Sets clinched the victory when Fred Stolle and Virginia Wade won the mixed doubles finale 63.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at California (n.)Hunter (1510) vs. Figueroa (109).

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 9, 1975

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: NoWrinkle Process for Denim
description: For the last 10 years the American textile industry has tried to find a way to make cotton competitive with manmade fibers, which have steadily been capturing a greater share of the apparel and home furnishings markets.

title: Late Falcon Kick Conquers Redskins
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Nick MikeMayer kicked a 19yard field goal with 15 seconds to play tonight as the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Washington Redskins, 1614, in a a Ntional Football League exhibition game.

title: GOOD GRAIN CROP IS SEEN FOR SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (UPI)A team of American agriculture experts flew home today with a decidedly optimistic impression after making a 19day inspection trip to the Soviet Union's grainproducing regions in Central Asia and Siberia.

title: New Law Requires Seekers of Divorce To Disclose Assets
description: A bill requiring both parties in a divorce action to file sworn statements of net worth before the start of the trial was signed into law yesterday by Governor Carey.

title: Market Place; 2 Bearish (Minority) Views on Stocks
description: Lots of investors who avoided the stock market during the first six months of this year, when prices soared to their best gains in years, undoubtedly feel they missed the boat.

title: Memories Of Ruffian Haunt Spa
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N..Y, Aug. 8The Queen is dead but her specter will overshadow the Alabama Stakes tomorrow when 11 pretenders to the distaff throne spring from the gate of soggy Saratoga in the 95th running of this prestigious race for 3yearold fillies.

title: YOUNG CHANTEUSE FROM BROOKLYN
description: Jane Olivor, a young chanteuse from Brooklyn who has been singing frequently on New York's proliferating boite circuit recently, is at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street, through tonight.

title: Cannonball Adderley, Jazzman, Dead
description: GARY, Ind., Aug. 8 (AP)The jazz musician Julian (Cannonball) Adderley died here today at St. Mary Methodist Hospital, nearly four weeks after having suffered a stroke that left him paralyzed and unable to speak. He was 46 years old.

title: Computer Setup Links a Variety of Devices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8A computer system invented at the upstate medical center of the State University of New York in Syracuse can control or collect information from hundreds or widely separated devices. Leo F. Walsh, instructor and assistant director of bioelectronic and computer sciences, was granted Patent 3,898,373 this week. A demonstration system, in operation at the center, controls medical research and administration equipment.

title: JOAN LITTLE JURY HEARS PROFESSOR
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 8A New York criminologist testified today at the Joan Little murder trial that Clarence T. Alligood, the night jailer at the Beaufort County Jail, may have tried to clean the blood off his body before he died.

title: Aid Cut Impels Rutgers To Weigh a Tuition Rise
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 8A tuition increase and a weeklong shutdown are among the measures being considered by Rutgers University officials to deal with a $7million reduction in state funds to the school.

title: Bankers Around U.S. Cool to M.A.C.
description: A sampling of bond specialists in a halfdozen cities indicated yesterday that the Municipal Assistance Corporation would continue to face difficulties selling its bonds, despite the steps the city has taken to restore investor confidence in its fiscal affairs.

title: It Depends On Where You Look
description: Belatedly, journalism is taking President Nixon's advice to dwell on what is good about America, and the result is a spate of print from American places where life is good.

title: Radioactive Matter Taken Through City Despite Recent Ban
description: Despite a ban announced last week against the transport of hazardous radioactive materials through the city's streets, a shipment of highly enriched uranium was carried by truck Wednesday from the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island to the George Washington Bridge, the city's Health Department disclosed yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today it was proposing rate increases on its interstate individual shorthaul private line voice grade services which are 25 miles or less in length.

title: U.S. GIVES PRAISE TO CITY BUT NO AID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Federal officials emerged from a twohour meeting with representatives of the Municipal Assistance Corporation here today still resolutely opposed to Government backing of municipal bonds but full of encouragement for the city's efforts at selfhelp.

title: Provincial Greece Relaxes in a Year of Civilian Rule
description: VOLOS, Greece, Aug. 5People feel much more comfortable, more secure, said Constantinos Kapourniotis, the owner of a flour mill in this provincial capital. Business is carried on without the uncertainty and anxiety there was before. We feel that the Government is controlled by us through Parliament.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in last Saturday's New York Times incorrectly listed the secondquarter earnings of the Exxon Corporation for 1974 and 1975 and of the Standard Oil Company of California for 1974. The percentage changes in the companies' earnings were also incorrect. A corrected version of the table appears today on Page 25.

title: Books of The Times
description: In this brilliant and delightful little book, Arthur Okun, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Lyndon B. Johnson, tackles one of the most critical issues of our time: how to distribute the goods of our system more equally without undermining the efficiency of the system. Trueblue capitalists have no trouble with the problem. Any thing that impairs the efficiency of the system, they say, is wrong economically, socially and morally. That outstanding 19thcentury champion of laissezfaire, Herbert Spencer, declared, The command, if any would not work neither should he eat, is simply a Christian enunciation of that universal law of nature under which life has reached its present heightthe law that a creature not energetic enough to maintain itself must die. Spencer was even against free public libraries, on the ground that they gave people something for nothing and encouraged loafing. Latterday Spencerians see the pursuit of equality as sapping the life of capitalist growthwith socialist Britain as the horrible example of economic decay.

title: GOV. SHAPP IS LINKED TO KICKBACK INQUIRY
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 8 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp will be interviewed by a Federal grand jury investigating contract kickbacks and asked to tell what he knows about the awarding of state contracts, informed sources say.

title: Congress Party Expels ExAide to Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 8 (UPI) Mohan Dharia, the lone voice of dissent in parliamentary action that cleared Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of election abuses, has been expelled from the governing Congress party.

title: Arabs Split on Ousting Israel From U.N.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 8Egypt's relatively moderate stand on the issue of expelling Israel from the United Nationswhich was brought into the open at last week's African summit meeting in Uganda, has underscored the sharpening divisions between two camps in the Arab world.

title: Architecture:
description: On the surface, little has changed in the maledominated profession of architecture. But the substrata has been stirring since 1971, with feminist ferment that may eventually alter the way both women and men function as professionals.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Homo Sapiens, the Manna Maker
description: The world is moving toward an age of limitless abundanceabundant energy, food, raw materials. Decades from now this late 20th century will be remembered as a period in which the world shifted from ageold scarcity to a new era of plenty.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater will open its second twoweek summer engagement at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center on Tuesday.

title: Refugees Caught in Union Dispute at Coast Egg Farm
description: MOORPARK, Calif., Aug. SPhan Than Khiet stands less than 5 feet 6 inches tall. He is thin and wan, and his right arm is gonehardly someone likely to aggravate a bitter labor dispute. But as he works in the sweltering California heat in a place they call Egg City, he is hearing a word for which there is no counterpart in his native Vietnamese.

title: STATE CUTS BACK AIRCONDITIONING
description: Airconditioning in state office buildings will not be turned on until the inside temperatute reaches 82 degrees, under a program of cost reductions announced in Albany yesterday by the State Division of the Budget.

title: FENCING CHAMPION ARRESTED IN POLAND
description: Lieut. Col. Jerzy Pawlowski of Poland, a leading world fencing champion has been arrested in Warsaw and charged with activities on behalf of a foreign country.

title: WILD BILL DAVISON KEEPS LIVELY STYLE
description: Wild Bill Davison, a prominent habitue of the two New York jazz clubs that Eddie Condon ran, is making his first appearance at the posthumous Condon's on West 54th Street this week. And it's almost as though nothing had changed.

title: Art: Portraits Done by a Farmer
description: Twenty years ago folk art was regarded in this country and elsewhere as something essentially provincial, limited and by implication secondrate. Fine art was above and apart, and anyone who studied folk art was thought to be playing safe. True ambition lay elsewhere.

title: SAMUEL GARFIELD
description: Samuel Garfield, who retired in 1965 as a real estate broker in Newark, died Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, L. I. He was 88 years old and had a summer home on Fire Island.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Portland, Maine  Mary Hagler, Brockton, Mass., knocked out Jesse Bender, Hartford, Conn, 1 round, middleweights.

title: Aromatic TShirts Can Smell Like Pizza, or Anything Else
description: Not long ago a man walked into the Tee Hee Shirt Company at 161 West Fourth Street, scratched his Tshirt and said: Quick, what do I smell like?

title: Steve Cady
description: It could have been worse. If he hadn't put his arm up to shield his head, Brian probably would have been killed instantly. If the boat's propeller had sliced half an inch higher, the main artery of the arm would have been severed. And if the crew of a commercial dredge hadn't been nearby, ready with a tourniquet and a shiptoshore radio, he might never have reached the hospital alive.

title: WIRING OF ALUMINUM IN HOMES RULED RISK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission declared today aluminum wire in use in perhaps two million American homes an unreasonable risk and directed that rules be drawn up to deal with the, problem.

title: Six NATO Ships Dock For Open House Here
description: Six ships of war bearing different flags sailed as one squadron into New York Harbor yesterday on the start of a sixday visit to the city by a special force of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Thais, in an Act of Retaliation, Expel 2 From Laotian Embassy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 8 The Thai Government today ordered the expulsion of two Laotian diplomats in retaliation for the arrest of two Thai military attachs in Vientiane Tuesday on espionage charges.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOCKSIDE COUNTRY Perhaps partly because of the outdoor setting and the salty summer breezes, bluegrass and traditional country music have already found an urban home in the weekend entertainments for visitors at the South Street Seaport, with its oldtime ships and picturesque facades. Today and tomorrow, there's to he a gala event on Pier 15, with 25 amateur bands expected competing for $500 in prize money and with samplings by 45 handcraft exhibitors from five states.

title: TWO L.I. DEALERS DROPPED BY G.M.
description: The Chevrolet Division of General Motors disclosed yesterday that it had canceled the dealerships of two of the larger of its Long Island dealers after auditing their books in its investigation of warranty discrepancies.

title: India Enacts Measure Shielding Leaders From Courts
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 8Parliament today completed legislative action designed to insulate the election of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi from challenges in the courts.

title: GORDON F. MAXWELL, A PAN AM EXECUTIVE
description: Gordon F. Maxwell, who retired last year as senior vice president for operations of Pan American World Airways, died Wednesday of cancer at Payson (Ariz.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Litchfield Park, Ariz.

title: Ontario Premier Extends Rebate to All Car Buyers
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 8The provincial government of Ontario, chided by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau yesterday for having instituted a 5 per cent tax rebate on the purchase of automobiles manufactured in North America, responded today by extending the concession to all cars.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Court Blames F.B.I. In Plane Hijacking; Awards $388,530
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has ruled that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was negligent in handling a 1971 airplane hijacking in which three persons died and has entered a judgment of $388,530.98 against the Federal Government.

title: Ford Impact Is Uncertain In Foreign Policy So Far
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8When Gerald R. Ford took over as President, he pledged to pursue the same foreign policies that had brought wide respect to Richard M. Nixon. A year later, Mr. Ford has not altered those policies significantly or left a discernible imprint of his own on international affairs.

title: Ford Impact Is Uncertain In Foreign Policy So Far
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8When Gerald R. Ford took over as President, he pledged to pursue the same foreign policies that had brought wide respect to Richard M. Nixon. A year later, Mr. Ford has not altered those policies significantly or left a discernible imprint of his own on international affairs.

title: U.S. ACTS TO OPEN CHARTER FLIGHTS TO MASS TRAVEL
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday a major liberalization of charter rules that will make ticketplushotel bargains available to anyone at prices that will frequently be less than just the cost of a scheduled airline ticket.

title: Between Drills, Giants Just Plain Folks
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 8Dave Jennings updated his two diaries, Karl Chandler began a Kipling short story, Toni Mullen and Scott Hunter battled away in backgammon.

title: F.E.A. RULED LACKING IN RENT AUTHORITY
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 8 (AP)A Federal judge has ruled that the. Federal Energy Administration does not have authority to control rents the Shell Oil Company charges its service station oroperties.

title: 7Day Suspension Drawn by Vasquez
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8Braulio Baeza became a virtual certainty to ride Foolish Pleasure in the Travers when it was announced today that Jacinto Vasquez had been suspended for seven days.

title: BANKS HERE AGREE TO HELP CITY CUT ITS INTEREST COSTS
description: Major New York banks have agreed to a plan that will ease the city's borrowing burden in the next 11 months and help to hold down interest costs.

title: U.S. STEEL LIFTS PRICES BY 3.8% ON A BROAD LINE
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, announced price changes yesterday that would raise the company's prices an average of 3.8 per cent between now and Oct. 1.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold priced Friday.

title: Damage Charges Against 9 Dropped In Kent State Case
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. S (AP)Damage claims have been dropped against nine former members of the Ohio National Guard in the $46million civil suit stemming from the 1970 Kent State University shootings.

title: Search for a Copy Editor Yields a Raincoat and Cap
description: RUNNEMEDE, Aug. 8 (UPI) Officials looking for a former Camden newspaper copy editor, missing since last month and feared to be a target of a contract murder, today found a raincoat and a ski cap apparently linked to his disappearance.

title: Bridge:
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 8The Spingold Knockout Team Championship continued here this afternoon with 15 teams remaining in contention, but the two topranked teams were not among them. Two major upsets in thirdround play last night removed Lew Mathe's topranked squad and Ira Corn's secondranked Aces.

title: Disk Brakes Will Raise Some Prices at A.M.C.
description: DETROIT, Aug. 8 (Reuters) The president of the American Motors Corporation, William V. Luneburg, said today that A.M.C. would raise prices a second time in January on its Pacer, Hornet and Gremlin models because disk brakes would have to be added to meet a Federal standard. He did not say how much prices would go up, but disk brakes now sell as a $47 option on these cars.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Attorney General William F. Hyland's office has filed suit against Allenhurst, in Monmouth County, contending that the municipality restricts access to public beaches by charging nonresidents higher fees than residents for use the Allenhurst Beach Club.

title: NAZI BOOTH STIRS DISPUTE AT FAIR
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 8Booths operated by Jewish and Nazi groups at the Wisconsin State Fair were closed today following outbursts of anger at the Nazi booth on the opening day of the 11day fair yesterday.

title: Of Rites and Rights
description: Whether or not women may be priests of the Episcopal Church is obviously a matter best left for decision within that church. Until now, in fact, it has been a question on which only that church's communicants were entitled even to an opinion. However, that situation is bound to change if the eleven women who have been thwarted in their pursuit of priestly office resort to civil proceedings, as their counsel says they will. Indeed, a preliminary action has already been taken before a human rights commission in Syracuse.

title: DAVID LAMSON, TRIED 4 TIMES FOR MURDER
description: David A. Lamson, who became a writer after having been tried four times, on a charge that he murdered his wife, died Wednesday at his home in Los Altos, Calif., apparently of a stroke. He was 72 years old.

title: Beef Packers, Inc., and Officers Indicted
description: OMAHA, Aug. 8 (AP)A Federal grand jury handed down today a 105count indictment charging officials of bankrupt American Beef Packers, Inc., of Omaha with conspiring to defraud livestock feeders in at least 13 states out of more than $20million.

title: M.A.C.'s Next Hurdle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8The Federal Government's partner in the delicate dance over possible help for New York City's financial problems has now become the respectable beauty called the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and her cajoling involves a seemingly costless device for Washington. But the courtship does not seem to have a much better chance of success than before.

title: City Claims Gains In Cutting Backlog Of Leftover Refuse
description: The Sanitation Department has reduced the backlog of uncollected garbage from 3,500 tons to 620 tons in the last seven days, according to Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh.

title: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Explosion Damages Denver Courthouse After Bomb Threat
description: DENVER, Aug. 8 (AP)An explosion tore through an entrance of the United States Courthouse in downtown ?? ver early today, the police said. There were no reports of injuries, although damage was extensive.

title: U.S. GIVES PRAISE TO CITY BUT NO AID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Federal officials emerged from a twohour meeting with representatives of the Municipal Assistance Corporation here today still resolutely opposed to Government backing of municipal bonds but full of encouragement for the city's efforts at selfhelp.

title: Cotton Prices Rising as Use Widens
description: Consumers are coming back to cotton, and the trend has been so pronounced of late that domestic use of cotton is expected to show the first significant increase in a decade for the crop year that began Aug. 1.

title: Test of Lethal Gas on Unwitting G.I.'s Is Confirmed
description: A highlevel Government medical researcher confirmed tonight a report by Representative Thomas J. Downey that the Army had tested deadly nerve gas on soldiers at the Edgewood Arsenal in Maryland without telling them exactly what they would receive.

title: PRICES OF GRAINS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: After their sharp surge in price earlier in the week, grains and soybeans dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: U.S. STUDY IS SET ON AUTO DUMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8The Treasury announced today a formal investigation into whether foreign cars are being dumped in the United States marketthat is, sold at a lower price here than in their home markets.

title: U.S. STEEL LIFTS PRICES BY 3.8% ON A BROAD LINE
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's Largest steel producer, announced price changes yesterday that would raise the company's prices an average of 3.8 per cent between now and Oct.,1.

title: $90MILLION RISE SOUGHT BY LILCO
description: Citing a record construction program for next year, the Long Island Lighting Company asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to increase its electric rates 15.6 per cent in 1976 for a total of $90million.

title: FRANCES M. ROBERTS
description: Frances Markley Roberts, who taught at St. John's University in Shanghai during a 32year stay in China, died Wednesday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. She was 74 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Jets Plan to Test Rookies Against Viking Regulars
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 8There are times when the Jets' coach, Charley Winner, sounds suspiciously like Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof.

title: Rome Draws Up Bill to Let Newsmen Withhold Sources
description: ROME, Aug. 8 (Reuters)The Italian Government today approved the draft of a bill that would allow journalists not to reveal the sources of their ticles even in criminal trials, Justice Minister Oronzo Reale announced.

title: Stock Prices Are Mixed In Slowest 1975 Session
description: Declines topped advances again yesterday in the slowest trading of the year on the New York Stock Exchange. Strength in two bluechip issuesU. S. Steel and Anaconda  helped the Dow Jones industrial average close with a slight gain on the day.

title: The Stage:
description: Brecht was, of course, right in his understanding of the values of translation. A classic translated can be subtly updatedthe translation can sensibly move with the seasons in a way that the text cannot. John Pasquin's staging, for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, tries to do for Shakespeare's Comedy of Errors what Frank Dunlop did for Moliere's Seapine. The attempt fails, but there is some incidental fun along the route.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in last Saturday's New York Times incorrectly listed the secondquarter earnings of the Exxon Corporation for 1974 and 1975 and of the Standard Oil Company of California for 1974. The percentage changes in the companies' earnings were also incorrect. A corrected version of the table appears today on Page 25.

title: Screen: Supervixens
description: The sexual revolution hasn't exactly rendered Russ Meyer obsolete, but since all restrictions have been removed from the manufacture of dirty movies, Mr. Meyer doesn't have much to tease us with any more. Mr. Meyer is the softcore porn king of the nineteensixties who first hit the big money in the late fifties with The Immoral Mr. Teas, about a wretchedly shy fellow who could see through women's clothing.

title: After 365 Days as a Private Citizen, Nixon Is Active in the Politics of 1976
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 8  A year after the scandals of Watergate drove him to resign the Presidency, Richard M. Nixon is emerging from the trauma of that ordeal and, according to associates, is taking an active interest in Republican party politics.

title: 2 Pilots Told of Winds Before Crash
description: DENVER, Aug. 8 (UPI)The pilots of two airplanes, including a passenger jet, reported to the airport tower by radio the existence of strong wind turbulence five minutes before a Continental Airlines 727 passenger jet crashed yesterday while attempting to take off, airport officials said today.

title: Algeria Frees Boy of 7, Easing Rift With France
description: PARIS, Aug. 8  Sevenyearold Borzani Kradaoui finally made it home to France today, aftera vacation with his grandparents in Algeria, averting at least temporarily an angry crisis in FrenchAlgerian relations.

title: Lure of Summer Jobs Draws Students to Washington
description: WASHINGTONAlthough the summer job market has dried up elsewhere, students have continued to stream, into Washington this summer.

title: Bridal Held for Annis Gilbert And Nicholas Joseph Kukulan
description: Annis Kendall Gilbert and Nicholas Joseph Kukulan, who both received master's degrees in social work in June from the University of Southern California, were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Clark B. Olsen, a Unitarian minister of Morristown, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Frederick Spofford Gilbert of New Canaan, Conn., the bride's stepmother.

title: Next Stop: Peking
description: After the smiling handshakes with Soviet party leader Brezhnev, the inevitable next foray in superpower diplomacy for President Ford will be the trek to Peking, scheduled for late this year. By contrast with the misguided and empty journey to Helsinki, a summit meeting with the Chinese has potential for helping to stabilize the United States presence in the Pacific.

title: StopGap Cabinet Installed By Portuguese President
description: LISBON, Aug. 8  President Francisco da Costa Gomes, after three weeks of turmoil and uncertainty following the resignation of two major nonCommunist parties from the Government, today swore in a new Cabinet devoid of any strong political base but leaning toward the Communists.

title: Refugees Caught in Union Dispute at Coast Egg Farm
description: MOORPARK, Calif., Aug. 8Phan Than Khiet stands less than 5 feet 6 inches tall. He is thin and wan, and his right arm is gonehardly someone, likely to aggravate a bitter labor dispute. But as he works in the sweltering California heat in a place they call Egg City, he is hearing a word for which there is no counterpart in his native Vietnamese.

title: JAWORSKI PRAISES NATION'S JUDGES
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 8  Leon Jaworski, the former special Watergate prosecutor, lavishly praised the nation's judges today for their work in both Watergate and other cases and castigated persons who criticize the judiciary.

title: N.S.A. Says It Is Not Eavesdropping
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Officials of the National Security Agency said in a closed session of the House Select Committee on Intelligence today that at the present time the agency was not eavesdropping on domestic or overseas telephone calls placed by Americans, the committee chairman reported.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. F. David Mathews, 39 years old, was sworn in yesterday as the Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. He is the youngest person ever to hold that post and is also the youngest member of President Ford's Cabinet.

title: WILLIAM D. GAILLARD
description: William D. Gaillard, a senior partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: The Cast
description: SUPERVIXENS, directed, written, produced, photographed and edited of Russ Meyer; executive producer, A. James Ryan; music, William Loose; distributed by RM Films International, Inc. Running time: 106 minutes. At the Embassy Theater, Broadway at 47th Street, and other theaters. This film has been rated X.

title: Ramsey Boy, 18, Is Seized In LiquorStore Bombing
description: An 18yearold Ramsey high school student was held in $100,000 bail yesterday on Federal charge of having set off a nailfilled pipe bomb last Monday night, wrecking an Allendale liquor store and injuring two children sleeping in an apartment upstairs.

title: Jobless to Get Training WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI)
Commodity Price Index Shows Decline for Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 198.7 from 201.2 last week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LOTTERY NUMBERS Aug. 8, 1975

title: Intrauterine Device Won't Be Sold Again
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 8 (AP)The A. H. Robins Company announced today that it was abandoning plans to put the Dalkon shield, an intrauterine contraceptive device, back on the market. A spokesman for the pharmaceutical manufacturer said the company remains firm in its belief that the Dalkon shield, when properly used, is a safe and effective I.U.D.

title: '74 GRAIN WARNING IS REPORTED GIVEN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 8A Louisiana state agency responsible for grain inspection was provided with information a year ago about posslhe extortion and bribery activity by some of its inspectors, a Federal prosecutor says, but has made no effort to investigate the situation.

title: Connecticut Cities Get Wide Development Powers
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 8Connecticut cities and towns were given sweeping powers today to borrow money in order to build and develop property and to attract new businesses and wipe out blighted urban areas.

title: Youngsters' FalseAlarm Thrills...
description: The New York Fire Department is planning to play a form of Russian roulette with fire alarms by answering those that they assume from past records are legitimate and ignoring those which have a bad record for being false alarms.

title: LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI SHELLING
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Aug. 8 (Reuters)Israeli gunboats appeared off southern Lebanon tonight as Israeli artillery shelled three villages close to the border, according to residents of the areas.

title: British Government Supports Daily Broadcasts of Parliament
description: LONDON, Aug. 8The BritGovernment has given official blessing to the idea that the daily radio broadcasting or parliamentary debates will benefit politicians and public alike.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Aug. 1, 1975

title: U.S. MailFraud Charges Against Bailey Dropped
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 8 (AP)United States District Judge John A. Reed dismissed today Federal mail fraud charges against F. Lee Bailey the lawyer. Judge Reed granted a motion for dismissal filed last week by Mr. Bailey, who asserted he had been denied a speedy trial.

title: Westchester Proves an Easy Landlord
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 8Westchester County discovered recently, quite by accident, that it had become a generous landlord over the year, in some cases providing gracious homes at token rents to complete strangers.

title: Libya Is Said to Consider Freeing the 10 Terrorists
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 8 (Reuters)The fate of 10 Japanese terrorists who landed here after a flight from Malaysia with four hostages remained unknown today.

title: Portugal on the Brink?
description: Is Portugal on the brink of civil war? The question rises naturally in the wake of mounting antiCommunist violence in numerous communities, public splits in the armed forces with many soldiers proclaiming that they will not fire on their fellow citizens, and the long delay in forming a new government.

title: Thousands of Whites Pouring Out of Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 8Same 20,000 whites are crowded into schools and exhibit halls in Nova Lisboa, Angola's second largest city, another 20,000 are trying to reach SouthWest Africa, and plans are under way to airlift out 200.000 more.

title: Dairylea Fined $100,000 By State on Sales Violation
description: ALBANY, Aug. 8The Dairylea Cooperative, Inc., which last year paid a $150,000 fine for adulterating and mislabeling milk and milk products, was fined $100,000 today for another and unrelated violation of the State Agriculture and Markets Law.

title: FordReagon Primary Preview Likely in New Hampshire Race
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Reports that both President Ford and former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California will campaign for Louis C. Wyman in New Hampshire's special Senate race appeared to set the stage today for a preview of their probable confrontation in that state's 1976 Republican Presidential primary.

title: Sandra Palmer Takes 2Shot Lead in Britain
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, (AP)Sandra Palmer of Dal las, playing with a badly blistered and heavily ban dages right foot, moved into a twostroke lead today in the third round of the Eu ropean women's open golf championship. She carded a twounderfor 72 for a 54 hole total of 211, on the sunscorched, 6,174yard Sunningdale course.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: In Westchester, Mansions at $2 a Year
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 8Westchester County discovered recently, quite by accident, that it had become a generous landlord over the year, in some cases providing gracious homes at token rents to complete strangers.

title: Hard Times Taking Toll Among Clubs of London
description: LONDON, Aug. 8One of the better stories reflecting the power and exclusiveness once enjoyed by the gentlemen's clubs of London involves a police raid near the turn of the century on Beefsteak's, a small club in a raffish neighborhood near Leicester Square.

title: U.S. Report Urges More Powerful Police Bullet
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) A new Government study suggests that policemen should change their standard ammunition from the traditional lowvelocity 159 grain 38caliber bullet to one with more stopping power.

title: Quarantine Center for Animals to Move to State
description: The United States Department of Agriculture's quarantine station for imported animath, in Clifton, N. J., since 1903, will be relocated at Stewart Airport, near Newburgh

title: New Law Requires Seekers of Divorce To Disclose Assets
description: A bill requiring both parties in a divorce action to file sworn statements of net worth before the start of the trial was signed into law yesterday by Governor Carey.

title: COLOR TUBE PRICE IS RAISED BY RCA
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday a 5 per cent increase in the cost of color, television picture tubes in the replacement market on an exchage basis, effective Sept. 1. The new price structure includes the replacement tube less any glass bulb tradein allowance on old tubes, the company said. The increase does not cover the Colorama A tubes. RCA said the increases were necessary to offset rising costs of tube components and production.

title: SILVIO V. MARINO
description: Silvio V. Marino, a vice president of Pinkerton's, Inc., the security organization, died yesterday at Franklin General Hospital, Franklin Square, L. I. He was 46 years old and lived in North Valley Stream.

title: WARNING IGNORED ON STRIPED BASS
description: At Gage & Tollner's in Brooklyn and at Sweet's in Manhattan, tourists and businessmen were eating striped bass as usual yesterday, and in Poughkeepsie they were drinking water as usual.

title: U.S. IS INVESTIGATING FERTILIZER INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) The Justice Department is investigating the fertilizer Industry, looking into allegations of price fixing and other antitrust violations.

title: CANADIAN AGENCY REJECTS MERGER
description: Westinghouse Canada, Ltd., of Hamilton, Ontario, said yesterday that it had been informed that the Canadian Foreign Investment Review Agency had rejected its $44 million agreement for WCI Canada, Ltd., to acquire Westinghouse Canada's home appliance business.

title: U. S. Animal Center to Move From Clifton
description: The United States Department of Agriculture's quarantine station for imported animals, in Clifton; N.J., since 1903, will be relocated at Stewart Airport, near Newburgh.

title: Prices Show a Drop On Amex and OTC In Slow Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market continued to decline yesterday in slower trading.

title: Ghost Town in New Mexico Is Reborn as a Community of People
description: MADRID, N.M.Somebody spotted a wisp of smoke near the old No. 4 coal mine shaft near town the other day and started shouting. Richard Blum stopped sawing. Demetrius Aiello stopped roofing. Terry Conrad stopped rolling a cigarette. Instead of leaving it to the county fire department, people all over town dropped what they were doing, rushed out with shovels and snuffed out the fire.

title: Smith Haven Holds Free Art Classes
description: LAKE GROVEThe Smith Haven Ministries, a nonprofit, ecumenically based social services organization housed in Smith Haven Mall here, is offering free art classes this summer.

title: Top Secret: Alligators!
description: What happens when baby alligators are snatched from the swamp by mercenaries, brought to a city store and sold as pets for kids? Well, after their first playful nip, the alligators are flushed down the toiletinto the sewers.

title: Matthew Kelly Marries Barbara Susan Bursch
description: Barbara Susan Bursch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Bursch of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Matthew James Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Kelly, also of Garden City.

title: Title to Miss Massey
description: OAKFIELD, Nova Scotia, Aug. 9 (AP)Debbie Massey of Bethlemem, Pa., the defending champion, won the Canadian women's amateur golf championship today by posting a fiveunderpar 69 on the final round. Miss Massey broke the course record for women by two strokes over the 5,934yard, par74 Oakfield Golf and Country Club layout. Her 72hole score was 293.

title: Free Funerals in Genoa
description: GENOA, Italy, Aug. 9 (AP)The new Marxistcontrolled municipal council today decided that starting Sept. I funerals would be free on request. Until now the cityowned burial service has been charging $480 for the cheapest funeral and burial.

title: Guest Observer
description: Should the American family, from the tiniest toddler on upward, be allowed to gaze upon Cher Bono's belly button? This is the semiawesome question that has jittery TV executives at CBS divided these days into a pair of angrily warring camps. The problem is that The Cher Show, on which the exMrs. Sonny Bono has frequently in the past displayed her belly button, is seen on CBS on Sunday evening from 8 o'clock until 9. And that, beginning in the fall, the hour each evening from 8 o'clock until 9 has been designated by the networks as TV's socalled family hourthat is, nothing can be shown in those simonpure 60 minutes that isn't entirely fit for everyone in the family to look at. In consequence, from 8 o'clock until 9, there will be no more rape, gore, adultery, shootouts, punchups or kicks in the groin. (On television, at least. What the American family does in the privacy of its home is its own business.) And, if one of the warring factions at CBS has its way, no more belly buttons either.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: There is an aspect of photography known professionally as picture editing which is often ignored by the nonprofessional. Neglect of picture editing, however, can be expensive for the photographer and deadly dull for his audience.

title: Janna Dresden Wed To Ronald Cervero
description: Janna Dresden Wed To Ronald Cervero Janna Dresden, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Max Dresden of Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday morning to Ronald Cervero, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cervero of Bridgeport. Conn.

title: Morristown Bars A Hallway House
description: MORRISTOWN  Several leaders in the mentalhealth community have intimated that permission to open what would be Morris County's first halfway house for former psychiatric patients was denied because neighbors of the proposed facility feared for their personal safety and property values, or simply did not want to associate with persons who had been institutionalized.

title: Electrocution, Not Hanging, Blamed in Indian's Death.
description: CUT BANK, Mont., Aug. 8An investigation into an apparent jail cell suicide of a young Blackfoot Indian here has fund the man could have died from electric shock before he was found hanging by a belt in his cell.

title: U.S. Sales of Arms Overseas Reach a Record of $9Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Foreign military sales by the United States in the fiscal year ending June 30 reached a record $9billion, with nearly half going to three Persian Gulf states.

title: Twotime winners
description: Oldfashioned, onceinalifetime, tilldeathdouspart marriage may be going on the rocks these days, but remarriage is booming. Divorce rates are soaring. Couples are breaking up like icebergs in a summer sea. Yet statisticians report that, of the nearly one million people who get divorced in the United States every year, four out of five are remarrying. (So far as marriages are concerned, one out of every four is now usually a second, sometimes a third marriage, occasionally even a fourth; only a small proportion of these are of widowed persons.)

title: Kenneth Emerson Knowles 3d And Martha H. Beebe Marry
description: Martha Holloway Beebe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sohn Eldridge Beebe of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Lake Placid, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Emerson Knowles 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Knowles Jr. of Oyster Bay.

title: Cooley HighMore Than Just a Black Graffiti
description: It is difficult to remember bow it really was all those years ago, in my Cooley High, when Miss Stokes and Mr. Phillips and Miss Smith dominated our lives; when everything was real sharp or real neat or cool, and 10thgrade boys wore their belts suggestively unbuckled, and girls applied hot irons and pounds of Dixie Peach to short hairdos. My Cooley High was Dunbar High School of the 1950's in Dayton, Ohio. It was similar to the early sixties Chicago school portrayed in the new movie Cooley Highwhich is to say, it was allblack, isolated in one small corner of the city, untouched by black consciousness and almost casual about that wider, white world surrounding it.

title: Like Jumping Over a Little Puddle
description: MONTCLAIR  Eighteen women sprint across the floor with varying degrees of abandon.

title: A Sailor's Split Second of Terror
description: SUMMER, and my landlocked thoughts turn between daydreams of warm breezy Sunday afternoons and reflections an last season's sails. Actually, on the first sail of the year aboard the good ship Nadja, bound for Block Island, whenfor an eternity of secondsmy life hung in the balance.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets will play at Shea Stadium all week. They will meet the San Diego Padres at 8:05 P.M. tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday. Thursday is an off day. The San Francisco Giants, with Bobby Murcer, are in for games at 5:30 Friday (doubleheader), 2:15 Saturday and 2:05 Sunday.

title: List of the Contributions Reported by Ashland Oil, Inc.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Following is the list of contributions reported by Ashland Oil, Inc.:

title: S.S. United States Price Cut
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 9 (AP) The United States Maritime Administration has slashed $4.5million from its asking price for the S.S. United States, the oncegreat ocean liner. The Federal Government, owner of the vessel, reduced the price to $7.6million from $12.1million yesterday and announced that the ship was for sale once again.

title: Jean Balukas Wins 4th Title
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (UPI)Jean Balukas, a 16yearold high school junior from Brooklyn, earned $3,000 and her fourth straight United States open women's pocket billiards championship today with a 10062 victory in 39 innings over Mieko Harada of Uji City, Japan.

title: Jack Scott: Polemics and Stereotypes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Two Arrested Men Freed For Helping in Fire Rescue
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP)Two men picked up for disorderly conduct won their freedom when they helped arresting officers rescue 20 persons from a burning North Side apartment building.

title: Grooms End Strike
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Aug. 9 (AP)  Narragansett Park grooms, who struck this week over the loss of night pay, returned to work today after saying they had made their point. The race track was shut down for five weeks this summer by a purse contract dispute with horsemen. It opened Monday and has stayed open despite the grooms' strike.

title: Let Us Not Praise Nashville's Failures
description: Robert Altman's colorful, selfindulgent, overblown and vastly overpraised new movie, Nashville, is basically like every other Altman film. It has the same strengths: some brilliant performances, moments of peculiar unnerving tension, an eye for realistic detail and a strong sense of place. And it has the same weaknesses; a story with more loose ends than you can count, a soundtrack deliberately designed to prevent you from hearing what the characters are saying to one another, a visual style that seems to have been learned at the knees of television news and quiz show cameramen, and, not least, a treatment of women that often borders on celluloid rape.

title: Bronxville Aging Softly, Swinging a Cane
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.This craggy, breathtaking square mile across the Bronx River from Yonkers is basking in the fulfillment of an earlier era's optimism.

title: Potomac Crew Upset in National Trials
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 9  A lightweight four without coxswain from the National Association of American Oarsmen registered a twolength victory today over the Potomac Boat Club, the national champion, at the N.A.A.O. small boat trials on Lake Carnegie.

title: Renovation to Close a Landmark Midtown Pub
description: A 90yearold building incongruously tucked amid the skyscrapers of Rockefeller Center will soon be restored as a restaurant fashioned after a 19th century tavern.

title: 5 UNIONS' STRIKES RETARD BUILDING
description: Current strikes by five building trades unions, if continued, could hold up construction and modernization projects and delay the opening of some city schools next month, according to school and contracting officials.

title: P.S.C. Prods 7 Major Utilities To Provide Realistic Cost Data
description: New York State's Public Service Commission has prodded the seven major electric utilities of the state to provide realistic data on production costs so the rate structure can be revised to charge more for usage that is responsible for peak demand.

title: Lauren Flint Totty Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Lauren Flint Totty, a secretary at the New York Law School, to John Taylor Higginbotham, who is with the legal department of the National Bank of North America in New York, took place in the Martha Mary Chapel at the Wayside Inn in Sudbury, Mass., yesterday afternoon.

title: Discount Utility Rates Proposed for Elderly
description: ATLANTIC CITYRepresentatives of organizations of elderly people from Atlantic, Cumberland, Camden, Cape May and Burlington Counties appeared at a hearing here last week by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners to urge it to recommend that the Legislature adopt a bill providing for utility discounts for the elderly.

title: Lakers Are Knicks' Foe In Opener
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar will make his regularseason National Basketball Association debut here as a Los Angeles Laker against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden Thursday night, Oct. 23.

title: North Bergen Is Guarding Its Identity
description: NORTH BERGEN  Residents of this Hudson County township say their biggest concern is retaining their identity as a community in the middle of the most urban area in North Jersey. North Bergen, one of the oldest communities in the state, was settled by the first Dutch who emigrated to what became New Jersey. And despite its age, North Bergen attempts to remain progressive, and is ahead of many younger communities in some ways.

title: More Dogs Being Left At Pounds in Recession
description: BOSTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)An increasing number of dogs are reportedly being left at pobnds because owners cannot afford to feed and care for them. And, according to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, beatings, starvings and other cruel treatment of animals have doubled.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 10, 1975

title: Friday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Vito Antuofermo, 160 pounds, Brooklyn, outpointed Vinnie Curto, 160, Miami, 10 rounds.

title: Economic Aid Bill Is On Its Own
description: When members of the House International Relations Committee approved a $1.35billion economic and food assistance bill for developing countries last week, separate from any military aid, they seemed almost to be certifying that foreign assistance programs were entering a new phase.

title: Milkman Goeth
description: The milkman, as one might have noticed, appears to be going the way of the iceman.

title: GIFTED PUPILS GET LANGUAGE SKILLS
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.In an attempt to show that more attention should be paid to gifted children in Westchester County public schools, a fourweek program at Manhattanville College has been exposing 46 elementary school children to Russian, Spanish. French and Japanese.

title: Lucy Albert To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy F. Albert of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Albert, to Thomas Valentine Bermingham 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bermingham, also of Scarsdale.

title: Miss Schwenk, Pranay Gupte Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Schwenk of Southampton. L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Barnes Schwenk, to Pranay Gupte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Balkrishna T. Gupte of Bombay, India.

title: Miss Van Voorhis Plans June Bridal
description: Steven C. Van Voorhis, vice president of the General Electric Company, and Mrs. Van Voorhis of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Van Voorhis, to Dennis B. Lord, son of Ethel Peace of Lakeland, Fla., and Howard Lord of Elberta, Ala.

title: Jumper Title Taker By Space Citation
description: AUGUSTA, N.J., Aug. 9Space Citation, a chestnut gelding who makes jumping look easy, won the amateurowner jumper championship with 13 points today at the Sussex County bourse show.

title: Smokey Bear Will Live Rest of His Days in Zoo
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 9Aging Smokey Bear and his mate Goldie will have to live out their days in the National Zoo in Washington because the cost of building a bear grotto in northern New Mexico far exceeds our estimates, a Forest Service spokesman says. A plan to transfer the two animals to the Ghost Ranch Museum in the Carson National Forest has been dropped. Six bids for the proposed grotto ranges from $64,219 to $93,602.

title: Hospital Loses on Medicare
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has the right to recover $6.3million from Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami, for allegedly unnecessary medical services to Medicaire beneficiaries, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled yesterday. Mt. Sinai is the largest provider of Federal health services in the Southeast, with 60 to 70 per cent of its bills paid by the department.

title: UNREST GROWING IN EL SALVADOR
description: SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 5When El Salvador bid successfully to host this year's Miss Universe contest, the Government saw the press and television coverage as an opportunity to promote this tiny Central American republic as a Pacific Coast tourist attraction.

title: India's Usual Dissenters Fall Silent
description: NEW DELHIAs the heavy monsoon rains fell on the luxuriant tropical shrubbery all around them, two Opposition members of the Indian parliament sat on a wide sheltered veranda late one evening last week, quietly reviewing what had happened to the vibrant democracy of which they used to be so proud.

title: Jovan, Inc.: Chicago's Fragrance Purveyor
description: They all laughed when Bernard A. Mitchell, a sixtyish entrepreneur who had already demonstrated financial wizardry in airconditioning, textiles, organs and wigs, announced he was going to found a perfume company in Chicago.

title: REPORTER PLANS HIGH COURT PLEA
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9William T. Farr, a reporter who has been fighting for years to protect his news sources, has lost another round in efforts to stay out of jail for contempt of court.

title: Vorster and Smith in Rhodesia Accord
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 9The Prime Ministers of South Africa and Rhodesia said today that they had agreed to proposals that could end the long racial and constitutional deadlock in Rhodesia.

title: ChurchState Legal Conflicts Persist
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7When the Billy Graham crusade decided, to visit Jackson, Miss., this year, the Jackson City Council decided to help out. It appropriated $1,000 for the crusade, and paid the money out of the city's general fund.

title: MAJOR HEALTH GAINS REPORTED BY HANOI
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 9 (AP)North Vietnam has reported major advances in controlling epidemics, reducing the mortality rate and lowering the birth rate since its revolution of August, 1945.

title: Led Zeppelin Tour Put Off
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (UPI) The English rock group Led Zeppelin has postponed its AugustSeptember tour of the United States because Robert Plant, its lead singer, was injured in an auto accident this week, it was announced yesterday. He suffered multiple fractures of his ankle, foot bones and elbow on the Greek island of Rhodes.

title: Food
description: Several years ago we dined on an uncommonly interesting dish in an Italian restaurant in Boston. It was roast chicken with a custardlike stuffing that proved to be extremely palatable, not only because of its delicate flavor but also because of its tender, gossamerlike texture. We honestly don't recall the name of the restaurant and would not name it if we did, for it was otherwise undistinguished. After numerous tries in our kitchen, we discovered that the filling was nothing more than wellseasoned scrambled eggs, which, when cooked in the bird, achieved that soughtafter and notably compelling stuffing. We further learned that a similar scrambledegg filling, lightly seasoned with tarragon, is delectable in a veal roll.

title: A Black Family's Trip to identity
description: GROWING up poor and black in sooty Midwestern mill town, I fervently wanted to escape, to go everywhere. I read the National Geographic with the same mouthwatering lust I read Fanny Hilland the National Geographic had pictures!

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.In 1970, as part of a Federal campaign to aid minority businesses, the Small Business Administration played matchmaker for what might seem an unusual couple: Multiplex Communications, Inc., based here, and the Indians of the Fort Peck Reservation, in Poplar. Mont.

title: Raymond G. Woolfe Dies; Steeplechase Trainer, 67
description: Raymond G. Woolfe, a leading steeplechase trainer for many years and a founder of the Colonial Cup International Steeplechase, died Friday evening at his home on Fishers Island. He was 67 years old.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONOn his recent trip to Europe, President Ford apparently has avoided what his top economic advisers would have considered a potential trapa fivepower conference of heads of state whose undisclosed purpose would have been a return to fixed currency exchange rates.

title: Book Ends
description: NameDrop. Leonard Lyons and Walter Winchell being out of business, we occasionally feel it our duty to revive the oldfashioned Broadway column, salted with a lot of wellknown names. Actually we do it at the urging of our 60yearold office boy, Broadway Joe, who fell under the influence of Walter Winchell early in his career and has never been the same since.

title: Letters: One Family, Two Faiths, in Israel
description: The Letters Column this week is de voted entirely to correspondence ad dressed to the Travel Section in response to Steven V. Roberts's article, Israel The Bible for a Baedeker which ap peared on July 20. Mr. Roberts's reply will be found at the end of the column

title: Randolphe Swenson Jr. Marries Abby Patterson
description: Abby Ann Newbold Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stuart Patterson of Princeton, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Randolphe Pierson Swenson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Swenson of Montclair, N. J.

title: DR. FRANK SULLIVAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (AP) Dr. Frank Sullivan, professor of English at Loyola Marymount University, died Thursday. He was 63 years old.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The performance two weeks ago of William Henry Fry's Stabat Mater at the Newport Music Festival sent this writer back to the reference books. Fry (181364), born in Philadelphia, was an Americantrained composer, and most histories of music state that his Leonora was the first fullscale opera ever composed by an American. It was produced in Philadelphia in 1845. He then became foreign correspondent for the Tribune in New York. His notices from abroad, especially his musical notices, attracted much attention. In Paris he became friendly with Berlioz, whose ideas influenced his own music.

title: East Meadow Votes To Retain School
description: The East Meadow Board of Education has reversed a previous school board's plan to close the Prospect Avenue Elementary School.

title: The Military Has Always Been Franco's Principal Strength
description: MADRIDA routine inspection of the stanchest remaining pillar of the Franco regime, the army, revealed some unexpected signs of erosion last week.

title: DeLorean's Formula for Chrysler
description: Last month, I sat next to the top economic planner of the General Motors Corporation at an international congress on automotive safety. I don't see this dramatic automotive turnabout every body is projecting for the fourth quarter. I said.

title: Europe's Inner Demons
description: Not long ago I was invited to discuss my research on witchcraft in Colonial America in a lecture to a small university seminar. Upon arriving at the appointed time and place, I found to my astonishment a waiting audience of several hundred people.

title: 32 Top Tennis Players to Compete in Tournament in Orange
description: SOUTH ORANGEFor one week this month, the Orange Lawn Tennis Club here will be in the international spotlight. Thirty  two of the world's best players, including Jimmy Connors, will compete in the $50,000 Tennis Week Open, a prelude to the United States Open at Forest Hills.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kent Barwick Is Appointed To State Arts Council Post
description: ALBANY, Aug. 9 (AP)Kent Barwick has been appointed director of the New York State Council on the Arts, Governor Carey's office announced today.

title: New & Novel
description: If you were a pheasant with cognitive powers, you might get some pretty funny ideas about why Man (spelled with a capital M) fed you at times and then shot you at other times. And if you were Bamber Gascoigne, you might work up these speculations into a parable with an agnostic message. Okay? So some of the birds in this crowd are ?? ??vivalists who believe that a pheasant's destiny is to rise to the status of a peacock. And some subscribe to the Morsel faith: that pheasant paradise is a casserole. Others are sun worshippers, since the hunting season is in fall and winter. A fowl called Ticker Khan has worked up yet another dogma, which forebodes the gamiest season ever. Jonathan Livingston Seagull flew into the big money on the power of positive thinking. What price futility?

title: Susan P. Conklin Is Bride of Nick Snow
description: Susan Page Conklin was married yesterday afternoon to Norman Nicoll Snow of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Jon Walton performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn.

title: But Their Effectiveness, as With the Old Laws, Depends on Enforcement
description: Faced with the spiraling nursinghome scandal early this year, Governor Carey acted both to punish past abuses in the industry and to prevent them in the future. He named a special prosecutor, Charles J. Hynes, who so far has obtained indictments against two major nursinghome operators, and a Moreland Act Commission, headed by Morris B. Abram, to study what went wrong and to recommend legislative improvements.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Aug. 9 (UPI)A Military tribunal today convicted 14 former army officers of having conspired to overthrow Greece's reborn democracy and sentence them to prison terms ranging from 4 to 12 years.

title: Not since Charlie Parker
description: When John Coltrane, the saxophonistcomposer, died eight years ago last month, at age 40, it seemed that jazz had been suddenly kicked in the belly and might be grappling for some time to regain its wind. Not since Charlie Parker, had a soloist offered a musical conception so compelling and selfsustaining that virtually thousands of musicians, professional and amateur, looked to his every record for sustenance in their own music.

title: Mets' Games This Week
description: TodayLos Angeles at Shea Stadium, 2:05 P.M.

title: Irrigation, an Israeli Export
description: A new method of irrigation developed in Israel is being adopted in other nations to improve agricultural yield and produce crops on land once considered unsuitable for farming.

title: Lawyer Is Appointed A Port Commissioner
description: Matthew Nimetz, 36yearold New York City lawyer and a former White House assistant, has been appointed by Governor Carey to a full sixyear unsalaried term as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Elizabeth Buryan Wed to George Kallop
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Buryan, an account officer in the national banking group of the First National City Bank here, to Arthur George Kallop, an assistant vice president in the bank's real estate industries division, took place in Woodbury, Conn., yesterday afternoon. Canon Earl Estabrook, assisted by the Rev. Andrew Mullins, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Ideas & Trends/Continued
description: SEATTLEDavid J. Evans died last yeartwice. In almost any other city he would have stayed dead the first time his heart stopped, but because he lived in Seattle he is alive today because of a pioneering and unusual program for training citizens to be amateur heart doctors in emergencies.

title: Mr. Ford Is Caught Between American Farmers and American Consumers
description: CHICAGO  The sizable Russian purchases of grain in the United States in recent weeks, and the prospect that the Russians may buy still more, have created political problems, both foreign and domestic, for the Ford Administration.

title: In the Teamsters, the Mob Remains in Good Standing
description: The disappearance of James R. Hoffa under circumstances straight out of The Godfather has brought back to the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters the kind of notoriety that engulfed it when the televised hearings of Senate rackets investigators were the most bloodcurdling crime show on the home screen nearly two decades ago.

title: TV's 19thCentury Sportscaster
description: This coming Saturday afternoon when the $100,000 Travers Stakes are televised from the Saratoga Race Track, one member of the CBS team of reporters will be Heywood Hale Broun, the sports essayist, who, with his icepick voice, his flair for the dramatic and a vocabulary drawn from Dr. Johnson's Dictionary, has won a reputation for treating viewers to commentaries of a sort not usually associated with TV sportscasters.

title: Volunteers Step Up Efforts to Convert To Metric System
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9  Once each hour a cheerfully brisk announcer comes up on Chicago radio station WBBM's broadcast to read another 20second metric memo.

title: Stage: Shoeshine Parlor, Theater for the People
description: There is a great deal more to Joseph Papp's Shakespeare Festival than Shakespeare. While there is a company playing The Comedy of Errors in Central Park and another group of strolling Shakespeareans offering A Chorus Line on Broadway, there is also the festival's Mobile Theater, and in its way this is the most Shakespearean of the lot.

title: Arthur Sheehan, 65, Dies; Biographer, Former Editor
description: Arthur Sheehan, a biographer and formerly an editor of The Catholic Worker and a film editor of CARE, died Tuesday at his home in City Island, the Bronx. He was 65 years old.

title: 3 FESTIVALS HERE OFFER MESSAGES
description: On the East River's Pier 15 it was bluegrass and oldtime country music and a crafts fair. On the Lower East Side's Tompkins Square Park, it was salsa and Puerto Rican national independence. And on the Upper West Side, at a triangular patch called Straus Park, it was jazz and brotherhood.

title: Daisies, Pinks And Other Summer Weeds
description: Unlike the flowers of spring, which tuck themselves away in shady woodlands, the flowers of summer spread wild and free in open fields and along roadsides. They dislike shade, welcome the sun and are Undaunted by the dust of country roads or the harsh blacktop of interstate highways. And why is everyone so insistent to downgrade them as mere weeds? Consider their common names: bindweed, milkweed, pokeweed, fireweed, smartweed, ragweed, horseweed (which it Is indeed), mayweed, knapweed, sneezeweed, greenweed, hawkweed, pineapple weed, butterfly weed and Joe Pyeweed!

title: Mrs. Gandhi Fundamentally Alters Indian Democracy With Discipline
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 9Two months ago, when an obscure provincial judge in Allahabad, found Prime Minister Indira Gandhi guilty of two electoral offenses, the ruling was widely hailed as proof that all citizens were equal before the law in India.

title: Oil Tankers Held More Of Threat Than Rigs
description: ITHACA, N.Y.A Cornell University professor has issued a report saying that Long Island faces a greater pollution threat from oil tankers than from offshore oil rigs.

title: The man at the money throttle
description: Money is human happiness in the abstract, said Schopenhauer, and he considered such an abstraction to be a poor substitute for the real pleasures of the spirit and flesh. These days, however, it is clear that a lack of money means human unhappiness in all too concrete forms: lost jobs, lost homes, lost businesses, lost education, lost career opportunities, lost weight, lost sleep, lost selfrespect.

title: Jane Moeller Has Bridal
description: Jane A. Moeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Moeller Jr. of Eaton's Neck, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Raymond J. Holland 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Holland of Bayvine, L. I. The Rev Dr. John Forden, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Moeller home.

title: Notes: Signs of Life in Congress, Fun and Games at Artpark
description: Before recessing on Aug. 1, the U.S. Senate made one of its infrequent ventures into cultural legislationit passed a useful bill known as the Arts and Artifacts Indemnity Act. Introduced by Senators Jacob Davits and Claiborne Pell (a similar bill sponsored by Congressmen John Brademas and Alphonzo Bell awaits passage by the House), the measure is intended to boost the number of international art shows throughout the country by having the Federal Government subsidize insurance costs.

title: Barbara Reese, Teacher, Is a Bride
description: Barbara Seymour Reese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Reese of Havre de Grace, Md., was married there yesterday to Dr. Harry James VanDolah 3d, who is completing a residency in diagnostic radiology at the Baylor School of Medicine in Houston. The Rev. F. Lee Cutair, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: M.A.C. CALLS ON U.S. TO PAY FOR RELIEF
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation has appealed formally to the Federal Government to take over the cost of welfare here as an essential step to restoring solvency to the city's fiscal affairs.

title: SHARKS SLAY HALF OF THOSE ATTACKED
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., Aug. 9 (UPI)Nearly half of all persons attacked by sharks die, according to a new study by marine biologists.

title: Malpractice Suits
description: A nationwide survey of 3;000 doctors confirms what has generally been reported, that malpractice suits and threats of suits have increased markedly over the last four years.

title: A Stand Provides Produce and Jobs
description: NEWARKA group of innercity teenagers, with help from the local Zion Baptist Church, operate a fruit and vegetable stand here, selling the produce at prices well below those in supermarkets. In addition, the coop that runs the stand provides summer jobs, which are scarce this year.

title: East Germany Badly Short of Workers
description: BERLINA recent advertise ment in an East German newspaper offered the use of a beauty parlor and a sauna, a choice of 10 luncheon menus and extensive sports facilities.

title: Medical Center Reflects A Builder's Flamboyance
description: A Staten Island builder has erected a medical center that is a stylistic relative of Dulles International Airport and the United Nations General Assembly building.

title: Closer Arab Ties With Nigeria Seen By Some Africans
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 9A highlevel Libyan delegation has begun talks here with Nigeria's 12day old military Government.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: Darcy Lorin Is Bride
description: Darcy Lorin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Lorin of Merrick, L.I., was married last night to Matthew J. Klein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Klein of Amityville, L.I. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony in Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I. The bride, a publicrelations writer, graduated cum Laude from the University of Pennsylvania. She attended Princeton during her junior year. Her husband, a student at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y., graduated cum laude from Hobart College.

title: Csonka, Kiick, Warfield Score as Southmen Win
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 9 (AP) Csonka, Kiick, Warfield & Co., otherwise known as the Memphis Southmen, staged a secondhalf comeback tonight and overwhelmed the Charlotte Hornets, 2311, in a World Football League game.

title: Title IX: No Reason for Fright
description: During a recent lull in the battle over Title IX, it dawned on me that I have accidentally become a man ahead of his time. Ahead in the sense that because I am the men's basketball coach at Queens College, I have already lived the experiences that so many men are emotionally speculating will occur under the implementation of Title IX.

title: Death of Shostakovich is Reported at Concert
description: The death in Moscow of Dmitri Dmitryevich Shostakovich, the Russian composer, was reported last night at the Tanglewood music festival in Lenox, Mass.

title: France Is Reducing Sales Of Arms to South Africa
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Aug. 9 President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France announced today that France would no longer sell arms having a continental use to South Africa.

title: Rabat Plans Saigon Ties
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  Morocco has decided to recognize the new Communist Government in South Vietnam it was announced here today.

title: WESTERN UNION CO. TO BE INVESTIGATED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) Congress will investigate the Western Union Telegraph Company to determine whether the message service has abused its role as a public utility and should be challenged competitively, it was announced today.

title: Visitors Swarm Aboard NATO Ships
description: Hundreds of landlubbers got their first glimpse of navy life yesterday as they swarmed over the decks of six NATO warships docked in the Hudson River, gingerly poking missiles, leafing through log books and peeking into portholes.

title: Elizabeth Curtiss Nelson a Bride
description: In the chapel of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon Elizabeth Curtiss Nelson, daughter of Wenley Dodds Nelson of Rosemont, Pa., and Nantucket, Mass., and Mrs. Richard Coast Murphy of Greenwich, Conn., and Walpole, N. H., was married to Frank Lawrence Wiswall Jr., son of Mrs. Wiswall of Castine, Me., and the late Mr. Wiswall. The Rev. Dr. Douglas E. Nelson, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Ray Dollenmeyer.

title: Miss Young Wins Again
description: LINCOLN, Neb. Aug. 9 (AP)A fivetime former champion, Jo Anne Young of Norfolk, Va., captured the junior women's style figure event last night at the United States amateur roller skating championships.

title: ARKANSAS COUPLE SCORED ON LOANS
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 9 A wave of criticism has broken out here over a legalaid lawyer and his wife who recently used the Federal bankruptcy law to avoid repayment of $18,382 in student loans.

title: Goodwill Industries Drops Brief Canning Lid Offer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) Goodwill Industries is getting out of the home canning lid business after just one week because it cannot handle the flood of orders it has received.

title: State Court Blocks Road in Douglaston
description: Construction of a plumed street at 39th Avenue between 234th Street and Douglaston Parkway has been blocked by a temporary injunction issued by Justice Moses M. Weinstein of the State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: William Saumsiegle Weds Miss Stokes
description: Nancy Johnston Stokes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pierson Stokes of Sandy Hook, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to William Joslyn Saumsiegle, son of Genieve J. Saumsiegle of Needham, Mass., and Robert W. Saumsiegle of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Pro Nader pro, con Nader con
description: Four or five years ago, when Ralph Nader was riding high, people used to ask him what he would do when the bubble burst, when the press began ignoring him and his Raiders made mistakes. The same thing I'm doing now, he would reply, a response that has proven to be truthful, even as it left unanswered the question of just what it is he does. It is that question which, from opposite ends of the political spectrum, these two authors address, leaving the reader to work out his own solution by triangulation.

title: America: New Maturity or Failure of Nerve?
description: WASHINGTONThis capital city is preoccupied, as usual, with the politics and personalities of the coming Presidential election campaign, but outside Washington, and also here, there is muted hum of debate about the mind and values of America, its purposes policies and intentions beyond the chatter, sham and posturing of politics.

title: PRESIDENT MARKS A YEAR IN OFFICE; HAILS ASTRONAUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9President Ford paid homage today to the last Apollo astronauts, and consulted with his advisers on economic, energy and national security matters. But there were no cheers, no backward glances on the first anniversary of his Presidency.

title: Classical, Pop, JazzKellaway Plays It All
description: Roger Kellaway suffers from the curse of unclassifiability. He is a brilliant and colorful jazz pianist, but his mind is as much in classical music as it is in jazz (he was trained at the New England Conservatory of Music). He is an arranger of individuality, as attested by his seven charts for Carmen McRae's new Blue Note album, I Am Music. He is a superior songwriter, as evidenced by I Have the Feeling I've Been Here Before. He is a serious composer who has done several film scores and who was commissioned by George Balanchine to write the music for the 1971 ballet Pamtgg (based, whimsically, at Balanchine's request, on themes from the TV commercial, Pan Am makes the Going Great).

title: CHINA HAS BUILT BIGPOWER NAVY
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 9With little notice by the outside world, China has quietly built up what is now regarded as the world's third largest navy.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: New Role for the Pierrepont
description: A proposal to convert the rundown, hallcenturyold Pierrepont Hotel into apartments for subsidized rental to the elderly is expected to clear a major hurdle within the next few weeks at a community meeting in Brooklyn Heights.

title: ISRAEL REVAMPING TAXATION SYSTEM
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 9Israel has replaced her harsh system of direct taxation with a comparatively mild one and has served notice that she will no longer cooperate in a system of authorized tax evasion.

title: C. W. Post Opening Center for Crafts
description: GREENVALE A crafts center will be opened for classes at C. W. Post College this fall, a spokesman for the college has announced.

title: BODY OF A GIRL, 15, IS FOUND IN PARK
description: The body of a teenaged girl, found Friday evening in a fairly secluded corner of Prospect Park, was identified by the police yesterday as that of a Brooklyn junior high school pupil from the Flatbush section who apparently was on her way to the Brooklyn Public Library at the edge of the park.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Image of Cleon Jones
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STAGE VIEWS
description: STRATFORD, CONN. It would take Polonius to provide a proper descriptive term for The Winter's Tale: tragicalcomicalhistoricalromanticalmythical, perhaps? Shakespeare's play is a dramaturgical monster, shuttling from neartragedy in Sicilia to pastoral comedy and pastoral romance in Bohemia, and then back again to Sicilia; at one point Time himself comes onstage to inform us that 16 years have just passed. This is the play in which one character is eaten by a bear, in which another is abandoned on the seacoast of Bohemia, and in which a statue comes to life. Yet this implausible farrago is also a profound poem about nature, fertility, reconciliation, renewal, and other matters that occupied Shakespeare's mind during his last years.
