Furthermore, it has moments of lyricism, comedy and general high spirits as ravishing as anything he ever wrote.

title: BRIDGE
description: Rubber bridge players who turn to tournament play have no trouble when they confine themselves to team events scored by international match points. They have plenty of scope in knockout and Swiss contests. All that they need essentially is a greater degree of partnership understanding.

title: Legislature Lauded On Open Meetings
description: TRENTON  Common Cause, the publicinterest lobby, has issued its assessment of the twoyear Record of the New Jersey Legislature, citing its approval of an openmeetings bill as the Legislature's most significant accomplishment in opening government to public scrutiny.

title: Brooks Bowen Becomes Fiance Of Miss Rogers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Elliott Rogers of Locust Valley, L. I., and Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Barbara Rogers, to Brooks Jefferson Bowen of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardy Jefferson Bowen of Greenville, Del. An October wedding is planned.

title: A Man Ain't Nothin' But a Man
description: Black American history boasts authentic heroes aplenty but few from folklore. An exception is the monumental John Henry, the subject of a widely sung black ballad, whose prowess with a steel hammer (and sometimes two one swung in each hand) made him the giant of raillaying and rockcrushing a century ago and pitted him at last in a fateful duel with the newly developed steamhammer. It was a duel John Henry won but died winning. Roark Bradford made a book and later a play out of the ballad 40 years ago, and the ballad itself is familiar to generations of schoolchildren.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHOLESALE PRICE INDEX rose 1.2 per cent in July, the largest increase since April when it rose 1.5 per cent. In the last 12 months the index rose 12.4 per cent.. .. The First National City Bank raised its prime rate to 7 per cent from 7 per cent. . . . W. T. Grant Company reached an agreement with 27 banks for extension of its loans to July 30, 1976 and subordination of $300million in loans In favor of vendors until then.

title: Amin Asserts Palestinians Serve in Uganda Air Force
description: LONDON, Aug. 9 (Reuters)Palestinian suicide pilots are serving in the Uganda air force ready for missions against white regimes in Africa, the Uganda radio today quoted President Idi Amin as having said.

title: U.S. Agency Urges L.I. Sound Clean Up
description: A major plan to reclaim the Long Island Sound by cleaning up the water, creating new parks and beaches, improving fishing, reducing flood damage and increasing ferry services has been advanced by the New England River Basins Commission, a Federal agency, after a fiveyear study.

title: Needed, 15 pages of practice
description: B. S. Johnson is dead. I knew it at once, before I read his jacket blurb; See the Old Lady Decently has been given an introduction. Introductions, you understand, are our epitaphs. They murder plot surprise; they seed the mind with unnecessary critical aperus. Only over his dead body would B. S. Johnson have put up with an introduction. Once writers have gone, it seems, their writing must be cosmeticized, explained away. The introduction is a rude autopsy, your publisher's last, unanswerable insult.

title: Paperbacks
description: BETWEEN MYTH AND MORNING, by Elizabeth Hardwick. (Morrow, $3.95.) Essays examining the changes in the social order that have been affecting women: intellectual strength expressed in elegant and supple prose.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: All the records reviewed below contain an element of surprisean unknown work of unusual interest which one might never hear in a lifetime of concert going, a familiar war horse given a completely fresh interpretation by a newcomer, an established artist inspired to surpass his or her highest standards. At any rate, each of these disks offers something to perk up summer record listening.

title: LETTERS
description: Nureyev Nureyev Nureyev

title: 2OO Here Protest Detention By British of Northern Irish
description: About 200 people rallied in front of the Fifth Avenue office of British, Airways yestrday to mark the fourth year of internment of Irish activists in Northern Ireland and to protest what they regard as harassment of Irish sympathizers in the United States.

title: Mosquito Infestation Is Eased By Weather
description: HAUPPAUGE  A record 3.600 telephone calls complaining about mosquitoes were received last month by the Suffolk County Health Services Department.

description: The arts for Living Centerthe new building of the Henry Street Settlement on Grand Street on the lower East Sidesums up in its name everything that urban architecture should be. It is a building meant to serve and expand the life of a community, and no better definition of architecture exists than that.

description: BASEBALL

title: STAMPS
description: There has rarely if ever been such a display of castles and churches, stately edifices, ancient untouched villages and other architectural masterpieces on stamps as this year, when the nations of Europe observe European Architectural Heritage Year.

title: Design
description: It isn't only people who have identity crises. It's also corporations. A corporate Identity crisis is a serious and expensive illness; curing it requires a specialist and the bill can reach a cool $1million. The cure involves analysisboth of the company's image projection and problemsand prescriptiona costly dose of design. The result is a symbol that is meant to express the corporate personality and identify it for the world. It is the voodoo sign of the business world.

description: The doctorpatient relationship, once a private transaction about which little was known, has come under statistical examination in recent years. Studies are now available which present key facts about who goes to the doctor's office, how often and why.

Diplomats who were with him at Peking Airport yesterday to greet the visiting Burmese Foreign Minister, U Hla Hpone, said the 63yearold Mr. Chiao was in perfect health.

description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 9Ronee Blakley was a little worried. Should she have borrowed a riot helmet from her nineteensixties college days as her film Nashville opened here last night?

title: 9 Lawmen Killed in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported that nine law enforcement officers were killed in the line of duty last month, compared to 16 in July, 1974, and that the total of local, state and Federal officers killed during the, first seved months of this year was 72, compared to 77 for the same period of 1974.

title: Revenues and Rights
description: Since its inception three and a half years ago, the $30billion, 5year general revenue sharing program has developed a large and powerful claque of supporters: the local government officials responsible for running the units of government which receive the money.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS UNUSED TRACKAGI
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug 9Connecticut has acquired quietly, or is in the process of acquiring, more than 200 miles of disused railroad rightsofway in the state.

title: Where Dance Memories Leap To Life
description: Dance, the oldest and most universal of the arts, is by its very nature the most difficult to preserve. The strokes of Giotto's brush, the jabs of Beethoven's pen, the blows of Rodin's chisel, are tangible evidences of genius for future generations; but what of the flutter of Camargo's arms, the spin of Taglioni's body, the thrust of Nijinsky's legs? Those arcs in space, which for a second or two could ravish the hearts of thousands, dissolved even as they came into being, like ripples in water.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 9Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, called on the State Department of Social Services this week to consider statewide establishment of the county's system of providing public financial assistance payments through bank deposits.

title: BERNARD GREEN, COMPOSER, DEAD
description: Bernard Green, a composer, conductor and arranger, whose career of more than 40 years embraced radio, television and films, died Friday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 66 years old.

title: Scandinavia on Foot
description: THE question my son Sebastian and I were asked most often white walking in Scandinavia was Don't you have mountains in the United States? Scandinavians know we have mountains, of course. What they welt really asking was why anyone would spend a lot of money on air fare just to go walking.

description: Michael Spencer wants to get a master's degree in business administration. He's joined the Navy. Kevin Smith wants more responsibility than his job with Master Charge offered, so he's joined the Marines. Patti Willis is getting a master's in library science this summer. Then she's joining the Navy.

description: A year after taking office in unprecedented circumstances, President Gerald Ford presides over a nation that is beginning to be restored in spirit but still finds economic stability elusive and a sense of political direction lacking.

description: MONTREAL, Aug. 9For the lawyer who forgets to bill clients for time spent on the telephone, there is help in sight

title: Democratic Unit Rejects 3 DelegateSelection Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) A Democratic party commission has turned down plans for selecting convention delegates submitted by the parties in Hawaii, Idaho and Nebraska.

title: City Prison Reform Plan Called Failure
description: A controversial study has branded the city's multimilliondollar criminal rehabilitation and prison  alternative programs a failure and has warned that these efforts, instead of reducing crime, may be adding to the problem.

description: Proponents and opponents of the proposed amendment to the state constitution to guarantee equal rights to women are gearing for what promises to be the most hectic battle for votes in the Nov. 4 general election.

title: Racing Again at 49: It's What I Want
description: After six years on the sidelines, 49yearold Darel Dieringer is making a comeback in stock car racingbecause it's what I want to do. A lot of people have asked me why I'm trying it after being out so long and I answer them with a question: Are you doing what you want to? Maybe 10 per cent say they are, but the other 90 per cent say hell no. Racing has been my whole life and it's what I want to do.

title: Nice Guys Finished
description: It is a baseball clich that when teams lose, they don't fire the players, they fire the manager. In New York, as Yogi Berra and Bill Virdon found out, not losing is not enough. Berra, manager of the New York Mets, was fired last week and replaced by one of his coaches, Roy McMillan, after his team dropped a doubleheader. The Mets have been winning more than they have been losing, but they were in third place. New York Yankee manager Virdon was even more a victim of great expectations. Sportswriters considered the Yankees so powerful at season's beginning that it was suggested they simply adjourn to the World Series and wait for an opponent. But injuries left the Yankees a distant third, and Virdon has been replaced by Billy Martin, a former Yankee player with a reputation as a tough guy.

title: MAJOR HARRIS SINGS AT BARNEY GOOGLE'S
description: The discotheque sound and the disco itself are very much the vogue in popular music in New York. People flock to such places just to jump around, get down or boogie to recordings, and the art of putting on and pacing these records into a palatable package is in demand. It is a sophisticated business, and the mere singer in person at these places has to compete against the expensive practices of the recording business, with the dubbing, multitracking and endless patience needed to get the finished product just right.

title: U.S. GROUP VOICES HOPES TO PORTUGAL

description: When Congress threatened to eliminate the 49yearold oil depletion allowance (and did so in March), the cry went up that oil operators would as a result become too poor to search out the energy the nation needed.

description: CENTERPORT, L.I.A cat was thrown from a moving car a few weeks ago, and, severely injured, it was brought to a facility that is an animal shelter in everything but name.

description: ATLANTIC CITY  When the state referendum on casino gambling went down to a crushing defeat last November, fears that this summer's season would be disastrous took hold of business interests that depend almost solely on the tourist industry.

description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 9Charges of unauthorized exorcisms and spiritual coercion at a now defunct Roman Catholic Pentecostal community here have fueled the first major controversy to face the eightyearold Catholic Pentecostal movement.

description: CASTINE, Me., Aug. 9Town officials here have agreed to comply with a court order and pay Castine's state education tax under the controversial school funding law.

title: Bank Ranking
description: The buyers of bank certificates of deposit  receipts representing amounts of $100,000 and uphave gotten quite finicky in the past year or so about the institutions with whom they deal.

title: Picking Up the Pieces From Biggest Bank Failure
description: Last summer, conversations about the Franklin National Bank had the flavor of baseball announcers making sure listeners know that a nohit game is in progress but never actually mentioning the words.

title: Politicians Find Ford Stronger Than Year Ago but Are Unsure About Prospects in '76
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 President Ford ended his first year in office today in a stronger political position than he began it. On that muchbut on very little elsethere is agreement among professional politicians.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug 9 (AP) The Government has announced a $1.8million experiment designed to reduce the cost, but not the quality, of medical care in Texas hospitals over the next two years.

description: FAIR LAWNThe art gallery of the Fair Lawn Public Library reminds viewers of a marina nowadays. On display is Two To One, a large environmental sculpture in the form of three large, brilliantly colored red and blue triangles, sewn of nylon sailcloth.

title: Hey NonnyNonny Time Is Big Bash at Cloisters
description: The yellow pennants were limp in the afternoon as the knight in red came thundering downfield on his steed toward the knight in black. Lances clashed, horses snorted and 15 seconds later the red knight lay sprawled on the grass, to all intents and purposes, dead.

title: 151 Spout Wins Alabama at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 9Spout, a little filly with a liking for mud, proved to be less than a Ruffian today but she still managed to beat the best of the current crop of 3yearolds in romping off with the $81,953 Alabama Stakes.

title: Virginia C. Lepori Married in Suburb
description: Virginia Celeste Lepori of Evanston, Ill., daughter of Mayor Lester Lepori of Hillburn, N.Y., and the late Virginia Lepori, was married yesterday in Suffern, N.Y. to Lawrence Joseph Dolan of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dolan of Lynbrook, L.I. The Rev. Thomas Doyle, assisted by Msgr. Thomas Daly, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: Lisbon's Revolutionary Council Suspends Nine Dissident Officers
description: LISBON, Aug. 9Nine dissident officers were suspended today from the High Council of the Revolution in an effort by the country's military rulers to halt a split in the armed forces that was endangering and isolating the Government formed yesterday.

title: Suffolk Digging Into Montauk's Past
description: MONTAUKLess than an hour into the day's dig, Walter Osband, a young anthropology student from the State University at Stony Brook who is participating in the excavation of sites at Suffolk County's recentlyacquired part at Indian Field here, had uncovered a brass knob.

title: The deliberate lies down with the random
description: In the pages of an art journal some years ago, John Ashbery wrote: Most reckless things are beautiful in some way, and recklessness is what makes experimental art beautiful, just as religions are beautiful because of the strong possibility that they are founded on nothing. Ashbery's own kind of recklessness takes the form of an austere refusal to honor any of the claims of sentiment, beauty and good conscience that poetry is supposed to make. Worse than that, he has brought into American poetry the practice of randomnessa ?? of composition  by  chance familiar to readers of French poets (Mallarm, Valry, Michaux) in whose works the last vestiges of moral instruction and spiritual uplift are crowded out by uncertified sensations and unsanctioned feelings. The factor of chance has already modified certain conceptions in the realm of physics and, in music and painting, has achieved almost the status of a mode. Yet in poetry it is still suspect and open to charges of frivolity. The publication of this remarkable book should make one thing obvious: if chance is going to have a chance in the pious annals of American poetry, Ashbery is the man to provide it.

title: Who Can Afford a Home
description: EAST BRUNSWICK (UPI)A New Jersey family needs an average income of 324,000 to purchase a home in today's market, according to a survey by the National Association of Home Builders.

description: Michele Antonea Franklin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell James Franklin of Spring Lake, N. J., and Naples, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick Anderson Peasley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Anderson Peasley, of Stamford, Conn.

title: Stafford Says All 3 Astronauts Are at Fault in Apollo Gas Leak
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Vance D. Brand, the Apollo astronaut, took the blame, but Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford said that all three crewmen must share responsibility for the mishap that let poison gas fumes into their spaceship as they returned to earth July 24.

title: PLAN FOR ART TAX STIRS BRITISH ROW
description: LONDON, Aug. 9What is the link between ideology and art? How does a socialist government, seeking to equalize incomes and blur class differences, rationalize the substantial family art collections in private homes that serve as lifelong security? Should valuable works face a yearly tax?

title: Coping With Power Peaks
description: During the years when electric power was cheap and the power producers were prospering, utility executives pald little attention to the degree of use they were getting out of their plants. As long as the maximum demand for electricity at any given time was being met, most everyone concerned was happy. To meet future demand, the answer was simply to build more plants.

title: Pupils Score High In a Test of Skills
description: PATERSONMost pupils scored between 65 and 70 per cent in the Revised California Comprehensive Test of Basic Sidlis given to 13,778 children in grades one to seven of the schools in the Roman Catholic Paterson Diocese, according to the Rev. John J. Carroll, the diocesan superintendent of schools.

title: 9 HOUSE MEMBERS TO REJECT PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) At least nine House members are planning not to keep the pay raise Congress voted itself last month.

title: Kennedy Is Ahead of Ford in Poll Despite Disavowal of Candidacy
description: Despite Senator Edward M. Kennedy's repeated disavowals of his candidacy, the Massachusetts Democrat's popularity as a Presidential candidate has reached the point that now, in a trial heat, he leads President Ford, 50 per cent to 43 per cent, according to a Gallup poll.

title: ...Muddled Economics...
description: Almost immediately upon taking office, the Ford Administration was engulfed by economic storms. Inflation remained dangerously high, while a severe inventory recession intensified by the drain on consumer income of paying for more costly fuel and food brought the steepest economic decline since the Great Depression of forty years ago. Mr. Ford: and his economic advisers, having initially misdiagnosed the nature of the economy's problems, proved flexible in shifting from a proposal for a tax increase in October to a proposal for a tax reduction in January. Unfortunately, they never gave up their doctrine that inflation, not unemployment, was Public Enemy Number One.

title: Experts See Millions in Savings Here By a Modernization of justice System
description: Millions of dollars could be trimmed from the city's crim final justice budget if two basic structural changes were made and if some of the system's most glaring anachronisms were eliminated, according to a dozen judges, lawyers and law enforcement and fiscal experts.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Two highranking Israeli officials will fly to Washington in the next few days to begin drafting with American officials the terms of a new EgyptianIsrael agreement on Sinai. The officialsMordechai Gazit, directorgeneral of Premier Yitzhak Rabin's office, and Meir Rosenne, the Foreign Ministry's chief legal adviserhad a major part in drafting the texts of Israel's accords last year with Egypt and Syria, also reached through American mediation. The State Department said they would begin talks on Tuesday with Under Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco on certain points related to the interim agreement. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Fishermen See a Banner Season for Blues
description: BRIELLEThe annual run of bluefish off the Jersey coast started late in May, a week earlier than usual, and anglers are hoping that the season will be another banner one.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Morrison's Seafood Inc., 2d and Bayfront, Beach Haven, Long Beach Island. (609) 4925111.

title: Don King, MiniConglamorate
description: In the penthouse at 30 Rockefeller Plaza far above Manhattan and two floors above the Rainbow Room, Don King directs the promotion of the rubber match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier for the heavyweight championship of the world, the thrill in Manila and the saga of our lifetime. Behind his desk is LeRoy Neiman's portrait of Ali, 8 feet tall, gloved fists lifted in triumph. On the wall at his left, Socrates contemplates the bust of Homer.

title: Happy Hunting for Autograph Hounds
description: Over the centuries the ranks of those who have become addicted to collecting autographsusually letters and documents bearing signatures of the great, neargreat or those associated with great eventshave in eluded the Roman orator Cicero (the prize in his collection was a letter from Julius Caesar); Goethe (who believed that handwriting . . . is related . . . to thought and character); Queen Viotoria (one of whose grandson's turned the tables on her by selling a letter she wrote him refusing his request for funds); and an unknown man who bravely asked President. Hoover for three signatures please, two of them to be traded for one of Babe Ruth.

title: The Nation/Continued
description: A Civil Service Commission report has documented what the public has long believed, that political interests often influence Federal appointments in a style that approximates a patronage system?

title: A Bronze Hadrian, by M. Leventhal
description: Each summer thousands of archeologists, both professional and amateur, comb the Middle East countries for ancient artifacts. Major discoveries are rare, but Morton Leventhal, a New York stockbroker, amateur archeologist and frequent visitor to Israel, recently made a discovery both rare and major: He found a lifesize bronze statue of Emperor Hadrian, dating from the second century.

title: Its Strength Has Come From Circumstance, Not Statute
description: The New York State legislature has not been known to downplay its own selfimportance. Nevertheless, few debates seemed as portentous as the one that preceded the creation in Albany of the Municipal Assistance Corporation in the predawn hours of Tuesday, June 10. This was so because no one challenged the assumption that they were debating the future of the autonomy of the government of New York City.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, Aug. 10, 1975

title: Teachers Seek Signatures Here To Prevent Job Cuts in Schools
description: The Citywide Coordinating Committee to Save New York Schools, a group of teachers and paraprofessionals, yesterday collected signatures in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn for a petition urging the Mayor and the Board of Education to rescind proposed cuts in jobs and services.

title: LETTERS
description: Butz Rebutted

title: Christie Bader, Yale '74, Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Victor D. S. Troxell of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of Mrs. Troxell's daughter, Christie Pierpont Bader, to Second Lieut. Andrew Davidson Walker, U.S.M.C., son of Col. Anthony Walker, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Walker of Middletown. R.I.

title: Stokes Awards Go to Rudolph and Collins
description: Mendy Rudolph, the chief official of the National Basketball Association, and Doug Collins, the Philadelphia backcourt man, have been named recipients of the Maurice Stokes Memorial Award. They will be honored at the 17th annual Stokes game Tuesday night at Kutsher's Country Club, Monticello, N..Y.

title: Anne Milliken, W. A. Hoglund Have Nuptials
description: Anne Eaton Milliken and William Allen Hoglund, graduates of Duke University, were married last evening in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Grant A. Morrill performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: 4.2Million More Cars in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9, (Reuters)An additional 4.2 million motor vehicles were driven on United States roads last year, the Department of Transportation reported, bringing the total to 129,943,087, including 104.8 million carsan average of nearly one car for every two citizens.

title: THE HIGH COST OF
description: Until the Supreme Court abolished them this June, minimumfee scheduleswhich prohibited lawyers in an area from charging less than a specified feehad a long lineage. The bar of Sedgwick, Kan., adopted one in 1872: Wills brought $10; uncontested divorces, $25, and contested ones, $50. By 1971, 34 states and about 800 local bar associations utilized fee schedules, so that a client could not get an uncontested divorce for less than $600 in New Canaan or dissolve a corporation for less than $350 in Akron. The purpose seemed clear enough: In 1965 the executive director of the Wisconsin state bar reported that obviously and desirably a fee schedule will tend to increase the income of lawyers. A study by economist Richard Arnould confirmed that a lawyer in an area where some form of jurisdictional fee schedule exists makes, on the average, $3,500 more per year than a lawyer in an area where no schedule exists.

title: BachPacking, or Carrying Music to New Heights
description: MT. WASHINGTON, N. H. They walked through a white cloud, their instruments protected from the moisture by large garbage bags. In the wooden shelter ahead of them a crowd in attire ranging from J. C. Penney undershirts to Abercrombie windbreakers straddled benches and pressed for space around the potbelly stove to watch the six arrivals loosen their boots and tighten their bows. As the wideboard pine wails of the small commonroom began to resound to the first bars of Vivaldi's Concerto for Sopranina, Op. 44, No. 11, weary hikers emerging from timberline imagined they were hearing piccolo and strings on the slopes of 6,288foot Mt. Washington, tallest peak in the Northeast. They were.

title: Grain Loaders Return
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., Aug. 9 (UPI)  Longshoremen who staged a wildcat strike completed loading today of 24,000 tons of wheat aboard the Banija, a Yugoslavia freighter that sailed for the Soviet Union. The members of the International Longshoremen's Association walked away from the vessel and the Continental Grain Company elevator Thursday in protest against the Soviet transaction.

title: Ruth L. Pinches Is the Bride Of Stephen Baker Finch Jr.
description: Ruth Louise Pinches, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Pinches of Lewiston, N. Y., was married in Washington yesterday afternoon to Stephen Baker Finch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finch of Lawrence, L. I., and New York. The Rev. Dr. Andrew K. Meeder performed the ceremony in the Western Presbyterian Church.

title: Cockpit
description: Jerzy Kosinski's first novel, The Painted Bird (1965), was internationally admired and generally misread as a harrowing social document, so that when the vastly more difficult and abstract Steps appeared in 1968 reviewers, looking in the wrong direction, were hard pressed to make sense of it. If Steps was an enigma, Being There (1970) and The Devil Tree (1973), disguised variations on the same themes, must have added to the mystification. The fact is that all of Kosinski's novels are extremely similar in method and impulse and extend into one another as if they were one long, fantastic, autobiographical nightmare, manipulations in slightly varied forms of the same obsessive materials.

title: The wonderful world of weapons
description: Ever since President Eisenhower in his farewell address warned of the dangers of a militaryindustrial complex in our society, the notion has flourished that a venal conspiracy is being played by industry, the Pentagon and sometimes Congress to spend and to waste the billions of dollars in the defense budget on more expensive, frequently useless weapons. The truth of the relationship is not that simple or horrendous, as James W. Canan, a Washington reporter for McGrawHill who has covered the Pentagon, makes clear in this weaponsoriented survey of the defense establishment.

title: San Francisco Paper Names Atlanta Editor
description: John R. Murphy, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, has been named publisher and editor of The San Francisco Examiner, it was announced yesterday.

title: Engagements
description: JamiesonLevin

title: Dodgers Defeat Mets by 20 on 3Hitter; Lopes Sets Steal Mark With 32 in Row
description: Burt Hooton has only one pitching arm, and Dave Lopes has only two runnings legs, but against the Mets yesterday afternoon the appendages of the Los Angeles Dodgers seemed multiplied as if by kaleidoscope.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: Aug. 13Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey 45mile night minirally (third of series); start at Bowlero, junction of Routes 3 and 46, Clifton, N.J. Registration: 7 P.M., first car off 8:01. Information: Anna Andrews, phone (201)2564397

title: August
description: August is ripe chokecherries, and flutters of jays and robins at them, scolding, quarreling over seedy fruit too puckery for any human use except in jelly. It is elderberries so heavy with their dark fruit the bushes are bowed like hunched old women in coarse purple shawls. It is chicory in bloom, a weed in the field, an herb in the kitchen, sky blue on sunny days but sulking and refusing to reveal its face to the clouds.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Louis Dleyfus Corporation, the New York branch of the Parisbased commodities trading organization, which has recently made major wheat deals with the Soviet Union and China, is negotiating the purchase of an eightstory office building and a twostory laboratory building at 24 Richmond Hill Avenue in Stamford, Conn. The owner is Louis Bardinis.

title: Full Out Is Victor In Sapling
description: OCEANPORT, N. J.. Aug. 9Thomas Evans's colt, Full Out, lived up to the expectations of the fans who established hint, as the favorite in the Sapling Stakes today as he won the sixfurlong race for 2yearolds at Monmouth Park.

title: Andretti Fastest In MidOhio Trials
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 9 (UPI)Mario Andretti drove a Lola T332 at a track record 105.29 miles an hour today in qualifying first for the opening heat in tomorrow's Buckeye Cup Formula 5000 race at MidOhio.

title: SixGame Streak Has Hopes High
description: Although some players and fans would not be surprised if it happened, it is highly unlikely the New York Jets will go undefeated in the National football League this season.

title: Variety at Morris Museum
description: MORRISTOWNThe Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences is offering not one but three different exhibitions for townfolk and summer visitors to the area.

title: Musing, in a New Mexico War Cemetery, on Our Imperial Pretense
description: TESUQUE, N. M. HEY ARE watering the gravesites of the New Mexico National Guard every day this summer. Without constant care, the brilliant mountain sun would soon scorch the cemetery back into the desert it once was. The natural scrub and pifion would have its own beauty, of course, but green grass is our conventional idea for the resting of heroes. Ana many or the men who lie here are very much heroes by tradition. They are the veterans of Bataan, the fourmonth defense in 1942 of an obscure Philippine peninsula that has entered our pantheon of military sacrifice along with places like the Alamo and Bastogne.

title: The Long Arm of the Regulator
description: There may be some sentiments in Washington about curbing regulation of some industries, but not so in California. And the case in point is raising some eyebrows in the energy and investment communities.

title: Letters
description: Signs of The Times

title: Viking Aims for Mars Tomorrow
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 9Scientific vehicles are about to leave the earth for Mars to carry out the first search for life on the surface of another planet.

title: Marjorie Siegel Bride Of Richard A. Morgan
description: Marjorie Siegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Si:egel of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday aftergon, to Richard A. Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor H. Morgan of Huntington, W.Va. Rabbi Daniel A. Wolk performed the ceremony at Tarrytown (N.Y.) House.

title: Can You Identify These Wild Flowers?
PERMANENT SHIFT FOR INDIA IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9In fhe estimate of toplevel United States specialists, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's imposition of emergency measures has permanently shifted the Government of India in the direction of authoritarianism. At the same time, they note that she appears to have wide support.

title: Union County Democrats Act to Restore Ethics to Politics
description: ELIZABETHThe Union County Democratic organization has taken a new approach toward party politics, in an effort to restore public confidence in the political system.

title: 75 CAPTURED HORSES RELEASED IN NEVADA
description: TONOPAH, Nev., Aug. 9Seventyfive wild horses that had been rounded up here for distribution to riding enthusiasts throughout the country have been released by the Bureau of Land Management after efforts to settle a jurisdictional controversy between the Federal and State government over the protection, management and control of the horses had failed.

title: Chance Keeps Faith in His Controversial Hull Design
description: He had been hailed as a genius. But by this time last year Britton Chance Jr., and his 12meter Mariner were finished in the America's Cup trials. Chance never apologized for Mariner. In fact, he said nothing. The 34yearold naval architect watched as Mariner's monumental defeat eclipsed his earlier successes. He now will discuss Mariner without regrets for the controversial hull design. Chance is convinced there definitely was technical merit in the idea (the fastback, or inverted stepstern, to reduce wake turbulence) and there still is.

title: F.B.I. Studies Car Stains in Hoffa Case
description: DETROIT, Aug. 9Federal agents were reported today to be examining stains found on the seat of an automobile said to have been driven by James R. Hoffa's foster son on the afternoon Mr. Hoffa disappeared.

title: COURT RULES OUT RACIAL JOB QUOTA
description: A warning against reverse discrimination has been issued by a Federal appeals court here, in a decision expressing strong support for Civil Service laws.

title: The Region
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursing home entrepreneur who was able to win the influence of some of New York's leading Democrats and Republicans, has been Indicted by both Federal and state grand juries on a variety of criminal charges, including the alleged theft of $1.2 million in Medicaid funds. The prosecutors indicated that as their inquiries continue, political intervention on behalf of Mr. Bergman would be among the subjects covered.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 9 (UPI)I haven't felt like this since I quit baseball, said Jim Bouton as he launched his comeback last night by pitching the Class A Northwest League Portland Mavericks to a 53 victory over Walla Walla. Bouton, who once won 21 games for the New York Yankees and later wrote the controversial best seller, Ball Four, had taken time out from his job as a CBSTV broadcaster in New York to fly to Portland to try to launch his second baseball career. I have this crazy dream, the 36yearold Bouton said, that my knuckleball is going to come round and that I'll go back to the big leagues. I know it sounds nuts, but everyone has a crazy dream and that's mine. Last night he went nine innings, allowed six hits, walked two and struck out six. He plans to come back here next week after returning to his job in New York.

title: A Corporal Is Convicted In Brig Beating of Recruit
description: WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. 9 (UPI)  Marine Cpl. William T. Mason was found guilty of maltreatment today in a courtmartial stemming from the beating of an 18yearold Navy recruit, Steven Stawnychy, three weeks before the recruit killed himself.

title: Dome Caps Seattle Efforts to Show It's Bim League
description: SEATTLEA huge, donutshapped structure looms over Puget Sound these days, not far from the space needle, the symbol of an earlier bid by Seattle for bigleague civic status.

title: Business Index Rises
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 418.8 from 415.1 a week earlier. A year ago it was 428.6.

title: The World /Continued
description: Hope for a new agreement between Egypt and Israel has run hot and cold since Secretary of State Kissinger's stepbystep approached failed in March. Last week, the negotiations seemed to be warming up again.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects Brighter for Arnsparger
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 9The New York Giants will open a new football season here tomorrow night with an old question: Is there any hope for improvement after the club's two worst seasons in history?

title: Cold Shipping Evades the Slump
description: Dry cargo and tanker shipping were thrown for a business loop by the crisis last year, and are only now beginning to recover.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sad News About Fish, Ice Cream
description: Still more foods have come under attack from prosecutors and environmentalists as containing too much bacteria or toxic chemicals. The latest charges concern a brand of ice cream and two types of fish.

title: Augustus John
description: Why is it that the art of biography, which affords so many evident pleasures and contributes so much in the way of worldly knowledge, inspires so much hypocrisy and condescension among literary critics otherwise known for their sophistication and sagacity? The late W. H. Auden, for example, never tired of repeating that On principle, I object to biographies of artists.... As a rule, I am opposed to biographies of writers, and then went right on reading, reviewing and praising such books until the day he died. More recently, George Steiner made the publication or John Wain's biography of Samuel Johnson a book infinitely superior in wisdom and style to the common run of novels that Mr. Steiner and his critical brethren are invited to pronounce judgment uponthe occasion for a New Yorker sermon on the follies of the biographical enterprise. And so it goes. Among the critics whose works we still read with unfeigned interest, only Edmund Wilson openly acknowledged his appetite for this genre, which he occasionally practiced, albeit in miniature, so expertly himself. Since Wilson's death, no literary critic has come forward to champion biography as a literary accomplishment.

title: Arabs Big Spenders in Britain
description: LONDON, Aug. 9  The biggest foreign customers of a RollsRoyce dealer here used to be Americans. Arabs have displaced them, buying both $35,000 Silver Shadows and $55,000 Phantoms.

title: Notes: Bargains in U.S. For Foreign Tourists
description: THIS may well be the best time ever to save money on travel within the United Statesprovided you're not an American. Programs designed to attract foreign visitors to the Bicentennial are proliferating, and as a result of promotional fares, special hotel rates and automobile rental discounts the traveler from abroad enjoys transportation and accommodation bargains that are making Americans green with envy in these red, white and blue times.

title: Margaret E. Maniatty Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Connie S. Maniatty of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ellen Maniatty, to Brian Paul Fullington, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norbert L. Fullington of Auburndale, Mass.

title: World Golf Shrine Has Woman's Touch
description: Collecting old golf clubs and golf balls is not one of Norma Smith's hobbies, it's her job. As curator for the World Golf Hall of Fame in Pinehurst. N. C.. Miss Smith is responsible Women for collecting golf artifacts and in memorabilia to Sports display in the $2.5  million shrine. Her duties, however, do not end there.

title: The Ford Trip Risked Little And Accomplished Little
description: WASHINGTONSome scenes of recent weeks go right to one of the questions that is beginning to consume Presidential electionminded Washington: How much dtente is enough, or, put another way, how much dtente is good politics?

title: ARKANSAS COUPLE SCORED ON LOANS
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 9 A wave of criticism has broken out here over a legalaid lawyer and his wife who recently used the Federal bankruptcy law to avoid repayment of $18,382 in student loans.

title: Pnin does a Ninotchka
description: A setting as grim as Russia, the jacket note promises readers of Leslie Epstein's first novel, and a situation as solemn as dtente turn into high comedy and hilarious romance. Translating freely: a Russian scientist  like Nabokov's Pnin but even more muddled and less adept at concealing the muddlefinds himself drafted for cultural exchange and loses his heart to an American dancing girl who is managed by an improbable, mayhemloving C.I.A. operative called L. T. Kapp. Hilarity is always ready to score in this sometimes over blown book, and it often sounds forced. This defect may be a sign of Leslie Epstein's honesty: he cannot hide the essential grimness of this particular corner of history, ttnd he knows that pathos will be at war with buffoonery throughout his story. Unfortunately, the result leaves him with a narrative tone that is vague and inbetween and not really comprehending. Yet there is an ease and warmth in the telling, and a nice crowding of the plot with minor characters, which make one read on.

title: Carey Signs 10 Measures to Improve Child Welfare
description: ALBANY, Aug. 9 (AP)Governor Carey has signed into law 10 bills to improve childcare, including one that sets up a statewide adoption service offering a picturebook method of listing children, the Governor's office announced today.

title: Latest Violence By Terrorists
description: Once again the minuscule Japanese Red Army, an estimated 30 commandos operating outside of Japan, has succeeded in a major act of terrorism. Five members of the organization captured hostages at the United States Consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and in return for their release obtained the freedom of five terrorists imprisoned in Tokyo.

title: A Charge Reduced
description: The judge in the Joan Little trial in North Carolina has ruled that there was insufficient evidence in the case to support a charge of firstdegree murder. Thus Miss Little escapes the possibility of the death penalty, though she still faces charges of seconddegree murder and voluntary manslaughter. The charges stem from the slaying almost a year ago of Clarence T. Alligood, the night guard at a jail where Miss Little was a prisoner. Miss Little claims that Mr. Alligood sexually attacked her, and that she killed him in selfdefense.

title: Economic Indicators
description: Statistics for commercial agricultural loans, carloadings, steel'Oil, electric power and business failures are for the preceding week and latest available.

title: EMMA GILLIES CORSI
description: Emma Gillies Corsi, former director of La Guardia Memorial House, died Friday on vacation in Windsor, Nova Scotia. She was 65 years old and lived at 60 East 96th Street.

title: Miss Edens Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Luther Edens Jr. of Winnetka, Ill., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Talbert Edens, to Jay MacLean Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Page Wilson of Brooklandville. Md.

title: Tobacco Institute Comments
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 9 (UPI) A spokesman for the Tobacco Institute attacked the health group's recommendation, saying the program actually serves to reduce the amount of tobacco on the market because production is limited under it. If it were abolished, he said, more tobacco would be grown, prices would fall, cigarettes would become cheaper and more people would smoke.

title: Restoration Begun On Morris Canal
description: WEST PATERSON  As part of celebration of the nation's 200th birthday, the West Paterson Bicentennial Commission has embarked on an effort to restore the Morris Canal, an early 19th century waterway that played an important part in industrial development of Northern New Jersey.

title: Deborah Tanzi Wed To Gary L. Applegate
description: The First United Methodist Church in Westfield, N. J., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Deborah Dorothy Tanzi, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent R. Tanzi of Colonia, N. J. to Gary Lloyd Applegate, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Lloyd R. Applegate of Allentown, N. J.

title: Former Nixon Aides Sued
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (AP) Two former legal advisers to former President Richard M. Nixon have been named in a $5.7million suit filed in Superior Court here. The action was filed yesterday by Diversified Mortgage Investors, a Massachusetts concern, and among others named Herbert W. Kahnbach and Frank DeMarco Jr. The fraud suit stems from a complex business deal for southern California land.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: Child Released in France
description: ANNECY, France, Aug. 9 (AP)  Stphanie Grenot, 2yearold granddaughter of a wealthy industrialist, was kidnapped, held for two days and then released unharmed after payment of a $93,000 ransom, the police said today. The child, taken from her grandparents' home Wednesday, was found in front of a church in this resort city near the Swiss border.

title: What's Doing in EDINBURGH
description: FESTIVAL CITYScotland's capital was a haven for philosophers who hated religion; a happy hunting ground for Christians who loathed other Christians; a home for executioners, and the pioneers of antiseptic surgery. Political reformers flourished too. Long before the Free Speech Movement advanced up Telegraph Avenue in Berkeley, Edinburgh had established a students' representative council  in 1884. It is an old capital with wide streets cleaner than London's and a new town that's 200 years young. The city is also the home of the annual International Festival of Music and Drama, which this year takes place Aug. 24Sept. 13.

title: Law Students Will Aid Dillon
description: MINEOLAA clinical law assistant program designed to aid law students and the prosecutor's office has been established by the Nassau County District Attorney.

title: The Recession Stops by at Sotheby's, Too
description: How fared the volatile world art market in the dim days of recession?

title: ISRAELIS DUE IN U.S. TO BEGIN DRAFTING SINAI AGREEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Two highranking Israeli officials will come here in the next few days to begin drafting the possible language of a new Sinai agreement in advance of a probable trip to the Middle East later this month by Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Care Urged in Picking Kennel For the Dog at Vacation Time
description: A problem facing many owners is what to do with their dogs when leaving on a vacation. A fortunate few have relatives or friends with whom they can deposit the family pets. But the vast majority must find a kennel. Necessary minimum requirements, when choosing a kennel, said Dr. Wendell Morse, the executive director of the American Animal Hospital Association, are space, air and cleanliness. The kennel should be free from odor and be well maintained. The dogs should be clean and active, with fresh water near the animals. A slight check will reveal if there are sick animals present, if the dogs look well fed and if there's adequate ventilation.

title: M.I.T. Receives Sea Grant
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 9 The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced that it had received a Federal grant of $890,600 for its $1.4millionayear Sea Grant Program, established in 1968, for marinerelated research, education and advisory service projects.

title: $3,200 Ransom Asked for StainedGlass Windows Stolen From St. Louis Building
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9Fifteen large stainedglass windows, stolen from the famed Wainwright Building here, are being held for a $3.200 ransom.

title: In Memoriam
description: BUCHBINDERHarry August 8, 1974; In loving memory of a beautiful man.

title: Nero, 25, Takes Adios Pace
description: MEADOW LANDS, Pa., Aug. 9Nero, who had lost only one race this year, avenged that defeat today with a strong stretch burst that carried him to a 1length victory in the final of the $111,646 Adios Pace at The Meadows.

title: CHESS
description: The king is deadly in escorting a passed pawn to the queening square, as can be seen in the game between Lubomir Kavelek and Kenneth Rogoff in the 1975 United States championship. That single factor, the advance of the black king, decided the game by itself.

title: Follow Up on The News
description: A volcano that had been dormant for thousands of years rumbled to life unexpectedly on the island of Heimaey, off Iceland, on Jan. 23, 1973. In what was called the biggest mass transportation in Iceland's history, almost all of the 5,500 inhabitants were hastily ferried to Reykyavik as a fissure opened on Heimaey and hot ashes and lava menaced residential areas.

title: Water Mill Gets Its Namesake Rolling Again
description: WATER MILLAfter long months of hard work, the namesake of this village at the Old Water Mill Museum has been put into operating order through the installation of a water wheel by the combined efforts of carpenters, housewives, schoolchildren and the energetic museum director.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Prosecutor Joseph C. Woodcock Jr. of Bergen County said that Thomas Roberts, 5.5 years old, of Ridgewood, N. J., believed to have died in a car accident, had actually died of cyanide poisoning. The victim, an engineer for Engelhard Industries in Carteret, was pronounced dead at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, on July 2, several hours after being injured in a car crash in Elizabeth. It was not explained how the cyanide got into his system.

title: Investigation Asked on Reported Abuses in Prison Furloughs
description: TRENTON  Charges that the state prison workrelease and furlough programsonce hailed as major progressive steps in penal reform  are being abused by both inmates and prison staff members have raised fears among reformers that the programs will be canceled.

title: Criminals At Large
description: John Crosbythe John Crosby whose witty and pungent radio and television columns in The Herald Tribune so delighted millions of readershas delivered himself of an intrigue novel. Crosby, who has been living in Europe for many years, has taken the current ArabIsraeli tension as a point of departure and has come up with a book revolving around an Israeli agent (male) and his Arab counterpart (female). The result is readable, but AN AFFAIR OF STRANGERS (Stein and Day, $8.95) does not come off as well as it might have.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Atlantic Salmon Endangered Species
description: To love Salmo salar, the endangered Atlantic salmon, is a kind of exquisite torment, and to take one on a fly is one of angling's sweetest pleasures.

title: A Signal From 10 Million Light Years Away
description: As more sensitive astronomical instruments are developed, scientific exploration into the nature of the galaxies grows more profound; one of the recent advances is the first recording of radio signals emitted by molecular carbon monoxide clouds in galaxies outside the Milky Way.

title: Connors, Rosewall in Final
description: NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Aug. 9It was Rod Laver's 37th birthday today, but 22yearold Jimmy Connors used the occasion to remind Laver that in competitive tennis the keener eye and ready reflexes of youth can often prove much too formidable a combination.

title: A Commemorative Bargain
description: The public has expressed again its strong preference for a bargain. While only a few million of the proof (at $12) and the uncirculated (at $9) silver Bicentennial coin sets have been sold, close to 100 million of the copper  nickel Bicentennial half dollars have been snapped upat face valueby souvenirseeking people throughout the country.

title: FILM VIEW
description: There were times during these past hot weeks when it seemed that the main social usefulness of New York's movie theaters was to blow cool air out onto the sidewalks. If garbage is piling up on the streets, it's also piling up at the movies. The distributors must be cleaning out their basements.

title: Miss Pittman's Background
description: As a small boy I used to listen to the old people who came to my aunt's house on a Louisiana plantation tell each other stories. My aunt, who brought me up, was crippled and could not walk at all, and so the people would come there to visit and talk. In summer they would sit out on the porch, in winter they would sit inside by the fireplace, and I served them lemonade or coffee.

title: Endpaper
description: Modern science, it would appear, has been guilty of a grievous omission. Although this paper may be taken as an equally grievous commission, I offer it anyway. For, despite the immense accumulation of physiological, psychological and behavioral data in recent years, researchers seem to have overlooked one of the most common, yet puzzling, of all the sensory phenomena in human experience.

title: PreDivorce Assets
description: The women's movement has won a major battle in New York State. A bill designed to end the manipulation or concealment of assets by parties involved in a divorce action has been signed by Governor Carey.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Bengals Fall To Dolphins' Late Score
description: MIAMI, Aug. 9 (AM)Earl Morrall revived a sluggish Miami Dolphin offense tonight and threw a 10yard touchdown pass to Nat Moore for a 73 National Football League exhibition victory over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: To the Barricades
description: The maneuvering for ultimate control of the Portuguese revolution now involves not only the nation's civilian and military politicians but thousands of ordinary Portuguese who are engaging in mass rallies. Violence and death have already occurred, and though civil war is still believed unlikely, it is obviously one possible result of the current trend.

title: Center of Jawboning
description: WASHINGTONSince the early nineteensixties the United States Government has used, in various forms, the technique known as jawboning in an effort to hold down some prices and wages. Jawboning has had occasional success in eyecatching industries like steel, but it never had a major effect on the overall inflation rate. In the early part of this decade, jawboning was replaced by outandout wage and price controls, which seemed to work for a while but which were abandoned ultimately as a failure by both Congress and the Nixon Administration because some prices were uncontrollable.

title: Women Going To the Rescue
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIPWhen the firstaid siren sounded at the East Windsor Rescue Squad building, three mothers, children in tow, arrived to drive the ambulance, and two women came in to take care of the children.

title: Lawn Care Business Gets More Competitive
description: Lawn care companies have been springing up like weeds. As a result, the homeowner who needs help keeping his grass trim and healthy faces a bewildering array of choices.

title: Card of Thanks
description: KUTCHERJoseph L. The family of the late Joseph L. Kutcher deeply appreciates the kind expressions of sympathy extended to us by our many friends in our recant bereavement.

title: Tigers Lose, 10, to Twins And Streak Hits Record 14
description: DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP)Dave Goltz pitched a fivehitter today and Glenn Borgmann singled home the run for Minnesota that beat Detroit, 10. The Tigers' loss was the 14th in a row, a club record.

title: Nicklaus Leads By 4 on 67205
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 9 The duel for the lead in the Professional Golfers' Association championship took a swing of eight strokes today. Jack Nicklaus started the third round four shots behind Bruce Crampton and finished the day four shots ahead.

title: Smithsonian Site Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) President Ford signed a bill today reserving an additional site on the Mall for the future use of the Smithsonian Institution. Now under jurisdiction of the National Park Service the area is used for sports activities.

title: Nader Group Says Tobacco Price Supports Spur Cancer Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Health Research Group a Naderrelated organization, has accused the Federal Government of subsidizing cancer deaths by price supports for tobacco, and it has called for the end of such subsidies.

title: Fierce Bazooka Battle Erupts in Angola
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 9 (UPI)A fierce bazooka battle erupted in central Luanda today, and for the first time the fighting embroiled all three rival black independence movements.

title: Griffith Loses Decision
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 9 (AP)Elijah Makhatini scored a decision today over the former world welterweight and middleweight champion, Emile Griffith of New York, in a 10round bout. The fight was held in Orlando Stadium, in the sprawling black community on the outskirts of Johannesburg.

title: Ruler of 600 millionarid alone
description: The news, flashed from New Delhi last June 12, made stunning headlines around the globe. Indira Gandhi, Prime Minister of what was then the world's biggest democracy  India has nearly 600 million people, a seventh of the human race  had been found guilty of corrupt electoral practices by the High Court of Allahabad, and would have to step down.

title: ALLAN CHRISTELOW
description: Allan Christelow, a retired ail executive who served the British Government during and after World War I as financial counselor at its Embassy in Washington, died Friday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. Be was 64 years old.

title: ONE DEAR 40 HURT IN BELFAST RIOTING
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 9  Widespread rioting erupted in Belfast last night, leaving one person dead and 40 injured.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A universal groan of Here they come! emanated from the North Fork after the article The North Fork Coming on Strong appeared [July 27]. But the biggest bargain of all remains: the 18th and 19th century landmarks going begging throughout Riverhead township simply because people are not aware of their existence.

title: TURKISH TRANSFER BEGINS IN CYPRUS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 9 (Reuters)The mass transfer of Turkish Cypriotes living in the Greek area of Cyprus began today when United Nations croops escorted about 250 vil lagers to the Turkishoccupied northern part of the island.

title: The Bear in the China Shop
description: STOCKHOLMThe most significant commitment of the European summit participants  and the least noticedwas the pledge that all one another's frontiers shall be inviolable. This specifically includes the SovietChinese border and, since the United States signed, it cannot help but alter the diplomatic balance affecting the neighboring Communist behemoths.

title: Pete Reiser: Why He Ran Into Walls
description: Over the winter of 1947 I was invited to talkfor the fifth timeto the Missouri School for the Blind in St. Louis. I was beginning to wonder about it. Every year, they were getting me. So I said to the director:

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Catnip. Are you an aelurophile? (To save you a trip to your classical dictionary, that's a catlover.) If you are, have we got a book for you! It's a small, oblong paperback named, very succinctly, Cat ($2.95). In 152 line drawings B. Kliban, who's a Playboy cartoonist when he's not watching his pet, discloses the fantasy life not only of catlovers but of cats themselves. The sketches defy description, but the one reproduced above will give you an idea.

title: Dog Days in Vermont
description: POWNAL, Vt.The billboards start as far away as Saratoga Springs, N. Y., 42 miles to the northwest. They catch the eye in a pastoral setting dominated by grazing cows and fields of corn as high as the August prices in Saratoga. And the roadside message gets right to the point: Green Mountain's Going to the Dogs.

title: Lieutenant Weds Elizabeth Lough
description: In the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N. Y., yesterday morning Elizabeth Ann Lough was married to Second Lieut. Charles Carroll Thebaud Jr. The Rev. Robert T. Kennedy. professor of canon law at the Catholic University of America performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: I went to Saratoga the other day, not for the races but for New York City Ballet. As it turned out, I had a better time at the races. The company was giving the supposed world premiere of a duet by Balanchine, to Bizet music from the suite Jeux d'Enfants, which he has used twice before and was Inspired by the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale The Steadfast Tin Soldier, from which it took its title. By the end, I felt rather a steadfast tin soldier myself.

title: What to do when the doctor goofs
description: Newspapers in March reported the sad story of Gail Kalmowitz, a nearly blind college student, who had undertaken to sue for negligence two doctors and the hospital where she had been born prematurely. She asserted that the defendants' failure to provide her adequate care following her birth in 1953 had caused her loss of sight. While the jury in her case was deciding its verdict, she became anxious about the outcome and accepted a $165,000 settlement offered her by the defendants' insurance company. A few minutes later the jury returned and she learned that had she not settled she would have won $900,000. Was she a fool?

title: The Nation
description: The Ford Administration has reversed itself and told the House Select Committee on Intelligence the approximate size of the nation's intelligence budget without explanation.

title: SABURO OYAMA DIES; A MANUFACTURER, 60
description: Saburo Oyama, chairman and chief executive officer of NEC America, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Nippon Electric Company, Ltd., of Tokyo, one of the largest manufacturers of telecommunications systems and equipment in Japan, died in a Tokyo hospital on Thurs. day. He was 60 years old and lived at 3 Mitchell Place here and in Tokyo.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The United States and the world economy appear to have entered a transitional phase that will persist at least for the rest of this year. Transitional periods are seldom very satisfying and this is no exception. One era ends, people and policies change, foundations are laid, rebuilding begins, hopes are raised, patience is counseledand we grow tired waiting for the promsed results. Sometimes the transitional arrangements themselves become the new norm.

title: The Promise of the Revolution Has Soured
description: LISBONThe crunch has come in Portugal. The revolution that excited the world because it promised to bring democracy to a country mired in dictatorship for almost half a century is, 15 months later, threatening to turn it back to dictatorship. Fascism is at the point of being replaced by Communism, in the opinion of a wide range of Portuguese.

title: BIG DROP REPORTED IN SMALLPOX IN ASIA
description: GENEVA, Aug. 9An intensive search by Indian and international medical teams has failed to uncover a single case of smallpox in India in the last 12 weeks, the World Health Organization has reported.

title: Book Sales Dip in Portugal, but Best Sellers Are Still on Politics and Sex
description: LISBON, Aug. 8Books on politics and erotica are still the best sellers in revolutionary Portugal, but sales are down.

title: Rhode Island to Fix Statue
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 9 (AP)Independent Man, an 11foot statue weighing 500 pounds, was lowered from the top of the Rhode Island State House today by a team of five workmen and a 320foot crane and taken away for repairs. The statue will also be recoated as part of the state's Bicentennial activities.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Securities Act of 1933, set up a system of Federal regulation of securities sales that has lasted to this day. The passage of time, however, brings new needs, or at least on occasion enables one to identify old ones, and perhaps it is time to reconsider one of the basic elements of that act.

title: Talent Time Show To Aid Ailing Child
description: BLOOMFIELD  Talent Time has been putting on shows in Bloomfield for 25 years to raise money to help young people disabled by disease, illness or accident.

title: About the Mets . . .
description: Jon Matlack, who bruised his left elbow and both knees in an automobile accident Wednesday night, threw on the sidelines before yesterday's game and was named as the probable starting pitcher for Monday night against San Diego. . . . Dave Kingman is hobbled by a strained right big toe suffered running out a grounder Friday night. Dr. James C. Parkes, the Mets' physician, said Kingman's return to the lineup was a daytoday proposition. . . Rube Walker, the pitching coach, missed yesterday's game to attend the wedding of his daughter Debbie to Richard Grabisch in Cheverly, Md.... Jack Heidemann on his new parttime job as bullpen coach since Joe Pignatano has been filling in on the firstbase lines: Ain't much to it. I bring the balls down there before the game and when the phone rings I pick it up and say, Hello. Sometimes they'll ask me how this guy or that guy is throwing, and I'll tell them if he's hanging the old slider or throwing it down the old chute.

title: Moslems Riot in Hebron In Dispute Over Tomb
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 (AP) Hundreds of Moslem worshipers stormed out of the tomb of the Biblical patriarch Abraham in Hebron after Sabbath prayers yesterday demanding an end to an Israel Government move to divide the shrine between Moslems and Jews.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. To slip into the Master Paintings from The Hermitage and The State Russian Museum, Leningrad at the National Gallery in Washington, you have to be either a friend of the director or a dwarf on rollerskates.

title: Banks Sisters Married In a Double Ceremony
description: Georgia Winters Banks was married yesterday to Edward John Grejtak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Edward Grejtak, in a double ceremony at which her sister, Charlotte de Camp Banks, was married to James Burton May, son of William Stratford May and the late Mrs. May. Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Banks are the parents of the brides. The three families live in Scarsdale, N. Y., where the Rev. Robert J. Gill performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Pius X.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Tom Weiskopf, bitter at finishing third in the Westchester Classic after leading until the final round: I am one of the five best golfers in the world and I'm going to get the last laugh on all them before I quit.

title: Antony Alda,TV Actor, Marries Leslie Clark
description: Leslie Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Clark of Boston and Rome, was married here early last evening to Antony Alda of Jackson Heights, Queens, son of Robert Alda, the actor, and Mrs. Alda of Rome and Hollywood.

title: BROWN W. CANNON
description: DENVER, Aug. 9 (AP)Brown Woodburn Cannon, a Denver businessman and executive vice president of the Beatrice Foods Company of Chicago, died yesterday following a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions most of the Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of the letters published here pose questions similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not appear here, but who will, nevertheless, find their answers printed below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

title: 66 Accidents in 6 Months Listed for General Aviation
description: BURLINGTON, Mass., Aug. 9 (AP)General aviation aircraft were involved in 66 accidents in the first six months of this year, three below last year's figure. The number of dead, 14, was the same in both periods.

title: Marriage Planned By Eileen P. Feder
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Feder of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Phyllis Feder, to James Alterbaum, son of Mrs. David P. Alterbaum of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Alterbaum.

title: Indian Upper House Approves an Amendment to Constitution Prohibiting Lawsuits Against Prime Ministers
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 9The Indian Government today presented its third piece of legislation in the last week that was designed to protect Prime Minister Indira Gandhi from entanglement with the courts.

title: Sir Dalrae Wins, Ties Pace Mark
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 9Sir Dalrae, a winner once in I4 previous starts this year, came up with a powerful stretch drive tonight and won the second leg of the $50,000 United States pacing championship by five lengths at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: The World
description: The Indian Parliament, and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi who controls it, began last week to amend that country's constitution to increase Mrs. Gandhi's powers, already nearly absolute. It also passed legislation that cleared her pending court case by retroactively making the election law that she broke in 1971 inapplicable to her.

title: North Korea Said to Ask U.S., Through Miki, for Direct Talks
description: TOKYO, Aug. 9President Kim II Sung of North Korea has informed President Ford, through Premier Takeo Miki of Japan, that he wants to open negotiations with the United States to settle outstanding issues on the troubled Korean peninsula.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: TodaySand and Sea K.C. allbreed and obedience, Ocean County Park, Ocean Avenue, Route 88, Lakewood, N. J.; 1,717 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Steel Prices, And Therefore Others, Going Up
description: The steel industry is about to impose price increases that will inevitably be felt throughout the economy and that could undermine the Ford Administration's careful economic strategy, which has been to drive the inflation rate down and keep it there.

title: 3 Senior Citizens Flourishing Among Youth of N.F.L. Camps
description: Pro football is widely represented as a young man's profession, but there were three senior citizens in the news from the training camps last weekLen Dawson. George Blanda and Blanton Collier. Dawson, now 40 years old, continues as quarterback for the Kansas City Chiefs. However his new head coach, Paul Wiggin, who is just six months older, says, We don't now know if anyone is going to do it, but our hope is that someone will heat him out of the No. 1 job.

title: Mrs. Young Victor In European Golf
description: SUN. NINGDALE, England, Aug. 9 (AP)Donna Young holed out a 60year chip shot for an eagle at Sunningdale's 11th hole today and went on to win the European women's open golf tournament and the $11.000 first prize.

title: 500 SAID TO DROWN IN SOUTHERN CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 9As many as 500 persons are believed to have drowned when two Chinese river boats collided and sank during a heavy rain storm near Canton early this week, unofficial Chinese sources indicated today. More than a hundred residents of Hong Kong on holiday trips were thought to he among the dead.

title: Cable TV Outlet Weighed In Queens
description: Civic, business and religious leaders in eastern Queens are looking into the possibility of setting up cable television for the area to promote educational and cultural programs.

title: Berra as Manager: A CliffHanging Tal
description: A few facts about Yogi Berra's managing career should be on record.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Samurai
description: Anyone who has ever had a word in print is asked at least twice a week why he doesn't sit down and write himself a best seller. Something with a lot of sex and violence. And why not? Surely six months or so of banging away at some lurid fantasy or other is as likely a way to finance one's unprofitable passion for, say, poetry, as grading freshman themes, or, like George MacBeth herethe previously respected author of 20 books of poemsproducing literary programs for the B.B.C.

title: Screening For Cardiac Prevention To Draw 600
description: NEWARKScreening for what has been called the most ambitious program of heartattack prevention ever undertaken in New Jersey will be completed before the Sept. 30 deadline, with more than the minimum goal of 600 participants signed up.

title: GEOLOGISTS FIND NEW EARTH SHIFT
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., Aug. 9(APGeologists say satellite pictures indicate that India is pushing China intothePacific, and that this sideways shoving could account for China's unusual pattern of earthquakes.

title: Preseason Football
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: LoriAnn Rosa Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gil Rosa of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, LoriAnn Rosa, to Frank Jones of the Bronx. The future bride attended Notre Dame Academy and the Wood School, both in Manhattan. Her fianc attended Springfield College in Massachusetts and graduated from the John Jay College of Criminal Justice here. He is a member of the New York City Police Department and plans to attend the Fordham Law School in the fall.

title: Muche Desloovere, E. J. Stephens Married
description: Muriel (Muche) Desloovere and Edgar Judson Stephens of New York, photo editors for The Associated Press here, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Concord Academy in Concord, Mass., where the Rev. Nigel L. Andrews performed the Episcopal ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John E. Booty.

title: First for jobs. The New York Times carries more job advertising than any other New York newspaper.
description: First for jobs. The New York Times carries more job advertising than any other New York newspaper.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Picture Credits

title: CATTLE TESTS SHOW FURTHER USE OF DES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) Illegal residues of the growthstimulant hormone DES are continuing to show up in cattle livers, an Agriculture Department report shows.

title: Dry Spell Beaches U.S. Title Canoeing
description: OLD FORGE, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP)The sixth annual national open canoe championship is scheduled for Aug. 23 and 24 on the Moose River, have been canceled because of an extended dry spell that has lowered the level of the river.

title: Reappearance
description: Three years ago, Herbert Itkin, a New York lawyer who said he had contacts with the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and organized crime, disappeared after his testimony helped convict several New York political figures. Speculation that Federal officials had established a new identity for Mr. Itkin to protect him was confirmed last week. Mr. Itkin, who now calls himself Herbert Atkin, turned up in Los Angeles during a bitter fight between two computer companies involving charges of industrial espionage and arson. Largely on the basis an investigation conducted by Mr. ItkinAtkin (now a private detective), the Data General Corporation has filed suit against the Keronix Company, charging it sought to destroy its rival. A countersuit by Data. General questions Mr. Itkin's reliability, calling him an associate of known underworld figures.

title: Beame Buys August, Finds It Is Expensive
description: Mayor Beame continues to barter bits and pieces of political and fiscal independence in exchange for the Money to run New York City; so far all he has gotten in return is monthtomonth survival, and that may be all he can expect for a while.

title: Former Nixon Aides Sued
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (AP) Two former legal advisers to former President Richard M. Nixon have been named in a $5.7million suit filed in Superior Court here. The action was filed yesterday by Diversified Mortgage Investors, a Matsachusetts concern, and among others named Herbert W. Kalmbach and Frank DeMarco Jr. The fraud suit stems from a complex business deal for southern California land.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Construction of Homes in State Increases Third Month in a Row
description: After a dismal 1974 and even worse showings early this year, residential construction activity in New Jersey has registered a modest upswing for three straight months.

title: 1,000 Fighting Brush Fires In Arizona National Forest
description: More than 1,000 men battled yesterday to control a 13,000acre brush fire in Arizona's Tonto National Forest, The Associated Press reported.

title: Music: A Moving Missa
description: The surprise of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis when one comes to it after an absence is its intense drama. The surprise is not justified, of course, in the light of the composer's other music, which is constantly being energized by theatrical contrasts, sudden loud or hushed chords, the pitting of extreme ranges against each other, the pauses that crackle with tension, the quickening tempos. Yet these devices do startle In their application to a religious text, so much so at times that they create an ambivalent reaction.
