Sometimes they seem original, brilliant and inspired, sometimes they seem artificially theatrical. No matter. In the end the details blend into a total conception that is overwhelming.

title: A Biker's Sweet Dream of Vermont
description: THEY were good days for making hay. From Franklin and Lamoille Counties in the north to Windham County in the south, I watched farmers sitting pretty on their MasseyFergusons and Farmalls, mowing down swaths of thick alfalfa and timothy and June grass. Through the valleys of the Mad and White Rivers I saw them come with their rakes in tow and comb the cuttings into windrows that lined the fields like stripes on a flag. And I was there on the roads of Morrisville and Hancock and Townshend to see the balers roll, swallowing windrows and throwing out solid blocks of hay.

title: Used Books Recycled in a Project to Help Brandeis Libraries
description: EAST ORANGEIn a luxury highrise apartment building here, five or six matrons bustle about a room, dusting, sorting, evaluating and crating secondhand books.

title: Of Hiroshima and Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9It is thirty years since Americans dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and the moral anguish of those actions torments us still.

title: Lydia Beebe Stevens Is Bride Of Bernard Gustin, Sociologist
description: The Chapel of Branford College at Yale University was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lydia Beebe Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Cooke Stevens of Greenwich and Sachems Head, Conn., to Bernard Henry Gustin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gustin of Toronto.

title: ...Pursuing Dtente
description: Also, on the positive side, the President carried forward the themes of dtente with the Soviet Union and China, though not always with great understanding of the need for making that constructive policy a twoway street Moderating the strong proIsrael line he had championed while minority leader in the House, Mr. Ford has adopted a carefully balanced stance toward Israelis and Arabs in the past year in an effort to sustain Secretary of State Kissinger's peacemaking efforts. These remain the best hope for a negotiated accord.

title: A Beauty Spa Reopens on the Coast, This Time in Guise of Japanese Inn
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif.  Elizabeth Gordon Norcross sipped delicately at her Japanese seaweed  based soup, nibbled at her stuffed zucchini, gazed with satisfaction at the Japanese hangings, screens and antiques on the surrounding walls and the Japanese crockery on the tables and declared, Now we have beauty.

title: S. CECIL BERNSLEY
description: S. Cecil Bernsley, a retired advertising and marketing executive, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Dallas Suburb Yields on Busing While a Fight Looms in the City
description: RICHARDSON, Tex., Aug. 9While parents of Dallas school children agonize over courtordered desegregation, parents in this suburb north of Dallas have voluntarily agreed to send 300 of their children to a previously allblack elementary school in order to achieve integration.

title: Hey Rube Is Victor As Bushongo Fouls
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Aug. 9 (AP)Dan Lasater's Hey Rube won the seventh running of the $33,550 Gettysburg Handicap at Keystone today when Montpelier's Bushongo, the first horse to finish, was disqualified. Hey Rube paid $4.40.

title: Ashland Oil Gives Up List Of $1.2Million Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Faced with the prospect of being taken to court by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ashland Oil, Inc., disclosed today the names of the recipients of its foreign payments and illegal domestic political contributions totaling $1.2million.

title: Capitalist Bays Rights To the Socialist Anthem
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 9 (Reuters) Every time the Internationale is sung or played in East Germany in the future, a capitalist publisher will reap the royalties.

title: 2 Mycenean Temples Unearthed in Cyprus
description: ATHENS, Aug. 9 (UPI)Greek Cypriote archeologists excavating a Bronze Age metalworking town in southern Cyprus have uncovered twp 3,200yearold Mycenean temples, an archeologist said.

title: City Reports 10 Projects In Housing Pipeline
description: Two years after the demise of the Federal mortgageinterest subsidy program, the city still has 10 housing developments in the pipeline that will utilize these funds.

title: HOUSE DELEGATION SEES SOVIET JEWS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10A group from the American House of Representatives, on an official visit to the Soviet Union, met today with a group of Soviet Jews seeking to emigrate and some said they had been emotionally moved by the encounter.

title: Angels Defeat Yanks, 10
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 10  A scoring drought that seized them after the first inning of last night's 81 loss to the Angels continued through today for the New York Yankees as they lost again to California, 10, on a ninthinning run knocked in by Lee Stanton's double.

title: Waterloo Village Reflects Past
description: WATERLOO VILLAGE, Aug. 10This living museum of 200 years of New Jersey history is getting more attention these days because of the Bicentennial, but those who work here say it is just a case of the rest of the country catching up.

title: David Frost Signs To Interview Nixon; Sum Is Undisclosed
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 10David Frost, the television personality, announced today that he had bought the exclusive rights to the television memoirs of Richard M. Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Starvation Is New Threat in Besieged Luanda
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 10 (Reuters)An official of this Portuguese colonial capital, which is occupied by one nationalist faction and besieged by another, said today that international help might be needed to stave off starvation in the city.

title: Hopes of Nicaraguan Opposition Rise With Shift of the U.S. Envoy
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua The imminent replacement of the controversial United States Ambassador to Managua, who over five years has become a friend and adviser of the longtime dictator, Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, is both raising hopes and causing concern here.

title: Princess From Uganda Takes Refuge in Britain
description: LONDON, Aug. 10 (UPI)Princess Elizabeth Bagaaya, the onetime fashion model who was Uganda's Foreign Minister until dismissed by President Idi Amin for alleged misconduct and forced to flee to Kenya six months ago, has arrived in Britain, the Home Office disclosed today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An offduty Port Authority policeman who got out of his car to chase a taxi driver's assailant on the Major Deegan Expressway around 3:30 A.M., returned to find his own car had been struck and demolished by another taxicab. The holdup victim, Jack Giardino of Richmond Hill, Oneens, and the second taxi driver, Malcolm Hurwitz of White Plains, suffered minor injuries. The policeman, William Murphy, was not harmed. The robber escaped emptyhanded.

title: Portable Heart Unit Is Developed
description: Doctors in Northern Ireland have developed a lightweight portable defibrillator that cardiologists believe may provide a major new tool in delivering emergency care to more persons who suffer heart attacks at home or at work.

title: Asbury Park Still Rundown 5 Years After Major Rioting
description: ASBURY PARKOn the official maps the name of Springwood Avenue, scene of the riots that injured more than 170 people and wiped out halfmilelong stretch of mainly black shopping district here five years ago, has been changed to Lake Avenue.

title: A Riddle in Music
description: Dmitri Shostakovich's music will pose a riddle: What would it have been like if the composer had lived in a free society rather than in the Soviet Union, where he was subjected to the whims of the heads of state and to the vacillations of the official musical. ideology From the premiere of his brilliant First Symphony, written when he was only 19, until his death, Shostakovich turned out large quantities of music. He composed in all forms, from musical comedy, films and ballet to symphonies, chamber music and oratorios. Much of it is meretricious; some of it is meritorious and looks durable for future decades.

title: Statewide Drive Is Started For More U.S. Welfare Aid
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 10 Orange County legislators, who last Friday refused to appropriate additional funds for welfare services, are beginning a statewide campaign to gain the support of other counties in pressuring the Federal Government into assuming a greater share of the welfare burden.

title: Precarious Unity Underlies City Charter Commission's Proposals
description: The hassling that frequently marked the deliberations of the 12 widely disparate members of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City was smoothed over last week as the commission resolved its differences by unanimously agreeing on six Charter revision proposals and then agreeing to disagree on, but still submit to the voters this November, three of the most farreaching Charter amendments.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Disquiet, Please
description: WASHINGTON  To promote a 'national dialogue about issues and values in our Bicentennial Year, Walter Cronkite came up with a suggestion for a nationwide American Issues Forum. That was a good idea.

title: West German Loyalty Checks Assailed
description: BONN, Aug. 10Hundreds of thousands of West German applicants for civilservice jobs are being subjected to loyalty checks, lawyers for enemies of the state are being jailed and other lawyers have been excluded from courtrooms where their clients are on trial.

title: Alana Northrop Bride of Victor Marmon
description: Alana Northrop, daughter of Lee Northrop of Simsbury, Conn., and the late Willard H. Northrop, was married in Simsbury yesterday to Victor Ira Marmon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Marmon of Culver City, Calif. Rabbi Charles P. Sherman performed the ceremony in the Farmington Valley Jewish Congregation.

title: Tomahawks Score, 1411
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 10The Long Island Tomahawks beat the Montreal Quebecois, 1411, in a National Lacrosse League game tonight and increased their firstplace advantage to 6 points.

title: NO NEW KOREAN WAR IS FORESEEN BY MIKI
description: Premier Takeo Mild of Japan said yesterday he saw only a limited, if any, chance of major hostilities recurring in Korea.

title: Statewide Drive Is Started For More U.S. Welfare Aid
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 10 Orange County legislators, who last Friday refused to appropriate additional funds for welfare services, are beginning a statewide campaign to gain the support of other counties in pressuring the Federal Government into assuming a greater share of the welfare burden.

title: Sylphide Is Danced 3 Times in One Day
description: Who could ever have expected August Bournonville's 1836 classic La Sylphide to have been given three times in one day by two different companies at Lincoln Center? This old but lovely Danish classic has never had such exposure. And, interestingly, both of these productions, one by American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater and the other by the National Ballet of Canada at the Metropolitan Opera House, were by Denmark's leading export (apart from Carlsberg beer). Erik Bruhn.

title: Volkswagen Plant Denies Dumping in U.S. Market
description: BONN, Aug. 10 (AP)The people who make the Volkswagen insist that their cars are not being dumped in the United States market. This denial is in response to Friday's announcement in Washington by the Treasury Department of an investigation into whether foreign cars are being sold in America at a lower price than lin their home markets.

title: West German Loyalty Checks Assailed
description: BONN, Aug. 10Hundreds of thousands of West German applicants for civilservice jobs are being subjected to loyalty checks, lawyers for enemies of the state are being jailed and other lawyers have been excluded from courtrooms where their clients are on trial.

title: Pirates Bow, 53; 5th Straight Loss
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates may be feeling a trifle claustrophobic these days as the Philadelphia Phillies and the St. Louis Cardinals inch closer to the National League Eastern Division leaders.

title: Advertising
description: Young & Rubicam International, which has more United States billings than any other advertising agency, has been adding to its strength in recent years by establishing affiliate agencies to specialize in particular industries or service categories.

title: Portable Heart Unit Is Developed
description: Doctors in Northern Ireland have developed a lightweight portable defibrillator that cardiologists believe may provide major new tool in delivering emergency care to more persons who suffer heart attacks at home or at work.

title: Good Try on Aid
description: The international development bill voted out of the House International Relations Committee last week constitutes a major step toward improving the nation's battered foreign aid program. It is also the beginning of a goodfaith effort to fulfill the United States commitment to the fight against world hunger.

title: VIKING HELD READY FOR TRIP TO MARS
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 10The first of two Viking spacecraft designed to land on Mars was declared today to be ready to take off tomorrow.

title: Denmark Heat Sets Record
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 10 (AP)  Denmark suffered today under the worst heat ever recorded in the country. A temperature of 98 degrees was recorded at Holstebro in Jutland, breaking the record of 96 degrees set in 1911 at Antvorskov, southwest of Copenhagen.

title: FURTHER PRESSING FOR FEDERAL HELP BY M.A.C. IS LIKELY
description: A board member of the Municipal Assistance Corporation said yesterday that the corporation was likely to press again for Federal helpdespite a rebuff in Washington last weekin an effort to sell $1billion in bonds next month.

title: About New York
description: Clubs do not exist so much to kill time as to abolish It. We climb the steps, we push on the great bronze door, the head porter greets us by name and we are off and away in a world where servants come running at the touch of a bell, where the pictures and the silver are finer than we can hope to have at home, where in principle we need see only the people we like most and where we shall never lack for a new book, another log put on the fire, a clean towel in the bathroom and a hot meal when we get round to thing of it.

title: Raiders Show Strength in Reserve
description: The Oakland Raiders appeared to have found a backup quarterback for Ken Stabler yesterday in their opening, preseason game.

title: Thought for Commuters
description: We're all in the same boat. There's no such thing as having headquarters in the city and living in Purchase or Chappaqua and paying no attention to the city after dark.Eli Ginzberg, professor of economics at Columbia University and author of New York Is Very Much Alive.

title: From Paris: Rembrandt on the Riviera
description: PARIS, Aug. 3Next to the advent of streaking in Moscow or the screening of pornographic movies in Peking, the most unthinkable event is probably a Rembrant exhibition in Nice. Well, it has happened. The Marc Chagall Museum is presenting works by the Dutch master on the theme of the Bible. There are several canvases, a hundred etchings and, least familiar and most remarkable of all, 27 drawings, a dozen of which come from the seldom available graphic collections of Dresden, Germany. Stunning as these sheets are, with their lightning conversions from light to shadow, image to sign and natural to supernatural, they do not alter our vision of Rembrandt, but they do drastically change our idea of the Riviera: Sunning, henceforth, must come second.

title: Music: For Shostakovich
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10Tanglewood, normally the least lugubrious of scenes on a Sunday afternoon, took on a solemn air today when Mstislay Rostropovich, the migr Soviet cellist, played Dmitri Shostakovich's strangely pained and dour Cello Concerto No. 2 in memory of the composer, who died yesterday at the age of 68. It was, by coincidence, a weekend of Shostakovich memorials, Mr. Rostropovich having conducted the Boston Symphony last night in the Symphony No. 5, one of the works that has been able to edge itself into the standard symphonic repertory in recent decades (it was composed in 1937).

title: South African Bank Rate Is Raised to 8 From 8%
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Monday, Aug. 11 (Reuters) South Africa has raised its bank rate a half percentage point to 8 per cent effective immediately, Reserve Bank Governor Theunis de Jongh announced today. The purpose is to reduce excess liquidity.

title: Nostalgia Is a Staple at Sagaponack General Store
description: SAGAPONACK, L.I.Some customers arrive on horseback. Some customers arrive in sports cars. But once they enter the Sagaponack General Store, they are all transported into another era.

title: 7 Gold Medals Captured By Greenwood in Track
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10Jack Greenwood, a star hurdler for Kansas University in the early nineteenfifties, increased his collection of gold medals to seven today as the threeday Amateur Athletic Union Masters national track and field championships concluded its stand at Glenn Loucks Memorial Field.

title: J. GEORGE GREENBERG
description: J. George Greenberg, who retired in 1971 as executive manager of the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., here, died Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Lauderhill, Fla., and formerly in Brooklyn and Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Texaco Raises Prices Of 3 Fuels by One Cent
JACOB I. GOTTLIEB
description: Jacob T. Gottlieb, a vice president of Food Fair Stores, Inc., and president of its J. M. Fields Discount Department Store division, died Saturday of a heart attack suffered while sailing near Loveladies, N.J. He was 57 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr. Pa.

title: Elton John and Dylan Get Rock Prizes
description: Elton John, Bob Dylan, Linda Ronstadt, Stevie Wonder and Joni Mitchell emerged as the top winners of the first Rock Music Awards, televised live Saturday night on the CBS network from the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium in California.

title: Briton Wins Title
description: SILVERSTONE, England, Aug. 10 (AP)Barry Sheene of Britain won the British Grand Prix motorcycle race today and earned enough points to clinch the International Motorcycle Federation's 750cc world championship.

title: Just Maybe the Red Sox Are Real
description: It is foolhardy to suggest it this early, but maybejust maybethose unlikely leaders of the American League East, the Boston Red Sox, are real. Quitting the snug safety of Fenway Park last Tuesday night, they set out through the Wild West filled with nameless, shapeless fears. Ahead lay many perils, but what they dreaded most was the specter of history repeating itself like a lush with a talking jag. Except for Denny Doyle, Fred Lynn and Jim Rice, this is the same team that led Baltimore by eight games last Aug. 29 and then proceeded with stately decorum back to Third place, seven games behind the Orioles. They could remind themselves that this was a different year and the addition of Doyle, Lynn and Rice had made the Sox a different baseball team, but in spite of these reassurances they remembered what did happen and knew it could happen again.

title: Sidney Friedman Marries Vivian Rivkin
description: Vivian Beatrice Rivkin of New York, daughter of Mrs. Eli Ickowicz of North Miami Beach, Fla., and New Haven, was married yesterday to Sidney Joseph Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Friedman of Columbia, S.C. Rabbi Leon B. Fink performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Lichtenstein of Merrick, L.I., brotherinlaw and sister of the bride.

title: DE ROULET DEAD; FORMER ENVOY, 49
description: Vincent de Roulet, former United States Ambassador to Jamaica, died Saturday of heart attack while vacationing in Falmouth Foreside, Me. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhasset. L.I.

title: A Coup in Portuguese Timor Is Reported With Few Details
description: DARWIN, Australia, Monday, Aug. 11 (Reuters)A coup has been staged in Portuguese Timor, according to a radio message received here today from the airport control tower in the Portuguese island territory.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 10 (AP)Bruce Jenner, scoring personal best marks in the 100 meters, shotput and discus, broke the world decathlon record today, piling up 8,524 points in the United StatesSoviet UnionPoland team decathlon meet at Hayward Field.

title: DISCLOSURE BILL SIGNED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, Aug. 10Public authorities and other agencies that control highways, bridges and tunnels will be required to make financial disclosures and hold public hearings before raising tolls or fees under a bill signed today by Governor Carey.

title: Hanoi Offers to Return Bodies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10A State Department spokesman said today that the United States had received a message from Hanoi declaring that North Vietnam was ready to return the bodies of three American pilots killed during the Vietnam war.

title: Terrier Is Best In Jersey
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J. Aug. 10  For 35 years Wilbert Etter of Quakertown, Pa., has been breeding Welsh terriers. A year ago, he won his first bestinshow award with Ch. Licken Run's Two Pence Sam at Perkiomen.

title: U.S. Reassures Nicaragua
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 State Department officials said the Ford Administration had recently assured Nicaragua that the replacement of Ambassador Shelton was not to be taken as representing any change in United States policy toward that country.

title: Food Stamp Reform
description: Concern about food stamps has increased sharply in the wake of large program increases caused by the recession. From a level of 15 million participants at an annual cost of $2.9 billion in the 1974 fiscal year, the program grew in recent months to 19 million participants at an annual cost of roughly $6 billion.

title: Stiff Tests Keep the Guv'nuhs in Britain Alert
description: LONDON, Aug. 7Arnold Sandler leaned across his desk. His eyes glistened.

title: Kheel Calls 50c Fare A Calamitous Mistake'
description: Theodore W. Kheel said yesterday that the 15cent increase in the city's bus and subway fare would be a major calamitous mistake if it went into effect Sept. 1, raising the fare to 50 cents.

title: Bacon's High Price Today Reflects 1974 Corn Supply
description: Bringing home the bacon is getting more expensive.

title: Giants Take Opener, 2814; Jets Revel in 2015 Victory
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 10 Trying to quickly blot out the bitter memories of last year, the New York Giants scored three secondhalf touchdowns and opened their exhibition season with a convincing 2814 victory over the New England Patriots tonight before a crowd of 40,726 at Schaefer Stadium.

title: APPAREL PRICES HOLDING STEADY
description: Seventh Avenue apparel manufacturers are in peak production for the backtoschool and fall season. By the end of this month, makers of coats, suits and sportswear for women and children will have shipped the bulk of merchandise that retailers have ordered for fall. Most of the producers report that their shipments this year are well ahead of those of a year ago.

title: MindDrug Tests a Federal Project for Almost 25 Years
description: American military and intelligence officials watched men with glazed eyes pouring out rambling confessions at the Communist purge trials in Eastern Europe after World War II, and for the first time they began to worry about the threat of mindbending drugs as weapons.

title: Eliminating Science's Evils
description: CARPINTERIA, Calif.  The exponential growth rate science has experienced since the 17th century is leveling off. This affects the technologicalfix doctrine that the cure for the evils of technology is more technology. New technologies depend on new science; if science is in trouble, so is technology, economy, growthmanship.

title: Kingsmen Start Practice
description: Brooklyn College's varsity football team begins practice tonight at the Kingsmen's new milliondollar AstroTurf field. Head Coach Vince Gargano expects 100 candidates.

title: Dmitri Shostakovich Dead at 68 After Hospitalization in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10Dmitri Shostakovich, the Soviet Union's most celebrated composer, died yesterday evening following hospitalization for a heart ailment at the beginning of this month. He was 68 years old.

title: A Cool Reception for Those Convenient Frozen Dinners
description: Livin' is pretty easy if you eat main course frozen foods. It's also, for the most part, pretty awful.

title: Editor Says Hoffa Told of Putting Money in Anthracite Venture
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP)A mystery subplot about the missing James R. Hoffa is arising here in Pennsylvania coal country.

title: Nicklaus 2Shot Victor in P.G.A. With 276
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 10Jack Nicklaus won the Professional Golfers' Association Championship today for the fourth time, but it wasn't as hohum as all that. It was not until the closing holes that the issue was settled, with Bruce Crampton trying gallantly to catch up, only to be thwarted by putts that lipped out or missed by inches.

title: Measure to Clear Mrs. Gandhi Signed By Indian President
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 10 (AP)  President Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed gave his assent today to a constitutional amendment designed to free Prime Minister Indira Gandhi from her conviction for corrupt electoral practices.

title: COMMUNISTS FIRE ON HOSTILE CROWD IN NORTH PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, Aug. 10  Communists opened fire on a crowd of hostile Roman Catholics in the northern town of Braga today, wounding 20 persons. three of them seriously.

title: Poorly Informed Drivers Are a Problem Here
description: Manya Starr, a film writer, recently hailed a cab near her apartment on East 82d Street and told the driver to take her to CBS on West 52d Street.

title: THE ARGENTINE PESO IS DEVALUED AGAIN
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10 (UP)  The Economy Ministry announced last night the fourth devaluation of the peso in five months and said it would take effect tomorrow.

title: Miss Hertz, Student Wed
description: Christine Anne Hertz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph E. L. Hertz of Pelham, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., was married in Pelham Manor, N.Y., yesterday afternoon to Douglas Charles Wolf, son of Mrs. Charles D. Coram of Huntington, W. Va., and the late Arien S. Wolf. The Rev. John Leonard and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 11, 1975

title: Thousands Flee Tension in Surinam
description: KLUNDERT, the NetherlandsThe Woodhouse Motel in this small farm town 30 miles south of Rotterdam is full this season as usual, but the guests aren't on vacation.

title: FURTHER PRESSING FOR FEDERAL HELP BY M.A.C. IS LIKELY
description: A board member of the Municipal Assistance Corporation said yesterday that the corporation was likely to press again for Federal helpdespite, a rebuff in Washington last weekin an effort to sell $1billion in bonds next month.

title: Anxiety Grips Australia Despite Good Life
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 10  Australians traditionally think of their land as a cornucopia, bountiful in beef and sheep, blessed with vast grazing areas and with huge mineral resources. Australia, as many put it, is the lucky country.

title: S.E.C. May Sue if Cities Fail to Reveal Bond Risks
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 10As a result of the New York City fiscal crisis, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today, the commission will consider bringsuit against municipalities that fail to disclose unfortunate circumstances that afflict them when they are selling bonds.

title: TAIWAN RESUMES FLIGHTS TO JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Aug. 10A China Air Lines jet bearing the flag of the Nationalist Government on Taiwan landed here today to mark the resumption of air traffic between Taipei and Tokyo by airlines of the two countries after a lapse of 16 months.

title: A Sampling From the City's Cabby Test
description: To become a tax driver, an applicant must pass a written, 20minute test on the locations of key city attractions and landmarks and routes to get there. To pass, the applicant must give correctly 14 of the 15 locations and 9 of the 10 routes asked. Following are some sample questions [answers are on Page 40.]:

title: 30 Injured in Israeli Crash
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Thirty people were injured, four of them seriously, when a ?? on its way from Tel Aviv to Eilat in the south overturned while negotiating a hairpin turn near Sodom

title: Albany's Deficit Budget
description: Governor Carey has cut back airconditioning in state office buildings, eliminated 338 more state jobs and imposed other economies in the third wave of a program to sweat excess fat from the $10.7billion state budget. In addition, Mr. Carey has served notice on his department chiefs that their budgets for next year must be frozen at this year's levels except for increases attributable to inflation or the completion of new facilities.

title: U.S. FastFood Chains Thrive in Tough Aussie Market
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaTough competition has closed out one of the American entrants in Australia's fastgrowing fastfood business. But the three surviving chains are continuing their expansion plans.

title: Poorly Informed Drivers Are a Problem Here
description: Manya Starr, a film writer, recently hailed a cab near her apartment on East 82d Street and told the driver to take her to CBS on West 52d Street.

title: Piragueros Refresh PassersBy and Keep the Wolf From the Door
description: Ramn Martinez is a 50yearold unemployed dishwasher with a wife and two children to support and $100amonth apartment on 108th Street in East Harlem. Despite visits to the unemployment office every two weeks, he has been out of work since last November.

title: U.S. Navy Study Finds Soviet Warship Design Emphasizes FirstStrike Role
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10A Navy study has concluded that superiority of Soviet warships in firepower has been achieved by sacrificing the endurance, electronic sophistication and crew comforts emphasized in American ships.

title: Time Reports Rumanians Ask to Buy U.S. Weapons
description: Rumania wants to buy F5 jet fighters and other modern weaponry from the United States, Time magazine said today in its latest Issue.

title: S.E.C. May Sue if Cities Fail to Reveal Bond Risks
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 10As a result of the New York City fiscal crisis, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today, the commission will consider bringing suit against municipalities that fail to disclose unfortunate circumstances that afflict them when they are selling bonds.

title: Cherry Hill Makes Bid As a Convention Center
description: CHERRY HILLThree mod Tern hotels have opened here and in adjacent Mount Laurel Township in recent weeks in a bid to make this metropolitan Philadelphia area New Jersey's leading convention center.

title: COMMUNISTS FIRE ON HOSTILE CROW IN NORTH PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, Aug. 10  Communists opened fire on a crowd of hostile Roman Catholics in the northern town of Braga today, wounding 20 persons, three of them seriously.

title: Arkansas City Is Uplifted By News Fit to Smile At
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Aug. 10Bad news has taken back seat in this industrial town of 65,393 persons, the site of a visit from President Ford today.

title: U.S. Interest in Southern Africa
description: NASHVILLEAmericans cannot regard with unconcern the worsening situation in subSahara Africa. The United States has a vital stake in maintaining access to the vast mineral wealth of southern Africa and in the security of the Cape sea route around Africa. Around the Cape of Good Hope move the tankers that carry oil to fuel industries and homes in Europe and America.

title: ExPress Aide Says Nixon Obstructed Justice on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Gerald L. Warren, deputy press secretary to President Nixon, said today that he believed that Mr. Nixon was guilty of obstruction of justice. Asked if he thought Mr. Nixon had committed any crime in connection with Watergate, he responded, Yes I do, I do indeed.

title: U.S Still Planning To Veto U.N. Entry Of Saigon and Hanoi
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10A United States spokesman confirmed today that we will veto admission of North Vietnam and South Vietnam to the United Nations when their applications are considered by the Security Council tomorrow.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey announced plans yesterday to develop a statewide health sciences university. The proposed university would coordinate the training of dentists and physicians and play a dominant role in educating nurses, therapists and allied health specialists, said the college's president, Stanley Bergen.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: The Husbands Are Dynamic and So Are Wives
description: The best way to hang on to a husband who is dynamic and successful is for the wife to be dynamic, too, Pamela Uttal, a student at Sarah Lawrence, has concluded after conducting a study. What she was most interested in was whether women who are married to what Mrs. Uttal calls stars have an identity of their own or whether they exist in the shadow of the great ones.

title: McCaffrey & McCall Picks New President
description: Don Durgin, who was president of the NBCTV network for more than seven years, is a president once more. Mr. Durgin, 50 years old, was named president of McCaffrey & McCall, Inc., succeeding David B. McCall, who remains chairman and chief executive officer of the agency

title: New Hope for Whales
description: In what seemed like a footnote to his twoday state visit to Washington, Premier Takeo Miki of Japan announced what was far from, a footnote for wildlife conservationists around the world. After years of Japanese leadership in the slaughtering of whales, the Premier quietly told reporters that Japan accepti without any reservations the quotas fixed by the International Whaling Commission at its meeting last June.

title: Bridge:
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 10A New York team, a Canadian team and two Californian teams, survivors of dramatic finishes in the early hours of this morning, battled this afternoon in the semifinal round of the Spingold knockout team championship.

title: BREZHNEV MEETS HUSAK AT YALTA
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, and Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak President and party leader, stressed today firm intention of their countries to implement all the principles of the declaration of the European security conference in Helsinki earlier this month.

title: COMMANDOS TRAIN FOR EMBASSY DUTY
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10Navy Seal commandos have received special training for possible assignment to American embassies in countries plagued by guerrilla terrorism, according to Navy sources here.

title: Josephine Irish Milton, 75, Honored for Aid to Children
description: Josephine Irish Millon, who was decorated by two Governments for her war work for children, died here Saturday. She was 75 years old and lived at 1192 Park Avenue.

title: Pamela Kalish Wed to Martin Edel
description: Pamela Sue Kalish and Martin David Edel were married yesterday morning at Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, LI., by Rabbi Norman Kahan.

title: Betty Ford Would Accept An Affair by Daughter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Betty Ford said today that she wouldn't be surprised if her daughter, Susan, 18 years old, decided to have an affair. Mrs. Ford suggested that in general, premarital relations with the right partner might lower the divorce rate.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Refugees Hail Ford Visit to Center at Ft. Chaffee, Ark,
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Aug. 10 Thousands of refugees from Indochina applauded, waved to and smiled at President Ford as he toured the Fort Chaffee refugee resettlement center here today.

title: Connors Downs Rosewall Again, 62, 62
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 10In barely 50 sunsoaked minutes on the clay courts of this mountain resort today, Jimmy Connors reaffirmed his mastery over Ken Rosewall in winning the $100,000 Volvo international tennis tournament. The scores were 62, 62.

title: AutoLoan Default Rates Showing Improvement
description: Signs of an economic recovery are evident in the trend in automobile loans, the largest category of consumer installment credit in the nation.

title: A Rise in Deterioration of City's Parks Is Feared Because of Budget Cutbacks
description: The sharp cutback in the manning and maintenance of the city's parks because of the fiscal crisis is leading officials of the Parks. Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration to worry that a cycle of deterioration may have begun that will be impossible to reverse.

title: ACCOUNTING RULINGS ISSUED BY INSTITUTE
description: Two rulings on financial statements that may be useful to stockholders have been issued by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. One ruling requires detailed descriptions of auditors responsibilities. The other concerns transactions that may have been subject to undue influence.

title: Cosmos and Pele Lose to Stars, 21
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP)Pelt put on a dazzling show with his passes, but the St. Louis Stars rallied in the late minutes to topple him and his New York Cosmos teammates in a 21 North American Soccer League exhibition game tonight.

title: Astronauts Back in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)The Apollo astronauts, delayed two weeks by poisonous rocket fumes in their spaceship, returned home today, saying their mission would lead to more cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union. Brig. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, Vance D. Brand and Donald K. Slayton were welcomed by 150 space agency employes, Air Force personnel and local residents.

title: Proxmire Says Lockheed Bribed Foreign Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Senator William Proxmire, who has begun investigating the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's overseas payments, has found that the payments ranged from a few thousand dollars to several million dollars and often went to foreign goverments' officials who were responsible for the award of contracts to Lockheed.

title: Looking for Favorite Hairdresser? He's Moved
description: It's musical chairs time for the beauty salons. If you can't find your favorite hairdressers at the same old stand, chances are he's opened a shop of his own, or the entire salon has moved to more resplendent quarters. Despite the moaning over hard times, a number of daring young men have recently left the security of established jobs to try out their own business wings.

title: Books of The Times
description: The Washington gossip mills provide the city's most lucrative literary export. Despite competition from such massive, direstfromthesource revelations as the Pentagon Papers or the Presidential transcripts, readers continue to gobble up inside dope from the capital, both personal and politicalDan Rather's The Palace Guard and Benjamin Bradlee's Conversalions With Kennedy being two recent examples. Even the appeal of a respected journalisthistorian such as Theodore H. White depends in part upon his weaving intimate scenes at the fount of power into his sweeping narrative.

title: No Immediate Job Boom Seen With Offshore Drilling for Oil
description: TRENTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)Oil companies are trying to dispel thoughts that drilling off the coasts of New Jersey and Delaware will result in an immediate Job boom.

title: Bond Dealers See Calm Week Ahead
description: After going through their most trying period of, 1975 last week, the capital markets should face calm sailing for a while. I think the adjustment was overdone. one economist said Friday, and prices should improve in the Government sector. It was quite an adjustment while it lasted, feeding on bad news and frazzled nerves, sending yields of Treasury securities to their highest levels since the autumn of 1974.

title: COMMANDOS TRAIN FOR EMBASSY DUTY
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10Navy Seal commandos have received special training for possible assignment to American embassies in countries plagued by guerrilla terrorism, according to Navy sources here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CAMERA SPECTRUM Two new shows feature camera art in personalized perspectives. In the collection opening today at the Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street, Reginald Wickman uses darkroom techniques to give blackandwhite pictures a lithographic quality, recording subjects suggestive of silhouettes, such as trees, barns and fences, portraits and candid action shots of nightclub musicians.

title: Susan's Girl $2.80 Victor At Delaware
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 10 (AP)Susan's Girl added more luster to her remarkable racing record today as the 6yearold mare easily won the $109,100 Delaware Handicap at Delaware Park.

title: 2 FOUND SHOT DEAD IN ABANDONED VAN
description: The bodies of two men, both of whom had arrest records on charges of narcotics peddling, were found in an abandoned van yesterday near West 122d Street and Claremont Avenue. Both men had been shot to death.

title: Personal Finance
description: Double or nothing appears to be a new phrase important to job hunters, people about to retire and career planners. Many are beginning to think in terms of two careers in a lifetime and the importance of training for them.

title: HOFFA CASE STAIN CALLED FISH BLOOD
description: DETROIT, Aug. 10Federal agents have identified as fish blood the stains found on the seat of an automobile driven by James R. Hoffa's foster son on the afternoon Mr. Hoffa disappeared, a source close to the investigation said today.

title: Bridal for Gail LeBoff And Stephen Zelman
description: Gail Frances LeBoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald LeBoff of Teaneck, N. J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Martin Zelmarr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Zelman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Judah Washer performed the ceremony in the Teaneck Jewish Community Center.

title: Dr. Morris Meister, Founder Of High School of Science, Dies
description: Dr. Morris Meister, the founder and first principal of the Bronx High School of Scifence and the founder and first president of the Bronx Community College, died last night at New York University Hospital after a short illness. Dr. Meister, who was 80 years old, lived at 315 Riverside Drive.

title: Redman Victor in Ohio As Andretti's Car Halts
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 10 (UPI)Brian Redman drove past the disabled car of Mario Andretti on the 31st lap and won the Buckeye Cup Formula 5000 race at MidOhio today.

title: Pakistanis Fear Crisis in India Could Lead to Border Clashes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 7While Pakistani officials have been withholding formal comment about the crackdown in India, the Pakistani press has begun denouncing it.

title: David Frost Signs To Interview Nixon; Sum Is Undisclosed
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 10David Frost, the television personality, announced today that he had bought the exclusive rights to the television memoirs of Richard M. Nixon.

title: Moderate Coast Quake
description: FRESNO, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) A moderate earthquake rippled through four Central California counties last night, rattling windows and dislodging rocks but causing no heavy damage or injuries, the Fresno County Sheriff's office said.

title: COLLEGES FAULTED ON DISCRIMINATION
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP)An esteemed academic council charged today that Federal affirmative action programs to end discrimination in university and college faculties were confused and chaotic.

title: Kenneth Traum Weds Diane Martha Lavenda
description: Diane Martha Lavenda, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lavenda of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Paul Traum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Traum of Oradell. N.J.

title: Hearing Is Set on Plan to Open Some Files on Persons to Them
description: TRENTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)The State Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled a hearing tomorrow on a proposal to give people access to files kept on them by government agencies and by consumer creditrating services.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 11, 1975

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SON OF BRONFMAN REPORTED MISSING
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said last night that it was investigating the reported kidnapping of the 21yearold son of the president of the Seagram liquor company.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetinos for wrote follows:

title: Southmen Triumph In W.F.L.
description: The Memphis Southmen, led by Larry Csonka, Jim Kiick and Paul Warfield, defeated the Charlotte Hornets, 2311, in. World Football League action Saturday night.

title: Margo Kahn Bride Of Robert C. Jakes
description: Margo Lee Kahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Otto Kahn of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Chester Jakes, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Jakes Jr. of Andover, Mass. Mayor Daniel Kruman of Deal, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Navesink Country Club in Middletown, N.J.

title: Hope Hartley Brock Is Married To Grant Winthrop in Bay State
description: Hope Hartley Brock, graduate of the Boston University Law School, was married yesterday afternoon to Grant Forbes Winthrop, who has a master's degree in journalism from Stanford University. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill of Brooklyn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Annisquam (Mass.) Church.

title: Proxmire Says Lockheed Bribed Foreign Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Senator William Proxmire, who has begun investigating the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's overseas payments, has found that the payments ranged from a few thousand dollars to several million dollars and often went to foreign goverments' officials who were responsible for the award of contracts to Lockheed.

title: Recovery Remains in Low Gear, Executives Say
description: The economy, which apparently hit bottom in late spring, so far hasn't shown much more bounce than a beanbag, and businessmen foresee an unspectacularalthough definiteexpansion for the rest or the year.

title: WELFARE IS FOUND A BURDEN ON CITY
description: New York City's statemandated 25 per cent share of federally sponsored welfare and Medicaid costs far exceeds the burden imposed upon any other local government outside of the state, according to Mitchell I. Ginsberg, dean of the Columbia University School of Social Work.

title: CRITICAL HANDBILLS DELIVERED IN PEKING
description: PEKING, Aug, 10Handbills protesting against the policies of the Chinese leadership have been found slipped into the local mail deliveries of several embassies in Peking.

title: Screen: 'A Pain in the ':French Farce Stars Jacques Brel
description: Pignon is a gangling, frog-faced necktie salesman. His car is decorated with plastic flowers and a teddy bear whose eyes light up when the brakes are applied. He is a man of damp enthusiasms and uncoordinated passion and probably wears socks in bed.Not surprisingly, his wife, who aspires to elegance, horseback riding and Paris-Match, has left him for the local psychiatrist. Pignon checks into the main hotel of the provincial capital and sets to work to kill himself.The room next to him is occupied by Ralph, a professional assassin who has arrived on the opposite mission. He is to shoot a key witness in a corruption trial that is to take place in the Palace of Justice across the street. The crowded French farce "A Pain in the A" ("L'Emmerdeur"), which opened at the 68th Street Playhouse yesterday, tells how the two men's efforts entwine hopelessly and are mutually frustrated.Ralph, played by Lino Ventura, puts out a "do not disturb" sign and is assembling his rifle when water floods through the door crack. Pignon (Jacques Brel) has tried to hang himself, managing only to snap off the showerhead.Furiously, Ralph helps the hotel bellhop extricate Pignon. The latter promptly directs the full force of his sticky fervor at the reluctant gangster, thrusting on him the role of spectator and rescuer at each successive suicide attempt. He involves him in a half-hearted campaign to get his wife to feel sorry for him and take him back.Each time Ralph settles down to put his rifle together. Pignon intrudes spectacularly. Finally, in one tussle, Ralph's rifles goes off, the police open fire, and the would-be suicide and assassin are both jailed."I am very glad to have met you," Pignon tells his victim near the end. "I was very lonely these last three months." Trotting around the jail yard just ahead of his admirer, the efficient loner Ralph has clearly been given a life sentence of incompetent companionship.Pignon is a character with enough originality and outrageousness to make this, potentially, a funny and biting picture. There are some fine moments. Pignon trots along on foot beside his wife on horseback, trying to win her back. He holds up some, photographs of their new house. "But they're in color," he bleats, as she rides away without looking.But "A Pain," though generally pleasant and often amusing, doesn't quite manage to be itself. One weakness is its French farce convention. It is packed so full of gags and reversesmany of them pretty worn outthat it becomes cloying. The French overeat, figuratively speaking, at their farces.A bigger weakness, though, is that although Mr. Brel is a considerable singer, he is not the marvelous actor that is needed to make the sprawling improbability of Pignon take off. He drags Pignon around manfully but can't get him going on his own. Similarly, though less crucially. Lino Ventura, in a part Jean Gabin might have played, is meager and stolid.

title: Carl Naumburg, 85, Dies; Broker, Kipling Collector
description: Carl T. Naumburg, a limited partner in the brokerage firm of Stern, Lower & Co., who was a noted collector of the works of Rudyard Kipling, died yesterday at a nursing home in Chagrin Falls, Ohio, where he had been living for the last two years. He was 85 years old.

title: Belfast Girl, 4, Slain In New Gun Battles; Boy, 15, Also Dies
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 10 (Reuters)Two children, one a 4yearold girl, were shot dead in sporadic firing tonight at a Roman Catholic stronghold in Belfast, a military spokesman said. He also reported that army marksmen had hit five gunmen.

title: A Man, 58, Fights Off 2 Central Park Gunmen
description: A 58yearold amateur photographer strolling in Central Park with a pair of cameras punched, kicked and. fought off two guntoting teenaged robbers who accosted him on a footpath yesterday morning, but was slightly wounded when one of the fleeing thugs turned and fired a parting shot at him.

title: Reduced Garbage Pickup Schedules To Begin in Effort to Regain Normalcy
description: Sanitationmen making their rounds today will fasten new schedules to garbage cans and slip schedules under doors or into mailboxes to tell superintendents, landlords and homeowners of the reduced collections going into effect tomorrow.

title: Blacks and Whites Are Kept Apart on Boston Beach
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10  Long lines of helmeted policemen held apart jeering, stone and bottlethrowing black and white crowds today on a South Boston public beach.

title: Lisbon's Divided Army
description: LISBON, Aug. 9The unity that Portugal's armed forces displayed when they overthrew the rightist regime more than 15 months ago has vanished. The divisions among the military over the course the revolution should take have become so deep as to arouse fears that the way may be open for a new coup or a civil war unless the crisis evident in military ranks is resolved quickly.

title: Stabilized Artpark Still Needs Funds;
description: LEWISTON. N. Y.The Earl Brydges Artpark in this quiet upstate New York border town seems to have found its equilibrium this year after a tumultuous first season in 1974 marred by staff discord, comntunity mistrust and problems stemming from its very newness.

title: STOCK DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices moved lower yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Embattled Mrs. Peron Reshuffles Cabinet and Gives Key Post to a Military Man
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 President Isabel Martinez de Perlin reshuffled her Cabinet for the third time in a month today in the midst of Argentina's worst economic crisis in a generation and continued bickering between factions in the Peronist movement.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court ruled that the State Parole Board had properly rescinded the parole of a man who was arrested with another man identified as a hit man for mobsters. The Appellate Division of Superior Court dismissed an appeal by the man, Abraham Prins of Bayonne, against the revocation of his parole.

title: EARL G. ROBERTS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP)Earl G. Roberts, Democratic candidate for clerk of Quarter Sessions Court, died yesterday at his home here. He was 45 years old.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Salmon Rights
description: When Canada's Atlantic salmon became dahgerously depleted a few, Years ago, steps Were taken to end the netting of them in New Brunswick po and in rtions of Quebec and Newfoundland.

title: Business Records
description: FREDA SCOTT,??

title: Prices Move Down in Grain Futures
description: Prices of basic farm commodities  grains and soybeanseased yesterday as the trade awaited the Government's regular report on crop estimates, which came out after the close.

title: Hoffa Grand Jury is Near; F.B.I. Lacks Firm Leads
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the bureau did not know whether James R. Hoffa was dead or alive and had no promising leads.

title: Susan Ford Likes Mother's Interview, But Others Criticize View on Affair
description: Betty Ford got mixed reviews inside and outside her family yesterday for her television interview in which she said she would not be unduly surprised if her 18yearold unmarried daughter Susan disclosed that she was having an affair.

title: About the Jets
description: Joe Namath and Emerson Boozer probably will start Saturday night's National Football League exhibition game against the St. Louis Cardinals in St. Louis. Namath relieved Al Woodall at quarterback in the Jets 2015 victory over the Minnesota Vikings last Saturday night. Boozer, a running back, did not play because of a groin injury.  Joe Wysock, a fifthround draft choice from South Carolina, has agreed to contract terms. Wysock, guard, underwent two knee operations in the offseason and a club spokesman says he may not be able physically to play this season.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: MOST BANKS JOIN IN RAISING PRIME
description: A quarterpoint increase in the prime lending rate of commercial banks spread swiftly across the nation yesterday, confirming the existence of strong upward pressure on shortterm interest charges in general.

title: For Craftsmen, Someone to Fetch and Carry
description: Perhaps you've hit on an idea for a line of tiedyed baby clothes, but your youngest is in college and nobody you know is in the market for baby things.

title: Crisis Noted in Teaching of U. S. History
description: The teaching of American history in the nation's public schools is in crisis, a special report by the Organization of American Historians warns. The study, a detailed survey of the 50 states and the District of Columbia, finds a movement away from history, atleast as history is traditionally defined and taught.

title: Butz Calls for Suspension Of Grain Sales to Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, following a report today by his department that dry weather in key producing areas had reduced the outlook for this year's corn crop, called on grain companies to withhold temporarily further sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Joan Little Says She Stabbed Jailer After Forced Sex
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 11Joan Little, choking up and breaking into tears on the witness stand today, described how she had stabbed Clarence Alligood repeatedly after grabbing away an icepicc she said he had used to force her into an act of oral sex in her jail cell.

title: JOHN A. GALVIN
description: John A. Galvin, chairman of Development Directions, Inc., a fundraising concern, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 7 Goldfinch Lane in Huntington.

title: Kidnappers Free Sicilian
description: ARIGENTO, Italy, Aug. 11 (AP)Nicola Campisi, 43 years old, a wealthy Sicilian land. owner and industrialist, was freed by kidnappers early today after his family paid a $1milIlan ransom, the police reported. Mr. Campiai was abducted July 1 as he was driving to his factory near this south Sicilian town.

title: Bishop E. Lani Hanchett Of Hawaii Episcopalians
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 11 (AP) The Right Rev. E. Lani Hanchett, bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Hawaii, died early today of cancer. He was 55 years old.

description: The theater marquee announced Live Every Friday IWA Professional Wrestling Sept. 6 The Ms All Bare America Contest with NBC's Don Imus. Inside, the New York Philaharmonic was rehearsing Mahler's Ninth Symphony under the direction of Pierre Boulez.

description: Football players suffer needless deaths during summer practices because of heat strokea condition incurred by sweating off too much fluid and body chemicals according to a doctor writing in the issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association published yesterday.

title: Ashe Loses To Orantes By 62, 62
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Aug. 11 (AP) Manuel Orantes of Spain upset Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion, 62, 62, in the final of the United States clay  courts tennis championship tonight.

title: PARIS ARMS CURB MAY BE SEMANTIC
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 11The ambiguous wording of remarks by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France that he would limit arms sales to South Africa has made it difficult for South African and foreign sources here to evaluate what effect the policy will have on South Africa's growing military capability.

title: Notes on People
description: Following weekend surgery  an unidentified hospital source said it was for a kidney ailemntDr. Werner Von Braun was in satisfactory condition yesterday at Baltimore's Johns Hopkins Hospital. The 63yearold German born rocket pioneer and NASA official has been a vice president at Fairchild Industries in Germantown, Md., since 1972.

title: Warped Standard.
description: The financial community, never in the forefront pressure for welfare reform, has been driven by New York City's brush with insolvency to recognize that fairness as well as fiscal soundness dictates Federal assumption of the full cost of welfare.

title: U.S.Panama Talks Set
description: PANAMA, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Negotiations between Panama and the United, States on a new canal treaty are to be resumed in September, the Panamanian Chief of Government Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, said today. General Torrijos made the announcement after a meeting with the Ambassador William J. Jorden, who called on the Panamanian leader on instructions from President Ford. Panama wants a new treaty to expire no later than the year 2000, but the United States wants a 50year treaty.

title: Music: Messiaen and Wife Perform His Visions
description: LENOX. Mass., Aug. 11We need the great artist as a presence among us almost as much as we need his works. We need to see the human being, to reach out to touch the corporeal reality at the same time that we stand in awe before the mystery of the creative achievement. Nothing lays a deader hand on art faster than the deification of the artist. So the Festival of contemporary Music being held this week at Tanglewood has done well to bring Olivier Messiaen in person for this annual orgy of new music, which is jointly sponsored by the Berkshire Music Center and the Fromm Foundation.

title: East and West, Timorese Live in Poverty,
description: KUPANG, Indonesian Timor, Aug. 8Two kinds of extreme underdevelopment exist sidebyside on Timor, a remote island closer to Australia's sparsely populated north than to the continent of Asiaunderdevelopment as a result of colonialism in the Portuguese east of the island and as a result of postwar independence in the Indonesian west.

title: Police Plan to Close L.I. Parkways Because of Carey's P.B'A. Bill Veto
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 11 The Long Island State Parkway policemen's union, angered by Governor Carey's veto of a bill that would have permitted it to act, as its own bargaining agent, today threatened motorists with ruleenforcement and safety checks that would result in huge traffic tieuns.

title: Court Upholds Ginzburg on His Dictionary Ads
description: Ralph Ginzburg, the magazine publisher who served eight months in a Federal prison on an obscenity conviction won a legal battle against the city's Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday when a State Supreme Court justice ruled that he had not falsely advertised a dictionary.

title: SKF, Its Parent And Federal Mogul Accused by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission accused three of the biggest bearing manufacturers today of engaging in anticompetitive conduct through mergers and an intercompany agreement.

title: Business Briefs
description: Savings banks in New York State experienced a net deposit inflow of $82million in July, the Savings Banks Association of New York reported yesterday. The increase was the seventh consecutive monthly gain.

description: RENO, Nev., Aug. 11 (UPI) Harrah's, the company that operates casinos and exhibitions at Reno and Lake Tahoe, announced today that it had bought the antique automobile collection of the late Winthrop Rockefeller, consisting of 71 vehicles, for $947,000. It will be added to Harrah's automotive museum collection of 1,400 cars near Reno.

title: Fund Lack Said to Imperil Jersey MassTransit Plans
description: New Jersey's top three mass transportation projects, including the controversial $347million plan to extend the PATH rapid transit line, may need far more Federal aid than will be available, Federal transit sources said yesterday.

title: PLASTIC WRAPPERS FOR FOOD FACE BAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration may ban some plastic food packages, such as vegetable oil bottles and some meat wrappers, because of a potential cancer link, a spokesman said today.

description: LISBON, Aug. 11Hundreds of demonstrators broke through a protective military cordon around the Communist headquarters in the northern Portuguese city of Braga today and set fire to the building after an afternoon and night of violence that left 30 persons injured, most of them with gunshot wounds.

title: In Memoriam
description: BARNETTAbraham. In losing memory of your birthday. We all miss you.

title: Businesses to Pay $50.4Million Rise For Phone Service
description: The Public Service Commission granted the New York Telephone Company yesterday a $50.4millionayear increase in rates charged to 330.000 business customers. Of that total, 300,000 typically have two to six incoming lines handled by key equipment on A bank, or on the phone, and 30,000 have private lines or tie lines

title: Driver's Condition Poor
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 11 (AP)B. J. Swanson, the 26yearold Bristol, Ind., driver injured in an accident during the Buckeye Cup Formula 5000 race at nearby MidOhio yesterday, was listed in poor condition today at Mansfield General Hospital. Swanson suffered severe head injuries when his car slammed into a bridge. Officials blamed the accident on a stuck throttle.

title: New Regime is Set Up For All Comoro Islands
description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, Aug. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)The Comorian Revolutionary council, set up here after the overthrow of Ahmed Abdullah on Aug. 3, today handed over its powers to a new 13man National Executive Council representing all four Comoro Islands.

description: This is Senator Edward M. Kennedy. He is not a candidate for President.

description: MONTREAL, Aug. 11Secretary of State Kissinger today offered the developing nations a compromise United States position on deepsea mining in an effort to remove a major obstacle in negotiations over a new law of the sea.

description: Several incidents in recent films vividly identify once again the soil in which roots of black alienation were firmly and long ago planted for blacks growing up in America during the 1940s and 1950'sroots still very much nurtured, to the continuing detriment of black youth in the 1970's.

title: Seagram Roots Are in Canada
description: When Edgar M. Bronfman, President of the Seagram Company, Ltd. was a child, he and his brother and sisters rode their bicycles on an enclosed track at the Bronfman mansion outside of Montreal.

description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 11Nassau county residents will vote this November for the 15 members of the interim system of government being imposed on the county, State Supreme Court Justice Joseph LW said today.

title: Ford Urged Not to Run By His 23YearOld Son
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 11 (AP)Jack Ford said today he had advised his father not to run for the Presidency in 1976, but that President Ford did not take the advice seriously.

title: Timor Rebels Said to Favor Lisbon Links
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug 11A reported coup d'tat in the Portuguese part of the is land of Timor appears to have been carried out by a conserva Jive, largely Roman Catholic land proindependence politica party, according to Indonesian sources that quoted monitored radio broadcasts from the island.

title: Garbage Backlog Is Cleared Up
description: The Sanitation Department in New York announced it had eliminated the 3,500ton backog of uncollected garbage that had accumulated on the city streets as a result of layoffs in the department. We're over the heap, said Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh. while conceding that litter baskets were still overflowing and that more mechanical sweepers were needed on the streets.

title: An Army of Relic Hunters is Despoiling Civil War Battlegrounds
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Aug. 10Tons of spent munitions and historic artifacts lie beneath the corn rows and wood lots here that were once the bloodiest battlegrounds of the Civil War. And they have attracted a 20th century army that is well equipped and bent on collecting souvenirs.

title: Fire and Casualty Insurers Have Credit Ratings Cut
description: Twentyfour per cent of the to set loan rates to the compafire and casualty insurance Dies. companies surveyed by the industry's bestknown credit service have had their credit ratings lowered since last year, the Associated Press reports.

title: Pier at Battery Place Designated U.S. Landmark
description: Pier A at Battery Place, home of the Fire Department's marine division and the berth of the fireboat John D. McKean, has received a Federal designation as a historic landmark.

title: KEY BERGMAN AIDE ADMITS CONSPIRING IN FEDERAL FRAUD
description: A key aide of Bernard Bergman pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy charge and indicated that he would be a major witness for the prosecution in the Bergman nursinghome case.

title: Packaging Mr. Nixon
description: Is executive privilege for sale to the highest bidder? After refusing to appear before Congressional corrimitteel and the Federal courts in Watergaterelated cases, former President Nixon has now made a deal to. tell all in a series of telecasts that will be filmed now and shown after the 1976 elections. No subject, including Watergate, has been barred, declares David Frost, the British talkshow packager and host who put the deal together.

title: Frisbee Accuracy May Carry Maplewood Boy to World Title
description: MAPLEWOOD, Aug. 11 (AP)Flying saucers are no mystery to 15yearold Andrew Schindel.

title: Carey Vetoes Measure to Establish 10 Regional Breast Cancer Detection Centers
description: ALBANY, Aug. 11Citing the radiation hazards of mass Xray screen techniques, Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that would have required the State Health Department to establish 10 regional breast cancer detection centers across the state.

title: Cheaper Air Travel
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board has taken a welcome step toward making air travel cheaper and more easily available to the American people. Beginning next month, new low charter fares will be available under far less restrictive conditions than those now existing. This will mean that for many travelers the combined cost of air fare and hotel under the new charters will be less than the cost of regularly scheduled air travel alone. addition, many present obstacles to utilization of charter flights will either be removed or sharply reduced.

title: Yanks Decline To Sign Jones
description: Cleon Jones, the rebel outfielder released by the Mets two weeks ago, offered yesterday to sign with the Yankees but was told that he had waited too long.

title: People and Business
description: Ohio's Governor, James A. Rhodes, whose state ran fullpage advertisement in The Wall Street Journal last May 29 assailing Federal Government red tape for contributing to natural gas shortages, has declared that the advertising campaign will be continued if nothing is done.

title: IRVING SCHIFFER
description: Irving Schiffer, deputy mayor of metropolitan Dade County, Fla., who retired in 1968 as senior real estate manager of the New York City Department of Relocation, died Saturday in Miami Beach. He was 63 years old and lived in North Miami.

title: Alfred Lee Loomis Dead at 87; Physicist, Financier and Lawyer
description: Alfred Lee Loomis, a noted physicist, financier and lawyer, died yesterday at his home in East Hampton, L. I. He was 87 years old.

title: City and M.A.C. Strive to Form Fiscal Troubleshooting Staffs
description: Both the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the Mayor's management advisory council took preliminary steps yesterday to recruit staffs and set priorities for their separate but related examinations of the operations of the city's government.

title: People in Sports
description: A Minneapolis prosecutor has decided to drop all criminal charges against Dave Forbes, the Boston Bruins hockey player who was accused of aggravated assault for allegedly hitting another player in the eye with the butt end of his hockey stick. The incident occurred during a game in Bloomington, Minn., Jan. 4.

title: Charging Orioles Defeat Royals,40
description: The Boston Red Sox say they won't look back at the charging Baltimore Orioles. When we lose a game, we hope Baltimore loses, too. Other than that we haven't got time to think about Baltimore. So said Jim Rice, Boston's outstanding rookie leftfielder.

title: U.S. VETOES BLOCK 2 VIETNAM STATES FROM JOINING U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11The United States today vetoed the proposed admission of North and South Vietnam to the United Nations during a lengthy Security Council session marked by an abundance of rhetoric and an absence of any real drama.

title: Stocks Show Mixed Tone; Dow Jones Climbs by 6.02
description: Stock prices recovered in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon. The DowJones industrial averagedown 4.07 points at 11 A.M.closed the day with a gain of 6.02 points at 823.76.

title: STATE AIDE ENTERS GARBAGEPACT SUIT
description: NEWARK, Aug. 11 (UPI)Anthony J. Grossi, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, stepped into civil battle between Jersey City and a garbage contractor today an effort to keep key depositions secret.

title: Jersey Youth Tries to Break Roller Coaster Record at Coney Island
description: Seventeenyearold Michael L. Boodley rocketed off on thq quest for his impossible dream yesterday afternoon at Coney Island.

title: Fighting Reported to Spread in Angola
description: LISBON, Aug. 11The Luanda radio in Angola reported tonight that the situation in the African territory was extremely confused and it said that communications with most of the interior had been lost.

title: GARBAGE BACKLOG GONE, GROH SAYS
description: The Sanitation Department announced yesterday that it had eliminated the 3,500ton backlog of uncollected garbage, but conceded that litter baskets were still overflowing and that garbage from the last few days was accumulating on the city streets.

title: Shipping/Mails
