title: M.A.C. Seeks Faster Pace On City Budget Reforms
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation has presented Mayor Beame with a new timetable for implementing budgetary reforms so that they will he in place and operating by the time the next budget goes into effect, in June, 1976.

title: Ford Defers Visit to India; Political Climate a Factor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11President Ford has put off indefinitely his plan to visit India this fall.

title: Documenting the Vietnam Story
description: HOUSTONThe end of the fighting in Southeast Asia has not, as we have seen, ended the debate about the Vietnam war here at home. Is there anything we can do to resolve the arguments that have been continuing about how the United States became involved in the war in the first place and what efforts the Government made to bring about an honorable settlement?

title: Crisis Noted in Teaching of U.S. History
description: The teaching of American history in the nation's public schools is in crisis, a special report by the Organization of American Historians warns. The study, a detailed survey of the 50 states and the District of Columbia, finds a movement away from history, at least as history is traditionally defined and taught.

title: LaidOff Women Police Officers Decide to Fight for Their Jobs
description: Maureen Kempton, a laidoff police officer who hasn't had much to do lately except take her three children to the beach, leaned forward in her chair in an East Side law office the other day, frowned, and said:

title: News Summary and Index
description: Hundreds of demonstrators broke through a protective cordon around the Communist headquarters in the northern Portuguese city of Braga yesterday and set fire to the building. About 20 people inside the building escaped. The incident followed an afternoon and night of violence in which 30 persons were injured, most of them with gunshot wounds. Meanwhile, in Lisbon a group of nine antiCommunist military officers said their campaign against Premier Vasco Goncalves was gaining support. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: Court Rebuffs Ford On Oil Import Fee
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The United States Court of Appeals here rued today that President Ford had no authority to levy fees of $2 a barrel on imported oil, as he has done this year.

title: GRAINSALE FRAUD LAID TO 15 BY JURY
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 11 (AP)Ten eastern Oklahoma residents were arrested today in connection with what the authorities described as a $360,000 grain sale fraud.

title: Ford Defers Visit to India; Political Climate a Factor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11President. Ford has put off indefinitely his plan to visit India this fall.

title: Sets Beaten, 2722
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 11 The New York Sets drive for the Eastern division pennant in World Team Tennis was slowed tonight by a 2722 loss to the Golden Gaters before 2,752 people in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: 50 NIGERIANS FREED BY NEW GOVERNMENT
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 11 The new federal military Government released 50 longtime detainees today, including five military officers involved in the military coup of January, 1966.

title: Europeans Pay Tribute To American Revolution
description: Continued From Page 31

title: 3 JUSTICE BILLS VETOED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday vetoed three of the more significant criminaljustice bills of the 1975 legislative session, including one that would have eased penalties under an importent section of the strict socalled Rockefeller drug laws.

title: Europeans Find Lessons In the American Revolution
description: TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Aug. 11As the aging, bemedaled French general took the salute during a Revolutionary War reenactment here today, The several hundred tourists lining the walls of the restored Fort Ticonderoga may have assumed incorrectly that he was an actor in the Bicentennial pageant.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (RadioWNEW, 8 P.M.)

title: Angels Steal 6 Bases, Top Yankees, 81
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 11 Manager Billy Martin shook up the New York Yankee lineup tonight but the California Angels proceeded to shake up the New York Yankees by stealing six bases in an 81 victory.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Our good friend, Roger Fessaguet, has sent us a copy of a letter he recently dispatched to President Ford concerning the President's views on dining that appeared in a recent issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: M.A.C. Seeks Faster Pace On City Budget Reforms
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation has presented Mayor Beame with a new timetable for implementing budgetary reforms so that they will be in place and operating by the time the next budget goes into leftect, in June, 1976.

title: Vivian Blaine Signed
description: Vivian Blaine has been signed to star opposite Milton Berle in The Best of Everybody, a comedy scheduled to open on Broadway Oct. 28, according to the producers, Mike Merrick and Don Gregory.

title: Dollar Up Abroad; Pound Sags Again; Gold Price Slips
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 11 (UPI)The dollar chalked up further gains on European money markets today as several large American banks raised their interest rates.

title: Connecticut General Registers Decline in Operating Earnings
Shell to Increase OilItem Prices
description: Increases in petroleumproduct prices were announced yesterday by the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Shell Oil Company. Atlantic Richfield said it had raised the price of gasoline and diesel and heating oils to its customers by cent a gallon, effective last Saturday, while Shell increased the price of kerosene, premium diesel, diesel fuel and furnace oil by 1.5 cents a gallon. Over the weekend Shell had announced a 1centagallon increase in the price of liquid petroleum gas. Texaco, Inc., over the weekend announced 1centagallon increase in the price of all grades of motor gasoline, tractor and diesel fuels, No. 1 and No. 2 heating oils and kerosene.

title: Straightening it Out
description: Except for other cities in New York State, this metropolis is almost alone in having to raise out of local taxes 25 per cent of its basic welfare costsroughly $1 billion a year and going up under the weight of disastrously high local unemployment. The staggering impact on municipal finances lends force to the plea made to Federal officials by the Municipal Assistance Corporation for a Federal takeover of the whole bill. New York banks are giving strong support to the plea in hopes of bolstering the market for M.A.C. bonds.

title: OPENING OF SCHOOLS IN BOSTON DELAYED
description: BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP)The, opening of Boston public schools under a new integration program was ordered delayed three days yestetday until Sept. 8.

title: Singer Unit in. Algeria Pact
description: The Singer Company said yesterday its American Meter division had signed a 10year technical assistance agreement with the Societe Nationale de l'Electricitie et du Gaz of Algeria, The agreement covers the development and construction of a multimilliondollar facility for the manufacture of Igas meters and regulators in Algeria. No financial details were disclosed.

title: Correctional Group to Meet
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 11 (UPI)The American Correctional Association will hold its 105th Congress of Corrections beginning here Sunday, and Will discuss probation and parole, education and training, legal issues and juvenile corrections and treatment.

title: U.S. Amateur Qualifiers
description: NEW JERSEY SECTION

title: Fund Sets Merger Plans
description: The International Holdings Corporation reported here yesterday that it had reached tentative plans to merge the closedend fund with the Cheapside Dollar Fund, Ltd., an open end fund to form an openend fund with Schroders, Inc., adviser to Cheapside, as adviser to the merged fund.

title: Liberties in Greece
description: ATHENSIn the citystate where it first flourished, democracy is on trial in the streets and in the courtrooms. A year after the downfall of the military junta, following seven tongueless years under colonels and nightsticks, the dictatorship has been dismantled, elections have been held, a new albeit imperfect constitution has been adopted and, symbolically, the goddess Athena has replaced the King's face on the coins of the republic. But democracy after tyranny is a delicate form of government, and nowhere mare so than along the Mediterranean littoral.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Yesterday's Monmouth Results
description: The Associated Press

title: Bronfman Kidnap Letter Asks Substantial Ransom
description: The family of Edgar M. Bronfman, head of the billiondollar Seagram Company Ltd., with worldwide liquor and other interests, said yesterday it had received a substantial ransom demand in a letter from the asserted kidnappers of his oldest son, 21yearold Samuel Bronfman 2d.

title: U. S. BARS PAYING OF PARKING FINES
description: The General Services Administration has reported that the Federal Government cannot pay New York City for parking fines owed by drivers of Government vehicles.

title: HOSPITAL STAFF PROTESTS LAYOFFS
description: Officials at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx said yesterday that a sickout by employes protesting staff cutbacks linked to the city's fiscal crisis had lengthened the waiting time in emergency rooms to as much as six hours. Normally, they said, emergency patients are seen within two hours.

title: 3D TEACHER GROUP MEETING ON COAST
description: Teachers from around the country who consider the nation's two major teacher organizations too liberal will gather this week in Anaheim, Calif., under the banner of a burgeoning third group, the National Association of Professional Educators.

title: ULSTER VILOENCE WORRIES BRITISH
description: LONDON, Aug. 11 With violence mounting in Northern Ireland, British officials are expressing fears that the ceasefire in the province is in danger of collapse.

title: Ways To Kill A Football Player
description: Method 1.Right from the start of the season, rigidly schedule the second practice session between the hours 2:30 to 6:00 each afternoon.

title: TV Issue Threat To Split N. C. A. A.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)The president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and a president of member college fired opening salvos today over a share  the  wealth proposal which threatens to split this week's special convention at which the nation's colleges will seek to cut escalating athletic costs.

title: Highs and Lows
description: NEW LOWS19

title: From Russia With Impact on West's Ballet
description: For those who consider that ballet depends upon stars (and not everybody does), then American Ballet Theater scored a coup at the State Theater here this summer by becoming the first company to present in one season Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: Chess
description: The results of the 1975 United States women's championship in Milwaukee show a further progress in two tendencies that have been developing for years the ascendance of youth to the top echelons and the wider spread of talent around the country. Nineteenyearold Diane Savereide, the new champion with a score of 7 points out of 10, comes from Culver City, Calif.. and is the youngest winner ever. Tied for second were Ruth Herstein of Los Angeles and Ruth OrtonHaring of Fayetteville, Ark., with 6 points each.

title: Rodino Endorses Bill to Open Dossiers
description: Trenton, Aug. 11Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, today endorsed proposed state legislation to regulate agencies that keep dossiers on private citizens.

title: SMALL BUSINESSES AT RECORD IN 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The number of small businesses operating in the United States reached a record last year, but at the same time, the number of smallbusiness failures during 1974 increased by 6 per cent.

title: Orange County Executive Scores Vote on Relief Aid
description: The Orange County Executive and his Commissioner of Social Services declared yesterday that there was no present alternative to continued county financing of welfare programs, and said that they would ask the County Legislature next month to reverse itself and appropriate additional money to maintain social services.

title: Floods Kill 63 in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 11 (Reuters)  At least 63 people have died in landslides and floods caused by heavy monsoon rain in the last six weeks, the Red Cross announced here today. The most damage appears to be in southeastern and southcentral Nepal.

title: High Court in India Delays Hearing in Gandhi Case
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11The Supreme Court of India today delayed its hearing on the legal challenge to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's election to consider a new constitutional argument advanced by lawyers noosing her.

title: Women in Coast Guard Have to Be Landlubbers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)The Coast Guard said today it would allow women to enter its academy for the first time beginning next Julybut the law still prevents them from going to sea on Coast Guard ships.

title: STUDENTS BUILDING SCHOOL WAREHOUSE
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP Aug. 11 (AP) The Board of Education in this South Jerser community believes it has put a crimp in high construction costs and at the same time is providing summer jobs for students.

title: Zaire Joins Oil Talks
description: GENEVA, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Zaire joined today the six other oilproducing and developing countries that took part in last April's energy talks with oilconsuming states in Paris to discuss strategy for a resumption of the Paris session. The meeting went on all day and is expected to end tomorrow.

title: Toro Star Takes Soccer Award
description: The players in the North American Soccer League who voted for Steve David of the Miami Toros as the most valuable player will be happy to know that the forward who scored 23 goals in 21 games can turn on a 50cent piece.

title: Auto Insurance Rate Rise Sought in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP)Massachusetts automobile insurers requested today a $244milliorr rate increase for 1976, saying that inflation and unprecedented numbers of accidents were causing companies to lose money.

title: Tomahawks Win, 1918
description: QUEBEC, Aug. 11Jim Johnston's third goal with minute 44 seconds left gave the firstplace Long Island Tomahawks a 1918 triumph over the Quebec Caribous tonight in aNational Lacrosse League game.

title: Mottram Gains. At Canadian Net
description: TORONTO; Aug. 11 (UPI) Mottrarn of Britain scored 60; 64 victory over Paul Gerken of the United. States; Coil Dowdeswell of Rhodesia beat bale Power of.  Ciinda 74, 63. and Patilite Pioirj of France defeated Boyce of Canadji 61 first roindti of the. Bothinan's Cansidian open tennis tournament today.

title: Study of Controller of Currency Cites Faults in Its Operations, but Says Office Maintains Strong System
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The Federal agency responsible for maintaining the integrity of the nation's 4,700 national banks has not kept pace with new banking methods, often focuses on the wrong problems and has too many informal contacts with bankers, a study released today asserted.

title: Events Today
description: THE SHOESHINE PARLOR by James Lee; Performed by the New York Shakespeare Festival Mobile Theater; at Eden. weld Houses Playground, Srhierfelin Avenue and East 229th Street, 8.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: 5th Ave. Group Wins Right to a Hearing On Landmark Status
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ruled that the Neighborhood Association to Preserve Fifth Avenue Houses was entitled to a public hearing of ils application to compel the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to designate 82d Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues a historic district.

title: DISSENTHEED RARE IN F.C.C. VOTING
description: An analysis of the voting records of the seven members of the Federal Communications Commission has found dissent to be exceedingly rare, with the commissioners voting in agreement with Richard E. Wiley, Chairman, an average 97.6 per cent of the time.

title: U.S. VETOES BLOCK 2 VIETNAM STATES FROM JOINING U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11The United States today vetoed the proposed admission of North and South Vietnam to the United Nations during a lengthy Security Council session marked by an abundance of rhetoric and an absence of any real drama.

title: Normalized Prague?
description: Of all the Soviet satellite states in Eastern Europe, Czechoslovakia undoubtedly imposes the most repressive conditions on its people. The secret police keep the populace under Intensive scrutiny. The worst blows are aimed at Czechoslovakia's foremost writers, some whom have even seen their children denied the right enter high school because they will not conform slavishly to Prague's demands.

title: MSGR. JOHN M'NAMARA
description: Msgr. John M. McNamara, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in the Crestwood section of Yonkers, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: General Electric Credit Lends 36.5Million to American Beef
description: OMAHA, Aug. 11 (UPI)The General Electric Credit Corporation said today it would give American Beef Packers, Inc., new line of credit totaling $36.5million, which should enable at least three of the company's plants to reopen and provide the funds necessary to finance the Beef Packer's creditors arrangement plan.

title: Butz Calls for Suspension Of Grain Sales to Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, following a report today by his department that dry weather in key producing areas had reduced the outlook for this year's corn crop, called on grain companies to withhold temporarily further sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Foolish Pleasure: Syndication Near
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11Foolish Pleasure, the Kentucky Derby winner who cost John L. Greer $20,000 at the yearling sales here two years ago, will probably leave the current meeting as the eighth most valuable stud in thoroughbred racing history.

title: Market Place
description: It is now more than seven months since Americans have been allowed to own gold after a hiatus of more than 40 years, and it is clear that the expected rush to gold bars has not materialized.

title: Store Manager Kills 2 of 3 Armed Men In Holdup in Harlem
description: The night manager of a Harlem supermarket shot and killed two gunmen with one of their own weapons early yesterday during an attempted holdup.

title: Consumers Find Little Comfort on Crops
description: Consumers received little comfort yesterday from either the Government's August crop report or its request that grain exporters continue to refrain from booking new business in the Soviet Union.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Monmouth County Superior Court Judge Patrick J. McGann Jr. temporarily restrained the Long Branch City Council and its citizens advisory board from investigating the Long Branch Police Department. The injunction, which requires the city to show cause Aug.. 22 why it should not be made permanent, was issued on behalf of two police captain and a patrolman. The investigation of the Police Department's operating methods stems from the shooting last October of a 16yearold black youth by a white patrolman.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Larry Morris

title: Pension Fund of Teamsters Scanned for Clues on Hoffa
description: In the background of the investigation of the disappearance of James R. Hoffa is the bizarre story of abuse and misuse of the Central States, Southeast and. Southwest Areas Pension Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Stage: Scarecrow, 1908 Play, in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11it is a widely held assumption that American drama began with Eugene O'Neill, and while in one sense this is accurate enoughfor O'Neill was unquestionably our first playwright of geniusit does disregard some very interesting earlier plays that made a real contribution to the American theater.

title: Stomach Pains Send McFeeley to Hospital
description: Ken McFeeley, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, was admitted to Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn last night suffering from severe stomach pains.

title: Ford Signs First Pay Rise Since 69 for Top Federal Officials
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 11President Ford has approved legislation granting the first pay increases in six years to members of Congress, Federal judges, thousands of high  ranking Government employes and Vice President Rockefeller, the White House announced here tnda v.

title: Board Proposes Teachers Lengthen Week 2.5 Hours
description: An increase in the work time of teachers and other measures aimed at achieving greater staff productivity were proposed yesterday by the Boand of Education in preparation for toplevel contract talks with the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Trial Gives New Twist to Old Racial Issue
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 11Before the murder indictment against Joan Little was reduced to a noncapital seconddegree charge, her supporters saw her trial as nothmg more than oldfashioned lynch law turned on its head, some new and bitter fruit from the hangman's tree that has come, half in myth, half in reality, to symbolize cases of summary justice cleat to blacks accused of s,.xual trespass in the South.

title: Missing Seagram's Heir Lauded as Unpretentious
description: Samuel Bronfman 2d, the heir to the Seagram's fortune who was believed to have been kidnapped while driving between his father's and mother's Westchester County homes last weekend, was described yesterday by friends and associates as an unpretentious, friendly person who did not like to flaunt his wealth.

title: Coop City Issue: Subsidized MiddleIncome Housing
description: The dispute at Coop City, in which most residents of the mammoth apartment development in the northeast Bronx are refusing to pay a 25 per cent increase in maintenance charges approved by the News state, crystallizes Analysis the problems of publicly assisted middle income housing here. And it raises the question of how much additional aid the city or state should give residents of such housing and, where such housing is a cooperative, whether the occupants have an even greater obligation to shoulder the development's higher costs than they would if they lived in rented apartments.

title: Bronfman Kidnap Letter Asks Substantial Ransom
description: The family of Edgar M. 1Bronfman, head of the billiondollar Seagram Company Ltd., with worldwide liquor and litinterests, said yesterday lit had received a substantial ransom demand in a letter from the asserted kidnappers of his oldest son, 21yearold Samuel Bronfman 2d.

title: Moscow Now Pressing Disarmament
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 11 The Soviet Union appears to be developing disarmament as a dominant new theme in its foreign policy, following visible satisfaction with the outcome of the European security conference.

title: No Listing Reported on Gift From Ashland to Gov. Moore
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 11 (UPI)  Secretary of State James McCartney said there was no listing of a $20,000 contribution to Gov. Arch Moore's 1972 campaign by the Ashland Oil Company.

title: Yogi and the Snipers
description: Make no mistake about it, Yogi Berra was not dismissed as manager of the New York Mets a week ago because the team skidded into a fivegame losing streak. That would be like saying Richard M. Nixon resigned President a year ago because our balance of payments was a little low that month. Yogi was gunned down after series of reverses that were not altogether his fault. The Mets lost nearly one million in home attendance over the last four years the Yankees crowded their way into Shea Stadium with Catfish Hunter and other new talent, they then signed Billy Martin as their manager, the Mets meanwhile found that their winter of trading wasn't producing a summer of winning and several of their Mite players developed the habit of sniping at Berra through the front office.

title: KEY BERGMAN AIDE ADMITS CONSPIRING IN FEDERAL FRAUD
description: A key aide of Bernard Bergman pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy charge and indicated that he would be a major witness for the prosecution in the Bergman nursinghome case.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Brooks Fashion Stores, Inc., said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a planned initial public offering of 500,000 shares of its common stock. The offering, through underwriters headed by Goldman, Sachs & Co., is ex.pected the middle of next month at an indicated price of between $9 to $11 a share. All of the shares are being offered by selling shareholders. The company operates a chain of 120 women's Junior apparel specialty stores.

title: Iran Arrests 4 Terrorists
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 11 (AP)Iranian authorities said today that they have arrested four more terrorists, completing the roundup of the group thought to have assassinated two United States Air Force colonels in May. Three others were arrested in July. All seven face a military trial and a possible death sentence by firing squad, sources said.

title: Bridge
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 11Two California teams clashed in the final of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here today, fighting for a place in the International Team Playoffs in October and possible world championship honors. The two teams, captained by Harold Guiver of Long Beach, Calif., and John Fejervary of Palo Alto, Calif., overcame strong opposition from Canadian and New York teams in winning their semifinal matches in the early hours of this morning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I take strong issue with your July 26 editorial opposing state legislation to control proprietary home healthcare agencies. Moreover, the premises upon which it based its conclusion are inaccurate. The Times own Albany correspondents will bear witness to the enthusiastic support by the legislators of this measure during the debates. At no time during his administration did former Governor Rockefeller have similar bill under consideration.

title: Canada's Price Index Off
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Canada's wholesale price index fell threetenths of 1 per cen in June, Statistics Canada said today. The index of the cost of living stood at 483.6 in June, down from May's revised figue of 485.2, the Government statistics office said. In June, 1974, the index stood at 452.9.

title: Medicaid Cuts Bring Worry to Many
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 11An elderly, crippled widow here is anxious about whether she will be unable to get her prescriptions filled locally and will have no way to make the necessary trip to satisfy her medical needs.

title: News Summary and index
description: Hundreds of demonstrators broke through a protective cordon around the Communist headquarters in the northern Portuguese city of Braga yesterday and set fire to the building. About 20 people inside the building escaped. The incident followed an afternoon and night of violence in which 30 persons were injured, most of them with gunshot wounds. Meanwhile, in Lisbon a group of nine antiCommunist military officers said their campaign against Premier Vasco Goncalves was gaining support. [Page 1, Col. 8].

title: Court Rebuffs Ford On Oil. Import Fee
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The United States Court of Appeals here ruled today that President Ford had no authority to levy fees of $2 a barrel on imported oil, as he has done this year.

title: Cuba Refunds Ransom in 72 Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba has returned the $2million ransom paid by Southern Airways in November, 1972, for a hijacked airliner, Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama said today.

title: U.S. Five Loses in U.S.S.R.
description: VOROSHILOVGRAD, U.S.S.R., Aug. 11 (UPI)  A lastsecond shot by Alexander Zhed gave the Soviet Union a dramatic 8584 victory over the Indiana AllStars today as the Americans ended their monthlong basketball tour of Europe.

title: New A.B.A. President
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 11Some lawyers spend most of their careers trying to become president of the American Bar Association. Those who succeed in the long.

title: China Indicates That Unrest in Chekiang Has Not Been Ended.
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 11Communist party workers in coastal Chekiang Province recently had the unusual experience of being treated to a seminar on the ABC's of Communist pracNotes tice followed by on a field trip to a rebellious factory China in Hangchow that was occupied by troops. It was one of 18 factories in Chekiang's scenic old provincial capital where more than 10,000 troops have been sent in the last month to quell factional bickering and labor unrest.

title: S.E.C. Disciplines 6 in Pricing Case
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 11 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had imposed various sanetions against a firm formerly known as Laidlaw & ??? and five other securities firms over alleged manipulations of overthe counter stocks from 1971 through 1973.

title: ISRAEL TO BOYCOTT U.N. CRIME MEETING
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 11Israel has decided to boycott a crimeprevention conference of the United Nations, it was announced here today. The conference, set for next month, was transferred to Geneva from Toronto when Canada reacted adversely to observer status for the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: INQUIRY ON ESTES BY I.R.S. REPORTED
description: DALLAS, Aug. 11 (AP)Billie Sol Estes, the onetime West Texas wheelerdealer who went to prison after his fertilizer tank enterprise collapsed in 1962, is reported to be the target of a new investigation by the Internal Revenue Serv. ice.

title: 23 INJURED IN CRASH OF COMMUTER BUS
description: Twentythree persons were injured early yesterday, most of them not seriously, when a commuter bus of Transport of New. Jersey smashed into a guard rail along the Garden State Parkway in Hazlet Township, Monmouth County, the state, police reported.

title: 3 JUSTICE BILLS VETOED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday; vetoed three of the more sigi nificant criminaljustice bills of the 1975 legislative session, in cluding one that would have leased penalties under an important section of the strict soi Icalled Rockefeller drug laws.

title: Advertising
description: Hello, Dolly could very well be the most popular show tune of the last couple of decades, and its melody is certainly as well known as any to millions of Americans. Beginning next Monday, they'll be hearing it again with different lyrics as part of a new advertising campaign by Hardee's Food Systems.

title: Dawkins 76ers Prime Pupil
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug11In reality, Darryl Dawa 6foot10inch24pound basketball player with a $1million contract rteom the Philadelphia 76ers, who hope he can fill their treat need for a center.

title: GOING OUR Guide
description: There should be something for everyone in Lincoln Center OutofDoors, a festival of 60 free events in dance, music and theater being previewed today and running through Labor Day in the plaza of the center. The festival starts today at noon with excerpts from the next three weeks programs. The sponsors are the Exxon Corporation, with aid from the New York State Council on the Arts and the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Sticking Valve Delays TakeOff Of Viking Craft on Mars Flight
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 11The takeoff of the first of two Viking craft, designed to land on Mars as part of a $1billion program, was delayed at least three days today by the malfunctioning of a valve that was to help steer the launching rocket.

title: GOLDIN DELAYING EXPENSE CLAIMS
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin, currently in the midst of crackdown on expense accounts, is holding up payment on more than 50 vouchers sub. flitted by city employes and members of the Board of Education and the Board of Higher Education, his office said yesterday.

title: HearstCase Figure Notified Of Dismissal From Rutgers
description: A former United States Olymplc team member, Philip K. Shinuick, who was questioned in the Patricia Hearst case, disclosed yesterday that he was dismissed effective next July as an assistant professor and director of sports studies at Rutgers University's Livingston College, United Press International reported.

title: Retail Sales Rose in July For 4th Straight Month
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11Retail sales rose strongly in July for the fourth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: War Prisoner's ExWife Must Account for $80.000
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (UPI) The former wife of an air Force pilot who spent 5 years in a North Vietnam prison camp has been ordered to account for more than $80,000 of his salary and allotments that she received during his captivity.

title: National Canoeing Shifted to Maine
description: WEST FORKS, Me., Aug. 11The sixth annual national open canoeing championships, originally scheduled on the Moose River in Old Forge, N. Y., have been shifted to the Lower Dead River here, according to Mike Waddle, the race chairman. The dates, Aug. 23 and 24, remain the same.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WESTBURY,.L: I., Aug. 11Bourbon, one of the fastest Italianbred trotters in history, was named today as the fifth entry in the 17th $200,000 Roosevelt International, set for Aug.. 23 at Raceway. Bourbon joins the defender, Delinonica. Hanoverof the United States, Bellino II a lnd. Dimitria, both from France, and Bairly II of the NetherJandsin the 1%mile race. The 6yearold horse was sired by the leading Italian stallion, Gigolo (who has some French blood), but of the exported American dam Tercel. Giansaverio Bianchi, an importer of wines and liquors from Milan, ovrs Bourbon and prefers to name his horses after his lousiness products. Bourbon, who was syndicated for $500,00 this year with Hanover Shoe Farm of Hanover, Pa., and 'astleton Farm of Lexington,.Ky., each purchasing shares, has won 26 of 71 career starts and $149,031. His career mark for the mite is 2:01.

title: GLENN BARS 76 BID AS A FAVORITE SON
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11 (UPI)Senator John H. Glenn Jr. of ??? disavowed today all speculation that he would run as a favorite son Presidential candidate in the Democratic primary in Ohio, but the former astronaut left the door open for a spot on the national ticket in 1976.

title: 20 to 30% Discount For Many Flights Proposed by United
description: United Airlines proposed yesterday a new system of 20to30 per cent discount fares that would be available on scorep..of flights traditionally flying with empty seats, and eliminate the minimum mileage restriction of current plans.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth
description: Today's Entries at Monmouth

title: 5 F.B.I. Agents Put on Leave In Richmond Wiretap Inquiry
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 11 (UPI)Five agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of a Federal grand jury investigation into a Richmond wiretap case, the F.B.I. said, today.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL TO SHIFT PRICES
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourthlargest steel producer, announced late yesterday that it would change prices of various lines of its products in line with price changes announced last week by the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer.

title: Rugged Week for Giants Linebacker
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 11After a week in which his wife underwent surgery, his home was ransacked and he played the entire preseason opener on defense for the New York Giants, Pat Hughes still had his sense of humor intact today.

title: Soviet Duo Wins
description: VIENNA, Aug. 11 (AP)Olga Morozova and Marina kroshina of the Soviet Union won the women's doubles event in the European amateur tennis championship today with a 46. 76, 64 victory over Martina Navratilova and Renata Tomanova of Czechoslovakia.

title: AdLib Auto Commercials Tried
description: The New York Ford Dealers Association, made up 111 dealers in the New York metropolitan area and southern Connecticut, has begun a sevenweek radio advertising campaign built around the theme, Mustang II M.P.G. means 34 Miles Per Gallon. But there will be no scripts for the announcers to read.

title: Europeans Find Lessons In the American Revolution
description: TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Aug. 11As the aging, bemedaled French general took the salute during a Revolutionary War reenactment here today, the several hundred tourists lining the walls of the restored Fort Ticonderoga may have assumed incorrectly that he was an actor in the Bicentennial pageant.

title: 2 ExFalstaff Executives File Suit Against Company
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) Two former vice presidents of the Falstaff Brewing Corporation have filed a $4.8million suit against the company and its president, Paul Kalmanovitz.

title: With Help, a Former NATO Base in France Gets Along
description: CHATEAUROUX, FranceMarcel Lembine; the Communist who is Deputy, for this region in the National AsSembly, got a bargain on his house in what had once been the American colony.

title: DETROIT NEWS SEEKS OKLAHOMA TV OUTLET
description: The Evening News Association of Detroit plans to acquire WKYTV in Oklahoma City. An application filed with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington indicated yesterday that the Oklahoma. Publishing Company, publisher of The Oklahoma City Oklahoman, planned to sell the station, for $22.6million.

title: LAWRENCE SMITH, 72 ; A ROOSEVELT AIDE
description: FREEPORT, Me., Aug. 11 Lawrence M. C. Smith, associate counsel to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and general coordinator of the legal division of the National Recovery Administration in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Administration died today at his summer home here. He was 72 years old and also lived in Philadelehia.

title: New Legislature For L.I. County
description: Residents of Nassau County, on Long Island, will vote in November for 15 members of an interim legislative body, State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Liff said. It will replace the present sixmember Board of Supervisors, which operates under a weightedvoting system that had been declared unconstitutional by the courts.

title: About the Giants.
description: Carl Summerell's fine showing at quarterback against the Patriots (seven completions in 10 attempts for 85 yards and one touchdown) has not surprised Ted Plumb, the assistant coach in charge of quarterbacks. He's got a good head, a quick release and he's alert, Plumb said. Pat Hughes likened Summerell, with his 6foot4inch frame and fresh beard, to a young Abe. Lincoln.  Injuries Jack Gregory (broken nose), Jim Pietrzak (muscle spasm) and Leon McQuay (pinched nerve) do not appear serious, Coach Bill Arnsparger said.  Bob Hammond missed the team bus and had to spend $20 for a taxi to Schaefer Stadium for the game, but the 5foot10inch, 172pound freeagent running back missed little else in his pro debut. He gets down there and ties their shoestrings, Arnsparger said of Hammond's qualities as a blocker despite his size.  In praising Rick Dvorak, who replaced Pietrzak at defensive tackle, Arnsparger called the secondyear pro one of the most fundamental football players we have.

title: About the Mets
description: Ken Sanders, who suffered a ruptured blood vessel in his right eye in Sunday's game when he was hit by a return throw from. John Stearns, the catcher, during his warmup, will remain for at least a day or two in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Eye Institute. Dr. Frank Hoefle, an eye specialist, said his vision has subjectively improved and further tests are contemplated. Sailders is still on the active roster.  Dave Kingman received the most popular Met player award for 1975 from the Catholic Youth Organization in a pregame ceremony.

title: Books of The Times
description: For the Greek poet Pifidar, athletics expressed the highest human aspirations. The philosopher Pythagoras wrestled in the Olympic games. The unity of the physical and the spiritual animated the golden age of Greek sculpture. In his classic Paideia, Werner Jaeger sees the split between the spirit and the body beginning as early as the sixth century B.C. For George Leonard, author of Education and Ecstasy, as well as The Ultimate Athlete, this lovers quarrel between mind and body was a major error in Western thought, one we are only now coming to understand. We are discovering that our bodies are models of the environment, even the world. The discredited human animal is heard to roar once more. In place of athletics as a profession, built around competition and winning, or amateur athletics as therapy for keeping arteries elastic, Mr. Leonard suggests sport as a dance. He cites the style of such black athletes as O. J. Simpson, Sugar Ray Robinson and Dr. J. as examples of the dance element even in professional play.

title: Birmingham Workers Accept 5% Pay Rise, Ending Strike
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 12 (AP)  Striking Birmingham city workers accepted a 5 per cent wage increase and some benefits tonight, ending 4weekold strike by nearly onethird of the city's work force. The workers will return to their jobs tomorrow morning.

title: Marine Found Not Guilty In Beating of Navy Recruit
description: WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. I; (UPI)A threeman military panel today found Marine Sgt. Michael Williams not guilty in the beating of a Navy recruit, Steven Stawnychy, at the Great Lakes Naval Training Center.

title: Henri P. Blanc, Headed Hilton's. Training Institute
description: Henri Pierre Blanc, director of Hilton International's Career Development Institute at Montreal, died there yesterday. He was 43 years old and lived in Montreal.

title: Carey Vetoes a Bill to End Prohibitions Against Hiring Felons, Calling It Vague
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12A bill designed to eliminate the maze of bureaucratic prohititions against hiring released felons was vetoed today by Governor Carey, who called the purpose of the bill commendable but said its specific provisions were vague, difficult to understand and impossible to implement.

title: Some Argentines Turn to Prayer as Economic. Crisis Deepens
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12Argentines are not usually considered among the most fervently religious Latin Americans. But last week a column of faithful stretching for 12 blocks waited to enter the Church of San Cayetano and pray to the saint who is the guardian of workers's jobs.

title: Gowon is in Britain To Join His Family
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reu ters)The deposed Nigerian head of state, Gen. Yakubu Gowon, arrived here by air today from Accra, Ghana, to loin his family.

title: Books of The Times
description: Reading Jean Raspail's novel The Camp of the Saints is like being trapped at a cocktail party with a normallooking fellow who suddenly starts a perfervid racist diatribe. Being politeand trappedyou listen, nodding glassily, waiting for a pause in his torrent so that you can excuse yourself. I don't know Mr. Raspail's other writings (according to the jacket, the Academie Francaise awarded him the JeanWalther Prize in 1970 for the whole of his work), but on the subject of race he apparently becomes a bit loony.

title: GULF OIL IS ACCUSED OF CREDIT VIOLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Gulf Oil Corporation of violating the Truth in Lending Act by failing to tell customers that credit costs were hidden in the price of merchandise promoted through the mails.

title: S.E.C. LAYS FRAUD TO WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed fraud charges here yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation as an outgrowth of the 1974 sale of its major appliance division.

title: St. Clair Calls Exposure Inevitable Without Tapes
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP) James St. Clair, attorney for President Nixon in the Watergate affair, said today that the scandal would have been uncovered even without the White House tapes.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Tuesday, Aug. 12, 1975

title: LOSSES CHARGED IN MEDICARE PLAN
description: Representative Elizabeth Ioltzman charged yesterday that Blue CrossBlue Shield omputer errors may have cost elderly New Yorkers as much as $12.7million in reduced Medicare payments last year.

title: Teamster Morass.
description: Two weeks after the disappearance of James R. Hoffa mystery still shrouds his fate. The deeper the law enforcement authorities dig into the mare's nest of underworld syndicates that envelops the twomillionmember International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the more baffled they seem to become about who or what might have caused the union's former leader to vanish as he started his comeback campaign.

title: BEACH POLLUTION REPORTED EASING
description: CAPE MAY POINT, Aug. 12 (AP)Swimming is still officially forbidden here because of pollution from the sewagetreatment plant of neighboring Cape May City, but a health official said today that the problem was beginning to clear up.

title: F.B.I. Says Hearst Figure Is in Its Protective Custody
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 I(AP)Walter J. Scott, reportedly a key witness in the investigation of the Patricia Heafst (case, is in protective custody lbecause he fears for his life, the Federal Bureau of Investination said today.

title: Advertising
description: A new entry in the children's chewablevitamin field will make its debut next week, bearing the name of one of the bestknown children's characters these days SpiderMan.

title: Ford's Strategy Can Adapt to Tariff Loss
description: The decision by the United States Court of Appeals that President Ford exceeded his authority by imposing a $2abarrel fee on imported crude oil appears to make the decontrol of domestic oil prices on Aug. Economic 31 all the more Analysis probable. Mr. Ford, even before the decision went against him, had signaled his intention of dropping the $2 tariff and the 60cent fee on imported refined products as means of holding down petroleum price lincreases after decontrol.

title: LISBON SPEEDS UP ITS ANGOLA AIRLIFT
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 12 (UPI)The Portuguese national airline accelerated the airlift of white refugees from the southern town of Nova Lisboa today and authorities said that they planned to evacuate 250,000 to 300,000 persons to Portugal by Oct. 31.

title: DDT BAN REDUCES LEVEL IN HUMANS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) The threeyearold ban on DDT has diminished sharply the levels of the chemical in human tissue and in animals but the threat persists, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Women at Work, From Bunny to Blacksmith
description: Frivolous news items like this about women breaking into nontraditional jobs really irritated Betty Medsger, a freelance photojournalist who is very much a feminist. But instead of sitting and stewing, she decided to do something about her anger.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The Manhattan telephone directory costs the phone company about. $2 to publish; a set of 76 directories covering everyone listed in the state costs $96.25, weighs 71 potds and costs an additional $35 to deliver.

title: Passion Play to Blame Lucifer, Not the Jews
description: BONN, Aug 12The elders of Oberammergau have decreed that the next version of the town's famous Passion Play will not use a sharply criticized text that blames the Jews for the death of Jesus.

title: Costlier Grain
description: Prices for grain futures closed substantially higher in Chicago yesterday, a portent of higher supermarket prices to come. Discouraging new estimates of the outlook for this year's balance of grain supply and demand indicate still worse pressure on food costs may lie ahead. Even Agriculture Secretary Butz, a fount of optimism earlier this summer, had to confess his own misgivings by keeping in force the newly established stop on further major grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Basque Hideouts Raided in Resort Visited by Franco
description: MADRID, Aug. 12 (UPI)The police uncovered a network of Basque guerrilla hideouts today in a region where Generlalissimo Francisco Franco is vacationing, and seized arms, ammunition and explosives, the national press agency Cifra said.

title: Report on Tender Offer
description: Mark & Spencer said in Montreal yesterday that a total of 2,820,990 shares of common stock of Peoples Department Stores, Ltd., a Canadian chain, had been tendered in response to its offer to buy 1,406,000 shares at $10.27 a share. The purchase of the shares will give Marks & Spencer, a European department store chain, a 55 per cent interest in Peoples Department Stores.

title: NATALIE COLE SINGS IN GOSPEL TRADITION
description: Natalie Cole, the 25yearold daughter of the late Nat (King) Cole, apparently has no intenion of challenging her father on his own vocal grounds. At Buddy's Place, where she is appearing with two backup singers and a fivepiece band, Miss Cole is stressing her gospel roots, working in the Aretha Franklin tradition.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Bicentennial Barge Will Extol 76 Common People
description: New York State yesterday introduced its major public project to commemorate the American Revolution a red, white and blue barge that will sail the state's waterways next spring and summer. It will stop in 32 ports, bringing with it the story of the common man in New York during the Revolutionary War.

title: SANCTIONS ASKEW FOR 125 DRUGGISTS
description: NEWARK, Aug. 12Virginia Long Annich, director of the Department of Consumer Affairs, announced today that list of 125 pharmacists who have refused to fill prescripdons paid for with Medicaid cards will be presented to the State Board of Pharmacists tomorrow with a request for appropriate legal action.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: SENATOR CHARGES GROUP IS USELESS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Senator Patrick J. Leahy and six youthful snoopers, prowling the jungles of bureaucracy, have discovered a Federal agency that, the Senator says, does almost nothing and spends $67.000 a year doing it.

title: FORD AIDES STUDY WELFARE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Ford Administration is reviewing the Government's social welfare programs with an eye toward reform and consolidation in various areas; John G. Veneman, counselor to Vice President Rockefeller, said tonight.

title: 2 Miles Up, Ford Relaxes With Golf
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 12Ohhh! exclaimed the President of the United States in mild exasperation as he threeputted the the third green of a golf course nestled nearly two miles up in the Rockies. Gerald R. Ford is on vacation.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: National League

title: FOOD STAMP RISE SCORED BY SIMON
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 32 (UPI)The food stamp program is a haven for chiselers and ripoff artists and is one example of letting the Government solve problems that people should solve for themselves, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today.

title: BANK REGULATORS SAID TO REIN S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) Federal bank regulators kept from the public conditions at two major banks that eventually collapsed, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John R. Evans, said today.

title: JERSEY PROPOSES BUS AND RAIL RISES
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12New Jersey's Commuter Operating Agency today proposed railfare increases of up to 70 per cent and busfare increases of up to 100 per cent on statesubsidized intrastate lines.

title: Lincoln Center Opens Its Fifth Year of Free Events Just Right for Everyone
description: Lincoln Center shed its black  tie, mostly  Mozart image yesterday to celebrate its fifth annual outdoor festival of free eventswhich, in the words of one young spectator, were just right for old people and just right for young people, too.

title: Staff Is Named by Beame For 3d CityAffairs Study
description: Mayor Beame yesterday an. flounced the staff of a third ad hoc group to study city affairs, the Temporary Commission on City Finances. The commission is charged with developing legislative programs that will ease some of the city's financial problems in the next decade.

title: Ford Going to Peoria
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) President Ford will meet central Illinois leaders for a daylong domestic affairs conference in Peoria next Tuesday, a White House spokesman announced today.

title: The Hoffa Puzzle Pieces Still Don't Fit
description: DETROITAug. 12About 1 P.M. on the warm and sunny afternoon of Wednesday, July 30, James R. Hoffa got into a Pontiac at his home 40 miles north of here and drove away into one of the biggest mysteries of the year.

title: SALE POSTPONED ON MORGAN BONDS
description: J. P. Morgan & Co. Inc., parent of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, postponed yesterday its offering of $150million of sevenyear notes, citing unsettled market conditions.

title: Paolo Contini, U.N. Law Expert, Dies With Son in Mountain Climb
description: Paolo Contini, an international legal expert, died last Thursday in a mountainclimbing accident on Athabasca Glacier, Jasper National Park, Alberta, Canada. He was 61 years old and lived in Rome.

title: Walker's 3:49.4 Mile
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 12(AP)John Walker of New Zealand shattered the world record in the mile run with a time of 3 minutes 49.4 seconds today. He became the first man to run the distance in under 3:50.

title: WINE TALK
description: A great many lines in this space have been devoted to the unconscionable prices many restaurants charge for wine. Some of the worst offenders are New York's French restaurants, but the problem exists everywhere.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Proposals before Congress to raise taxes on income from foreign investments and certain export earnings are provoking a battle in which the chief antagonists are the national labor unions and the multinational corporations.

title: Passion Play to Blame Lucifer, Not the Jews
description: BONN, Aug 12The elders of Oberammergau have decreed that the next version of the town's famous Passion Play will not use a sharply criticized text that blames the Jews for the death of Jesus.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: A Child Is Being Beaten Violence Against Children An American Tragedy, by Naomi Feigelson Chase (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $8.95).

title: WALDHEIM URGES ARMSCUT EFFORT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 Secretary General Waldheim, in a report on the work of the United Nations, urged the world organization today to commit itself more strongly to international disarmament.

title: Complaints Listed By N.F.L. Union
description: Terming its relationship with the league as scarred by animosity, the National Football League Players Association opened testimony yesterday before the National Labor Relations Board on its charge of unfair labor practices against the N. F L.

title: IT'S SUMMONS DAY ON L.I. PARKWAYS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12The Long Island State Parkway police said they issued more than twice as many summonses to motorists today than on a normal day, under their job action, which they described was a superenforcement of vehicle and traffic laws.

title: Chinese Aide Gives Description of Public Execution
description: TIENTSIN, China, Aug. 6 (Reuters)A lone policeman, in the blue uniform of China's Public Security Bureau, stood at the center of the crowded, execution ground and killed a prisoner with a single shot.

title: Codd Is Critical of Revisions of Charter
description: The proposal by the State Charter Revision Commission for common boundaries for most New York City departments would lead to fragmentation of police protection, heap an $85million changeover bill on a financially pressed city, and risk intrusion of neighborhood politics into police decisions, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 8 FORMER AIDES OF FRANKLIN BANK INDICTED BY U. S.
description: Eight former officials and employes of the Franklin National Bank and its parent company, the Franklin New York Corporation, have been indicted on Federal charges involving the loss of more than $30million of the bank's money in unauthorized speculation in foreign currencies.

title: People and Business
description: Charles F. Mansfield, president of Marine Midland BankNew York, was named chief executive officer yesterday following the resignation for personal reasons of John S. Lawson as chairman of the board. Mr. Mansfield is 53 years old.

title: STORM HALTS REPAIR OF VIKING SPACESHIP
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. Aug. 12 (AP)A violent lightning storm passed over the rocket pad today and for three hours held tip technicians who were replaying a faulty Valve that postponed the launching of the Viking probe to Mars.

title: City Will Question Former Employes To Find Means to Prevent Pilfering
description: Questionnaires are to be mailed within two weeks to 2,000 former city employes in an effort to uncover patterns of pilferage and other dishonest practices, investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday.

title: Playing Chicken With Turkey
description: COPENHAGENRight now, to use fowl language, the United States is playing chicken with Turkey. Our most urgent foreign policy problem is the need to compose relations with Ankara and Athens while encouraging a modus vivendi for the disputed island republic of Cyprus.

title: Crop Reports Shaped Amid Strict Security
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)Early in the dim hours of morning, guards seal the corridor windows, disconnect telephorres and look for hidden microphones in a quiet, undistinguished Washington basemant.

title: SolzhenitsynWhite House Issue Revived
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Aug 12 (AP)  President Ford's appointment secretary said here today that the recent snubbing of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was the result of agreements between the United States and the Soviet Union at the time the writer was exiled from his home country.

title: From the Journal of a Newly. Retired Man
description: Following are excerpts from the forthcoming book Threshold The First Days of Retirement, by Alan H. Olmstead, who was editor of The Manchester Evening Herald, in Connecticut.

title: Stocks End With a Gain For Fifth Successive Day
description: The stock market rose for three and a half hours yesterday and then gave up roughly half its gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, up 10.02 points at 1:30 P.M., closed at 828.54. Its gain for the day was 4.78 points.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange which had lagged behind while Big Board prices were making small gains most of the last week, finally joined the advance yesterday. Prices were higher for the first time in eight trading days, but volume remained light.

title: Kleindienst Given Month's Suspension From Capital Court
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI  Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has been suspended from practicing law for one month before the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia for, not telling the truth alout White House involvement in the antitrust case against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Military officers petitioned President Francisco da Costa Gomes to end what they view as efforts by Premier Vasco Gongalves to turn Portugal into a Communist state on Eastern European lines. The petition's sponsors claimed 90 per cent support in the armed forces. It was drawn up by nine officers suspended Saturday as members of the High Council of the Revolution for creating divisions within the armed forces. The widespread and often violent campaign to oust the Premier and the fourdayold Cabinet picked up speed. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: State Adopts Beaver and Brook Trout
description: The beaver, an amphibious rodent that receives mixed notices from those who know it well, and the brook trout, an elusive quarry known for its shyness, have gained official recognition with the signing of two bills making them New York State's official animal and fish.

title: TEACHER FUND HERB SUES ON INVESTMENT
description: The city's Teachers Retirement System, which provides retirement allowances from funds vested in it by tilt monthly contributions by teachers, filed suit yesterday against. the United States Trust Company to recover losses totaling $13,313,000 sustained allegedly because of poor investments.

title: Miss Hill, Mrs. Syms Gain
description: NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP)Cindy Hill, the defender, and Nancy Roth Syms, the medalist, led the advance today in the opening round of the 75th women's United States Amateur golf championship. Both are from Colorado Springs.

title: Music Cleve Leads Mozart Festival
description: Two symphonies and two concertos made up the generous program on Monday night that introduced George Cleve as conductor to the Mostly Mozart Festival audience in Avery Fisher Hall. The Viennese  born, American trained musician was heard here with the New York Philharmonic 10 years ago. He has been busy on the American scene elsewhere since then and currently is music director of the San Jose Symphony in California.

title: City U. Cutting Budget by $87Million, But Postpones 2d Ordered Reduction
description: The City University, still implethenting measures to absorb an $87million reduction in its projected budget, is delayingin hopes of avoiding partially or completelythe imposition of an additional cut of $32.2million that has been ordered by Mayor Beame.

title: Transactions
description: Transactions

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday, London Morning fixing 163.15. up $1.25: afternoon fixing $163.50, up $1.60.

title: Michigan Schools to Use SlowScan TV
description: HANCOCK, Mich., Aug. 12School officials here are exper imenting with a system that will allow them to broadcast locally produced instructional television programs over a radio station by electronically compressing the TV pictures into a narrow radio band signal.

title: A Pledge to Assign 12 Nurses Ends Lincoln Hospital Protest,
description: A fourday sickout at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx by employes protesting staff cuts ended yesterday and services at the municipal instituition returned to normal.

title: The Night Watchman Gets New Image as Alert Guard
description: There are things you watch for in the business and Captain Reid knew something didn't look right.

title: Different Faces of Venet Agency
description: When an agency establishes a reputation for expertise in one field, it often finds difficulty in breaking out of that niche. Venet Advertisingwhich spent more than 15 years specializing in retail accountsis no exception.

title: Shazar's Widow, 86, Dies
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 12 (UPI)Rachel ShazarKatznelson, widow of Israel's third President, died yesterday. She was 86 years old. She immigrated to Palestine in 1912 and was founder and editor of Davar Hapoelet, a women's magazine of the Labor Zionist movement. Her husband, Zalman Shazar, who died last year, served two terms as president between 1963 to 1973.

title: RHODESIANS AGREE TO CHARTER TALKS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 12After nearly 10 years of stalemate, the black and white leaders of Rhodesia announced today that they had agreed to meet within two weeks to discuss a new constitution for the racially divided country.

title: Schlesinger Opposes Navy Plans for Big Carriers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has issued a preliminary directive to the Navy to stop planning more giant aircraft carriers and to start planning for smaller ones, and the admirals are fighting the order.

title: JAPAN ARRANGES TO BUY U.S. GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Japan. America's biggest overseas customer for farm goods, arranged to buy at least 14 million tons of grain and soybeans from United States companies in each of the next three years.

title: Stokes Game A Flashback For Grevey
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y. Aug. 12One night, more than a decade ago, Maurice Stokes sat, limp and grinning, in a wheelchair in Cincinnati Gardens as thousands cheered him; and Kevin Grevey, in grade school at the time, was there with his father.

title: Proponents Start Big Push For the Versatile Coconut
description: BANGKOK, ThailandThe coconut has fallen upon hard times.

title: RICHARD D. PARKER
description: ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP)Richard D. Parker, a cofounder in 1943 of the Fenway Victory Gardens in Boston's Back Bay section died yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Citibank Prefers Closing in Colombia To Ceding Control
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 12 (UPI)The First National City Bank told the Colombian Government today that it would not turn over a controlling interest in its Colombian branches to local shareholders and that it would rather close than obey a Government order to cede majority control.

title: Suspect in Hotel Holdups Here Is Apprehended cat the Waldorf
description: A 27yearold man was seized in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel After a robbery yesterday afternoon, and the police officers said he was a possible suspect in 20 or more recent holdups of guests in midtown hotels.

title: Burden Hurt in Crash
description: SYRACUSE Aug. 12 (AP) Luther (Ticky) Burden, who recently signed with the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association, suffered cuts and bruises early today when the car he was driving struck a tree along the New York State Thruway near Mattydale, the state police said.

title: CRIPPLED CHILDREN WILL GET LESS AID
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)The State Health Department imposed cutbacks today in its $1.3million program of hospital care for crippled children.

title: Grain Prices Advance Sharply
description: Prices of corn, wheat and soybeansthe basic foodstuffs shot upward yesterday, the day following the Government's largely optimistic survey of crop conditions on Aue. 1.

title: Army Discloses Man Died In Drug Test It Sponsored
description: The Army disclosed yesterday that a 42yearold patient at the New York State Psychiatric Institute died 22 years ago in an Armysponsored experiment with hallucinogenic drugs.

title: Alexander's Taking Klein Queens Lease
description: Alexander's, the New York retail chain, announced yesterday that it was taking over the lease of the Klein's Department Stores in Flushine. ??? Jt was also learned that S. Klein is closing its main store at Union Square at 14th Street and its branch in Yonkers on Saturday.

title: Angolan Debacle
description: An unspeakable tragedy which might easily become peril to international peace and security is unfolding relentlessly in Angolaand the world seems totally indifferent. Only hardpressed Portuguese forces are making any effort to halt what has now exploded into outright civil war among three African liberation movements; and even their actions are often halfhearted.

title: VICTOR HACKLER, 69, EXA.P. EXECUTIVE
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP)  Victor Hackler, former liaison officer for The. Associated Press with its organization of member newspapers managing editors, died of cancer on Monday. He was 69 years old.

title: State Adopts Beaver and Brook Trout
description: The beaver, an amphibious rodent that receives mixed notices from those who know it well, and the brook trout, an elusive quarry known for its shyness, have gained official recognition with the signing of two bills making them New York State's official animal and fish.

title: Stage Moliere'sDoctor
description: For its second production of its current series at the Playwright's Horizons Theater, the Lion Theater Company is offering, an exuberant chase through Moliere's A Doctor in Spite of Himself. The performance begins athletically. In warmup suits, the actors tumble and jump. Then they leap into the play, and we see Moliere's malady: He hated doctors.

title: Issue of $275Million in M.A.C. Bonds Is Reported Selling Kind of Slowly
description: The drive to market $275million in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds was reported to be encountering difficulty yesterday, and bond sellers prepared for a meeting today or tomorrow to decide whether to raise the interest rates tol sour sales.

title: 9 Hurt,17 Arrested As Violence Flares In Section of Boston
description: BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)Nine persons were injured, one seriously, as several hundred youths attacked motorists passing through Boston's Mission Hill and Orchard Park housing projects today, the police said.

title: Work Is Starting on Plant to Convert Trash Into Oil
description: EL CAJON, Calif., Aug. 12Construction will, begin her tomorrow on the first large. scale recycling plant designee to demonstrate that municipalties can profitably convert their trash and garbage into. flue oil to help meet the nation energy needs.

title: RHODESIANS AGREE TO CHARTER TALKS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 12After nearly 101 years of stalemate, the black and white leaders of Rhodesia announced today that they had agreed to meet within two weeks to discuss a new constitution for the racially divided country.

title: About New York
description: Walt Whitman could never get enough of New York. He even loved it in August, when most peoplethen as nowfound it unbearable.

title: Music Serena Catches the Imagination
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12It doesn't often happen that the newest piece on a concert program is also the best, but that is how it was last night at Tanglewood, where the annual Festival of Contemporary Music is under way.

title: People in Sports
description: President Ford, writing as a private American citizen with a lifetime interest in sports, has endorsed in a letter to Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, a petition by the United States Olympic Committee requesting that the late Jim Thorpe be restored to recognition by the I.O.C.

title: Bankruptcy Step Is Taken By Drew National Concern
description: The Drew National Corporation, a large doortodoor distributor of home furnishings and major appliances as well as women's apparel, filed a petition yesterday for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York. The company listed assets of $24.89million and liabilities of Bankruptcy Step Is Taken By Drew National Concern.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Military officers petitioned President Francisco da Costa Gomes to end what they view as efforts by Premier Vasco Gonsalves to turn Portugal into a Communist state on Eastern European lines. The petition's sponsors claimed 90 per cent support in the armed forces. It was drawn up by nine officers suspended Saturday as members of the High Council of the Revolution for creating divisions within the armed forces. The widespread and often violent campaign to oust the Premier and the fourdayold Cabinet picked up speed. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Yanks End Slump, Get 15 Hits And Beat A's, 72, for Medich
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 12 Walt Williams, Chris Chambliss and Thurman Munson gat three hits apiece tonight as the New York Yankees accumulated 15 and scored a 72 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: Crunchy Dialogue
description: She I feel bad about our relationship.

title: Collins Ahead in Met. Golf
description: JERICHO, L. I., Aug. 12Bill Collins, the 47yearold Brae Burn pro who won the Buick open on the Professional Golfers Association tour in 1962, led the opening round today of the $25,000 Metropolitan P.G.A. championship over the 7,101yard Meadow Brook course with a twounderDar 70.

title: Yablonski Is Resignjng Post As Mine Union's 'ounse
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 12Joseph A. Yabloniki, a son 01 a murdered reform leader of the United Mine Workers, dis. closed today that he was resigning as the mine union's general counsel.

title: Howard Swain, 75, Dies; ExNewspaperman Here
description: Howard A. Swain, a veteran newspaperman, died Friday in Stuart, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived there. Between 1924 and 1932, Mr. Swain was associated with The New York Evening Graphic. When that paper folded in 1932, he was its editor and publisher.

title: Soviets Invoke Helsinki
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12We are beginning to see already how the Soviet Union intends to interpret the principles of the Helsinki conference to promote its own revolutionary objectives even in Western Europe.

title: MANSON CALLS NIXON KEY TO CONVICTION
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Charles M. Manson says that a pronouncement of his guilt by thenPresident Nixon  prominently displayed in newspaper headlines  was the main reason he and three female followers were found guilty of the TateLabianca slavings.

title: U. S. Silence on India Noninterference or Immorality?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Ford Administration's decision not to criticize publicly the authoritarian trend in India has revived the dispute over over whether the United States should speak out against injustices News in other countries Analysis or whether it should avoid interfering in the internal affairs of others. The dispute has been the source of. sharp contention in Washington.

title: A SECOND U.S.PLAN ON CHILE IS CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Nixon Administration planned a covert campaign to keep Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming President of Chile in 1970 through military and diplomatic channels separate from operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, authoritative Government sources said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced halffare, privileges for handicapped persons in offpeak hours on all its subway and bus lines in the city, as well as on the Staten Island Rapid Transit Line, effective Sept. 2 Also, starting on the same date, handicapped and elderly persons using M.T.A.'s commuter rail service on the Penn Central's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven lines and the Long Island Rail Road will be carried for half fare.

title: Army Discloses Man Died In Drug Test It Sponsored
description: The Army disclosed yesterday that a 42yearold patient at the New York State Psychiatric Institute died 22 years ago in an Armysponsored experiment with hallucinogenic drugs.

title: City Suspends Three For Doing Private Job
description: Two Department of Public Works employes who were found repairing their foreman's automobile while on duty were suspended along with the foreman yesterday.

title: Medical Students Sue to Curb Proposed Increases in Tuition
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  A group of medical students at George Washington University Medical School has filed suit against the university because of proposed increases in tuition.

title: About Education
description: To researchers at the Educational Products Information Exchange Institute, the Mission Impossible image of selfdestructing tape recorders is not a fantasy but a grim possibility.

title: Miki Urges Opposition Parties To End Blocking of Legislation
description: TOKYO, Aug. 12Premier Takeo Miki, fresh from his trip to America, turned his attention to domestic politics today and called on Japan's leftist opposition paities to stop blocking legislation.

title: U.S. Informing Hoffa's Friends They Will Be Called to Testify
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12Federal officials have begun notifying longtime friends and acquaintances of James R. Hoffa that they will be among witnesses called before a grand jury soon to tell under oath what they may know about the disappearance 13 days ago of the former president of the Interntional Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Aug. 12, 1975

title: HARDSHIPS ARE SEEN IN FT. DIX CLOSING
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12 (AP)Closing Fort Dix, or even a major cutback of the Army post, would inflict major damage on the Burlington County economy and affect the entire state, according to a State Labor and Industry Department report.

title: Laver, at 37, Leads Advance in Canada
description: TORONTO, Aug. 12 (UPI) Rod Laver of Australia, who won this tournament in 1970, whipped Mexico's Joaquin LoyoMayo, 62, 63, in his opening, match today at the $130,000 Rothman's Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Congressional Reports Support Floating Rates for Currencies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Several Congressional committees in a joint report gave unanimous support today to the Ford Administration's position in favor of floating currency exchange rates, and opposed any new rules of the International Monetary Fund aimed at an eventual return to fixed rates.

title: DR. EDWARD W. DENNIS
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)Dr. Edward W. Dennis, a heart specialist here and a professor of cardiologyinternal medicine at Baylor College of Medicine, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday in Portland, Me. He was 52 years old and had been vacationing at his summer home.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KUNGSHOLM, Swed. Amer. Lett Glen, garritt Aug. 6; due 8:45 A.M. at W. 55th Lt.
