title: Railroad Strike on Sept. 4 Threatened by Shop Union
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UPI) The President of the Railway Employes Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Origanizations said today that about 85,000 shop craft employes would strike the nation's railroads Sept. 4 unless agreement was reached on wages and working conditions.

title: DEFENSE CLOSES FOR JOAN LITTLE1
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 12The Joan Little defense rested today after Miss Little underwent more than three hours of wheedling, battering crossexamination that failed to evoke any anger from the yonng black woman or elicit any alteration of her account of the stabbing of Clarence Alligood, a jailer.

title: For Summer Canning A Peck of Recipes for Peter Piper to Pick
description: Cucumbers can be pickled, of course, and so can corn, squash and beets. Those and other vegetables are readily available now, so it's the perfect time to start thinkine about pickline.

title: Patient Dies in NursingHome Plunge
description: A 71yearold man, left alone tin his 11thstory room in one of the towers of the Florence Nightingale nursing home, plunged to his death early yesterday morning.

title: Reds in Show of Strength
description: EVORA, Portugal, Aug. 12Thousands of Communist demonstrators broke through military barriers in front of their party headquarters here tonight shouting triumphantly, This is the force of the Communist party.

title: Timor Rebels Now Reported To Be Seeking Independence
description: LISBON, Aug. 12 (Reuters)A political party in Portuguese Timor that says it has staged a successful coup demanded immediate independence today, according to the office of the ortuguese President.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 12 (UPI)The Bank of Japan announced today it was reducing the official discount rate from 8 7 per cent, effective tomorrow. It is the third halfpoint reduction of the discount rate this year. The central bank said the step was being taken to stimulate the protracted business slump. The past reductions carried out in April and June failed to stimulate business.

title: British Drive May Be Injurious To Tobacco Companies Health
description: LONDON, Aug. 12In the background are the blurred dials and switches of a walnut dashboard. Closer up, the tanned, confident hand of a man, a pilot perhaps, with two gold stripes on his cuff and a rugged steel watch. The hand grasps the floormounted gearshift and a newly lighted Rothman's kingsize cigarette.  when you know what you're doing, reads the text of the advertisement.

title: Market Place
description: Since midJanuary, investors have been able to buy a limited number of Treasury notes and bonds on the PBW and American Stock Exchanges. These are pilot programs that could open the door to widespread individual ownership of all government securities. Until recently the bulk of trading in government securities has been for institutions dealing in the overthecounter market, with a limited amount of dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cardin for the Younger Set
description: Some kids kept waving to the photographers; a couple of them burst into tears. One child scratched her mosquito bites. The boys kept threatening to lose their roomy pants, and the babies tried to toddle into the pool at the Four Seasons restaurant yesterday morning. But they looked mighty cute in the Pierre Cardin clothes, and the store buyers were enchanted.

title: Remember Me to Herald Square
description: I'm packing tonight. I just cleaned out another closet. There wasn't a hell of a lot in it. After all, ten years in apartments and you learn to pitchandthrow every three months or so.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Hugh Carey, who has five daughters among his 12 children, indicated yesterday that he differed with Betty Ford, who said on a Sunday television program that she would not be surprised if her daughter, Susan, announced she was havirtg an affair.

title: The Night Watchman Gets New Image as Alert Guard
description: There are things you watch for in the business and Captain Reid knew something didn't look right.

title: Wrestling Coach Resigns
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 12 (AP)Don Corrigan resigned today as wrestling coach at Purdue University. His assistant. Mark Sothman, was named to succeed him.

title: B'NAI B'RITH SAYS U.S. AIDS ARAB BOYCOTT
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith made public yesterday a complaint to Secretary of Commerce Rogers C. B. Morton charging his department with cooperating and assisting the Arab boycott of Israel although it warned American businesses that they must report demands for boycott com ???

title: MAYOR CUTS BOND FOR PARK FIESTA
description: Mayor Beame, overruling the decision of his Parks administrator, yesterday ordered that the Puerto Rican Fiesta Committee receive permission to hold a festival in Central Park in exchange for posting a $5,000 bond to cover the cost of cleanup.

title: Pinhas Sapir, 68, of Israel, ExCabinet Minister, Dies
description: Pinhas Sapir, a founder of the State of Israel and its Finance Minister for many years, died yesterday, apparently of heart attack, in Beersheba, Israel. He was stricken on a visit to Moshav Nevatim, a cooperative settlement, in the Negev. He was 68 years old and had been out of public office since May, 1974.

title: Red Smith
description: Baseball's latest dip into the roily waters of collective bargaining is a month or two old, and so far the owners have given no useful answers to any of the proposals put forward by the players. That is, the men who own baseball have not said yes, no, or we'll see. However, another negotiating session comes up the day after tomorrow and perhaps they will say something then.

description: LISBON, Aug. 12Military officers today petitioned Piesident Francisco da Costa Gomes to end what the officers view as efforts by Premier Vasco Gongalves to turn Portugal into a Communist state on Eastern European lines.

title: Blue Ribbon Restaurant in Times Square Shuts Doors
description: The Blue Ribbon restaurant, a Times Square landmark mark for six decades and onetime gathering spot of operatic greats, has served its last Wiener schnitzel.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LIGHT AND AIRY Since summer calls for cooler garb, two local restaurants have adopted a policy of bringing sports clothes and sports appointments to patrons as a midtown diversion.

title: Passion Play to Blame Lucifer, Notthe Jews
description: BONN, Aug 12The elders of Oberammergau have decreed that the next version of the town's famous Passion Play will not use a sharply criticized text that blames the Jews for the death of Jesus.

title: 2 Major Cambodian Communists Named Deputy Cabinet Ministers
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Aug. 13 (Reuters)The Cambodian Government radio today announced the appointment of two Deputy Ministers, one of them a proFlanoi hardliner, to key positions in the Government.

title: For Simon It's California Suite Now
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12He is, maybe, the quintessential New Yorkerurbane, witty, a poor son of the Bronx who conquered Broadway, a man with more sensitivity than perhaps anybody else to what constituted the character of New York and New Yorkers. He is, definitely, not an OutofTowner.you don't walk to get any place, you have to get into a car and drive. The only thing you can do is read the license plates, and I found that fairly interesting.

title: Seaver Wins, 94, For 16th
description: The baseball game at Shea Stadium last night sometimes resembled the theater of the absurdor a throwback to Met games of another era. But amid the strange doings, Tom Seaver won his 16th game and the Mets picked up a notch on the Pittsburgh Pirates and now trail the National League Eastern Division leaders by 6 games.

title: Dollar's Rise Ends As Pound Advances After Long Losses
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 12 (UPI)The dollar lost ground on some major world money markets today after four straight days of advances, but continued to fare well on others.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: To the agonies of unemployment, add a new variation, circa 1975 the municipal employe, fired for budgetary reasons, who sees a federally funded employe hired for his or her job.

title: 8 FORMER AIDES OF FRANKLIN BANK INDICTED BY U. S.
description: Eight former officials and employes of the Franklin National Bank and its parent company, the Franklin New York Corporation, have been indicted on Federal charges involving the loss of more than $30milion of the bank's money in unauthorized speculation in foreign currencies.

title: Giants Trade Reed for ExIrish Tackle; Jets Drop Baker and Get Steelers Back
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 12In an attempt to add depth and strength to their defensive line, the New York Giants traded Henry Reed, a veteran linebacker, to the Denver Broncos today for Greg Marx, a former tackle at Notre Dame, who studied law books instead of football playbooks last season.

title: CORRECTION BILL SIGNED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12Governor Carey today signed a bill restructuring the State Commission of Correction and nominated Herman Schwartz, a law professor and longtime advocate of prisoners rights, as the commission's first fulltime chairman.

title: Todd Wins Right to Name G.O.P. Finance Chairman
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12  The state Republican chairman, Webster B. Todd, won the right today in a test of strength to appoint a new chairman of the state Republican Finance Committee.

title: Week's Market Basket
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose 0.6 per cent last week, paced by a 5centsapound rise in the average price of pork chops to $2.18 and a 4cent increase in the price of bottom round roast to $2, the City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 12The allCalifornian Spingold team championship final ended here in the early hours of this morning, with San Francisco scoring an easy victory over Los Angeles.

title: Bronfman Kidnap Demand Of $4.5Million Reported
description: The kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d were reported to be demanding a $4.5million ransom and to have buried the 21yearold son of the head of the billiondollar Seagram Company, Ltd., with a 10day supply of air and water, according to lawenforcement officials.

description: No winners emerged from the exercise in gamesmanship that succeeded this week in keeping North and South Vietnam as well as South Korea out of membership in the United Nations.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Lottery Commission announced it would hold its second $1million Instant Lottery grand prize drawing on Aug. 21 at the Great Adventure amusement park Jackson Township. Holders of three million tickets turned in to the commission before July 30 are eligible for the top prize of $1,000 a week for life, with a minimum of $1million. There will be nine additional prizes totaling $130,000. Tickets turned in after July 30 will be eligible for a final grand prize drawing in the fall. The date has not been selected.

description: Isidore Waxman, a retired actor, died Monday at the Jewish Institute of Geriatric Care, 27111 76th Avenue, New Hyde Park, Queens. He was 87 and a resident of the institute.

title: Gamma Satellite Turned On
description: PARIS, Aug. 12 (Reuters)The European Space Agency reported today that it had successfully switched on its orbiting COSB satellite. The satellite, designed to study extra terrestial gamma radiation, was launched Saturday from Vandenberg Air Force Base, California.

title: 50% ARE PARDONED BY CLEMENCY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Presidential Clemency Board said today that it had granted about 6,000 unconditional pardons to persons who received punitive military discharges or were convicted of desertion or draft evasion in the Vietnam war era.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12rn Scottsdale, Ariz., they make burglary calls. In Atlanta they diagram crime scenes and photograph corpses. And here their voices crackle across the air waves ordering squad cars to city trouble spots.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)The Massachusetts House voted overwhelmingly today to cut welfare spending and drop thousands of recipients from the state welfare roles.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12In Scottsdale, Ariz., they make burglary calls. In Atlanta they diagram crime scenes and photograph corpses. And here their voices crackle across the air waves ordering squad cars to city trouble spots.

description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) The Industrial and Mining Development Bank of Iran is raising a $100million fiveyear Eurocurrency loan, the Iran Overseas Investment Bank, Ltd. said here today.

title: Norton Simon Raises Its Sales and Earnings to Record
description: Norton Simon, Inc., announced yesterday record sales and earnings for the quarter and fiscal year ended June 30 and an increased quarterly dividend.

title: Mile Runin 3:49.4
description: John Walker of New Zealand became the first man to run the mile in less than 3 minutes 50 seconds. His time was 3:49.4 at an international track meet in Goteborg, Sweden. Page 39.

description: The U.S. Industrial Chemicals Company announced yesterday price increases ranging from 5 per cent to 12 per cent for all low, mediumand highdensity polyethylene resins, powdered polyolefins and ethylenevinyl acetate copolymer resins. The increases are effective Sept. 1.

description: THE SHOESHINE PARLOR by James Lee; performed by the New York Shakespeare Fesival Mobile Theater, Joseph Pace. Producer; at Qurenshridge Park, Vernon Boulevard at 41st Avenue, 8.

description: Herman Blank, a former New Jersey Assemblyman, died Monday at Martland Medical Center, Newark, N. J. He was 68 years old and lived in East Orange, N. J.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The United States reported to Israel tonight the latest Egyptian views on the differences, still holding up a new Egyptian Israeli agreement in Sinai.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)The Rev. Leo J. McDonough, former chaplain at Boston College, died here yesterday. He was 52 years old.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Charter 3 P.M.

title: The Dance U.S. Terpsichore Troupe
description: It is difficult to know the precise level at which a company calling itself U. S. Terpsichore should be evaluated. This troup of some 34 dancers opened a week's season at the small yet attractive Marymount Manhattan Theater, a seemingly useful modern facility at Marymount Manhattan College, 221 East 71st Street.

title: Bronfmans Are New in Secluded Area
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 12The Bronfmans are newcomers here, but the seclusion they were seeking even before the kidnaping of Samuel Bronfman 2d is as old. as, this northern Westchester community.

title: Bergdorf Executive Fined $25,000 in Fixing of Prices
description: Leonard J. Hankin, the executive vice president of Bergdorf Goodman Inc., was fined $25,000 yesterday, completing a criminal pricefixing case involving three of the city's most fashionable stores.

description: TRENTON, Aug. 12  New Jersey's Commuter Operating Agency today proposed railfare increases of up to 70 per cent and busfare increases of up to 100 per cent on statesubsidized intrastate lines.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare will gather in Cleveland tomorrow to plan steppedup enforcement of school desegregation in Northern districts.

title: COAST BOARD BACKS SIRHAN CASE REVIEW
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI)  The County Board of Supervisors formally instructed its agencies today to support reopening the investigation into the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy to determine whether Sirhari B. Sirhan acted alone or whether there was a second gun.

title: Mile Run in 3:49.4
description: John Walker of New Zealand became the first man to run the mile in less than 3 minutes 50 seconds. His time was 3:49.4 at an international track meet in Goteborg, Sweden. Page 39.

description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 12State Supreme Court Justice Morris Pashman stayed at least temporarily today an appeals court decision ordering the opening of a sealed 500page deposition given by George Katz, a contractor, in a civil suit involving a garbage removal contract in Jersey City.

title: Phony Beach Badgei. Just Don't Hold Water
description: MARGATE, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP)  The police in this shore community are hot en the trail of someone who bas been manufacturing counter, feit beach badges.

title: Steingut Calls Rise In Fare Exorbitant And a Peril to City
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut accused the Federal Government yesterday of turning its back on the city's transit problems and then recommended a regional approach in finding new revenue to help stabilize the fare in the future.

description: ALBANY, Aug. 12Governor Carey today signed a bill restructuring the State Commission of Correction and nominated Herman Schwartz, a law, professor and longtime advocate of prisoners rights, as the commission's first fulltime chairman.

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: F.H.A. and V.A. Loans Show InterestRate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Mortgage interest rates on loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Adiministration and the Veterans Administration continued to climb in June, the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported today.

title: Olympians Reject $9.3Million TV Bid
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP) The organizing committee for the 1976 Olympics has rejected an offer of $9.3million from five broadcasting unions outside Canada and the United States for television rights to the Games.

title: Immunity to Law?
description: Congress has just passed a law establishing tighter rules than ever before to prevent abuse of fiduciary responsibility by the labormanagement trustees of all pension funds. The degree to which that law can eradicate the flagrant malpractices in the Central States fund will be a crucial test of its effectiveness.

title: Los Angeles Power Line Is Closed Because of Fire
description: SUNLAND, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI)Power officials closed 500,000volt line that carries power from the Hoover Dam to Los Angeles today as a brush fire raced toward the line. A Long Beach generating plant was used to provide power to Los Angeles.

title: ALASKA DOCTORS REFUSE PATIENTS
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 12Women considering pregnancy here are thinking twice about it these days. The state's malpractice dilemma has forced many of the city's obstetrician gynecologists into the growing list of doctors refusing to see new patients until insurance coverage that they regard as adequate is available.

title: DR. WARD D. O'SULLIVAN
description: HIGHLAND LAKES, N.J., Aug, 11 (AP) Dr. Ward D O'Sullivan, chairman of the surgery department at Mercy Catholic Medical Center, Philadelphia, died today at his summer home here. He was 58 years old and lived in Rose. mont, Pa.

title: AfghanPakistani Trouble Brewing Again Near the Khyber Pass
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan Aug. 8Local headmen near the Khyber Pass have voiced anger. Arms caches are being unearthed with ominous frequency. There are charges of outside meddling among the border tribes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SARXTOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12LeRoy Jolley, trainer of Foolish Pleasure, confirmed today that John L. Greer's 3yearold colt would stand as a syndicated stallion at Greentree Farm in Lexington, Ky. That's the only part of the deal that has been completed, Jolley said. The contracts for the syndication haven't been printed yet. It will be some time before they're signed.

title: President Will Ask Changes in Rules For Truck Industry
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP)President Ford soon will send Congress proposed legislation that would work major chan ges in the regulation of the, trucking industry, Harold R. Taylor Jr., Deputy United States Attorney General said today.

title: Royals 2Run 10th Stops Orioles, 42
description: The Baltimore Orioles, who had won 22 of 29 games since the AllStar break in midJuly, lost to Kansas City last night, but it took the Royals 10 innings to accomplish the feat. The final score at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium was 42.

title: Broniman Kidnap Demand Of $4.5Million Reported

title: A.B.A. FIGHTS CURB ON VOTING OUTLAY
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 12The American Bar Association approved today a resolution calling for legislation what would ban any statutory limitations on campaign expenditures.

title: Members of Congress Warn Soviet on New Strains
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12A visiting Congressional delegation. wound up talks with Soviet legislators today, with at least one member warning that lack of movement on issues like emigration might put new strains on SovietAmerican accommodation.

title: Cynthia Hill Eliminated In U. S. Golf
description: NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP)Marilyn Palmer, a seventhgrade teacher in western Canada, scored a stunning upset with a 5and victory over the defending champion, Cynthia Hill, today in the second round of the 75th women's United States Amateur golf championship.

title: New Lulus Queried by Levitt, Who Asks Lefkowitz's Opinion
description: The thousands of extra dollars that New York State legislators voted to pay themselves on the last day of their session will be held back because of questions raised about their constitutionality.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: Semifinal Round  Robert Cloughen, RidgeNand, defeated Ernest Tompkins, Knollwood, 3 and 1; Peter Adams, C.C. Darien, defeated Guy Kennen, Brookfield (Conn.) High School, 7 and 5.

title: Neville Lost to Patriots
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP)The New England Patriots of the National Football League lost Tom Neville, an offensive tackle, for the season today when he suffered a broken left leg during a routine practice drill.

title: Levi Plans to Curb F.B.I. On Domestic Operations
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 13Attorney General Edward H. Levi disclosed today Justice Department proposals to curtail the Federal Bureau of Investigation's domestic intelligence operations. The proposals include a ban against using informers to instigate crimes; a requirement that the Attorney General report periodically to Congress on preventive action plans that he authorized the F.B.I. to conduct, and the limiting of intelligence gathering to those situations where the activities to be investigated may involve unlawful force or violence.

title: Sundance, Mare, Wins U.S. Final
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 13 Sundance, a 6yearold Palomino mare, scored 754 points and won the national final in the American Horse Shows Association large pony competition today.

title: "The Land That Time Forgot' Shows Bright Splashes
description: "If I'm not mistaken," the German captain says as his submarine floats in the mysteriously tropical Antarctic bay, "that's a diplodocus."Susan Penhaligon has been hard at work turning out moues of fear, hope, horror and resoluteness. Now she squeezes and produces an expression of scientific skepticism."A diplodocus?" she says. Of course it's a diplodocus. Those were pterodactyls just now, and soon the place will be thick with tyrannosaurs and stegosaurs and other specimens from American International Pictures' carpentry shop."The Land That Time Forgot," a screen adaptation of a story by Edgar Rice Burroughs at neighborhood theaters is an initially agreeable picture about the discovery of a mystery realm where various stages of evolution coexist. Dinosaurs and cavemen. Ancient plant forms and more modern ones.A German U-boat sinks a British transport ship during World War I. A boatload of survivors, including an American submarine expert played by Doug McClure, Miss Penhaligon as a biologist, and several British seamen, manages to seize the submarine when it surfaces and overpowers the crew. Later the crew, led by their gentlemanly Captain Von Schoenvorts (John McEnery), overpowers the overpowerers. Still later they are overpowered back again.Amid all the confusion the U-boat drifts south and finds shelter in an undiscovered Antaractic island left warm by volcanoes. Friends, by now, the submarine's occupants settle down to repair the vessel, fight off dinosaurs and explore the island. Erupting volcanoes and natives eventually destroy them, leaving Mr. McClure and Miss Penhaligon as the only survivors. They are last seen, dressed in yak suits, climbing the snowy north slopes of the island, determined, as Mr. McClure puts it, "to move forward into the greater mysteries." Just as the much grander "Jaws" became less scary the moment its mechanical shark appeared, the early virtues of "Land" collapse once the island is reached and the traffic jam in artificial monsters develops.There had been some good moments in the submarine, chiefly because of the sympathetic performance of Mr. McEnery as the neurotic but courtly captain. Possibly you have wondered how German U-boat commanders managed to sink all those ships when the visors on their caps were so very stiff, making it hard to look through the periscopes. The picture explains: each time the periscope goes up Mr. McEnery twists his cap around to the back. When it goes down he replaces it. There is something engaging about a movie that teaches."Land" answers another question, perhaps not conclusively. What does a tyrannosaurus say when he is gored by a triceratops?"Ow!"

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13  Secretary General Waldheim announced today that he would ask the forthcoming General Assembly to approve a $737million budget for the next two years, 21.6 per cent above the twoyear $606million budget for 1974 and 1975.

As it is, Miss Brown, who is appearing at the Ballroom on West Broadway just below Houston Street, has an attractive and effective voice, particularly in the lower register. And when she is not wrapped up n facial and vocal mannerisms, she has a warm, easy, conunitnicative personality.

I think it's a bit too early to announce, but my present plans are indeed to run acain, said the Sixth District Representative, who defeated Representative Wiley Mayne in the last election.

The city also honored two men and four women who have aided women's sports: Fred Thompson, coach of the Atoms Track Club and meet director of the Colgate Women's Games; Eleanor Riger, an ABCTV sports producer: Phyllis George, CBS sports commentator and a former Miss America; Donna deVarona, Olympic gold medal swimmer and ABC sports commentator, and Lucille Kyvallos, coach of the Queens College women's basketball team. Foster, chairman and chief executive officer of ColgatePalmolive, for that company's support of women's sports.

Whether or not the President appeals to the Supreme Court, oil controls will expire Aug. 31 if Mr. Ford makes good his threat veto Congress's bill extending the Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act, with its authority for continued control.

In 1790, there were only thirteen Federal judges in addition to the six Supreme Court Justices; today, there are over 500 Federal judges and nine Justices.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A group of radical but antiCommunist officers in Portugal called for a political system based on organizations such as neighborhood and worker associations but excluding political elections as an aspect of middleclass democracy. This group of officers, who are commanded by Gen. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, a triumvirate member and military security chief, is the third struggling for predominance. The others are the supporters of proletarian control under Communist leadership, backed by Premier Vasco Goncalves, and the gradualists seeking a transition, supported by free political parties, to democratic socialism. AkiiBua was timed in 49.4 seconds, twotenths of a second ahead of Bolding but well off his world standard of 47.8.

description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 13Closing arguments in the Joan Little murder trial began today. Earlier, a prosecution attorney predicted that, because of the composition of the jury, the best the state could reasonable hope for would be a hung jury.

title: Bethlehem Steel Lists Increase in Prices
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel maker, announced yesterday product price changes that would lift the company's overall price average by just under 4 per cent. The National Steel Company, fourth largest, also announced similar changes.

title: If You Decide to Have Your Own Greenhouse
description: Fresh peas for Thanksgiving dinner, leaf lettuce in January and carnations to cut in Marchthese are real possibilities with a greenhouse.

title: Mao Bid to Nixon Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon has told friends that Chairman Mao TseTung has invited him to visit China, Jack Anderson, the columnist, said today. Mr. Anderson wrote that Mr. Nixon had not accepted the invitation because he was buiy writing his memoirs.

title: CRISIS ON WELFARE PERSISTS IN ORANGE
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 13Orange County's welfare crisis remained unresolved today and County Executive Louis V. Mills said he would renew efforts for Congressional legislation for special Federal revenuesharing funds for welfare.

title: Rhodesian Parley: Tiny Step on a Long, Rocky Road
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 13The announcement yesterday that the white and black leaders of Rhodesia would at last meet to discuss a new future for the racially divided country was a cause for at least some optimism. But the chances that they will actually reach a mutually satisfactory agreement are not very good.

title: MRS. ALEXANDER HAWES
description: Elizabeth Armstrong Hawes died yesterday at her summer home in Little Compton, R.I. She was 68 years old.

title: Volunteers Fill Gap In Cleanup Effort Around the City
description: This town here is a real oldfashioned town, said Pat Racana, a resident of College Point, Queens, as he watched 75 youngsters from the Neighborhood Youth Corps working yesterday with rakes, shovels and axes to clean up the College Point Sports Complex, 124acre field.

title: LISBON OFFICERS OFFER NEW PLAN
description: LISBON, Aug. 13A group of radical but antiCommunist officers today called for the establishment of a political system here based on such organizations as neighborhood and worker associations.

title: Ailey Displays Some Gems of Dance
description: Dance nowadays seems to be an inexhaustible New York resource. No sooner has American Ballet Theater vacated the New York State Theater than the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater comes in. In fact, Ballet Theater vacated last Saturday.

title: Ladies Home Journal Cuts Rates
description: The Ladies Home Journal announced yesterday a reduction in its guaranteed circulation, page rate and cost per thousand, effective with the January, 1976, issue. We're returning to the era of the reader, said Louis E. Porterfield, publisher, adding that 56 per cent of the magazine's revenue is now derived from circulation.

title: Aug. 110 Car Sales Off
description: The American auto industry has reported Aug. 110 sales of 131,218 new cars, off 28.9 per cent from a year ago and a sharper decline than had been expected by analysts. Page 42.

title: GRAINTRADER DENIES ROLE IN VIOLATIONS
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 13(AP)Cook Industries, Inc., one of the tion's leading grain traders, said today that some of its employes might have violated Federal laws involving the grading and storage of grain.

title: FORD APPEAL SEEN ON OIL FEE RULING
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 13President Ford will probably ask the Supreme Court to reverse an appellate judgment that his $2abarrel oil import fee is an illegal tariff, the White House said today.

title: Youths in Queens Get Exhibition of Basketball Skills
description: I can't teach them how to play the gamethey know how to do that, said Greg Jackson, a guard for the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association. But maybe I can tell them about some other things like school and hygiene they'll need to know.

title: Bomb Kills 3, Harts 26 At a Tavern in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 13, (Reuters)At least three people were killed here tonight and 26 wounded when a bomb was thrown into a tavern in one of the city's Protntant districts.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP)Walter Scott, reportedly a key figure in the hunt for Patricia Hearst, said tonight that his brother Jack had offered to deliver the missing newspaper heiress to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in return for $100,000 and a grant of immunity from prosecution.

Y., Aug. 13 Mrs. Kenneth Springer of Ridgeway posted a 40, 3676 over the 5,856yard, par 37, 3774 Sunningdale Country Club today for a 36hole score of 79, 76155 and a onestroke lead in the Women's TriCounty Golf Association's Wheeler Memorial tournament for the women's one championship of Westchester, Fairfield and Putnam Counties.

title: Greenhouse Gardening: A FastGrowing Hobby Not Just for the Rich
description: For nine years Charles Bauerlein of Allendale, N.J., toiled in vain, trying to get a passion flower vine to yield one blossom. Under the best of conditions, it is a singular event, for the flower opens for less than 24 hours and then falls off. So, it's an occasion that you take movies of, Mr. Bauerlein said the other day.

description: After generations during which going to college was assumed to be a sure route to the better life, collegeeducated Americans are losing their economic advantage over those less educated and the value of college as a guarantee of upward social mobility is slipping.

description: I think I was honest, said Betty Ford when asked yesterday if she had regrets about saying she wouldn't be surprised if her 18yearold daughter, Susan, told her she was having an affair.

title: WILSON ASSAILED BY MRS. THATCHER
description: LONDON, Aug. 13Margaret Thatcher's biggest single frustration is that she cannot order up a national election tomorrow.

title: We Band of Brothers
description: Brotherhood will reach a milestone sometime in the next few days when Jesus Alou gets into the lineup for the New York Mets and gives the three Alou brothers of the Dominican Republic a combined total of 5,000 games in the major leagues.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: WalMart Stores, Inc., said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed secondary offering of 180,000 common shares.

description: Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, who replied Nuts! to a German ultimatum to surrender Bastogne in the Battle of the Bulge, died in Washington. He was 77. Page 34.

title: Beach Community Relents in Charge Of Nudity at Age 3
description: SEASIDE PARK, Aug. 13 (UPI)Seaside Park officials decided today to ask for the dismissal of charges involving public nudity by Jessica Santos, 3 years old, of Toms River, who was spotted walking nude near the boardwalk here last month.

title: Take the Children to a Wildlife Refuge
description: Some of the wildest wildlife this side of the Everglades is within two hours ride from the city, in New Jersey at a couple of national wildlife refuges. If your children have reached the stage where they whisper in the presence of wild animalspartly out of fear of scaring them away and partly out of reverencethe refuges are naturals for a summertime outing.

title: Push and Shove Comes to Anchorage
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 12 There's nothing quite like driving around for half an hour or so looking for a parking space in downtown Anchorage to make a resident or a visitor come abruptly to terms with what has happened in the last few years to this sprawling city on the quiet waters of Cook Inlet.

title: Humane Diplomat
description: When Stephen Smith was freed unharmed recentlythe last of four American students to be released by the socalled Popular Revolutionary party which had kidnapped them from an animal research station in Zairea 67day ordeal came to an end. None of those who had incurred risks to save the students expected public acclaim. But surely, amid the general rejoicing, none imagined that anybody who had worked to effect the liberation of the young hostages might possibly be penalized for such efforts. Yet, this is precisely what may happening to W. Beverly Carter, the American Ambassador to Tanzania, one of the rescue operation's unsung heroes.

title: Attempt on Cuban Envoy
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13, (Reuters)  Ambassador Emilio Aragones Navarro of Cuba survived an assassination attempt here today, an embassy spokesman said. His car was machinegunned from another moving vehicle.

title: THEATERS OPPOSE NEW EQUITY CODE
description: A meeting to discuss objections by Off Off Broadway producers to a new code for showcase productions, issued Aug. 4 by the Actors Equity Association, broke down yesterday when a committee representing 49 theaters walked out of the offices of Donald Grody, executive secretary of Equity.

title: Screen: Detective Yarn:Mitchum Is Marlowe in New Version of Chandler's 'Farewell My Lovely'
description: Around the beginning of the nineteen-forties when Raymond Chandler wrote his thriller "Farewell My Lovely," Leopold Stokowski decided that Bach was too spare for contemporary ears and made a series of lush, big-sound transcriptions with the Philadelphia Orchestra.Lush Bach is long out of fashion, but old movies are still getting the big-sound treatment. A new film version of "Farewell," directed by Dick Richards, opened yesterday at Loew's State I and Tower East. It has been touched up with a little contemporary sex and violence and more than a little contemporary cinematic self-indulgence.It's as if someone had put pillow springs, power-steering and a tape deck into a classic racing-car. It is still handsome and it still goes, but it is a handsome mediocrity.Mr. Richards has been less ambitious than Robert Altman, who two years ago translated another Chandler work, "The Long Goodbye," into personages and a setting totally of the seventies. "Farewell" is kept back in the forties; it is just that certain present-day movie mannerisms have been talked on. When Marlowe, the detectiveplayed by Robert Mitchumerupts into a brothel, the whores earn the picture its R rating by appearing naked. In the picture's most repugnant scene Mr. Mitchum is allowed to deal the fat old womanadmittedly, a villainessa crunching and bloody blow in the face.The camera can linger endlessly on yellow and brown interiors, on neon lights, on the technicolored dilapidation of back-alley Los Angeles. It is a movie interlarded with photography; about 15 excess minutes' worth.Chandler plots can be confusing in the movies: people still argue about just what happened at the end of Howard Hawks's version of "The Big Sleep." "Farewell" deals with the efforts of Marlowe to track down a mysterious Velda, the lost love of a great, hulking ex-con who wants her back even though she hasn't written him all the years he was in jail.Marlowe's search, which cuts across a swath of metropolitan corruption, is attended by elusive clues, red herringsblood-red, usuallyand a great many corpses. So much is unresolved along the way that the few violent minutes of elucidation at the end produce some confusion. If you are a critic you can refer to a synopsis. If you are a member of the audience you may have to read the book, or perhaps pay to sit through another showing.The strengths of this movie are in Mr. Chandler and in the high quality of a lot of the acting. The author's lines, tough, funny and baroque, get full value. As in a 1945 version of the same book, with Dick Powell, there are substantial sections in which the narrator simply reads Mr. Chandlerin this case, with the camera wandering as he does it.There are lines that stand out. When the ex-con, a virtual giant played with brutality and vulnerable charm by Jack O'Halloran, is asked what Velda is like, he replies:"Cute. Cute as lace pants." His lips and neck quiver with the effort and triumph of finding a verbal equivalent for the delicate memory that torments his great bulk.As a drunken widow, Silvia Miles plays a role that seems an overdone clich until you realize that she is doing it with such subtlety that her lost beauty keeps flickering back. John Ireland, another fine and subtle actor, improves on his stock part as a cynical, tired and honest detective.Robert Mitchum always takes getting to know in a role. He comes on too strongly at first: too stagey, too droopy an eye, an excessively dangling cigarette. But he settles into his part, his performance drops away and he moves through the picture with force, humor and unexpected humility. Inevitably you think of Bogart: he isn't Bogart but he is very good.With Charlotte Rampling, long-haired and slinky, you think of Lauren Bacall: the imitation is both painfully intentional and painfully bad. Presumably the director noticed it; probably he ordered it. He should have stopped it. Miss Rampling has had some bad roles but she is beautiful and expressive and should have been allowed a more congenial way to play her part.

title: I.T.T. PROFIT FELL 31%1N 2D QUARTER
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 31 per cent in secondquarter net income and 17 per cent in the first half, reflecting lower results for its insurance, Grinnel and Rayonier operations as well as European automotive and consumer products.

description: LEE Mass., Aug. 13Tenatity has to be the first requirement of anyone trying to establish a new dance company.

title: On Exporting Morality
description: WASHINGTONAn American aircraft manufacturer has just asserted in a forthright way that it paid at least $30 million over the past five years to foreign politicians.

title: More City Layoffs Loom In Drive Against Spending
description: Faced with the prospect of continued inflation in the cost of materials and services purchased by the city, Beame administration officials concede that further reductions in the municipal work force will be needed to prevent exceeding the promised 2 per cent limit on budget increases.

title: CLAUDE F. HOULBREQUE
description: Claude F. Houlbreque, who had been a senior officer and film director in the publicinformation division of the United Nations from 1946 until his retirement in 1973, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived in East Marion, L.I.

title: MARK B. SLATER
description: Mark B. Slater, newsstand sales manager for Time Inc. publications and later, for Time magazine, died of cancer Tuesday evening in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 64 years old and lived at 11 Normandy Road. Bronxville.

title: Burlington Raising Wages
description: Burlington Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that its manufacturing divisions will raise wages by an unspecified amount within the next month. Burlington's move follows similar announcements of Cannon Mills, Springs Mills Avondale Mills, Granite Mills and United Merchants and Manufacturers.

title: Personal Finance: Credit Card Holders Get Break
description: A change in the Federal law governing credit billing has given the consumer some help when he makes a credit card purchase of an item that goes bad, and the seller can not agree on a settlement.

title: Scorecard Disqualifies Met. P.G.A. CoLeader
description: JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 13Bill Collins of Brae Burn, the 1956 titleholder, held on to the lead in the annual $25,000 Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today on a technicality.

title: Data on 1953 Drug Death Omit Role of Army in Tests
description: The acting chief medical examiner of Manhattan said yesterday that the city's records on the death of Harold Blauer, who died in an Armysponsored experiffient with hallucinogenic drugs at the New York State Psychiatric Institute 22 years ago, made no mention of the fact that. Mr. Blauer had been involved in an experiment or that the Army had in any way been involved.

description: New York 3, Oakland 1. California 8, Boston 3. Chicago 4, Cleveland 3 (12 inn.).

Nixon's papers under subpoenas issued by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, Ford Administration sources said today.

title: Clashes in Ohio
description: ELYRIA, Ohio (AP)Scores of youths smashed windows and harrassed firemen fighting blazes in downtown Elyria tonight in the second night of violence stemming from a police shooting, the authorities said.

title: 10,000 in Saxony Continue To Fight Spreading Blazes
description: HANOVER West Germany Aug. 13 (Reuters)More than 10,000 men many already exhausted continued for the sixth day today to fight a spreading series of woodland fires in northern Germany. No rain was forecast.

title: Many Indictments Likely In L.I. Park Board Inquiry
description: MINEOLA, LI., Aug. 13A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is expected to return many indictments soon as a result of investigations of allegations of !corruption in the awarding of contracts by the Long Island State Park Commission, an official of the commission said today.

title: M.A.C. DEFERS END OF ITS BOND SALE TO WIN CUSTOMERS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, disappointed that $125million of its $275million August bond issue remains unsold, yesterday deferred until tomorrow the closing of the offering to give salesmen more time to scour the country for customers.

title: Under New Rules, What Was a Farm May No Longer Be
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)  Government statisticians have devised a new definition of a farm that may remove about half a million small farms from Federal records.

title: Films
description: HALL OF FAME FOR GREAT AMERICANS, presents American history through 95 bronze busts of famous inventors, authors, statesmen, artists, actors, musicians, explorers, educators and others, at a Revolutionary War site, Hall of Fame Terrare and Sedgwick Avenue, oft Major Deegan Highway, at West 179th Street. Free. Often 10 A.M to 5 P.M. daily. 5334450, extension 297.

title: Bongo Antelope Born in Zoo
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 13 (UPI)  A bongo antelope, one of to rarest animals in captivity, was born yesterday at the Milwaakee County Zoo and was reported to be in good condition. The zoo director, George Speidel, said that only about four other zoos in the country had bongos, which come from dense bamboo forests in Africa.

title: JOB AID IS URGED FOR WARREFUGEES
description: James R. Dumpson, the city's Human Resources Administrator, called on the Federal Government yesterday to set up special job and education programs for Vietnam refugees rather than have them rely on existing programs and voluntary efforts on their behalf.Mr. Dtunpsonts remarks came at a conference of local voluntary and public agencies called to discuss problems and procedures in resettling Vietnamese refugees in the New York area.

title: Mario DeStefano Dies; Reputed Loan Racketeer
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) Mario DeStefano, reputed loan racketeer whose two brothers were victims of ganglandstyle slayings, died yesterday of a heart ailment at PresbyterianSt. Luke's Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Two Irishmen Row Boat 1,800 Miles Around Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Two Irishmen have rowed 1,800 miles around Ireland in 45 days tin a frail 27foot currach, a canvascovered boat still used by Irish fishermen.

title: Urban Legislators Get a Farmers View of Jersey
description: DEERFIELD, Aug. 13The nation's oldest agricultural society gave some city slickers an education today with a farm tour of Cumberland County.

title: Thomas Mann's Papers Opened, Yielding Diaries
description: PARIS, Aug. 13  When Thomas Mann, one of this century's major writers, died near Zurich, Switzerland, in. 1955 he left four bulky packages wrapped in brown paper to be opened 20 years after his death.

title: Pound Moves Up; Dollar Shows Drop In Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS. Aug. 13 (UPI)The pound, buoyed by reports of the release tomorrow of optimistic British trade figures for July, rallied slightly on money markets today at the expense of the dollar and other currencies.

title: M.A.C. DEFERS END OF ITS BOND SALE TO WIN CUSTOMERS
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, disappointed that $125million of its $275million August bond issue remains unsold, yesterday deferred until tomorrow the closing of the offering to give salesmen more time to scour the country for customers.

title: U.S. Accuses Wilson Of Illegal Payoffs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) The Agriculture Department issued today an administrative complaint charging Wilson & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest meat packers, with commercial bribery, illegal rebates to customers and conversion of cooperative advertising funds to its own use.

title: Federal Welfare Head Resigns And Calls for Abolition of Job
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Federal welfare commis sioner, Robert B. Carleson, submitted his resignation today and recommended that his job be abolished as a symbolic gesture that welfare is a basic and primary responsibility of the states.

title: Levi Plans to Curb F.B.I. On Domestic Operations
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 13Attorney General Edward H. Levi disclosed today Justice Department proposals to curtail the Federal. Bureau of Investigation's domestic intelligence operations. The proposals include a ban against using informers to instigate crimes; a requirement that the Attorney General report periodically to Congress on preventive action plans that he authorized the F.B.I. to conduct, and the limiting of intelligence gathering to those situations where the activities to be investigated may involve unlawful force or violence.

title: 5Run Eighth Sinks Mets, 85
description: Savoring the promise of moving within 5 games of first place last night, the Mets found disappointment instead at Shea Stadium and went down to defeat before the San Dieeo Padres. 85.

title: Curtis Will Return $5,000 In Illegal Ashland Donation
description: GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Aug. 13 (UPI)A spokesman for Senator Carl Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, said today an illegal $5,000 contribution to his 1972 campaign committee would be returned to Ashland Oil, Inc.

title: Wigger Sets Mark In Title Rifle Shoot
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI)Army Maj. Lones Wigger of Carter, Mont., broke a national Rifle and Pistol championships record today in winning the smallbore prone championship. Wigger, a former Olympic star and veteran member of the United States Army marksmanship training unit, fired a 6,399, one point away from a perfect score. The previous record of 6,396 was set by David Ross in 1970.

title: F.T.C. Says Market Forces Caused Rise in Sugar Price
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission says the last year's 400 per cent rise in raw sugar prices resulted from natural market forces, but warned its study was not exhaustive.

title: DR. HORACE WOOD 2D
description: Dr. Horace E. Wood 2d, who retired as a Rutgers University biology professor in 1959, died yesterday at a Swainton, N. J., nursing home. He was 74 years old and lived in Cape May Court House. N.J.

title: Showdown in Lisbon?
description: A showdown appears at hand in the struggle of the democratic forces in Portugal to abort the imposition a Sovietstyle dictatorship ostensibly run by leftwing military officers but actually following a strategy dictated by the Communist party. Portugal's friends and allies will watch the denouement in Lisbon with anxiety but also with higher hopes for the survival of freedom than could have been justified even a few days ago.

title: Report Sees F.A.A. Laxity On Airport Safety Permits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) The General Accounting Office, an investigating agency of Congress, said yesterday that the Federal Aviation Administration had granted airports safety certificates without even inspecting them.

title: Catholics in Portugal Unite In Campaign Against Reds
description: LISBON, Aug. 13The Roman Catholic Church, initially intimidated and embarrassed by a revolution that it neither promoted nor foresaw, has 15 months later taken the offensive against it in terms suggesting almost a crusade.

title: BARTOK CONDUCTED BY BOULEZ IN PARK
description: As music director of the New York Philharmonic, Pierre Boulez has followed it out into the city parks more faithfully than anyone else. Tuesday night he led the orchestra in Central Park for the fourth time in as many summers. In turn, he had the faithful with him.

title: FREDERICK SCOPINICH
description: Frederick Scopinich Sr., a retired boat builder in Freeport, L. I., died Tuesday at his home in East Quogue, L. I. He was 84 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: A.B.A. Opposes News Curb in Proposed Federal Criminal Code
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 13The American Bar Association registered its opposition today to restrictions on news organizations in sections of the proposed Federal Criminal Code before Congress.

title: Abbott Pleads No Contest In Adulterated Drug Case
description: NEW BERN, N. C., Aug. 13 (AP)Abbott Laboratories has pleaded no contest to charges that it conspired to introduce adulterated and misbranded intravenous solutions into Interstate commerce.

title: NEW NIGERIAN HEAD BACKS GOWON PLAN
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 13Nigeria's new head of state, Brig. Muritala Rufai Mohammed, threw his full support behind the previous government's $45billion fiveyear development plan today, urging officials and citizens to carry out the program with courage and industry.

title: Old Thai Temple Collapses
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 13 (AP)The ancient Phra Thart Phunom temple in northeast Thailand, revered by millions of Thais and Laotians, collapsed Monday night after having been weakened by four days of rain, the Fine Arts Department reported today. The 174foothigh temple, said to be 2,285 years old, was situated in Nakorn Phanon Province bordering Laos.

title: Cash Prices
description: Wednesday, Aug. 13. 1975

title: Kissinger Sees Dinitz
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Secretary of State Kissinger met again with Ambassador Simcha. Dinitz of Israel today to discuss the Israelis request for clarifications of Egypt's latest views.

title: The Biggest Lovers of Smallness Are Making
description: RENSSELAERVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 13For a conference here this week on The Uses of Smallness, the Institute on Man and Science put out a welcome mat2 inches by 1 inches.

title: The 50Cent Fare
description: The 50cent subway and bus fare that will take effect here next month is a necessary evil, dictated by the city's fiscal plight, the soaring deficit of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the failure of public officials to develop adequate policies for the support mass transportation.

title: Concert: Miss Ran's Ensembles for 17
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13The idea that music is a selfcontained system, referring to nothing outside itself, is a seductive one for many composers. Music, in this spartan view, is aboutand only aboutthe interplay of sounds. There is something appealingly neat in this way of composing and listening to music that finds a response in our scienceoriented society. It is a fair generalization to say that the academic avant  garde in America has elevated this useful concept into an unchallengeable article of faith during the last 25 years or so.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The manager of the National Community Bank branch in Franklin paid $10,000 to an extortionist after receiving telephone threats against his family, the authorities said today. The Sussex County prosecutor's office said the man ager, Edward Remus, did not inform the police until after he had taken the money from the bank and placed it under a tin behind a tree near a pond here Tuesday.

title: Trotter Replaces Noe in N.Y.R.A. Post
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13Kenny Noe Jr. joined Yogi Berra and Bill Virdon in the ranks of the unemployed today. With the same dispatch used on the baseball managers, New York's racing establishment deposed its racing secretary and returned Tommy Trotter to that job.

title: Beaux Arts Group Plays Mostly Mozart
description: Avery Fisher Hall is the kind of place that daunts all but the most impressive chambermusic players. But the Beaux Arts Trio, which was making its debut atthe mostly Mozart Festival on Tuesday night, is certainly an impressive aggregation, and the result was a superb (if inevitably somewhat anemicsounding) night of music.

title: U.S.I.A. Is Withdrawing Its India Correspondent
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)The United States Information Agency said yesterday that it was withdrawing the Voice of America correspondent from India because of the New Delhi Government's insistence that the reporter accept rigid conditions of censorship.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A group of radical but antiCommunist officers in Portugal called for a political system based on organizations such as neighborhood and worker associations but excluding political elections as an aspect of middleclass democracy. This group of officers, who are commanded by Gen. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, a triumvirate member and military security chief, is the third struggling for predominance. The others are the supporters of proletarian control under Communist leadership, backed by Premier Vasco Goncalves, and the gradualists seeking aktransition, supported by free political parties, to democratic socialism. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: 4,000 Refugees Cross Border
description: OSHAKATI, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 13 (Agemce FrancePresse)South African authorities here took emergency measures today to cope with 4,000 refugees who have flooded in over the last 24 hours to escape the Angolan civil war.

title: Bastogne Hero Dies
description: Gen. Anthony. C. McAuliffe, who replied Nuts! to a German ultimatum to surrender Bastogne in the Battle of the Bulge, died in Washington. He was 77. Page 34.

title: GENERAL MOTORS RAISES 76 PRICES OF CARS BY 4.4%
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13The General Motors Corporation said today it was raising prices on its 1976model cars by an average of $206, or 4.4 per cent, a smaller increase than had been forecast by industry analysts.

title: Golf Officials Are Questioned on Rules
description: Golf purists claim that most hackers cheat at some time during the majority of their rounds. This may be a rather harsh judgment since most golfers may only be guilty of not knowing the rules. After all, if officials who referee tournament matches do not know the exact letter of the golf law, it is difficult to accuse average players of cheating.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The current events in India were preordained by the dramatic increase in oil prices by the OPEC cartel. Mrs. Gandhi was forced to take action to protect the institutions of democracy in India. Further hesitation by any Indian Government would have resulted in a massive deterioration of all democratic forums in that country.

title: Vast Amazon Road Project Is Bogged Down
description: CRUZEIRO'DO SUL, BrazilThis is the end of the road, the last deadend stretch of highway in this nation's mad, heroic attempt to explore and conquer the vast world of equatorial jungle and river called Amazonia.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 28.9% AUG. 1 TO 10
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13 The United States auto industry reported 131,218 newcar sales in the Aug. 110 period, off 28.9 per cent from a year ago and a sharper decline than had been expected by analysts.

title: People and Business
description: Sir Frank McFadzean has been named to succeed Sir David Nicolson as chairman of the staterun British Airways. The changeover will take place on Jan. 1, when Sir David will resign to devote more time to his interests in the private sector. He has served as chairman since 1972 when British Airways was established in the merger of the staterun British Overseas Airways Corporation and British European Airways.

title: Bridge
description: Ubiquity would be a useful property for some bridge players. The truth of this statement is illustrated by the sad story of Bill Sides of Van Nuys, Calif., who was trying to be in Miami Beach, Fla., and New York City simultaneously last Monday and could not quite manage it.

title: Nastase Is Net Victor In Toronto
description: TORONTO, Aug. 13 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania strode to center court at the raindelayed, $130,000 Canadian open tennis championships just as the sun emerged today and beat Steve Krulevitz of Baltimore, 64, 75.

title: Charter Co. Is Planning Merger For Its Bartell and Downe Units
description: Raymond K. Mason, chairman of the Charter Company, said yesterday that two of Charter's subsidiaries, the Bartell Media Company and Downe Communications, Inc., would be merged into third unnamed company, which can utilize the $35million tax loss carry forward of Bartell and Downe.

title: 3 Cars Jam the Southern State; Parkway Police Sue in Dispute
description: MINEOLA, L.L. Aug. 13Traffic on the Southern State Parkway was tied up for a halfhour this morning when three motorists, thought to be offduty members of the Long Island State Parkway Police, presented $100 bills at three toll booths at the Valley Stream Plaza and refused to move until they received change.

title: The Quiet Potomac
description: In midAugust, Washington gasps in the summer sun and even the Potomac loiters slowly to the sea. President Ford is out in the mountains of the West, and the Congress is off vacationing and campaigning, but Henry Kissinger is still on deck dealing with the clatter of the world.

title: LISBON RESUMES CONTROL IN ANGOLA
description: LUANDA, Angola, Friday, Aug. 15Portugal resumed administrative control of embattled Angola last night in a move that effectively sealed the collapse of the transitional government here.

title: About the Giants
description: Bruce Bannon, a 6foot4inch, 230pound linebacker, joined the club yesterday, after being acquired from the San Diego Chargers. Bannon, a thirdyear pro from Penn State, had played for Coach Bill Arnsparger at Miami There will be no barefoot hooter on the Giants this season, with the release yesterday of Ricky Townsend, the rookie placekicker from Tennessee. Townsend's departure leaves George Hunt and Jim O'Brien challenging the incumbent, Pete Gogolak. Other cuts announced yesterday to reach the 60player limit were Steve Buchanan, running back; Ed McCartney, tight end; Jim Micklos, defensive lineman, and Leonard Dunlap and Honor Jackson, defensive backs. Jackson was claimed by the Detroit Lions.

title: M.A.C. HEAD JOINS ADVISORY BOARD
description: William M. Ellinghaus, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, was among eight business, financial and labor leaders named yesterday by Mayor Beame to his new management advisory board.

title: 2D BERGMAN AIDE ADMITS HIS GUILT
description: Samuel A. Dachowitz, the personal accountant for Bernard Bergman, pleaded guilty to Federal fraud charges yesterday and disclosed that he was cooperating with the prosecution in the Bergman case.

title: Jewish Groups Hail Decision to Change Passion Play's Text
description: The American Jewish Con gress said yesterday that it was gratified, that the 1980 revival of the Oberammergau Pas on Play would be based on a script that ascribes the Crucifixion not to the Jews but to Lucifer, the fallen anael.

title: State Modifies Directive On Disclosure of Incomes
description: The financial statements that are required of state officials who earn more than $30,000 a year, or who are in policymaking positions, must detail all assets and sources and amounts of income, but only the sources will be open to public scrutiny, the chairman of the Board of Public Disclosure said yesterday.

title: Argentine Army Vows To Stay Oat of Politics
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14 (AP)Argentina's army commander and nine other top generals met for seven hours today and declared that the army would not intervene in the nation's political affairs.

title: All Mustangs and Cougars Of '68'69 Ordered Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) The Government today or dered the Ford Motor Company to recall all 1968 and 1969: Ford Mustangs and Mercury Cougars because of defects that it said could cause partial collapse of the front seat.

title: Club Pro's 64 Leads by Shot
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 14Like an echo of the opening day of last week's Professional Golfers Association championship, which they were calling the Who's He? Open, a club pro shot 64 today and a tour freshman added a 65 to dominate the first round of the $200,000 Greater Hartford.

title: TopLevel Parley Begins On Contract for Teachers
description: Toplevel talks began yesterday between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers in an effort to reach agreement on a contract before the scheduled start of the fall school term on Sept. 8

title: Iran, Despite Her Oil Wealth, Is Borrowing on a Grand Scale
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 14 After almost two years of huge petrodollar inflows accompanied, by massive internal development programs and expensive external investments, Iran is borrowing moneyalso on a grand scale.

title: Terpsichore Dancer's Promising Giselle
description: A penny for the thoughts of some young dancer about to undertake the taxing lead in Giselle for the first time might unleash a torrent of seemingly contradictory feelings. The role calls for the expression of tenderness, youthful love, betrayal, anguish, nobility of spirit and a host of minor emotional grace notes to flesh out the portrayal. Bronwyn Thomas of U.S. Terpsichore showed a good grasp of the role at. the Marymount Manhattan Theater on Wednesday evening.

title: Britons Buy Japanese and Dismay the Government and Industry
description: LONDON, Aug. 14Citizens here are being urged to buy British, but to the dismay of the Government and industry, they're buying Japanese instead.

title: AGENT IS FAMILIAR WITH ABDUCTIONS
description: William F. Beane, the Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in charge of the Bronfman case, is no stranger to kidnapping inquiries.

title: Antoniou's Evocative Music Is Played at Tanglewood
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 Words and music. Like man and woman, they need each other, but their relationship is fluid and often uneasy. Any composer who uses words knows the problem: They are essentially meaningless in a strictly musical sense and yet they can provide him with a strong framework on which to hang ideas.

title: INTEREST RATES ON M.A.C. BONDS SET Al NEW HIGH
description: Underwriters for the Municipal Assistance Corporation raised interest rates on corporation bonds to record levels yesterday as a part of a complicated package of financing to meet the city's cash needs for August.

title: FORD WILL APPEAL BAN ON 0IL OIL TARIFF
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Ford Administration will appeal to the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court's decision that President Ford's tariff on imported oil is illegal. Solicitor. General Robert H. Bork announced today.

title: Bridge
description: A MemphisDetroit partnership won the life master pairs at the American Bridge Association's Summer Nationals at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel here yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: Fears were confirmed yesterday when tests showed that David Knight, a starting wide receiver for the New York Jets, had torn a cartilage in his left knee when he hit the ground during Wednesday's practice. The 24yearold player will undergo surgery Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He is not expected to return to the field until midOctober, according to Jets spokesman. Last season Knight was the team's second leading receiver behind Jerome Barkum with 40 catches for 579 yards and four touchdowns. He was eighth in receiving in the American Football Conference. Knight is starting his third with the jets.

title: 100 Legislators Accompany Byrne as He Juggles Apples and Issues
description: VINELAND, Aug. 14Governor Byrne today joined 100 state legislators and others on a farm tour here. He juggled apples, apples, identified a field of tall green stalks as corn, and won the applause of farmers for his expressions of concerh over agricultural problems in this highly urbanized state.

title: MANILA REPORTS MINDANAO TRUCE
description: MANILA, Aug. 14The Philippine Government announced tonight that rebels in southern Mindanao who fought under the banner of the Moro Liberation Front had accepted a ceasefire.

title: Administration Moves to Deny Welfare Payments to Strikers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Ford Administration has reopened an old labormanagement dispute by proposing regulations that would deny welfare payments to striking workers.

title: More Than a Cemetery
description: With the Bicentennial only months away, one of the country's most historic sites is ironically threatened with conversion into a cemetery bordered by housing developments and a hotelofficeshopping center plaza.

title: Carey Sets Up Olympics Commission
description: WATERTOWN, Aug. 14Pledging that the winter Olynrpics scheduled for Lake Placid in 1980 would prove a dividend to our environment and not a detriment, Governor Carey today created by executive order a state commission to plan the state's role in the international events.

title: RABBI TEITELBAUM, OF QUEENS YESHIVA
description: Rabbi A. Simcha Teitelbaum, founder and dean of the Yeshiva High School of Queens in Holliswood, died Wednesday evening in Long Island Jewish Hospital after heart surgery. He was 44 years old and lived at 7033 173d Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Pressure Rises in Lisbon Against ProRed Premier
description: LISBON, Aug. 14President Francisco da Costa Gomes sought today a 45day delay in replacing his Communistbacked. Premier, Gen. Vasco Gongalves but Socialists and other political opponents applied pressure to make the Premier step down nnw.

title: ISRAEL REPORTED WILLING TO RETURN OILFIELD TO EGYPT
description: WASHINGTON; Aug. 14Israel has agreed, as part of an accord with Egypt now in the final stage of negotiation, to return the oilfield at Abu Rudeis to the Egyptians.

title: Bask Unit of Magnetism Believed to Be Detected
description: A particle representing whose existence has been si century but had stubbornly the basic unit of magnetism, spected for most of the past eluded detection, is now believed to have been observed.

title: M.A.C, HEAD JOINS ADVISORY BOARD
description: William M. Ellinghaus, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, was among eight business, financial and labor leaders named yesterday by Mayor Beame to his new management advisory board.

title: $22Million Voted to Improve Port Authority Station
description: The Pprt Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved an expenditure of $22million to modernie and improve the main concourses and loading platforms of the midtown bus terminal on Eighth Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets.

title: Yanks Beaten, 51, on 5Hitter By Bosman and A's 4Run 8th
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 14 Well, one good thing, said Manager Alvin Dark of the Oakland A's last night, right after his team had been beaten by Catfish Hunter and the New York Yankees, 31. Our club hasn't lost three straight for quite a while.

title: Son of a Dairy Head and 4. Held in Phony Kidnapping
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J. Aug. 14 (AP)The 18yearold son of a dairy president, three other young men and a girl have been charged with extorting $50,000 from the executive by staging a phony kidnapping of the son.

title: June Slowdown Is Shown In Paring of Inventories
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The steep decline in business inventories that began in February slowed markedly in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Vietnam Refugees Given Orientation On Coping With City
description: To ease the fears of 200 newly arrived Vietnamese refugees and help them adapt life in the metropolitan area, an orientation session was held last night at the American Red Cross of Greater New York, 150 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Boston Police Try to Halt Racial Pelting of Motorists
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14  It was getting close to midnight. The police Tactical Patrol Force swarmed down the hill and onto the intersection by the BromleyHeath housing project in a blur of blue jumpsuits, helmets and nightsticks, and the rockthrowing bands of black youths disappeared into the warren of drab brick buildings.

title: Lost Coast Girl, 7, Rescued; Alien Accused of Kidnapping
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 14 (UPI)Sheriff's deputies rescued 7yearold Elaine Marguerite Taylor apparently unharmed near the Mexican border today and charged an illegal alien with abducting her from her bedroom.

title: and the Next One
description: If the coming weeks do produce another successfully negotiated pact, it will be important for the diplomats on all sides to broaden their approach immediately and contemplate the overall framework in which Israel and the Arab states might one day coexist in peace.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged the Raymond Lee Organization of 230 Park Avenue, an invention development concern, with misrepresenting its services and failing to disclose that Raymond Lee is not an attorney and giving any interest in an invention to the concern without a written agreement to the contrary gave it the right to dispose of it without consulting the inventor. The company said the charges were unjustified and it would fight them.

title: Bronfman Asks Abductors For More Proof Son Lives
description: Edgar M. Bronfman made a public plea yesterday to kidnappers of his 21yearold son, Samuel Bronfman 2d, for additional evidence that Sam is still alive and well.

title: Mu jib Reported Overthrown and Killed In a Coup by the Bangladesh Military
description: NEW DELHI, Friday, Aug. 15 Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the President of Bangladesh, was overthrown and killed today in a military coup d'etat, according to Government broadcasts monitored in India.

title: TAX FOR TRANSIT GAINING SUPPORT
description: Support continued to grow yesterday for a special tax in the 12county region served by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to stabilize bus, subway and commuter train fares.

title: Jersey Seedings Made
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 14Jimmy Connors was seeded No. 1 for the $50,000 Tennis Week open tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, beginning next Monday afternoon.

title: Saudis Achieve SyrianIraqi Agreement
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 14Mediation by Saudi Arabia ap?ears to have softened a dispute between Syria and Iraq over water of the Euphrates River, but there is no sign that an ideological quarrel between the two Arab neighbors has abated.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 14 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.1billion, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $1.01billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.54billon, up 6 per cent from last year's 0,510.88billion.

title: HARTFORD SEEKS MORE H.U.D. FUNDS
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 14The City of Hartford has filed suit in Federal District Court here against the Department of Housing and Urban Development to prevent the department from granting more than $4million in Federal funds to seven relatively affluent Hartford suburbs, it was announced today.

title: About New York
description: To learn to live with the New York subway is one thing. To learn to love it is quite another. No one has ever managed it. You could gut and fillet Attwater's Dictionary of Saints and not come up with a candidate.

title: L.I.R.R. Gives Out 100,000 Brochures of Safety
description: One hundred thousand safety brochures were placed on Long Island Rail Road passenger seats yesterday to tell commuters how to stop a train if a passenger gets caught in a car's doors.

title: CALIFORNIA FACING A WELFARE CUTOFF
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif:, Aug, 14 (UPI)The Federal Government has threatened to cut off $245million in welfare funds for California unless the state complies with paperwork requirements.

title: West German Fights the System
description: COLOGNE, West Germany Gtinter Wallraff is a 32yearold writer who thinks West Germans are selfsatisfied about overcoming the past, and he is doing his best to make them feel uncomfortable.

title: People and Business
description: Thomas C. Graham, 48, who had been president and chief operating officer of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation since Jan. 1, 1974, will become chief executive officer of the company on Sept. 1, succeeding Roscoe G. Haynie, 65, who will retire on that date.

title: Stocks Off on Amex And OTC
description: Stock prices declined again on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading, Dealers reported that trading activity, like volume on the New York Stock Exchange, was light.

title: M.A.C.'s Last Miracle?
description: When the Municipal Assistance Corporation finally patched together a $960million funding package last week to help New York City meet its August obligations, a weary corporation official observed, with more relief than rejoicing We've achieved our monthly miracle.

title: Philippine Ship Burns
description: MANILA, Aug. 14 (UPI)A Philippine domestic passenger ship caught fire while docked here today, forcing panicky passengers to jump into Manila Bay. At least one person was killed and 11 others were injured.

title: About the Yankees.
description: Pat Dobson, George Medich and Catfish Hunter will be the Yankee starters in the three games at Kansas City this weekend.  That will end a fivecity trip, and the Yankees will then be home for two weeks, playing Chicago, California, Oakland and Kansas City, their last games the season against Western Division teams.  Hunter made his wonlost record 1611 by beating the A's in Oakland Wednesday night, and a year ago, pitching for the A's, his record was 179 on the same date. In his three victories over his former teammates, Hunter allowed just nine singles in 27 innings, and two runs, but Hunter, still believes the A's will finish first without him and so do they. Oakland is concerned about the injured thumb of Joe Rudi, who has gone on the 15day disabled list. One doctor told him he would be out of action for six weeks.  Oakland's attendance has passed the 850,000 mark, surpassing last year's total with 19 home dates remaining.

title: PekingHanoi T ants Marked by Coolness
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 14 A visiting North Vietnamese economic delegation held talks with Chinese officials in Peking today in an atmosphere that appeared diplornatically correct but lacked th warmth and fanfare that marked relations between the two countries during the Indochina war.

title: The Rocky Road to Rock Stardom
description: It was as if Mick Jagger had decided to play in a 400seat club. The sidewalks of Mercer and Fourth Streets surrounding the Bottom Line Wednesday night were alive with restless rock fans, some herded into lines and some milling excitedly about.
