The cause of all the turmoil was a man who might just be the next Mr. Jagger, a 25yearoid rock n roll poet from New Jersey named Bruce Springsteen. And as his earlier performances here had led one expect, he gave two shows Wednesday that will rank among the great rock experiences of those luck/ enough to get in. Mr. Springsteen has it allhe is a great lyricist and songwriter, he is a wonderful singer, guitarist and piano player, lie has one of the best rock bands anybody has ever heard, and he is as charismatic a stage figure rock has produced.

title: HARTFORD SEEKS MORE H.U.D. FUNDS
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 14The City of Hartford has filed suit in Federal District Court here against the Department or Housing and Urban Development to prevent the department from granting more than $4million in Federal funds to seven relatively affluent Hartford suburbs, it was announced today.

title: Cash Prices
description: Thursday, Aug. 14, 1975

title: LEAD PRICES UP AS DEMAND RISES
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday it had increased its posted lead price to 20 cents, a pound from 19 cents, f.o.b. Herculaneum, Mo. The company said the increase was prompted by increasing demand for pri mary lead and the sustained rise in world lead prices over the last month as reflected by the London Metal Exchange.

title: British Ships Transit Suez
description: CAIRO, Aug. 14 (UPI)Three British Navy frigates and two support vessels transited the Suez Canal today from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea, the British Embassy said. The embassy said that they were the first British warships to transit the waterway since it reopened last June 5.

title: Turkey Devalues Its Lira
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 14 (Reuters)Turkey devalued today the lira against the dollar by approximately 1.8 per cent. The official Gazette listed the new price as $1 to 14.50 lira. Previously the rate was $1 to 14.25 lira. Turkey devalued the lira against the dollar, by the same amount just over a month ago.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Is the phrase investor confidence to become a local variation of national securitythat is, a phrase employed to justify the use of political power in an antidemocratic manner?

title: JUDGE APPROVES A SIRHAN REVIEW
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14A state judge today ordered a reexamination of the ballistics eviaence used to convict Sirhan B. Sirhan of the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Meo Tribesmen From Laos Facing Death in Thailand
description: BAN NAM LAN, Thailand (AP)Thousands of mountain tribesmen who fled Laos in the last two months are barely subsisting in the jungles near here, weary, sick and in some cases starving.

title: Business Records
description: RICHARD L. PULKOSKI, 433 E. 75th St., N.Y. Liabilities $7,274.76; assets $1,607. RONALD DOUGLAS KUNDA also known as Ronald D. Kunda, 19 Musselman Drive, Poughkeepsie, N. Y. Liabilities 511,787.74; assets 5200.

title: THURLOWGORDON,91, ANTITRUST LAWYER
description: Thurlow Marshall Gordon, a retired partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, who specialized in antitrust cases, died yesterday at his home in Stoneham, Mass. He was 91 years old.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Aug. 14, 1915

title: The Unwelcome Guest
description: WASHINGTONThe most sensitive and perplexing political problem confronting the nation is one that most politicians are understandably reluctant to talk about, much less act upon. It is how to maintain social harmony and, ideally, achieve greater social justice while also protecting the environment in the approaching period of modest economic growth.

title: Nearby Yachting
description: 1, Preset Y.C., Southport, Conn., Dixon Smith; Peter Dleinik (2211)25 points; 2, Larchmont, N.Y., Y.C., Douglas Lynn; Ted Luckett (112)16 3, American Y.C., Rye, N.Y., Rob Capita; Wendy Jack, Thomas Mundinger (35432)13; 4, Sea Cliff, L.I., Y.C., Bruce Klein; Peter Rossi (44343)12; 5, Orlenta Beach Club Y.C., Terence Frimmet; Carol White (disoualitied352disqualified)18.

title: Chinese Crop Periled By Flood and Drought
description: PEKING, Aug. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)  Northern China's autumn harvest is being threatened by drought while crops in central and southern China have been endangered by flooding, according to a report today in the Communist party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao.

title: Miss Horton in Golf Semifinal
description: NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP)Donna Horton, a native of North Carolina who moved to Florida to further her golf career, and three comparative unknowns advanced today to the semifinal round in the 75th United States Women's Amateur golf championship.

title: FORD DECLARES VAIL BICENTENNIAL TOWN
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 14Al though this ski and golf resort is barely 13 years old, President Ford declared it a bicentennial community today in a brief ceremony at the home of Mayor John A. Dobson.

title: From Madrid, Observations on Military Behavior
description: MADRIDIt appears that in all countries; during all periods; under a variety of social and historic conditions, the military's dominant virtue has been its willingness and talent for sacrifice.

title: About New york
description: To learn to live with the New York subway is one thing. To learn to love it is quite another. No one has ever managed it. You could gut and fillet Attwater's Dictionary of Saints and not come up with a candidate.

title: Death of 2 Doctors Poses a Fitness Issue
description: The strange case of the Marcus brothers, identical twins whose parallel lives led them from prominent careers as gynecologists through drug addiction to lonely deaths in the throes of barbiturate withdrawal, has become the new focus of an old controversy in medicinehow to deal with doctors who become unfit to practice.

title: KISSINGER GIVES. LISBON ANTIREDS STRONG BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14At a time of mounting crisis in Portugal, Secretary of State Kissinger today gave the strongest United States support to I,date to the forces who oppose the Communists in that country.

title: Sets Begin Final Drive Tonight
description: The New York Sets have lost only nine of their 42 World Team Tennis matches this season. But with two remaining on the schedule they are still in danger of finishing second in the Eastern Division behind the Pittsburgh Triangles.

title: U.S. Money Supply Rose $1.9Billion in the Week
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the nation's money supply had climbed $1.9billion in the week ended Aug. 6.

title: Reds Top Pirates For 5th Straight
description: Because of his penchant for lifting his starting pitchers as soon as they show any sign of weakening, Sparky Anderson, the Cincinnati manager, is known as Captain Hook, and his club set a mark for consecutive incomplete games this season. Captain Hook did his act again last night in the Reds 61 victory over visiting Pittsburgh, but it was probably because the reeling Pirates were already falling off the gangplank.

title: YIELD UP TO 8.25% IN TREASURY SALE
description: The Treasury sold $2billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an astonishingly high average yield of 8.25 per cent. This Governmentbacked security, like others, is exempt from state and local income taxes. Some Credit analysts noted that Markets yields have climbed with such speed recently partly out of inflation fears, that they now approach the return of the fabled 9 per cent coupon issues sold just a year ago when interest rates were at an alltime peak.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Truckload of Meat Stolen Here, The 20th Such Theft This Year
description: While a driver for an upstate meat company was unloading a shipment of cold cuts in an Italian market on Grand Street yesterday, someone drove off with his truckload of bologna, ham and capicola.

title: Deceptive Practices Alleged In Sale of Cracker Jacks
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UPI)The City of Chicago has issued tickets for deceptive practices against Borden, Inc., and four retail stores, charging that the manufacturer and stores were selling outdated Cracker Jacks.

title: Mrs McIngvale Triumphs
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13 (AP)Cynthia Mclngvale of DaHat, won the women's oremeter crown and Lieut. Phil Boggs of the Air Force took the men's threemeter title today in the Amateur Athletic Union national outdoor diving championships.

title: CHEAVNG IN TRADE OF GRAIN OUTLINED
description: BONDURANT, Iowa, Aug 14 A former grain inspector who has pleaded guilty to a bribery indictment described at a Senate field hearing today allegedly corrupt practices in the grading and handling of grain to be exported from the Port of New Orleans by two large grain corporations.

title: In Building Together, They Learned a Lot
description: KINGSTON, N. Y.Looking at the piles of lumber and painted tires, the halffinished platforms and upright posts, there was no way to tell what was being built.

title: BARNABY BYE PUTS STRESS ON SINGING
description: Barnaby Bye is a Long Island group by way of Canada (where it records) that has made occasional appearances in Manhattan without achieving much of a breakthrough. The group's appearance at the Other End on Bleecker Street on Wednesday night was its best yet, and some of the talent heard on its recordings (which have the benefit of careful preparation) came through.

title: Basic Unit of Magnetism Believed to Be Detected
description: A particle representing the basic unit or magnetism, whose existence has been suspected for most of the past century but had stubbornly eluded detection, is now believed to have been observed.

title: County Official Says Orange Is Obliged To Pay for Welfare
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 14The acting Orange County Attorney, James Tarnsen, in report to County Executive Louis V. Mills, has determined that the county has a legal obligation to pay welfare costs, and that failure to do so could result in court action.

title: Mideast Another Step
description: The detailed bargaining now gaining intensity between Egypt and Israel holds genuine promise only if the proposed new accord is viewed as the start of a process, not an end unto itself. A new interim agreement in the Sinai would be an important diplomatic achievement, the certifying of a contractual and mutually beneficial relationship between two longtime enemies; yet, standing alone, it would scarcely begin to address the real problems of establishing a durable peace.

title: GIMBEL RETIRES AS STORES HEAD
description: Bruce Alva Gimbel, the 62yearold chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced his retirement yesterday. His departure, effective Aug. 31, from the department store chain his great grandfather founded 133 years ago ends another family dynasty in American retailing.

title: Variety of Fish Are Reported Being Taken in Local Waters
description: AREA ABlues from 10 15 pounds have been taken the ocean off Point Pleasant, with the Klondike and Manasquan Ridge areas reporting good catches. Fluke 5 to 11 pounds are being taken by drift boats off the beach, and there are reports of tuna, albacore and bonita mixed in with the blues. At Surf City the report is labeled thin for surf fishing. A few flounder have been taken off the beach and in Beach Haven and Barnegat Inlets. Snappers (baby blues) 6 to 12 inches are plentiful in Barnegat Bay. Bonita, dolphin and tuna, taken by spoons, have been reported off Barnegat, and along the shore fluke fishing is reported very good from the drift boats.

title: HARRY G. LOIS
description: Harry G. Lois, a retired florist and the father of George Lois, chairman of the Lois Holland Callaway, Inc., advertising agency, died yesterday in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: BUDD ROGERS, 84, MOVIE EXECUTIVE
description: Budd Rogers, a motion picture executive for 51 years, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 50 Sutton Place South.

title: WARD'S REGISTERS 15.6% RISE IN NET
description: The first two major merchandising chains to report results for their most recent quarters, showed a mixed trend. Montgomery Ward increased earnings by 15.6 per cent in the second fiscal quarter ended July 31. Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had a 28.1 per cent decline for its third fiscal quarter ended June 30.

title: Deficit Quadruples 647Million Loss Shown for July
description: LONDON, Aug. 14 (UPI)Britain reported today that its overall balanceofpayments deficit more than quadrupled in July.

title: Equestrian Trials Today
description: GLADSTONE, N.J., Aug. 14The United States Equestrian Team will hold trials for the PanAmerican Games dressage squad at its training base here tomorrow through Sunday. Nineteen ridersthe largest entry ever in a PanAmerican Games trialswill be on hand. John Winnett of Tuxedo Park. N.Y., and Edith Master of New York City, both of whom competed for the U.S.E.T. in the 1972 Olympic Games, will he among the riders trying out.

title: A Distinctive Image Kept Up by Lateef In His Jazz Playing
description: For 20 years, Yusef Lateef has nurtured a jazz image consistently his owna slightly exotic use of reed and woodwind instruments that is just far enough removed from the jazz form to be distinctive, but not so far as to seem a labored attempt to be different. The balance wheel is his strong, forthright, swinging attack, which invariably comes charging into view before he can become too precious.

title: TwoYear Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Treasury sold today $2billion of twoyear notes at an average return of 8.25 per cent. The department received $4.9billion of tenders for the notes.

title: Egyptian Is Head of UNICEF!
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (Reuters)Dr. Hassan Sabry elKholy, an aide to Egyptian Presidents for more, than 10 years, today was named special representative in the Middle East for the United Natio's Children's Fund.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Two U.S. Diplomats Charged by Laotians With Spy Activities
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Laotian Government has accused United States Embassy officials in a diplomatic protest of spy and sabotage activities in photographing a government compound.

title: Buying British Found Troublesome in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 14'Buying British, especially a British car, can be difficult here

title: Seales Bout on TV
description: Sugar Ray Seales of Seattle and Cyclone Hart of Philadelphia, middleweights, will meet in a nationally televised 10round fight at Atlantic City's Convention Hall, tonight. WORTV (Channel 9) will carry the fight in the New York area beginning at 11:30 P.M.

title: Bills Trade Is Voided
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 14 (UPI)A trade in which the Buffalo Bills acquired Mike Hancock, a tight end, from the Washington Redskins was voided today when Hancock flunked the Bills physical examination, a spokesman said. Buffalo acquired Hancock Tuesday in a trade for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Guide
description: SUMMER SIMMER The young people who entertain at Once Upon a Stove, a restaurant at 325 Third Avenue (between, 24th and 25th Streets) are showbiz aspirants doubling as waitresses, bartenderi and busboys. Fridays and Saturdays, from about 8 PM to T A.M. they take turns on the podium of the Valentine Room. This chandeliered aerie (with a $1 cover charge) is reached by Zigzag stairs past three more dining and drinking are Vs, including a cavernous room directly below with a gothic. llar, flanked by a huge painting of Gina Lollobrigida from the Movie Woman of Straw.

title: A Fifth Democrat, Carter, Eligible for Campaign Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14Jimmy Carter, the former Governor of Georgia, announced today that he has been qualified for Federal subsidies in his race for the Presidential nomination next year. He is the fifth Democrat to do so.

title: Prosecutor and Defense Present Final Arguments in Joan Little Trial
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 14In nearly seven hours of impassioned oratory, the prosecutor and the defense in the murder trial of Joan Little alternately characterized the slight young black woman as a heroine guided by Divine Providence and a calculating killer who lured Clarence Alligood into her cell and slew him at the moment of ecstasy.

title: Mike Marshall's BigLeague Beds
description: Prof. Mike Marshall, baseball's most celebrated authority on kinesiology and physiological psychology, who had been working for the Los Angeles Dodgers without a contract, signed up the other day for what's left of this summer and all of next. In addition to his salary, estimated at $270,000 for two seasons, the agreement provides for incidental amenities such as a water bed wherever the team stops on the road. This must warm the cockles of Lee Scott, the road secretary, who felt he was being put upon when

title: STUART ROSE, EDITOR AND FOX HUNTER, 76
description: Stuart Rose, an author and book and magazine editor, whose avocation was fox hunting and steeplechasing, died Monday in the Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 76 years old and lived in West Chester, Pa.

title: Pilot Lands Near Memorial
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (Reuters)An Air Force helicopter made an emergency landing today at the Jefferson Memorial about a mile from the White House. There were no injuries to the threeman crew and two passengers, an Air Force spokesman said. H esaid that the pilot had landed the helicopter after hearing a bang.

title: Mujib Reported Ousted
description: NEW DELHI, India, Friday, Aug. 15The armed forces of Bangladesh mounted a coup before dawn today, ousting the President, Shiek Mujibur Rahman, from the helm of the country he led to independence four years ago, Western diplomatic sources reported.

title: 3 Puerto Ricans at U.N. Assail U.S. Rule
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14A leader of the movement for the independence of Puerto Rico charged in a United Nations committee today that the United States had increased repression on the island recently.

title: INTEREST RATES ON M.A.C. BONDS SET Al NEW HIGH
description: Underwriters for the Municipal Assistance Corporation raised interest rates on corporation bonds to record levels yesterday as a part of a complicated package of financing to meet the city's cash needs for August.

title: N.C.A.A. Cuts Athletes Aid
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14The National Collegiate Athletic Association opened a twoday special convention on economy today by attempting to cut some of the high costs of athletic scholarships. However, some of the members at the meetings in the Palmer House doubted that big savings would result from these first steps.

title: Viking Launching Due Aug. 20; July 4,1976 Goal Still Possible
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP)The launching of the troubleplagued Viking spacecraft was rescheduled today for Aug. 20, giving the mission another chance to land on Mars on July 4, 1976, space agency officials said.

title: CITY HOUSING UNIT MAKES BOND SALE
description: Four major banks have joined with four cityemploye pension funds to buy $65million in bonds and notes issued by a statecreated agency that finan ces construction of middlein come housing here, city officials reported yesterday.

title: Watts Plus Ten
description: Ten years ago, a summer of bloody riots and devastating arson in the black ghetto of Watts on the south side of Los Angeles shocked the nation and helped generate a new commitment to social justice and urban development. It was not so much the programs that were developed in the wake of urban rioting that inspired a sense that a powerful and healthy force was abroad in the country. Rather, it was the spirit of urgency and high purpose shared by Federal bureaucrats, community spokesmen and local civic leaders alike that provided hope that the long, hard task of working toward social justice had begun in earnest.

title: 2D BERGMAN AIDE ADMITS HIS GUILT
description: Samuel A. Dachowitz, the personal accountant for Bernard Bergman, pleaded guilty to Federal fraud charges yesterday and disclosed that he was cooperating with the prosecution in the Bergman case.

title: Praise for Afrikaans Is Protested in English
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 14 (Reuters) Afrikaners today celebrated 100 years of their mother tongueagainst an irreverent background of mild protest in plain modern Engish.

title: Death of 2 Doctors Poses a Fitness Issue
description: The strange case of the Marcus brothers, identical twins whose parallel lives led them from prominent careers as gynecologists through drug addiction to lonely deaths in the throes of barbiturate withdrawal, has become the new focus of an old controversy in medicinehow to deal with doctors who become unfit to practice.

title: Philippines Reports Truce in Mindanao
description: MANILA, Aug. 14The Philippine Government announced tonight that rebels in southern Mindanao who fought under the banner of the Moro Liberation Front had accepted a ceasefire.

title: Bronfman Asks Abductors For More Proof Son Lives
description: Edgar M. Bronfman made a public plea yesterday to kidnappers of his 21yearold son, Samuel Bronfman 2d, for additional evidence that Sam is still alive and well.

title: Circus Joyously Mixes Circus and Religion
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 13The bleachers of the Andrew Ward High School gymnasium were bristling with little arms reaching for the rafters.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Morris County dairy farmer who was ordered to raise the price on his bargain milk 7 cents a gallon said he would appeal the ruling. Superior Court Judge Bertram Polow ordered E. Gilbert Taylor, the farmer, to raise the price of his milk to $1.26 per gallon, the minimum retai price set by state regulation. Mr. Taylor operates a dairy farm in Long Valley and sells milk from his farm and from retail outlets in Chester and Succasunna.

title: 'Birth of Nation Is Public's
description: The silent film classic The Birth of a Nation has been ruled to be in the public domain. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals decision reversed a Federal District Court decision of 1973, and it means that the D. W. Griffith movie is public property and may be distributed and shown without royalt payments. The court held t the original 28year copyright of the 1914 film had not been properly renewed by the Epoch Producing Corporation.

title: Hockey Post to Edwards
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 14 (UPI)Mary Edwards, backup goalie and assistant coach for the parent California Seals, was named coach today of the Salt Lake Golden Eagles of the Central Hockey League. Edwards replaces Jack Evans, who moved up to run the National Hockey League club after leading the Eaglets to the title last season.

title: Shostakovich Funeral Is Held; Thousands File Past His Coffin
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (UPI)Dmitri Shostakovich was buried today to the strains of Schubert's Unfinished Symphony, Chopin's Funeral March and the Soviet National Anthem.

title: Court Voids A Drug Log On Patients
description: A threejudge Federal panel yesterday struck down as an unconstitutional invasion of privacy a state law requiring that the names of patients receiving controlled drugs, such as Ritalin, codeine, Percodan and morphine be filed with the state.

title: Pilot Lands Near Memorial
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (Reuters)An Air Force helicopter made an emergency landing today at the Jefferson Memorial about a mile from the White House. There were no injuries to the threeman crew and two passengers, an Air Force spokesman said. He said that the pilot had landed the helicopter after hearing a bang.

title: ISRAEL REPORTED WILLING TORETURN OILFIRD TO EGYPT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14  israel has agreed, as part of an accord with Egypt now in the final stage of negotiation, to return the oilfield at Abu Rudeis to the Egyptians.

title: 700 SANITATIONMEN STRIKE IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Aug. 14 (UPI) Detroit's 700 sanitation truck drivers made good their strike threat tonight, walking off the job and leaving city residents to face a pileup of garbage.

title: Money
description: Money Rates NEW YORK ey rates for Thursday (AP) Mon.

title: FOOD STAMP LOSSES BILLED TO 3 STATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) California, Washington State and Hawaii have been billed total of slightly more than $1million for losses due to their administration of the Federal food stamp program, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Jury Asks to Hear Shapp; Campaign Fund Likely Topic
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (UPI) Gov. Milton J. Shapp, a possible contender for the 1976 Presidential nomination, has been asked to appear before Federal grand jury here, presumably to answer questions concerning an alleged unreported $20,000 campaign contribution.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger gave strong United States support yesterday to nonCommunist forces in Portugal in a major policy declaration. He seemed to involve the United States openly in the country's political turmoil by stating that the United States was ready to help a democratic Portugal. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Business
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 14 (AP)General Motors, PeugeotRenault of France and Volkswagen of West Germany are the three foreign automotive companies that will be allowed to remain in Chile, the national news service, Orbe, said today.

title: Miss Epstein Loses
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14Lynn Epstein of Miami, the secondseeded star, was eliminated today in the United States girls 18andunder grass court tennis championship after being at match point three times. She lost to Beth Norton of Fairfield, Conn., 26, 76, 62, in the quarterfinals at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

title: Michael Shapiro Weds Theresa Vorgia
description: Theresa Vorgia was married yesterday to Michael Jeffrey Shapiro, a pianist and composer who plans to start law studies next month at New York University. Rabbi Irving Axel performed the ceremony at the Town House in Huntington, L. I.

title: Exercise Price on Warrants Cut 48c a Share by LTV
description: The LTV Corporation said yesterday that the exercise, price of its common stock purchase warrants expiring Jan. 15 1978, had been reduced to $56.98 a share from $57.46. As a result, the number of shares, that can be purchased on exercise of each warrant has been increased to 2.0183 shares from 2.0014.

title: Huge Concert Organ Pays City a Visit
description: Black Beauty will be installed in the north plaza of Lincoln Center today but it won't be a horse like the one in Anna Sewell's famous book. It is an organ, to be used for a concert at 8 P.M. as part of the free cultural events called Lincoln Center OutofDoors.

title: The Rocky Road to Rock Stardom
description: It was as if Mick Jagger had decided to play in a 400seat club. The sidewalks of Mercer and Fourth Streets surrounding the Bottom Line Wednesday night were alive with restless rock fans, some herded into lines and some milling excitedly about. The cause of all th turmoil was a man who might just be the next Mr. Jagger, a 25yearold rock n roll poet from New Jersey named Bruce Springsteen. And as his earlier performances here had led one expect, he gave two shows Wednesday that will rank among the great rock experiences of those lucky enough to get in. Mr. Springsteen has it allhe is a great lyricist and songwriter, he is a wonderful singer, guitarist and piano player, he has one of the best rock bands anybody has ever heard, and he is as charismatic a stage figure as rock has produced.

title: Paul Gaynor Is Dead at 54; Advertising, Publicity Man
description: Paul Gaynor, board chairman and president of Gaynor & Co., Inc., a diversified communications concern whose companies include Gaynor & Ducas, an advertising agency, and PR Associates, Inc., an publicrelations company, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 133 East 3Oth Street.

title: Liza Minnelli Lends Talents to Chicago
description: Bob Fosse's Brechtian outpost of glamour, squalor and sublime discontent, Chicago, at the 46th Street Theater, has a surprise guest starLiza Minnelli.

title: Foolish Pleasure Held Doubtful
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14  Foolish Pleasure became an uncertain starter today for Saturday's 106th running of the Travers Stakes, setting off a stampede of its.

title: 6 MORE IN CUSTODY IN BERGEN BOMBINGS
description: RAMSEY, Aug. 14 (AP)Two 21yearold youths and four juveniles have been arrested on charges of involvement in several pipebombings in northwest Bergen County.

title: 2 California Earthquakes
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Aug 114 (AP)Two moderate earthquakes sent shivers through this southern California desert resort early today and official said they produced a flurry of phone calls from anxious residents. An engineer at the California Institute of Technology said the first tremor occurred at 1:09 A.M. and measured 4 on the Richter scale. The second, two minutes later, measured 3.7.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger Speech Backing Lisbon's AntiRed Forces
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Kissinger today before the Southern Commodity Producers Conference in Birmingham, Ala., the text of which was released by the State Department:

title: The Pop Life
description: War, the basically black septet that is the headline act in a show at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, has been around for long time. The core of the group goes back to 1962, but the present configuration came together as the backup band for Eric Hurdon in 1969 and 1970.

title: Alcoholism Programs
description: Dr. Morris E. Chafetz, director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, says the increase in the number of occupational alcoholism programs conducted by major corporations in New York City, is an encouraging development. Page 51.

title: TeenAger Wins Trapshoot Event
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 14 (AP)The first preliminary event of the 76th annual Grand American trapshooting tournament was won today by 17yearold Gary Rainey Jr. of Carlisle, Ill.

title: FordCongress Rift Grows On Executive Agreements
description: I WASHINGTON, Aug. 14A major battle is brewing between Congress and President Ford over the longstanding Presidential practice of making executive agreements with other nations that are not subject to Congressional approval, but 1 that must be transmitted to Congress.

title: Dow Dips 3.52 to 817.04 as Volume Gains
description: While the stock market again drifted lower, yesterday in light, latesummer trading activity, goldmining stocks continued to decline along with the price of gold itself in London and Zurich.

title: Market Place
description: These are happy but confusing days for shareholders of the Apco Oil Corporation.

title: 7% DROP EXPECTED IN AUTO PRODUCTION
description: DETROIT, Aug. 14United States automobile production is expected to decline 7 per cent this week from last week as more plants are closed for model changeovers, according to the trade paper Automotive News.

title: About Real Estate
description: Rent control is an old horse, staggering under the burden of an obsolescent housing supply, a compl icated administrative system, a bitter and discouraged ownership class, a corrosive inflationary spiral, and an unjust rent pattern in which tenants subsidize their neighbors and the aggregate rent income citywide is grossly inadequate for sound maintenance of the stock.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: We have been waiting until the middle of August, when everybody is out of town, to slip in notices of a couple of restaurants that can't take care of any more people than they already do. One of them, Pietro's at 201 East 145th Street, has been around a long time but we mention it in our obligatory capacity as restaurant encyclopedist. The other, Piro's, at 1350 Madison between 94th and 95th Streets, is new and obscure and we mention it to show that we are on the ball.

title: Gertrude Ederle Dedicates Ederle Park
description: HIGHLANDS, Aug. 14Gertrude Ederle, the first woman to swim the English Channel, dedicated a park adjacent to the Highlands Bridge in her own name today as part of a series of celebrations honoring this borough's 75th anniversary.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.9 billion tonmiles, 7 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 450,615 cars, 9.9 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonrage was 13.2 per cent below last year.

title: Unveilings
description: WEINSOFFThere will be an unveiling of the monument to the memory of Lillian and Arthur Weinsoff, Sunday, Aug. 17, 11 A.M., Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, N.J.

title: U.S. Railroads Record 67.4Million Total Loss
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (Reuters)  American railroads reported a total loss of $67.4million in the second quarter of 1975, the Association of American Railroads said today.

title: Anaconda Seeking Advice of Lawyers On Offer by Crane
description: The Anaconda Company told its shareholders yesterday that an offer by the Crane Company to purchase 5 million of Anaconda's common shares, or about 22.6 per cent of the coinpany, in excnange for. Crane 10year subordinated debentures could raise various legal questions and we have asked our counsel to examine its legality under antitrust and other laws.

title: Today's Saratoga Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Tomahawks Lose In Overtime, 2521
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 14 Andy Cawker scored four goals in the overtime period to lead the lastplace Quebec Caribous to a 2521 upset over the leading Long Island Tomahawks in a National Lacrosse League game tonight before 4,520 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although not invisible, the mysterious narrator of Jerzy Kosinski's novel Cockpit, a man named Tarden, partakes of some of the invisible man's powers. He is rootless, without country, job, friends or family. He is wealthy, and he rotates his home among several apartments, which are well secured and literally mined with explosive charges. Once he was a professional photographer; now he points his camera randomly, freezing shifting figments of reality, his ememory is photogiaphic, too, and he must take care not to overload it. His blood pressure is so low that he is cold as the dead when asleep and needs the constant stimulus of excitement to prod him alive.

title: Sports Today
description: Drag racing, at National Speedway. Center Moriches, L. 1., 8 P.M.

title: Inquiry Is Reopened on Cuban Nominee
description: Bureau of Investigation reopened today its inquiry into the background of a CubanAmerican who was appointed last week director of the Cuban refugee program.

title: Barrel Explosion Kills Youth
description: HAMPDEN, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP)  A youth helping his father weld a barrel was killed yesterday when the barrel exploded. David R. Niccum Jr., 14 years old, died of a fractured skull, a medical examiner said.

title: Welfare Protesters Storm Legislature In Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) More than 100 demonstrators angered over proposed cuts in the Welfare budget stormed the Massachusetts House chambers today. Fistfights broke out among legislators, protesters and court officers.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON. Aug. 14 (AP)The International Olympic Committee called tonight for the organizing committee Montreal to reconsider a television deal and enable Europeans to receive live telecasts of next year's Olympic Games.

title: Bus Fare to Kennedy Airport From Midtown Increased to $4
description: A 50cent increase in airport bus fares from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The increase will take effect on Sunday.

title: Pfizerand Others Make a Settlement In Antibiotic Suit
description: Pfizer, Inc., said yesterda it had settled in Federal Cour in Minneapolis litigation relat ing to tetracycline and ccrtair other broadspectrum antibiotics between the InternationalRectifier Corporation and Pfizer, the American Cyanamid Company, the BristolMyen Company, the Squibb Corpora tion and the Upjohn Company, Reuters reports.

title: WILLIAM BOYLAND, TAX OFFICIAL, DIES,
description: William E. Boyland, president of the City Tax Commission and head of the Real Property Assessment Department from 1949 to 1966, died here yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Abernathy Could Back Ford With Black as Running Mate
description: ANNISTON, Ala., Aug. 14 (AP)The president of thel Southern Christian Leadership Conference says he could support President Ford in the 1976 election if he chose a black as his running mate.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Europeans Reduce Rates on Lending
description: In an effort to stimulate their sagging economies, the central banks in West Germany and the Netherlands announced yesterday that they would each cut their key lending rates by onehalf of one percentage point, effective today.

title: Mrs. Court Defeated at Toronto Net
description: TORONTO, Aug. 14 (UPI)Dianne Fromholtz, a 19yearold Australian, upset her more famous countrywoman, Margaret Court, today in a quarterfinal match of the $130,000 Canadian open tennis tournament. The scores were 62. 36. 62.

title: KISSINGER GIVES LISBON ANTIREDS STRONG BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14At a time of mounting crisis in Portugal, Secretary of State Kissinger today gave the strongest United States support to date to the forces who opposa the Communists in that country.

title: Ford Company's Mileage Claims Are Called Deceptive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14A Federal Trade Commission judge found today that the Ford Motor Company had engaged in deceptive advertising in its use of gasoline mileage figures for its 1974 models, and prohibited the company from making any unsubstantiated gasoline mileage claims in the future.

title: Court Orders State to End Medicaid Drug Chargel
description: Medicaid patients in New Jersey no longer have to pay 25 cents for a drug prescription, and pharmacists had 25 cents restored to state subsidies of these prescriptions under a temporary order issued in Newark yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Morris Pashman.

title: G. G. Stiebel Weds Penelope Hunter
description: Penelope J. Hunter, a member of the curatorial staff of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Gerald G. Stiebel, an art dealer and partner with his father in Rosenberg & Stiebel, Inc., were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: Advertising
description: Lord & Taylor, the Fifth Avenue based department store that will celebrate its 150th anniversary next year, has developed a new look new advertising, new logo, new packaging, new image.

title: Harris Finds Crowds Small but Receptive in Midwest Traveling
description: ELY, Iowa, Aug. 13Fred R. Harris does not have much credibility in Washington. He could not get reelected to the Senate from Oklahoma, the wiseacres say, so he decided to run for President in 1972; that didn't work, so he is back at it this time.

title: Rhodesia Leader Cautious On New Talks With Rebels
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 14 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith tonight warned Rhodesians not to put too much faith in the new attempts to resolve the country's constitutional problem.

title: A Top Fencer Reported Jailed By Warsaw as Spying Suspect;
description: BONN, Aug. 14Lieut. Col. Jerzy Pawlowski, the Polish fencing champion, has been in jail in Warsaw for more than two and a half months, apparHantly under suspicion of espionage, according to reports reaching here.

title: Countess of Berkeley, 91, An Artist, Dies in Assisi
description: The Countess of Berkeley, an artist specializing in charcoal drawings, decorative screens and murals of tempera, died Tuesday in Assisi, Italy, where he lived. She was 91 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger gave strong United States support yesterday to nonCommunist forces in Portugal in a major policy declaration. He seemed to involve the United States openly in the country's political turmoil by stating that the United States was ready to help a democratic Portugal. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: In Memoriam
description: BROWNRay. Darling; haooy birthday in heaven. Eternal love.

title: Riley Wins 2 Races In Finn Class Sail
description: SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 14H. Sanford Riley of Toronto sailed off with victories today in the opening two races of the Finn Class national championship on Great South Bay. On the Olympic scoring system, Riley's two victories over ninemile Gold Cup courses gave him no penalty points. John Dane of New Orleans, who placed second and fifth, has 13 points. three fewer than John Hahn of Buzzards Bay, Mass.

title: Rockefeller Will Move Into Mansion Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Vice President and Mrs. Rockefeller will be moving into the turreted Victorian mansion that is their official residence early in. September; and they plan a series of housewarming parties for more than2,000 guests in the following Month.

title: Notes on People
description: Near Yalta yesterday, Leonid I. Brezhnev gave 18 visiting United States Congressmen a tour or a summer palace of the 19thcentury Czar Alexander III. The delegation, which has been in the Soviet Union since Aug. 7, had talked with Mr. Brezhnev for more than two hours at his holiday retreat on the Black Sea, a modern, glasswalled house nestled in a pine grove.

title: L.I.R.R. Gives Out 100,000 Brochures on Safety
description: One hundred thousand safety brochures were placed on Long Island Rail Road passenger seats yesterday to tell commuters how to stop a train if a passenger gets caught in car's doors.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: SEPT. 10 IS LAST DAY ON INSTANT LOTTERY
description: TRENTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)Instant lottery tickets will no longer be sold after Sept. 10, the New Jersey Lottery Commission announced today.

title: A Plea to Prevent Rikers Island Jail Conditions From Exploding Into Bloodshed and Death
description: While New York City is in the midst of fiscal crisis, the conditions in the city's jails have so deteriorated that the risk of mass violence cannot be ignored.

title: Jersey Told to End Medicaid Drug Cost
description: Justice Morris Pashman of the New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday temporarily canceled a 25cent surcharge that the state had recently ordered Medicaid patients to pay Qn prescriptions, and he restored a 25cent cut in dispensing fees that had caused some druggists to stop filling Medicaid prescriptions.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: American League

title: 2 Policemen and 3 Citizens Are Injured In Dawn Gun Fight in California City
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Aug. 14 Two policemen and three residents of a MexicanAmerican neighborhood in this Southern California city were shot in bitter exchange of gunfire before dawn today.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday. London Morning fixing $162.:5, down $0.15; afternoon flxino $161.110, down $0.50. Paris (Holiday).

title: Knicks Sign Short, No. 1 Draft Choice
description: The Knicks have begun the long and arduous task of trying to become a big winner again with the signing yesterday of Gene Short of Jackson State, their firstround draft choice.

title: Efforts Rise To Assist Alcoholics
description: Occupational alcoholism programs have increased in number in recent years, according to a survey of major corporations with headquarters here. This is termed an encouraging development by Dr. Morris E. Chafetz, director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.

title: Canada's Output Index Up
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 14 (Reuters) Canada's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production rose 0.1 per cent to 208.4 (base 1961) in June from the revised 208.3 in May, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: 8 Named to Management Advisory Board
description: Chairman and president of Seamen's Bank for Savings since 1968. Practiced law with firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons, and Gates for eight years starting in 1956.  Appointed first deputy superintendent of banks by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1964.  Born Aug. 2, 1929, in Southampton, L. 1., grew up in Montauk. Graduated Phi Beta Kappa, Colgate University 1951. Editor of the Yale Law Journal, graduated Yale Law School, 1956 Son of an East Hampton banker, but 1 didn't set out to be a banker.  Former chairman of Temporary State Commission on the Water Supply Needs of Southeastern New York, which issued its final report last spring.  New York has to survive, and it will survive.  Lives with his wife in Bronxville.  Member of the boards of several corporations, including Consolidated Edison.

title: Film: 'McGonagall,' Son of 'Goon Show'
description: The brand of humor devised 20 years ago by Britain's "Goon Show"Spike Milligan, Peter Sellers and Harry Secombeand revived more recently by "Monty Python's Flying Circus," has a shadowed, hallucinatory quality to it. Its wild associations are the kind that come as we drop off to sleep and just before we wake up.It is particularly suited to the passive, divided attention with which we watch television. The non sequiturs, the outrageous inventions take form just outside the field of vision, loom up suddenly and just as suddenly switch to something else. Things blur; their sequence is obscure: The result is hilarity under ether.It is hard to transpose this kind of thing to a movie. People have come to see it; they have paid admission; their attention is more sharply focused; the screen image is big, clear and detailed. A two-headed bearded lady can't lope by quietly in the background: she requires to be explained somehow.If "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" worked, it is because the whirling lights were strung along a plot, rudimentary as it may have been.Years after the Goons broke up, Mr. Milligan and their director, Joseph McGrathboth collaborated on the screenplayhave tried to put together a full-length Goon-style picture."The Great McGonagall," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Village, is endearing, and parts of it are lovely and hilarious. But it lacks enough of an organizing principle in its chaos to succeed as a movie.It centers on the true figure of William McGonagall, an unemployed 19th-century Scottish weaver who imagined himself so passionately to be a poet that he in fact wrote verse and got it published. For instance, an ode to a cow:The Hen it is a noble beastThe Cow is more forlorner Standing in the rainWith a leg at every corner.In no way can the plot be summarized. Things happen, one after the other: some belong to McGonagall himself, some to his dreams, some to his dying hallucinations. We struggle too hard  we shouldn't, perhaps, but we doto disentangle dream from dream and reality from reality.Mr. Milligan is the bearded, gentle McGonagall who prefaces every recitation of his verse with an inarticulate howl that allows everyone time to flee.He sees, or imagines he sees, Queen Victoria at a theater variety show. He is invited, or imagines he is invited, to go to Balmoral Castle to read his poems. He goes, or imagines he does, and is turned away, or imagines he is.The pace is frenetic, the level of reality shifts every two minutes, it is stuffed with visual absurdities, old jokes and take-offs. Some work, some exasperate. McGonagall dances with Queen Victoriaa monotonous, one-joke role played patiently by Peter Sellersto an orchestra composed of Adolf Hitlers. He and Victoria and Prince Albert pump away at a steam calliope that projects dirty slides to the tune of "Amazing Grace."McGonagall does Macbeth on stage, wearing a Band-Aid on his nose. With the vegetables hurled at him he gives a cast party. He locks the doors so the guests can't escape when he recites his poetry.Finally, he lies on his death bed. The poet Tennyson and a man named King Theebaw of the Andaman Islands walk in carrying a decoration from the Queen. They strip to their Victorian underwear and climb decorously into bed with him while his wife serves cookies and tea.McGonagall dies, and you are sorry. Despite his madness, his delusions, his bad poems, you miss him. He is a radiant failure. So, in a way, is his movie, with all bad jokes, carelessness and confusion.

title: Achieving a Contented Union
description: The day after Woodrow Wilson was married to Edith Bolling Galt, he was observed (by his Secret Service guard) dancing a jig and singing Oh, you beautiful doll! You great big beautiful doll, words from a popular song. The President was 59 and Mrs. Galt was 44 at their marriage in 1915; both had been widowed; and both were seeking a union of passionate contentment. They achieved it, and it lasted until President Wilson was stricken in 1919. Thereafter, his wife was his protector and his nurse until he died in 1924.

title: Art: How Europeans Saw New World
description: Americans may well be very odd. But they are not quite so odd as they were thought to be when news of them first got back to Europe. Nearly 200 years elapsed between Columbus's first landfall and the moment in 1776 at which the ideal America was defined once and for all. During that time the European imagination made free with the notion of America and came up with some very peculiar formulations.

title: GEORGE B. BEVERIDGE

title: The Great Beaver War
description: After due deliberationa couple of hundred yearsthe New York State Legislature has passed a bill designating the beaver as this state's official animal. Governor Carey, in signing the measure into law, alluded to its (the beaver's, not the Legislature's) qualities of quiet industriousness and perseverance. At that, the beaver just got through by the skin of its teeth. It seems that Oregon (the Beaver State) complained that New York didn't give a dam about its prior claim to proprietorship, that this was yet another instance of New York cadging off the rest of the country. In fact, the reverse is true. The official seal of the City of New Amsterdam (New York City when it was a Dutch treat) shows a beaver. The present seal of the City of New York (which is located in New York State) includes a windmill, flour barrels, an Indian, what looks like an English sailor playing with a yoyo but actually dropping a sounding line, and two beavers.

title: GOING OUT Guide

Now it's time for another Sunday exploration, a guided insomniacs bicycle tour starting tomorrow at 1:30 A.M. and ending at Alley Pond Park in Queens with a sunrise breakfast (bring your own, plus a spare tire). The tour tab is $1.

description: ATLANTA, Aug. 15 (AP)Willie Davis, plagued by financial woes stemming from a broken marriage, left the St. Louis Cardinals today before the team's game here tonight and was immediately placed on the disqualified list. The effect of such a move, a club spokesman said, was that the outfielder would not receive his salary and the club could fill his opening on the active roster with another player. The 35yearold Davis said his decision to leave stemmed tto.n wage garnishments applied to his baseball salary by his farmer wife. Last year he was jailed briefly for nonpayment of alimony.

title: En Route to Nowhere
description: The number of jobs a person can perform for himself grows smaller every year. This is because of the famous increasing complexity of twentiethcentury society. Not too long ago, for example, an ordinary person could repair his own automobile, a task which now requires three appointments with a garage, consultations with a service manager and the ministrations of sundry specialists, in automotive geriatrics, carburetor cardiology and front end orthopedics.

title: Concert

But the group plays mostly familiar repertory, pieces it has had the time to polish. Thursday night, as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival, it offered two less standard pieces along with an old favorite, all in the unflattering acoustical ambiance of Avery Fisher Hall. The results left a lot to be desired.

Operations of the Long Island Rail Road were not affected. but trains on the Penn Central lines were delayed in most cases no more than eight min??? a railroad snokesman said. No iniuries were reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As an urban planner I am concerned over the fiscal instability of New York City. I recognize that this instability will threaten future social programs for the betterment of all city dwellers. However, what most bothers me is the quality of life within the Empire City.

And last week those who were worried about the rising cost of living could call Washington and have a real farmer tell them that it isn't his fault.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: John B. Clayton of Verga, N.J., filed a $500,000 lawsuit in Federal Court in Philadelphia against a television station and a hospital for alleged invasion of privacy and defamation of character. He contended that he had been filmed and taped against his will by a WPVITV team while he was attending an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting in St. Luke's and Children's Medical Center in Philadelphia on Aug. 15, 1974. He added that portions of the tape had been broadcast without his permission.

title: Music: Boulez's Rituel
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15Since he took up conducting as a steady occupation, Pierre Boulez has not composed much music that anyone knows about. Two or three pieces have surfaced, and that is about the size of it. But Mr. Boulez still must he regarded as one of the composing craft's bestequipped living members, and the music world is justifiably aroused by the prospect of any new works by the 50yearold Frenchman.

title: CampaignDisclosure Law Nearly Nullified in Jersey
description: TRENTON Aug 15An important section of New Jersey's campaign disclosure law was all but nullified today in clarification ruling handed down by Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman.

title: CASTRO SAID TO FEEL HE WAS WRONG IN' 62
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)  Premier Fidel Castro has said that he Was wrong in sisting removal of Soviet missiles from Cuba in 1962, Senator George McGovern said today.

title: 2 Bikers Fugitives Seized in Gun Fight
description: Two escaped prisoners from Rikers Island were recaptured by the police last evening in shootout that left one of the fugitives critically wounded the police reported.

title: CITY AIDES DIFFER ON CUTS EFFECTS
description: A disagreement over whether eventual savings or a net deficit will result from the recent economies in the city's $12.028billion budget has divided city financial officials.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The new Government of Bangladesh moved swiftly yesterday to consolidate its control following a predawn coup d'tat in which the country's President, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, apparently was killed. The Bangladesh Radio, monitored in Calcutta, repeatedly issued bulletins assuring a quick return to normality under the new President, Khondakar Mushtaque Ahmed, the former Commerce Minister, Who was a longtime associate of Sheik Mujibur. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Foolish Pleasure Skips Travers
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15Can a oncelazy California horse who still would rather eat than work adjust to the role of favorite for America's oldest stakes race? This became the latest chore facing Saran Stable's Forceten today after John L. Greer's Foolish Pleasure was declared out of tomorrow's 106th running of the $109,200 Travers Stakes.

title: LUTHERAN GROUP WILL BOLT SYNOD
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15After six years of struggle with the conservative majority in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, the dissenting moderate factions has approved a formal break and the establishment of a new synod to serve as a transitional body before merger with another group.

title: SOYBEANS CLIMB ALLOWABLE LIMITS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP)Soybean and soybean meal futures soared to allowable limits for one session on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: Bridge
description: A team of local champions scored a narrow victory in the American Bridge Association's national knockout team championship, which ended about 5 A.M. yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Narks Indian Anniversary With Talk on Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 (Reuters)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi marked India's independence anniversary today wit her first major public speecl since the Government declared a state of emergency almost two months ago.

title: The Greatest Empire Left
description: COPENHAGENVery few peopleincluding the Danesare aware that the largest overseas empire remaining in the world is Denmark's, thanks to the fact that this country controls not only the. Faeroes archipelago but also the greatest island on earth, Greenland, which comprises 839,781 square miles.

title: Percy Cerutty Dies at 80; Coached Australian Milers
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 15 (AP)Percy Cerutty, the flamboyant Australian coach who trained the miler Herb Elliott for his 1960 victory at the Rome Olympic Games, died yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: New Giant Players To See Coast Action
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 15The New York Giants will play their second preseason football game tomorrow night against the San Diego Chargers.

title: CONCERN MOUNTS IN BRONFMAN CASE
description: Lawenforcement authorities and the family of Samuel Bronfman 2d maintained wary silence yesterday over efforts to renew contact with his kidnappers and exchange a huge cash ransom for the 21yearold heir to the Seagram fortune.

title: MAYOR ORDERS CUT IN CAPITAL BUDGET
description: Mayor Beame yesterday released a list of $419million in vulnerable capital budget projects from which $345million must be cut for this fiscal year.

title: Canadian Finds Smooth Sailing in L. I. Race
description: BLUE POINT L.I. Aug. 15 It wasn't just the choppy waters and the clam boats in Great South Bay that H. Sanford Riley had to contend with in his sailingchampionship races today.

title: Baseball Sets 2 Night Playoffs
description: The third and fourth games of the American and National League championship playoffs will be played at night. Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, announced yesterday.

title: Even to the Neophyte, Fishing is a Snapper
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 15It is a ritual dance, intensified every August. Millions of shiny little fish, called snappers, flood into the bays and inletsand thousands of people rush down to the piers to catch them.

title: CETA AID VIEWED AS WAY TO REHIRE
description: The city sought Federal approval yesterday to use funds for a publicservicejobs program to retire 2,616 dismissed city employes.

title: Ford Bids Public Accept Increased Cost of Fuel
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 15Presilent Ford said today that Americans who had been Squandering energy should iccept increased costs of gasoine and other fuels as a very small price to pay for long???erm solutions to energy problems.

title: Rest of M.A.C. Bonds Sold Plans Laid for Next Issue
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, which yesterday completed a modest public bond sale that assures the city of meeting its cash needs this, month is laying plans to convene a meeting of toplevel bankers from across the country within the next two weeks.

title: 3 Homers Back Webb 7Hitter in 2d Game
description: One sudden, calamitous inning out of 18 cost the New York Mets a chance to take a giant stride forward in the National League's Eastern Division pennant race last night as they split a doubleheader at Shea Stadium with thc. San Francisco Giants.

title: Bangladesh at a Glance
description: GeographyBangladesh has an area of 55,126 square miles and a population of 75 million that is overwhelmingly Bengali and Moslem. It has 10 million Hindus, 400,000 Buddhists and a few Christians. The largest cities are Dacca, the capital, with a million people, and Chittagong, with 500.000.

title: City Officials Differ Over Effects Economies Will Have on Budget
description: City budget officials are in disagreement with the Controllet's office and some members of the Board of Estimate on the impact of recent economies on the city's $12.028billion budget.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: St. Paul, Minn Ken Norton, 218 pounds, San Diego, knocked out Jose Garcia, 213, Venezuela, 5 rounds.

title: Albert Ashforth Weds Erika Winterhoff
description: Erika Winterhoff, daughter of Mrs. Martin Winterhoff of Hermannsburg, West Germany, and the late Mr. Winterhoff, was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Albert Edward Ashforth, teacher and writer. He is the son of Mrs. Edward Ashforth of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Ashforth.

title: Bangladesh Upheaval
description: The overthrow and death of President Mujibur Rahman of Bangladesh represent a personal tragedy inextricably linked to the larger unfolding tragedy of that infant nation itself.

title: Lefkowitz Rules Latest Lulus Are Legal
description: The $878,500 that New York State legislators voted for themselves on the last day of their sessionextra payments known as lulusmay properly be paid under the State Constitution, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled yesterday.

title: In Memoriam
description: BELASCO BEATRICENANA BEA, WE KA Miss YOU EVERY DAY LOVE YOU ALWAYS. NEILA WENDY ERICA 6 MARTIN GRAVESDesmond R. 8/16/63. Mourned and missed. E. J.

title: U.N, ACTION ASKED ON PUERTO RICO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15Cuba and four Arab and African countries submitted a draft resolution in the United Nations Decolonization Committee tpday that would recognize the small movement for the independence of Puerto Rico as representing the legitimate aspirations of the Puerto, Rican people.

title: Peking Welcomes Cambodian Delegation and Talks Begin at Once
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 15A delegation of senior Cambodian Communist leaders arrived in Peking today to a warm welcome and immediately began talks with top Chinese officials, the official Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported.

title: T.W.A. REQUESTS FARE RISE OF 5%
description: Trans World Airlines, one of the most financially pressed companies in its industry, applied yesterday to the Civil Aeronautics Board for a 5 per cent fare increase, to become effective Oct. 1. At the same time, Continental and Frontier airlines, both of which are still operating profitably, asked for increases of 3 per cent to become effective Sent. 15.

title: Sports Today
description: Drag racing, at National Speedway, Center Moriches, L. I. 8 P.M.

title: Welfare Program for Aged, Blind and Disabled Overpaid $403Million in First 18 Months
description: WOODLAWN, Md., Aug. 15The new Federal welfare program for the nation's aged, blind, and disable dhas overpaid its clients $403,798,830.74 in its first 18 months of operation.

title: DPF Files a Suit to Compel Special Meeting for Interstate
description: DPF, Inc., which recently purchased a 37 per cent interest in the Interstate Brands Corporation, a wholesale baking company based in Kansas City, Mo., filed a suit yesterday in Delaware Chancery Court to compel Interstate to convene a special meeting no later than Oct. 10 to consider changes in Interstate's bylaws.

title: Contract Award
description: Rockwell International Corporation has been awarded a $297.3million increase in an Air Force contract to develop the new BI bomber. The contract amendment covers fourth test prototype plane and design refinements which the Air Force said could produce cost savings.

title: U.S. ASKED TO CURB AID TO 2 HOSPITALS
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, DemocratLiberal of Queens, said yesterday that he sent a letter to the United States Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare demanding that all nonemergency Federal funds be withheld from New York Hospital and the Cornell Medical Center pending a review of the affiliated institutions handling of the case of Dr. Stewart and Dr. Cyril Marcus.

title: ROSE CELL JACOBS, HADASSAH LEADER
description: Rose Gell Jacobs president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, from 1930 to 1933 and from 1935 to 1937, died Thursday at her home 201 West 77th Street. She was 86 years old.

title: Green, Bies Tie At 131
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 15Hubert Green, who has been in a costly slump since winning four events last year, felt like Jack Nicklaus and Johnny Miller today in shooting a 65, to tie Don Bies for the lead in the second round of the Greater Hartford open golf tournament.

title: Rest of M.A.C. Bonds Sold; Plans Laid for Next Issue
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, which yesterday; completed a modest public bond sale that assures the city of meeting its cash needs this month, is laying plans to convene a meeting of toplevel bankers from across the coun try within the next two weeks.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The new Government of Bangladesh moved swiftly yesterday to consolidate its control following a predawn coup d'tat in which the country's President, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, apparently was killed. The Bangladesh Radio, monitored in Calcutta, repeatedly issued bulletins assuring a quick return to normality under the new President, Khondakar Mushtaque Ahmed, the former Commerce Minister, who was a longtime associate of Sheik Mujibur. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: New Process Cuts Air Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15An oil company chemist has invented a new process that can decrease the amount of airpolluting oxides of nitrogen given off by large oiland gastired Patents power plant boilers and industrial of the furnaces. Richard Week K. Lyon, a research associate in the corporate laboratories of the Exxon Research and Engineering Company at Linden, N. J., will be granted Patent 3,900,554 next week.

title: Henry Luce 3d Marries Nancy Bryan Cassiday
description: Nancy Bryan Cassiday and Henry Luce 3d, vice president and director of corporate planning of Time Inc., were married in the chapel at the Princeton (N. J.) Theological Seminary yesterday afternoon.

title: ETHYL IS RAISING
description: The Ethyl Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing the domestic price of all standard mixes of antiknock compounds by onehalf of 1 cent a pound, effective with shipments on Sept. 19. Ethyl said the increases were the result of higher lead metal costs.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Rep. Downey Sees Army CoverUp in Drug Death
description: Representative Thomas J. Downey, who has been investigating the military's drug experiments with humans, said yesterday that there appeared to have been a deliberate effort to cover up the death of a patient in an Armysponsored experiment at the New York State Psychiatric Institute 22 years ago.

title: Joan Little Acquitted in Jailer's Slaying
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 15Joan Little was acquitted today of seconddegree murder in the death of her jailer, Clarence T. Alligood.

title: ANGOLA MOVEMENT RESISTS PORTUGAL
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 15The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, the only one of the three rival independence groups that has troops remaining in this capital, said today that it would not abdicate its government functions despite an announcement by Portugal's acting high commissioner that he was resuming executive power in the territory.

title: New President of Bangladesh
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Khondakar Mushtaque Ahmed, the new President of Bangladesh, is a professional politician who spent many years in jail during his nation's long struggle for independence. Diplomats in Washington who knew of him said, however, that he could not have been the leader of the coup against Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the controversial founder and leader of Bangladesh.

title: BRITISH INFLATION AT A RECORD HIGH
description: LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Inflation in Britain reached a record annual rate of 26.3 per cent in July. But the rate of increase is slowing down, according to Government figures issued today.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange advanced sharply enough yesterday to push the Dow Jones industrial average up 8.60 points to 825.64, but trading activity totaled only 10.61 million shares, the, lightest of the year.

title: Sets Defeat Nets, 2618, In W.T.T.
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 The New York Sets beat the Cleveland Nets at the Ohio Coliseum tonight, 2618, setting the stage for a World Team Tennis showdown match with the Pittsburgh Triangles tomorrow night in Pittsburgh.

title: Life on a Losing Streak
description: When the Detroit Tigers losing streak reached 15 games last Sunday, a man who owns a jewelry store thoughtfully sent the team 31 gold charms on gold chains with a Hebrew message for good luck and good health. The Tigers were touched but then went out and lost to the Texas Rangers, 70, for their third straight shutout, and that was No. 16.

title: Yuping Wu Is Bride Of Edward Eddy 3d
description: Yuping Wu and Edward Danforth Eddy 3d, who are studying for master's degrees at Cornell University, were married yesterday afternoon in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Davis Bordon Price, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Mellon Student Center of Chatham College, of which the bridegroom's father is president.

title: CONCERN MOUNTS IN BRONFMAN CASE
description: Lawenforcement authorities and the family of Samuel Bronfman 2d maintained a wary silence yesterday over efforts to renew contact with his kidnappers and exchange a huge cash ransom for the 21yearold heir to the Seagram fortune.

title: LEADERS OF COUP MOVE TO SOLIDIFY BANGLADESH RULE
description: CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 15The new Government of Bangladesh moved swiftly today to consolidate its control following the predawn military coup d'etat in which Sheik Mujibur Rahman was overthrown and apparently killed.

title: BREZHNEV HINTS DELAY ON RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, has reportedly indicated that the Soviet Union will insist upon further discussions with individual countries before implementing humanitarian provisions of the European security conference document signed at Helsinki two weeks ago.

title: Thais Hand Refugee Role To 3 World Relief Groups
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  Thailand has reached an agreement with three international relief organizations under which they are taking over most of the responsibility for the Indochinese refugees who continue to enter this country. The move is apparently deIsigned to ease some of the tensions the refugees have created between Thailand and her Communist neighbors.

title: London Sentences Six
description: LONDON, Aug. 15  Six members of the Provisional I.R.A. were sentenced to life imprisonment today for mount ling bomb attacks that took 21 lives and injured more than 1180 persons in Birmingham last November.

title: Team Sizes Are Limited By N. C. A. A.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15Major college football teams can take no more than 48 players on the road and suit up no more than 60 for home games as a result of costcutting action taken today at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's special convention on economy. It was the second and last session of the meeting.

title: Books of The Times
description: For 15 years the United States has been ravaged by an unprecedented crime epidemic. During that period billions of dollars were poured into expanded police departments and more intensive prison rehabilitation programs. At the same time, incalculable tons of analytic rubbish were published about the problem. But Prof. James Q. Wilson believes we are still engulfed by a crime wave largely because of our reliance on discredited theories for controlling or containing criminal offenders in America.

title: POLLY DYKE
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 15Polly Dyke, national vice president of the League of Women Voters from 1956 to 1958, died Monday. She was 80 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday about the deaths from barbiturate addiction of Drs. Stewart and Cyril Marcus, it was stated inadvertently that drug dependence is sometimes called an occupational habit of doctors. It should have read occupational hazard.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: 2Run Double by Chambliss Is Decisive
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15With opportune hitting and a little clutch pitching, the Yankees wrung a 54 victory from the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: The Marcus Tragedy
description: Cornell University Medical School and New York Hospital are among the world's most prestigious medical institutions. The notion that they would have on their faculty and attending staff physicians who saw patients and even operated on them under the influence of drugs is almost impossible to credit. Yet, it must now be accepted that this incredible situation actually did exist in the last months of the lives of Drs. Stewart L. Marcus and Cyril C. Marcus, twin brothers whose drugrelated deaths last month have already provided material for a bizarre chapter in the history of modern medicine.

title: Notes on People
description: Slated for extensive responsibilities for the firm's work in the Middle East, Ron Ziegler has been named managing director of international services for Syska & Hennessy the New York engineering consultants with branches in Washington, Paris and Teheran, Iran. The former Nixon press secretary will be based in Washington but will have lots to do with Teheran, according to Arnold Windman, executive vice president. He declined to name a salary for Mr. Ziegler, a former advertising man and 1961 graduate of the University of Southern California.

title: Rhodesia at the Falls
description: The longdelayed talks between black and white leaders on the political future of Rhodesia will get back on the tracks within, ten daysspecifically on the railroad tracks across the Victoria Falls that link whiteruled Rhodesia with blackgoverned Zambia. In that magnificent setting, Prime Minister Ian Smith and senior ministers of his white minority regime will meet the Rev. Abel T. Muzorewa and other leaders of Rhodesia's African National Council in plush railroad cars provided by South Africa.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted) Thurs.

title: Conservation Corps Mixes Study and Work
description: BRANCHVILLE, Aug. 15 (UPI)Roger Hernandez says the chance to work and study outdoors for the summer has helped change his philosophy and will help him look at cockroaches differently when The returns home.

title: Alaska Natives Pact: Reality Intrudes
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 15Roy Huhndorf, a tall, conservatively dressed Alaskan Indian leader, sat thoughtfully the other day in a paneled conference room here, surrounded by maps and reports and half a dozen other board members of Cook Inlet Region, Inc.

title: Party Game
description: At the final party, in the great mil of the last great house, the children played pass the parcel with the most magnificent parcel ever seen. It was so big that a regiment of liveried servants was needed to roll it from child to child. The game was played to music commissioned from Lu Tsin, and a famous New Guinea orchestra had been flown in to perform it.

title: KITTY M'DONALD TIMES PHONE CHIEF
description: Katherine Theresa MacDonald who retired in 1961 as chief telephone operator of The New York Times after 33 years with the newspaper, died Thursday in San Leandro Calif where she had been living with a sister Ellen Neuber. She was 74 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, whose resignation as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare became effective this month, has been elected a vice president and director of the privately held Bechtel group of companies.

title: Strengthening the Fourth World
description: A great debate has been going on will recent developments culminate in a crisis similar to the one in the 1930's? I think we should think more along the lines of what should be done in order to preclude such a development. In this attempt we would have to start with the experience which we acquired toward the end of those critical developments.

title: Elderly Dominate the Prague Summer Scene
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 10A blazing summer sun has made the ancient cobblestones of Prague's winding streets uncomfortably hot. The business of the nation has wound down for cucumber season and the capital seems to have slipped back into an older, more relaxed age. Some citizens bask on a not overly clean artificial beach on the Vltava (Moldau) River, which runs through the center of town. Others have left in their new cars for summer houses in Bohemia or resorts in other Communist countries, especially on the Black Sea.

title: Joan Little Acquitted in Jailer's Slaying
description: RALEIGH N. C. Aug. I5Joan Little was acquitted today of seconddegree murder in the death of her jailer Clarence T. Alligood.

title: Two Gauges of Payments Balance Differ
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The Government reported today mixed developments in two measures used to keep track; of money flows in and out. of the United States.

title: CETA AID VIEWED AS WAY TO REHIRE
description: The city sought Federal approval yesterday to use funds for a publicservicejobs program to retire 2,616 dismissed city employes.

title: Over 200 Questioned In Shooting Incident At Event in Madison
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, Aug.15Detectives questioned 200 families here last night in connection with the shooting of a man on the athletic field of Morristown High School and collected 35 legally owned 22caliber handguns.

title: ARMY ABANDONS DEFENSE OF TOCKS
description: The North Atlantic Divisioa of the Army Corps of En, gineers, which had recommend. ed a decade and a half ago that the Delaware River be dammed upriver at Tocks Island and had pressed for construction of a dam, has now recommended that Congress deauthorize the $400million project.

title: DEEP VELVET SOUND IN MISS LEA'S SONGS
description: Twenty years ago a very promising young singer named Barbara Lea, who reminded; some listeners of Lee Wiley, was beginning to make an imipression on records and in clubs. such as the Village Vanguard. But suddenly nothing more was heard of herbecause, it now turns out, she began studying acting to improve her presence as a singer and, through this, went into theater.

title: A Cooky Transforms An Agent Into a Star
description: HOLLYWOODAfter one of his few promising clients broke an ankle last fall, and another leased an expensive car when she owed him money, Wally Amos decided to forsake his career as a show business agent and establish what's believed to be the first chocolatechip cooky store.
