title: Old City in Portugal Quietly Defies Lisbon
description: TOMAR, Portugal, Aug. 14This 12thcentury center of tradition and wellbeing 70 miles northeast of Lisbon is quietly resisting the proCommunist military Government of Portugal.

title: Man Killed, 59 Hurt in Ulster Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 15Fiftynine persons were injured and one man killed in violence in Belfast tonight. The violence included two explosions, and the injured included four members of Roman Catholic crowd that attacked a British Army patrol called to the scene of one of the blasts.

title: A ONESTOP SHOP HELPS THE VOTERS
description: An infant wailed. The child's mother murmured to a woman busily writing notes on a yellow pad. Telephones jangled. An electric fan hummed hopelessly against the steamy heat. Typewriters tapped.

title: MERV HINTS DELAY ON RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid 1. Brazhnev, has reportedly indicated that the Soviet Union will insist upon further discussions with individual countries before implementing humanitarian provisions of the European security conference document signed at Helsinki two weeks ago.

title: Mujib Led Long Fight to Free Bengalis
description: Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who was reported killed yesterday in a coup d'etat in Dacca, is widely regarded as the father of Bangladesh.

title: Danes Cut Discount Rate
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 15 (AP)The Danish National Bank said today it would reduce its discount rate to 7 per cent from 8 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Cav and Pag Given in Central Park
description: There was a neat contradiction between nature and art Thursday night in Central Park. The real skies were darkening into night as Easter was dawning onstage for the opening of Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana. The work was being given together with Leoncavallo's Pagliacci as the third of four free, fully staged presentations by the New York Grand Opera this summer on the Mall.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, doled 34 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Janes Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min. from Sandy Hook lime.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The North Atlantic Division of the Army Corps of Engineers which had recommended a decade and a half ago that the Delaware River be dammed upriver 4 Tocks Island and had pressed for construction of a dam recommended that Congress deauthorize the $400million project.

title: Foreign Stock Index
description: Pester Prey. 1975

title: CHARLES CAMP, 82, A PALEONTOLOGIST
description: BERKELEY, Aug. 15 (AP)Dr. Charles L. Camp, a paleon prepare exhibitions for the NeCalifornia at Berkeley and an authority on Western American pioneer life, died of cancer yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: Japan Steel Sales to U.S. Up
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP)Japan's stainless steel exports to the United States totaled 30,243 metric tons in the first five months of this year, up 92 per sent from a year earlier.

title: Toll 166 at Berlin Wall
description: BERLIN, Aug. 16, (Reuters)A total of 166 people have been killed trying to escape to the West from East Germany since the Berin Wall went up 14 years ago, Justice authorities report here.

title: Nixon Pension to Rise On CostofLiving Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon stands to get an increase of $3,000 or more in his $60,000ayear pension as a result of new legislation that gives Congressmen, Federal judges and otherlevel officials a costofliving pay rise.

title: Dance: Miss Fedicheva
description: U.S. Terpsichore, which has undertaken a week of performances at Marymount Manhattan Theater, presented on Thursday evening Kaleriya Fedicheva, formerly a principal dancer of the Kirov Ballet, who is now living in the United States. It made for a tearfully warm occasion.

title: Abuses Laid to F.B.I. in Hearst Search
description: HARRISBURG Pa Aug. 15 The Federal Bureau of Investigation was accused today of using illegal wiretaps mail intercepts prejudicial publicity and a general pattern of governmental harassment in its unsuccessful 18month search for Patricia Hearst.

title: National League
description: San Francisco 6, New York 2 (1st, twi). New York 9, San Francisco 4 (2d). Houston 4, Chicago 1. Montreal 8, Los Angeles 4. Cincinnati 8, Pittsburgh 3. Philadelphia 4. San Diego 3. St. Louis 4, Atlanta 1 (1st, twi.). St. Louis 2, Atlanta 1 (2d).

title: Gen. Haig Testifies On the C.I.A.'s Role In Chilean Aff airs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., former White House chief of staff under President Nixon, testified today on Central Intelligence Agency involvement in Chilean affairs in 1970 in a closed meeting with members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, sources familiar with the investigation said.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CLEVELAND (AL)Placed John Ellis, catcher, on 15day disabled list with Pulled hamstring in right leg. Recalled Rick Cerone, catcher, from Oklahoma City. of the American Association.

title: BEARING IS ENDED FOR WALTEMADE
description: After eight weeks and more than one million words of testimony, the hearing to determine if a State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx should be removed from the bench ended yesterday on a characteristically bizarre note.

title: National Airlines Reports Profit in the 4th Quarter
Cash Prices
description: SUP. 13 AUL 14

title: Eleanor Wendt Wed To Rolfe K. Hughes
description: Eleanor Wannemacher Wendt of Montclair, N. J., widow of J. Henry Wendt, was married at noon yesterday to Rolfe K. Hughes, a widower of Nutley. N.J.

title: Cats Are a Pet Cause In the Notices Posted At City Supermarkets
description: Supermarkets are sober and calculating, but beneath those marts of gold lies a smidgen of sentiment.

title: Kennecott's Dividend Cut to 25c From 50c
description: Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation voted yesterday to cut the quarterly dividend to 25 cents from 50 cents. It is payable Sept. 22 to stockholders of record Aug. 26.

title: Market Place
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, the smallest of the Big Five international oil companies, is regarded as somewhat undervalued in Wall Street where it had long been viewed with reservations.

title: 4 Directors Added To Exchange Board
description: New York Stock Exchange members voted here yesterday to add four new directors to the exchange's 20man board, all from Big Board firms. The exchange's board of directors, which has 10 members representing Wall Street and 10 representing the public, would thus have the balance of power in the hands of stockbrokers.

title: Oil Companies, Already Plying Ocean, Believe Offshore Drilling Is Inevitable
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI)Major oil companies, which are spending thousands of dollars a day exploring the Atlantic Ocean far enough out from shore not to be observed, believe drilling for oil off the shore of New Jersey is inevitable.

title: Jets Are Eager to Beat Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15The Budweiser Clydesdales probably get more fan mail than the Cardinals football players, who will have to prove again tomorrow night that they really exist.

title: Taiwan Victor, 21
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 16  Lee Chung Yung pitched a twohitter as Taiwan won the championship of the 1975 Big League World Series tonight with a 21 victory over San Antonio, Tex.

title: Coast City Upheld on Broad Growth Curbs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16A Federal appeals Court upheld this week the legality of what environmental and legal experts throughout the country have characterized as one of the mostfarreaching growthcontrol ordinances ever enacted by a small city.

title: Dock Ellis Suspended By Pirates
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (UPI)Dock Ellis, the Pittsburgh Pirates' controversial righthander, was indefinitely suspended without pay today after throwing a temper tantrum at Manager Danny Murtaugh.

title: S. J. Del Giacco Weds Mary K. Lanigan
description: Mary Kay Lanigan and Stephen J. Del Giacco were married yesterday afternoon at St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. The Rev Robert T. Dunn performed the ceremony.

title: The Winter Wife
description: We meet the Indian hunter, alone in the bleak rawness of the winter woods. He has set traps and, unafraid of cold and storms, fears only loneliness. And then one day he sees the moose. There is a suggestion of intimacy and understanding as the moose recognizes the hunter's loneliness. From that day his traps are full and his longing for companionship is fulfilled by the mystifying appearance of a hauntingly tender silent woman. She is the winter wife. The chill of the frosty woods thaws in the warmth of the hunter's new happiness. But the days pass and the hunter returns in the spring to the village of his father. For the first time the winter wife speaks to warn him against marrying another. The hunter goes to the village without her, and through the summer months he yearns for her. With the first snow, he returns to the silent wife, and now there is a child. Several years pass in similar fashion. The hunter becomes wealthy but each summer he must go back to the village where pressures build to marry the chief's daughter. Two worlds vie for the hunter's affections and finally he makes an unusual choice.

title: Access to Airport Will Be Improved
description: NEWARKHoping to reverse declining passenger business at Newark International Airport's handsome new terminals, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the state are moving on two fronts to improve access to the airport.

title: Libertarian Party Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Libertarian party, with national headquarters here, announced Wednesday that Robert H. Meier, of Chicago, is its new national director. Mr. Meier, 30 years old, succeeds Ned Hutchinson, who died last March.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Sparky Lyle, Yankees' reliever who has been having his problems this season: I feel I'm still as good as anybody. I just haven't shown it

title: CBS
description: Fifty years ago a fractured radio beam went out from New York to a motley collection of stations. The broadcast was noteworthy for little except it marked shaky beginnings of the Columbia Broadcasting System, a company that, in the intervening half century, has elegantly rushed to our democracy's defense and blatantly pandered to its meanest democratic tastes. C.B.S. has given us Edward R. Murrow, Petticoat Junction and enough tales of corporate plotting and chicanery to make the mediamovers the railroad barons of our century. It has all happened so quickly that many of the men who created and nurtured C.B.S., and the radio and TV industry, are still walking our streets.

title: Hotel to Become Apartment House
description: Delmonico's Hotel, on the northwest corner of Park Avenue and 59th Street, is to be converted Into a rental apartment building by William Zeckendorf Jr.

title: Savoir Winner In Trot
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 16Savoir, with Del Insko substituting as driver for the hospitalized John Chapman, easily won the $50,000 American Trotting championship tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The victory put Savoir in next Saturday night's $200,000 Roosevelt International as the United States representative.

title: The Effects of Ice on Scotch
description: In countries where Scotch has been consumed for centuries, ice and whisky ly mingle. But on this side of the Atlantic, the picture is quite different. While a small percentage of American Scotch drinkers take it neat, better than 35% drink it on the rocks. The rest of us add varying amounts of water, dub soda, etcetera. And ice. Always plenty of ice the great American drink requisite.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: When the talk turns these days to ways of lifting the economy out of its slumpparticularly in terms of employmentmuch of it centers on incentives for business investment in general and the purchase of equipment in particular. The equipment tax credit has even, strangely, been labeled a job development credit, although among its effects must certainly be some inducement to substitute machinery for labor.

title: HUNT FOR WRECKS TO START ON SEPT. 1
description: Two wire drag ships will begin searching New York Harbor next month for at least nine wrecks regarded as dangerous to shipping. The wrecks are strung out in the Barnegat to Ambrose traffic lane, an area 2 to 11 miles off the New York New Jersey Coast, stretching in a southerly direction from a point in the Ambrose Channel, five miles off Rockaway Beach, to a point off Sea Girt, N.J.

title: TShirts Given Artistic Touch
description: SOUTHAMPTON  Silkscreen Sarabelle has a mission. The screen printer otherwise known as Sarabelle PrincePicasso is an artist, I'm a screen printerwould like to share her craft [or art] with as many people as she can.

title: O'DWYER OPPOSES CHARTER REVISION
description: City Council President Paul O'Dwyer assailed the prosposed new City Charter yesterday for its provision that would eliminate the office of Controller as presently constituted and said he had no choice but to oppose the charter in toto.

title: A Tribute to The Modern's LongLost, Adventurous Past
description: The Museum of Modern Art's new exhibition, Modem Masters: Manet to Matisse, is a beautiful collection of more than 100 paintings that begins with a nod to Manet and carries on through to the School of Paris in the 1950's. It is an informal history in which anyone interested in those wonderful hundred years (Manet's Boy with a Sword, which opens the exhibition, was painted in 1861) can find omissions and overemphases, even without questioning the limitation to European painting. But a foolproof historical survey in fewer than several hundred examples would be impossible. The beauty of this selection is that the ranks of familiar but individually inexhaustible paintings are punctuated here and there by surprises, and that all, familiar and unfamiliar, are conjoined into an extraor dinary unity by the personal taste of William S. Lieberman, who organized the exhibition for showings in Australia under the sponsorship of the museum's International Council.

title: Town Drops Reassessment Effort
description: GALLATIN, N. Y.Even before the Court of Appeals ruled recently that all real property in New York State must be assessed at 100 per cent of market value, the assessors in this rural Columbia County town had tried to meet that standard, but gave up in despair.

title: State Police Defended by Chief
description: WEST TRENTONAn anticipated legislative investigation of the state police next month will, in the opinion of the force's retiring superintendent, bear out my contention that we don't have to take a back seat to any other state police organization in the country.

title: Sets Defeated, 2622; Face Playoff Tonight
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16Iron City beer, not champagne, was the postgame beverage for the New York Sets, who lost to the Pittsburgh Triangles, 2622, tonight in a match that decided first place in the Eastern Division of World Team TennisBy winning, the Triangles gained an openinground bye in the playoffs, whereas the Sets must return to Nassau Coliseum tomorrow night for a onematch playoff with the Boston Lobsters. The SetsLobster winner meets Pittsburgh in the semifinals, a twoofthreegame series beginning Monday.Paced by Evonne Goolagong Cawley's 62 triumph over Billie Jean King and a 63 victory in the men's doubles, the Triangles made short work of New York. They finished the season with a wonlost record of 368 to New York's 3410.The largest crowd in the league's twoyear history, 10,850, cheered the Triangles. The Sets have never won a match in Pittsburgh's iglooshaped Civic Arena.I just get outplayed here, what can I tell you? said Mrs. King. I wouldn't mind having the support at home.Mrs. Cawley had opened with erratic play in the women's doubles, which she and Peggy Michel lost to Virginia Wade and Mona Schallau, 63. But the roaring support of the home crowd helped steady her in the singles, and she trounced Mrs. King.Billie Jean's volleys, particularly her backhand, were weak, and with growing agitation she watched Mrs. Cawley's shots improve in accuracy and strength.Evonne Coolly held service in the seventh game with four straight points and broke Mrs. King's service twice during the set. The crowd leaped to its feet screaming as Mrs. Cawley stretched to return what looked like a winning drop shot and they stood again when she claimed the seventh game with a deep forehand that touched the line, passing Billie Jean by a few feet.

title: Miss Studley Is Wed to Eric Zahler
description: Jamienne Shayne Studley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack H. Studley of Woodridge, N.Y., was married last night to Eric Jeffery Zahler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Zahler of North Merrick, L.I. The couple graduated in June from the Harvard Law School.

title: Cranford Students Excavate Old Mill
description: CRANFORD  Archeology is where you dig it, not just in exotic lands, and a group of New Jersey students have found that they need travel only short distances to explore the past.

title: B'nai B'rith Says H.U.D. Is Blocking Housing for Aged
description: HOUSTONB'nai B'rith, the Jewish service organization, which now has five fully occupied lowrent housing developments for the elderly and a sixth scheduled for completion, says that it is blocked in its efforts to accelerate the nonprofit, nonsectarian programby a lack of Government mortagage loans.

title: City Agency Heads Told to Designate Women's Advisers
description: In an effort to encourage equal opportunity for women in the city's government, Mayor Beame directed the heads of all the city's agencies yesterday to designate a member of their staffs to serve as a women's adviser.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: SEATTLEWilliam McPherson Allen, a man who took some of the biggest gambles in the history of American businessand won most of themsays One secret to success is finding and trusting good managers, and then leavening their output with a grain of salt.

title: Nontitle Fight Won By Conteh
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 11 (AP)  The World Boxing Council's lightheavyweight champion, John, Conteh of England, used his left jab to bloody New York's Willie Taylor tonight, and earn a 10round unanimous decision.

title: The best doubleheader all summer
description: Eric Hoffer once wrote that the first thing he looked for when studying a certain period in history was what games they played. Much could be) learned, he advised, from the created leisure of civilization. Inadvertently (I am sure), the old dockwalloper has found disciples of his theory over the last decadenot least among the authors of several recent baseballassocialhistory books.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Ways and styles. What's the best way to cope with the pressures of modern living? Cherish the ways of our agrarian past? Adopt alternate lifestyles? During the past half dozen years two works, with their own answers to those questions, have each sold 1,500,000 copies. Both will be reappearing in updated gear during the next few weeks.

title: Mary Margaret Nugent Wed To Robert Patrick McGovern
description: Mary Margaret Nugent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Paul Nugent of Morristown, N. J., and Watch Hill, R. I., was married in New Vernon, N. J., at noon yesterday to Robert Patrick McGovern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Paul McGovern of Chatham,.N. J.

title: The Hazards of Label Phrasing
description: Businessmen generally are not a literary lot, but lately many have been perusing the printed word with positively avid interest. What they are reading is hardly the stuff with which to while away a lazy vacationit's labels, the prose that is stamped, printed, pasted, branded, riveted or tattooed on products headed for the consumer or industrial market.

title: Mt. Sinai Names Director
description: Samuel Davis, executive president of Mount Sinai Hospital of Minneapolis, has been named director of Mount Sinai Hospital of Ne wYork, at Fifth Avenue and 100th Street, and senior vice president of its medical center. He succeeds as director Dr. S. David Pomrinse, who will continue as the hospital's chief administrative officer and as executive vice president of the medical center, according to Gustave L. Levy, Mount Sinai board chairman.

title: What's Doing in THE MAINE LAKE COUNTRY
description: THE LAND  Maine's lakes and mountain trails are not as highly touted as its famous rockribbed coast, but they draw millions of fishermen and lovers of the outdoors. There is plenty of elbow room, for the state has 17 million acres of forest land, 2,500 lakes and 5,000 rivers and streams. Fall foliage watchers start heading ??on Maine as early as midSeptembet to catch the leaves changing color. Agricultural fairs scheduled to coincide with the seasonal display include the Lewiston State Fair, which runs from Sept. 5 through 13 and features an Old McDonald Farm exhibit for the edification of city slickers, and the Oxford County Agricultural Fair from Sept. 10 to 14, in South Paris with pig scrambles and a lamb auction. The Maine Department of Conservation (2072892791) will issue weekly reports in September on how the fcliage color is coming along. Exceptional viewing areas include the Moosehead Lake region and Grafton Notch State Park, near Fryeburg, where the color reaches its peak about Oct. 1.

title: Pirates Bow, 53; Losing String at 5
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP) Tony Perez's tiebreaking tworun homer and Cesar Geronimo's clout in the eighth inning powered the Cincinnati Reds to a 53 triumph that sent the Pittsburgh Pirates staggering to their fifth straight defeat.

title: S.D. Ryan 3d Weds Miss Handy
description: The marriage of Evelyne Romaine. Handy, a greatgreat  granddaughter of Charles B. Manville, cofounder of the JohnsManville Corporation, to Stephen David Ryan 3d, a greatgrandson of James Butler, the grocery chainstore magnate, took place in the outdoor chapel of St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., yesterday afternoon.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Those fussbudgets forever fidgeting with their jewelry will love the quartet of mobile pendants at Altman'schic toys of sterling and 18karat gold, little puppetlike figures to dangle on a chain.

title: ANGOLAN LEADER REPORTED SEIZED
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Mateus Neto, a leader of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, one of the territory's three feuding independence movements, was kidnapped in Luanda yesterday by six armed men, his wife, who is living here, said today.

title: Introspective Prima Donna
description: I'm a shy person who doesn't fit into the star pattern of glamour and personality, confesses Benita Valente. On Friday and Saturday nights the Met soprano will be appearing in just the kind of musical environment she seems to prefernot as a star but as part of an ensemble, doing the role of Hanne in Haydn's oratorio The Seasons, the final offering of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Namath Sits Out Jet Victory
description: ST LOUIS, Aug. 16For the second straight hot Saturday night, the New York Jets toppled a defending division champion. Tonight they posted a dramatic 1413 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in the last two minutes.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Brattleboro, Vt., to participate in the Experiment in International Living, you will have a choice of summer programs ranging from four to eight weeks in duration and spring and fall programs lasting 15 weeks in duration. Successful completion of any of the programs entitles the participant to academic credit.

title: F.B.I. CHECKING TIP OF HOFFA'S BURIAL
description: DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation searched a construction site in northern Lower Michigan, and the family of James R. Hoffa unveiled a bumper sticker campaign today in efforts to find the former president of the international Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Sandra Gordon Bride Of Charles P. Starkey
description: Sandra Scott Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Gordon of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon in San Francisco to Charles Pritchard Starkey of San Francisco, where the ceremony was perfromed in the Calvary Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Robert Young.

title: Nobody Makes Me Cry
description: 261 pp. New York: Saturday Review Press. $7.95.

title: Test of UniTicket Is Begun in Nassau
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has begun a sixmonth UniTicket experiment in two Nassau County communities designed to increase ridership to and from Long Island Rail Road stations.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayAmerican Hot Rod Association National Challenge drag racing at National Speedway, Center Moriches., L. I. (Exit 70 Long Island Expressway). Gates open at 8 A.M., practice: 10 A.M., racing starts at 2 P.M.

title: A.K.C. Tightens Requirements For Facilities at Show Grounds
description: More and more complaints are being registered by fanciers about conditions at show sites. Frequently the exhibitor has a long distance to walk from the parking area to the rings. Rest room facilities often are inadequate. There may be only one vehicle entrance to the grounds, causing a traffic backup.

title: Caren Levine Plans A Wedding in June
description: Carl Levine of New York, a vice president of Bloomingdale's, and Adrienne Levine of Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caren Levine, to Kenneth B. Stanley, an instructor of speech art and science at Hofstra University.

title: W. Reed Moran Weds Cathy Ann Carlson
description: Cathy Ann Carlson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland F. Carlson of Berkeley Heights, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to W. Reed Moran, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Moran of Greenwich, Conn., and Eastham, Mass.

title: Schools Differ on What to Do With the Gifted Children
description: In most public schools, gifted children are given low priorityMany become bored with the regular curriculum and are not stimulated to their educational capacity. Whether these students should be given special, more challenging programs is a matter of debate among educators.

title: Letitia Lynn, D. R. Valiunas Plan Marriage
description: Angier Biddle Duke, Commissioner of Civic Affairs and Public Events, and Mrs. Duke of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Duke's daughter, Letitia Chandler Lynn, to Dominicus Rytis Valiunas, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Valiunas of New Rochelle, N. Y., formerly of Kaunas and Saulial, Lithuania.

title: A Bountiful Blackberry Harvest
description: Blackberry, big, plump and velvety black, is the deluxe berry. The flavor is acidsweet, rich and heady, like no other.

title: CHANGE IS URGED FOR MATTEAWAN
description: Benjamin Ward, State Commissioner of Correctional Services, is urging that Mattewan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane, which critics have long called a horror house, be transferred from his department to the Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Answers/Questions
description: ANT HILL (July 27)

title: Joseph Durso
description: When the baseball season lowers the curtain next month, Robert Merrill will reluctantly leave his regular spot on the grass near second base and immediately open two other seasons. He will join the Baltimore Colts on their stadium grass Sept. 28 when they play the Oakland Raiders in the National Football League. Then he will head for the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House in New York for the season that really counts. Whatever the season, he will be there to do one thing: sing. And by November, when the World Series has faded away and maybe the Baltimore Colts, too, he will be deep into his 30th season in grand opera  starring in The Masked Ball and La Traviata but sort of yearning for the start of spring training and another summer of The Starspangled Banner.

title: A NEBRASKA FAN FIGIIIS POLLUTION
description: PAPILLION, Neb.  Larry Schram, a cattle feeder who weighs over 200 pounds, is sometimes referred to jocularly by his friends as the world's biggest guinea pig.

title: The Forgotten Americans
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 16In the last few days, the Foreign Secretary of Mexico, Emilio O. Rabasa, has been in Moscow signing art economic, scientific and technological agreement with the Soviet Union and the other members of the Communist economic bloc.

title: West Berlin Reforming Its Prisons
description: BERLINWhen Horst Du??k gets up in the morning to go to work he is awakened by a prison guard, not an alarm clock. No later than 9 P.M., after supper with his wife and two children, he returns to Tegel Prison, West Berlin's largest, where he is serving time for burglary and theft. He expects to be home soon for good.

title: Swan Beats Giants, 42, In His Return to Mets
description: The Mets' staff of starting pitchers, bothered by an assortment of minor injuries in recent days, was bolstered yesterday when Craig Swan made a strong showing to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 42, before a dampened and chilled crowd of 20,751 at Shea Stadium.

title: STAMPS
description: It was inevitable that the Soviet Union, having for the first time allowed its people to see on television one of its ventures in space, last month's joint mission with the United States, would make a philatelic todo about the ApolloSoyuz linkup. It has.

title: Eyewitness Book Gives Insight on Lincoln Plot
description: A vivid eyewitness narrative of the events leading up to the assassination of Abraham Lincoln and of the trial of the conspirators, unknown to historians, has come to light and will be published as a book next month. The manuscript was written in the eighteennineties by Louis J. Weichmann, a key prosecution witness at the plotters' trial in 1865, as his final recounting of an experience that had haunted his life.

title: A Trip Into History On the Westport Bus
description: THIS is Joanne Woodward, your Westport neighbor, welcoming you on behalf of the Bicentennial Committee to Westport's History on Wheels. The mellifluous voice comes over the loudspeaker in Westport's Bicentennial bus, which is about to take off on its maiden tour of the Connecticut town's historic sites. As the last passengers board, a wellgroomed blond matron rushes up demanding, Is Joanne Woodward here? When she finds out that Miss Woodward's voice is embalmed on tape, she apologizes and departs. I just wanted to get a good look at her husband, she says.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Surprise, the Bass Are Biting
description: MENEMSHA, Mass.Vineyard Sound was shimmering and still except for small ground swells when we set forth from Menemsha in our 22foot launch to cast for striped bass along the north shore of Martha's Vineyard Island.

title: The Fare Increases May Not Be the Last, Either
description: The upcoming fare increases on New York City's subways and buses will do little to solve the region's longrange transportation problems. But they clearly are bringing the city's fiscal problems to the suburbs.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: In 1961, Bashir Ahmed, a Pakistani camel driver, was riding a crest of fame. Invited by then Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson to visit the United States, he toured this country as a celebrity and received a new Ford truck as a gift. He went home to Pakistan a folk hero.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TV VIEW
description: I returned from the Netherlands to U.S. Customs at Kennedy Airport without having anything to declare about Dutch television. (Except for the women and the beer, everything in Holland is flat.) This was a mistake, for a great newspaper was waiting for its copy. And so, feeling a little like Captain Jetlag himself, David Frost, I sat down last Saturday night to watch my first. American TV program in almost a month. That program turned out to be The First Annual Rock Music Awards on CBS.

title: DR. JOSEPH KLEIN, TAX EXPERT, DIES
description: Dr. Joseph J. Klein, a lawyer and accountant specializing in tax law and a teacher, died yesterday at his home, 101 Central Park West. He was 91 years old.

title: Pool Insurance Rates Face 35% Rise
description: More than 91,000 tenants and owners in New York State who are insured under the socalled Fair Plan may soon be hit with rate increases averaging 35 per cent, largely because of claims resulting from the recent rash of fires in the South Bronx.

title: The Man At the Wheel
description: AT exactly 9 A.M., Al Young swung closed the stainless steel door on Greyhound Americruiser 3285. He switched on the ignition and the whine of the eightcylinder diesel in the rear compartment resounded at the front of the coach. He put an envelope with 16 passenger tickets on the dashboard, then checked the rearview mirror as he rested his right foot on the accelerator. A tremor of vibration rattled the bus as it backed off Platform 14 of the lower level of New York's Port Authority bus terminal. As he had done thousands of times before, Al nudged the shift lever into forward gear and maneuvered the bus through a wide curve and onto West 40th Street. At 9:01 A.M. Run Number 2086, express service to Boston, was on the road.

title: Azoreans Try to Keep Out of Lisbon Strife
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores, Aug. 16There are 300,000 people on these Portuguese islands between New York and Lisbon and almost everyone has a relative in the United States.

title: NureyevThe Canadians' Passport
description: To finish one's brief career as a dance critic by being publicly denounced in these pages by Martha Graham, and then to go on to a brand new career as a drama critic, must seem rather exciting. John Fraser, the young Canadian writer who stirred up such a surprising furor by suggesting in this section of The Times on July 27 that Rudolf Nureyev should keep out of Canadian ballet, has for the last two or three years been dance critic of the Toronto Globe and Mail. Beginning next season, he is taking his considerable charm and limited experience to the drama desk on the same publication. Although Mr. Fraser basically Deems to a very nice person, he unfortunately works himself up into a passion about things Canadian.

title: Soviet Says Divorces Tripled in 13 Years
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Divorce in the Soviet Union nearly tripled between 1960 and 1973, according to official figures quoted this week in the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta.

title: Shop Talk
description: ROCHELLE PARK  Are you into Mediterranean dcor, but not as deeply as you would like? Do you covet ornamental ironwork, large lamp bases of glass or perhaps a squarebuilt chair covered in red velvet and decorated with nail heads?

title: A Democratic Alternative
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Speaker Carl Albert is making headway with a plan that could significantly influence the 1976 campaign and, if his party wins, the formative months of a new Democratic administration.

title: CHESS
description: Opening national championships to foreign participants is an old tradition that is currently being revived in Europe. Earlier this year, Germany, which had held its first international championship in 1879, but broke off the series in 1927, staged its West German international championship, the third in a new oddyear series begun in 1971. Now Switzerland has followed suit with an international championship of its own.

title: Miss Gresser Wed to B. C. Petermann
description: Deborah Grasser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Newton H. Gresser of Hackensack, N. J., and Sippewissett, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Bradford Charles Petermann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Petermann of New Milford, N. J.

title: Wall Street's New Reality
description: Weeden & Co., long a gadfly of the Wall Street establishment and an advocate of restructuring the nation's securities markets, is finding itself under pressure from some of the very business forces it has helped to unleash.

title: Bushwick Traffic To Be Improved
description: A new program designed to increase roadway capacity along Bushwick Avenue in Brooklyn during rush hours is under way.

title: Patricia Gould, J. M. Rossbach Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maxime Gor don Gould of Kingswood, Surrey, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Elizabeth Gould, to James Michael Rossbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rossbach of New York.

title: TV Notes: The Case of the TriggerHappy Letter Writers
description: Nothing triggers emotional mail like the announcement of a TV documentary involving guns. Last March, NBC News was riddled with letters, mostly wrathful, about a documentary produced by Lucy Jarvis and entitled A Shooting Gallery Called America. Such a response from viewers would not have been unusual except for the fact that the documentary had not yet been shown. Miss Jarvis, wanting more time to work on her film, had it withdrawn shortly before its originally scheduled air date but too late to change the program listings in the press. The letter writers who professed to have seen the documentary had in fact seen only the log listing of a postponed show.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Good Luck, Roy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Friday's Fights
description: TokyoMasahiro Misako, 152 pounds, Japan, outpointed Min Cho, 154, South Korea, 10 rounds.

title: Executives, Seasonally Adjusted
description: It's August again, and off go the nation's top executives in pursuit of fish, forests and forgetfulnessoften with the wholehearted support of the management experts who hold that a little less total commitment to corporation improves headoffice performance.

title: ZUMWALT WEIGHS RACE IN VIRGINIA
description: WILLIAMSBURG, VA., Aug. 15The retired admiral who brought long haid to the Navy, billeted women on ships of the line and gave a better break to black seamen during his widely publicized tour as Chief of Naval Operations is cruising Virginia this summer and making waves on the otherwise calm political waters of Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr.

title: Learning to See With Dogs
description: SMITHTOWNThe Guide Dog Foundation in Smithtown, which has put the word mobility back in the lives of hundreds of blind men and women, is running a fiveweek program that costs the students nothing and gives them room and board, a qualified dog, equipment and instruction on how to handle a dog.

title: Chart of The Travers
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: INTEGRATION ROLE ON CITIES ASSAYED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 15Analysis of Federal data on the racial composition of American public elementary schools does not bear out the widespread assumption that desegregation significantly encourages the exodus of whites from the cities to the suburbs, according to a University of Michigan demographer.

title: Saratoga Scene
description: The summer meeting at Saratoga race track means, to many, an annual pilgrimage. It is a holiday in a picturesque setting, an opportunity to enjoy the August sun and the thrill of watching your horse come from behind and win a close stretch battle with the oddson favorite.

title: S. KEIN CLOSES AFTER 65 YEARS
description: Klein's department store, a bargainhunter's paradise on Union Square for 65 years, dosed its doors yesterday with little fanfare and few mourners.

title: Eugenie McKay Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Eugenic Maxine McKay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. McKay Jr. of Flushing, Queens, and Candlewood Isle, Conn., to Michael Andrew Kolivosky took place in Jamaica Estates, Queens, yesterday morning.

title: A Reporter's Notebook on the Hamptons
description: SOUTHAMPTONThis is the time of year to be in Suffolk County.

title: $1Million XRay Contract
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP)The National Cancer Institute of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has award a $1million contract, to a Cambridge concern, American Science and Engineering, Inc., to develop a computerized Xray, that photographs slices of the human body.

title: Varied Sailing Routes Make Vineyard Race Risky to Pick
description: Entries for the 41st annual Vineyard Race from Stamford, Conn., to Buzzard's Bay Entrance Light and back close tomorrow. A fleet of more than 100 yachts is expected to start the 236mile race, one of the most prestigious in the f??, on Aug. 29. The ?? is ??ed by the Stamford Yacht Club, which also awards the Northern Ocean Racing Trophy for outstanding performance in four major distance races, including the Vineyard.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Maine Harp Colony Thrives, and Sound Is Not Ethereal
description: CAMDEN, Me.Elbows up, fingers well  rounded, a young woman plucked the strings of a harp while her teacher, Jeanne Chalifoux, cried out in an encouraging sort of way:

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Chicago White Sox meet the New York Yankees in a threegame series at Shea Stadium beginning Tuesday. All three games begin at 8 o'clock. The California Angels face the Yankees Friday night and Saturday at 2 P.M.

title: ExCoast Nazi Leader Slair
description: EL MONTE, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP)The former local head of the American Nazi party was shot to death yesterday in front of the group's El Monte headquarters. The police arrested an 18yearold youth for investigation of murder in the slaying of Joseph C. Tommassi, 24, of El Monte, who had formed a splinter group of the organization a year ago.

title: Report Warns of Peril of Too Many Sewerage Systems
description: TRENTONA report detailing the findings of a joint Federalstate study on regional sewerage systems warns that, although such facilities are the critical ingredient and guiding force for growth in New Jersey, too many of them may be counterproductive for the state.

title: Reasons for Keeping City Bonds
description: With the Municipal Assistance Corporation's $960million bond sale last week seemingly again saving New York City from default, owners of the city's $7billion of bonds and $4billion of notes can relaxuntil the next M.A.C. sale, planned for September.

title: U.S. Couple Tell of Quiet Saigon Mood
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16An American husbandwife team just back from Saigon reports hat the most striking change in the city's atmosphere since the Communist victory is an absence of tension.

title: Payson Brickley Weds Ann Pyle, Gallery Aide
description: Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Seal Harbor, Me., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Ann Townsend Pyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Tolman Pyle of Oyster Bay, L.L, to Payson Brickley, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Payson Brickley of Wayne, Pa.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: NEW YORK. PARIS. LONDON. BRUSSELS. BOSTON. CORAL GABLES. COLUMBIA. MD. OPENING SOON IN WINNETKA FORT LAUDERDALE.

title: Nastase, Orantes In Final
description: TORONTO, Aug, 16 (AP)Marcie Louie of San Francisco defeated Laura DuPont of Charlotte, N.C., 61, 46, 64, in the women's singles final of the $130,000 Canadian open tennis championships today. The victory was worth $6,000.

title: No New York State Judge Has Ever Been Removed for Courtroom Behavior
description: You just can't tell what happens to a man once he mounts the bench, a lawyer active in judicial politics said recently.

title: Preseason Football
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: The Region
description: Two men in a position to know about the business affairs that led to the indictment of Bernard Bergman have themselves pleaded guilty to related Federal charges and will testify against the New York nursing home entrepreneur.

title: Flopping with a network that succeeded
description: Poor Sally! The way she tells it she had a perfectly awful time two summers ago when she was plucked from her happy hearth writing spicy social features for The Washington Post's Style section to be coanchor of the C.B.S. Morning News. We're Going to Make You a Star is her account of the nationally publicized meteoric fall of Sally Quinn, and it is a sad tale indeed.

title: A Haven for the Commuters
description: BERGENFIELDThis is a great town to live in, said Mrs. Edythe Hiller, who moved here from The Bronx eight years ago. The signs as yon enter the borough say, Welcome to the City of Friendly People, and, as far as I'm concerned, that's the way it is. Bergenfield is a selfcontained unit. Everything we need is here.

title: Denise Packer, Geologist, Married
description: In St. Philomena Roman Catholic Church in Livingston, N. J., yesterday morning, Denise Edwina Packer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Simpson Packer of Livingson, was married to Richard Charles Quittmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Quittmeyer of Port Washington, L. I.

title: Elaine Kobin Is Bride of Eric Berson
description: Elaine Beth Kobin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kobin of Woodmere, L. I., was married last night to Eric C. Berson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour B. Berson, also of Woodmere. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Saul Teplitz in the Sephardic Temple, Cedarhurst.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The head of the bridge and tunnel officers' union has threatened a strike against the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority because the agency plans to use automated toll gates for tokens, starting Sept. 1. The union head, Anthony Mauro, said the plan imperiled 650 jobs.

title: South Lebanon: A Reluctant Battlefield
description: KAFR KILA, Lebanon, Aug. 16  Israeli artillery opened sporadic fire this morning on the brown stony hills and orchards that roll along the Lebanese border from Mount Hermon to the Mediterranean.

title: When Music Takes To the Streets
description: Walking along Fifth Avenue these days is a little like switching stations on a radio. Through the roar of buses and blare of horns comes the plunk of a bluegrass string band on 53d, the soothing tones of a Bach flute sonata on 52d, the skirl of bagpipes on 51st, the bellow of a trumpet on 50th. This summer there have been more street musicians, than ever, plucking, bowing, strumming on their instruments despite steamy cement heat, bus exhaust, deafening decibels and being chased by cops.

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: Mortgage holders have taken over three midtown commercial properties.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 401.1 from 418.8 a week earlier. A year ago it was 405.1.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: 6 ORDERED TO AID STORM KING STUDY
description: The Public Service Commission has ordered the six other major power utilities in the state to cooperate with the Consolidated Edison Company on a study of Con Edison's stated need for the Storm King Mountain pumped  storage project at CornwallonHudson.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Joan Phillips of Sotheby's Bride Of Stephen B. Timbers in Ohio
description: Joan Phillips, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Konstantine Phillips of Youngstown, Ohio, was married there yesterday afternoon to Stephen Bryan Timbers, son of Mrs. Aalseth Henly of McLean, Va., and James G. Timbers of Hinsdale, Ill.

title: ...Angola's Agony
description: Though often indecisive in confronting the political crosscurrents of his homeland, Portugal's President Costa Gomes has taken a necessary firm stand in Angola. He has ordered colonial military commanders to reassume executive power in the Angolan capital, a move designed to forestall a forceful takeover by the Marxist Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, one of three rival nationalist factions struggling for postindependence power.

title: Blanche Ittleson, 99, Dies; A Pioneer in Mental Health
description: Blanche Frank Ittleson, a pioneer in mental health care, died yesterday at her home here. She was 99 years old and lived also in Kintnersville, Pa., and formerly in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Crater Lake Inquiry May Cause Health Changes in Park System
description: CRATER LAKE, Ore., Aug. 16Closer monitoring of routine health tests, along with other changes, particularly in improving internal communications, are likely here and possibly throughout the National Park Systems.

title: Ballet PartnersMatches Not Made in Heaven
description: In front of the golden curtain, in the blaze of the footlights, the ballerina wrests a single scarlet rose from an armful of flowers. To the accompaniment of the audience's applause, she kisses the flower and, bowing, offers it to her cavalier. Accepting italways as if it were the first time such an impetuous gesture had been madehe bends and kisses the inside of her wrist.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor.

title: Troops in Portugal Rescue Reds Under Attack by Mob
description: ALCOBACA, Portugal, Sunday, Aug. 17 Troops arrived in this embattled town early this morning to rescue Alvaro Cunhal, the Portuguese Communist leader, and several hundred of his followers who had been trapped by an antiCommunist mob while attempting to hold a party rally.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Entomologists are having another look at Japanese beetle control. Phone calls from golf course superintendents who are concerned about increased grub damage to their lawns and complaints from gardeners who are seeing more adult beetles on their roses, zinnias, grapevines and corn silks have caused the bug experts to have a look around and see what's up.

title: Mary Alicia Shiland Has Nuptials
description: Mary Alicia Shiland, daughter of Mrs, Ralph Stewart Gallagher of Chappaqua, N.Y, and the late Andrew Shiland, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Elder Rounds Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Rounds of Norwell, Mass. Msgr. R. J. Skelly performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Mary in Chappaqua, assisted by the Rev. Robert Jones of Norwell, an Episcopal priest.

title: Music: Organ Concert
description: The organ is so much a?? instrument of the indoorschurches, theaters, home par lorsthat to see it outside seems heretical.

title: With Mile Mark Below 3:50, Prospect of a 3:40 Is Raised
description: Is a 3:40 mile possible? Yes, and it probably will happen by the year 2000, according to an informal poll of track and field experts conducted after John Walker of New Zealand broke the 3:50 barrier last Tuesday with a clocking of 3 minutes 49.4 seconds in Goteborg, Sweden.

title: Clinton Will Present Bicentennial Concerts
description: CLINTONAs a part of its Bicentennial celebration, the Clinton Historical Museum Village will present one of a series of concerts next Saturday night.

title: Town Gives Strays New Lease on Life
description: EAST BRUNSWICKStray pet animals found in this town no longer face the probability of being put to death if they are not claimed by their owners in seven days; formation of the Animal Rescue Force has given them a lease on life.

title: Dr. Steiphardt Weds Alice Rogers
description: Alice Meier Rogers of Scarsdale, N.Y., a therapist at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Guidance Center, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Roger Steinhardt, an internist here.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Our house has a brick and concrete stoop that, was painted brick red by the previous owner. I was told that the red paint would stain the shiny new vinyl floor covering we are putting down inside as tiny particles are carried in by shoes. Can you tell me if all paint were removed from the stoop would we then have trouble with red dust (from the bricks) being tracked in? How can we remove the paint without damaging evergreens that surround the stoop?C.W., New Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: N.C. A. A. Economy Steps Called Too Few by Colleges
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 16College administrators expressed dissappointment with the National Collegiate Athletic Association's attempts to establish serious and immediate costsaving programs during its special convention on economy this week. But some executives did express optimism that the N.C.A.A. might develop broad fiscal policies in the future that could mean big savings for the majority of the 703 member institutions.

title: Leslie J. Bryan Wed To William B. Maloy
description: Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Oak Bluffs, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Leslie Joan Bryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Henan Bryan of Wilton, Conn., and East Chop, Mass., to William Bruce Maloy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe Bruce Maloy Jr. of Hendersonville, N.C. The Rev. James W. Clark performed the ceremony.

title: DACCA IS VEERING TOWARD PAKISTAN
description: CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 16The new Dacca Government moved today to take Bangladesh out of the political orbit of India.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. Teaching and teachers are not exactly the two most popular subjects in downtown Washington on a hot afternoon in August. So if I say that The Dye Is Now Castat the National Portrait Gallery is a firstrate teaching instrument, the show will lose its audience almost as fast as I shall lose my own.

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16 Jim Maloney, who trains horses, walked briskly through the stable area with Mrs. Maloney, who had a small dog on leash. This is Burch, Mrs. Maloney said, introducing the pup. Named for Elliott Burch, the bestbred trainer on the grounds. So Elliott got a bitch and named her for me.

title: WILLARD A. PATE
description: Willard A. Pate, a retired insurance broker with Chubb & Son, Inc., of 90 John Street, died Thursday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived on Pecksland Road. Greenwich.

title: Poland Will Compete In National at Garden
description: Since the end of World War II, an equestrian team from Communist Bloc Eastern Europe has not appeared at the National Horse Show.

title: Private Forests Yield Timber
description: HOPEWELLThe din of George Horner's chain saw resounded through the forest here, and in less than five minutes a large white oak had been felled, trimmed and hooked to a log skidder for its journey to the outside world.

title: Two Horses Tie for Title In Jumping
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 16 Spy Commander, owned by the Country Club Farms of Phoenixville, Pa., won the stake and pulled into a tie for the open jumper championship with Stillmeadow Farms' Radnor II today at the Monmouth County Horse Show.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Aug. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)Premier Chou Enlai of China conferred today with Cambodia's Deputy Premier, Khieu Samphan, who is on his first visit outside Cambodia since the Communists captured Phnom Penh on April 17.MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (AP)The wife of Andrei D. Sakharov a wellknown Soviet physicist and civil rights activist, left Moscow by train for the West today to obtain treatment of an eye ailment that she says is gradually causing blindness.

title: Janet Ely, Vosler Win In Diving
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 16 (AP)Kent Vosler of Eaton, Ohio, upset two more publicized divers, Lieut. Phil Boggs and Tim Moore, to win the men's 10meter diving title today, in the final day of the Amateur Athletic Union's National outdoor diving championships.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Not long ago I was right about something. I knew it for an absolute fact, an indisputable certainty. It was a rare moment. Like most people, I am almost always wrong about whatever the business at hand may be, and for an instant it was exhilarating to sense that I was the only person in a room full of people who was absolutely right.

title: Gentlemen, Start Your Arguments
description: The marriage between the Sports Car Club of America and the United States Auto Club, which resulted last year in a joint sanction of the Formula 5000 series, seems headed for the rocks. Top officials of the two sanctioning bodies have held intensive meetings at each of the last two Formula 5000 racesat Road America and at MidOhio  and have emerged from both to say that their union was still strong. But there are indications to the contrary, most prominent that USAC apparently will cease its efforts to make the stockblock engine competitive for Championship carracing.

title: JOSEPH WARSHOW
description: Joseph Warshow, chairman and former president of H. Warshow & Sons, Inc., a manufacturer of elastic fabrics, died of a heart ailment in Beth Israel Hospital on Thursday. He was 78 years old and lived here and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Black's in South Carolina Protest Shootings by Police
description: GREENWOOD, S.C., Aug. 16 (UPI)About 1,000 blacks, singing We Shall Overcome, marched through downtown Greenwood today to protest the shooting of a black man by a white South Carolina highway patrolman.

title: Social Security Chief Foresees Change in Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Social Security, which marked its 40th anniversary this week, may have to change its benefits structure drastically in the next 40 years to keep up with social changes, Commissioner James B. Cardwell says.

title: Vulcans 2211 Losers To Express
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP)George Mira's passing and Tommy Reamon's running helped the Jacksonville Express post a 2211 World Football League victory tonight over the Birmingham Vulcans.

title: Reports of Chemical in Fish Initially Withheld
description: Staff members of the State Department of Environmental Conservation were informed of unhealthy quantities of PCB in fish at least five years ago but did not report their findings to the Commissioner's office, according to department officials.

title: For Six Weeks, I Was a Yugoslav
description: IT was a warm July night As my sister Snezana and I walked home from the disco, we heard through open windows the broadcast of the championship basketball game between Yugoslavia and the United States. Every television set in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, was tuned in.

title: Panel May Approve Retaining S.C.I.
description: TRENTONA committee appointed by Governor Byrne to evaluate the State Commission of Investigation is expected to release its findings soon. Most state officials anticipate that it will recommend retaining the agency.

title: DR. JOHN T. E. FLYNN
description: Dr. John T. E. Flynn, retired associate medical director of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Friday at New York University Medical Center after a long illness. He was 50 years old and lived at 29 Irving Avenue, Englewood Cliffs,. N. J.

title: LISBON'S PREMIER ADMITS PROBLEMS
description: LISBON, Aug. 16  Premier Vasco Gonalves, opposed by a large part of Portugal's military and political forces for his Communist leanings, acknowledged for the first time tonight that he was having trouble governing.

title: HOSPITALS CHIEF QUASHED STUDIES URGING CUTBACKS
description: Analyses saying that the city's municipal hospital system could be strengthened by closing some hospitals and dismissing hundreds of employes were deliberately withheld from the board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation when it was deciding how to economize in the budget crisis.

title: Ruling on Confining Mentally Ill Argued
description: In the seven weeks since the United States Supreme Court ruled that certain mentally ill persons may not be confined against their will, the decision has not, apparently, led to the release of a single mental patient other than Kenneth Donaldson, the original plaintiff.

title: Catherine T. Dolan Is Married on L.I.
description: Catherine T. Dolan, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. James R. Dolan of Massapequa, L. I. was married yesterday to James Johnides, son of John Johnides of Melville, L. I., and Valarie Kane of Fort Lee, N. J.

title: Women's Art Is Being Shown
description: HUNTINGTONThe exhibition of Twenty Women Artists at the Heckscher Museum fits in with the spate of celebrations in honor of International Women's year.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Can Now Do What She Wants With the Economy
description: NEW DELHIIn a sunbaked red mud village 150 miles south of the capital, a farmer who is typical of most of the people in India because he is impoverished and illiterate and has a hard, rural life that seems almost hopeless, stopped hacking away at the dry earth for a moment to talk about the affairs of the nation.

title: Priscilla Martin, Lawyer, Engaged
description: Priscilla Anne Martin of Beverly Hills, Calif., a greatgranddaughter of M. H. de Young, founder of The San Francisco Chronicle, plans to be married in October to Curtis Sloane Tamkin, a realestate developer in southern California.

title: Chicano Mural Art  A Mixture of the Barrio's Rage and Pride
description: SAN DIEGO From a distance, the concrete pylons look simply like supports for a graceful bridge that whisks commuter cars over a deteriorating MexicanAmerican barrio on the way from affluent Coronado Island to San Diego. Up close, these concrete pillars turn out to be the canvases for an indigenous art forrnChicano, or MexicanAmerican, mural art. With paint and spray, and a mixture of rage and pride. Chicano youngsters and adults, few with any formal schooling in the arts, have produced a blend of the modern and the ancient. Their murals, which stand in Chicano Park, reflect the influences of Picasso and Diego Rivera, Walt Disney and Peter Max, as well as ancient Latin American culture.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERTH WATERS
description: Robert H. Waters, president and founder of Robert H. Waters Company, Inc., a general contractor of 120 Wall Street, died Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 227. East 57th Street and in Sands Point, L. I.

title: Alcohol Advising To Lead to Degree
description: A new program leading to a bachelor's degree with specialization in alcohol counseling will be offered this fall under the joint sponsorship of Adelphi University and the South Oaks Hospital's Alcohol Treatment and Education Center.

title: Yankees Toppled By Royals, 4 to 3
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 16A nervous young lefthander with one inning of major league pitching under his belt stifled a Yankee rally tonight and preserved a 43 victory for the Kansas City Royals.

title: CampaignContribution Reform
description: WASHINGTON  Reform is a fashionable word in the current political scene. In spite of this, a mostneeded reform is rarely addressed: elimination of specialinterest contributions to Federal election campaigns.

title: Papadopoulos Says He Led Coup to Block Reds and Civil War
description: ATHENS. Aug. 16 (Reuters) Former President George Papadopoulos said here today that he led the 1967 coup to save the country from Communism and civil war.

title: An Editor's Report
description: More than two years ago I was taken out of academe into the thickets of journalism as literary editor of The New Republic. I came to the magazine in high spirits; secretly I was scared to death. I felt like a footbound Oriental woman commanded to walk the marathon with such figures as Malcolm Cowley, Edmund Wilson, Richard Gilman, Robert Evert, Reed Whittemore, all of whom had been there before me.

title: Youths Working To Save Trees
description: An eightweek experimental program aimed at preserving the city's trees is under way in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Bonefish Is Victor In Trot
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 16 Stanley Dancer and his 25. yearold son, Ronnie, celebrated a highly profitable fatherandson day this afternoon as they brought home the first two finishers in the $111,000 Empire State Trot at the New York State Fairgrounds.

title: Virginia C. Hassell To Marry Oct. 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Pate Hassell of Summit, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Cameron Hassell, a general agent with American Airlines in Tucson, Ariz., to Viateur Jacques Pilon of Tucson.

title: Poolside Dinners Can Be Elegant
description: MOUNTAINSIDEThere is no reason why members of a community pool should settle for hot dogs or sea food at their annual party, insisted Vivian Collyer, a pool member herself and selftaught caterer. Why not, she asked, a gourmet dinner of stuffed zucchini and cucumber boats, cool seafood paella with saffron rice, green beans vinaigrette, miniature cinnamon muffins and lemon mousse?

title: Advising Tonga by Mail Is Slow Process
description: SAYREVILLEWhen Dr. George Marotta, a metrics consultant to the state's Department of Education, recently attempted to send a package addressed to King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV, Nuku'alofa, Tonga, the postal clerks at the post office here were justifiably confused.

title: The East, a Black Culture and Education Centers Brings Bit of Africa to Brooklyn
description: There is a bit of Africa on a short block running off Fulton Street and not far from Franklin Avenue called The East that has become a source of pride for the BedfordStuyvesant section in Brooklyn.

title: Off Broadway Fades Victoriously
description: While we are rejoicing over Broadway's newfound health (with our fingers crossed), there is a simultaneous phenomenon that at first sight seems exceedingly ominous. Off Broadway is deador at least that is the way Joseph Papp put it as he prepared to abandon his normal activities at the downtown Public and move his stable of notquiteproved writers uptown this season to the Booth. Mr. Papp was careful to be clear in a late spring interview with Mel Gussow of The Times, spelling out what he meant: DEAD.

title: Mr. Levi's Initiative
description: Attorney General Levi's speech to the American Bar Association represented an admirable start toward fulfilling his commitment to develop public guidelines governing electronic surveillance and other activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Support for Portugal...
description: After long assuming that a Communist takeover was almost inevitable in Portugal, Secretary of State Kissinger has finally set United States policyin its public expressions, at leastonto a more constructive tack. His Birmingham speech offered just the kind of psychological support that Portugal's embattled democratic forces have been needing as they press their resistance to Communistbacked Premier Gonalves and the radical leftwing minorities of the Armed Forces Movement.

title: New & Novel
description: Jack Higgins, who has put himself into his own book as its narrator, begins by looking for the grave of a 17thcentury English sea captain. He finds instead the grave of a German officer, gunned down in 1943 while attempting to abduct and/or assassinate Winston Churchill. This leads the author to fabricate the story of Operation Eagle, a fantasy in which a detachment of German daredevils lands in Britain to duplicate the feat of Otto Skorzeny, who kidnapped Mussolini when he was an Allied prisoner. Unlike Skorzeny, Steiner and his boys fumble the job although they are abetted by a unit of American Rangers clumsy enough to get themselves massacred. The Nazisaided by a resident Mata Hari, some collaborators, and a likable I.R.A. typeare really not bad fellows at all. They will do anything to save the lives of civilians and behave more in the spirit of Beau Geste than Malmedy. This chivalry is returned by their adversary. Colonel Corcoran, who feels at Steiner's death a strange sense of personal loss.

title: A Court Order Limits Access
description: When Alexander Butterfield, a former deputy assistant to the President, first told the Senate Watergate committee under oath that President Richard Nixon had ordered his automatic taping system installed for historical purposes, he confirmed what many people already knew about the President: that he wanted to preserve a unique living record of his administration.

title: FILM VIEW
description: A side from the anonymous obscene phone call, modern technology provides no potentially sneakier way of getting across a punchy message than filmediting. Take fat men. In real life they are not really funnier or more sinister than anyone else. But if you film a fat man walking on a crowded sidewalk, edit to make his gait halting and jerky, synchronize the jerkiness with, say, the percussive bursts in Rite of Spring, and freeze the frame at some point when his mouth is open, the fat man will be making a statement.

title: They Exchange Arms and Talk, but They're Not Quite a Brotherhood
description: LONDONIllich Remirez Sanchez, the bespectacled Venezuelan assassin sought by police in four European countries for shooting to death two detectives and an informer in a Paris flat, was given weapons training in Lebanon by the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. That is what the Popular Front asserts and there is little reason doubt it; the dead informer was one of their men who had changed sides.

title: Intense XRay Surge, Detected in Orion, Is Puzzling Astronomers
description: Far out in the constellation Orion an event releasing catastrophic amounts of energy is occurring. While its nature is unknown, it has generated Xray emissions that in recent days have reached an intensity five times greater than any observed before in the heavens.

title: Tigers Finally Win
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP)The Detroit Tigers ended their losing streak tonight at 19 defeats. They beat the California Angels, 80, behind the twohit pitching of Ray Bare.

title: Beth Daniel, 18, Wins U.S. Amateur, 3 and 2
description: NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP)Beth Daniel, a Furman University sophomore from Charleston, S.C., won the 75th United States Women's Amateur golf championship today, 3 and 2, from Donna Horton of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Lawyer Weds Gail Kachadurian
description: In St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus here yesterday afternoon Gail Kachadurian, a former member of the New York City Ballet, was married to Kenneth F. McCallion, who is a special assistant attorney general with the Special State Prosecutor's Office for Health and Social Services. The Rev. PeterRoberge performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. David J. Bowman.

title: Haskell Handicap Chart
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Toward the end of the first week of August, the Government reported that the wholesale price index had jumped at a 14.4 per cent annual rate in July. Then the Treasury disclosed that It would have to borrow $2billion more than expected. And then the First National City Bank raised its base rate on corporate loans, an increase that came a little sooner than the money market had anticipated.

title: Sag Harbor Offers a Plan for Sewage
description: SAG HARBORUnder an agreement now being worked out between this village and the Suffolk County Health Department, food businesses on Main Street have won a reprieve on a threat to close them because of pollution.

title: Woman Umpire Story: The Perils of Christine
description: Part of America's sports mania is its preoccupation with being No. 1, both directly (through participation) and vicariously (through spectatorship). The seed for this oftenexcessive absorption, planted in remote historical ground, has germinated, sprouted, blossomed and borne fruit, which, spreading through the years, has crept over the continent's fields like a national cucumber.

title: Borzov Takes Europe 100Meter Title
description: NICE, France, Aug. 16 (UPI)Valery Borzov of the Soviet Union, an Olympic champion, had to wait more than 10 minutes to discover he had beaten Pietro Mennea of Italy toady in the 100 meters on the opening day of the Europa Cup track and field finals.

title: Utah's Yodel Country
description: I AM an aging, citybred gaffer full of nostalgia for a place and time I never knewwhich explains why the tiny town of Midway, tucked away in a valley beneath the protective ramparts of the Utah Rockies, draws me back year after year.

title: InflationIt's Not the Real Problem
description: The pace of inflation in the United States has accelerated in the last month, which has produced new cries of alarm throughout the land. The reaction, however, is both premature and grossly overdrawn.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: One of the more intriguing puzzles of the summer is the trend to popart Tshirts with a brand label commercial trademark. To the surprise of even the businesses that benefit, millions of Americans have become walking billboardsand paying to do so.

title: Saigon Is Placing Sale of Gasoline Under State Rule
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 16 (UPI)  South Vietnamese officials have pledged to wipe out black markets in medicine and gasoline, turning distribution over to the Government.

title: Emily FredriksonFleisher Is Married
description: Emily FredriksonFleisher of Granby, Conn., daughter of Elizabeth FredriksonFleisher of Washington, formerly of New York, and Dr. Eric Wilfrid Fleisher of Washington, became the bride yesterday evening of Ronald Bauer Jones Wisner, son of Mrs. Carl A. Ericson of Neshanic, N. J., and stepson of Mr. Ericson.

title: Bruce Johnson Weds Miss Burden
description: Michele Lee Burden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Burden of Brookside, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Stuart Johnson son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Frederick Johnson of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Thomas C. Sheffield, assisted by the Rev. John Hutchison, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian ChurchontheGreen in Morristown, N.J.

title: Darts No Longer Kid Stuff Get the Point?
description: It all started, we can assume, in a cave about a million years ago. Bored after a long day's hunting, a caveman or cavewoman scratched a circle on the rough wall of the family living room with a stone, stood back several feet and heaved a crude spear toward the mark. The sport of darts had been invented.

title: Refresher Course Slated for Nurses
description: WAYNEThe School of Nursing at William Paterson College is offering a refresher course for registered nurses who have been inactive for at least five years.

title: THOBYMARCELIN, 70, HAITIAN NOVELIST
description: Philippe ThobyMarcelin, coauthor with his brother Pierre Marcelin of Haitian novels, died Wednesday at his home in Cazenovia, N. Y. He was 70 years old.

title: I'm the biggest model, period
description: The first thing I learned about women who model is that they can be washed up at 25. The girl everyone wants, who commands fees of $100 an hour and appears regularly on the covers of fashion magazines, can in no time at all become the girl no one wants. Fashion models have the same builtin obsolescence as automobile models. This is the dark side of a profession which, on the surface, seems like glamorous fun. Whatever happened to Jean Shrimpton?

title: INVESTING
description: Last week Consolidated Edison decided that the $80million, 25year bond issue it had postponed earlier this month should be revived in an eightyear form.

title: Belgians Find Tank Defect
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 16 (AP)Forty tanks have been temporarily removed from active service in the Belgian Army after cracks were detected in special aluminum armor plating, the Defense Ministry said today. An investigation is under way to determine the cause of the defects.

title: A Record 7 Liners Are Docked at New PassengerShip Terminal
description: More than 5,000 suntanned passengers carrying straw bags and other mementos from Bermuda and Nassau disembarked from six ships yesterday at the new Passenger Ship Terminal here, part of a record day for passenger shipping in the port.

title: Surge in Nuclear Exports Spurs Drive for Controls
description: For most industries growth has been a prime goaland for those in the multibilliondollar business of exporting nuclear materials, the dynamics are the same.

title: 22 Summer Camps Found in Violation Of New State Health and Safety Code
description: TRENTON  State inspectors have uncovered 22 health or safety violators among New Jersey's summer camps in the last eight weeks, a figure that accounts for 18 per cent of the 112 establishments that have registered this year under the mandatory licensing provisions of the Youth Camp Safety Act.

title: Viking Shot Preparations Proceed on New Schedule
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 16 (UPI)Engineers aiming for a Wednesday launching of the twicepostponed Viking mission to search for life on Mars said today that preparations were finally going smoothly.

title: Food
description: Pho gu (Ricenoodle soup with Chicken)

title: Neurosis and Rainbows: The Garland Legend Grows
description: Who still cares about the phenomenon of Baby Frances Ethel Gumm, later to be called Judy Garland? If America's publishers are to be trusted, a vast audience does, a stillhungry horde of those who filled the orpheums showing her films, jammed her concerts or dedicated a section of their childhoods to TV replays of The Wizard of Oz.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: Students of Arts Learn in Pastoral Setting
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. Marylou Speaker, dressed in yellow ankle socks, Hush Puppies, a blue skirt and white head scarf, sat in the stone  and  glass teahouse overlooking the swimming pool and instructed Nadia Ghent, a student, in a Beethoven violin concerto between sprays of insect repellent.

title: Fiction
description: CLARA REEVE, by Leonie Hargrave. (Knopf. $8.95.) A proper Victorian young lady enmeshed in some Gothic machinations; welldone evocation of the period.

title: Whatever happened to Mary Janes?
description: That emerging enchantress. that beautiful adventurer trembling on the lowest rung of adolescence, your daughter you think she is a sartorial disaster in painter pants and Earth Shoes?

title: Golf Lead To Washam On 2d 69
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 16 (UPI)Joann Washam, a thirdyear pro, shot her second straight fourunderpar 69 today to take the secondround, lead over four experienced players in the Patty Berg Classic on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: How New York became a fiscal junkie
description: On the morning of May 14, 1965, Robert F. Wagner, his stride slow from 12 years at City Hall, blinked into the hot camera lights in the ornate Board of Estimate chambers and announced his last budget as Mayor. At $3.87billion, it was a record budget, $255.8million short on revenues, so Wagner proposed to balance it by borrowingborrow now, repay later, he called itat least until a referendum would allow the city to change the realestate tax formulas and raise new taxes to pay the borrowing back.

title: Letters: Cars Only At a Long Island Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Heather C. Chalmers Is Married
description: Heather Clare Chalmers, a legal assistant with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Johnson Green, who is with the accounting concern of Price Waterhouse & Co. in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Charles L Hoffman performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Woods Hole, Mass.
