title: Jack Johnson and the White Supremacy Issue
description: Although it would be too much to say that Jack Johnson's boxing career, lifestyle and the ensuing reactions were a pivotal point in race relations in the country, he did have a tremeadous impact on both white and black Americans.

title: New Hearing Is Set On Waterfront Plan
description: JERSEY CITYWhile a newly formed City Council committee begins to investigate the city's $8.2million contract with the Port Jersey Corporation to develop 650 acres along the Hudson riverfront, the State Supreme Court's refusal to grant the National Kinney Corporation an injunction voiding that contract has ended, at least until Sept. 12, .a series of legal challenges to the project.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES PAROLE METHODS
description: A suit has been filed in Federal District Court here diallenging the constitutionality of parole procedures for 1,500 prisoners serving sentences of a year or less in the city's jails.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 17, 1975

title: Engagements
description: FiermanJosell

title: A Highly Seasoned Comedy Of Errors
description: The fat maid teetering on a terrace of Santo Loquasto's cuckooclock of a revolving set feverishly twirls a large round piece of fabric over her head until it completely envelops her Is this meant to be a pizza the size of a tablecloth or a tablecloth shaped like a pizza? It doesn't matter. The sight gag gets an easy laughthat time and every time it is reintroduced. As staged by John Pasquin and as produced by Joseph Papp in the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, this is a lowcomedy, broken  Italian version of Shakespeare's The Comedy of Errors. Eggplants and zucchini are thrown like hand grenades. Steaming hot, barber towels are dropped down the front of men's trousers. Barnsize bloomers are exhibited like battle trophies. The Duke of Ephesus is a broadbellied Mafioso in white suit and pencil moustache and his bodyguard is a pistoltoting gangster (the production must set some sort of New York Shakespeare Festival record for gunfire). The carabiniere looks like Mussolini (this Comedy takes place in the thirties in a small Italian village). The dialogue is heavily spiced not just with muse and the cosa? but with dissa and datta. And how many jokes can you make about flatulence?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Goldenrod
description: If goldenrod were still a symbol of good fortune, this would be a year of triumph and this autumn should be remarkably beautiful. August always brings the glow of goldenrod, but this year seems to be specially endowed. Every old field and neglected pasture and most rural roadsides show the richness of those golden plumes typical of late summer.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne has the happy faculty or unhappy faculty, depending on one's point of viewto appear relaxed and to be having fun while the state wends its way through one crisis after another.

title: The Roof Of New England
description: MOUNT MONADNOCK, a massively sloping ridge in southern New Hampshire that looms with an austere guarding presence over the town of Jaffrey, holds a central place in the minds of northern New Englanders. Though not much more than half a mile high at its summit, it rises smoothly from blackish pine forest to gleaming gray rockface with a grandeur that has attracted climbers, campers, trekkers and philosophers for two centuries.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 16 (AP)Alwin Schockemoehle of West Germany took first place in the individual standing today by tying Vitorrio Orlandi of Italy in the second event of the European equestrian championships. Schockemoehle, aboard his 9yearold gelding Warwick, and Orlandi, on his 12yearold gelding Fiorello, each collected four penalty points on their first run through the tough 700meter course.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals land the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Baseball's Hall of Fame Opens Doors to 5 Tomorrow
description: COOPERSTOWN. N. Y., Aug. 16 (AP) On a lawn not far from a converted cow pasture, baseball will celebrate its past by inducting five top figures into the Hall of Fame on Monday.

title: Design
description: In this evenhighercostforlessspace era of housing, the loft bed is perhaps the logical successor to the bunkbed that allowed generations of siblings to share their bedrooms. Equipped with its own lighting, bookshelves and storage areas, the loft frees the floor beneath it for seating, more storage and work counters. When photographer Gsta Peterson and his wife had squeeze their two children of opposite sex and disparate age into one 10footwide, 21footlong, 10foothigh bedroom in their city coop, they cut the room in two and doubled up on the use of space.

title: Marie Buttrick Is Bride of Kevin Hume
description: Marie Grace Buttrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Niemann Buttrick of Rye, N. Y., was married there yesterday morning to Kevin Michael Hume, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Hume of Westbury, L. I. Msgr. John Slater performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in the Resurrection Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Chinese Wedding: Reconciling Two Cultures
description: Kenny Tang, an engineering student at City College, and Sandy Woo, an employe of the Social Security Administration, were married in the True Light Lutheran Church here the other day and, after the ceremony, the focus shifted from the customs of the West to those of the East.

title: John C. Gavejian Weds Elaine Manteiga
description: Elaine Marie Manteiga, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Manteiga of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to John Clifford Gavejian, a lawyer and son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gavejian of Tenafly, N.J.

title: They Also Return to Europe
description: Europe, of course, retains appeal for the American executive, on vacation or off. But the people who go, and the style they maintain, are subject to change.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Westport to ride the Bicentennial bus, take the Connecticut Turnpike (Interstate 95) to Exit 17, then follow Route 33 North to State Street (U.S. 1), turn right, cross the bridge, take the first right at the stop light, and you will be at Jesup Green, the departure point. Reservations are advised. Call Minnybus: 2032267171 Monday to Friday 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. You can pick up your tickets at the bus until 15 minutes before departure time. Or write Minnybus, 311 East State Street, Westport, Conn. 06880, enclosing selfaddressed, stamped envelope. Tickets cost $1.50 for adults, $1 for children under 12 accompanied by an adult. A mimeographed takealong sheet lists the points of interest. Arrangements may also be made to schedule group tours (maximum 30 persons) during the week.J.E.

title: Riley Takes Title in Finn Class Sail
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 16  H. Sanford Riley, a 24yearold Toronto lawyer, captured the Finn Class national sailing championship today. He did not sail in the fifth and final race on Great South Bay.

title: Pakistan Is Bolstered by Aid From Other Moslem Nations
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan The learning of Arabic is being encouraged in Pakistan. Editions of the Koran marred by typographical errors are barred from bookshops. Airline employes, announcing flight plans, stipulate, If Allah wills.

title: Don't Call Nightshade A Feminist Rock Group
description: The Deadly Nightshade sidles into the songsly, backalley, sidestreet truckin music with the hint of burlesque gumpopping, hipswaying strut and flounce.

title: William B. Holmberg Is Fiance Of Patricia G. Going, a Teacher
description: Patricia Gardiner Going, who teaches at the New Canaan (Conn.) Country School, plans to be married in October to William Barker Holmberg of New York, a vice president in the municipalfinance department of Kuhn, Loeb & Co.

title: Maria Bueno Is Eager to Regain Her Tennis Skill
description: WYCKOFF, N..J, Aug. 16Frustration has replaced pain as Maria Bueno's tormentor on the international tennis circuit. Once considered the sport's most gifted and graceful stylist, the threetime singles champion at both Forest Hills and Wimbledon has found herself trying to run with one leg in a new bame where the the emphasis is not on what you've won, but how much.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... to Mount Monadnock, it will probably be by car, since public transportation is not available in the vicinity of the mountain. The fastest route from New York is the New England Thruway/Connecticut Turnpike (Interstate 95) east to New Haven, then 191 north to Exit 3 in Vermont. From there go east on State Route 9 to Keene, N.H., east on Route 101 to Dublin, then turn south to the entrance to Monadnock State Park.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Diane Fisher Plans A December Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Ackerman Fisher of Oakhurst, N. J., and Ludlow, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Marie Fisher, to William Alexander Despo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Despo of Loch Arbour, N. J.

title: The sudden and secret war
description: The withdrawal of their troops from Norway and France in 1940 left the British with no foothold on the European mainland and no plans for an early return to northern Europe. Their immediate aims were to safeguard the United Kingdom against invasion and air attacks; build up their forces in North Africa; defeat the Uboat; avoid or postpone a confrontation with Japan; and wear down their enemies by blockade and bombing. From the summer o 1941 they made it their business to send arms to Russia, even at the cost of delaying the expansion of their own armed forces.

title: Herbert Hoover
description: Americans who remember Herbert Hoover are most likely to regard him, as Joan Hoff Wilson readily admits, as an arch conservative or even a reactionary, a man who was clearly out of tune with the urban brand of liberalism arising out of the depression. In this study, a new entry in the distinguished Library of American Biography series, Wilson offers a reconsideration that she terms positive without being eulogistic and she successfully challenges the major interpretations of Hoover's career, interpretations held by both the public and by professional historians.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television prograins was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Notes: Of Stuntwomen, Critics and Coincidence
description: Movie stuntmen  those former athletes, ex  rodeo stars and macho daredevils who create illusions of danger on the screenare being pushed on the defensive these days in Hollywood by a small but growing number of women who want an equal chance to be knocked down stairs, slammed into walls and crushed beneath runaway buckboards. The crux of this unusual battle of the sexes is the practice, dating back to the beginnings of the movie industry, of using a stuntman in drag rather than a stuntwoman when a script calls for some particularly gruesome fate to befall a female.

title: Perilous Voyage
description: The voyage in Lael Wertenbaker's novel takes place within the mind of the protagonist. a woman of 84. And it is completely enchanting. Superficially, Augusta Turnley is a vegetableparalyzed in a car accident and rendered speechless. But her mind is undimmed. and she can blink her eyes in Morse code, when she has the will to communicate. Her days are spent traveling in memory: back to the first awareness, at age 5, of her own

title: Foes of TransitFare Rise Propose 2 Alternatives
description: A group of Federal, state and local officials proposing a new regional transportation tax to stabilize transit and commuter fares said that the tax would be far less burdensome on the public than fare increases.

title: MANY NEW TRENDS IN THEATER SEEN
description: WATERFORD, Conn., Aug. 16New forms for the theater are emerging from storefronts, church basements and other makeshift stages across the country, according to Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the National Playwrights Conference.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
description: Includes games of Aug. 15

title: Dolly Purdo
description: When she is orphaned at the age of 14, circa 1870, Dolly Purdo heads West from Indiana into one of the tallest tall stories you can imagine. Accompanied by her best friend. Cordelia, and her halfwitted guardian, Uncle Cyril, Dolly makes it to the Dakota Territory. Here she ends her days as the mistress of both a cathouse and a gold mine in the city of Deadwood. Would you care to find out how Dolly and Cordelia become temporary. Indians, and Cyril an unsuccessful bank robber? How Cordelia shoots a grizzly, mistaking it for a moose? How they fall in with an Indian named Weasel, who travels in a wheelchair and a derby, and a dwarf named Francis who has a drinking problem? How the girls and Uncle Cyril wind up on different sides of a battle between Indians and white militia? Go ahead and find out, for all the good it's going to do you.

title: Mobile Van Linking L.I. to Washington
description: BRENTWOODIt was a rainy day, but the miserable weather failed to deter constituents from visiting representative Tom Downey, whose newly acquired mobile office was perked in a shopping center in this Sou?? Shore community.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayAt Kansas City.

title: Tennis Coach Beats Odds
description: Arnold Lynn thinks that he might have been a top tennis pro if he had been a different color. As it was, he did manage to succeed in a sport that has attracted few blacks.

title: A NEBRASKA FARM FIGRTS POLLUTION
description: PAPILLION, Neb.  Larry Schram, a cattle feeder who weighs over 200 pounds is sometimes referred to jocularly by his friends as the world's biggest guinea pig.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayMonmouth County, County Show Grounds, East Freehold, N. J. Open, amateurowner and junior jumpers; regular, green, amateurowner, nonthoroughbred and children's working hunters; ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 17, 1975

title: Simon Gray's New Play Anatomizes a Likable Creep
description: LONDON Butley was so much the end of the line that nobody could be sure Simon Gray, its author, could write anything to follow it. Happily, he has now done so; his new play, Otherwise Engaged, has just opened here at the Queen's Theater under Harold Pinter's direction and with Alan Bates once again in the principal role. Otherwise Engaged is good and what is almost more importantit is different.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Railroad Sells Town In Nevada for $18.000
description: GERLACH, Nev., Aug. 16 (AP)The residents of Gerlach were tired of paying land rent for the last halfcentury so they bought this tiny town for $18,000.

title: TACHUNG LIU
description: Tachung Liu, a professor of economics at Cornell University since 1958, died Thursday at Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 60 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Congress Is Widening Its Struggle for a Foreign Policy Role
description: WASHINGTONOn a number of Issues recently, including military aid to Turkey and trade credits for the Soviet Union, Congress has successfully challenged the President's traditional dominance over foreign policy. Now some Congressmen are poised to challenge Presidential hegemony by attempting to subject all executive agreements with foreign nations to legislative scrutiny.

title: MARA TRAINING LABOR ARBITERS
description: MANILA, Aug. 16Two experts from New York City's Office of Collective Bargaining are helping train Filipino arbitrators who will perform a critical function In labor relations here.

title: FEAR OF DEFAULT CRUCIAL OBSTACLE TO CITY BOND SALE
description: The chance of an eventual default by the cityconsidered a possibility for monthshas now become the major factor in the Municipal Assistance Corporation's difficulties in raising the cash the city needs to meet expenses.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Bellevue

title: . . . Dead End for Recovery
description: As it confronts rising auto prices, rising oil prices, rising food prices, rising production costs, the Federal Reserve Board insists that, to halt the inflation, the growth of the money supply must be held down and interest rates allowed to rise. Already rates are risingon Federal funds, Treasury bills, municipal bonds and on business loans at the commercial banks. It is difficult to see how the high price of money will stop OPEC, the Department of Agriculture, General Motors or the Teamsters Union, whose national wage agreement expires next spring. But tight money will surely slow the recovery and help keep unemployment high. A tight money policy is no mere placebo. It is a remedy that clearly worsens the disease of stagflation.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1Seymour Chwast

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION, the Government announced Friday, rose onehalf of 1 per cent in July to an Index of 108.8 (with 1967 as 100). . . . General Motors annou??ed a price increase on 1976 models averaging 4.4 per cent. . . . Republic Steel, following other steel producats, raised prices almost 4 per cent. Bethlehem Steel increased its prices 4 per cent. . . . Car sales in the first 10 days of August totaled 131,218 units, down 28.9 per cent from the yearearlier level.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Tomorrow at noon a special gala ceremony will be held in Chicago to formally release the cupro  nickel Bicentennial quarter into nationwide circulation. The debut will take place on the plaza of the Federal Building and will be conducted by officials of the Chicago district headquarters of the Federal Reserve Bank. The affair will be under the cosponsorship of the U.S. Mint, with Director Mary T. Brooks and other officials hand.

title: Ehrlichman Seeks Freedom Since Nixon Did Not Testify
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) John D. Ehrlichman, former White House aide, has asked the United States Court of Appeals to overthrow his conviction in the Watergate coverup case because former President Richard M. Nixon did not testify at his trial.

title: Libertarian Party Chief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Libertarian party, with national headquarters here; announced Wednesday that Robert H. Meier, of Chicago, is its new national director. Mr. Meier, 30 years old, succeeds Ned Hutchinson, who died last March.

title: Bar Moving to Provide Legal Services for Poor
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 14A major fact of the American legal system is that millions of Americans do not get the legal services they need.

title: Mrs. Court's Track Failure Gave Tennis World a Star
description: When Margaret Smith lost a 220yard race by five yards at the Glenys Beasley Meet in Australia in 1966, track and field lost a potentially great competitor.

title: Horse Kidnapped in Italy
description: MONTECATINI, Italy, Aug. 16 (AP)Wayne Eden, one of Italy's most successful trotters, was kidnapped from his stall early this morning at the race track of this Tuscan spa just hours after winning a $15,000 purse. Track officials said the Americanbred 5yearold hay disappeared between 4 and 6 A.M. The stall door was found unlocked and a ventilation window, large enough for a small person to climb through, was open.

title: Notes: Wax Museums Are Not on the Wane
description: CONTRARY to what many tourists believe, interest in the venerable institution of the wax museum is not waning. It'syou guessed it waxing, both here and abroad. In fact, the International Association of Wax Museums, with headquarters in Chicago, has just updated its threeyearold directory of members and the new list shows several additions.

title: Minorities Assisted By Medical School
description: NEWARKA New Jersey Medical School program that enables disadvantaged minority students to prepare for and cope with the rigors of a medical education has been so successful that other schools are requesting aid in establishing similar projects.

title: College for Women Gets New Deadline On Male Exclusion
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 16An experimental Women's Studies College at the State University here has been given until Oct. 15 to justify the exclusion of men from some of its courses.

title: Bies Leads Green by Stroke on 67198
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 16Don Bies, a softspoken, selfeffacing golf pro who is still looking for his first victory after nine years on the tour, took a onestroke lead over Hubert Green today in the third round of the Greater Hartford open.

title: Texas Group Begins Program to Reduce Heath Care Costs
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 16The Texas Hospital Association, under a contract from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, has begun a pilot program that may reduce health care costs across the nation.

title: In Abu Dhabi, a Boom Checks In
description: ABU DHABIThe Japanese Embassy holds its receptions here; an armed guard protects is the corner of the seve?? floor occupied by the Saudi Arabian Embassy; Archbishop Makarios, executives from American construction companies and European trade delegations drift regularly through the lobby; the Presidential Palace has 22 rooms always reserved; the Foreign Ministry keeps four rooms and two suites (with government priority for any other rooms needed), the Finance Ministry takes rooms under government priority and uses the dining rooms and ballroomall for important official guests.

title: Endpaper
description: (1) Cut it out (2) make holes for your eyes if you wish; (3) tape a string to points A and B; (4) try it on. Passive smoking. as a United States Surgeon General's report has noted, is the health hazard, even to nonsmokers, of cigarette smoke in confined spaces. Recently, a British study concluded that it takes no more than one or two smokers to contaminate a vehicle or building. and that virtually all urban nonsmokers have . . . nicotine in their body fluids throughout most of their lives . . . derived from the indoor air they breathe Caution: Smokers may find this mask incendiary.

title: Edward Hayes Jr. Marries Miss Myers
description: Patricia Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Myers of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Edward P. P. Hayes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hayes of Rahway, N. J.

title: Mets' Games This Week
description: TodaySan Francisco at Shea Stadium, 2:05 P.M.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: WEEK ENDED AUGUST 15, 1975

title: L.I. Gasoline Price May Rise 10 Cents
description: MINEOLA  A gasoline price rise of about 10 cents a gallon by the end of the year has been predicted by the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association. This would put the average price for regular gasoline at 69.7 cents a gallon and premium at 74.6 cents.

title: Wonza E. Williamson Is Bride Of Robert Hilary Sinclair Here
description: Wonza Elizabeth Williamson, daughter of Mrnd Mrs. William Elliott Williamson of New York, was married here yesterday to Robert Hilary Sinclair, son of Evelyn E. Sinclair and Thomas V. Sinclair, also of New York, by Justice Herbert Evans of the State Supreme Court at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Births
description: Gluckman

title: ATOM PLANT HOLDS MOCKBLAST TEST
description: PRESCOTT, Ore., Aug. 18At 9:38 A.M. last Wednesday, Thomas James, shift supervisor of Portland General Electric Company's Trojan nuclear plant near here, received a sealed envelope. The message inside told him that a radioactive waste tank had exploded, releasing twice the lethal, hourly dose of radiation.

title: JUDGE IN DETROIT BARS BUSING PLANS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 16A Federal District judge declined today to order the widespread busing here of children to promote racial desegregation of public schools.

title: Dr. Jacob Feld, Design Engineer On Buildings Here, Dead at 76
description: Dr. Jacob Feld, designing engineer on many important buildings, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: The Migration to the Cities Is a Significant Factor
description: LOS ANGELESRural poverty in the United States is not what it used to be. Over the last 15 years, the number of people classified as poor living in the countryside has declined 56 per cent, largely because of migration to the cities and economic diversification.

title: 18Month RentRise Dispute Ends at Cadman Plaza North
description: A year  and  a  half  long battle against a 31 per cent increase in maintenance charges, waged by many residents of a cityfinanced cooperative apartment building in Brooklyn Heights, has come to an end with the residents agreeing to pay the increase retroactive to December, 1973.

title: Letters
description: Doubts and confusions

title: Ransom Is Paid by Bronfman; Son Still Missing Hours Later
description: A ransom believed to be $4.5million in cash was left for the kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d well before dawn yesterday, but early today, nearly 24 hours afterward, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said that he had not yet been released.

title: Budget Cuts Imperil Cultural Projects
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Symphony Orchestra is facing a fight for survival, and scores of other cultural organizations in the state are being forced to economize or seek new sources of revenue, as a result of a 16.6 per cent cut in the budget of the State Council on the Arts.

title: Rosemary Lyman Wed to Peter Van Slyck
description: Rosemary O'Brien Lyman of New York and Peter Van Slyck of Niantic, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. George K. Dreher, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Bigelow, friends of the couple.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: DEAR DIARY: A week's economic news rushes by in a blurprices up, markets down, Big MAC's troubles, Fed disputes, airline woes. Sometimes it's hard to figure out what it all means, and interpretations or course can vary. Here are some random thoughts on what it looked like day by day.

title: Parent and Child
description: Last April, when 2,000 Vietnamese orphans were brought into the United States, many Americans protested that there were plenty of American children waiting to be adoptedso why import more? Yet later that same month, Senator Walter F. Mondale's Subcommittee on Children and Youth heard two days of testimony about the severe shortage of adoptable infants and the existence of a black market in babies, who are being sold to waiting couples for as much as $25,000. And, in California, two couples unable to bear children because of the wife's infertility advertised in The San Francisco Chronicle for babymakerswomen willing to submit to artificial insemination with the husband's sperm in order to conceive and bear a child for the couple. One of the couples was willing to pay up to 510.000 for this service, after learning that they would face a threetosevenyear wait to obtain a child through an adoption agency. The Los Angeles Deputy District Attorney says he can find no state law that is violated by someone who pays a woman to have a baby for purposes of adoption.

title: Headliners
description: The British talkshow packager and host, David Frost, has won the bidding for Richard Nixon's television memoirs. Mr. Frost announced last week that the former President had agreed to tell all in four telecasts that will be filmed now and shown after the 1976 elections. He said he believed a major network would be involved in broadcasting the interviews, but he said he could not say which until an agreement was signed. Mr. Nixon also will not be under oath, and there is no indication yet Mr. Frost will have an expert in both Watergate and interrogation to aid in the interview. A recent television interview of H. R. Haldeman, also said to be without restriction as to subject, produced no news but did provide a forum for Mr. Nixon's former chief aide to insist on his innocence. Terms of Mr. Frost's deal were not disclosed, but industry speculation went as high as $1million.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It is something of a relief to get away from the Arabs and Israelis, who seem to have taken over the corpus of espionage/action fiction these days, and turn to something like A DISAPPEARANCE by Robert Carroll (Dial, $7.95). Now here is a suave book, very much in the Eric Ambler lineone thinks of A Coffin for Dimitrios. Carroll has the formula down pat: the amateur who becomes involved with criminal professionals; the chase through Europe; the penetrating menace of a vicious killer; constant action without heavybreathing heroics.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, August 17, 1975

title: Lincoln Scholar Who Aided Nixon Is Indicted for Lying
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP)The president of the Chicago Public Library Board has been indicted on charges of lying to Internal Revenue Service agents in connection with Richard M. Nixon's historical papers.

title: California Forbids Chrysler to Market BigEngine Models
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (UPI)The state Air Resources Board announced today that it was forbidding the sale in California of new Chrysler Corporation cars equipped with the company's largest engine because the automobiles did not meet state antipollution regulations.

title: American Aids Prague Pest Research
description: PRAGUE  An American and two Czechoslovaks have formed a surgical team operating on brown moths here in the hope of finding pestcontrol techniques not involving chemical insecticides.

title: At Bronfman's Homes, Clues to Activity
description: The skies were overcast and the streets were nearly deserted in the quiet predawn darkness as the yellow cab drew up to the green canvas canopy at 3 East 77th Street with two men in the back seat. They had said nothing on the short ride from 72d Street and Lexington Avenue, but they seemed to be in a big hurry.

title: Bergen Project Aids Handicapped Youngsters and Parents
description: PARAMUSA recently instituted project involving groups of eight Bergen County youngsters 5 to 16 years old is providing not only fun for them but also what is often a muchneeded breather for their parents.

title: Emily Sanford Has Nuptials
description: Emily Christine Sanford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Sanford of Foster City, Calif., was married yesterday afternoon to John Christopher Massey, son or Mr. and Mrs. John F. Massey of Newark, Del. The Rev. David Lowry performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washineton, L.I.

title: BROADER SUBSIDY ON HOUSING URGED
description: Pressed by the city and state the Ford Administration's top housing official here has asked his superiors in Washington to raise the maximumincome limits for admission to apartments that will be subsidized here under the nation's major new housing program for the poor and nearpoor.

title: Angela Cecile Nugent Married To John S. Young in Queens
description: In the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens, yesterday afternoon, Angela Cecile Nugent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Nugent 2d of Jamaica Estates, Queens, became the bride of John Spruille Young. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Young of Glen Ridge, N. J.

title: Rock n Roll Station in Babylon Is Converting to Gospel Music Next Month
description: BABYLONWBABAM, a rock n roll station here, will become the only primary gospel radio outlet on Long Island next month.

title: BRIDGE
description: If a philosopher of the French Revolution were brought back to life to view the modern world, he might find in, tournament bridge an acceptable practical application of the great motto of his age: Liberte, Egalit, Fratenit. All players are at liberty to select their own partners and teammates, with rather modest restrictions. All are equal under the laws, and face equal problems with identical hands. Each partnership and team is a fraternity.

title: 249 FLEEING TIMOR ARRIVE IN PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, Aug. 16 (UPI)  A stream of settlers fleeing Angola was joined today by a planeload of refugees from Portugal's other colonial trouble spot Timor.

title: Coast Farm Vote May End Labor Feud
description: DELANO, Calif., Aug. 16In this dusty agricultural town and others like it throughout the state, organizers for the United Farm Workers and International Brotherhood of Teamsters are engaged in what may be their last battle to see who will represent the 250,000 field hands who harvest California's nearly $1billion worth of crops each year.

title: Wajima Takes Travers Before Record Crowd
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16With Foolish Pleasure and Forceten in their stalls listening to the roar of a record crowd, Wajima raced to a onesided victory today in the 106th running of the $108,700 Travers Stakes.

title: Terry Van Gilder Is Bride of M. P. Bolan
description: Terry Van Gilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Dirck Van Gilder of Short Hills, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Patrick Bolan, son of the late William Francis Bolan and the late Helen Klein Bolan and stepson of Mrs. William Francis Bolan, all of Short Hills.

title: Finches Sublet a Terrace Flowerpot, RentFree
description: We never meant to sublet our eighthfloor terrace on East 63d Street, but this spring it was occupied by a family of six.

title: Dolphins Win, Csonka On Bench
description: MIAMI, AUG 16 (AP) Earl Morrall threw two firsthalf touchdown passes tonight to lead the Miami Dolphins to a 2014 National Football League defector, Larvictory over the Detroit Lions.

title: Vesper Pair Wins Rowing Trial Final
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 16 Bill Miller and Jim Moroney of Philadelphia's Vesper Boat Club rowed to a 7minute20.02second victory today in the pair without coxswain final of the. National Association of American Oarsmen smallboat trials.

title: The Politics of Salmon
description: COPENHAGENAs its special contribution to maintaining the world's ecological balance and, incidentally, with heartfelt thanks from sport fishermen on both tildes of the ocean, Denmark is now in the final stage of applying measures to insure that the renowned Atlantic salmon, river lord of the Northern Hemisphere, shall no longer be threatened with depletion.

title: The World
description: Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the President of Bangladesh, has been killed in a coup, and the new Government has already promised the people they will have more democracy and new Government programs to relieve the chronic illiteracy and malnutrition that afflict Bangladesh.

title: Girl Triumphs in Soap Box Derby
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 16 (AP)  Karren Stead, who likes both ballet and building minature race cars, today became the first female to win the AllAmerican Soap Box Derby world championship.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SITE FOR V.A. CEMETERY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Veterans administrator, Richard L. Roudebush has announced the selection of a site in Massachusetts for a New England regional national cemetery for veterans.

title: Due respect for the mountain
description: Good mountaineering literature charts a sometimes precarious route between two dangers. On one side is the commercial sensationalism that exploits the risks of the sport to the detriment of its considerable esthetic compensations. Sensationalism makes moneywitness the financial success of the best selling novel, The Eiger Sanction but it also lures, for the wrong reasons, thrillseekers and fools to the mountains, where they tend to flesh out the statistics that one can find in the annual accident report of the American Alpine Club.

title: Royal Glint, $17.60, Wins at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 16It came as no surprise to Dan Lasater that his Royal Glint breezed to an eightlength victory in the $109,150 Amory L. Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park today. But it did come as something of an eyeopener to most of the 24,218 fans who bet in the belief that at least four of the other five horses in the 1mile stake race would do better.

title: What Alice Said About John At Tea
description: The sexual adventures of the eminent are seldom obscure for long. They do not wait for the scholar or even the professional scavenger. Real or imaginary, they are the swiftest currency of society. Yet not in open fact, nor in all the mills of Washington, nor In all the mythology about John L. Lewis, is there any warrant thatbefore or after the death of his wife Myrtahe led anything but a proper private life.

title: Point of View
description: Now that New York City is taking all sorts of dramatic and painful steps to restore its fiscal integrity, it is time to tell the truth about the city's most fundamental source of revenue and its only measure of debt capacityits real property tax base.

title: Libraries Offering Varied Programs
description: NORTHPORT  Schoolchildren are making their way in record numbers to Suffolk County libraries this summer for games, craft workshops, art activities and programs that feature entertainers ranging from folk singers to a 10foot python named Irving.

title: The Way It Was 1876
description: Lexington and Concord had celebrated the birth of American liberty, separately and with mutual recriminations, the year before. Boston had held appropriate exercises at Bunker Hill. Then, on the Eve of the New Year, the bells at Philadelphia rang out 1776 and 1876, followed by a hundred peals.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Yamaha to Drop Allegations On Safety of Motorcycles
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) The makers of Yamaha motorcycles have agreed to stop contending their motorcycles are safer than cars and to warn old customers that they run a substantially higher likelihood of accidental death or serious injury, the Federal Trade Commission announced yesterday.

title: L. H. GREGORY
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 16 (UPI)L. H. Gregory, sports editor of The Oregonian for more than 50 years, died in a nursing home here yesterday. He was 89 years old.

title: Saul Bellow's new, open, spacious novel about art, society and a bizarre poet
description: Wittgenstein once described the philosopher's task as that of showing the fly the way out of the flybottle. Might we not say about a certain kind of novelist that the effect, if not the conscious aim, of his work is to demonstrate to the fly that it's in fact in a bottle, that those transparent surfaces are no temporary impediment? I've always thought of Saul Bellow as a novelist of this type, seeing in his work a species of desperate entanglement, usually antic but sometimes grave and even somber. as in The Victim and Mr. Sammler's Planet. I've felt a dry fever rising from, his pages, a fever induced, it may be, by the damp walls of the trap. When it hasn't risen too high. resulting in querulousness and a shuffling over of old remedies, it gives his novels their lucidity and edge. preventing them from being taken as bad dreams, fictions in the wrong sense.

title: Back to Stagflation. . .
description: Stagflation appears to have taken its place as one mankind's least understood and most incurable diseases. With economic recovery barely begun and unemployment still hanging above 8 per cent, inflation is reviving. One gets the feeling of dj vumixed with despair.

title: Sealyham Wins Twice In Two Days
description: EASTON, Md., Aug. 16A saucy little Sealyham terrier from Wales, who had been away from the ring for two months until she was named best in show at Mispillion in Harrington, Del., yesterday, was right back in the ring today for the 24th time.

title: The Monthly Miracle
description: All of the distasteful medicine New York City has been forcefed for several weeks was supposed to improve not only its financial condition but its appearance, especially in the eyes of potential investors across the country. The evidence is strong that the effort has so far been a failure.

title: The Nation
description: Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, the Ford Administration's point man in reconnoitering the delicate question of whether to sell more grain to the Soviet Union, has taken a prudent temporary position. He has called for a halt in sales while he gets a better reading on the size of the coming American crop and, presumably, on the severity of the political reaction that will come as a consequence of his decision.

title: SAM B. SAPIRSTEIN
description: Sam B. Sapirstein, a specialist in life insurance estate planning, died Friday evening at his home, 10 Plaza Street, Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

description: TeamAB, 4,041; H

title: Policeman Killed in Spain
description: MADRID, Aug. 16 (AP)Four gunmen ambushed and killed a policeman near his suburban home today, raising to eight the number of policeman killed by terrorists in two months, officials said. The assailants, who escaped, left pamphletS identifying themselves as members the Patriotic and AntiFascist Revolutionary Front.

title: Kids' Clothes:
description: Fashionable, for 1975 kids, is a long way from what grandmother used to think was proper. Mary Janes, smocked Liberty lawn dresses and Eton suits are on the list of endangered species. Today's child wears a collection of clothes that includes jacquard sweaters, pea coats, football team jackets, jumpers, overalls, Chinese padded jackets and Ultrasude shirts.

title: CANADA'S PARTIES LOSE BIG DONORS
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 16  The aftermath of corporate scandals involving American companies abroad has hurt political fundraising in Canada, where the two leading parties traditionally rely upon business contributions, which are legal here, to cover a major proportion of their campaign expenses.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: THE GOOD OLD BOYS, by Paul Hemphill. (Anchor, $2.95.) A talented journalist's eulogy and epitaph for the world he grew up inthe South of rednecks, country singers, stock car racers, moonshiners and hard preachers.

title: Mary S. Ayres, Randall Hack Have Nuptials
description: Mary Stuart Ayres, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Dillaway Ayres of New York and Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Randall Anthony Hack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn., and Lyme, N.H.

title: Gardiners I. Is Opening To Visitors
description: GARDINERS ISLANDRobert David Lion Gardiner has a 4,000acre island he loves to show the general public. For a price, that is, with proceeds going to a worthy cause.

description: TodayAnnapolis K.C. allbreed and obedience, Sandy Point State Park, Route 50, west end of Bay Bridge, Annapolis, Md., 2,027 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Archives Document History Of City
description: Most of the city's archives the documentation of its triumphs and its defeats and its many verbose Mayorscan be found in Brooklyn. The rest of the archivessome 15 per centis stored at the Municipal Archives and Record. Center, 23 Park. Row, Manhattan.

title: Explosion and Fire Level Most of a Syracuse Block
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 16 (UPI)A fire and explosion, apparently caused when an electrical spark ignited leaking gas, leveled most of a city block in downtown Syracuse tonight.

title: Sonorous names with identical suffixes
description: One of the more curious features of Americans struggling with their pedigrees is our embarrassing tendency to treat our ancestors the way we treat our children. The wish is not so much to rediscover as to vindicate and reform, to set them straight, to create them in our own image. Our ancestors, like our children, must be worthy of us. So it was an occasion of some pain when Michael J. Arlen (a staff writer on The New Yorker, where this book originally appeared), remembered how slightingly his father, whose family name was Kouyoumjian, spoke of Armenians (They end up boring you to death). The father was remote, dismissing, and his legacy to the son was an uneasiness the son sometimes calls fear and sometimes hatred for the fact of being halfArmenian.

title: U.S. U2 Crashes in Thailand
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 16 (UPI)A highaltitude U2 reconnaissance plane being ferried to Arizona crashed yesterday after takeoff from a United States airfield, in Thailand, an Air Force spokesman here said. The plane was not on a reconnaissance mission, he said. There was no immediate word on the fate of the pilot.

title: Catalytic Converters Called An Automotive Fire Hazard
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Environmental Protection Agency says that the catalytic converter can be a fire hazard if a car's engine is not maintained properly.

title: Greece Is Expected to Become the 10th Member of the Common Market Only After Extensive Bargaining
description: ATHENS, Aug. 15The acceptance of Greece as the 10th member of the European Ecomomic Community seems virt??ally assured since none of the nine present members would oppose the application publicly. Some of the nine have doubts, however, and a lengthy process of hard bargaining lies ahead, according to diplomats. Greek officials know that their economy will have a tough time competing against the industrialized nations of Western Europe, but they are hoping that the bloc will provide the incentive and the resources Greece needs to modernize her agriculture and industry.

title: LatinAmerican Drug Sales Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16A research study financed by Consumers Union says it has found evidence that multinational drug companies take advantage of a weaker regulatory situation in Latin America to pursue labeling and advertising policies of a dangerous kind.

title: A Tercentenary for Salem
description: SALEMAs if marking the nation's Bicentennial were not enough, Salem County also has another important celebration on its hands: its tercentenary.

title: Music: Entremont Fils
description: Philippe Entremont usually follows in the footsteps of his pianist mother, but every so often the French virtuoso takes after his conductor father instead. On Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Entremont did both, repeating his 1973 tour de force of conducting three concertos from the keyboard. On this occasion, he Stayed true to the festival title and made it Mostly Mozart: the Concerto in C (K. 415) and the Coronation Concerto (K. 537), plus the Piano Concerto No. 1 of Beethoven.

title: Jessica S. Whalen Is Affianced To S. Alexander Haverstick 2d
description: The engagement of Jessica Stevenson Whalen to S. Alexander Haverstick 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Whalen of Short Hills, N. J., and Hilton Head Island, S. C., parents of the future bride.

title: Looking for the Answers on Energy Shock'
description: WASHINGTON  Energy shock is a relatively new term used by economists to describe the unusual effect of an increase in oil prices on the economy at largedemand, production, employment, the price level.

title: Replacing Damaged Sections of Wood Clapboard or Broken Wood Shingles
description: When the exterior wood siding around the outside of a house starts to split or rot out in sections, repairs should be made promptly to keep moisture and insects from entering, and to keep the condition from getting worse (defects such as this allow water to enter and cause paint to peel from surrounding boards, as well as possibly hastening the swelling and eventual rotting of other sections).

title: Kissinger Briefs Ford on the Mideast
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 16Secretary of State Kissinger briefed President Ford here today on the progress of Middle East negotiations as they evidently awaited a signal from Israel that would lead to a resumption of shuttle diplomacy by Mr. Kissinger next week.

title: Deck Planters Solve a Space Problem
description: A space problem? Why not raise squash and melons in planters? We have tried it on a sunny deck and friends who said it couldn't be done are now eating their wordsand my squash!

title: Dtente on the rocks
description: LITTLE DIOMEDE ISLAND, AlaskaFor most Americans, the Soviet Union, despite jet travel and nuclear ICBM's, seems half a world away. But even on a misty day in the middle of the Bering Strait, the 130 Americans of Little Diomede IslandEskimoscan see the nearby gray hulk of Big Diomede Island, which is in the Soviet Union. The two rocky islands are less than three miles apart. During half of each year, when the sea's surface is frozen hard, the people of Little Diomede (pronounced dieuhmede) can walk from their village to the SovietAmerican border in about 15 minutes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Modern automated cameras, which are designed to insure accurate exposure, have given photographers freedom to concentrate on their subject, but they may also tend to inhibit a more creative approach that can result from the selective use of individual camera controls. Fortunately, many cameras have manual overrides for their automated features which make it possible to achieve the special effects that are inherent in a camera's operation.

title: Lobbyists' Employers Warned on Fee Statements
description: Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo has warned that he will seek imposition of a $100aday penalty if people employing lobbyists fail to file statements of fees paid to lobbyists for their work in Albany. The deadline for filing is Sept. 12.

title: China's Summer Crops Reported at Peak Yield
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16 (AP)China's wheat, barley and other summer crops reached new highs in production this year, Peking's official Hsinhua press agency reported today in a broadcast monitored here.

title: MRS. NEIL M'ELROY
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 16Mary Camilla McElroy, widow of Neil McElroy, former Secretary of Defense and president of the Procter & Gamble Company, died here Thursday. She was 72 years old.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The summer music festival season in the United States starts tapering off this weekend. It is a phenomenon, and it seems to get bigger and bigger every year. Only a generation ago, at the end of World War II, there was very little music in this country eluring the summer. The Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood was the big one. Various cities played host to their orchestrasNew York in Lewisohn Stadium, Hollywood at the Bowl, and so onbut those were not really festivals.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Bloomfield, Clifton, Frankford Township, Hackensack, Passaic and Wayne. Further information can be obtained by calling the respective libraries.

title: School Planetarium Enlarges Schedule
description: TOMS RIVERIn response to requests by Ocean County residents, the show schedule at the Robert J. Novine Planetarium at Ocean County College has been expanded. The pubic can now attend programs daily, except Mondays, at 120 and 3 P.M., as well as Friday and Saturday evenings at 7:30 and 9.

title: Cynthia Baum Fiancee Of Mark S. Baicker
description: Cynthia Bette Baum and Mark Scott Baicker, graduates of Washington University in St. Louis, who will continue their studies next month at Temple University, plan to be married next July.

title: Connecticut Democrats Adopt '76 Presidential Primary Plan
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 15 In keeping with an order from the Democratic National Committee, Connecticut's Democrats have adopted a plan providing for a Presidential primary next May 11 to choose 51 delegates to the party's national convention.

description: EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 16 (AP)Ron Ray of North Carolina Central, one of the runners involved earlier in a dispute over qualifying heats in the 400 meters, raced to victory today in the trials for the United States PanAmerican Games team. His time was 45.42 seconds.

title: Correction
description: The article TV's 19thCentury Sportscaster, which appeared in last Sunday's Arts and Leisure Section, incorrectly stated that Heywood Hale Broun would be part of the CBS reporting team for yesterday's Travers Stakes at Saratoga.

title: CALIFORNIA SEEKS SMITH EVIDENCE
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 17The State of California will go into Federal court tomorrow in an effort to obtain stillsecret grand jury evidence against C. Arnholt Smith, to be used in a new criminal investigation of the once powerful financier and patron of Richard M. Nixon.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 17 (AP)The Australian Government has given a tract of land back to an aboriginal tribe on the basis that it was the tribe's traditional property. It is believed to be the first time such an award was made.

description: The head of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday again denied that he had quashed studies recommending hospital closings and layoffs in the midst of the city's fiscal crisis.

description: AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 17The Russian boar is threatening Utopia.

title: Pilot Nutrition Program Is Operating in the State
description: ANDOVERA new kind of preventive health care program has been operating quietly but successfully in New Jersey since early 1974. It is a pilot nutrition program financed solely by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Woman, 79, Found Slain In Room at the Barbizon
description: The police interviewed the staff and guests yesterday at the Barbizon Hotel at 140 East 63rd Street, where a 79yearold woman was found strangled to death in the bathroom of her 11thfloor room Friday morning.

description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 17President Ford directed Secretary of State Kissinger today to undertake a critically important mission to the Middle East this week in search of a successful conclusion to negotiations for a new separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces in Sinai.

description: CAMDEN, Aug. 17 (AP)One man was killed and 15 persons were injured yesterday when two firetrucks rushing to a blaze collided at an intersection here.

title: Algerian Aide Seized By Refugees in France
description: PARIS, Aug. 17 (AP)A group of displaced Algerians living in France seized an Algerian official in central France today and demanded that the French Government provide housing for 1,400 persons living in refugee camps, the French police reported.

title: Housing Starts Gain

Dodge Division, an authority on housing developments, said today 320,716 new housing units were built during the quarter. title: BRONFMAN'S SON RESCUED IN CITY AFTER A PAYMENT OF $2.3MILLION; MONEY RECOVERED, 2 SUSPECTS HELD
description: Samuel Bronfman 2d, the 21yearold heir to the Seagram liquor fortune, was rescued at 4 A.M. yesterday on the ninth day of his kidnapping. He was freed without violence by 40 to 60 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and New York City policemen who surprised a captor in an apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Two Suspects' Neighbors Bemused and Incredulous
description: Mommy, why are all the people in the lobby? the little towhead asked his mother as they emerged yesterday from their firstfloor apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn at 6:30 A.M. and noticed the group of women in housecoats talking near a table in front of a 10foothigh mirror.

title: Portuguese Reds to Meet in Hostile City
description: ALCOBACA, Portugal, Aug. 17  The Portuguese Communist party announced today that it would go ahead with its plans to hold a rally Tuesday night in Oporto, the capital of the antiCommunist north, despite its humiliating defeat here last night.

title: Two Suspects' Neighbors Bemused and Incredulous
description: Mommy, why are all the people in the lobby? the little towhead asked his mother as they emerged yesterday from their firstfloor apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn at 6:30 A.M. and noticed the group of women in housecoats talking near a table in front of a 10foothigh mirror.

title: Student Experimenters Tap Their Ingenuity in Contest to Solve Energy Crisis
description: There, spread across two acres of pavement, stood a carnival of contraptionsmirrors, clamps, hoses, reflectors, converters, wires, propellers, ducts, cables, sails, meters, gauges, and, here and there, something referred to as an anaerobic digester or a Darrieus rotor.

title: Federal Hearings Planned On College Hiring Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17The Department of Labor will begin this week a series of hearings to study the rules governing affirmative action plans to end employment discriminalion in higher, education.

title: Soviet's Reports Are Cautious
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Soviet newspapers today published cautiously worded Tass press agency reports on the coup in Bangladesh that appeared to indicate that Moscow was deferring judgment of the new regime.

title: Miss Silverman Chicago Bride
description: Bonnie Sue Silverman, who is with the Becker Securities Corporation, was married yesterday to Douglas S. Winter, a vice president of Lewco Securities. Rabbi Victor Weisberg performed the ceremony at the Drake in Chicago.

title: Study Here Finds Inequities For Hispanic Defendants
description: Inequities in the city's criminal justice system jeopardize the constitutional rights of thousands of Spanishspeaking defendants, according to a report released yesterday by the New York County Lawyers' Association.

title: Hawthorne Unit Wins
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Hawthorne, N.J., Caballeros successfully defended their senior drum and bugle corps championship with a final score of 89.30 in competition this weekend at the American Legion's national convention here.

title: KISSINGER MISSION FOR MIDEAST PACT BEGINS THIS WEEK
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 17President Ford directed Secretary of State Kissinger today to undertake a critically important mission to the Middle East this week in search of a successful conclusion to negotiations for a new separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces in Sinai.

title: LUCILLE MILNER, 87, A FOUNDER OF A.C.L.U.
description: Lucille Bernheimer Milner, who was a founder of the American Civil Liberties Union and a spokesman for many facets of social legislation, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Doctors Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived at 325 East 79th Street.

title: CHARLES OLIVIER, ASTRONOMER, DIES
description: Dr. Charles Pollard Olivier, an astronomer and a leading authority on meteors, died Thursday in Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Narberth, Pa.

title: Fiddles Burn While Bluegrass Plays at Festival
description: FORT ANN, N. Y., Aug. 17 I burned my fiddle today, the man told Raymond McLain Jr. And after hearing your sister, my friend is burning his bass, too.

title: Egyptians Welcome Trip
description: CAIRO, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Egyptian officials expressed welcome tonight for the Middle East visit by Secretary of State Kissinger to put final touches on an interim EgyptianIsraeli agreement on Sinai.

title: 2 TV Makers Accused of False '73 Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission accused the makers of Panasonic and General Electric color television sets today of falsely advertising that their 1973 models were more reliable than competitors'.

title: Whites Report Rise in Contacts With Blacks Over Last Decade
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17  Whites say their contacts with blackst slowly but steadily increased between 1964 and 1974.

title: Morton Raises Giants' Summer Stock
description: Morton Raises Giants' Summer Stock

title: Deregulation of Crude Oil To Drive Up Cost of Fuels
description: After the Ford Administration deregulates domestic crude oil prices at the end of August, motorists and homeowners are likely to face increases of 2 cents to 4 cents a gallon for gasoline and homeheating fuel during the following four months, and additional sizable increases in the first half of 1976, according to analysts and industry experts.

title: Randall J. LeBoeuf Jr. Is Dead; A Specialist in Utility Law, 78
description: Randall J. LeBoeuf Jr., a former state Assistant Attorney General and a founder and counsel of the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, died Saturday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Man Held in Ford Threat
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 17 (Reuters)A former convict has been arrested here for threatening to kill President Ford when he visits here next month. A police spokesman said that Thomas Elbert, 34 years old, made the threat in a telephone call to the local office of the Secret Service yesterday. The police said that the arrested man had threatened to kill President Nixon while he was in office.

title: CUBANS ACCLAIM MEXICAN LEADER
description: HAVANA, Aug. 17Premier Fidel Castro and over half a million Cubans gave President Luis Echeverra Alvarez of Mexico a tumultuous welcome in the streets of Havana today. It was the first meeting between the two men.

title: G.M. Workers Returning
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 17 (AP)About 2,900 furloughed workers return to work this week as the General Motors assembly plant here starts production of the subcompact Chevette, a company spokesman said over the weekend.

title: Talk With Sihanouk Hinted as Cambodia Leader Visits China Port
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 17Khieu Samphan, the Cambodian leader visiting China, flew without explanation today from Peking to Luta, a port in northeastern China seldom seen by foreigners.

title: About New York
description: This has been a sobersided summer in New York. The traditional flow of hotse?? son news has been upstaged by the City Hall production of If I Had a Million, a daytime series starring Mayor Beame and Big Mac.

title: Dr. Robert Brill Marries Alice Lytton
description: Alice Lytton of Larchmont, N. Y., and the. Springs, East Hampton, L. I., widow of Budd Lytton and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Cole of Sarasota, Fla., was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Robert Brill of Fort Lee, N. J., son of Mrs. Morris M. Brill of New York and the late Dr. Brill, an osteopath.

title: Indochina in Flux
description: The Communist bloc's own power struggle for preeminence in Indochina shows signs of intensifying, just three months after the United States abandoned the region in defeat. A complex tangle of ideological and historical rivalries is provoking friction, not only between China and the Soviet Union but between Vietnamese and Cambodians, and among differing factions in their revolutionary regimes.

title: CHARTER REVISION GETS WHITNEY AID
description: A campaign to sell the idea of charter change to New York City voters is being assembled with the financial assistance of one of the city's wealthiest Republican contributors, John Hay Whitney.

title: Martha Mitchell Links Nixon to Marital Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Martha Mitchell said today that former President Richard M. Nixon was responsible for the breakup of her marriage.

title: Neto Is Reported Unhurt
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Mateus Neto, a leading figure of the National Front, reported to have been kidnapped at the Luanda airport Friday, is being held in the Luanda headquarters of the Popular Movement and is unhurt, his wife said today.

title: Block of Stores in Syracuse Leveled by $3Million Blast and Fire
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 17 (UPI)An explosion and fire leveled most of a downtown city block here and caused at least $3million damage.

title: Commodity Trading Soaring to Records
description: Trading in commodity futures is booming after being in the doldrums since last fall. Commodity brokers report record volumes of business and see no letup in the foreseeable future.

title: Kissinger, in Tanzania Case, Affirms Curbs on Ambassadors
description: VAIL, Cola, Aug. 17Secretary of State Kissinger strongly reaffirmed here today that United States ambassadors were forbidden to negotiate with terrorists for the release of captured Americans.

title: F.B.I. StakeOut Led to Capture
description: For 24 hours before Samuel Bronfman 2d was rescued from his kidnappers, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents were sitting in stakeout cars outside the Brooklyn homes of the two alleged abductors, evidently unaware that the boundandgagged victim was only steps away.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In his first major shakeup of prison personnel, the New York State Commissioner of Correctional Services, Benjamin Ward, announced yesterday the replacement of three of the four top officials at the Great Meadow State Correctional Facility at Comstock. He said the action followed disclosures of serious deficiencies in the operation of the prison under the previous administrators.

title: Greece and Turkey Seeking More Equality in U. S. Ties
description: ATHENS, Aug. 15  Twentyeight years after the Truman Doctrine proclaimed American responsibility for Greece and Turkey, both countries continue to rely heavily on the United States for their military and economic wellbeing. But these two Mediterranean nations have emerged into a new stage of development in which they are demanding more equality in their relationships with Washington.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A joint legislative committee tomorrow plans to inspect the Menlo Park Diagnostic Center, the only residential center in the state for troubled children, which is scheduled to close Sept. 1. State Senator Alexander J. Menza said members of the Joint Legislative MentalHealth Committee would then recommend to Governor Byrne whether the center should remain open. Menlo Park was a victim of massive state budget cuts, and although a special bill was passed by the Legislature to restore $2million in appropriations, the Governor has not decided whether to sign the measure.

title: AUDIENCE BOOGIES TO WAR, SOUL GROUP
description: War, the soul group, was the headliner at a Madison Square Garden concert Saturday night that was so geared to dancing music it was amazing the promoter deemed seats necessary. And it further underlined the fact that the discothque craze has taken over a large portion of the music scene today.

title: Deregulation of Crude Oil To Drive Up Cost of Fuels
description: After the Ford Administration deregulates domestic crude oil prices at the end of August, motorists and homeowners are likely to face increases of 2 cents to 4 cents a gallon for gasoline and, homeheating fuel during the following four months, and additional sizable increases in the first half of 1976, according to analysts and industry experts.

title: In Memoriam
description: GREENEJean O. Every day you are our hearts and minds with abiding love forever. The Greene Family

title: Mademoiselle Mobilizing Beauty
description: Mademoiselle magazine, written for the 18to30yearold single female market, has long had an active marketing and promotional program. Its youth marketing department uses college and career women for research and sampling purposes, while its sounding board brings some of its readers before some of its advertisers to discuss product likes and dislikes.

title: Times Using Photocomposition To Produce Its Classified Pages
description: The New York Times today began producing its classifiedadvertising pages by photocomposition, eliminating the traditional Linotype machines and hot type.

title: Wisconsin Scout Band Wins
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 The Madison Scouts of Madison, Wis. used banjos to win the DrumCorps International Championship last night. The 135member drum and bugle corps used dueling banjo routine to win. They also won the marchand hornline titles.

title: They Still Love Lulu
description: The end product of much hotpotato throwing at top levels in Albany has been a decision by Attorney General Lefkowitz that it is legal to let members of the State Legislature have the $878,500 in lulus which they voted for themselves on the final day of the 1975 session.

title: Jets Find Victory A Laughing Matter
description: The Jets had a long laugh yesterday, still chuckling over their 1413 victory the night before over the Cardinals at St. Louis.

title: Champagne Party Greets Freed Heir in Yorktown
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 17Samuel Bronfman 2d came home today at 4:49 P.M.

title: CURFEW IS EASED BY DACCA REGIME
description: CALCUTTA, India, Aug 17The new Government of Bangladesh, declaring that the country was fast returning to normal after the military coup Friday, eased the curfew today in the major cities.

title: Koosrnan Helps Seaver Win,30; Yankees Beaten, 53, by Royals
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 17The Yankees had one of those afternoons today when nothin went right.

title: BRONFMAN'S SON RESCUED IN CITY AFTER A PAYMENT OF $2.3 MILLION; MONEY RECOVERED, 2 SUSPECTS HELD
description: Samuel Bronfman 2d, the 21yearold heir to the Seagram liquor fortune, was rescued at 4 A.M. yesterday on the ninth day of his kidnapping. He was freed without violence by 40 to 60 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and New York City policemen who surprised a captor in an apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: RAYMOND HENDERSHOT
description: W. Raymond Hendershot, who retired in 1962 as associate budget director at New York University, died Saturday at his home, 207 Belvidere Avenue, Washington, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Theme Amusement Parks Flourishing In the State, and Economy Is the Gainer
description: SMITHVILLE, Aug. 17The famed New Jersey seashore is the heart of the state's $3.5billion tourist industry, but another aspect of the recreation business, one with a greater potential for growth, is flourishing in the hinterlands.

title: State Finds 20% of New Pupils Lack Sufficient Immunization
description: ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP)The State Health Department said today that 20 per cent of the children starting school in the state each year were not adequately immunized against polio, measles, diphtheria and rubella.

title: Fern Zimel Wed
description: Fern Zimel of Freehold, N.J., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Margolis of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon to David S. Lande, a lawyer and Republican district leader in New York. Rabbi Irving J. Bloch performed the ceremony at the Carlyle. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Jerome J. Lande of New York, and the late Mr. Lande, also a lawyer and Republican district leader. Mr. Lande's mother, Selma Lande, is a portrait painter. Both the bride and bridegroom were previously married and divorced.

title: A Bit HeavyHanded
description: Mopie and Hodari specialize in abstract paintings with interesting textures, but they're hardly runofthemill artists. All they want for their work is an occasional banana.

title: Soviet Trawler Seized Off Cape May On Violation of a U.S. Fishing Statute
description: A Soviet fishing trawler was seized by the Coast Guard 84 miles off Cape May, N.J., early yesterday on charges of illegally fishing for lobster and crab on the Continental Shelf.

title: Contract to Rumanian Unit
description: AMMAN, Aug. 17 (Reuters)A Rumanian enterprise, Industrial Export, today won a 58 million dinar (about $174million contract to expand Jordan's oil refinery, according to refinery sources.

title: Living in New York: An Artist Finds Art, and Tools, in SoHo
description: Jim Starbuck, bounding like a stork through the caverns of SoHo with an eye peeled for treasure, finds a bonanza between the garbage bins on Broome Street.

title: New FlareUp Reported in Angolan Port
description: LUANDA, Angola, Monday, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola captured the territory's major harbor city of Lobito from two rival groups yesterday but the city was later counterattacked, the Portuguese High Commissioner here Raid.

title: J. S. Lefkowitz Weds Judith Cohen
description: Judith Ann Cohen of New York, daughter of Mrs. Marvin Stafford Cohen of Hollywood, Fla., and the late Mr. Cohen, was married yesterday to Jeremy Samson Lefkowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lefkowitz of New York. Rabbi Max Gelb of New Rochelle, N. Y., uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at his home there.

title: Utopia, Tex., Blames The Russian Boar For Taxation Woes
description: AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 17The Russian boar is threatening Utopia.

title: WageFreeze Law Is Seen As Threat to Bargaining
description: The future of collective bargaining by public employes in the city and the state has been seriously jeopardized by the wagefreeze legislation passed by the City Council last week, according to worried laborrelations officials and union leaders.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Spa's Diana Captured By Heloise
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 17 (AP)Tartan Stables Heloise, ridden by Michael Venezia, held off the closing rush of James H. Black's Victorian Queen to win by a neck in the 37th running of the $59,000 Diana Handicap at Saratoga today.

title: MOSHE SILBERG, 75, LED ISRAELI COURT
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 (AP)Moshe Silberg, former president of Israel's Supreme Court and a leading authority on Jewish law, died yesterday at the age of 75.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: City Justice System: If the State Pays More

title: Influx of Latin Tourists Saving Miami's Summer
description: MIAMI, Aug. 17A record high influx of Latin visitors has given the ailing tourist industry here a badly needed financial shot in the arm, improving the prospects of a summer season that many hotel men feared would be the worst in a decade.

title: Cambodians to Visit North Kor
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The North Korea radio announced today that the Cambodian leaders now visiting China would pay an official goodwill visit to Pyongyang soon. They are expected to meet there with Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

title: L.I. Parkway Police Seek Panel to Study Complaints
description: Leaders of the Long Island state parkway police union offered yesterday to suspend a superenforcement drive on traffic infractions if the state appointed a special panel to look into the police officers' complaints.

title: Whites Report Rise in Contacts With Blacks Over Last Decade
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17  Whites say their contacts with blacks slowly but steadily increased between 1964 and 1974.

title: 45% FOUND TO BACK FORD AS PRESIDENT
description: After a year in office, President Ford commands the support of 45 per cent of the nation, according to the latest Gallup Poll, as against the 71 per cent he had when he entered the White House.

title: TREASURY ISSUES DRAW INVESTORS
description: Disintermediation  a bugaboo in 1974 to savings institutions but a boon to cashrich investors and regional banksis starting to rear its head again. This is a process where by money, spurred by rising interest rates, moves out of savings banks and savings and loan associations, into higheryielding Treasury securities.

title: CAMPAIGN REFORM DUE FOR MICHIGAN
description: LANSING, Mich., Aug. 17Gov. William G. Milliken plans to sign this week a comprehensive political reform measure that provides for partial public funding of campaigns for the governorship.

title: Lisbon Military, Roots MiddleClass, Disproves Rhetoric of the Revolution
description: LISBON, Aug. 17The Portuguese armed forces are provling much more moderate in their outlook toward change in Portugal than the revolutionary rhetoric of the past year has indicated.

title: Amy Davis Married
description: Amy Elisabeth Davis, daughter of Mrs. Martin D. Davis of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Dr. Davis, was married yesterday in New Haven to Arthur Asher Stein, son of Mrs. Joseph Stein of University Heights, Ohio, and the late. Mr. Stein. Rabbi Alvin Berkun performed the ceremony in the Branford Chapel of Yale University, where the bridegroom received master's degrees in international relations and political science. He and his wife are graduates of Cornell University. She will retain her maiden name.

title: U.S. Seizes Soviet Ship 84 Miles Off Cape May on Fishing Violation
description: A Soviet fishing trawler was seized by the Coast Guard 84 miles off Cape May N.J., early yesterday on charges of illegally fishing for lobster and crab on the Continental Shelf.

title: Nude Bathers Move to Reclaim Cape Cod Beach
description: TRURO, Mass., Aug. 17Wouldbe nude bathers are renewing efforts to reclaim the Cape Cod. National Seashore's beach at Truro that has been banned to them this summer by a Federal order.a Federal judge's ruling last month that bathers must be attired. A hearing before a threejudge panel is expected in late October.

title: AT POINT O'WOODS, L. I. GREAT SOUTH BAY Y.R.A.
Aaron Steinberg, Translator, World Jewish Congress Aide
description: Dr. Aaron Steinberg, for many years director of the cultural department of the World Jewish Congress in London, died there yesterday. He was 84 years old and had made his home in Londo since 1934.

title: EDWARD N. GODDARD
description: Edward N. Goddard, a pilot in World War U, who was shot down over Belgium and imprisoned by the Germans for 22 months, died Friday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Albany Medical Center. He was 54 years old and lived in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: In Czechoslovakia, Car and Good Salary Are Rewards for the Politically Loyal
description: MLADA BOLESLAV, Czechoslovakia  Last week Petari Louda, a 25yearold government farm worker and Cornmunist, took delivery of the new car for which he had been saving.

title: Bronfman Ransom Ranks 4th in Recent Kidnappings
description: The $2.3million given to the kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d was among the highest ransoms ever paid, but at least three recently paid ransoms have been larger.

title: Charming Chelsea: A Multifaceted Neighborhood That Cares
description: Chelsea has treeshaded streets and some of the loveliest brownstones in New York. It also has highrise co  ops, public housing projects and seedy tenements. On one of its blocks, the renters of a $900amonth duplex look out on beer drinkers on the stoop of a $25aweek rooming house.

title: Recovery Signs Outside U.S. Few and Feeble
description: Outside the United States, signs of recovery from recession are few and feeble. Forecasts earlier this year that an upturn would now be starting in such other industrial countries as West Germany and Japan were inaccurate.

title: J. J. George, Meteorologist, Set Up Eastern Airline Unit
description: MIAMI, Aug. 17 (UPI)Joseph J. George, who founded Eastern Airlines meteorology department and was a member of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's advisory committee on weather control, died Thursday at his home in Coral Gables. He was 66 years old.

title: The Diana Handicap Chart
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Revolution in City Hall?
description: The seven top business leaders and the president of the Central Labor Council whom Mayor Beame named last week to serve with insurance executive Richard R. Shinn on his new Management Advisory Board seem unlikely candidates to manage a revolution. But that is what they will have to accomplish if they are to fulfill their mission of overthrowing antiquated and inefficient municipal management practices, so that New York can cut expenses without crippling vital services,

title: Patience, Faith and $600,000
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.
