Y., Aug. 17Barn 73, which houses some of the horses handled by Steve DiMauro beside the training track called Oklahoma, is identified by a blue sign with a capital D in Old English script and the words: The DiMauralizer. Steve's runners have more than lived up to that description lately. On the last four weekends he saddled four starters in four stakes offering $100,000 each in added money. On July 26 he won the Sorority at Monmouth Park with Dearly Precious, the daughter of Dr. Fager who tops the 2yearold fillies right now. On Aug 2 he sent Wajima out to take the Monmouth Invitetional. On Aug 10 the 4yearold Pass A Glance brought $21,820 back to the barn after finishing second to 6yearold Susan's Girl in the Delaware Handicap. And yesterday Wajima smothered the opposition in the Travers Stakes, 112yearold showpiece of Saratoga's annual meeting.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss has proposed volunteer patrols to cope with the problem of dogs that are allowed to run free in the parks and foul the city's sidewalks. To discuss the subject, he scheduled an open meeting of his Committee on Environmental Protection at 10 A.M. tomorrow in the City Council offices on the second floor of City Hall.

title: Los Angeles Ends Pornography Clash
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17Mayor Tom Bradley's intervention has brought about a truce in a dispute between the liberal City Attorney, Burt Pines, and the conservative, outspoken police chief, Edward M. Davis.

title: World Team Tennis
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES Pittsburgh 26, New York 22. Golden Gate 25, Los Angeles 24. Indiana 26, Cleveland 25. Phoenix 31, Los Angeles 19. FINAL STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL ON HEARING AIDS
description: Governor Carey has signed a bill that will permit the state o take a new approach to regulation of the hearingaid industry in an effort to end abuses that threatened the health and, in rare cases, the lives of some people.

title: Hoffa's Wife in Hospital; Strain and Stress Blamed
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17 (UPI) Josephine Hoffa, the ailing wife of the missing former Teamsters union leader, James R. Hoffa, collapsed at her home on the 18th day of his disappearance today and was taken to a Detroit hospital.

title: BURDETT O'CONNOR SR.
description: Burdett H. O'Connor Sr., a former yacht salesman for Colonial Cruisers, died Thursday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N. J. He was 79 years Told and lived in Verona, N. J.

title: Personal Finance: I.R.S. Takes Dim View of Mexican Divorce
description: Mexican divorces may resist challenge in some courts but the Internal Revenue Service continues to take an extremely dim view of their validity for income tax purposes.

title: Shelley Taub Wed To Engineer Here
description: Shelley Miriam Taub, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Taub of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday afternoon to Alfred Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Klein of Yonkers.

title: Vladimir Kuts, Track Star, Won Soviet Olympic Medals
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP)Vladimir Kuts, the longdistance runner who earned the Soviet Union its first Olympic gold medals, died yesterday, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: HOWARD U. ARCHER
description: Howard Underhill Archer, editor and owner of The Rye (N.Y.) Chronicle, a weekly newspaper, died Friday at his home in Glenville, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: AT GREENWICH COVE R.A. EASTOFRYE Y.R.A.
Bridge:
description: The American Bridge Association, which organizes tournaments on all evels primarily for black players, wound up its Summer National at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel here Saturday, completing nine days of activity.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: KERN'S TURN. There have been nostalgic salutes to showbusiness musicians in recent years, in both recordings and stage tributes, most prominently on Broadway in the packages of Sammy Cahn tunes and Rodgers & Hart. Except for an occasional revival Off Off Broadway (with a Broadwaybound Roberta due this fall), the music of Jerome Kern has been neglected.

title: Republican Courts Mississippi Blacks
description: COLUMBUS, Miss., Aug. 15 In several ways, Gil Carmichael is the most unlikely candidate of the year.

title: Decline in Major Faiths' Influence in City Reflects Last 10 Years of Urban Change
description: New York City's three major religious faiths, buffeted by theological, cultural and social forces, have undergone striking changes in the last 10 years.

title: MoneyTrading Business Calm and Restrained Year After Crisis
description: A major international oil company recently approached a big New York bank and said it needed five million British pounds to complete one of its overseas transactions. Two years ago, the deal would have been routine.

title: Job Well Done
description: Buffeted by the frustrations and riddles still surrounding the names of Patty Hearst and James Hoffa, an anxious public has been treated to a happy ending in the case of 21yearold Samuel Bronfman 2d,

title: A HOMELAND CHIEF IN AFRICA IS SLAIN
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 17Chief Philemon Elifas, principal minister of the partly selfgoverning tribal homeland of Ovambo in SouthWest Africa, was shot to death last night outside the home of his brother in the village of Ondangwa.

title: Mary Solomon Is Bride Of David Lloyd Perkins
description: Mary Elizabeth Solomon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Jacob Solomon of Woodmere, L. I., was married last evening to David Lloyd Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lawrence Perkins of Westbury,L. I. Rabbi Mark Kunis performed the ceremony at the Washington Hotel in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: London Likely to Be Otherwise Engaged
description: LONDONThe big London hit at the momentit opened a couple of weeks ago  is Otherwise Engaged at the Queen's Theater, which is not likely to be otherwise engaged for a long time ahead. The play brings together once more the three people who had earlier given us Butley, the playwright Simon Gray, Harold Pinter as director and its star, Alan Bates. They have proved that lightning can strike twice in the same place, and indeed this is probably a more substantial play than Butley, and Mr. Bates, at his most magisterially comic, is even better, deeper and funnier than in his Tonyaward winning performance in the earlier play. In fact, not to waste words, Mr. Bates is terrific.

title: President Plays Tennis And Golf in Colorado
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 17 (AP) President Ford relaxed by playing tennis and golf today as he prepared for a twoday trip to five cities in four states tomorrow and Tuesday.

title: Donald Malcolm, Book Critic For New Yorker, Dies at 43
description: Donald Malcolm, a book critic and former OffBroadway theater critic for The New Yorker magazine, died Friday in New York Hospital after an operation. He was 43 years old and lived at 1517 First Avenue.

title: Sits Beaten By Lobsters In Playoff
description: UNIONDALE. L.I., Aug. 17 The Boston Lobsters stunned the Sets tonight by winning a 9point tiebreaker in a match that had been tied at 2424 and ousted the New Yorkers from the World Team Tennis playoffs.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Books of The Times
description: I like everything else in Michael Halrody's Augustus John better than John himself. John simply does not seem interesting enough to sustain 676 pages of relentless examination. His stature as a painter I will leave to more qualified judges, but the man's life was a shambles. It was not even a particularly significant shambles, the kind that would illuminate his work or his world.

title: F.B.I. StakeOut Led to Capture
description: For 24 hours before Samuel Bronfman 2d was rescued from his kidnappers, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents were sitting in stakeout cars outside the Brooklyn homes of the two alleged abductors, evidently unaware that the boundandgagged victim was only steps away.

title: POLICE DIRECTOR QUITS IN PROTEST
description: LONG BRANCH, Aug. 17John M. Buffin, the city's Director of Public Safety, said today that he would resign his post because of a City Council investigation of the Police Department.

title: Educators Are Divided On Preschool Screening
description: MUNCIE, Ind.When 300 children begin kindergarten at four elementary schools here next Month, their young lives will be an open book to the teachers. Can the child identify where sounds come from? Which side of his brain is dominant? How good is his eyehand coordination? Does he wet the bed?

title: SAVECITY GROUPS TO COST MILLIONS
description: The attempts to resolve the city's fiscal crisis by newly created outside agencies will cost the city and state millions of dollars, much of it in personnel costs and legal fees.

title: 3 Former Colonies Of Lisbon Expected To Win U.N. Entry
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17The Security Council is expected to recommend tomorrow the admission of three former Portuguese colonies to the United Nations.

title: IRANIAN INVESTING UPSETS VIRGINIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17Resentment over a real estate investment in this country by wealthy Iranian businessmen has brought the threat of a lawsuit here by suburban Virginia apartment owners.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Educators Are Divided On Preschool Screening
description: MUNCIE, Ind.When 300 children begin kindergarten at four elementary schools here next month, their young lives will he an open book to the teachers. Can the child identify where sounds come from? Which side of his brain is dominant? How good is his eyehand coordination? Does he wet the bed?

title: Mrs. Gandhi Defended By Ambassador to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (Reuters)India's Ambassador to the United States, T.N. Kaul, defended his country's state of emergency, saying the average Indian was very happy.

title: HearstCase Figure Retracts Remarks
description: Walter J. Scott, reputedly the, Federal Bureau of Investigation's chief informant in the Patricia Hearst case, has retracted his statements that he saw the fugitive heiress twice since her disappearance and that his family helped harbor her.

title: Exercise in Hypocrisy
description: The United Nations Decolonization Committee appears headed for an annual exercise in hypocrisy and double talk of precisely the kind that has brought the world organization into contempt and imperiled its future. Under Cuban prompting, the 24nation group is likely this week to reaffirm solemnly the inalienable right of the people of Puerto Rico to selfdetermination and independence.

title: ROBERT G. WALCUTT
description: Robert G. Walcutt, an inventor of the jeweltip phonograph needle marketed under the Walco trade name, died in Hackensack (N. J.) Hospital on Tuesday of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 58 years old and lived in River Edge, N. J., and on Fire Island, L. I.

title: Living in New York: An Artist Finds Art, and Tools, in SoHo
description: Jim Starbuck, bounding like a stork through the caverns of SoHo with an eye peeled for treasure, finds a bonanza between the garbage bins on Broome Street.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at Houston (n.)Tate (411) vs. Richard (88).

title: SixCar Crash in Alabama
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 17 (AP)DeWayne (Tiny) Lund, one of stock car racing's most popular drivers, was crushed to death today in a sixcar crash on the eighth lap of the Talladega 500 Grand National stock car race, won by Buddy Baker.

title: Article 3  No Title;
description: The day that he arrived for summer training camp with the New York Giants, Craig Morton established preseason priorities.

title: J. D. COLEMAN
description: J. D. Stetson Coleman, former chairman of the finance committee of the Pennzoil Company of Houston, died Saturday in Saratoga, Wyo. He was 70 years old.

title: Benjamin Levinson, Banker; Jailed in '67 for V.A. Fraud)
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17 (UPI) Benjamin Levinson, a mortgage, banker and friend of two Presidents who was convicted eight years ago of conspiring to defraud the Veterans Administration of hundreds of thousands of dollars, died in a hospital here Friday of cancer. He was 70 years old.

title: PHILIP GROVE, LED BUILDING CONCERN
description: Philip Grove, chairman of the Grove Group, made up of a number of companies in construction died Saturday at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse as a result of injuries received in a recent automobile accident. He was 70 years old and lived at 781 Fifth Avenue and in Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Tigers Find Winning Ways
description: With one streak out of the way, the Detroit Tigers have shifted gears and are heading in the other direction. They stretched their latest streak to two victories yesterday with a 70 decision over the California Angels at Anaheim, Calif,

title: Social Security Reaches Age 40
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Forty years ago, Aug. 14, 1935, on a warm afternoon in the Cabinet room of the White House, President Franklin D Roosevelt signed the landmark Social Security bill into law. He said the law represents a cornerstone in a structure Which is being built but is by no means complete.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 2470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 34??7767.

title: Closing of SEEK Residence Is Put Off for 3 Years
description: The City University said a residence for more than 100 black and Hispanic students enrolled in its SEEK program would be phased out over the next three years.

title: Los Angeles Ballet Fights Uphill Battle
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14A gust of wind blows lime dust and a fine grit from a construction site directly behind the outdoor rehearsal stage of the Los Angeles Ballet, causing the dancers to flinch. A torn sheet of plastic backdrop on the temporary stage flaps madly.

title: Timor Death Toll Is Put at 100; Portuguese Families Flee Island
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 17 (UPI)A Portuguese officer said today that about 100 people were believed to have been killed in fighting between rival political parties in Portuguese Timor. Families of Portuguese military and civilian officials in Timor have been evacuated, and arrived in Lisbon yesterday.

title: ISRAEL APPROVES KISSINGER MISSION
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 17The Israeli Cabinet, after a sixhour meeting today In Jerusalem, authorized its negotiating team to work through Secretary of State Kissinger for an interim agreement with Egypt on the separation of forces in Sinai.

title: Health Inspectors Report Violations In 10 Food Places
description: The Health Department said 10 more foodhandling establishments had failed a second healthcode inspection and warned that violations found upon a final inspection could lead to closing orders. The department also named 10 other food outlets that had had their third inspection, and listed the results as follows:

title: Juan Carlos Cuts Vacation And Flies to Meet Franco
description: MADRID, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Prince Juan Carlos interrupted his summer vacation today for an unscheduled visit to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the chief of state, increasing speculation here over a possible replacement of Premier Carlos Arias Navarro.

title: The Kenny Noe Case: Why He Was Ousted
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18Kenny Noe Jr. looks like a paratroop major: tall, crewcut frizz over a squarejawed face and only an incipient softness through the midsection diluting the image.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN QUIET TRADING
description: Prices moved lower yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Venezuela's Senate Sets Oil TakeOver
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 18 (AP)The Venezuelan Senate passed today legislation that would nationalize the country's oil industry, most of which is operated by United States oil companies.

title: Mets Lose, 40; Yield Two Hits
description: HOUSTON, Aug 18 Though their pitchers were stingy with hits, the Mets were generous with errors and bases on balls tonight and dropped a 40 decision to the Astros at the Astrodome.

title: MARION L. HELMS
description: Marion L. Helms, widow of Herman H. Helms, an executive of the Aluminum Corporation of America, and mother of Richard Helms, Ambassador to Iran and former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday in the Crestwood Nursing Home, Whippany, N.J. She was 86 years old and formerly lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on foreignexchange trading in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly reported the amount of losses uncovered by the Union Bank of Switzerland in its own accounts. The correct figure is 142 million Swiss francs, now equivalent to about $53.5million.

title: Kidney Transplant Survival Is Linked to Tissue
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Transplanted kidneys in patients in the United States are more likely to survive over the long term when there is a good match between tissue types of the donor and the recipient, an international registry reports.

title: Expatriate American Cartoon Maker Finds His Life in Prague Gratifying
description: PRAGUE  Czechoslovakia is among the most xenophobic of the nations of the Soviet bloc toward American entrepreneurs of any kind. Even today, only one official of an American companythe station manager of Pan American World Airwaysis allowed to live in Czechoslovakia.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NO DIALING Television watchers at home who might want to sample a retrospective of fare in recent years at different premises can look in at the Museum of Modern Art, which keeps a weather eye on the video medium with exhibitions from time to time. The museum's new show, running through Oct. 30, is its most ambitious to date, including seven hourlong programs of 12 works on videotapes.

title: PALESTINIANS SEE DANGER IN ACCORD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18Palestinian spokesmen are sharply attacking what appears to be an imminent agreement between Egypt and Israel for another troop disengagement in Sinai.

title: New Chief Sets State Arts Unit's Goal: Do It Better
description: I think this agency has done a good job, the new director of the New York State Council on the Arts, Kent Barwick, said. But that does not mean we cannot do it better.

title: CHINA COMBATING FACTIONAL STRIFE
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 18China has begun what appears to be an important drive to end factional bickering and labor unrest like the events that recently led Peking to send more than 10,000 troops into factories in the coastal city of Hangchow, broadcasts from the provinces indicate.

title: BERGMAN AND SON PLEAD NOT GUILTY
description: Bernard Bergman and his son Stanley pleaded not guilty yesterday to a Federal indictment that charged them with filing more than $1million in false Medicaid claims for the Towers Nursing Home.

title: On Sinai, Pledges and Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Barring a lastminute setback, Secretary of State Kissinger hopes to achieve in the next two weeks what is essentially the agreement between Israel and Egypt that eluded him during his diplomatic shuttle in March.

title: Old Saybrook's Serenity Roiled by Gambling Raid
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 18For years the people of Old Saybrook have lived with stories about organized crime invading this quiet, unobtrusive shoreline town during the summer. The strangers come, often with their families, in sleek cars or in yachts, which they tie up at the marina on Saybrook Point, by the Terra Mar, the elaborate blackandyellow resort motel that springs to life when the warm sun banishes the gray pall that hangs through much of the winter over Long Island Sound.

title: Women Begin to Speak Out Against Sexual Harassment at Work
description: For years, many women accepted it as a job hazard. Now, with raised con??usness and increased selfassurance, they are speaking out against the indignities of workrelated sexual advances and intimidation, both verbal and physical.

title: July Horne Starts Up 14% In First Big Gain of Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Housing starts in July increased 14 per cent over the previous month and showed their first substantial pickup of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WORLD OIL PARLEY IS VIRTUALLY SET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18A 27nation conference of oil producers and consumers is virtually set to convene in Paris in December to discuss energy, raw materials and economic development. The only differences that remain are over how to add monetary issues to the agenda.

title: EXPERT IS URGED ON SCHOOL TALKS
description: The Public Education Association yesterday urged the City Board of Education to hire a topflight outside counsel for its current contract negotiations with the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: For Her Cakes and Long Kindness, a Salute
description: An honor guard of 20 firemen lined up yesterday and saluted the coffin of Irene Rinko, who brought sweet pastries and kind words to a firehouse on Eighth Avenue for the last 30 years.

title: Timid Bakshi Is Czar of Film Violence
description: The pen may be mightier than the swordalso handier and more legalbut try telling that to somebody who has had a sword whacked down on his pen hand.

title: Rabin Hopeful on Accord; Some Israelis Assail Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 18Premier Yitzhak Rabin gave the Israeli Parliament today a guardedly hopeful assessment of the outlook for Secretary of State Kissinger's impending resumption of shuttle visits between here and Cairo, but he warned against undue optimism.

title: Potato Futures Extend Rise
description: Prices of Maine potatoes for delivery next April and May rose the daily permissible limit of 50 cents a hundred pounds yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fifth consecutive trading session.

title: Racism Forces Family To Leave Hartsdale
description: Alice Peters, who took her three young sons and sought refuge with relatives after arsonists set fire to her car and sprinkled gasoline in front of her Westchester County home last week, moved out permanently yesterday after receiving an anonymous note calling her a spic and a nigger.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Economic Summitry . . .
description: President Giscard d'Estaing of France continues to press his campaign for a fivepower international economic summit conference this fall, but the United States continues to resist.

title: Garbage Truck Drivers End Walkout in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI)Detroit garbage truck drivers approved a twoyear contract, ending a fourday strike that left about 6,000 tons of refuse in city streets. Officials said the strike caused only minor inconveniences.

title: General Mills Joint Venture
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  General Mills Inc., said today its General Mills Chemicals, Inc., subsidiary and Rhodia, Inc., (U.S.), a subsidiary of RhonePoulenc, S.A., of France have formed a joint venture which will build and operate a multimillionpound plant to produce gum and other biopolymers by fermentation of sugar, starch or similar carbohydrates. The new facility will be constructed in the Keokuk, Iowa, area and will be on stream in early 1977, General Mills said.

title: Lindsay and Wagner Silent on City's Fiscal Crisis
description: While the city has been in the throes of its fiscal crisis, the last two occupants of City HallJohn V. Lindsay and Robert F. Wagnerhave been significantly silent. They have not volunteered a n y substantive cornment, and, in fact, have even brushed off efforts to solicit their views.

title: C. ARNOLD SMITH REBUFFED ON JURY
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 18A Federal Court ordered today the release of secret grand jury evidence to the State of California for a new criminal investigation of C. Arnholt Smith under California laws.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GRAZ, Austria, Aug. 18 (AP)Mark Donohue, who suffered brain injuries in a prerace accident before yesterday's Austrian Grand Prix auto race, was still listed critical condition today after surgery at the neurosurgical clinic of Graz Hospital. However, further information on the American driver, who had a blood clot removed from his brain was sketchy. The hospital imposed a news blackout on his condition after a doctor said earlier today there was serious danger to his life and that it would be four or five days before the crisis was over. Doctors were also worried about brain bruises. Roger Penske of Reading, Pa., for whom Donohue has driven since 1966 and a close friend of the 1972 Indianapolis 5500 winner, was expected arrvie in Austria from the United States to be with Donohue and Donohue's wife of eight months, Eden. Donohue was Injured when his car blew a tire and crashed through a guard rail. Also injured in the mishap were two track security men. The mishap occurred less than a year after Donohue ended brief retirement to resume race driving.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: United States Foreign Policy And the West European Left
description: DAVIS, Calif.In the aftermath of America's Indochina debacle, it has become fashionable to view the future with concern and trepidation or to find that we are close to a national nervous breakdown, as Secretary of State Kissinger has said. As applied specifically to Western Europe, such fears and their concomitant mood of Spenglerian gloom are clearly exaggerated.

title: SouthWest Africa Is Placed On Police Alert After Slaying
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 18South Africa dispatched police reinforcements to SouthWest Africa today in the wake of, the murder Saturday of the Ovambo Chief Minister. Chief Filemon Elifas.

title: Citicorp Survey Finds Use of Savings on Rise
description: American have increasingly been turning to their savings accounts to pay bills and meet the rising cost of living, according o a survey by Citicorp.

title: Market Place
description: Why did Moore McCormack Resources common stock sink 10 points last week on the New York Stock Exchange?

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED IN VIETNAM'S FAIL
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (UPI)Ronald Reagan and Gov. George C. Wallace, potential conservative Presidential, candidates from both parties, told the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention today that weak wills in Washington, not United States military forces, lost Vietnam.

title: Lisbon Newsmen Defy Communist Line
description: LISBON, Aug. 18  Portuguese newsmen have started to fight against Communist domination of Lisbon's main news organizations.

title: Catholic Church in City Basically Very Healthy
description: Among the cascade of changes pouring from Vatican II, none had more personal impact on the individual parishioner than the Kiss of Peace.

title: Cabinet Switch in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18, (Renters) The Egyptian Minister of Information, Ahmed Kamal Abul Magd, has apparently been relieved of his post and the Minister of Culture Yousef elSibai has taken over the portfolio. An official announcement tonight said that President Anwar elSadat had appointed Mr. Sibai as Minister of Information and Culture, indicating that Dr. AbulMagd had been relieved of the post.

title: U.S. and Spain Open Talks On Renewal of Bases Pact
description: MADRID, Aug. 18 (UPI) Spanish and United States negotiators today started the ninth round of their negotialions for the renewal of the agreement granting the United States the use of military bases in Spain.

title: Sig Arno, 79, Character Actor On Broadway and Film, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug 18 (AP) Sig Arno, actor in character and comedy roles in movies and on the stage, died at the Actors Fund Hospital late last night from complications of Parkinson's disease. He was 79 years old.

title: Phone and Telex Cut Off At Times Bureau in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 18The Indian Government has cut off the telephone and the Telex machine at The New York Times bureau in New Delhi. The Government said today that it had acted because William Borders, the Times' resident correspondent, had violated its selfcensorship rules.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 19, 1975

title: No Protests Received
description: BONN, Aug. 18West Germany had received no diplomatic protests tonight from Czechoslovakia over Mr. Meeker's flight.

title: MARITIME UNIONS CALL A BOYCOTT ON GRAIN LOADING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Maritime unions of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called a boycott today against grain shipments to the Soviet Union, demanding Government action to guard against rising food prices as a result of the grain sales and more protection for United States shipping interests.

title: Rush for Land Is Following Route Of New Highway Into Amazon Region
description: PORTO VELHO, BrazilThe railroad station has been turned into a museum, vines are growing over the old rolling stock and roadbuilding equipment is stored in the railyard. The rubber train southwest to Guajar Mirim, on the Bolivian border, stopped five years ago with the crisis in the rubber industry.

title: Production of Steel Shows Little Change For the Latest Week
description: Steel production in the week ended Aug. 16 showed virtually no change from the previous week, resulting in a continuation of the downward slump in steel production for the year, weekly steel production statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute indicate.

title: People in Sports
description: With the best record in major league baseball this season and an immense lead in the National League's Western Division, the Cincinnati Reds appear to have little to worry about.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Pays Strong Tribute to Slain Bangladesh Leader
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 18Prime Minister Indira Gandhi delivered a strongly worded and personal tribute tonight to Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the President of neighboring Bangladesh who was killed in a military coup d'tat Friday.

title: Bridge:
description: The important advice that Alice received from the Caterpillar should be taken to heart by many declarers: keen your temper.

title: ABUSE IS CHARGED IN DEFENSE HIRING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18The controversy over the interchange of personnel between the Department of Defense and its military contractors has been renewed with a report by the Council on Economic Priorities that concludes that the conflictofinterest abuses prevalent in the past are still widespread.

title: How I Learned to Love Again
description: For a long time I did not love my oil company any more. I behaved cruelly, said terrible things and accused my oil company of betraying me.

title: Mary Queenofscots Victor at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 18 (AP)Sookie Stable's Mary Queenofscots beat Happy Hill Farm's Queens or Better in the feature race before 17,889 fans at Saratoga today. Mary Queenofscots, ridden by Eddie Maple, trailed for most of the sevenfurlong test for 3 and 4yearold fillies, but came on strong in the stretch to score by a halflength.

title: United Brands Sees Hope in Panama
description: Officers of the troubleridden United Brands Company assured worried stockholders yesterday that the company was going to stay in the business of raising and exporting bananas in spite of the mounting problems of its Central American operations.

title: July Horne Starts Up 14% In First Big Gain of Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Housing starts in July increased 14 per cent over the previous month and showed their first substantial pickup of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CHINA COMBATING FACTIONAL STRIFE
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 18China has begun what appears to be an important drive to end factional bickering and labor unrest like the events that recently led Peking to send more than 10,000 troops into factories in the coastal city of Hangchow, broadcasts from the provinces indicate.

title: State Power Authority's First Nuclear Plant Starts Operating
description: ALBANY, Aug. 18The New York State Power Authority's first nuclear power plant went into commercial operation late last month, five years after construction started.

title: New York Hospital Defends Its Actions On Marcus Twins
description: Officials of New York HospitalCornell Medical Center said yesterday that they had become aware last year of the deterioration of the Marcus brothers, twin gynecologists who died a month ago of barbiturate addiction, and had attempted several corrective steps culminating in dismissal of the doctors from the hospital's staff as of July 1.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Jewish Museum has put on permanent exhibition objects related to observances of the Sabbath, Passover, Hanukkah, birth, marriage and death. The items range from a tombstone from the Roman catacombs to a 17thcentury Italian gilded jewel box to objects created in the museum's silversmith workshop.

title: New Mission for Ship
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) The Glomar Explorer will perform an undisclosed mission off the California coast, it was revealed today.

title: Hanratty Sidelined
description: LATROBE, Pa., Aug. 18 (AP)Xrays of Terry Hanratty's injured left ankle were negative, the Pittsburgh Steelers said today. However, the quarterback is expected to miss several games.

title: Dance: Ailey's Mooche
description: One can start a lively debate discussing whether Alvin Ailey's company dances better at State Theater than at its own home on 55th Street. The topic will never be settled but in its second summer season at the larger house, the company looks good, is dancing well and finds the big stage an eminently suitable frame for its new production of The Mooche. The piece was shown for the first time this season Sunday afternoon.

title: F.T.C. Offices Revised
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission today announced a national reorganization of its regional operations.

title: Notes on People
description: Peter B. Edelman, who was a legislative assistant to the late Robert F. Kennedy, was named by Governor Carey yesterday to be the $47,800ayear director of the State Division for Youth. Mr. Edelman, aged 37, was planning director for Arthur J. Goldberg's 1970 Democratic candidacy for Governor and before that was his law clerk when Mr. Goldberg was Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. Since 1972 Mr. Edelman has been vice president for policy of the University of Massachusetts.

title: Witnesses Assail Rise In Train Fares on S.I.
description: Speakers at a sparsely attended hearing on a 25 per cent fare increase for the Staten Island Transit Operating Authority yesterday criticized the proposal as a particular hardship for residents of the island.

title: Police Moustaches Approved
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Indiana State Police board adopted today a regulation allowing troopers to have mustaches.

title: S. S. Kresge Raises Profits in Quarter And for First Half
description: The S. S. Kresge Company, one of the nation's largest general merchandisers in sales and unit operations, reported yesterday an upturn in profits in the quarter and 26week periods ended July. The upturn follows a steady decline the company showed for a year and a static position in the first quarter.

title: N. N. Coates, Manufacturer, HunterHorse Owner, Dies
description: Norman N. Coates, chairman of the Volco Brass & Copper Company of Kenilworth, N.J., and of U.N.A. Corporation of Boston, specialty steels, died here Sunday. He was 64 years old and lived in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Medicaid Cheater Jailed
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP)A judge sentenced a Westfield nursing home owner to 13 to 16 years in prison today for cheating on Medicaid reimbursements. William Verveny, 45 years old, accused of collecting 523,000 in unjustified reimbursements, was sentenced by Judge Samuel Tisdale in Superior Court.

title: World Squad Trapshooting Mark Tied
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP)Five shooters broke 997 of 1,000 targets and tied the world squad record today in the opening day of the 76th annual Grand American trapshooting tournament.

title: Business Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 18 (AP)The steel industry agreed today to amend past racial and sevual discrimination by promising to comply with Federal antidiscrimination regulations and creating a $31million backpay fund. The agreement was approved by a Federal Appeals Court and came in the form of two consent orders enjoining 245 plants of nine steel companies in 25 states from discriminating by race or sex in employment and promotion.

title: Chiefs Defeat Cowboys, 2620
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 (AP)Tony Adams threw a 4yard endzone pass to Billy Masters with 45 seconds left, giving the Kansas City Chiefs 2620 victory over the Dallas Cowbows tonight in a National Football League exhibition game

title: Grains Slump on Boycott of Loadings
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP)Maritime unions in the United States announced a boycott against the loading of vessels with grain bound for the Soviet Union, and some grain futures contracts fell the allowable limits in trading today.

title: U.S. Aiding Jobless
description: In a little more than four months of effective operation of the Trade Act of 1974 there have been 30,800 workers certified as eligible for benefits because imports contributed importantly to the actual or prospective loss of their jobs. Page 48.

title: Negotiations Begun on Rift Over Coop City Fee Rise
description: New York State housing officials and residents of Coop City began negotiations yesterday for the first time since their dispute over rising maintenance costs began last June.

title: Jerusalem Hotel Awaits Kissinger Reservations
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 18 (UPI) Secretary of State Kissinger is coming to Israel Thursday, but he has not reserved the 100 rooms at the King David Hotel customary for his visits here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on foreignexchange trading in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly reported the amount of losses uncovered by the Union Bank of Switzerland in its own accounts. The correct figure is 142 million Swiss francs, now equivalent to about $53.5million.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Government Employes Insurance Company has put off accepting new automobileinsurance customers in New Jersey to protest the state's delay in acting on what the company regards as an adequate rate increase.

title: COST SEEN RISING ON MARKET BASKET
description: To feed an average family of four in New York City nutritiously for a week costs about $73, $5.67 more than had been thought up to now.

title: Bills for Land Regulation Are Adopted by 17 States
description: While proposals for Federa landuse coordination have been languishing in Congress, at least 17 states have enacted land planning and control bills so far this year.

title: Death Penalty in Libya
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug . 18 (Reuters) Libya today proclaimed a law imposing the death sentence on anyone who tried to overthrow the Government or belonged to an illegal organization, the Iraqi press agency reported from Tripoli. The dispatch followed Cairo press reports of an attempt to depose Col. Muammar eQaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: UTILITY SEEKING NEW RATE RISES
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company served notice yesterday on its 600,000 electricity customers in Essex, Monmouth, Ocean and 10 other counties in New Jersey that it would seek a $45million rate increase in the fall and would ask for advance clearance of a $94million additional increase to take effect if its costs rise next year.

title: RECOVERY SUIT FILED AGAINST CHASE BANK
description: A $45million recovery suit was filed against the Chase Manhattan Bank in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta, Ga. by the courtappointed trustee of the North American Acceptance Corporation. Robert E. Hicks, the trustee, also petitioned the Court to diallow a $9million claim made by the bank as creditor against North American last December.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE CUP

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: August 19, 1975

title: Rev. McIntyre Reported Delinquent on Realty Tax
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 18 City officials said today that Cape May's largest landholder and taxpayer, the Rev. Carl McIntire, had not paid his taxes on any of his 21 propetries for 1974 or the first three quarters of 1975.

title: Bay State Finds a Case of Equine Encepalitis
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (UP)The Massachusetts Department of Public Health says it has confirmed the year's first case of Eastern equine encephalitis.

title: Four HiFi Makers Accept Prohibition On Fixing of Prices
description: Four major manufacturers of highfidelity audio components have signed consent agreements with the Federal Trade Commission that prohibit them from coercing dealers and using other illegal means to fix the prices of their products.

title: U.S. Program Aids 30,800 Hurt by Imports
description: WASHINGTON,Aug. 18 More than 30,000 workers whose loss of jobs have been connected with rising imports are already witnessing the working of one major but littlenoticed change in the nation's basic trade law contained in the 1974 trade act. The act was passed by Congress late last year.

title: RISE IN MILK PRICE BY WINTER IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The price that consumers pay for milk at supermarkets will increase by up to 4 cents a half gallon by winter, a milk industry spokesman said today.

title: Joan Little's Top Attorney Loses Bid to Get Out of Jail
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 18 (UPI)  The North Carolina Supreme Court turned down today a request to review the contempt of court charges against Jerry Paul, Joan Litttle's chief attorney, until his case is considered by the state appellate court.

title: Kelley Calls for Citizens To Help Fight on Crime
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 18 (UPI)  Americans are losing the fight against crime but increased citizen involvement could turn the tide, Clarence M. Kelley, Director of Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.

title: Dr. Holloman's Error
description: How hard it is to squeeze waste out of the city's bloated budget is underscored by the disclosure that the head of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., hid from his board of directors knowledge of staff analyses showing where important economies might be made in his organization. This lack of candor and openness would be ethically serious in any situation; it is inexcusable in the midst of New York City's worst financial crisis, a time when every municipal dollar is precious.

title: SPEAKERS ASSAIL S.I. RAIL INCREASE
description: Speakers at a sparsely attended hearing on a 25 per cent fare increase for the Staten Island Transit Operating Authority yesterday criticized the proposal as a particular hardship for residents of the island.

title: PROFITS UP IN '74 FOR TV NETWORKS
description: CBSTV made pretax profits of $110million in 1974, almost as much as the profits for the other two networks combined, according to Television Digest. In spite of the general business recession, it was a record year for all three networks. The 1973 profits for CBSTV were $88.2million.

title: NEW M.A.C. BONDS SELL AT PREMIUM
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation's newly issued bonds maturing in 1983 traded actively all day yesterday and ended the day selling at a premium.

title: Aide Says J.A.L. May Balk At Flights for Terrorists
description: TOKYO, Aug. 18 (UPI) A Japan Air Lines spokesman expressed the view today that the airline would refuse any future requests to fly terrorists to safety in countries that might offer them political asylum.

title: Police Call Strike In San Francisco In Bidfor 13% Raise
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (AP)Policemen angered by the city's refusal to meet their pay demands walked off the job today, and a department spokesman said that more than 90 per cent of the 1.935member force was on strike.

title: City Hall Picketed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18Some 150 picketcarrying members of the Commitee Against Racism paraded in front of City Hall today amid a massive show of police force.

title: Family of Byrne Joins Him at Bail Hearing
description: Most observers agreed that Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic Byrne did not look like a pair of kidnappers when they entered Federal District Court here yesterday for their bail hearing.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: A Noisy Night at the Speedway
description: MALTA, N.Y.In the pit area behind the stands, spidery little cars snarl and belch and spin gravel from wide tires as they move out arrogantly for their warmups. Each car has a number painted on its side, and most have names: Bubble Gum, The Sexy European, The Rat, The Fly'n Goose, Love Is a Bed of Sweat II.

title: F.B.I. Asserts Two Admit Abducting Bronfman Heir
description: Mel Patrick Lynch, a city fireman, and Dominic Byrne, a limousine operator, have admitted kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d and threatening that both he and his multimillionaire father, Edgar, would die unless a ransom demand was met, according to a Federal Bureau of Investigation complaint yesterday.

title: 27 States Withholding $206Million in Dispute With Social Security Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Twentyseven states are withholding a total of $206million from the Social Security Administration in a dispute over the nation's new adult welfare program.

title: PREMIER IN LISBON DEFIES OPPONENTS IN SPEECH TO REDS
description: LISBON, Aug. 18Premier Vasco Gonalves, under intense pressure to resign because of his proCommunist policies, made a fighting speech tonight before 5,000 cheering Communists and asked for confidence from patriots, progressive people and democrats.

title: 3 Sought in Tanker's Hull
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Aug. 18 (UPI)Coast Guard officials today searched the charred wreckage of the oil tanker Globtik Sun for the remaining three crewmen missing since last week's collision with an unmanned oil derrick. The tanker's hull still holding nearly 350,000 barrels of crude oil.

title: F.B.I. Asserts Two Admit Abducting Bronfman Heir
description: Mel Patrick Lynch, a city fireman, and Dominic Byrne, a limousine operator, have admitted kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d and threatening that both he and his multimillionaire father, Edgar, would die unless a ransom demand was met, according to a Federal Bureau of Investigation complaint yesterday.

title: Byrne, Bat Not Lynch, Is Recalled in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 18 (AP)Dominic Byrne, the New Yorker arrested in the kidnapping of Samuel Bronfman 2d, was remembered today in his home town in western Ireland as a good Catholic and a hard worker.

title: Rabin Hopeful on Accord; Some Israelis Assail Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 18Premier Yitzhak Rabin gave the Israeli Parliament today a guardedly hopeful assessment of the outlook for Secretary of State Kissinger's impending resumption of shuttle visits between here and Cairo, but he warned against undue optimism.

title: Edgar F. Hazleton, 85. Dies; Former Suffolk Surrogate
description: Former Surrogate Edgar F. Hazelton of Suffolk County died yesterday in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Northport, L.I.

title: HAROLD L. BEHLKE
description: Harold L. Behlke, retired vice president for advertising of U.S. News & World Report magazine, died yesterday in Hudson, N.Y., where he was at his summer home. He was 74 years old and lived in La Quinta, Calif.

title: Yield of 3Month Bill Increases to 6.452%
description: The Treasury began a week of heavy borrowings yesterday by auctioning a record total of $6.3  billion of three  month and sixmonth bills at its regular Monday sales. An additional $5.2  billion of Treasury and Federal agency debt will also be sold this week. Yesterday's auctions of bills produced an avend age yield of 6.452 per cent for the shorter issue, compared with 6.349 per cent a week earlier. The sixmonth average yield was 7 per cent, up from 6.809 per cent.

title: New Hampshire Rivals Agree to 2 TV Debates
description: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 18 (AP)The Democratic and Republican candidates in the New Hampshire Senate election tentatively agreed today to two debates. One is to be nationally televised, the other carried locally.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 18 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Transit Authority Cites Sharp Cut in Overtime
description: The Transit Authority, which has been criticized for the huge overtime payments collected by some of its workers, now reports that it has cut such work substantially in the last year.

title: Mob in Azores Wrecks Leftists' Offices
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, Azores, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Thousands of farmers went on a rampage today in Angra do Herofsmo on the island of Terceira in the Azores, destroying the offices of leftwing parties and beating up Communists in the street.

title: F.C.C. LISTS AIDES TIED TO INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Four of the six commissioners who left the Federal Communications Commission in the last five years are now employed by communications companies or are representing such companies in legal matters, according to the commission.

title: Buckley and McCarthy Plan Appeal on '74 Campaign Act
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Senator James L. Buckley, a conservative, and former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, a liberal, will ask the Supreme Court to rule the 1974 campaign reform law unconstitutional, Mr. McCarthy said today.

title: Sam Bronfman Watches TV and Goes Swimming
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 18Samuel Bronfman 2d watched television soap operas and swam in the pool at his mother's estate here today on the first full day after his kidnapping ordeal.

title: Back to the Jolly Roger?
description: Sandwiched among the scores of bills signed by Governor Carey last week, in the wake of the legislative session, was one opening the first small crack in the power of the Waterfront Commission to police the crimeprone Port of New York.

title: U.S. Filter in Soviet Pact
description: A unit of the United States Filter Corporation has signed an agreement with the Soviet Union's Licensintorg organization, giving it the right to license certain Russian energyrelated processes to United States industry, the company announced yesterday. Two processes involve recovery of oil from shale formations.

title: Wounded Policeman Shoots One Suspect In New burgh Hold up
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 18A Newburgh policeman suffering from two bullet wounds managed to shoot an armed robber here today, moments after the man and his accomplice shot a police lieutenant in the head authorities said.

title: 3CAGALLON RISE IN GASOLINE IS DUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Federal Energy Administration said today gasoline prices would increase an average of 3 cents a gallon, with the end of oil price controls.

title: ARGENTINE ARMY SPLIT ON POLITICS
description: BUENOS AIRES Aug. 18The appointment of an active army officer to the Cabinet of President Isabel Martinez de Pern has divided the Argentine armed forces.

title: MARITIME UNIONS CALL A BOYCOTT ON GRAIN LOADING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Maritime unions of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called a boycott today against grain shipments to the Soviet Union, demanding Government action to guard against rising food prices as a result of the grain sales and more protection for United States shipping interests.

title: Carey Directs Aide To Hear Grievance 1, Of the Police on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 18Concerned over the many summonses issued by the Long Island State Parkway Police in continuing labor dispute, Governor Carey today directed the State Office of Employe Relations to meet with members of the police unit in an effort to resolve the problem.

title: Guerrillas Kill Officer
description: BUENOS, AIRES, Aug. 18 (UPI)An army captain was shot to death today by guerrillas who raided a military shooting range in northern Buenos Aires and made off with an army truck loaded with 70 rifles, police sources said. Guerrilla casualties were unknown.

title: Cash Prices
description: Monday. Aug. 12. 1975

title: Vladimir Kuts, Soviet Runner Who Won 2 Olympic Titles, Dies
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (AP)Vladimir Kuts, the long distance runner who earned the Soviet Union its first Olympic gold medals, died Saturday, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported yesterday.

title: Connors Advances In Jersey
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 18Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., was hard pressed to score a 75, 76 victory over Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., before a nearcapacity crowd of 3,100 in a firstround match of the $50,000 Tennis Week open tonight at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation received a $32.3million Navy contract providing additional advance procurement funding for 5014A fighters being bought by Iran.

title: STATE HOUSEKEEPER APPOINTED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, Aug. 19James C. O'Shea, a 62yearold lawyer from Rome, N.Y., today was appointed Commissioner of the state's Office of General Services by Governor Carey. The nost nays $47.800 a year.

title: The Stones of Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM 'If someone introduced a resolution in the United Nations declaring that the earth, was flat, said Amos. Oz, the young Israeli novelist, as he strolled through an old quarter of Jerusalem, it would pass by a twothirds Majority of the Arabs and thirdworld bloc, with France abstaining.

title: Stock Market Indecisive In a Day of Quiet Trading
description: The stock market, unable to extend last week's modest upturn, closed mixed yesterday in lackluster trading.

title: LUKE SHORT DEAD; WROTE WESTERNS
description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 18 (AP) Luke Short, whose stories of hardriding, hellfor  leather Western heroes sold millions of paperback novels over a 30year period, died today after a ninemonth bout with cancer. He was 67 years old.

title: New York Group Purchases True
description: The sale of True magazine by the Petersen Publishing Company to Magazine Associates, Inc., of New York, was announced yesterday. The New York company will take over publication of the maleoriented publication with the November issue.

title: $4.1Million Paid By PickIt Lottery In First 2 Months
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18Bettors who play the PickIt lottery, the state's version of the numbers game, won $4.1million during the first two months of the new game, and received better odds than offered by the illegal operators, according to lottery officials.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Giants' Deal Sends Small To Browns
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 18Another fabled No. 1 draft choice bit the dust with the New York Giants today.

title: Averill Assails Hall of Fame Selectors
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 18In perfect weather that caused 73yearold Earl Averill, once a slugging star for the Cleveland Indians, to comment, It was a diy fit for a tripleheader, five former stars were inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame this morning.

title: Hanoi Denies Arms Deal
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 18 (Reuters)North Vietnam today denied a report of a possible arms deal between Pakistan and Hanoi involving American weapons captured in South Vietnam. The report appeared in Newsweek magazine.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Ewald B. Nyquist, State Commissioner of Education, announced that $150,000 in the state's supplemental budget would be used to establish a new statewide arts program for qualifying high school students. He said at Saratoga Springs that the New York State Summer School of the Arts would begin next year, featuring courses at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in drama, ballet, and modern dance. Instructors will be members of the Acting Company, formerly the City Center Acting Company, and members of the New York City Ballet.

title: U.S. Court Upholds Steel Industry Pact To End Job Bias
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today upheld two consent degrees against the steel industry. One ordered the establishment of a $31million fund for back pay for victims of alleged discriminatory hiring and promotion.

title: U.N. Council Votes to Admit Three ExPortuguese Colonies
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. The Security Council unanimously recommended this afternoon to admit three former Portuguese colonies Mozambique, So Tom e Principe, and Cape Verdeto membership in the United Nations despite Western reservations as to the international status of the last of the three.

title: Kent State Defense Rests After Replay of Tapes
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 18Defense attorneys in the $46million Kent State University civil trial rested their case today after six days of testimony from 21 witnesses.

title: Plans Made to Save S. Klein's on Square
description: S. Klein's department store on Union Square, which closed last Saturday after more than 65 years of existence, will reopen early next year under new ownership but with the same name.

title: Postmark Names Returning After an Editor's Crusade
description: The advocates, of keeping things the way they ought to be have won a modest victory. The Postal Service is going back to printing the names of cities in postmarks.

title: Plans Made to Save S. Klein's on Square
description: S. Klein's department store on Union Square, which closed last Saturday after more than 65 years of existence, will reopen early next year under new ownership but with the same ??ame.

title: WHITNEY M. YOUNG SR.
description: LOUISVILLE, Aug. 18 (AP)Whitney M. Young Sr., a civil rights leader, died today at Jewish Hospital. He was 77 years old. Mr. Young, who headed the Lincoln Institute, a school in Lincoln, Ky., from 1935 to 1966, was a former president of the Kentucky Negro Education Association and the Kentucky Education Association.

title: Ford Says Big Grain Sales To Russians Benefit Nation
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 18  President Ford, defending large grain sales to the Soviet Union, declared at the Iowa State Fair here today that a sound, fully productive agriculture is a key element of this nation's quest for peace.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 19, 1975

title: Bears Put Pardee's Patience to Test
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 18 Jack Pardee, one of the best linebackers in the National Football League for 15 years, is now the new head coach of the Chicago Bears, a team that has been going nowhere for a dozen years. Pardee is part of a new look for one of the N.F.L.'s pioneer teams and he is facing up to his problems with patience. Consider two plays in last Saturday night's preseason game in Milwaukee, one lost to the Green Bay Packers, 139.

title: Arabs Urge More Aid For Palestine Refugees
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Representatives of Arab countries where Palestinians have taken refuge called today for more donations to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency to avoid severe cutbacks in food and education.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Newark Boy Drowns
description: RIVERDALE, Aug. 18 (AP)An 8yearold boy drowned today in Sun Tan Lake off Route 23 in this Morris County community, the police said. He was Robert Walker Jr. of Newark.

title: Old Saybrook's Serenity Roiled by Gambling Raid
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 18For years the people of Old Saybrook have lived with stories about organized crime invading this quiet, unobtrusive shoreline town during the summer. The strangers come, often with their famines, in sleek cars or in yachts, which they tie up at the marina on Saybrook Point, by the Terra Mar, the elaborate blackandyellow resort motel that springs to life when the warm sun banishes the gray pall that hangs through much of the winter over Long Island Sound.

title: Rejection Rate on Home Loans Found Highest Among Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The Federal agency that regulates institutions making the bulk of the nation's home loans reported today that lenders refused mortgages to blacks more than twice as often as they refused whites.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the movie Bad Day at Black Rock, from which (along with the flametempered black granite of which it is constructed) CBS's headquarters at 51 West 52d Street got its nickname, Spencer Tracy barges into a sinister town called Black Rock in search of the truth about what happened to his Army buddy, a Nisei. In attempting to write an informal corporate History or Lass, Robert Metz, a financial columnist for The New York Times, has exhibited a similar temerity and, for his pains, has been roughed up by the corporate truth squad before publication day. The company's initial reaction was to ignore the book as not worthy of comment; later it decided to ignore it to the extent of a fivepage bill of particulars reporting errors in it.

title: Martin Adds Excitement, Not Remedy
description: The Yankees have concluded their first road trip under Billy Martin, and it possibly could be pointed out, now, that even though they are only one game over .500 with Martin as manager, they have become a more exciting baseball team.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GOTBETTERThe wife and children of the late Herbert Gotbetter wish to express their gratitude for the warmth and affection shown by friends and family during ?? period of bereavement.

title: Dollar Weakened By Profit Taking On the Continent
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 18 (UPI)The dollar closed lower on all major European money markets today except in London, where it marked time.

title: Guard at Sutton Shot Thwarting Holdup Men
description: A guard at the Sutton movie theater, at, 205 East 57th Street, was shot in the stomach and seriously wounded last night during an exchange of gunfire with three apparent robbers, according to the police.

title: Unveilings
description: LEVITINHerman. The unveiling for ?? man Levitin will be held on Sunday, Aug, 24, at 10 A.M. at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: HearstCase Figure Dropped In Federal Grand Jury Inquiry
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 18A Federal grand jury here withdrew its subpoena for Walter J. Scott today after he said he had lied about his family's relationship to Patricia Hearst.

title: STATE CRITICIZED IN OILFARM CASE
description: HOBOKEN, Aug. 18A Natural Resources Council hearallowed riparian rights along a section of the Hudson River in Hoboken and Weehawken turned into condemnation of the State Environmental Protection Agency today.

title: Mrs. Peron Vacations At Atlantic Coast Resort
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Aug. 18 (AP)President Isabel Martinez de Perln began a vacation today at this Atlantic coast resort, buoyed by expressions of support from cheering crowds as she left Buenos Aires and on arrival here.

title: Citibank Cairo Branch Set
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The First National City Bank will open a branch bank in Cairo Nov. 1. Citibank said the branch would not deal in domestic currency but would offer other banking services, including Suez Canal toll remittances. It also will serve as reimbursing agent for foreign currency transactions.

title: New York Hospital Defends Its Actions On Marcus Twins
description: Officials of New York HospitalCornell Medical Center said yesterday that they had become aware last year of the deterioration of the Marcus brothers; twin gynecologists who died a month ago of barbiturate addiction, and had attempted several corrective steps culminating in dismissal of the doctors from the hospital's staff as of July 1.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of cost positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Early Jail Release Spurs Inquiry on Suffolk Sheriff
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 18Suffolk County grand jury is investigating allegations that Sherifw Philip F. Corso maintained links to moo figures and gave preferential treatment to political associates serving time in a local prison.

title: 3 Sugar Refiners. Cut Their Prices $1 per 100 Pounds
description: Three large sugar refiners, the Amstar Corporation, the Sucrest Corporation and the Corn Products division of CPC International, Inc., announced reductions yesterday of $1 per 100 pounds in the price of industrial sugar. The reductions are effective this morning and will cut the list price to $27.70.

title: Kramer, of Allied Stores, To Head Gimbel Brothers
description: Martin S. Kramer, a 54yearold retailing executive, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., effective Sept. 1.

title: Surging Phils Catch Pirates
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, picked by many observers to finish first in the National League's Eastern Division, finally pulled into a firstplace tie with idle Pittsburgh last night by beating the Braves, 63, in Atlanta.

title: JOHN T. GIBALA, 74, TRAFFIC CHIEF HERE
description: John T. Gibala, the city's first director of traffic control when the Department of Traffic Engineering was established in 1949, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived at 25124 51st Avenue, Little Neck, Queens.

title: Chicago Man Is Acquitted In Scuffle With Bill Mauldin
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UPI)A Cook County Circuit Judge today found Thomas D. Flanagan, an insurance executive, not guilty of charges of battery in connection with a fight involving Bill Mauldin, the cartoonist.

title: Four HiFi Makers Accept Prohibition On Fixing of Prices
description: Four major manufacturers of highfidelity audio components have signed consent agreements with the Federal Trade Commission that prohibit them from coercing dealers and using other illegal means to fix the prices of their products.

title: The Grouse Problem, and a Palatable Solution
description: The guns of August are booming again on the moors of Scotland, but for the third consecutive year, none of the heatherfed grouse beloved of aficionados of game birds will adorn American tables or succor the craving palates of devotees here.

title: Advertising
description: Advertisers were offered a new tool yesterday in their quest to pinpoint potential customers, with the introduction by U.S. News and World Report of its 1975 Study of American Markets.

title: Richard Wendt, 54, Dead; Former Times Aide in Paris
description: Richard Wendt, former general manager of the International Edition of The New York Times in Paris, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 54 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: ALLBRITTON ACTS TO BUY UP STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Joe L. Allbritton, publisher of The Washington Star, offered today to buy all the stock of the newspaper's parent corporation.

title: Improving the Bench
description: A test of the screening vs. the political method of designating Supreme Court candidates for New York State is in the offing for the First Department (embracing Manhattan and the Bronx). There is a rare opportunity to put the machinery to workvoluntarilythat can lead to merit prevailing in the choice of judges.

title: Police Call Strike In San Francisco In Bid for 13% Raise
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (AP)Policemen angered by the city's refusal to meet their pay demands walked off the job today, and a department spokesman said that more than 90 per cent of the 1.935member force was on strike.

title: Shoplifting and PurseSnatching Lead In Crime Increase at Shopping Centers
description: Shoplifting and pursesnatching, crimes generally attributed to teenagers, appear to be on the increase in some of the major shopping centers that straddle New Jersey's suburbs.

title: PICKIT LOTTERY PAID $4.1MILLION
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18Bettors who play the PickIt lottery, the state's version of the numbers game, won $4.1million during the first two months of the new game, and received better odds than offered by the illegal operators, according to lottery officials.

title: Ford Motor Fighting Order For Recall of 600,000 Cars
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company went into court today to fight a government order to recall and pay for repairs on more than 600,000 Mustangs and Cougars with allegedly defective seat backs that could collapse.

title: . . . An Obstacle Eased
description: Faced with firm United States opposition, the French President has moderated his stress on fixed rates as the aim of a monetary summit, and is putting more emphasis on finding ways to restore, stability and prosperity to the industrial nations. Here he has the full support of West German Chancellor Schmidt, who cannot see how to spur his nation's economy sufficiently without a strong growth in foreign demand for its exports.

title: Parker Pen in Pact to Acquire Manpower, Inc., for $28Million
description: The Parker Pen Company of Janesville, Wis., announced an agreement yesterday with Manpower, Inc., for Parker's acquisition of Manpower for $28.2million. Manpower, Inc., based in Milwaukee, is the world's largest temporaryhelp service company. In 1974 it reported net income of $5.6million on revenues of $161.1million. Parker, a maker of writing instruments, had sales of $117million last year and a net income of $8.7million.

title: Censorship Broadened
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Foreign correspondents here were told tonight that they must submit all their reports on developments in Bangladesh to the Indian Government for censorship before sending them abroad.

title: Amtrak to Offer Bargain On Fares to Foreigners
description: Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, will inaugurate a bargainrate USArall pass starting Nov. 1, allowing foreign visitors unlimited coachfare travel on its 25,000mile network.

title: Bail Set in Ford Threat
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP)Bail was set at $100,000 today for Thomas D. Elbert, 34 years old, who is accused of threatening the life of President Ford. Mr. Elbert was released from prison in May after serving five years for threatening the life of Richard M. Nixon.

title: PREMIER IN LISBON DEFIES OPPONENTS IN SPEECH TO REDS
description: LISBON, Aug. 18Premier Vasco Gonalves, under intense pressure to resign because of his proCommunist policies, made a fighting speech tonight before 5,000 cheering Communists and asked for confidence from patriots, progressive people and democrats.

title: Algerians in France Forced By Police to Release Hostage
description: AGEN, France, Aug. 18 (Feuters)The police swept today into a camp housing Harkisformer Algerian soldiers of the French Armyand forced them to release an Algerian hostage, they seized Saturday.

title: FORD CAR PRICES RISING WITH G.M.'S
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 18 (AP)Lee Iacocca, president of the Ford Motor Company, said Ford's 1976 car prices would be raised in line with the 4.4 per cent average rise announced last week by the General Motors Corporation.

title: Ford Continues to Slip In Harris Opinion Poll
description: President Ford continues to slip in public esteem, the Harris Poll said yesterday.

title: ROBERT JAHRLING, 77, A CITY COLLEGE AIDE
description: Dr. Robert Jahrling, who formerly supervised student teacher personnel of the education department at City College and founded its division of public service training, died yesterday in Lakewood, N.J. His age was 77.

title: Indianapolis Paper Says Hartke Office Was Bugged in 1970
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 18 (AP) Senator Vance Hartke's offices were allegedly bugged before the 1970 election by persons trying to gain information about his contributors, The Indianapolis Star said today.

title: State High Court Asked To Rule in Garbage Suit
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 18Justice Morris Pashman today delayed for a hearing by the full New Jersey Supreme Court the question of whether a 500page deposition apparently covering some of the investment activities of Anthony J. Grossi, president of the Board of Public Utilities Commissioners, should be unsealed.

title: Spotlight on History
description: A generation ignorant of its past lacks a reliable road map to its future. Any decline in the quality of, and emphasis on, the study of American history in the nation's high schools thus is a matter of serious concern. It would therefore be the height of irresponsibility to ignore the warning issued by the Organization of American Historians that the public schools are slighting this basic subject and students are turning away from What ought to be an exciting as well as essential exploration of their country's origins.

title: Guilt Denied in Tax Case
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UPI)Ralph G. Newman, a Lincoln scholar and book appraiser, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he lied to Internal Revenue Service agents about his role in helping to falsify President Nixon's 1969 income tax returns. He appeared before United States District Court Judge. Frank McGarr after being indicted last week for a second time on the charges. Trial was set for Oct. 20.

title: Unit of Hadassah May Leave W.H.O.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18The Hadassah Medical Organization, an American affiliate of the World Health Organization, said today that It would withdraw from that body if it did not cease conducting a political campaign against Israel.

title: Catholic Church in City Basically Very Healthy
description: Among the cascade of changes pouring from Vatican II, none had more personal impact on the individual parishioner than the Kiss of Peace.

title: Winner Is Dissatisfied With Jet Pass Defense
description: I'm sure we'll see Craig Morton more than we've seen the other quarterbacks, said Coach Charley Winner of the Jets yesterday, talking about the Giants' quarterback.

title: S.C.I. Denies It Is Investigating State Police Intelligence Policy
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18  The State Commission of Investiga tion today denied published reports that it had begun an investigation into New Jersey State Police intelligence procedures at the request of a state Senator.

title: Chess:
description: Bluffing an attack with the real objective of provoking an overreaction by the defender was a device introduced by Emanuel Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921. Prior to his time, the sophistication in judgment necessary in foretelling the probable outcome of an attack was lacking and, therefore, such a selfconscious strategy as bluffing was impossible.

title: I.R.A. Denies a Link
description: Irish Republican Army members in Dublin and Belfast denied that the two Irishborn suspects might have intended to funnel part of the $2.3million ransom to the I.R.A., according to United Press international.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
Citizens Panel Finds Lag In Boston Integration Plan
description: BOSTON, Aug. 8A citizens' panel appointed by the Federal court charged the Boston School Committee today with footdragging in preparation for this fall's school desegregation.

title: Investigators Link Hoffa's Disappearance to His Early Alliance With Organized Crime
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18The disappearance of James R. Hoffa on July 30, many investigators believe, may have its roots in the alliances Mr. Hoffa forged with organized crime a quarter century ago in his drive for control of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: U.S. Discloses It Owns Glornar In Suit Against Coast Tax Levy
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18The Justice Department filed suit today in Federal court here to block the Los Angeles County assessor from taxing the Glomar Explorer, the ship that reportedly recovered a portion of a sunken Russian submarine for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Cities in West Are Starting to Protect Architectural Relics of a Gaudy Past
description: DENVER, Aug. 18  Just like in the old days, the citizens of this city tramped through the muddy ruts of Larimer Street last weekend in silks and satins, buckskins and denim. They drank beer out of tin buckets, played rudimentary games of chance, and watched a theater troupe declaim The Innkeeper's Daughter under a striped tent.

title: Suspects' Friend, 72, Can't Believe It
description: Morris Greenberger shook his head yesterday as he lay in his bed at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Shouting to a Different Drum: Children Who Make Their Own Instruments
description: These were the earshattering sounds being made by several dozen joyous children at the Museum of the City of New York the other day: clangy metallic sounds, gentle tappingonwood sounds, dissonant sounds, harmonic sounds, upanddownthescale sounds, syncopated rhythmic sounds. And all on homemade instruments.

title: Amphibious Plane Crashes
description: HARLINGEN, Tex., Aug. 18 (AP)A World War II amphibious aircraft owned by the Confederate Air Force crashed near the airport here today killing three persons and injuring two others. The Confederate Air Force, which has a museum here, is composed of pilots who collect and fly old military aircraft as a hobby.

title: In Mermoriam
description: ADELMANLeon L. Aug. 19, 1903April, 7, 1974. Rest in peace, Dad.

title: China and Cambodia Sign Pact for Economic and Technical Cooperation
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 18China and Cambodia signed an agreement on economic and technical cooperation today, The Chinese press agency reported, after a Cambodian delegation returned to Peking from an unexplained visit to a North China port.

title: LAWRENCE MURPHY, ASSEMBLYMAN, DIES
description: Lawrence P. Murphy, a Brooklyn Assemblyman from 1944 to 1970, died Sunday of a heart attack in Peninsula Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 65 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Catena, Still Silent, Free After 5 Years
description: TRENTON, Aug. 19  The New Jersey Supreme Court today freed Gerardo Catena, the reputed boss of the Vito Genovese Mafia family, after five years of imprisonment, saying it was convinced he would never tell what he may know about organized crime.

title: State Retracts Its Threat Of Evictions at CoOp City
description: The state yesterday withdrew its threats of evictions, foreclosures and contempt citations against the thousands of tenants of CoOp City in the Bronx who had refused to pay a 25 per cent increase in carrying charges.

title: French Bishop Ousted By South Vietnamese
description: PARIS, Aug. 19 (Reuters) A French bishop just expelled from South Vietnam said today that the Vietnamization of the Roman Catholic church was now under way.
