title: Port Agency in Camden Obtains Another Wharf
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 19The port of Camden, which in three years of existence progressed from zero to a millionton volume per year, today was assured of space for future growth with the purchase of more waterfront property from the city.

title: Brutalized Children
description: FITCHBURG, Mass.I am a clinical psychiatrist seeing large numbers of white working families, and I find myself simply amazed.

title: AILEEN T. TURNBULL
description: Aileen Timothy Turnbull, widow of Phillips R. Turnbull, former president of Rogers Peet Company, died Sunday at the Royal Victoria Hospital, Montreal. She was 62 years old and lived at Juno Beach. Fla.

title: John Kriza of Ballet Theater, U.S. Dance Pioneer, Dies at 56
description: NAPLES, Fla., Aug. 19 (AP) John Kirza, a former principal dancer of American Ballet Theater, was found dead yesterday, floating in the Gulf of Mexico. The police said that Mr. Kriza had apparently drowned. He was 56 years old.

title: Dollar Off Sharply In Europe Trading; Gold Prices Drop
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 19 (UPI)The dollar tumbled against major European currencies today as more dealers sold the currency in weak trading.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Reform the City's Civil Service System

title: Potato Salad Is Their Domain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Potato salad is a rather mundane dish, one that has 350 calories per cup, one that has been known to cause heartburn, one that is lacking in mavens and one that never seems to be sold out at the neighborhood delicatessen.

title: WNCN Returns to Air
description: WNCNFM will return to the air with primarily a classicalmusic format next Monday at 8 P.M., it was announced today. Page 75.

title: . . . Muscovites Rush to Try Them, Too
description: MOSCOWThe fickle winds of fashion, which once seldom buffeted Soviet women, have wafted in one of Moscow's most spontaneous fadsthe patterned anklelength skirt.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A public offering of 600,000 common shares of the Minnesota Power and Light Company, at $17 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co.; Damn Kalman & Quail, Inc., and Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, Inc.

title: CAR MAKERS BAR AN IMPORT STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The automobile industry declined today to take a position on whether it is being injured by foreign cars allegedly sold in this country at dumping prices.

title: Measles Drive Reported Saving $1.3Billion in First 10 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The nationwide measles immunization campaign saved government, industry and individuals at least $1.3billion in its first 10 years, a Federal health agency reported today.

title: 23 Troupes Arrive Here Aug. 28 For 11th Free Festival of Dance
description: Adam A. Pinsker, executive producer of the New York Dance Festival, recalls the time when he once walked out of a performance being held at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: GRAIN PRICES UP; SOYBEANS IN RISE
description: Prices of grain and soybeans for future delivery advanced on a wide front yesterday after a late rally erased the effects of heavy liquidation of contracts early in the session.

title: Assessor Agrees to Defer Tax Levy Against Glomar
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP)  The county tax assessor agreed today to delay his effort to tax the Summa Corporation $7.5million for the Glomar Explorer until a hearing next month to determine who owns the ship.

title: Donohue, 38, Dead Of Racing Injuries
description: GRAZ, Austria, Aug. 19 (AP)Mark Donohue, who ended an eightmonth retirement as an auto driver last year because he couldn't keep away from racing, died tonight of injuries suffered Sunday at the Austrian Grand Prix.

title: MRS. GANDHI ACTS TO REFUTE CRITICS
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 19 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who maintains that many Westerners are not even trying to understand the recent events in India, has stepped up her efforts to explain the situation to them.

title: 4 ExJunta Leaders in Athens Face Death Penalty for Revolt
description: ATHENS, Aug. 19At least four leaders of the military junta that seized power in Greece in 1967 face mandatory death sentences if the Athens Court of Appeal trying them on charges of high treason and revolt accepts the recommendations made by the prosecution today.

title: Caracas Invites Ridgefield Pupils
description: The time was spring and the senior history class at Ridgefield Memorial High School had two Venezuelan guests fielding questions about their country and its oil policies as part of a Latin America area study.

title: Con Edison Again Postpones Bond Issue
description: Market conditions, characterized by rising rates necessary to float new corporate issues, resulted yesterday in postponed offerings by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and the Western Union Telegraph Company. Con Edison once again postponed an $80milion of fering of first mortgage bonds for an indefinite period, citing current market conditions.

title: Why Go to College?
description: The depressed economic outlook for college graduates has led to a popular reassessment of the benefits that could reasonably be expected to flow from a student's considerable investment of time and money in higher education. Though upsetting, it is hardly surprising that a study conducted at Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that the decline in economic advantages that used to flow from the college degree has begun to undermine the public faith in higher education.

title: Contract Awards
description: Continental Airlines has agreed to sell its last three Boeing 747's to Intercontinental Aircraft, Ltd., thereby sustaining an aftertax loss of $8.9million in the transaction. The aircraft will be transferred by Intercontinental to Trans World Airlines, which will perform some technical work and resell them to Iran. Continental said that the capital loss incurred in the deal would be offset in the future by reduction of the costs of carrying the disposed aircraft.

title: Bank Loan to South Korea
description: MANILA, Aug. 19 (AP)The Asian Development Bank approved today a $43million loan to South Korea to finance its roadimprovement project. In a statement, the bank said the primary objective of the project, was to meet the Government's general policy of linking together all areas of the country and all sections of the population with paved road transport facilities.

title: VALLI'S SONGS AVOID NOSTALGIA PITFALLS
description: Frankie Valli, the singer and the Four Seasons, a quartet he is both with and apart from, who appeared at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Monday, are truly musicbusiness phenomena. Singing their own hits that date back almost two decades, with several million dollars in sales figures, Mr. Valli and his group manage to avoid the pitfalls of rock nostalgia, the musicinaspic aura.

title: Moore Duo Leading by Shot on 77
description: JERICHO, L. I., Aug. 19Ruth Moore of Rockville Links and Jean Cici of Cedar Brook, a former Metropolitan champion, led today's opening round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Barbara S. Kirkland Memorial 36 hole Pinehurst championship. They scored 77 over the 5,698yard, par72 course at Meadow Brook Club.

title: Klein Pressing to Hold Suffolk Land
description: CUTCHOGUE, L.I, Aug. 19Twelve members of the Suffolk County Legislature, guided by John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, inspected the rolling acres of open space that the county administration wants to acquire as part of is $60million farmlandpreservation program.

title: Three Rob Pleasantville Bank; $30,000 Found Later in Woods
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Aug. 19Three masked gunmen held up the main branch of the First National Bank of. South Jersey today, disarmed the guard, forced the customers to lie on the floor, cleaned out the six tellers' cash and fled.

title: ISRAELI CAUTIONS ON U.N. EXPULSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.Israel's new chief representative at the Uniited Nations, Haim Herzog, said today that negotiations for an interim Sinai agreement between his country and Egypt had reached a very advanced stage, but he hinted that it might prove unworkable if his delegation were to be ousted from the coming General Assembly session.

title: I.T.T. IS PLEDGING NO POLITICAL DEAL
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that it would sign al pledge to shareholders promising to confirm each year that it had not taken part in partisan political activity, Reuters reports.

title: Protestantism in the City Divided on Racial Lines
description: The recent decision by Central Presbyterian Church to sell its building at Park Avenue and 64th Street sent waves of anxiety through much of the Protestant community.

title: Israelis Given Assurances On a Peace Force in Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Egypt, Israel and the United States have agreed to support the establishment of an independent peacekeeping force in Sinai if the United Nations Security, Council should unexpectedly refuse to renew the mandate of the present buffer force during the threeyear life of a projected new accord between Israel and Egypt.

title: Angry Thailand Policemen Attack Home of Premier
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Aug. 20A mob of angry policemen stormed the residence of Premier Kukrit Pramoj late last night, looting and wrecking the building in protest against the Thai Government's recent release of nine detainees in response to pressure from leftwing students.

title: Additional Wheat Sold To Soviet by Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 19 (AP)The Australian Wheat Board has sold 250,000 tons more of wheat to the Soviet Union, following the July sale of 750,000 tons, the wheat board's chairman, Jack Cass, said today.

title: FORD TALK A PART OF TOUGHER STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19High Administration officials said today that progress toward a hew SovietAmerican nuclear arms pact was too slow and uncertain and that President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger wanted to apply additional pressure on the Russians.

title: Monday's Fight
description: PhiladelphiaBenny Briscoe, Philadelphia, outpointed Eddie Gregory, New York, 10 rounds, middleweights.

title: Britain's Motorcycle Industry Sputtering
description: WOLVERHAMPTON, England, Aug. 18  In this flat indiztrial town west of the steel mills of Birmingham, the 3,500 workers at a lonely outpost of the oncethriving British motorcycle industry are fighting against oppressive odds to save their fobs.

title: Mets Win, 63, to Spoil Debut Of Virdon as Astros' Manager
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19Showing form fit it for a pennant race, Jon Matlack of the Mets stopped the Astros, 63, at the Astrodome tonight, marring Bill Virdon's debut as the Houston manager.

title: OPERATOR FREED IN MEDICAID CASE
description: Donald E. Ross, former presdent of the New Jersey Nurs??g Home Association, has been ??cquitted of charges of derauding the Federal Government of $170,000 in inflated ledicare claims.

title: Thinking Man's Driver
description: Along pit row, Mark Donohue was known as the thinking man's driver, especially by rivals who looked at the Ivy League graduate's chubby face and couldn't figure out any other way this kid was beating them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1975

title: Books of The Times
description: At first hand I know very little of the pleasures of train travel. The pressure of time has generally forced me into the oversimplification of airplanes, from which I saw nothing but the anticlimax of space and a glimpse of the ugly suburbs that always surround arrival and departure. Airplanes are now trying to tempt people from their books, their sleep or drinking with movies, but there are no movies, and few books, that can compete with the life that streams past the train window.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: LAURENCE GOODSTEIN
description: Laurence Goodstein, an executive of Goodstein Bros. & Co., men's clothing, died Monday at his summer home in Lake Mahopac, N. Y. He was 70 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.

title: Oven Interest
description: Tuesday, Aug. 19, 1975

title: LOFGRIN AND KOOPER SHARE A ROCK BILL
description: Nils Lofgrin and Al Kooper toil in the fields of rocknroll, knowledgeable of the music and capable of performing it, as they did at the Bottom Line on MondayBut it was a predictable evening of much professionalism and little surprise.

title: A NIXON DEPOSITION ATTACKS CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Richard M. Nixon's lawyers contended today that an angry Congress sat in judgment of Mr. Nixon, found him guilty and then punished him by passing a law seizing his Presidential papers.

title: STATE ARTS COUNCIL CRITICIZEDONGRANTS
description: The State Council on the Arts has been charged with discriminating against museums and related cultural institutions and favoring performing arts groups in grants made from this year's budget. William Conway, chairman of the City Cultural Institutions Group, made the charge yesterday.

title: Castro On The Road
description: HAVANA, Aug. 19In the last few days, Fidel Castro has been showing President Luis Echeverra Alvarez of Mexico around Cuba, talking about the importance of fish, the breeding of milk cows, and the health and the education of the Cuban people.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Chicago at New York (8 P.M.) Wood (1216) vs. May (118).

title: About New York
description: The green thumb is one of New York's larger underground brotherhoods, with a membership of thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, who are determined to let nature poke up through the concrete caging of the city.

title: WNCN to Return as ClassicalMusic Station
description: WNCNFM will return to the air with primarily a classical music format next Monday at 8 P.M.

title: Sewer Drains to Be Tried As Street Toilets for Dogs
description: Dog owners will be asked to have their animals use sewer drains along East End Avenue as toilets in a twomonth pilot project starting next month in Carl Schurz Park.

title: U.S. Won't Penalize Airline on Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)  The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today it had decided not to penalize Flying Tiger Airlines for flying 99 Vietnamese refugees into the United States without proper entry documents.

title: L. ROY HAWES
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Aug. 19 (AP)L. Roy Hawes, former Massachusetts commissioner of agriculture, died yesterday at Brattleboro Memorial Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: 3 Men Die in Fire
description: IRON RIVER, Mich., Aug. 19 (UPI)Three men were killed and several other persons were injured early today when fire damaged a portion of a home for the mentally and physically disabled here. The victims were residents of River House, Inc., a twostory brick structure on the edge of the city. About 20 persons are housed in the building, the police said.

title: FUND ISSUE SPLITS ELECTION AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Federal Election Commission is deadlocked on a strategically important question about matching grants to Presidential candidates.

title: HOLLOMAN FOCUS OF BOARD DISPUTE
description: A key member of the board of city's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that he had to threaten immediate resignation to get the corporation's president to turn over to board members material on possible budget cuts that h had withheld.

title: Bayh Withdraws as Sponsor of Criminal Code Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Senator Birch Bayh announced today that he would lead a drive to defeat the proposed revised criminal code if it was not rewritten to eliminate repressive provisions restricting availability of Government information.

title: FRANCIS S. APPLEBY, A LAWYER, 80, DEAD
description: Francis S. Appleby, lawyer and former billiard champion, died yesterday at his home in Old Brookville, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: Soviet Climbers Train in Shawangunks
description: The first Soviet mountainclimbing team ever to visit the United States unlimbered yesterday by doing some rockclimbing in the Shawangunk Mountains near New Paltz, N. Y., in preparation for more serious climbing in the Rockies later this month.

title: Study Asks for Caution In Sale of Atom Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The widespread use of nuclear reactors in the world's less developed countries would lead to the production of enough plutonium for these countries tol make a total of 3,000 small atomic bombs each year, according to a study done for the Energy Research and Development Administration.

title: City Bond Tax Brings Warnings
description: The imposition last Friday of a corporate bond tax by New York City under which buyers and sellers both are charged 25 cents for each $1,000 bond traded has raised a new furor in the financial world.

title: Brazil Gaining in Drive To Eradicate Illiteracy
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil (Reuters)Blackboards fill the aisles and teachers replace preachers in the cathedral of this northeastern city as Brazil strives to eradicate illiteracy by 1980.

title: Legislature With 15 Ordered for Nassau By a State Justice
description: MINEOLA, Aug. 19Joseph Liff, a State Supreme Court Justice, today ordered Nassau County to adopt a 15member legislature from equal population districts to replace the present Board of Supervisors.

title: Viking Is Poised for Launching Today for '76 Landing on Mars
description: Preparations went forward yesterday at Cape Canaveral, Fla., for the twice  delayed launching at 5:22 P.M., Eastern daylight time today, of the first of two American craft designed to put a lander on the surface of Mars next summer.

title: Mujib's Two Daughters In Seclusion in Bonn
description: BONN, Aug. 19The two daughters of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who was killed in Dacca with the rest of his family in a coup d'tat Friday, are in seclusion in the Bangladesh Embassy in Bonn.

title: Grand Jury Investigation of Hoffa Is Unexpectedly Postponed
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19A Federal grand jury investigation, said by investigators to represent the best hope of solving the mystery of the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, former teamsters' union president, has been delayed unexpectedly until at least after Labor Day.

title: FORD TALK A PART OF TOUGHER STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19High Administration officials said today that progress toward a new SovietAmerican nuclear arms pact was too slow and uncertain and that President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger wanted to apply additional pressure on the Russians.

title: SUSPECT INSISTS HE'S NO KIDNAPPER
description: Dominic Byrne has cast himself as an innocent unwittingly involved in the Samuel Bronfman 2d kidnapping who didn't want to hurt anybody, including the perpetrator, and ended up with thanks from the 21yearold victim, according to Mr. Byrne's lawyer.

title: GETTY AND PHILLIPS SETTLE LITIGATION
description: The Getty Oil Company announced yesterday an agreement settling all existing litiation with the Phillips Petroleum Company. As a result, Getty said, some $30million after taxes will be added to its consolidated net income for the third quarter of 1975.

title: Critic's Notebook: Contemporary Music to Some Ears
description: Opinion molders, wouldbe molders and sheeplike followers were present in considerable number, as usual, at the Festival of Contemporary Music that recently ended in Lenox, Mass.

title: Korea Bishop Loses Appeal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 19 (AP)The Supreme Court today upheld a military court verdict and 15year prison term against the Most Rev. Daniel Tji, the Bishop of Wonju, who was convicted of providing financial aid to an alleged student conspiracy against President Chung Hee Park's government.

title: A Culebra Celebration
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Puerto Rico plans to celebrate on Sept. 30 the closing of the naval weapons range on Culebra and will invite all Congressmen and others ho helped stop the target shelling. Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon announced tonight. The Puerto Rican Government is scheduled to take over the Culebra range next month when the United States Navy transfers its target range to a nearby, uninhabited island in the British Virgin Islands.

title: McIntyre's Followers Are Told About Flying Saucers
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 19Sightings of flying saucers tHat have stumped others posed no puzzle for the Rev. Carl McIntire's fourth annual U.F.O. conference here.

title: McDonald's in Sweden Is Damaged by 2d Blast
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 19 (UPI) A bomb exploded outside McDonald's today, causing some damage but no injuries. It was the second bombing of the hamburger restaurant in two months.

title: Bridge
description: Those bridge players who invest in the stock market should be aware that their assets can boom or slump at the card tableand the financial impact can be considerable if they are playing for stakes.

title: Methadone and Jobs
description: Federal Judge Thomas P. Griesa has injected sanity into a highly controversial area by ruling that it was unconstitutional for the New York City Transit Authority to exclude all methadonemaintained exaddicts from employment.

title: Judge Stays Dock Boycott Of Soviet Grain in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19Longshoremen who refused today to load wheat bound for the Soviet Union were ordered by Federal District Judge James. Noel in Galveston tonight to return to work tomorrow morning while he decides whether to issue a permanent injunction halting the dayold work stoppage.

title: Typhoon Killed 56 in Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 19 (AP)The toll from this year's fifth typhoon has risen to 56 dead and 12 missing and at least $37million in damage to agrcultural and marine products in western Japan, the national police and the AgricultureForestry Ministry reported today. The typhoon caused landslides and floods, particularly in Shikoku, Japan's smallest main island, on Sunday. It dwindled to a moderate tropical storm yesterday.

title: BOYCOTT IS URGED ON FARE INCREASE
description: Representatives Bella S. Abzug and Herman Badillo yesterday urged a lunchtime rally of nearly 1,000 people in Lower Manhattan to refuse to pay the increased transit fare sccheduled to go into effect Sept. 1.

title: WNCN Returns to Air
description: WNCNFM will return to the air with primarily a classicalmusic format next Monday at 8 P.M., it was announced today. Page 75.

title: RABBI DAVID MOGILNER
description: Rabbi David Mogilner, national director of the Ramah camps of the Jewish Theological Seminary died yesterday apparently of a heart attack, at a Ramah camp in Hanover, Pa. He was 42 years old and, while he lived in Israel, had been in this country as a camp operator for the summer.

title: WORK TO RESUME ON PARKWAY HERE
description: The longdelayed reconstruction of a dangerously dilapidated section of the Henry Hudson Parkway between 72d and 81st Streets will begin immediately, Governor Carey said yesterday in announcing the award of a construction contract.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission recently took the first step toward what may become the most extraordinary product recall in history.

title: Excerpts From the Speech by the President to the American Legion
description: Now that Americans are no longer fighting on any front, there are many sincere, but in my judgment, shortsighted Americans who believe that the billions for defense could be better spent for social programs to help the poor and disadvantaged. But

title: New Bangladesh Regime Asks India for Amity and Cooperation
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 19The new Government of Bangladesh, in a conciliatory gesture toward its giant neighbor, made an appeal tonight for friendship and cooperation with India.

title: Cambodian Leaders Dine With Sihanouk
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Aug. 20Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's nominal head of state, and Khieu Samphan, the new Cambodian Communist leader, attended a banquet in Pyongyang last night given by President Kim II Sung of North Korea, the Chinese press agency reported.

title: A Daring Underground System Aids East Germans in Fleeing to the West
description: BONN, Aug. 19In secret compartments built into auto trunks, on boats and, rarely, in aircraft, hundreds of East Germans desperate to leave their country are helped to escape in lucrative but dangerous operations carried out by foreign professional helpers.

title: PRICE OF AIR FARE AND FUEL LINKED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)  The Ford Administration asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to let airlines pass along increased fuel costs to customers without C.A.B. hearings.

title: Police Out, San Francisco Faces Fire and Transit Strikes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19Sporadic violence erupted and Mayor Joseph L. Alioto appealed for calm today as San Francisco's police force completed the first day of its first strike.

title: DR. CORNELIUS HAGGARD
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI)  Dr. Cornelius P. Haggard, who had been president of Azusa, Pacific. College for 36 years, died Saturday after surgery. He was 63 years old.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday.

title: Unveilings
description: LEVITINHerman. The unveiling for Herman Levitin will he held on Sunday, Aug 24, at 10 A.M. at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Seven Hurt in Belfast Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 19 (Reuters)A carbomb exploded in a Roman Catholic area of Belfast early today, slightly injuring seven people, police officials said.

title: Expectations Fade For Grain Backlog
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The Agriculture Department has reduced its estimates of world grain stocks for next year by almost 8 million metric tons. Although large crops are expected in the United States, drought elsewhere is expected to prevent world grain reserves from being rebuilt, the department said today.

title: Advertising
description: This agency is built upon the proposition that women are different from men, and thank God they are. Lois Geraci Ernst said yesterday in describing her agency. Advertising to Women, Inc.

title: AndAt the End Of the Line?
description: TEL AVIVThe main thrust of United States policy at this critical stage of Middle East peacemaking is concentrated on persuading Israel to take a longrange view of history and of its own role. This, according to the American viewpoint, involves recognition of certain world realities that have nothing to do with tactical vantage points along either interim or ultimate frontiers.

title: SUSPECT INSISTS HE'S NO KIDNAPPER
description: Dominic Byrne has cast himself as an innocent unwittingly involved in the Samuel Bronfman 2d kidnapping who didn't want to hurt anybody, including the perpetrator, and ended up with thanks from the 21yearold victim, according to Mr. Byrne's lawyer.

title: Court Victor, 61, 63
description: HARRISON, N.Y. Aug. 19A preview of how the new HarTru clay surface will affect next week's United States Open tennis championships was afforded today at the MediQuik Women's Classic at Westchester Country Club.

title: A's Retain Boise Club
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 19 (AP) The Oakland A's announced today the renewal for 1976 of a working agreement with their Boise farm tlub of the Northwest League Boise returned to organized baseball this season after a 13year absence.

title: Nursing Home Aide Acquitted in Jersey Of Medicaid Fraud
description: Donald E. Ross, former presdent of the New Jersey Nursing Home Association, has been acquitted of charges of defrauding the Federal Government of $170,000 in inflated Medicate claims.

title: Wary Indians Dicker Over Rights to Coal
description: CROW AGENCY, Mont., Aug. 17The rows of tall white canvas teepees rose like sentries in a grassy meadow of the Crow Indian Reservation in southeast Montana, as they always do this time of year. From 16 states, thousands of Indians from more than two dozen tribes have gathered for the 57th annual Crow Fair and Rodeo, a weeklong celebration of parades, contests, traditional dances and good times.

title: Ford Reaffirms His Opposition To Busing as Integration Tool
description: PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 19Presidnt Ford reaffirmed today his opposition to busing as a method of integrating public schools, but defended his Administration's overall record on civil rights.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HESTON'S HOME RUN The chariot race in Ben Hur as Charlton Heston guided four white steeds in a thundering dash around a stadium of Old Rome, is a screen spectacle not easily forgotten. The first race, in the 1926 original with Ramon Novarro, was no slouch, either.

title: Poland Discloses Details Of Ethnic Germans' Exit
description: WARSAW, Aug 19 (Reuters) Poland will grant about 125,000 visas within the next few years to ethnic Germans who want to emigrate the Polish Communist party newspaper Trybuna Ludu said today.

title: Soviet Grain Blockade
description: As if the Ford Administration were not doing enough in its own right to mishandle the problem of Soviet grain shipments, the A.F.L.C.I.O. and its rapacious maritime unions have made a messy situation messier by reasserting their right to dictate foreign policy by economic might.

title: London Cricket Field Is Vandalized In Protest Against the Legal System
description: LONDON, Aug. 19A group campaigning for the release of an imprisoned man vandalized a cricket field today, causing the cancellation of a crucial match between England and Australia and angering millions of Britons.

title: Mrs. Willie Davis in the Outfield
description: Latest word from St. Louis is that Willie Davis is approaching a compromise with his former wife and she may not have to play for the Cardinals, after all. Red Schoendienst, the St. Louis manager, is relieved. With his salary garnisheed for back alimony, Willie quit the team last Friday saying, Let my wife play the outfield.

title: BAD WATER IS FOUND NEAR URANIUM MINES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Tests of drinking water near uranium mines in western New Mexico have found high levels of radioactivity and poisonous wastes, and Environmental Protection Agency report says.

title: Tractor Defect Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)  John Deere & Co., of Moline, Ill., has notified a Federal safety agency that about 1,400 of its lawn and garden tractors may experience sudden failures that could be hazardous. The company said that transmission control linkage pins on its Model 400 tractors could fall out.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP)Pel, who signed a record $4million contract with the New York Cosmos just after the start of the season, was named today to the North American Soccer League AllStar team. Pel was one of the three forwards selected. The others were Gordon Hill of Chicago and Steven David of Miami.

title: Penney Net Down; Federated and May Show Profit Gains
description: The J. C. Penney CoMpany, the nation's second largest retail merchandiser, continued to show profit declines in the quarter and half ended July 26, while Federated Department Stores, Inc., and the May Department Stores Company, two other leading chains, realized substantial increases in earnings over a year ago, according to their reports yesterday for similar periods.

title: Pirates Sink Giants And Lead Alone
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who came off a 212 wonlost road trip, including six straight defeats, returned to their home park last night and beat the San Francisco Giants. 40.

title: HERMAN BELTH
description: Herman Belth, a former partner and sales executive for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, in New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 923 Fifth Avenue.

title: SCIENTISTS WEIGH FUTURE OF PACIFIC
description: VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 19 Scientist from nations around the Pacific were offered three possible scenarios today for the next centuryone grim, one more hopeful and one optimistic.

title: James Summey, 61, Dies; Grand Ole Opry's Jody
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 19 (AP)James Clell Summey, who was with country music's Grand Ole Opry for 30 years and known for the song On Top of Old Smokey, died yesterday. He was 61 years old.

title: Frances Dustin Dies
description: DEXTER, Me., Aug. 19 (UPI)  Frances E. Dustin, the first (woman aide to step on the floor of the United States Senate while it was in session 29 years ago, died yesterday at her home. Mrs. Dustin was an administrative assistant to former Senator Ralph Owen Brewster, Republican of Maine.

title: S.E.C. Cites Natomas
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in Washington yesterday that the Natomas Company had committed fraud in its 1974 takeover of the Thermal Power Company of California, Both are San Franciscobased energy concerns. Details. Page 54.

title: KISSINGER QUERIED ON ENVOY'S FUTURE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Members of the Congressional black caucus said today following a meeting with Secretary of State Kissinger that the Secretary had assured them that nothing will be done to impede the State Department career of W. Beverly Carter Jr., the former Ambassador to Tanzania, who is black.

title: A Few Hints on Barbecuing Chicken From a Man Who Really Should Know
description: ITHACA, N. Y.  Prof. Robert C. Baker is the uncrowned king of barbecued chicken in New York State and the surrounding area.

title: Savoir Gets Post 5 for Trot
description: Joey Heatherton ran into a tough critic yesterdaya complaining Frenchman.

title: JOHN R. HULTEN
description: John R. Hulten, former Puerto Rico regional vice presdent of the Union Carbide Corporation, died of a heart attack here Aug. 12, He was 54 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: BANK SALE IS SET BY N L INDUSTRIES
description: N L Industries Inc., announced yesterday that it had signed a contract for the sale of the Lake View Trust and Sayings Bank of Chicago for $40million. The buyer is William N. Lane, also of Chicago, N L Industries acquired 99.89 per cent of the bank's stock as an investment in 1969. Changes in the Bank Holding Company Act in 1970 required that the company divest itself of this holding.

title: About the Giants . .
description: Faddie Tillman, a defensive end, was released yesterday. It was his fifth tryout failure with an N.F.L. club and left the Giants with three more cuts still to be announced to reach the 55player limit. ... Karl Chandler, who won a spot last season as a free agent, appears assured of a berth at center or guard. He gets better every time he plays, Arnsparger said of the Princeton offensive lineman, citing Chandler's improved footwork and use of his body. He's a competitor, intelligent and he's earned everything he's got.

title: PHILLIP W. BROWN
description: Phillip W. Brown, who retired in 1963 as a partner in charge of the trading department of Smith, Barney & Co., investment banking and brokerage concern, died Saturday at his home in East Hampton, L. I. He was 75 years old and lived also in Key Largo, Fla.

title: State to Act on Oneida's Welfare Curb
description: The State Commissioner of Social Services, Stephen Berger, announced plans yesterday to seek an injunction against elected officials in Oneida County, where the local Board of Legislators has refused to appropriate county funds for welfare costs.

title: Carey Meeting Former U.S. Officials And Bank Aides in the Fiscal Crisis
description: Governor Carey will move into a critical behindthescenes role in the city's fiscal crisis today, in separate meetings with bankers and former Federal officials to renew a campaign for assistance from Washington for the Municipal Assistance Corporation and New York City.

title: Market Basket
description: Beef from grassfed cattle reached New York City food stores last week, lowered prices a little and, together with seasonal fluctuations in the prices of fruit and vegetables, reduced the cost of feeding a family of four in the city slightly, 0.3 per cent.

title: South Africa Starts Crackdown On Dissidents in Ovamboland
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 19  South African officials have begun a crackdown on dissident elements in the disputed territory of SouthWest Africa following the murder of a proSouth African tribal leader on Saturday.

title: Fund Crisis at Beirut School
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The American University of Beirut said today it had raised tuition fees by an average of 30 per cent and had canceled salary increases for teachers and senior staff members. It cited a growing budget crisis, after a deficit of more than $3million last year.

title: Market Place
description: Since early 1973, Wall Street has been checking out a new thesis to help explain why stocks move the way they do. According to this thesis, rising Treasury bill rates cause prices to fall.

title: GRAND JURY HEARS FROM MRS. HEARST
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 19Patricia Hearst's mother made, a brief appearance here today before a grand jury investigating the possibility that her daughter and other Federal fugitives were harbored in a Pennsylvania farmhouse last year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON ME AND OTC
description: Prices moved broadly lower yesterday in moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Blue Cross Picket Arrested
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19 (UPI)A picketing New Jersey Blue CrossBlue Shield worker and four strike sympathizers were arrested today on charges of blocking the entrance to the medical service's headquarters here, the police reported. Th 1,500 strikers, members of the Office and Professional Employes International Union A.F.L.C.I.O. walked off their robs on June 4 to protest ??alled contract negotiations.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mayer Eliminated In Jersey, 63, 76
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 19Sandy Mayer of Mendham, N. J., and Paul Gerken of East Norwalk, Conn., two of the East's leading players, were defeated today in firstround action of the 50,000$ Tennis Week open. The tournament is being played on clay courts at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Ice Blocks Supplies For Alaska's Pipeline
description: ICY CAPE, Alaska, Aug. 19After all the years of environmental debate over the TransAlaska pipeline, it is the environment itselfin the form of the daily weather reportthat is getting the closest reading today in this iceshrouded area 300 miles southwest of Prudhoe Bay.

title: WINE TALK
description: The widespread practice among otherwise conscientious restaurateurs of making a big profit on the sale of wine by the glass was discussed here last week. Quite a few readers both buyers and sellers, responded.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation has reached agreement with the California Air Resources Board to test some of its cars that were banned in that state to see if they meet its cleanair standards, which are believed to be the toughest in the nation.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS OF ATOM BUILDUP IF ARMS TALKS LAG
description: PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 19President Ford warned today that he would be compelled to accelerate the nucleararms race if the Soviet Union did not agree to a curb on strategic weapons this year.

title: Connors, Miss Evert No. 1 In Forest Hills Seedings
description: Jimmy Connors was seeded No. 1 yesterday for the United States Open tennis championships, which begin next Wednesday at Forest Hills in Queens. Stan Smith, coranked with Connors as the top American player in 1974, wasn't seeded at all.

title: U.S. TO STOP FUNDS IN MEDICARE FRAUDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The Social Security Administration announced today that it would begin denying pay ment to doctors, hospitals and nursing homes who defrau?? Medicare.

title: Australian Budget Exempts the Poor From Paying Tax
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Labor Government today introduced its 197576 budget, which contains a radically new income tax system that will exempt 500,000 lowincome workers from paying a tax.

title: GRAND JURY HEARS FROM MRS. HEARST
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 19Patricia Hearst's mother made a brief appearance here today before a grand jury investigating the possibility that her daughter and other Federal fugitives were harbored in a Pennsylvania farmhouse last year.

title: Portugal Confrontation
description: The ink is barely dry on the Helsinki declaration signed with such pomp earlier this month; yet the harsh realities are already peeking through the cosmetic goodwill. Portugal, the most sensitive country on the European continent at the moment, is rapidly becoming the focus of what looks suspiciously like a classic SovietAmerican confrontation.

title: HELPERN TESTIFIES IN KENT STATE SUIT
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (UPI) Dr. Milton Helpern, former New York City chief medical examiner, testified today that he thought one of the students wounded during the Kent State University shootings had been struck by a bullet from the type of weapon National Guardsmen were carrying.

title: New Yorkers Stay Cool in AnkleLength Skirts...
description: In the 1950's it was called a patio dress and suburbanites loved it for al fresco cocktail parties. When it turned up again five years agocalled the maxiskirt and meant for street wearthere was pandemonium. Girl watchers howled that it would spoil their pleasure in looking at miniskirted legs.

title: Blighted Dream . . .
description: Most of the 90,000 New York. City families living in apartments built with city and state subsidy to house middleincome families moved in joyously. The predominantand usually effusiveview was that they had found a way to stay in New York in pleasant, wellkept buildings, often surrounded by greenery, at rents or carrying charges they could afford without excessive pocketbook strain.

title: Hadassah Plans to Step Up Youth Center Program in Israel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19Hadassah will increase its youth centers in Israel to integrate Jewish children of Middle Eastern and African backgrounds who pose serious social and educational problems in the Jewish state.

title: Boucha Undergoes Operation on Eye
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 19 (AP)Henry Boucha, injured in a stickswinging fight with Dave Forbes of the Boston Bruins last January, underwent further surgery on his injured right eve today.

title: DONALD H. M'LEAN, EXREP. OF JERSEY
description: Former Representative Donald H. McLean of New Jersey who also was a former Judge of the New Jersey Superior Court, died yesterday at Fanny Allen Hospital, Winooski, Vt. He was 91 years old and lived in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: . . . New Vision Needed
description: The state understandably blanched at carrying out its threat to oust CoOp City rent strikers. Even a token move against a handful of militants would have involved great risk of violence and martyrdom. As an alternative to evictions, the city is exploring the feasibility of a plenary class action for contract default againt dissident tenants in its properties. A judgment would open the way for garnisheeing their bank accounts or attaching their automobiles.

title: Philadelphia Firemen Keep Watch at Site of Oil Blaze
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP)  Firemen maintained their vigil most of today at a charred oil storage tank, the last vestige of an 11alarm fire that claimed six lives at the Gulf Oil Company refinery.

title: Frank X. Shields Is Dead at 66; Tennis Star Led '51 Davis Team,
description: Frank X. Shields, a former tennis star and captain of the United States Davis Cup team in 1951, died suddenly yesterday, appatently of a heart attack, in a taxicab after dining in a Manhattan restaurant. He was 66 years old and lived here.

title: S.E.C. Charges Natomas With Fraud in Business TakeOver
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the Natomas Company today with fraud in the 1974 takeover of the Thermal Power Company of California, a geothermal steam company.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Tuesday, Aug. 19, 1975

title: Pressure Mounts on Portuguese Premier
description: LISBON, Aug. 19Military and civilian groups applied increasing pressure today to oust Premier Vasco Goncalves.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1975

title: Special Dividend Declared
description: Directors of Reynolds Securities, Inc., declared yesterday a special dividend of 10 cents on the common stock, payable Sept 15 to shareholders of record Aug. 29. Now on a 40cent basic annual rate, payable semiannually, the company also pays a minimum of onethird of any additional earnings above the 40 cents yearly, it roted. The stock was split 3for2 last April 15.

title: Dow Drops by 14.24 to 808.51
description: Bluechip and glamour issues led the stock market sharply lower yesterday after an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury warned that the next few months are likely to be a turbulent period.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS OF ATOM BUILD UP IF ARMS TALKS LAG
description: PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 19President Ford warned tday that he would be compelled to accelerate the nucleararms race if the Soviet Union did not agree to a curb on strategic weapons this year.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: General

title: Hicks Will Go All Out tIn Barzilauskas Duel
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 19John Hicks is prepared to pay the price to keep Carl Barzilauskas away from Craig Morton in Sunday's GiantJet exhibition at Yale Bowl.

title: New TV Commercials Make Life Begin at 40
description: The documentaries and testimonials are fading. So are the plainlooking people. Extravagant musicals are out. What's new in the world of the television commercial is older people.

title: State Detracts Its Threat Of Evictions at CoOp City
description: The state yesterday withdrew its threats of evictions, foreclosures and contempt citations against the thousands of tenants of CoOpCity in the Bronx who had refused to pay a 25 per cent increase in carrying charges.

title: N.A.A.C.P. TO APPEAL ON DETROIT SCHOOLS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19  A desegregation ruling requiring no immediate school busing in Detroit has drawn the fire of civil rights leaders, who accused a Federal judge of judicial lawlessness.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: LEWIS OSTERMAN SR.
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 19Lewis Osterman Sr., founder and board chairman of Osterman Jewelers, a 19store chain in five states, died here yesterday. He was 77 years old.

title: Dance: Giselle in London
description: LONDONAmerican Ballet Theater, which is celebrating its 35th anniversary this year, is not the only ballet company with an anniversary to cemmemorate. London Festival Ballet is ha years old this year and is marking the occasion with a number of seasons here, including the current one at the Royal Festival Hall, which for many, many years has been one of the company's homes.

title: Recovery and the Fed: A Diagnosis Due
description: The Federal Open Market Committee, thta august monetary policymaking body that consists of the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board and the presidents of five regional Federal. Reserve Banks, held its regular monthly meeting in Washington yesterday. Exactly what it decided won't be known for another 45 days, when its summary minutes will be released, although astute Fedwatchers in the money market will know long before then whether the central bank has significantly altered its policy.

title: UTILITIES RESIST INSULATION PLAN
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19Representatives of elecricity and naturalgas utility companies took issue today with a proposal that would direct them to offer energysaving insulation to New Jersey homeowners on a nonprofit basis, at the same time increasing publicity and advertising on insulation's importance in conserving fuel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: District Attorney Denis Dillon of Nassau County said a majoroffense bureau would be set up next month to deal with violent crime. I believe the best deterrent to violent crime is swift and certain punishment, he said in his first news conference since taking office in January. The aim of this bureau is to move these cases from arrest to disposition in 90 days. It will combat an increase in violent crimes and focus resources on habitual offenders and restrict pleabargaining in these cases. The bureau will be staffed by seven assistant district attorneys, who will be on 24hour call.

title: Gomez Dismissed by Houston
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19The Houston Astros reached all the way back to their general manager's neighborhood in Oyster Bay, L.I., today in their search for a new field manager, and came up with Bill Virdon.

title: Only Side Saddles Permitted in Show
description: MOUNT HOLLY  The state's horse world will score another first on Sept. 6, when a show restricted to side saddlers will take place at Foggy Meadows Farm.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Music
description: In relatively uncomplicated chamber works, the presence of a conductor is not only unnecessary but often an annoyance. So one could hardly object to JeanPierre Rainpal's basic approach as star instrumentalist and sometime conductor at Monday night's Mostly Mozart concert.

title: Aircraft Workers on Strike
description: LYNN, Mass., Aug, 19 (AP)More than 1,000 aircraft workers joined others on strike against the General Electric Company's Riverworks plant today. The action brought to 5,000 the number of members of Local 201 of International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers on strike.

title: RUSSIANS INVOKE MASS SOLIDARITY WITH LISBON REDS
description: MOSCOW, July 19  The Kremlin today called for solidarity with the Portuguese Communists, who have been thrown on the defensive in the deepening political crisis.

title: P. S. C. Examiner Cuts Increase Sought by Brooklyn Union Gas
description: A Public Service Commission examiner yesterday recommended that the regulatory body increase the annual revenues of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company through rate increases by $40.9million, rather than the $64.2million that the company is seeking.

title: Notes on People
description: Because of a lesion on his left lung, Donald K. (Deke Slayton, at age 51 the oldest of the astronauts, will undergo exploratory surgery in a Houston cancer hospital next week. The consensus of the medical team, said the NASA announcement yesterday, was that the lesion is not the result of inhalation of nitrogen tetroxide gas during the ApolloSoyuz project mission.

title: Rights in SovietA Fading Hope
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 19Hopes that the Soviet Union might take some initiative in carrying out the human rights provisions of the recently signed European security conference declaration have been dissipating since the document was signed two and a half weeks ago. Instead of opening up even modestly to the freer movement of people and ideas urged in the declaration, Moscow has indicated that new negotiations might be necessary for progress on even minor points.

title: People and Business
description: One of the major factors in yesterday's stock market decline was a speech delivered in Tuscon, Ariz., by Sidney L. Jones, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy.

title: Head Injury Spurs Bat Helmet Recall
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The Rawlings Sporting Goods Company said today it was recalling 150,000 baseball batting helmets that could split if hit hard by a bat or ball.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Essex County Prosecutor's office is investigating allegations that Mayor Carmen A. Orechio of Nutley, who is a Democratic State Senator, has abused the powers of his office in dealing with the town's police force. Assistant Prosecutor Joseph Fusco said the investigation had been prompted by complaints from a police captain, a lieutenant and a patrolman who listed at least 15 examples of alleged interference and impropriety by Mr. Orechio since he was elected Mayor in 1972. Mr. Fusco said the three officers had contended, among other things, that Mr. Orechio had used town vehicles to transport customers of his travel agency and had exercised undue influence in dismissing parking tickets. Mr. Orechio called the complaints trumped up charges.

title: Israelis Given Assurances On a Peace Force in Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Egypt, Israel and the United States have agreed to support the establishment of an independent peacekeeping force in Sinai if the United Nations Security Council should unexpectedly refuse to renew the mandate of the present buffer force during the threeyear life of projected new accord between Israel and Egypt.

title: Yankees Beaten In 11th
description: Billy Martin lives by the suicide squeeze play and he dies by the suicide squeeze play. Last night he died.

title: 7 SEIZED IN BRONX ON GUN CHARGES
description: Luis Soto, leader of the Dirty Dozen youth gang in the South Bronx, was arrested with six other persons yesterday on charges of selling guns.

title: How Tax Benefits Work
description: The investment arrangement for Manhattan Plazain which a group of organizations and wealthy individuals has bought the $4.8million equity in the project from Richard Ravitch, the developeris basically similar to many financing deals in publicly assisted housing.

title: In Memoriam
description: RUTHERFORDJean, Jim and ??we will be reunited some day.

title: Walker Bid To Set 1,500 Mark Fails
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 19 (AP) John Walker, who set a world record in the onemile run last week, failed in his bid to break the 1,500meter mark today at an international track and field meet.

title: G.M. Pressed on Chile
description: The General Motors Corporation is being pressed by church, trade union and human rights groups not to enlarge its investment in Chile.

title: Jets' Tannen Out for Season
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 19Steve Tannen found out today his Jets' season was finished.

title: Judge Stays Dock Boycott Of Soviet Grain in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19Longshoremen who refused today to load wheat bound for the Soviet Union were ordered by Federal District Judge James Noel in Galveston tonight to return to work tomorrow morning while he decides whether to issue a permanent injunction halting the dayold work stoppage.

title: About the Jets . . .
description: Only one of the three starting linebackers, Jamie Rivers, played with the team last season. Jamie tests us for an hour every night, said Godwin Turk, speaking for himself and Rich Lewis, the other starters. We can't cheat. He's right on top of us. . . . Al Woodall on his passing performance Saturday night at St. Louis: I tried to figure out why I went bad. I think it was my play selection. Coach Charley Winner on Woodall's performance: Five Al's passes were dropped. If those were caught he's 13 for 21 instead of 8 for 21. . . . Bob Gresham, one of the startling surprises in the two preseason games with the club's four touchdowns and 103 of its 252 yards rushing, probably will see action against the Giants despite a strained knee.

title: About Education
description: In recent days a national historians' organization sounded an alarm that secondary schools were abandoning American history, employing teachers with little training in the field, and producing students preoccupied with current events and distracted by specialty courses.

title: Protestantism in the City Divided on Racial Lines
description: The recent decision by Central Presbyterian Church to sell its building at Park Avenue and 64th Street sent waves of anxiety through much of the Protestant community.

title: People in Sports
description: The parents of Luis Tiant, Boston Red Sox hurler, are in Mexico City on their way to the United States from Cuba for a visit with their son. Tiant hasn't seen his father, who was a pitcher in Cuba, since 1960. He had a brief reunion with his mother in Mexico several years ago.

title: Firestone Net Falls 7.8%; Other Concerns Report
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the second largest tire producer, after the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, reported yesterday !reduced earnings for the guarter and nine months ended July 31, reflecting higher operating costs and the depressed state of the automobile and housing markets.

title: TURKISH CHIEF CITES TREASON BY ALLIES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 19 (AP)President Fahri Koruturk, touring provinces near the Soviet border today attacked the treason of Turkey's friends and allies in a clear reference to strained relations with the United States

title: Equity Off Broadway Rules Stir Rift
description: Actors Equity Association, under attack by Off Off Broadway producers, playwrights and actors, has called a special membership meeting for Monday to discuss objections to its new code governing the use of Equity actors in Off Off Broadway theaters.

title: Police Out, San Francisco Faces Fire and Transit Strikes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19Sporadic violence erupted and Mayor Joseph L. Alioto appealed for calm today as San Francisco's police force completed the first day of its first strike.

title: And Proud of It
description: I first met my wife Rosemary at 2 A.M. on Friday night in an unfamiliar bar in Richmond Hill, which is in Queens. Today, the same bar almost never stays open that late, and through most of the evening hours the door is opened by a buzzer operated by the bartender, who only lets in those faces pressed to the window which are familiar.

title: PICATINNY CLOSING STILL NOT SETTLED
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP Aug. 19Undersecretary of the Army Norman R. Augustine toured Picatinny Arsenal here today and said no decision had been made on whether to keep the facility open and retain the jobs of 5,700 civilian employes

title: Quick Time of Modern Life Takes Hold In a Village Isolated in Alaskan Tundra
description: BETHEL, AlaskaMaybe there's something about this town, spilled haphazardly along the crumbling banks of the broad and sluggish Kuskokwim River, isolated in the endless tundra 500 air miles west of Anchorage, that makes people pause and grapple with the imponderables of life.

title: Jazz at Other End Starts With 2 Groups
description: The Other End, the Bleecker Street club that normally runs a gamut of rock, pop, comedy and folk, has added jazz on Monday and Tuesday evenings. It began its jazz policy on Monday with two superficially similar groups that produced distinctively different resultsthe Jeremy Steig Quintet and Raices, both featuring a flute lead and Latin percussion.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP) Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
About New York
description: The green thumb is one of New York's larger underground brotherhoods, with a membership of thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, who are determined to let nature poke up through the concrete casing of the city.

title: Corn Syrup Prices Raised by Sucrest; Sugar Costs Cut
description: The Sucrest Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised the wholesale price of two corn syrups used in sucrose blends. The company. which on Monday had reduced by $1 a hundred pounds the price of industrial sugar, raised the list price of its 42DE corn syrup by 62 cents to $19.86 a hundred pounds. It also increased the price of Its 62DE corn syrup by 61 cents to $19.95 a hundred pounds.

title: Portuguese Reds Cancel a Major Rally
description: OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 19 Portugal's Communist party canceled a major rally here tonight after a new outbreak of antiCommunist violence north of here and the failure of the military to curb it.

title: RUSSIANS INVOKE MASS SOLIDARITY WITH LISBON REDS
description: MOSCOW, July 19  The Kremlin today called for solidarity with the Portuguese Communists, who have been thrown on the defensive in the deepening political crisis.

title: Manhattan Plaza Is Focus Of Dispute for High Stakes
description: A $95million apartment development rising on West 42d Streetonce a bright sym bol of hopes to clean up and revitalize the entfre Times Square areahas become the focus of a bitter, highstakes dispute involving millions of dollars and the issue of whether proposed changes in the project would imperil the area's improvement.

title: Chevron Oil Sues Exxon And Globtik in Collision
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP)The Chevron Oil Company filed a halfmilliondollar damage suit against the Exxon Corporation and a tanker company today to recover losses it said were incurred in the collision last Friday of a tanker and an offshore drilling platform.

title: 4 Former Employes Of Franklin National Give Not Guilty Plea
description: Four former employes of the nowdefunct Franklin National Bank have pleaded not guilty at their arraignment on charges stemming from an alleged plan to use $30million in bank funds for foreigncurrency speculation.

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Horses listed in order of Past positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: F.B.I. Investigating Possible Drug Link To Hospital Deaths
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 19 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Veterans Administration medical team are investigating the possibility that at least eight deaths and 34 other cases of respiratory difficulties at a V.A. hospital here may be the result of a drug used to suppress breathing.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Catena, Still Silent, Free After 5 Years
description: TRENTON, Aug. 19  The New Jersey Supreme Court today freed Gerardo Catena, the reputed boss of the Vito Genovese Mafia family, after five years of imprisonment, saying it was convinced he would never tell what he may know about organized crime.

title: Los Angeles Gains as Site Of Democratic Convention
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The Democrats strong prefer ence for New York City as the site of their 1976 national convention has declined, in part because of the city's fiscal crisis, and Los Angeles is now regarded as running at least even in the contest for the meeting.

title: Woodall Visiting Sick Father
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 20Al Woodall left the Jets training camp today because his father, who, has been stricken with cancer, was seriously ill.

title: L.I. POLICE REACH A MERGER ACCORD
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 20The rigid enforcement of traffic rules by the Long Island State parkway police for the last 10 days is expected to end as a result of an agreement in Albany today on the principle, of a merger of the parkway police with the Nassau and Suffolk police departments.

title: Viking Off for Mars
description: After nine days of delays, the Viking spacecraft was successfully launched yesterday on its 10month trip to the planet Mars. Page 31.

title: Agriculture Agency  Sees Further Drop In Prices of Sugar
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) Sugar br:ices probably will decline again this Fall as buyers react to prospects of a bigger world sugar harvest, the Agriculture Department has forecast.

title: FORD VOWS TO END DISPUTE ON GRAIN
description: VAIL, Colo., Aug. 20President Ford, urging all sides to cool it a bit, pledged here today that he would resolve the dispute threatening to disrupt massive shipments of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Connors Ailing, but Still Wins
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 20Jimmy Connors, who helped attract a recordbreaking crowd of 3,100 for his firstround match Monday night, did it again this afternoon in the $50,000 Tennis Week open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Personal Income Off
description: The Commerce Department reported yesterday that personal income declined in July following an increase in June attributed largely to special Government payments. Details, page 56.

title: RCA Cuts Transistor Costs
description: A series of price reductions on 27 types of generalpurpose and 22 Darlington power transistors were announced yesterday by the RCA Solid State division, a unit of the RCA Corporation. The devices are used in general electronic applications in the industrial, instrumentation, computer, consumer and automotive markets. In the generalpurpose category, prices were reduced] by an average of about 8.3 per cent. Some items were cut as much as 60 per cent.

title: GREEKS, IN CRISIS, TOOK U.S. SUPPLIES
description: ATHENS, Aug. 20The Greek military command seized several million dollars worth of American ammunition during the Cyprus crisis last summer, according to Greek and American officials here.

title: 2 Rulings Declare Tennessee's Law On Genesis Invalid
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 20 (AP)A Federal judge and the Tennessee Supreme Court today ruled unconstitutional a 1973 Tennessee law requiring text books to provide equal space to Biblical theories on the creation of the universe.

title: Marshall Brown's Jazz Refuses To Stay Put in Single Category
description: For the last dozen years, Marshall Brown has been somewhat of an oddity in jazz not only because he plays valve trombone, a gruff, grumpy instrument whose only other notable jazz adherents are Bob Brookmeyer and Maynard Ferguson, but also because he refuses to stay put in any specific jazz category. He once had a group with Pee Wee Russell that focused on traditional jazz and he has also had a group, with Lee Konitz that played modern jazz.

title: U.S. STEEL AGREES ON FEDERAL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) The SenateHouse Defense Production Committee was told today the Uinted States Steel Corporation had agreed it could comply with Government accounting standards in contracts involving Trident nuclear submarines.

title: Emergency Called In San Francisco; Firemen Join Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20Following a night of robberies and scattered violence that included a bomb explosion outside the home of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto, the County Board of Supervisors today passed a resolution declaring a state of emergency in San Francisco and asking the Mayor to summon at least 200 state highway patrolmen to replace striking city policemen.

title: Tomahawks Win, 1715
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 The Long Island Tomahawks clinched a tie for the championship of the National Lacrosse League by scoring a 1715 victory over the Philadelphia Wings last night at the Spectrum. Paul Mur.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide yesterday incorrectly reported that the weekly guided tours of Brooklyn conducted by Singer's (8759084) leave on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. The correct days are Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday. The tours depart from Joralemod Street, between Court and Adams Streets, at 10:30 A.M.

title: 1,370 Square Miles Designated By U.S. for Offshore Oil Wells
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) The Interior Department today announced the tentative selection of 1,370 square miles of ocean bottom off New Jersey and Delawarl as the site for the first East Coast offshoreoil and gasdrilling venture.

title: Books of The Times
description: With the appearance in 1940 of her first novel, The Heart is a Lonely Hunter, Carson McCullers pecked her way out of the egg of Southern smalltown anonymity and burst upon the literary scene, a writer in full feather. As chronicler of the misfit, the freakish, the unrequited lover, she touched a deep nerve of American loneliness. Discarding the novel's traditional social and intellectual baggage, she made the poet's unencumbered pilgrimage, to the heart. She bathed the familiar, mundane American landscape in a garish surreality. A contemporary readership, living on the knife edge of depression and war, tired of both the discredited middleclass verities and the new social consciousness and flirting with a new privatism that would be concealed in World War H patriotism, was ready for her.

title: Apawamis Women Winin Golf
description: JERICHO, L. I., Aug. 20Jean Ashley Crawford, a former United States amateur titleholder, and Marion Choate cauaured the eighth womens Metropolitan Golf Association Barbara S. Kirkland Memorial Pinehurst championship today over the par72, 5,698yard Meadow Brook Club course with a score of 79. 77156.

title: Advertising
description: One would have to have been shipwrecked the last two years not to realize that a large part of the world's wealth is flowing into the oilproducing countries of the Middle East. Consequently it has become the fastest growing market for goods and services in the world.

title: TEXAS'S IMA HOGG, PHILANTHROPIST
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)Ima Hogg, a philanthropist who preserved many treasures for Texas, died yesterday in a hospital in London, where she had been vacationing. She was 93 years old.

title: Portugal Reports Situation on Timor Is Out of Control
description: LISBON, Thursday. Aug. 21 (Reuters)Portugal today said that her forces in Portuguese Timor could not control the situation on the island, where fighting has broken out between rival political groups.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Francisco da Costa Gomes of  Portugal, yielding to pressure from antiCommunist military and political forces, revealed that the Government of Premier Vasco Gongalves would be replaced in a matter of days. Two competing military groups had presented him with a common platform to govern the country and were said to have threatened force if he did not oust the Premier quickly. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: Mets Are Beaten, 54, in 10th; Yankees Drop 4th in Row, 53
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20Bill Virdon, making a change a minute in a tight game, managed the Astros to a 54, 10thinning victory over the Mets at the Astrodome tonight.

title: BEANIE EXCLUDED AS BOARD MEETS ON FISCAL CRISIS
description: The Board of Estimate, dissatisfied with what one member described as Mayor Beame's drift in the fiscal crisis, met without the knowledge of the Mayor Tuesday and considered a program, advanced by Controller Harrison J. Goldin to reduce the city's borrowing next month and beyond.

title: BEAME EXCLUDED AS BOARD MEETS ON FISCAL CRISIS
description: The Board Of Estimate Panel Hears Plan by Goldin to Cut Borrowing and Avert City Default

title: Shaw Sets World Mark In Swim
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 20 (AP)Tim Shaw of Long Beach, Calif., broke his own world swimming record in the men's 400meter freestyle tonight with a time of 3 minutes 53.31 seconds.

title: Survey of Women Indicates Striking Shift in Sexual Mores
description: One of the largest surveys ever conducted on the sexual mores and habits of young, middleclass, married women has concluded that an overwhelming majority of them no longer subscribe to a sexual double standard, and that woman have abandoned the role of passive sexual partner.

title: DDay at Dover a Snafu As U.S. Dinghy Capsizes
description: LONDON, Aug. 20  The United States Army tried yesterday what Napoleon and Hitler dared only contemplatecross the English Channel and scale the white cliffs of Dover. The American invaders ran out of fuel, lost their rations and had to be towed to safety.

title: MAXWELL R. MAYBAUM
description: Maxwell R. Maybaum, a retired diamond and pearl merchant and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home at 12 West 72d Street. He was 85 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U. N. Today
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Some Victims Identified
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 20 (Reuters) A Danish orchestra conductor, Erling Hoey, and his family and a Polish theater director, Konrad Swinarski, were among the victims of the crash at Damascus.

title: IPORTUGUESE CHIEF SAYS GOVERNMENT WILL FALL IN DAYS
description: LISBON, Aug. 20President Francisco da Costa Gomes, yielding to anti  Communist military and political forces, said today that the Government of Premier Vasco Gongalves had only a few days to live.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Helsinki Text Affirmed
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today hailed all 10 principles of the Helsinki declaration as equally valid, but said that if one issue was more important than the rest it was the agreement that frontiers were inviolable.

title: SIHANOUK LIKELY TO RETURN SOON
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Aug. I 21Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's nominal head of state who has been staying in North Korea, was host at al banquet in Pyongyang last night for the North Korean President, Kim Il Sung.

title: 4 Die in Fire Despite the Efforts of 2 LaidOff Firemen
description: Four members of a Brooklyn family died early yesterday despite rescue attempts by twolaidoff New York City firemen when fire tore through a wooden house in the Flatbush section.

title: Farm Losses and Toblessness Mount
description: BRIDGETON, Aug. 20Crop losses from storm damage in New Jersey are continuing to mount and more seasonal farm workers are finding themselves out of jobs, spokesman for farm agencies here and in Trenton said today.

title: Battle on Inflation Hits Iranian Retailers
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 20Butchers have been arrested in Abadan. A baker has been jailed in Tabriz. And a plasterer in Rezaieyh  also known as Urmiahas gone underground.

title: VIOLATIONS FOUND IN 8 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The Health Department has released the names of eight more food establishments charged with violating the city's Health Code and which failed two inspections. It also named restaurants and stores that had their third and final inspection. The establishments and the results follow:

title: ELIZABETH BERENSON
description: Elizabeth Berenson, sister of Bernard Berenson, the art critic who died in 1959, died Monday at La Cumbra Convalescent Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 97 years old and had lived at the hospital for several years.

title: Bid Here Is Improved
description: In its bid to be the site of the Democratic National Convention next July, the city has agreed not only to rent and refurbish Madison Square Garden for the convention, but also to close off adjacent streets for security and parking.

title: Rangers Schedule
description: Oct. 8, Chicago; 12, Los Angeles; 15, Atlanta; 19, Vancouver; 26, Philadelphia; 29, St. Louis.

title: Edgat Bronftnari Weds in Fariiily Reunion Atthosphere
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 20In a wedding guarded by the police and punctuated by the sound of circling helicopters, Edgar M. Bronfman, head of the billiondollar Seagram Company, Ltd., married a 25yearold Englishwoman, Georgiana Eileen Webb, here today.

title: CAREY ESTIMATES A HUGE CITY DEBT
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that the city's total deficit, accumulated from prior budgets and in the current $12.3billion budget, stands at $2.8billion, according to information provided him by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Events Today
description: THE SHOESHINE PARLOR, a Play by James Lee; directed by Marvin Felix Camillo; performed by the Mobile Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival; at St. John's Recreater Center Playground, Prospect Place and Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, 8.

title: Congressman, on Visit to Soviet, Presses Officials on Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20A visiting member of the House of Representatives said today that Soviet visa officials had conceded to him that the recent Helsinki declaration might necessitate some change in emigration policies.

title: REVENUE SHARING ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Thei $30.2  billion revenue  sharing program, which the Administration wants to renew before it expires next year is financing largescale discrimination in state and local public employment and services, according to a report released today by four national organizations.

title: People and Business
description: Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, who has been under attack recently by consumer groups, and labor unions for United States grain sales to the Soviet Union, was in turn critical of agricultural policy in the Soviet Union. In a speech in Washington yesterday he said: There is no greater folly than to try dictating agriculture policy from the political arena. Centralized decision making for agriculture doesn't work. It never has, it never will.

title: Linebacker Dealt Crist Dropped
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 20  Ron Hornsby finally found a home today  with the Green Bay Packers.

title: GRAINS FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Longshoremen Again Load Ships. Bound for Soviet Grain on prices rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as longshoremen resumed loading grain on ships destined for the Soviet Union.

title: DEAL IS DISCUSSED BY LOEB, RHOADES
description: Loeb, Rhoades & Co., one of Wall Street's largest investment houses, confirmed yesterday that it was negotiating for the purchase of the 24 branch offices of Edwards & Hanly. Until the last year or so, Edwards & Hanly, established in 1953, has been one of the most aggressive advertisers for the brokerage trade of the small investor. The branches extend from Boston to Miami.

title: ISRAELIS REPORTING 3 GUERRILLAS KILLED
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 20 (Reuters) Three Arab guerrillas were killed and one Israeli soldier was wounded in a clash near the Lebanese border today, military sources said.

title: MAJOR GAIN SEEN ON A SINAI ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Egypt and Israel were repurted today to have narrowed their differences significantly on one of the key remaining issues holding up completion of a new agreement on the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Kent State Testimony Ends; Jury Could Get Case Today
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (UPI) Testimony ended today in the $46million Kent State civil damage trial and the case, lin its 14th week, could go to the jury tomorrow.

title: Opulent Fashions of the Twenties: An Era Is Lovingly Recreated
description: It is January. 1920, in Boston the opening scene of Beacon Hill. Mazy Lassiter sweeps out of the Model T taxi in her steamer wrap coat of black moleskin dripping with gray chinchilla, burnt vulture feathers quivering on her broadbrimmed hat. The Louis Vuitton luggage is ordered into the redbrick Georgian home where butler, housekeeper and three starched maids await.

title: Business Briefs
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 20 (AP)Memhers of the Pulp, Paper and Woodworkers of Canada union in British Columbia voted 84 per cent against accepting contract proposals by a special mediator, the union said.
