description: Behind the double locks and the grille work protecting the staid rarebook division of the New York Public Library there was a smile of elation and a flutter of excitement late yesterday over the news about the reported Gutenberg Bible find.

title: Progress Cited in Heredity Research
description: HARBOR SPRINGS, Mich., Aug. 20Scientists are making rapid progress in mapping the basic sructures of human heredity, according to a report presented oday to a conference sponsored by the National FoundationMarch of Dimes.

title: THEODORE S. HALL 3D
description: Theodore S. Hall 3d, who had been in the realestate business on Long Island for more than half a century when he retired last year, died Tuesday in Port St. Lucie, Fla. He was 68 years old and lived in Port St. Lucie.

title: U.S. Wins a U.N. Victory on Puerto Rico
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 A United Nations committee under strong pressure from the United States, voted today to put off indefinitely its consideration of a resolution affirming the inalienable right of the people of Puerto Rico to selfdetermination and independence.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Following are excerpts from a deposition taken from former President Richard M. Nixon by lawyers for the Government, which is the defendant in Mr. Nixon's suit to gain custody of his Presidential tapes and documents, and intervening defendants:

description: The only valid way to judge the proposed interim agreement which Secretary of State Kissinger is now carrying between Israel and Egypt is to consider the alternative. Would the nations of the Middle East, and of the world at large, be more secure if this negotiation now failed? The answer is clearly no.

description: LEVITINHerman. The unveiling for Herman Levitin will be held on Sunday. Aug. 24, at 10 A.M. at Cedar Park Cometery, Paramus, N.J.

description: Wednesday, Aug. 20, 1975

title: ROBFRT T. H. THAYER
description: Robert T. H. Thayer, a financial analyst and a vice president of LoomisSayles, Inc., investment counselor, died Tuesday in Hamilton, Mass., where he lived. He was 44 years old.

description: George G. R. Van Allen, a retired professor of English literature at Cornell University, died Friday at a nursing home in Doylestown, Pa. He was 79 years old.

title: Rep. Dingell Sees Costlier Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) Representative John D. Dingell, the chairman of the Commerce Committee's energy and power subcommittee, predicted today that gasoline prices would rise to 90 cents a gallon if controls were allowed to expire.

title: Milton Waldor, 50, Lawyer, An ExJersey State Senator
description: Milton A. Waldor, a lawyer and former Republican New Jersey State Senator, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, N.J. He was 50 years old and lived in West Orange.

title: Business Fears a Disaster If City Defaults on Loans
description: Business and financial execulives in New York, distressed by the financial crisis, are urging that the city take the necessary steps to avoid defaulting on its securities.

title: Notes on People
description: If reporters had asked Betty Ford how often she sleeps with the President, she said in an interview published yesterday, she would have answered, As often as possible.

title: Good Sense at the U.N.
description: By a narrow but significant margin, the United Nations Decolonization Committee has sidetracked an outrageous effort, fueled by Cuba, to inject the world organization into the affairs of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. This victory for common sense represents an important first dividend for a tough but reasoned stance by the United States and its partners against the hollow rhetoric and mindless majorities that have brought the United Nations into disrepute and eroded its sunnort.

title: Population Shifts Beset Jewish Community Here
description: The Jewish community in the West Bronx these days is frequently described as a disaster area. A number of syna gogues have closed and others have only remnant congregations. In other parts of the city, howeverForest Hills, Queens, for examplesynagogues are thriving.

title: Stock Gauge Falls to Lowest Level Since April 11
description: Stock prices declined yesterday for the second consecutive day as the Dow Jones industrial average, which opened lower by 7.35 paints, fell 15.25 to 793.26, its lowest level since April 11, when it stood at 789.50.

description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow. Queens. 8 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 8 P.M.)

Premier Vasco Gongalves would be replaced in matter of days. title: Houston Longshoremen Obey Court and Load Grain for Soviet
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20 The maritime workers boycott of Sovietbound grain shipments was temporarily halted today when longshoremen here obeyed a restraining orderand, returned to work loading wheat purchased by the Soviet Union onto a Yugoslav freighter.

title: Yanks Eye Berra
description: No, Yogi Berra said last night, the Yankees haven't asked him to return as a coach next season, and no, he hasn't decided what he wants to do. However, the former manager of the Yankees and the Mets said he would listen to what the Yankeesand anyone else for that matterhave to say.

description: In urging New Yorkers to refuse to pay the higher subway and bus fare when it becomes effective next month, Representatives Bella S. Abzug and Herman Badillo and other prominent speakers at a downtown rally the other day launched a worthy cause on a dangerously misdirected track.

title: TV:Ustinov Joins Cavett on Saturday
description: Catching up with television's predictable spate of summer miniseries, those lowbudget candidates for harmless entertainment, the anxious buff might, for no pressing reason, begin with the schedule of the Columbia Broadcasting System. Earlier in the season, the network had Joey and Dad, in which Joey Heatherton gave weekly demonstrations on how to sing with one's upper torso. More recently, the limitedrun fare bas included Dick Cavett, formerly of the ABC network, and a singing group called the Manhattan Transfer, formerly of clubs and concert halls.

title: A Chutist Lands in Park To Publicize His Movie
description: A 49yearold man parachuted 10,500 feet into Central Park yesterday in the hope that the publicity would persuade a movie company to distribute a film he made more than three years ago and hag been unable to get before a paying audience.

title: Contract Awards
description: The NCR Corporation has received a $35.7million order from the Sumitomo Bank of Japan for about 2,400 electronic bank teller terminals and 200 minicomputers and associated equipment. The equipment will be used at the bank's 190 branches.

title: Bergman Indicted Again, On Coop Fraud Charges
description: Bernard Bergman, who is already facing Federal and State charges in connection with his ownership of nursing homes, was indicted yesterday on charges of defrauding the state and investors during the conversion of a $17million, apartment house into a cooperative.

title: LESSERPLEA MADE BY 3 IN GRAIN CASE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20Three defendants, accused along with the Bunge Corporation of conspiracy to commit systematic thefts of grain from interstate and foreign commerce, were allowed to plead guilty to a lesser charge today in return for their cooperation with investigators.

title: Walker 2d As Dixon Wins 1,500
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 20. (AP)John Walker was upset by a fellow New Zealander, Rod Dixon, in the 1,500meter run at an international track and field meet here tonight. At the same meet, Faina Melnik of the Soviet Union set a women's world record in the discus and Mike Boit of Kenya ran this year's fastest 800 meters.

title: Cicadas Take Warning: Killer Wasp is in Town
description: Cicadakiller wasps two inches long are turning up in the metropolitan area, but callers to the American Museum of Natural History are being reassured that the insects seek to avoid stinging humans.

title: PERSONAL INCOME DOWN FOR JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Personal income declined as expected in July, following the bulge in June that was associated with special Government payments, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Jobs Scarce as Slump Hits Liverpool Hard
description: LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 18Near the pier the men sit shirtless on the grass and gaze at the pills floating over the River Mersey. Youths leaning against a fence toss looped string across the grass in a sullen sport designed to trap a pigeon's leg. At midday crowds climb off buses and surge toward ferryboats.

description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 20John Fowler, associate professor of architectural design at the Yale University School of Architecture, died yesterday of complications resulting from pneumonia at YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived in Guilford.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Bicentennial Commission announced Would award grants to help restore five historic sites. Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, the commission chairman, said the grants added up to $24,298. They are $10,000 for the Morris Canal at. Waterloo Village in Sussex County; $10,000 for the Eagle Tavern, Trenton; $2,500 for Pomona Hall, Camden; $1,000 for Potter's Tavern, Bridgeton, and $798 for Chestnut Neck in Atlantic County.

title: 126 on Czechoslovak Jet Die in Crash at Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 20 (AP)A Czechoslovak airliner crashed into a small hill and exploded in flames while trying to land at the Damascus airport early today, spreading wreckage and bodies across a wide area. Officials said 126 of they 128 people aboard had been killed.

title: Dance: Phoebe Snow
description: The Phoebe Snow, that legendary train, had a smooth and easy road, quite unlike the difficult, agitated paths of those who lived near its right of way. The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Company presented The Road of the Phoebe Snow as the opening work of its third program on Tuesday evening at the New York, State Theater.

title: Bridge:

title: EDWARD L. BIGELOW

description: TRENTON, Aug. 20 (AP)The executive director of the State Election Law Enforcement Commission said today he would appeal a court decision that he believed thwarted the purposes of new campaignfinancing laws.

description: Bill Madlock, the Chicago Cubs third baseman who is leading the National League in batting by a substantial margin, was the victim of an unusual twofer in the fine department when he was penalized $200 yesterday for his behavior in last Saturday's game at Houston.

description: As the Yankees sink rapidly in the East, they can ponder many aspects of what was supposed to be their seasontheir failure to get fired up under Billy Martin, for example.

description: In his first use of the merit system in filling vacancies on the bench, Governor Carey yesterday announced the appointmtnt of three judges to various courts in the state.

description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 20(GPODuring the ApolloSoyuz flight last month, American astronauts observed a mystery star 300 light years away, emitting one million times as much ultraviolet radiation as the sun, an astronomer said yesterday.

title: 2 Utilities Bond Sales Get a Warm Reception
description: Two new corporate offerings by utilitiesone a $35million sale and the other a $20million financingfound a warm reception yesterday on the part of buyers. Thus, some new debt issues continue to reach sellout staCredit tus in a slimmeddown calendar at a time when others are posponed because of erratic market conditions.

title: MAJOR GAIN SEEN ON A SINAI ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Egypt and Israel were reported today to have narrowed their differences significantly on one of the key remaining issues holding up completion of a new agreement on the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Kennecott to Close Chase Metal Works
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday it would permanently close its Chase Brass and Copper Company subsidiary's Chase Metal, Works operations and would take an aftertax charge of $16million to 1975 earnings on the shutdown.

title: Norman MacLeish, 84, Dies; Artist Was Poet's Brother
description: NAPLES, Fla., Aug. 20 (AP)Norman MacLeish, an artist and brother of the poet Archibald MacLeish, died here yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: State Ethics Study Group Set Up
description: State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein of Manhattan, the Democratic minority leader, appointed five Democratic Senators to a study group to write a, code of ethics for Assemblymen and Senators that Mr. Ohrensteinsaid he would offer as a bill in the 1976 legislative session. The chairman is Joseph L. Galibir of the Bronx. The other members are Carol Bellamy of Brooklyn, Emmanuel R. Gold of Queens, Howard C. Nolan Jr. of Albany and Chester J. Straub of Brooklyn.

title: Man Held in 25 Car Thefts
description: REDDING, Calif., Aug. 20 (UPI)The police held Dwayne Nottingham, a 32yearold transient, today who they said used 25 automobiles stolen from car lots and left at other lots to drive 600 miles from the Los Angeles area to Redding during the last three weeks.

title: Nixon Asserts He Is Judge On Release of His Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Former President Richard M. Nixon, seeking possession of his Presidential documents and tape recordings, said in a sworn statement released today that he would make the material public as expeditiously as possible,'but that he and his family alone had the right to decide what should be released.

title: Glomar Explorer Sails
description: LONG BEACH, Calif. Aug 20 (UPI)The Central Intelligence Agency's submarinehunting ship Glomar Explorer, temporarily free of legal action by the county tax assessor, left today for nine days of tests near Catalina Island 26 miles away. On Monday, the Federal Government said that the agency owned the ship under a classified contract with Howard Hughes as registered owner and filed a suit in Los Angeles to prevent collection of 7.5million in taxes sought by the Los Angeles tax assessor.

title: Transit Officer Kills Boy, 14, Who Tried to Stab Passenger
description: A Transit Authority policeman yesterday shot and killed a 14yearold boy, who, according to the police, had attempted to stab a security guard from Mount Sinai Hospital who was waiting on a platform of the 96th Street Lexington Avenue IRT.

title: HADASSAH RAISES $23MILLION FUND
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20Hadassah has raised more than $23million this year to support and maintain its network of medical, social, vocational and educational services in Israel and for programs in this country.

title: COURT BARS A MOVE ITO SEIZE C.I.A. FILES
description: A motion to compel the Central Intelligence Agency to turn over all its files on Grove Press to a court for safekeeping was rejected yesterday by Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Archer  Daniels  Midland Company said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 2 million common shares through underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody & Co.

title: $500,000 in Jewels Stolen From Park Slope Penthouse
description: Jewels valued at a halfmillion dollars and $17,000 in cash were reported stolen yesterday from a penthouse apartment in Brooklyn's Park Slope section.

title: At V.A. Hospital in Michigan, Mysterious Deaths Stir Talk of a Poisoner as the F.B.I. Presses Investigation
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 20Families sit in the lobby of the Veterans Administration Hospital, talking quietly to sons or fathers or husbands who are patients here. Nurses move quickly along the halls. Doctors, make their rounds. All seems normal.

title: Park Sees Seoul Needing U.S. Force Only Till 1980
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 20President Park Chung Hee says that in five years his nation will no longer need American ground, air or naval forces or even logistic support to help defend itself if North Korea attacks without Chinese or Soviet aid.

title: Lumber Industry Remains Depressed by Housing Starts Decline
description: PEHASTIN, WashIf the legendary, Paul Bunyan were alive today, he might be out of work.

title: L. I. POLICE REACH A MERGER ACCORD
description: MINEOLA, L I., Aug. 20The rigid enforcement of traffic rules by the Long Island State Parkway police for the last 10 days is expected to end as a result of an agreement in Albany today on the principle of a merger of the parkway, police with the Nassau, wand Suffolk police departments.

title: Lou Lou Victor in L. I. Race Week
A Son of Liberty Sails Home to the Coast Guard
description: NORTH LUBEC, Me., Aug. 20  Running before the wind, her sails full and halyards slapping against the tall masts,the United States Coast Guard bark Eagle was at sea today, headed for New London, Conn., with the coffin of Capt. Hopley Yeaton, the first man commissioned into the maritime service by President Washington.

title: ELI HANOVER
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 20 (AP)Eli Hanover, the fight promoter who revived boxing in Baltimore in recent years, died at Baltimore County General Hosvital last night. He was 54 years old.

title: Bud Reed Is Handy Man To Know for Pedigrees
description: George (Bud) Reed is known among many fanciers as Mr. Pedigree. For when a breeder is in a hurry to obtain a pedigree, frequently he turns to the Ridgefield, Conn., entrepre, neur. A breeder may obtain a pedigree from the American Kennel Club but he has to wait several weeks, said Reed. I turn one out in 24 hours. In order to make it easier to read, list ancestral champions in red ink. I also include foreign ancestral champions that are not listed in the A.K.C. studbook. When it comes to imports, the A.K.C. doesn't go back further than the parents in the studbook. My pedigrees go back for six generations.

title: New YorkJersey Victor at Garden
description: Nate Archibald, who grew up in New York and now plays for the Kansas CityOmaha Kings of the National Basketball Association, scored 30 points to lead a squad of New YorkNew Jersey pros to a 117112 victory over the BuffaloWashington team for the championship of the 21st Century invitational basketball tournament last night.

title: Bilking of City in Medicaid Laid to BackBilling Flaw
description: A legislative investigation into Medicaid fraud has shown that a gimmick known as backbilling is allowing hundreds of doctors to doubleand triplebill the city with immunity, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

title: A. T. &T. to Offer Public Stock; Dow Drops by 15.25 to 793.26
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it would sell 12 million common shares worth $552million in a financing that, for the first time, would not give current shareholders preemptive rights to subscribe to the new issue.

title: A Gutenberg Bible Is Reported Found
description: BONN, Aug. 20  A 37yearold schoolteacher said today that he had discovered an original Gutenberg Bible in a church attic in Irrunenhausen, West Germany, and that experts have confirmed its authenticity.

title: Catena Now Expected to Meet Gambino
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20Gerardo Catena, the reputed Mafia bos who was released from a stat reformatory after five year yesterday, will have to meet soon with Carlo Gambino, th New York crime family boss and the dominant underworlc figure in the Metropolitan area, according to state and county, law enforcement officials.

title: U.S. Study Assails Officials on Boston Integration
description: BOSTON, Aug. 20The United States Commission on Civil Rights charged today that public officials ranging from members of the Boston School Committee to President Ford had encouraged resistance to busing by their failure to support last year's courtordered school desegregation plan here.

title: Hicks & Greist Picked By American Distilling
description: Hicks & Greist, Inc., has been appointed to handle the complete line of whiskies, vodka, gins, cordials and liquors from the American Distilling Company. No billing figures were given.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four members of a Brooklyn family died early yesterday, despite rescue attempts by two laidoff New York City firemen, when'fire tore through a wooden House in Flatbush.

title: Lewis Trial Postponed
description: ROSEBURG, Ore., Aug. 20 (UPI)The trial of Woody Green a Kansas City Chief running back and Rich Lewis, a New York Jets linebacker. has been postponed until next Tuesday. The two National Football League players were scheduled to go on trial on rape charges at Douglas County Circuit Court today. They were charged the alleged rape of a 16yearold girl at Loon Lake on May 11.

title: SARDINE DECLINE CALLED CYCLICAL
description: VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 20Despite a hue and cry against West Coast fishermen for allegedly overfishing sardines, the recent decline in the size of their catch has been due chiefly to a natural cycle, according to a specialist in marine resources.

title: Cool Tea and No Sympathy
description: George J. Mintzer is a patient man. Like most people, he can shrug off life's vicissitudes.

title: DELAY SUGGESTED ON OFFER FOR STAR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Godfrey W. Kauffmann, president of The Washington Star's parent corporation, is urging fellow stockholders to ignore Joe L. Allhritton's tender offer until the Kauffmann family and other principals have planned a concerted strategy later this week.

title: AntiDefamation Group Asks Boycott of U.N. Crime Talks
description: Eleven international organizations have been asked to boycott the United Nations Congress on Crime and Criminality in Switzerland because of the expected presence of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Market Place
description: The stock of Utah International, a wideranging mining corporation that derives the bulk of its sales from coal, declined more sharply Tuesday than any other on the New York Stock Exchange, sinking 6 to 53 Early yesterday, it slid further, touching a low of 49 before it regained ground to close at 52.

title: Steve Cady
description: The European with the jetset tan smiled forgivingly when somebody asked if he was stable manager for the race horses supported by ConstantinPeter Goulandris.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOUNDING OFF It's the last call tonight for those fullrigged, free operas that Vincent La Selva's New York Grand Opera Company has been presenting on the Central Park Mall. The final production, complete with scenery, costumes, chorus and orchestra, is Puccini's Turandot. The time is 8 o'clock. (The rain date is next Tuesday, same hour.) Mr. La Selva will conduct, and the leading roles will be taken by Janice Yogis as Turandot, Walter Rinaldi as Prince Calaf and Pyramid Sellers Liu.

title: Turnover Is Slightly Higher on Both the Markets
description: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER DROP

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 20 (AP)  Richard DelConte and Scott Schulman singled in runs in the seventh inning as Lakewood, N.J., rallied in the extra inning tonight to defeat Northridge, Calif., 20, in the opening game the 1975 Little League Series. The game was a pitchers duel between Lakewood's Dion Lowe, who struck out eight, and Craig Stevenson, who fanned 15, for the regulation six innings. The victory puts Lakewood in the final game Saturday against the winner of tomorrow's game between Tampa, Fla., and Davenport, Iowa.

title: Londos, Golden Greek Of Wrestling, Is Dead
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif., Aug. 20 (AP)Jim Londos, once known as the Golden Greek when he ruled professional wrestling's major circuit in the United States, died last night of a heart attack at Palomar Memorial Hospital. The popular matman, a top figure in the sport for about 16 years, did not know his precise age, but it was believed to be about 80.

title: SHEARSON HAYDEN REPORTS ON PROFITS
description: Shearson Hayden Stone, Inc., the nation's 10th largest securities firm, reported yesterday profitable operations for the fourth fiscal quarter and year ended June 30. Sanford 1. Weill, chairman, said the firm had been pro'fitable in each quarter during the year with revenues up 9 per cent and earnings 10 per Irent the third auarter.

title: Guerrillas in Argentina Kill 5; ExLeader Assails Mrs. Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20Leftwing guerrillas today attacked the police headquarters in Cordoba, Argentina's second largest city, killing at least five Policemen.

title: New Delhi Lifts Suspension Of U.P.L's Communications
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 20 (UPI) Telex communications in the United Press International's New Delhi bureau were restored today, more than two weeks after the Government cut off the bureau's communications because of violations of self censorship rules regarding India's state of emergency.

title: Nixon Asserts He Is Judge On Release of His Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Former  President Richard M. Nixon, seeking possession of his Presidential documents and tape recordings, said in a sworn statement released today that he would make the material public as expeditiously as possible, but that he and his family alone had the right to decide what should be released.

title: CONFLICT IS ALLEGED IN F.D.A. DRUG STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) A study that casts doubt on the value of oral diabetic drugs taken by more than one million Americans may have been prejudiced by a conflict of interest oh the part of one of the investigators, a researcher in the study said today.

title: 5050 Chance Seen
description: Although a final decision will not be reached until a committee meeting here next Wednesday, party leaders reported today that the California city had gained considerable support in recent weeks, rising to the status of a strong contender.

title: HEARST MEETINGS WITH SCOTT CITED
description: Jack Scott has confirmed series of meetings with the parents of Patricia Hearst that the participants thought might have been helpful in securing her surrender to the Federal authorities, according to Mr. Scott's friends and associates.

title: Friend of God
description: The wrestler, born in Argos, Greece, was the 13th child and was named Chris Theopheluswhich Londos would explain meant Friend of God. In his heyday, he was considered small for a wrestler5 feet 8 inches tall and weighing 200 pounds  but his muscular thighs were the levelers.

title: First Claim Paid To Tourist Infected At Park in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 20The Department of the Interior has paid the first of hundreds of claims from tourists infected by contaminated drinking water at Crater Lake National Park in southern Oregon.

title: A Plot to Slay Kosygin Fails in Russian Roulette
description: Premier Aleksei Kosygin is arriving in Canada to talk about disarmament. A hawkish K.G.B. faction decides to kill him. They grab a Latvian employe of the Central Intelligence Agency  a nasty man who ogles dirty pictures in the shower and confiscates children's hockey balls  stuff him full of explosives, and prepare to drop him out of a faked police helicopter right smack on Kosygin's head as he arrives at his hotel.

title: DATA HELD MISSING IN KENNEDY KILLING
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (UPI)  At least two pieces of evidence in the assassination of Senator Robert F: Kennedy have been destroyed Or are missing, a special counsel in the City Atorney's office said today.

title: In Memoriam
description: SHELLYGervey. Dear Shelly, you were loved dearly and always will be.

title: Texan Pays Sevetal Million for Rare MSS.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 20It cost John H. Jenkins of Texas several million dollars to perform what he called a cultural shift to the Southwest. Mr. Jenkins, who is a 35yearold bespectacled bibliophile, rare book dealer and publisher, has bought the rare book and manuscript collection of Edward Eberstadt & Sons, formerly of 888 Madison Avenue, New York.

title: Serving the Needy
description: Congress and the Administration have imposed bureaucratic burdens that are as demeaning as they are unnecessary on social services programs profoundly affecting the lives of millions. Specifically, Congress has inflicted a means test on senior citizens who receive social services under Title XX of the Social Security Act. For its part, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has promulgated regulations subjecting the elderly and beneficiaries of such other programs as day care, foster care and homemaker services to the extraordinary burden of reestablishing their eligibility every three months.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: MAXIM GORKI (Black Sea), Left Nassau Aug. 20; Dur 8 A.M., at W. 55th St.

title: Business Records
description: WINDSOR CARRIER CORPORATION, 277 Park Ave. N.Y. Signed by Sven Hansen, vice president. Liabilities 0127,002; as. sets $2,612,349.

title: Democracy for Nassau?
description: After seven years of litigation, hearings, lastditch roadblocks by political leaders and referendums designed to confuse the electorate, democracy is on the horizon for Nassau County. If the ruling board of supervisors abides by the recommendation of a nonpartisan citizens commission and the State Supreme Court, the constitutional doctrine of oneman, onevote will finally replace the oneman, manyvotes system that now obstructs truly representative government.

title: Britain Opens Driveto Win Support for Pay Restraint
description: LONDON, Aug. 20The Government opened a $4.4million campaign today to win public support for Prime Minister Harold Wilson's policy of limiting wage increases to $12 a week for the next year.

title: Westinghouse Set to Sell EconoCar to 2 Investors
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell EconoCar International, a subsidiary, to two private hivestors, E. Philip Saunders and Wil

title: Packers Lose Hayhoe
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 20 (UPI)Bill Hayhoe, starting tackle, has been lost to the Green Bay Packers because of a broken left leg.

title: Postal Service Sued
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (UPI) The Postal Service has been charged with discrimination against whites in a suit filed in United States District Court here by Edward J. Smith, a white postal clerk. The class action suit was filed for Mr. Smith by Richard B. Kay of the Ohio Justice Foundation and is said to represent some 3,000 employes.

title: Edgar Bronf man Weds in Family Reunion Atmosphere
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 20In a wedding guarded by the police and punctuated by the sound of circling helicopters, Edgar M. Bronfman, head of the billiondollar Seagram Company, Ltd., married a 25yearold Englishwoman, Georgiana Eileen Webb, here today.

title: Cave Explorers Rescued
description: CUMBERLAND, Md., Aug. 20 (AP)  A husbandandwife team of spelunkers, trapped in a cave for 13 days, was found early today by friends who initiated a search after their pickup truck was found on mountainside. Admitted to Memorial Hospital suffering from malnutrition and exposure were Robert Mongold, 29 years old, and his wife, Anita, 25, of Burlington, W. V.

title: Familiarity Breeds Victory for Pirates
description: Pittsburgh's return to its home field, Three Rivers Stadium, apparently was the tonic the Pirates needed after a trip in which they lost 12 of 14 games, including six in a row.

title: Bangkok Students Attack a Campus As Violence Grows
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 20 (UPI)  Technicalschool students, firing pistols and hurling fire bombs, used a stolen bus as a battering ram today to break through the gates of Thammasat University. They looted offices and stores do the neighborhood and set fire to the school's law building.

title: MEDICAID CHANGES SCORED IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20 (UPI)Drug companies, doctors and dentists, the poor and the elderly today attacked state plans to alter Medicaid services beginning Sept. 1.

title: Dream for Broadway in 76
description: The Dream, a psychological thriller by Leonard Spigelgass, is scheduled to be presented on Broadway early next year by Joel W. Schenker, the producer. The play, based on book of the same title by Lucy Freeman, will be directed by Joseph Hardy.

title: Showdown on Sinai
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 20No matter how strongly Premier Yitzhak Rabin's Government protests that Secretary of State Kissinger's arrival tomorrow does not mean that an interim agreemerrt with Egypt on Sinai is a foregone conclusion, official circles take it for granted that it is.

title: Improving Incarceration
description: In appointing Herman Schwartz, a law professor and a committed champion of prisoners rights, as chairman of the reconstituted State Commission of Correction, Governor Carey has signaled an awareness that what goes on within jails and prisons has a great deal to do with the quality of life outside the walls as well.

title: Same Time, Next Year In $1Million Film Deal
description: Morton Gottlieb, producer of Bernard Slade's Same Time, Next Year, said yesterday that the film rights to the play, now at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, had been sold to the Mirisch Corporation for $1million plus 10 per cent of the gross over $10million. He said this was the largest price ever paid for film rights to a play.

title: Windows Held for Ransom Are Received in Missouri
description: ST. tOUIS, Aug. 20Fifteen stained glass windows stolen from the Wainwright Building here on July 18 and held for $3,200 ransom were recovered Tuesday night near rural Farmington, about 90 miles south of here.

title: Emergency Called In San Francisco As Firemen Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20Following a night of robberies and scattered violence that included a bomb explosion outside the home of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto, officials today declared a state of emergency in San Francisco and asked the Mayor to summon at least 200 state highway patrolmen to replace striking city policemen.

title: Snow Knight First On Saratoga Turf
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP)A record weekday crowd of 24,608 saw Windfield Farm's Snow Knight, ridden by Jorge Velasquez win the 13th running of the $40,000added Seneca Handicap at Saratoga today. Snow Knight, who hadn't won since June of 1974 when he captured the Epsom Derby under English ownership, scored by 1 lengths over Archie Donaldson's topweighted Golden Don, ridden by Mike Hole.

title: Bakshi's Film Coonskin Is Earthy, Poignant
description: In cartoon profile, the black woman has the mournful elongation of an African mask. She sits in the infested Harlem tenement rocking her baby and talking to herself. She is young and her life is gone.

title: After 9Day Delay, Viking Is Launched on 10Month Trip to Mars
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 20 A Viking spacecraft set off on a 10month cruise to Mars today, beginning a mission to search for evidence of life.

title: State Says City Reneged on U.F.A. Pact
description: The State Public Employmen Relations Board found yesterday that the city had failed to execute an agreement it had made with the firefighters'l union and ordered the city to negotiate in good faith with the union.

title: Mark Donohue: Returns to Die
description: The doctors in Graz, Austria, said yesterday that the racing driver would have been crippled for life had he survived. And Mark Donohue couldn't live with retirement.

title: F.P.C. SETS STUDY ON COAL DEALINGS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. Aug, 20 (AP)  The Federal Power Commission is investigating the coal dealings of the American Electric Power Company, a (holding company that owns seven electric utility compavies, including the Kentucky, Power Company, based in Ashland, Ky.

title: BANGLADESH HEAD PLANS FOR TRIALS
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Aug. 201 (AP)The new President of Bangladesh has assumed the power to set up special tribunals for punishing offenders.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide yesterday incorrectly reported That the weekly guided tours of Brooklyn conducted by Singer's (8759084) leave on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. The correct days are Wednesday. Thursday and Saturday. The tours depart from Joralemon Street, between Court and Adams Streets, at 10:30 A.M.

title: Imports of Crude Oil Into U.S. Rise to 4.9 Million Barrels a Day
description: Crude oil imports into the United States rose sharply last week but otherwise basic petroleum industry statistics remained virtually unchanged.

title: Population Shifts Beset Jewish Community Here
description: The Jewish community in the West Bronx these days is frequently described at a disaster area. A number of synagogues have closed and others have only remnant congregations. In other parts of the city, howeverForest Hills, Queens, for examplesynagogues are thriving.

title: JOANNE SCHWARTZ
description: Dr. JoAnne Schwartz, visiting research investigator in audiology at Douglass College of Rutgers University and coordinator of the audiometric screening program of the Bureau for Handicapped Children of the city's Department of Health, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday in Englewood, N. J. She was 31 years old and lived at 1 Harbor Terrace, Edgewater, N. J.

title: Asks Meany and Exporters to Cool ItSays Sales to Russians Will Be Made
description: VAIL, Colo.. Aug. 20President Ford, urging all sides to cool it a bit, pledged here today that he would resolve the dispute threatening to disrupt massive shipments of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Madonna InnAn Architectural Fantasy in Southern California
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif. Beside Route 101 here, midway between Los Angeles and San Francisco, sits a building with what may be the only pink Rotary Club insignia the world. The building is the madonna Inn, Where not only the signs but also he lampposts, Cetral.cola machines and the leather banquettes in the dining room are the same bright shede of pink. The creamy'pinki which resembles PeptoBismol, is the theme color of the Madonna Inn, a 109roonr motel that is increasingly aPIIgrimage spot for lovers of Southern California architectural fantasy.

title: Legislature to Convene For Byrne's Address
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20 (AP)Legislative leaders annouced today they would call the Legislature into session Tuesday to hear a gubernatorial address on the state's economy and to move bondissuelegislation into position for a vote early next month.

title: AARON FURMAN
description: Aaron Furman, a certified public accountant, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Nixon's Lawyer Asks Definition of Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The transcript of former President Richard M. Nixon's questionandanswer session included this exchange between R. Stan Mortenson, one of Mr. Nixon's lawyers, and William A. Dobrovir, lawyer for Jack Anderson, the columnist:

title: City's Bicentennial Committee Hamstrung by the Fiscal Crisis
description: The people planning the Bicentennial celebration in New York City have been forced to accept payless paydays, lay off seven of their 26member staff, wangle a twomonth reprieve from their landlord and stack up unpaid bills since their city funds ran out on June 30.

title: PORTUGUESE CHIEF SAYS GOVERNMENT WILL FALL IN DAYS
description: LISBON, Aug. 20President Francisco da Costa Gomes, yielding to anti  Communist military and political forces, said today that the Government of Premier Vasco Gongs Ives had only a few days to live.

title: Personal Finance: Moving Costs
description: More than 12 million Americans hire moving companies every year when they change their residences. Some of them find the experience of dealing with a professional mover frustrating, more costly than expected and filled with unforeseen situations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editors: Your Aug. 12 editorial advocating that the Federal Government assume an additional 25 per cent of New York's A.F.D.C. and Medicaid costs is politically unrealistic. New York's share of the Federal Ikelfare dollar already exceeds its share of the nation's poor by quite a bit. The discrepancy in the case of Medicaid is even greater: With less than 8 per cent of the country's lowincome population, the state absorbs 20 per cent of Federal Medicaid outlays.

title: Viking Off for, Mats
description: After nine days of delays, the Viking spacecraft was successfully launched yesterday on its 10month trip to the planet Mars. Page 31.

title: U.S. Wins a U.N. Victory on Puerto Rico
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20  A United Nations committee, under strong pressure from the United States, voted today to put off indefinitely its consideration of a resolution affirming the inalienable right of the people of Puerto Rico to selfdetermination and independence.

title: Track Coach Resigns
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP)Robert Epskamp, Ohio State University's varsity track coach the last 10 years, resigned today to become director of athletics at Jackson, Mich., Community College.

title: Masters First Obstacle For Connors in Open
description: With nonchalance and great rapidity a panel of United Nations officials and Bill Talbert, the tournament chairman, and other notables drew the names out of a silver bowl. But the path to the finals of the United States Open tennis championships next week will not be quite so easy for the seeded players who were dispersed through the tournament draw yesterday.

title: Bangkok Is Calm After Wide Rioting And Student Attack
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 21 (Reuters)Bangkok was calm today after a day of violence by students and dissident policemen that reflected growing pressures on Thailarid's weak democratic system.

title: F.D.A. Recalls Bandages Found to Be Not Sterile
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) White Cross brand bandages made before last Jan. 30 are being pulled off store sheIVes because they are not sterile, the Food and Drug Administration said today. The Government said the recall included adhesive strips, absorbent cotton, cotton balls, cotton swabs, gauze bandage surgical gauze, gauze pads and firstaid kits made by the. American White Cross Laboratories, Inc., of New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: TV: A Season Sample, Big Eddie
description: The programing game of the moment is called sampling The goal is to have the new television product seen by large audiences as quickly as possible. When the new Season opens officially in a couple of weelc, the primetime weekly Schedule will be jammed with 70 shovis, more than a thitd of them new. So, some are being releasect early, on the theory that a good many viewers, suffering from rerun bloat, might be more tolerant Of unknown ties.

title: CORRECTION
description: As a result of a transmission error, a Hong Kong dispatch in The New York Times Wednesday said that the meeting Tuesday between Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Deputy Premier Khieu Samphan of Cambodia was their first. It should have said that the meeting was their first since the end of the war in Cambodia.

title: BLAME REJECTS CAREY'S FIGURES
description: Mayor Beame and city budget officials rejected yesterday Governor Carey's estimate that immediate application of accounting reforms would mean an $800million deficit in this year's budget and $2billion in a cumulative deficit from previous years.

title: Welfare Era Dawns In the Alaskan Bush
description: KWIGILLINGOK. AlaskaAs the fourseated, redandwhite float plane swooped low to land on the narrow stream that skirts this village of 230 people on the The Talk of the Alaskancoast of the Bering Sea, a score of Eskimos, most of them children, Bush gathered on the steep, muddy banks to watch.

title: Familiar Refrain
description: Yet the Administration and the Federal Reserve doggedly try to check the costinflation, for which their own policies and absence of policies are largely responsible, by trying to rein in demand even more tightly, as though they were fighting a runaway boom. In consequence, interest rates have climbed and the stock market, which had risen smartly from early this year until July, has gone into a nosedive. The financial distressand climbing costs of capitalhave been intensified by fears that New York City might default on its obligations.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Abrams Leads New Reform Party Fight
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx, who had blurred his image as a fighttothedeath foe of the regular Democratic organization by running with regular support for Attorney General, has been talked into a new antiorganization fight by his oldtime friends in the party's reform faction.

title: Record G.M. Outlay
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to spend a record $15billion through 1979, mainly to develop and make smaller cars. Page 43.

title: Events Today
description: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL, Avery Fisher Hall, PreCOnCETI recital, 7; regular concert, 8.

title: CORRECTION
description: As a result of a transmission error, a Hong Kong dispatch in The New York Times Wednesday said that the meeting Tuesday between Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Deputy Premier Khieu Samphan of Cambodia was their first. It should have said that the meeting was their first since the end of the war in Cambodia.

title: OTB Renews Bid for Garden
description: There were strong indications yesterday that efforts of the Offtrack Betting Corporation to buy Madison Square Garden were very much alive again, in spite of earlier signs that the proposal had been abandoned.

title: Kansan to Head Company
description: Kansan to Head Company

title: Homosexuality and the Family
description: It is no accident that the increasing acceptance of homosexuality parallels increasing attacks on the family. The pitch of anger between the sexes and the number of people who regard the families in which they grew up, or the families they have formed, as arenas of frustration and unhappiness have made it difficult for people who are not homosexual to insist that heterosexuality and the family are intrinsically better than anything else.

title: Sound of Charlie Parker Still Echoes in Jazz World
description: Charlie Parker would have been 55 years old next Friday.

title: Year's OverAll Climb in Prices Now Expected to Be 9 Per Cent
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that the increase in food prices in 1975 would total 9 per cent, with 1.5 per cent attributable to the sale of 9.8 million tons of grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Music Season to Open With Salome
description: Every music season is a thrilling vista of endless peaks, in prospect. Only later, when actuality intrudes, do a few valleys of disappointment and sloughs of despond begin to develop. So, as the 1P7576 season comes into view with the New York City Opera's Salome on Wednesday night, with Maralin Niska as the headhunting temptress, it is time again to chart the probable high points. What follows is a selective, anything but encyclopedic preview.

title: WALKOUT BY MINERS JOINEDIN 2 STATES
description: CHARLESTON, W Va., Aug. 21 (AP)A wildcat coal mine strike spread into eastern Kentucky today from southern West Virginia, where it has idled some 30,000 miners. A small group of Ohio miners also walked out in apparent sympathy.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MINI IBERTA Tourists who can't make it to, Spain this summer will find a snug, atmospheric reminder in the setting andentertainment of the Flamenco Suite, just off the downstairs entrance corridor of the thateau Madrid, Lexington Avenue and 48th Street. It is often by passed by patrons heading for the revue in the big room. The smaller room, with its dimly lit red and black colors, wall shawls and deep'divans, is a yearround minishowcase for Spanish music and dance.

title: FRAGMENTS STUDIED IN A BOWDEN DANCE
description: Sally Bowden took a slight idea and made an even slighter piece of it on Wednesday evening at the Construction Company Studio. The two contrasting sections of her untitled work showed elements and fragments of dance movement and then in the second part they were combined into a waltz.

title: Market Place
description: Investing in the municipal bond market, it has become obvious this year, can no longer be taken for granted. With greater frequency, bondholders are discovering they can be faced with problems.

title: Swim Mark Broken By Bruce Furniss
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 21 (AP)Bruce Furniss of Long Beach, Calif., broke his world record in the men's 200meter freestyle tonight in a stirring battle with Tim Shaw. also of Long Beach.

title: Notes on People
description: It was a short odyssey, and a surprising one, for Robert Sparks, 39 years old, Pottersville, N.J., who wanted to make the first solo balloon flight across the Atlantic and lifted off from the New Seabury Country Club on Cape Cod at 1:05 A.M. yesterday. But he soon nag company. His crew chief, G. Hadden Wood, 44, of Greenwich, Conn., intentionally hung on to a trailing nylon rope when the balloon lifted off andpassing over the heads of 3,000 startled spectatorsbegan he journey dangling 12 feet below the gondola. An hour later, Mr. Sparks hauled his crew chief aboard with a winch.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Department of Commerce reported today that Departmentstore sales last week were an estimated $1.12billion, up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $1.03billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.49billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $10.86billion.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY DECLINED IN WEEK
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the nation's money supply had declined in the latest statement week after recording sharp increase during the preceding week.

title: Museum Will Auction Some Bits of Its Past
description: K MORRISTOWN, Aug. 21Hundreds of items ranging from old music boxes to Thomas Edison phonographs will be put on auction. Saturday as the Yesteryear Mu.

title: Mrs. Probert Keeps Shot Lead in Golf
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 21  Mrs. Edward Probert, putting consistently. well, shot a five overpar 7 today for 155 and a onestroke. advantage in the second round of the 52d Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54hole championship at the Someset Hills Country Club. The leaders:

title: 3 HELD IN SLAYING OF TOURIST HERE
description: Three young men were taken into custody by the police yesterday for questioning in the fatal stabbing of a 22yearold tourist from Virginia early Wednesday in a street robbery on the Upper West Side.

title: U.S. ELECTION PANEL CLARIFIES VOTE LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) The Federal Election Commission ruled today that tale $1,000 Federal political contribution limit applies to business partnerships as well as to individuals.

title: Sound of Charlie Parker Still Echoes in Jazz World
description: Charlie Parker would have been 55 years old next Friday.

title: People in Sports
description: Tony Conigliaro, who hit 32 home runs for the Boston Red Sox in 1965 and 36 in 1969, has retired from basebalL The slugging outfielder was hit in his left eye by a pitched ball in 1967 and nearly blinded. He sat out the 1968 season returned to the Red Sox in 1969 and was named he comeback player of the year. Following the 1970 season, when he had 36 homers and 116 runs batted in, he was traded to the California Angels and played 74 games in 1971 before the eye injury forced him to quit the team.

title: Stocks Shrug off Consumer Price Rise
description: After a twoday price skid, the stock market turned mixed yesterday, taking in stride the July upturn in the Consumer Price Index but still burdened by uncertainties on the economic front.

title: Alioto Imposes Pact In Face of Dissent; Calls Strike Over
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21Mayor Joseph L. Alioto invoked his emergency powers today to impose a compromise wage settlement for this city's striking police and firemen after the Board of Supervisors had rejected it by a vote of 9 to 0.

title: Gunmen in Northern Ireland Kill Catholic and Protestant
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Aug. 21 (UPI)Two men, one Roman Catholic and the other Protestant were shot and killed today in sectarian murders.

title: Ashland Chief Cites Moral Shift in U.S.
description: ASHLAND, KY., Aug. 21A shift in the nation's moral attitude since the Watergate scandal has made corporate political contributions unacceptable as well as illegal, Orin E. Atkins, chairman and chief executive officer of Ashland Oil, Inc., said here today.

title: U.S. Negotiators in Madrid Make No Headway on Bases
description: MADRID, Aug. 21 (Reuters) American and Spanish negotiators today ended their latest round of talks on United States bases in Spain without reporting any significant breakthrough. They agreed to meet again in Washington next month.

title: Carey Will Press Mayor For More City Economies
description: Governor Carey has decided to prod publicly for more economies by Mayor Beameand risk a potential partysplitting confrontationafter meetings with leading bankers and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, top Carey advisers said yesterday.

title: Geiberger Cards 66 For Lead
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 21When a dog chases a rabbit in this kind of Texas heat, they both walk. And a. golfer chasing birdies today in temperatures above 100 degrees had to move even slower to complete and survive the opening round of the Tournament Players Championship.

title: DR. MAURICE S. BARSHAD
description: Dr. Maurice S. Barshad, dentist with offices at 30 Central Park South who had practiced here for many years, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack; in White Plains Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 530 Park Avenue.

title: G. M. Spending $15Billion In 6 Years for Small Autos
description: DETROIT, Aug. 21The General Motors Corporation will spend $15  billion through the end of the decade, with most of the record amount going for its program to develop and produce new smaller cars, according to Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the company.

title: $100Billion Body to Aid Energy Is Urged on Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Ford Administration considering a bill to create a quasipublic corporation that would channel up to $100billion of loans and other kinds of financing to projects aimed at making the United States independent of foreign sources of energy.

title: Rahway Prison Artists in a 3Day Exhibit in Newark
description: NEWARK, August 21An electric group of 50 paintings done by artists at Rahway State Prison went on view here today at Hallmark House, 10 Hill Street, across from City Hall.

title: Prof. Robert C. Whitford, 83, Of Pratt and L.I.U. Is Dead
description: Dr. Robert C. Whitford, formerly dean of the division of general studies at Pratt Institute, director of students at Long Island University and professor of English at both schools, died Wednesday in Utica, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Brookfield. N.Y.

title: Resistance Groups in Cambodia Fight Red Rule, Reid gees Say
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 21 (AP)Refugees recently arrived from Cambodia say that several armed resistance groups are continuing to fight against the new Communist Government in at least four parts of the country.

description: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 21 (UPI) C. Darrow Tully, 43 years old, has resigned as president and general manager of The Wichita Eagle and Beacon to become president and general manager of the San Francisco Newspaper Printing Company, Inc.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)operations to secure access to Middle Eastern oilfields. in case of another embargo would be unlikely to, succeed and would cause grave consequences if they failed, Representative Lee H. Hamilton Democrat of Indiana, said today.

title: A Revolution
description: LONDON In times of remarkable change, it is easier to see individuals as exemplars of tendencies, developments. An example: Idries Shah. He was not fifty when he was given a Festschrift. Usually, people have to be seventy, and the contributors are scholars in a limiced field. Because this is such an unusual Festschrift, I nronose to use it to make three points.

title: Culinary Landmark Closes
description: For one dizzy moment at the Bazar Francais yesterday Laura and Frank Pignatellf, a couple of young schoolteachers almost boeght 22 quiche dishes for a bid of Howard Mandel, a post office worker; nearly had anew meat slicer for his Brooklyn food coop plus a bean slicer, a dumpling maker and an armload of cutting boards for $30 bid.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21New orders for durable goods rose strongly in July in a further indication of recovery in the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The idea of seasons, once firmly established by calendar, has broken down in sports. It use to be selfevident that the football season followed the baseball season, that basketball and hockey filled the winter months until baseball could start again, and that golf and tennis were as appropriate to, summer as skiing to snow.

title: Defense in Greek Treason Trial Asks for Leniency
description: ATHENS, Aug. 21The principle defense counsel asked for leniency today as arguments ended in the trial of 20 former Greek officers accused of high treason and insurrection for plotting the 1967 coup.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)There is no available evidence that the milk, meat. Bread and beer induitries gaged in profiteering over the lest three years despite skyrocketing consumer prices, a Federal Trade COmmissiorf study said today prices wenttip primarily because costs rose the study said.

title: World Vegetarians et to Talkand Eat
description: ORONO, Me, Aug. 21 Some are reedslim, the way vegetarians are always thought to be; others are quite obese. Some have healthy, glowing complexions; others have acne. They are young and old, rich and poor, longhaired and shorthaired. Many are..passive by nature, but some are pushy and aggressive especially when they have to wait in the long cafeteria lines for some of the most exotic vegelarian foods they have ever encountered

title: Dr. Albert H. Marckwardt Dies; Taught English and Linguistics
description: Dr. Albert H. Marckwardt, educator and an authority on the history and structure of the; English language, died Wednesday on a visit to London. He was 71 years Old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md., and formerly in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Race Week Struck by High Winds
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 21One Shields was dismasted and a number of Lasers and Sunfish capsized as tardy southwesterly winds, up to 16 knots, delayed the second round of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 43d annual race week today.

title: FILIPINO REBELS PLEDGE LOYALTY
description: MANILA, Aug. 21Six commanders of the leading insurgent group in Moslem Mindanao arrived here today and pledged allegiance to President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

description: CHICAGO, Aug: 21 (UPI) The American Hospital Association says that hospital costs increased 17:5 per cent in the United States in the first half of this year, the highest rate of increase in 15 years.

description: PRAGUE, Aug. 21 (Reuters) Czechoslovakia charged tonight that the West German security police and armed forces had been behind an American helicopter pilot's clandestine flights to meet East Germans in Czeghoslovakia and fly them to West Germany.

description: OXFORD, Miss., Aug. 21 (UPI)The University of Mississippi will become a legal worldwide supplier of standard grade marijuana, a university spokesman said today.

description: DURHAM, N. C., Aug. 21 (AP)Duke University named Bill Barton, a former Indiana University star swimmer, as its swimming coach and director of aquatics today. Barton succeeds Jack, Parsons, who retired.

description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose slightly to 207.8 from 207.7 last week.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States yesterday lifted its 12yearold bah oh exports to Cuba by.foreign subsidiaries of American companies, but, State Department spokesmansaid, the embargo on direct trade between Cuba andthe United States remained force. A high State Department official appeared to go out of his way to avoid characterizing the action as a conciliatory gesture toward Cuba or as a *prelude to other steps. It was, he explained, related. to the recent removal of trade sanctions against Cuba by the Organization of America States. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: DEAL BY SWEDLOW TO PRODUCE CASH
description: Swedlow, Inc., of Garden Grove, Calif., a manufacturer of plastic sheets, said yesterday that it would distribute to shareholders about $7.8million in cash as a result of the forthcoming sale of its acrylic sheet division to Montedison, S.A., of Milan, Italy, for $25million. Swedlow announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell the division for a cash payment of about $14million, with Montedison assuming approximately $11million of Swedlow's liabilities. An agreement in principle on the deal was announced on May 30.

title: STAR OWNERS REJECT ALLBRITTON'S OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)  Directors representing three families that have long controlled the Washington Star rejected today an offer by Joe L. Allbritton to buy their stock in the parent Star Communications Company, Inc., and advised fellow stockholders to do the same.

description: LISBON, Aug. 21Premier Vasco Goncalves was expected today to leave office by Monday in accordance with a deadline believed to have been set by officers representing most of the Portuguese armed forces.

title: Taming of the Arkansas Leaves Valley Thriving
description: DARDANELLE, Ark.The Corps of Engineers used to cause a good bit of merriment around here by contending that the Arkansas River would some day run blue.

title: Los Angeles Offers $1.7Million to Get Democrats in 1976
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (UPI) The City Council approved today a $1.7million bargaining, agreement designed to lure the Democratic party to Los Angeles for its Presidential nominating convention next year.

title: Nastase Defeats Dibley
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 21Ilie Nastase is labeled as a master on the clay court and the Rumanian star proved that today to the dismay of Colin Dibley in the secondround of the $50,000 Tennis Week open tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: JONES AND LAUGHLIff TO INCREASE PRICES
description: The Jones and Laughlin Steel corporation, Pittsburgh, became yesterday the last of the major steel companies to announce plans to raise prices. Thomas C. Graham, president of the unit of the LTV Corporation, said Jonei & Laughlin would raise prices to the levels of its competitors on sheet and bar products on Oct. 1 and on pipe and tubing products, Sept. 1.

title: Consumers Found to View Food Cost With a Growing Fury and Frustration
description: Marianne Osborne, the wife of a New Orleans lawyer, is outraged by a $1.99apound price tag on pork chops. Nancy Drew, a Manhattan actress, is appalled at $3 honeydew melons. Mrs. George White, a Los Angeles housewife, is stunned by bacon at $1.99 a pound.

description: Governor Carey has offered Mayor Beame what may be a last chance to escape from the sense of drift at City Hall that is carrying New York toward the disaster default.

title: Italy Granted I.M.F. Loan
description: ROME, Aug. 21 (Reuters)The Italian Treasury confirmed today that the International Monetary Fund had approved Italy's request for a loan of about $840million from the fund's oil facility. A statement said the decision was taken at a meeting today of the I.M.F.'s Administrative Council.

title: Pacific Science Parley Assailed For Curbing Rebuttal of Theory
description: VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 21 In vehement response to lecture by Dr. Thor Heyerdahl, the adventurer and anthropologist, anthropologists attending the Pacific Science Congress here have protested that the good name of science was prostituted because the congress denied them an opportunity to answer Dr. Heyerdahl.

title: Miss Heldman Out In Harrison Upset
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 21 The girl with nothing to lose lost nothing today. Surprising nearly everyone, including herself, Iris Reidel Of Berlin eliminated fifthseeded Julie Heldman, 6.3, 63, to gain the quarterfinals of the $75,000 MediQuik tennis tournament at the Westchester Country Club.

title: CATHOLICS CRITICIZE BILL TO CURB ALIENS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 21 (UPI) A Spokesman for the Nation's Roman Catholic Bishops urged President Ford and Congress today to reject proposed legiklation dealing with illegal aliens as unjust and discriminatory.

title: On Sleep: The Long and the Short of
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.One of the most pervasive and mischievous myths about sleep is that everyone needs eight hours of it per night. As it happens, study after study shows that the average amount of sleep that people get turns out to be seven and onehalf to eight hours. Unfortunately, it seems to be human nature to turn an average into a norm or a target to achieve. But just as there are tall and short people or people with big and little feet, there are short and long sleepers.

title: Deaths
description: KRAMERHarriet. Young Israel of the West Sine mourns the passing of Mrs. Harriet Kramer, beloved sister and sisterinlaw of our esteemed members Evelyn and Nat Lebowitz. May the Comforter of Zion console the entire family. EMANUEL GETTINGER, Rabbi HENRY I. ROTHMAN, President

title: Calendar of Highlights
description: Following is a calendar of the 197576 season's major musical events:

title: The Elephant, King of Beasts
description: In all Africa there is no more vivid sight, no more electrifying experience for most visitors than that of elephants: Not the plodding performers you see in the circus or the popcorn stuffed inmates of the zoo. With few exceptions these are domesticated Indian elephants  the tamer, smaller and differently shaped cousins of the magnificent African elephant, the largest land animal alive and, it is now apparent, one of the most socially advanced mammals on earth.

title: Governor Appoints A 13Member Panel On the Bicentennial
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 21Governor Carey today announced the formation of a 13member Bicentennial coordinating council to aid in the planning of the state's Bicentennial celebrations.

title: Phones on Metroliners To Be Dropped Oct. 31
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21telephone booths on the Metroliners will soon wear out of order signs; the government has decided that it cannot spare the radio frequency.

title: 10 Die in French Chain Crash
description: BOURGES, France, Aug. 21 (AP) A chain collision and fire killed 10 persons today and injured 26 near here, the police reported.

title: DOMINIC J. MASUCCI,
description: Dominic J. Masucci, director of safety for the New York City Transit Authority, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 50 years old and lived at 1116 85th Street, Brooklyn.

title: MEDIATOR's REPORT GAINING IN CANADA
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 21More than 130 companies accepted today $250million package of mediator's recommendations for restoring peace to the British Columbia forest industry and ending a strike by 13,000 pulp and paper workers. But the two striking unions showed no sign of calling off the fiveweek walkout.

description: For 10 minutes last night after the Yankees had lost again to Chicagothis time by 21Manager Billy Martin ranted and raved, about how two umpires decisions had cost them the game.

description: The Reuschel brothers, Rick and Paul, combined for a sixhit shutout yesterday, pitching, the Chicago Cubs to a 70 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Wrigley Field.

title: WALTER L. BROWN
description: Walter L. Brown, who retired in 1964 as a vice president and general counsel of the Western Electric Company, died Sunday in New Canaan, Conn. He was 72 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Met Museum Aided, to Reopen Tuesdays
description: Two foundations have given the Metropolitan Museum of Art $300,000, enabling the museum to reopen for six days a week beginning next Tuesday.

title: U.S. Will Relieve Envoy To Saudis in Big Shuffle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21James E. Akins, who has been Ambassador to Saudi Arabia for the last two years, is losing his post there as part of a high  level State Department personnel shuffle.

title: Byrne Calls for Orderly Way To Seek Oil and Gas Offshore
description: TRENTON, Aug. 21Governor Byrne said today that the United States Department of the Interior was still operationg on the wrong theory as it moved ahead with plans to lease offshore areas for exploration for oil and eas.

description: GOLMANA monument to the memory of Bette Golman will be unowned Sunday, Aug. 24, 2 P.M., at the U.S. National Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off 8%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads, during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.1 billion tonmiles, 8.3 percent below the Corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 456,591 cars, 10.5 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truek tonnage was 12.3 per cent below last year.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 12% IN JULY, A RECORD FOR 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Consumer prices rose in July by the largest amount for any month this year, marking the second. consecutive month of substantial increases, the Labor Department reported today.

title: VOLKSWAGEN PLANS INCREASED OUTPUT
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Aug. 21 (AP)Volkswagenwerk, A.G. plans to increase production temporarily in two of its domestic plants at the end of August to reduce a backlog of orders attributed to a staff layoff, the giant West German auto maker said today.

title: Earthquake Hits Alaska
description: PALMER, Alaska, Aug. 21 (1231)A moderate, earthquake rocked the Kenai Peninsula of Alaska this afternoon, shaking residents from Homer to An chorage. No damage was re ported.

title: Guerrillas Renew Attacks
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, Aug. 21 (UPI)A carload of gunmen attacked a police station today and sporadic sniper fire was reported in other parts of this major industrial city. No injuries were reported.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Tod frequently the question comes up in an awkward Circumstance:.. The, young mother is standing at thesupermarkee checkout counter pondering nothing more than the inflationary spiral when, her 4yearold pops the big one; do. Ixtbies come from Mommy? And even the cash register seems to go still, waiting to see how. she handles it.

title: CHILDCARE UNITS SCORED BY BIAGGI
description: Representative Mario Biaggi charged yesterday that a number of childcare agencies had amassed more than $500million in profits from Federal, state and city funds by keeping homeless children off the adoption market and making little effort to rehabilitate natural parents.

title: Looking Into Corporate Power
description: In February, 1912, the House of Representatives authorized a subcommittee of its Committee on Banking and Currency to inquire into the concentration of financial resources and power in the United States.

title: JOB LOSS FEARED FROM A U.S. BILL
description: New York, New Jersey ana Connecticut could over the next five years lose as many as 20,000 jobs and up to $494million in Federal aid for the construction of sewagetreatment plants if Congress passes a pending bill, according to Representative Bellas S. Abzug.

title: IRATE BEAME BARS ANY FURTHER CUTS IN VITAL SERVICES
description: Mayor Beame asserted angrily yesterday that he would make no further budget cuts in police, fire, sanitation and other vital lifesupport services in the city.

title: Local Anglers Find Fish Plentiful and Catchable
description: AREA ATrolling charter boats have been taking tuna in the 75to85pound range at the Klondike and about seven miles off Manasquan Inlet with cedar plugs and feathers. Fluke and weakfish are being found in quantity between Sea Girt and Lavalette. Most are from 3 to 5 pounds. Surf casters have been having success with bluefish at Seaside with bait and, on occasion, jigs, the lure. Bluefish are being taken in number at Barnegat Ridge by boats fishing at night as well as by day. In Barnegat Bay, fluke up to 5 pounds have been in evidence.

title: 3d Suspect in Coast Plot
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (UPI) The District Attorney's office announced the arrest today of la third suspect in the plot to swindle the city treasury out of millions of dollars through the theft of blank municipal computer checks. The suspect, Joyce Lewis, 45 years old, is already facing a major trial in Boston in a multimillion dollar bogus. money case involving; several. New England Mafia figures.

title: Court Tells Oneida County To Appropriate Relief Aid
description: A State Supreme Court Justice directed Oneida County officials yesterday to issue food vouchers and emergency aid checks to welfare recipients and needy applicants.

title: Talent Bank Set Up To Aid Job Search For Those Laid Off
description: A computer system to help laidoff city workers find jobs in both the private and government sectors has been set up In the city's Personnel Department, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Wheat Technique May Be Boon to Turks
description: AKYURT, TurkeyThe farmers stood in the field of golden grain, breaking off heads of wheat, rolling them between their palms, blowing off the chaff. In the cups of their calloused hands they counted the hard, brown durum grains that remained.

title: About Real Estate

description: Born in Kansas City, Kan., In 1920, Charlie Parker grew up in Kansas City, Mo., a lively jazz center in the twenties and thirties. He started playing alto saxophone at the age of 11, inspired, he once said, by Rudy Vallee.

title: Lebanon Says Israeli Raid Killed 12 and Injured 28
description: BEIRUT, Aug. 21, (Reuters)Twelve people were killed and 28 wounded last night when Israeli planes attacked a remote Lebanese valley, a Lebanese miliary spokesman said today.

title: Stress Found in Contacts Of Healthy and Disabled
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 21When nonhandicapped persons meet someone who is disabled, their palms sweat and their hearts beat faster, according to it Dartmouth psychologist. Moreover, they try so hard to like the disabled person that they later say they very much enjoyed the encountereven though their nonverbal behavior reflects the opposite.

title: Men's Prison Gets A Woman Warden In State ShakeUp
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Aug. 21As a result of a recent shakeup of state prison administrators, a woman has been named to head a men's prison for the first time in the history of the New York Department of Correctional Services.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two suspected underworld figures have applied to the tate Commission of Investigation for release from jail, citing the same reasons as Gerardo Catena,.a reputed New porkNew Jersey mob chieftan released Tuesday by court drder. Frank L. Holstein,'the S.C.I. executive director, said tliat John Lardiere of Newark, who has been in jail four years, had applied for release, and that a hearing on the request was scheduled for Sept. 12. He also confirmed that Robert Manna, of Jersey City, had earlier requested release *rid that the applications would be heard on Sept. 10. The two alleged organized, crime figures were jailed after being found in civil contempt for refusing to answer questions before the commission. Mr. Catena was released on the round that his continued confinement was unconstituiiitaal.

Another former champion, Mikhair Tal of the Soviet Union, lost to the West German grandmaster Wolfgang Unzicker. Ljubonir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia defeated grandmaster Ulf Andersson.

title: Reminders From Prague
description: As historians from around the world gather today San Francisco for the International Congress of Historical Sciences, they will be given stark reminders of the barriers to free scholarship erected by totalitarian governments but also of the indomitability of the human spirit in confronting tyranny. Neither lesson is new; but their forceful presentation may have special pertinence in a time of official EastWest detente.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

The suspects were identified as Edward Harth, 32 years old, of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Barbara Doyle, 25, of Franklin Square, L.I. Mr. Harth, according to the police, was being sought by Florida authorities for escape from a Tallahassee prison, in which he had been serving a sevenyear term for burglary.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States yesterday lifted its 12yearold ban on exports to Cuba by foreign subsidiaries of American companies, but, State Department spokesman said, the embargo on direct trade between Cuba and the United States remained in force. A high State Department official appeared to go out of his way to avoid characterizing the action as a conciliatory gesture toward. Cuba or as a prelude to other steps. It was, he explained, related to the recent removal of trade sanctions against Cuba by the Organization of America States. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: Unemployment in Britain Climbs to 5.4% in Month
description: LONDON, Aug 21Unemployment. a bitter backlash of Prime Minister Wilson's effort to ??? Britain's virulent inflation, has increased by 15 per cent in a single month and now stands at 5.4 per cent of the work force, tho highest in three decades.

title: U.S. and Soviet Offer to Outlaw Military Weather Manipulation
description: GENEVA, Aug. 21The United States and the Soviet Union today submitted to the disarmament conference here their proposal for a pact to outlaw attempts to manipulate thel weather or otherwise modify the environment for military orl, other hostile purposes.

title: Tiants Reunited After 15 Years
description: BOSTON, Aug. 21 (UPI}The Boston Red Sox pitcher, Luis Tiant, was reunited with his parents at Logan International Airport tonight for the first time in 15 years. Tiant, accompanied by his wife and three children, embraced his parents, who live in Cuba, as they debarked from their flight from Chicago and spoke briefly with them in Spanish. He also wept a little. The reunion was made possible in a meeting earlier this year between Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota and Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba. Tiant last saw his mother, Isabel, in 1968 in Mexico City. He had not seen his father, Luis, for 15 years. Neither of his parents have seen him play in the major leagues, although he has been pitching since 1964. Tiant's father had never seen his son's wife or his three grandchildren, whose ages are 12, 7 and 1.
