description: Jolynn Powell Kujawski, daughter of Col. Joseph Stephen Kujawski, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Kujawski of Atlanta, and Brigantine. N.J., was married yesterday morning to Donald Edward McFadyen of Windsor, Conn. The Rev. James L. Shannon performed the ceremony in Christ Church Episcopal in Philadelphia.

title: DEATHS OF SALMON IN RIVER STUDIED
description: BOYNE CITY, Mich., Aug. 23 An international expert on effects of pollution in the Great Lakes on fish endocrinology hits joined three Michigan state fish biologists on the banks of the Boyne River near here to begin new research into the cause of the mysterious mortality of Atlantic salmon planted in the river during the last four years.

title: APPLE FARMERS SHORT OF PICKERS
description: ACCORD, N.Y.  The stream of migrant workers from the South coming north to pick the apple crop of New York State seems to be drying up, according to some farmlabor specialists in Ulster County.

title: Muilims Here Open Campaign to Clean Own Neighborhoods
description: Members of Muhammad's Temple of Islam No. 7A in Washington Heights pushed brooms along the sidewalks of the nearby streets yesterday to prepare for a rally and street fair announcing the start of a cleancommunity campaign. The activities were attended by 100 people, including women draped in colorful, caftans and headdresses.

title: Island Wages Go Up 18 Per Cent Over 2 Years but Do Not Keep Pace With Prices
description: Wages on Long Island went up an average of 18 per cent over the last two years, according to a survey by the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry.

title: Prohibition Is Ended In New Mexico Town
description: PORTALES, N. M., Aug. 23 For the first time in 58 years, the citizens of this otonservative eastern New Mexico municipality can legally buy an altohnlic drink within city limits. The Plains Hotel, the first of five approved liquor outlets to open, started serving customers this week in a makeshift lounge as Pohibition came to an end in Portales, a city with a population of 11.500.

title: Portugal Tennis Victor
description: LUXEMBOURG, Aug. 23 (UPI)Portugal clinched a victory over Luxembourg in the first round of the 1976 Davis Cup tennis competition today by taking the doubles for an unbeatable 30 lead.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The classic French qualities of clarity, proportion and elegance, not to mention an infallible instinct for le mot juste, are nowhere more apparent than in that country's vast musical literature for the keyboard. True, the piano was temporarily neglected during the heyday of the Paris Opera in the early 19th century, when French music was in the grip of the operatic spectaculars of Meyerbeer. But the refined spirit that motivated Rameau.

title: The Relationship With Salazar Was Satisfactory
description: LISBONIn the extraordinarily wide range of forces that have arrayed themselves against Premier Vasco Gongalves, one of Portugal's oldest institutions, the Roman Catholic church, has assumed a formidable role.

title: Investigator Says Search for Hoff a Getting Nowhere
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23  The search for James R. Hoffa is getting nowhere, one of the men investigating his disappearance said today. Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other investigators are just plowing old ground, he said.

title: Outdoor Events Today
description: Chinese Bicentennial Observance of 200 Years of American Independence 9:30 A.M., minimarathon, Community Center, Mott Street; 11 A.M., opening ceremonies, with costumed Lion Troupe, 62 Mott Street; 12 noon, outdoor art exhibit, Columbus Park; 3 P.M., Summer Cultural Festival, Columbus Park; 6:00 P.M. Chinese Cooking Demonstration, lower Mott Street.

title: JEWISH HOMES AID AIMLESS YOUTHS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 22They drift in regularly, as many as 20 a day. Some are well dressed; some in tatters. They are angry and moody, frightened and p erplexedpeople trying to find themselves.

title: A Classy New TV Series About the Classless Society
description: Tomorrow evening at o'clock CBS premieres a television series about classa subject that ??? many Americans so uncomfortable they pretend it doesn't exist, rather like the Victorians denial of sex. Not surprisingly, commercial television executives in the United States weren't interested in such a darkling topic until the runaway success on public television here of the servants and masters in the British Upstairs, Downstairs (continuing on PBS next Jan. 4 with 13 new episodes).

title: A FREEZE ON TAXES OFFERED BY BEANIE IN FISCAL PACKAGE
description: Mayor Beame said last night that the key element in a package of fiscal proposals he is submitting to restore investor confidence in the city would be a guarantee of no new taxes, or tax increases, in the next three years.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel both said last night after another round of talks that the latest exchanges between Egypt and Israel had moved the two sides nearer conclusion of a new Sinai agreement. It appeared to newsmen that both men were clearly satisfied with the way the final stage of the negotiations was going. We are contining to make progress, Mr. Kissinger said. Difficulties continue to be removed. And we have encountered no unexpected difficulties. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Put a Gurgle In Your Garden
description: Rare, indeed, is the landscape that cannot be improved by adding water. The satisfying appeal of crystalclear water cooling the air or merely reflecting the surroundings in its mirror is welcomed. If this useful commodity is lacking, plan for a unique garden feature that combines sound, movement, reflection and sculpture all in one. From birdbath to pond, water is a relatively lowmaintenance addition worth investigating.

title: Lombardy and Benko Tie For First in Chess Open
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 23 (AP) William Lombardy of Ridgefield, N. J., and Pal Benko of Jersey City, ended up in a tie for first place in the United States Onen chess tournament.

title: GUERRILLA CHIEFS CONFER IN MANILA
description: MANILA, Aug. 23A field marshal and a political commissar of the Moro National Liberation Front, which has been fighting the army in the jungles of southern Mindanao, say that they have come to Manila to test the sincerity of the Government, which last week announced a ceasefire in the guerrilla war.

title: Kenneth Hersey Colburn Weds Alice E. ??? in Fairfield
description: Alice Emily Armitage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Armitage of Fairfield, Conn., and Kenneth Hersey Colburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Colburn of Wakefield, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Michael Thornburg, assistant minister, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: This summer, Rudolf Nureyev, Dame Margot Fonteyn, Karen Kain and Paolo Bortoluzzi performed Jose Limon's 1949 moderndance classic The Moor's Pavane at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C. At a crucipl moment in this highly stylized retelling of Othellojust before Kain's Emilia was to give Desdemona's handkerchief to Bortoluzzi's lagoBortoluzzi did a pirouette and inserted a series of jumped ballet steps, known as assembles, that are not in the original choreography. No, it was not the end of the world. But it was very much like kicking a football on a baseball diamond.

title: Laser Class Race Off
description: OYSTER BAY, LI., Aug. 22 The Atlantic Coast Laser Class championship race, scheduled at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, was postponed today because of a calm. Three races are planned tomorrow on Long Island Sound.

title: Less interested in promoting woman's rights than humankind's
description: George Sand is a literary paradox: she is far more read about than read. In her own lifetime, she was not only a legendary personality, buL revered as agreat artist by figures as various as Heine and Dostoevsky. But now her literary fortunes are so diminished that her biographers preface their works with quasiapologies. As Curtis Cate puts it in this first major biography since Andre Maurois's Llia (1953) We have some trouble understanding how a major literary critic like SainteBeuve could  consider George Sand to be the finest and most original of French prose writers. Maurois himself prefaced Llia with the question Why George Sand?

title: Civil Service Workers Are United and Militant
description: The financial squeeze on the nation's cities putting mayors and unionized civil service workers on a collision course. New York City and San Francisco, a continent apart, have been the most spectacular battlegrounds thus far.

title: Louise D. Wilmer Is Married To Timothy Adrian N. Stebbins
description: In St. Barnabas Anglican Church in North Hatley, Quebec yesterday afternoon Louise Derby Wilmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Whittingham Wilmer of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Baltimore, became the bride of Timothy Adrian Nelson Stebbins.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Collectors Of numismatic memorabilia know that history sometimes comes in small packages. The latest example of this is reported by the Calvin Coolidge Memorial Foundation of Plymouth Notch. Vt.

title: Kent State Jury Retires
description: CLEVELAND. Aug. 23 (UPI) Jurors in the $46million Kent State University civil damages trial retired for the weekend today and were again sequestered under heavy security because of a death threat to one juror. The jury is to resume deliberations on Monday.

title: Nation/Continued
description: BOSTONSchool desegregation is slowly Flaking its way north of the MasonDixon line.

title: The Nation
description: The nation's economic vital signs have given further indication that the recovery from the recession is continuing and that it is likely to be a difficult process.

title: Met Buys, for $5.1Million, Major Japanese Collection
description: The Metropolitan Museum has agreed to pay $5.1million for 412 works of Japanese art, a collection that will raise its Japanese holdings to among the finest of any museum in the country.

title: Correction
description: In an article in The Week in Review of Aug. 10, a paragraph concerning terrorism in the province of Quebec contained several errors. The erroneous sentences should have read Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, in 1970, declared a state of emergency when the members of the Quebec Liberation Front kidnapped British consular officer James Cross and the Quebec. Minister for Labor and Immigration, Pierre LaPorte. Mr. Cross Was released unharmed after 59 days, Mr. LaPorte was found murdered.

title: Food
description: It has always seemed to us that fish and shellfish are more toothsome in the summer than in any other season of the year. We offer here a trio of fish and shellfish dishes contrived during the recent warm months. They include a fish soup delicately flavored with saffron; a creole dish with a base of tomatoes, onion and sweet peppers plus capers; and a special fish and shellfish stew, or ragout andalouse.

title: Calendar of Events
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange Loot. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Sept. 6). $3.5044.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Design
description: This vacation houseactually a cluster four buildingsis set in the middle dense woods in Seal Harbor, Me., away from the shoreline. Unlike many new houses that seem to need to call attention to themselves, this one sits quietly, paying its respects to the architecture of the area. Its shingled walls, pitched roofs and narrow doorways recall the forms and details of a Maine fishing village.

title: Back Road to Forest Hills is a Bit Longer
description: Some players may have to win six singles matches to qualify for the United States Open championships, which begin a 12day run Wednesday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: It Didn't Mean a Thing, Back Then, If It Had No Swing.
description: The Swing Erathat decade when big bands and jitterbug dancers dominated popular musicwas born 40 years ago last Thursday, on Aug. 21, 1935, at the Palomar Ballroom in Los Angeles. And it began in the only possible way it couldwith a shout.

title: People in Florham Park Hail Its Stability
description: FLORHAM PARK  Residents of this Morris County borough are convinced that their community is a wellplanhed and stable one. They say that few if any problems exist here, and that their only major concern is keeping the town secure for its 8,500 inhabitants. As George Opresnick, a 17year resident, put it the other day:

title: Canoeing on the Passaic
description: ROSELANDEvery Saturday and Sunday from April to November, the Center for Environmental Studies offers guided canoe trips down the Passaic River.

title: Bayh Leads 76 Straw Poll I As Youna Democrats Meet
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (UPI)Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana easily led all other announced and unannounced candidates for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination in a straw loon taken today at the convenItion of the Young Democrats I of America.

title: ara Walter Wed
description: ara Walter, daughter and Mrs. Earl N. WaltRoselle Park, N.J., and ????rsburg, Fla., was mar1 Yonkers at noon ay to Owen J. Ward, Owen J. Ward of the and the late Mrs. Msgr. Raymond P. performed the cereSt. Eugene Roman Church.

title: Court Backs Illegitimacy In Dispute On Benefits
description: A Federal appeals court has awarded Social Security benefits to the illegitimate child of a Brooklyn woman in an unusual decision that cited the humanitarian aims of the law.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Hans Koningsberger, who writes under the name of Hans Koning, as in THE PETERSBURG  CANNES EXPRESS (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95), is European  born, though he has lived in New York since 1951. Like so many educated Europeans, he is a cosmopolite with a wry, realistic attitude toward life. He has done news reporting in the past and has written historical novels. He always gets deep into his Eurppean characters, as only a European cosmopolite can, and so he has done in this novel.

title: Army Is Planning to Adopt Weekly Volunteer Quotas
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 23 (UPI)Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann says that the Army is planning to switch from monthly quotas to weekly quotas of enlistees.

title: Feminists Ask Role In Establishment Of Rape Crisis Unit
description: Calling present Police Department units set up to deal with rape victims inadequate and understaffed, feminist leaders yesterday advocated the allotment of Federal funds to women's groups to allow them to organize rape crisis centers of their own.

title: What's Doing in SUFFOLK COUNTY
description: GEOGRAPHY  Suffolk County the easternmost part of Long island, is about 86 miles long and 26 miles wide, but each year, because of coastal erosion, it becomes narrower. The county was shaped by huge glaciers about 40,000 years ago, and the result is nearly 1,000 miles of superb beaches, sandy coves and rolling meadows. Suffolk, with its North and South Forks that jut into the Atlantic.

title: Ruling Due Today on Bid For Relief in Alabama Jails
description: MONTGOMERY. Ala., Aug. 24Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. is expected to rule tomorrow in Federal District Court on a request for. Immediate judicial intervention into the operation of Alabama's prison system.

title: RHODESIAN TALKS WIDENED IN SCOPE
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Aug. 24  The impending meeting of black and white Rhodesian leaders on a new constitution was substantially broadened tonight with the announcement that Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa and President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia would join them for the first direct talks on how to avoid racial warfare in southern Africa.

title: INQUIRY ON NAZIS CALLED LAGGING
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman in letters to Secretary of State Kissinger, has charged anew that the State Department is blocking efforts to investigate alleged Nazi war criminals living in the United States.

title: Giants. Score 2120 Victory Over the Jets As Bad Snap Foils Kick in Last Seconds
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 24Using a timeout and a magic word, the Giants squashed a 38yard fieldgoal attempt on the final play of the game today and saved a 2120 Preseason victory over the Jets.

title: G.M. Strike Ends
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP)Members of United Auto Workers Local 1714 ratified a tentative agreement today, ending a strike at the Fisher Body fabricating plant here, a General Motors Corporation spokesman said. The 2,200 workers struck five weeks ago in a dispute over production standards.

title: Miss McMorrow Wed to Elliot Cashdan
description: Catherine Rosemary McMorrow daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. McMorrow of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday aftertoon Elliot R. Cashdan, son of Lester Cashdan of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Sarah Cashdan. The Rev. Alan Egly, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the Community Church.

title: MAJOR OBSTACLES BELIEVED CLEARED FOR SINAI ACCORD
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24Egypt and Israel were reported tonight to have resolved virtually every major substantive issue in the way of a new Sinai agreement. Secretary of State Kissinger said that he hoped to conclude the accord within the week.

title: California School Reforms Proposed
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 24A design for overhauling all of California's 1,600 junior and senior high schools has been announced by the California Commission for Reform of Intermediate and Secondary Education.

title: Bridge:
description: Most players, if pressed, could cite some episode in their bridge careers that might justifiably be considered unique.

title: Stable Rates Seen In Credit Markets
description: Wall street analysts expect stable rates and possibly improving market conditions to prevail in the final week of August for the Government and corporate sectors. If this fore?? rect, it would mark the lull after the storm of last week when unsettled market conditions forced the postponement of several corporate offerings.

title: Fog at Los Angeles Airpor
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (UPI)Los Angeles International Airport was closed by a heavy fog for seven hours early today, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTA listing

title: Plaque Marks Site Sinatra Got Start Doing it His Way
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, Aug. 24 (UPI)For motorists passing on Route 9, Stellatos's Exxon service station here is no different from others along the highway.

title: Mobil Opposes Decontrol of Oil; Urges Phaseout of Price Curbs
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation broke ranks with other major petroleum companies yesterday by publicly opposing President Ford's plan to decontrol all domestic oil prices next Sunday.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24A consumer's guide to Federal, state, county, municipal and nongovernmental organizations in New Jersey is now available from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: First Use, First Strike
description: President Ford's warning that failure to reach an early SALT agreement with Moscow would necessitate spending an extra $3billion for nuclear weapons over the next two years raises countless questions of public priorities and policies. It also complicates further the ongoing debate about nuclear strategic doctrine.

title: Burns Says Soviet Grain Sales May Raise Food Costs by 2.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that grain sales to the Soviet Union might result in a 2.5 per cent increase in the cost of food in the United States by the end of next year.

title: Return of Best U.S. Little League Team Unites a OnceDivided Lakewood, N.J.
description: LAKEWOOD, Aug. 24Four thousand people turned out here this afternoon to welcome home thebest Little. League team in the United States.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York was ranked 20th in a study of masstransit systems conducted by the Council on Municipal Performance. Boston has the best mass transit system and Miami the worst, according to the nonprofit research group. San Francisco ranked second and Los Angeles 27th. Ratings were based on Federal data showing how people get to and from work, taking into account percentages of people using public transportation, employment density, economic level and transportation networks.

title: Mobil Opposes Decontrol of Oil; Urges Phaseout of Price Curbs
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation broke ranks with other major petroleum companies yesterday by publicly opposing President Ford's plan to decontrol all domestic oil prices next Sunday.

title: Quarter Horse Derby to Filly
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N. M., Aug. 24 (UPI)  Vim and Vigor, taking the lead out of the starting gate, outran Easy Date, the heavy favorite, and Jet Comanche today to win the $418,200 All American Derby by a nose.

title: Gardening on England's Public Lands  The Parsnip Issue
description: LONDON, Aug. 24Gary Williams, an insurance executive who lives in the London borough of Richmond, remembers vividly the day his allotment came through from the local council.

title: Country Music Fans in City Get Yahoo and Twang
description: Over 1,000 footstomping countrymusic fans flocked to a New York countrymusic festival yesterday, carrying colored balloons and yahooing to their favorite tunes from 20 groups in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza.

title: F.B.I. Said to Study Possibility Of a Woman in Bronfman Case
description: Federal authorities investigating the kidnapping of Samuel Bronfman 2d earlier this month are pursuing the possibility that the two men now in custody for the crime may have had a woman accomplice, according to reports in Time and Newsweek magazines.

title: LINDSAY AIDE NAMED EDITOR OF THE VOICE
description: Thomas B. Morgan. former press secretary for Mayor John V. Lindsay, has been appointed to the newly created. post of editor of The Village Voice, effective Sept. 4.

title: TampaWins Crown, 20, In N.A.S.L.
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)  Arsene Auguste, a substitute defender, broke a scoreless tie with a secondhalf goal and Clyde. Best scored later to give the Tampa Bay Rowdies a 20 victory over Portland for the North American Soccer League championship today.

title: Angolan Front Leader Admits Kidnapping Report Was Faked
description: LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  An Angolan guerrilla leader who had been reported kidnapped 10 days ago admitted here last night that the incident had been faked.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Hamptons Are Newest Stop on Campaign Trail
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24  Late August in the Hamptons: A full moon, fresh corn and tomatoes. And in every sand dune or at every private party, somebody is running for public office.

title: 4 HELD IN MAILING OF BOMB TO STORE
description: An 18yearold Rutgers University chemistry student and three teenaged friends are to be arraigned before a United States magistrate in Newark today on charges of having mailed a pipebomb to the student's grandmother in a scheme to obtain a $10,000 inheritance.

title: NoHitter for Halicki
description: Ed Halicki of the San Francisco Giants pitched a nohit game in defeating the New York Mets, 6 to 0, in the second game of a doubleheader in San Francisco. Mets won first, 95. Page 35.

title: Puerto Ricans Hold a Fiesta
description: Undaunted by a daylong drizzle, thousands of Puerto Ricans took to Central Park yesterday, as much to show that they could have a festival and keep the park clean as to celebrate the 10th annual Folklore Fiesta.

title: Lower Level of Bridge Closed by Accidents
description: Minor accidents involving motorists returning to the city produced major traffic jams on the George Washington Bridge yesterday and forced the closing of the bridge's lower level.

title: VESSEL FROM TIMOR ARRIVES AT DARWIN
description: DARWIN, Australia, Monday, Aug. 25 (Reuters)A Norwegian freighter arrived in Darwin today with 1,11,5 refugees from the civil war in Portuguese Timor.

title: MAID REMEMBERS SLAIN FRIEND, 80
description: A maid at the Murray Hill Hotel on West 35th Street yesterday recalled with a sad smile the year she had spent caring for Alvita Garside, an 80yearold resident who was found strangled Saturday in the bathroom of her fifthfloor room.

title: Young CaribbeanBorn Poets Explore Identity Problems at Brooklyn Festival
description: The presence of millions of Caribbeanborn men and women in the United States is leading to the expansion of black American culture to include, among other things, a body of black poetry whose roots trace from Puerto Rico down through Guyana.

title: Personal Finance: Fair Credit Billings
description: With the Fair Credit Billing Act scheduled to become effective Oct. 28, the Federal Reserve Board has issued a number of proposed regulations to implement this law. Among the more controversial of these proposals are those dealing with discounts and surcharges for cash and credit card customers.

title: 2 Convicts Help Trenton's Food Plan
description: TRENTONTwo men serving life sentences at Trenton State Prison for conspiracy to commit murder are working with a Roman Catholic priest to provide food for the poor land for people requiring aid on, la temporary basis.

title: Sadat Said to Expect Economic Gains
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 24President Anwar elSadat and many other Egyptians appear to view a Sinai disengagement as a small but important move in a major gamble to revive the longstagnant Egyptian economy.

title: Turks to Visit U.S. in Bid To Change Public Opinion
description: ANKARA, Aug. 24 (Reuters) A delegation of Turkish businessmen and, industriau plans to visit the United States early next month in an effort to change American public opinion, the stateowned radio station reported today. The spokesman for the deelgation said the trip would b ea goodwill tour, and representatives from Turkish unions had also been invited.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: OKLAHOMA STARTS REFUGEE PROGRAM
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., Aug 24  Oklahoma has established its own refugee relocation program, pledging to find sponsors for 1,500 Vietnamese. That number is in addition to the 1,919 Vietnamese refugees already sponsored by individual residents of Oklahoma.

title: Advertising
description: Talk about cultural shock. Think about the Black kid from Boys High in Brooklyn starting as a freshman at some college in rural North Dakota. That's cultural shock.

title: N.B.A. Beats A.B.A.
description: TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP)Jim Fox's basket with 70 seconds left gave the National Basketball Association a 131130 triumph over the American Basketball Association here in a game between touring players.

title: Carey Gloomy on Default Unless U.S. Gives City Aid
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 24In one of his most pessimistic assessments of the city's fiscal crisis, Governor Carey said this weekend that unless the Federal Government intervened, the city had only a 5050 chance of avoiding default on its obligations.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: NEW JUSTICE UNIT SOUGHT TO COMBAT CORPORATE CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Asserting that we are in the midst of a corporate crime wave, Ralph Nader and four members of Congress, including three from the New York metropolitan area, urged today the establishment of a division on corporate crime within the Justice Department.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S, GAMES California 9, New York 0 (1st) California 4, New York 3 (2d). Texas 8, Baltimore 7 (n.). Boston Chicago 1. Kansas City 5, Cleveland 2. Milwaukee 7, Oakland 6. Minnesota 3, Detroit 1.

title: TV: Beacon Hill Bows Tonight as 2Hour Special
description: Beacon Hill, the American offspring of England's Upstairs, Downstairs, becomes a new CBSTV series tonight at 9. The premiere takes the form of a 2hour special. Beginning next week, it will be presented as hourlong productions on Tuesdays at 10. The debut, part of the most ambitious project in the new TV season, despite a couple of worrying flaws, is most successful, nicely introducing its unusually large cast of characters and cleverly establishing relationships and situations ripe for future plucking and development.

title: Wefer Captures Race Week Sail
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 24  The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 43d annual Race Week wound up a fiveday stand in rain and dying southerly winds today. Top awards went to Doug Wefer of the Port Washington Y. C., who won the Thomas M. Fraser Trophy for the best performance in a centerboard yacht; Katie Morgan, best woman performer; Charles Van Hagen 3d, best performer among hostclub members, and Jim Miller, who swept four races in Laser oddnumber competition.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BRAY'S DAY The father of screen animation, John Randolph Bray, will celebrate his 96th birthday today by coming from Bridgeport, Conn., to the Museum of Modern Art where programs of his vintage cartoons will be shown today at 2 and 5:30 P.M. and repeated Sunday at 12:30 and 3 P.M.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLECKNERJack. You are always in our thoughts and in our hearts. ETTA, JEFF, PETER & FERN

title: Jersey Pitcher Recalled From Minors in May
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 Ed Halicki, a 24yearold, 6foot7inch righthander, who started this season in the minor leagues, pitched the National League's first nohit game of the season today as the San Francisco Giants defeated the New York Mets, 60, in the second half of a doubleheader. The Mets won the first game, 95, before San Francisco's second largest crowd of the season, 24.132, on Jacket Day.

title: GREEK PARLIAMENT WILL NOT BE CALLED
description: ATHENS, Aug. 24 (Reuters)The Greek Cabinet tonight rejected demands by the Opposition for an emergency session of Parliament to deal with charges that it had hastened to commute death sentences imposed on three leaders of the 1967 military coup.

title: Defeated Girls' Team Returns to L.I. in Glory
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., Aug. 24The defeat of the Dix Hills Girls' Little League team in the national softball championships yesterday was made more bearable for them by an overwhelming reception from the community today. As far as everybody here was concerned, they were still the best.

title: Miners in West Virginia To Continue Illegal Strike
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 24 (UPI)Coal miners vowed today to prolong an illegal strike in West Virginia until they get a document permitting them to strike without reprisals over local grievances.

title: Charles Revson of the Revlon Empire Dies
description: Charles Haskell Revson, president of Revlon, Inc., the cosmetics giant, died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: A.A.U. Swimming Summaries
description: SATURDAY NIGHT

title: Industrialized China
description: Peking's economic growth has apparently recovered significantly from the slowdown it suffered last year. Industrial production may have risen as much as 11 per cent in the first of of 1975, while the spring grain harvest was officially reported to be the best in history. And recent successful orbiting of a Chinese earth satelliteona widely regarded as Peking's first spy sputnikis a reminder of China's prowess in one of the more sophisticated areas of modern technology.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Defends Practice Of Jailing Foes Without Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India said in an interview broadcast today that the political prisoners arrested in her country in the last two months had not been granted trial because the courts were slow and individual guilt was difficult to prove.

title: CanAm Car 2Lap Victor In Handicap
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., August 24A MirageFord driven by Vern Schuppan of of Australia posted a lopsided victory in today's 252mile handicap auto race at Road Americaa race in which faster cars gave slower ones a head start.

title: Tax Politics
description: Two years ago the State, Commission of Investigation complained of the frivolous application of discretionary standards by, the City Tax Commission in determining local real estate taxes. Little seems to have changed, despite the urgent new pressuresfor fairness engendered by the city's financial pinch and the shaky status of metropolitan real estate.

title: L.I. Little League Girls' Team, No. 2 in Play, No. 1 in Dix Hills
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., Aug. 24The defeat of the Dix Hills Girls' Little League team in the national softball championships yesterday was made more bearable for them by an overwhelming reception from the community today. As far as everybody here was concerned, they were still the best.

title: Little Is New but Price in 1976 Autos
description: DETROIT, Aug. 24They sat there unobtrusively, littlenoticed, gleaming in a side lot of Krejenke Buick Sales, Inc., in central Detroitsix new cars fresh from an assembly plant in Flint, the vanguard of the millions of 1976 models on which the automakers are pinning their hopes for economic recovery.

title: 250 Go Nude at Beach, 7 Arrests Are Made
description: TRURO, Mass., Aug. 24 (AP)National Park Service rangers issued a few written warnings today as rain and cold limited nude bathing here.

title: Study Says Con Ed Misled Public on Indian Pt. Saving
description: The Council of Economic Priorities has accused Consolidated Edison of misleading the public in contending that operation of its Indian Point nucleir plants in 1974 had saved $95million in fuel costs and has asserted that a coalfired plant of equivalent scale would have been $25.8million cheaper overall.

title: Tacy Feinman Bride Of Dr. K. R. Sandler
description: At Temple Beth ZionBeth Israel in Philadelphia at noon yesterday Tacy Feinman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Feinman of Woodmere, L. I., was married to Dr. Kenneth Richard Sandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pinkus Sandler of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Reuben J. Magil performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Morris Purges.

title: Chinatown Celebrates Spirit of '76
description: Firecrackers popped, performers snaked through the traditional dragon dance and 75 youngsters raced each other along a fiveandahalf mile course in the hopes of winning a trophy yesterday as a weeklong bicentennial celebration in Chinatown got off to ?? lively start.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL Mets. vs Padres at San Diego (RadioWNEW, 10 P.M.)

title: SHRIMPBOAT RAIDED, MARIJUANA IS SEIZED
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 24 (AP)United States Customs officers  raided a shrimpboat as she began unloading 18 tons of marijuana and 19 persons were charged with smuggling, Federal officers reported today.

title: Alan Gelb Weds Karen Levine
description: Karen Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Levine of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday, to. Alan Lloyd Gelb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Gelb of Scarsdale, N. Y. Rabbi William A. Grentlicher, assisted by Cantor Fuchs, performed the ceremony at the Bayside Jewish Center in Queens.

title: Premier Says Laotian Coalition Continues Intact
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 24Everything is calm here, always calm. There is no change. I am still Prime Minister.

title: Bed Designs for Sailing Off to the Land of Nod
description: When Rohan and Morgan Young, aged 6 and 3, respectively, go to sleep at night, they go in style. Rohan sails off to the Land of Nod in a ??iny blue boat; Morgan ??urls up in a redroofed barn.

title: FAMILIES OF G.I.'S IN TURKEY MISS PX
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 24 (AP)The 15,000 Americans living on United States military installations in Turkey are finding a new style of living: boiling their milk, haggling with butchers in a strange language and doing without American products.

title: NINA B. SOLOMON KOVE
description: Nina B. Solomon Kove, wife of Moses L. Kove, chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, died Thursday in Brookda le Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived at 336 West End Avenue.

title: Detroit Greyhound Bus Held Up by 2 Gunmen
description: DETROIT, Aug. 24 (UPI}Two armed men held up a bus bound for Paducah, Ky., today, forcing 15 passengers to put their money and jewelry in a plastic garbage bag.

title: Government by Default
description: WASHINGTONGaps in resources, technology and capital are at the heart of the energy crisis that increasingly imperils our economy and threatens domestic order. Thus, we turn to Government for leadership and solutions, as we must when national priority transcends the right or ability of private enterprise to solve the problem alone.

title: As Castro Discussed Better Ties With U.S.
description: In Havana on Thursday, Premier Fidel Castro expressed his desire to negotiate with Washington; now that hemisphere nations have ended their trade embargo with Cuba. We do want to discuss with the United States, he said, but We require equal conditions and dignity to make discussion possible. The quotations here are excerpted from an interview published Friday in The New York Times. Photographs are by Sally Reston. A related article appears on Page 3.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Castro Prepares Himself for Negotiations With U.S.
description: HAVANA, Aug. 22Fidel Castro is obviously getting ready for diplomatic talks with the United States. He has done his homework on the United States claims for the American property he took over here, and he is marshaling counterarguments and counterclaims.

title: About New York
description: One of the largest cadres of New York summer migrants is coming back to town and, if your streets have been quiet for the last eight weeks, you will hear about it before Friday rolls around.

title: One Dead in Boston Fire
description: BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP)One unidentified person died tonight in a threealarm fire that engulfed two buildings in downtown Boston, officials said. One of the fourstory brick buildrigs housed the Mini Theater, an adult movie house.

title: Israelis Are Found Anxious And the Egyptians Hopeful
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 They'll wake up the whole neighborhood, a security man said disapprovingly when protesters in soundtrucks tried to make themselves heard by Secretary of State Kissinger before dawn Friday.

title: NAVY FACING DELAYS ON 50 OF ITS SHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The United States Navy, already deeply concerned about the growth and aggressive operations of the Soviet fleet, faces delivery delays on 50 nuclear submarines, destroyers, frigates and amphibious assault ships.

title: BEAME IS ASSAILED IN REHIRING STUDY
description: In his layoffs this year, Mayor Beanie has tended to dismiss employes delivering the city's services instead of administrative bureaucrats, according to a study done by Councilman at Large Henry J. Stern.

title: Divided Peronists Reelect Mrs. Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 24President Isable Martinez de Perrin was reelected head of the Peronist movement and her candidates won the other leadership posts late last night at a tumultuous party congress that saw half the delegates walk out

title: Prices of Key Metals Rising
description: Prices of copper and other key base metals have turned upward after declining for 18 months. Normally, this would signal that the recession was almost over because no economic recovery in modern times has been unaccompanied by rising base metals Prices.

title: Peter Elser, Stockbroker, Began Soccer Team Here
description: Peter F. D. Elser, formerly a stockbroker and an owner of Mark Cross, Inc., died Saturday in Memorial Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and in Rome.

title: Jerseyans Among Stars at Philadelphia Folk Festival
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 24The Philadelphia Folk Festival, playing its 14th year this weekend, called on sonic neighbors from across the Delaware River to get the first two days of the threeday gathering of singers, pickers and dancers started.

title: Music: Mahler in Lenox
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 24All of Mahler's symphonies demand of their interpreters a willingness to try to embrace the universe, but none of his works call for longer arms than the Second Symphony, the stupendously ambitious Resurrection. This sixmovement monster is nothing for timid people to wrestle with, and it specifically refuses to yield to a conductor who tries to play down its stark contrasts between earthly violence and otherworldly peace. Seiji Ozawa, who ended the Boston Symphony's Tanglewood season here this afternoon with a performance of the Resurrection, has grown in recent seasons into one of the rare conductors emotionally capable of grasping Mahler's conceptions and technically capable of realizing them in performance.

title: Carey Gloomy on Default Unless U.S. Gives City Aid
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 24In one of his most pessimistic assessments of the city's fiscal crisis, Governor Carey said today that unless the Federal Government intervened, the city had only a 5050 chance of avoiding default on its obligations.

title: Lender of Last Resort. . .
description: The assurance by the Federal Reserve System that it will act promptly to prevent a national crisis in banking and credit if New York City defaults on its obligations is an important safeguard for the country's economic stability. But it does nothing directly to ease the city's financial crunch or to rescue it from the danger of impending insolvency.

title: When Cops Become Robbers
description: WASHINGTON  In the Boston Police Strike of 1919, the Mayor asked the Governor of Massachusetts for 3,000 State Guard Troops to maintain order. The Governor reluctantly took charge, broke the strike by permanently firing a thousand police officers, and rallied public opinion across the nation with these words:

title: Roads Flooded as Rainfall Sets Record
description: Another drenching Sunday thunderstorm struck the metropolitan area last night, raising ing the summer's rainfall to a record level and disrupting the close of the weekend holiday for hundreds of travelers.

title: GEORGE NICOLS, 70, OF STATECOURT, DIES
description: Justice George H. Nicols of the State Supreme Court, who served in Brooklyn, died Friday after his car overturned on the Adirondack Northway south of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: Alice Herman Bride of Robert Lehrer
description: Alice Herman and Robert Lehrer, graduates of the University of Hartford, were married yesterday afternoon in Long Beach, L. I. Rabbi Ephraim Kolatch performed the ceremony there at the home of David Lippel, the bride's grandfather.

title: Yanks Drop 2 To Angels by 90, 43
description: The California Angels crushed the Yankees, 90, in the first game of yesterday's doubleheader, and Frank Tanana, the pitcher who stymied them on four hits, said, it's nice to embarrass them like they did to us.

title: Randi Prezant Is Bride
description: At Temple Israel in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday at noon, Randi Lee Prezant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Sam Prezant of Jamaica Estates, was married to Lee Michael Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Mack Friedman of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ronald Millstein. The bride is a magna cum laude graduate of C.W. Post College. Her husband, an alumnus or New York University, received a master's degree in education there.

title: Janet Castleman Wed To Charles I. Bruder
description: Janet Laura Castleman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Castleman of Neponsit, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Irwin Bruder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Bruder of East Meadow, L. I. Rabbi Israel Nobel performed the ceremony at the East Meadow Jewish Center.

title: MAJOR OBSTACLES BELIEVED CLEARED FOR SINAI ACCORD
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24Egypt and Israel were reported tonight to have resolved virtually every major substantive issue in the way of a new Sinai agreement. Secretary of State Kissinger said that he hoped to conclude the accord within the week.

title: Retailers Report a Mixed Profit Pattern But Results Generally Top Expectations
description: Retailers showed a mixed profits pattern in their second fiscal quarter, but on the whole they did better than many expected.

title: One Man, One State
description: WASHINGTONThe polluted air in the, capital has been thick with, among other things, praise for John A. Durkin, a Democrat, and the wouldbe junior Senator from New Hampshire. His act of heroism was to back down after months of deadlock and agree with Louis C. Wyman, a Republican and also the wouldbe junior. Senator from New. Hampshire, that the best way, to settle their dispute was to go home and have a new election.

title: MAYOR CONCEDES $28BILLION DEBT AS BASIS FOR PLAN
description: In formulating his plan to avoid city default, Mayor Beame for the first time agreed that the city's total indebtedness was about $2.8billion.The existence of the plan was confirmed in a news conference at Gracie Mansion late Saturday night when the Mayor announced that his program included a freeze on taxes, and management reforms that would allow the city to stay within its previously announced budget ceiling.

title: 13 G.O.P. Leaders in South Oppose Rockefeller for '76
description: WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH N.C., Aug. 24 (UPI)Republican party chairmen of 13 Southern states told Gov. James E. Holshouser Jr., of North Carolina this weekend that President Ford would be wise to drop Vice President Rockefeller from the ticket in 1976.

title: BID TO OUST ISRAEL FROM U. N. RENEWED
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 24 (Reuters)The Arab states reportedly agreed tonight to urge the conference of nonaligned nations meeting here to support demands for the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations.

title: Susan J. Shapiro Bride of Jay Lee
description: Susan Jo Shapiro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin r. Shapiro of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Jay Ellington Lee, a composer and partner in Logo Music, Ltd., here. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony at the Shapiro home.

title: Triangles Tie W.T.T. Finals
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (AP)  Mark Cox and Vitas Gerulaitis combined for a 63 doubles victory to help the Pittsburgh Triangles edge the Golden Gaters, 2825, today in the World Team Tennis final playoff.

title: Books of The Times
description: As Aleksandr I. Solzhenttsyn's recent visit to this country showed, prophets make White House guestswhen they are without honor back home. They also make difficult bedfellows, if the memories of his first wife, Natalya Reshetovskaya, in her book, Sanya, are to be trusted. The Nobel laureate's sojourn caught a nation with dtente in the summer of its discontent. The lone man who was considered a threat to the good order of the Soviet Union became a political undesirable at the White House.

title: Belmont Opens Today
description: Racing resumes today at Belmont Park for a 48day meeting, following Saratoga's closing Saturday. There was no Sunday program at Belmont yesterday because the Totalisator equipment was being shipped from Saratoga.

title: Purged Peking Aide Gets New Post
description: TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP)Wang Pingnan, a former deputy foreign minister of China purged during the Cultural Revolution, has been politically rehabilitated and named president of the People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries.

title: O'HAGAN HOPEFUL ON LAIDOFF MEN
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the terms of a union contract now being negotiated would lead to the retirement of about 400 firemen, who, added to 200 present unfilled vacancies, would make it possible for him to seek the reinstatement of 600laidoff men.

title: World Football League
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Conformity Is Made Law Under New Town Codes
description: WESTLAKE VILLAGE, Calif., Aug. 24Don't put a teleivison antenna on your home here. Don't plant a tree in your backyard unless The Committee says you can. Don't paint your house unless The Committee approves the color. And, if you don't mow your lawn, expect The Committee to order it done and send you a bill.

title: Ruling on Control of Community Growth Is Assailed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24Two prominent lawyers, representing opposite sides in the nationwide controversy over community growth controls, have sharply criticized a Federal court for putting its stamp of approval on a California population limitation plan.

title: Geiberger Defeats Stockton by 3 Shots
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 24Alphonse and Gaston, also known as Al Geiberger and Dave Stockton, gave the Tournament Players Championship to each other a couple of times today, but when the holes were running nut Geiberger kept it.

title: JACK H. WORTH
description: Jack H. Worth, president of the Worth Supply Corporation of Garden City, L. L, a constructionequipment company, died Saturday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L. I. He was 71 years old and lived at 327 Lester Court, West Hempstead, L. I.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two marches, part of a nationwide Eaual Rights Day action protesting violence against women, have been scheduled this week by the 31chapter New Jersey National Organization for Women. Tonight at midnight the feminist group is to march on the county courthouse in Newark. Tomorrow, the women will march on Marlboro's Main Street to demand that town officials permanently rename the thoroughfare in honor of Sojourner Truth, the Civil War activist and black poet.

title: Canto Retains Title
description: MERIDA, Mexico, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Miguel. Canto of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council flyweight title last night when the referee stopped his bout against Jiro Takada of Japan in the 11th round.

title: St. Louis to Replace Bad Fish Removed From 5 of Its Lakes
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24With the help of several truckloads of carp and bullheads, fishing Will return to the St. Louis summer recreation scene tomorrow after all the fish in live city park lakes had to be killed two weeks ago.

title: Sadat Said to Expect Economic Gains
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 4President Anwar elSadat and many other Egyptians appear to view a Sinai disengage ment as a small but important move in a major gamble to revive the longstagnant Egyptian economy.

title: Hawaiians Get Thomas; Bell Protests
description: There were two surprise signings in the World Football League: 1, the Hawaiians signed Duane Thomas; 2, Thomas signed autographs.

title: 51% in National Poll Favor U.S. Aid to Ease City Crisis
description: A nationwide survey shows that a majority of Americans favor Federal aid to help bail New York City out of its fiscal straits.

title: A Portuguese Crowd Attacks Building Of ProCommunist Party in Coast City
description: LEIRIA, Portugal, Monday, Aug. 25  A furious mob assaulted the headquarters of the proCommunist Popular Democratic Movement here shortly before midnight last night, sacked it and burned all the furnishings and documents in a huge bonefire in front of the Roman Catholic cathedral.

title: F.T.C. CHALLENGES DENTUREAID ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission accused the Block Drug Company today of making false and unsubstantiated advertising claims for its denture products Polident cleanser and PolyGrip adhesive.

title: Kathie Yoswein Wed to J. D. Siegfried
description: Kathie Irving Yoswein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Yoswein of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Jonathan Dick Siegfried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Siegfried of New York. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony in the Crystal Room of the Plaza.

title: Equity to Meet Today on New Code
description: special membership meeting of Actors Equity Association will be held today to try to solve a dispute that is crucial to the future of Off Off Broadway, the nonprofit developmental theater movement that has become one of the liveliest segments of the New York theater scene.

title: British Football
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Consumer Leader And Farmer Back Soviet Wheat Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)  Farm and consumer spokesmen urged today an investigation of food processors and sellers who they said might be using the recent sale of wheat to the Soviet Union as an excuse to raise food prices.

title: Return of Best Little Leaguers in U.S. Unites OnceTorn Lakewood
description: LAKEWOOD, Aug. 24Four thousand people turned out here this afternoon to welcome home the best Little League team in the United States.

title: J. EDWARD CONWAY, STATE RIGHTS AIDE
description: J. Edward Conway, who retired in 1972 from the State Commission for Human Rights, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital, Albany. He was 73 years old and lived in Guilderland. N.Y.

title: The Champion and the Magician
description: A note from Jimmy Grippo contains news that probably will not give Joe Frazier food for thought as he pummels people and punching bags in Philadelphia, but perhaps should. Jimmy mentions that he has been giving lessons in magic, hypnotism and autosuggestion to Muhammad Ali, from whose comely person Frazier plans to extract the heavyweight championship of the world Sept. 30. Even without instruction, the deft Ali can shuffle a new deck of cards while wearing boxing gloves, and when the lifts his voice he induces a numbness akin to hypnosis. With these natural talents polished by Grippo the Great, he may weave such a spell that Frazier will enter the ring in Manila as goofy as he was leaving it in Kingston, Jamaica, a couple of years ago. On top of that, chances are that in addition to learning sleightofhand and mesmerism, All will pick up a smattering of clairaudience, clairvoyance, dream interpretation, extrasensory perception, handwriting analysis, palmistry, prerecognition, psychokinesis, telekinesis and telepathy, for Mr. Grippo is a recognized authority on all of these.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Attends U.S. Envoy's Dinner
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 (AP)  Prime Minister Indira Gandhi attended a dinner tonight, given by the United States Ambassador, William B. Saxbe, at his residence in the American Embassy compound.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Save the Nation's Railroads

title: Gibson Says U.S. and State Do Little to Help His City
description: Mayor Kenneth Gibson of Newark said in New York yesterday that he was not getting much help from Democrats in Trenton or Republicans in Washington in revivifying his city.

title: NoHitter for Halicki
description: Ed Halicki of the San Francisco Giants pitched a nohit game in defeating the New York Mets, 6 to 0, in the second game of a doubleheader in San Francisco. Mets won first, 95. Page 35.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 25, 1975

title: Hopewell Indignant at Cost Of Its Bicentennial Duties
description: HOPEWELL, Aug. 24 (UPI)  The Bicentennial celebration is giving a $1million headache to officials of Hopewell township, which sits on the site where George Washington crossed the Delaware on Dec. 25, 1776.

title: DR. THOMAS BURNAP ANESTHESIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Thomas K. Burnap, a past chairman of the board of governors of the American College of Anesthetists, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital, where he had been chief of anesthesiology since 1974. He was 51 years old and lived on Skyridge Road in Greenwich.

title: Israelis Are Found Anxious And the Egyptians Hopeful
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 They'll wake up the whole neighborhood, a security man said disapprovingly when protesters in soundtracks tried to make themselves heard by Secretary of State Kissinger before dawn Friday.

title: BARS IN MONTANA FACE DRY AUTUMN
description: BILLINGS, Mont, Aug. 24A strike by 260 members of the Montana Council of Retail Clerks against stateoperated liquor stores has bar owners predicting a dry autumn.

title: Surgery for Astronaut
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Donald K. Slayton, the oldest United States Astronaut, is scheduled to enter a cancer hospital tomorrow for exploratory surgery on a lesion in his left lung. Mr. Slayton, 51 years old, said that doctors had told him that there was a more than 50 per cent chance that the lesion is cancer. Surgery is scheduled Tuesday at the M.D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute.

title: Angry Farmers Shun Blame for Food Costs
description: PRETTY PRAIRIE, Kan., Aug. 22The amber waves of grain that mean harvest and profits each spring for farmers in the nation's biggest wheatgrowing state, have turned into angry waves of protest this summer.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A few weeks ago we participated in a twoperson chili contest on Dinah Shore's television show. Dinah made an excellent chili along somewhat standard lines, which is to say with ground meat and tomatoes; we prepared one of our favorite chilies, which uses cubed meat and no tomatoes.

title: I.M.F. IN APPROVAL OF FLOATING RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The International Monetary Fund, long a stanch defender of fixed currency exchange rates, gave a general blessing today to the 30month experiment in floating rates that began under conditions of crisis in March, 1973.

title: Mrs. Rankin Wins in Golf By 2 Shots
description: LITTLETON, Colo., Aug. 24 (AP)Judy Rankin, withstanding a charge from Sandra Haynie and Jane Blalock, ended a yearlong victory drought today by winning the $40,000 National Jewish Hospital open golf tournament. She carded a 71 for a 54hole total of 207 and a twostroke edge.

title: Political Impasse Continues
description: LISBON, Aug. 24Forces for and against Vasco Gonalves, the Communistoriented Premier, stood their ground today waiting for a decisive move on his future by President Francisco da Costa Gomes, but it was not forthcoming.

title: U.S. Eight, Belden Lose World Titles
description: NOTTINGHAM England, Aug. 24  The defending champion United States crew lost the title to the West Germans, and Bill Belden's singlesculls crown was taken by a Swiss oarsman today in the world lightweight rowing championship.

title: Return of Best U.S. Little League Team Unites a OnceDivided Lakewood, N. J.
description: LAKEWOOD, Aug. 24Four thousand people turned out here this afternoon to welcome home the best Little League team in the United States.

title: Deaths;
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) /4/0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
Mujib's Loyal Followers Reported to Plot Vengeance
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 24Bangladesh moved toward another phase of violence and chaos over the weekend when stanch supporters of the country's assassinated leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, began to regroup into an underground movement.

title: RHODESIAN TALKS WIDENED IN SCOPE
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Aug. 24  The impending meeting of black and white Rhodesian leaders on a new constitution was substantially broadened tonight with the announcement that Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa and President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia would join them for the first direct talks on how to avoid racial warfare in southern Africa.

title: NEW JUSTICE UNIT SOUGHT TO COMBAT CORPORATE CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Asserting that we are in the midst of a corporate crime wave, Ralph Nader and four members of Congress, including three from the New York metropolitan area, urged today the establishment of a division on corporate crime within the Justice Department.

title: Tuna Fleet to Protest Poaching in Conservation Zone in Pacific
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 24  A large part of the American tuna fleet is meeting at sea for a demonstration in San Diego Bay tomorrow to dramatize the fishermen's anger over violations of an international conservation zone extending across 5 million square miles of the eastern Pacific.

title: KOPECHNES VOICE DOUBT ON MISHAP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The parents of Mary Jo Kopechne indicate in an article published by New Times magazine that they are not satisfied with Senator Edward M. Kennedy's account of the auto mishap that took their daughter's life.

title: The Democrats' Convention City
description: WASHINGTONThere has been so much speculation, accurate and inaccurate, about the criteria used by a political party in its decision on selecting a city for its convention that I thought I would set down the Democrats' considerations.

title: Joel Mintz Weds Miss Rochelson
description: Meri  Jane Rochelson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eli G. Rochelson of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Joel Alan Mintz, a lawyer assigned to the onforcement division of the United States Environmental Protection Agency in Chicago.

title: Portuguese Demand Evacuation
description: LUANDA, Aug. 24 About 5,000 Portuguese demonstrated outside government headquarters here today demanding swift evacuation from Angola.

title: OffDuty Officers Shoot 4 in Incidents
description: Four people were wounded in three separate incidents involving offduty policemen and an offduty corrections officer who fired their guns late Saturday night and early yesterday morning.

title: Linda D. Abramson Bride of Fred Raff
description: Linda Dale Abramson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ephraim Abramson of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Fred David Raft, son of Mrs. Francis Herskowitz of Brooklyn and the late Michael Raff. Rabbi Jonathan Eichhorn performed the ceremony at the Abramsons' country home in Hunter. N.Y.

title: Walter Young, ExOfficer Of JournalAmerican, 82
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 24 (AP)Walter A. Young, a former associate publisher of The New York JournalAmerican, died today at Waterbury Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Naugatuck.

description: WESTLAKE VILLAGE, Calif., Aug. 24Don't put a teleivison antenna on your home here. Don't plant a tree in your backyard unless The Committee says you can. Don't paint your house unless The Committee approves the color. And, if you don't mow your lawn, expect The Committee to order it done and send you a bill.

title: Oil Oozes in Columbia River
description: ASTORIA, Ore., Aug. 24 (UPI)An oil slick described by the Coast Guard as two miles long and 30 yards wide oozed slowly toward the mouth of the Columbia River today. The oil escaped from a fishing boat that hit a submerged object and capsized Friday.

title: About New York
description: One of the largest cadres of New York summer migrants is coming back to town and, if your streets have been quiet for the last eight weeks, you will hear about it before Friday rolls around.

title: Washingtoniana on Display at Library
description: During the Revolutionary War, George Washington was beset with worries about the poor provisions to his men, but his wife was concerned that he was not writMe her frequently enough.

title: How Youth Won Probation After Four Subway Crimes
description: An 18yearold youth who committed four subway crimes at knifepointincluding one in which a 55yearold woman was held hostage for nearly an hourhas received a five year probationary sentence under the state's Youthful Offender law.

title: Alice Faye's Auto Is Robbed of Jewels
description: Alice Faye, the actress, was robbed of $10,000 in jewels early yesterday when her chauffeured limousine was broken into outside 919 Third Avenue and two bags containing the gems were stolen from it, the police reported.

title: Leftists on Crete Fight Foreign Bases
description: CANEA, Crete  Leftwing forces have mounted an energetic campaign against four potentially important military bases maintained on this Greek island by the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: . . . First Duty for City
description: The country shares with the people of this city concern over the adequacy of the still only partly disclosed plans of Mayor Beanie for a threeyear freeze on new taxes and for enforcement of budget ceilings and account reforms that will get the city started back on the road to solvency.

title: Ambitious Builder Here Facing $2.9Million Liens on 4 Projects
description: Six months ago Christopher Boomis was building three luxury apartment houses here worth $17million and a cityfinanced pier costing $12million. The 53yearold realestate developer said then that he was confident he could raise $45million more for four other projects.

title: Braves Fail to Catch Brock or Cardinals
description: An important part of the dramatic rise of the St. Louis Cardinals in the National League's Eastern Division since the AllStar Game in midJuy has been the flying feet of Lou Brock, the speedster who set a record for stolen bases in one season last year with 118.

title: SIDNEY BUCHMAN, SCENARIST, DEAD
description: Sidney Buchman, film producer and scenarist, who wrote the screenplay for Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, starring James Stewart, in 1939, died Saturday in Cannes, France, where he had lived for the last 10 years. He was 73 years old.

title: Commuter Agency To Begin Hearings Today on Fare Rise
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24 (UPI) The New Jersey Commuter Operating Agency will hold the first of its 22 public hearings here tomorrow on proposed increases in bus and rail fares that are scheduled to go into effect Oct. 1.

title: 4 HELD IN MAILING OF BOMB TO STORE
description: An 18yearold Rutgers University chemistry student and three teenaged friends are to be arraigned before a United States magistrate in Newark today on charges of having mailed a pipebomb to the student's grandmother in a scheme to obtain a $10,000 inheritance.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Barbara Freeman Wed
description: Barbara Ann Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Freeman of Long Beach, L.I. was married last night to Steven Jay Rappaport, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rappaport of North Woodmen, L.i., by Rabbi Ephraims Kolatch of Temple Beth El Long Beach, at the temple. The bride graduated summa cum laude from Boston University. Her husband, an alumnus of Cornell University, is a.thirdyear student at Suffolk University School of Law in Boston.

title: L.I. Little League Girls' Team, No. 2 in Play, N. 1 in Dix Hills
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., Aug. 24The defeat of the Dix Hills Girls' Little League team in the national softball championships yesterday was made more bearable for them by an overwhelming reception from the community today. As far as everybody here was concerned, they were still the best.

title: A Battle of Nerves at Yale Bowl
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 24The fans put their drinks down in the outdoor bar known as the Yale Bowl today as the Jets were about to attempt a 38yard field goal against the Giants in the waning seconds of the game.

description: An 18yearOld youth who committed four subway crimes at knifepointincluding one in which 55yearold woman was held hostage for nearly an hourhas received a fiveyear probationary sentence under the state's Youthful Offender, law.

title: SOUNDS IN MOTION AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: Sounds in Motion, Dianne McIntyre's energetic and didactic company of dancers and musicians, draws its performance materials from the black experience. Miss McIntyre translates black history into movement homilies. She presented Free Voices at the fountain in Lincoln Centerlate Saturday afternoon as part of the arts center's outofdoors festival.

title: Fishermen Are Vying With Oil in Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 19 Down through the years, fishing has become accustomed to taking a back seat to the occasional glamour industries, such as gold, and now oil, that have stirred excitement and imagination about Alaska.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York was ranked 20th in a study of masstransit systems conducted by the council on Municipal Performance. Boston has the best mass transit system and Miami the Worst, according to the nonprofit research group. San Frarcisco: ranked second and Los Angeles. 27th. Ratings were based on Federal data showing how people get to and from work, taking, into account percentages of people using public transportation, employment density, economic level and transportation networks.

title: About New York
description: One of the largest cadres of New York summer migrants is coming back to town and, if your streets have been quiet for the last eight weeks, you will hear about it before Friday rolls around.

title: MAYOR CONCEDES $2.8BILLION DEBT AS BASIS FOR PLAN
description: In formulating his plan to avoid city default, which includes a guarantee of no new taxes or tax increases for three years and a request for an advance in state aid, Mayor Beame has for the first time agreed that the city's total indebtedness is about $2.8billion.

title: The Bills' Surprise: Marangi
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Marangi of Salem Road in North Valley Stream, L.I., watched the nationally televised Buffalo BillsLos Angeles Rams National Football League preseason game Saturday night in Buffalo with great interest. So did many other Long Islanders when they noticed that Gary Marangi was the Bills' starting quarterback. They remembered him from Elmont Memorial High School where he was the school's best athlete, a threesport letterman, and a Nassau County AllScholastic player.

title: Fireflies' Light Gains New Uses in Medical and Technical Research
description: The light of the firefly, long the subject of scientific curiousity and nocturnal wonder, has sparked a growing interest in luminescence as a technique in medical and biochemical research.

title: FORD DEDICATES DAM IN MONTANA
description: LIBBY, Mont., Aug. 24President Ford and Donald S. Macdonald, Canada's Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, declared today at the dedication of Libby Dam that their nations would have to go it alone in confronting energy problems.

title: Murray Louis, the Global Choreographer
description: If Murray Louis should wake up one morning and wonder if he's in Denmark or Dubuque, the confusion will be understandable. I'm a compulsive choreographer, he says, but he might also be described as a compulsive world traveler. As a result his name is becoming a household word in the dancing world of Europe.

title: Simon Criticizes Lockheed For Obscurity on Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon today chastised the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for apparently not having been forthright with the Government about the bribes that the company has paid overseas.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Mexico City  Miguel Canto, Mexico, knocked out Jiro Takada, Japan, flyweights, 11 rounds; Canto retained World Boxing Council flyweight title.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 26, 1975

title: BEAME PLAN LATE, IRKING M.A.C. AIDES
description: Mayor Beame failed to complete yesterday the threeyear budget plan that he hopes will convince investors that they should lend more money to New York City, irritating state and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials who waited all day to receive the Mayor's proposal.

title: Chess:
description: MONTILLA, Spain, Aug. 22 The black pieces held sway in the opening round of the fifth international Torneo del Vino here, scoring three victories and two draws. That does not mean that some new way of overturning the advantage of the first move has been discovered, but rather that errors ruled the play.

title: MORTIMER E. LOWE
description: Mortimer E. Lowe, a broker with Travelers Insurance Company for more than 40 years, died here Sunday. He was 66 years old and lived at 136 East 55th Street.

title: Actors Reject Code
description: A special membership meeting of the Actors Equity Association voted overwhelmingly against a new code for noncommercial productions. The code had come under fire as a threat to Off Off Broadway Page 36

title: SALES OF CHAINS ROSE 7.7 % IN JULY
description: The nation's chainstore organizations in July chalked up a gain in sales volume of 7.7 per cent, compared with July of 1974, according to a survey by Chain Store Age magazine. The increase last month was slightly below a gain of 7.9 per cent in June. It compared with a rise of 8.4 per cent in May and no gain in April.

title: Wider Disclosures On Stocks Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a set of proposed regulations aimed at stripping away some of the mystery obscuring who owns or controls American business.

title: Beame and Credibility
description: Four times this year, Mayor Beame has labored day and night with his closest budget advisers to produce a dramatic resolution to the city's deepening fiscal crisis, each time hoping that his solution would avert the disaster that seemed just around the corner. First, Mr. Beame agreed reluctantly to the creation of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which diluted much of his previously unquestioned authority over city fiscal affairs.

title: Fiscal Crisis Deters Carey on Equal Rights
description: Preoccupation with the city's fiscal woes caused a delay in Governor Carey's plans to begin a statewide campaign for approval of the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: Capital Needs for State
description: Governor Byrne and the State Legislature will have to decide between today and Sept. 4 how big a bite of state's projected capital needs voters will be willing to swallow at one time. The Capital Needs Study Commission appointed by the Governor has identified $9.1 billion in longterm capital needs over the next 10 years and recommended financing $1.75billion of the capital construction through bond issues.

title: Week's Steel Output Is Up 2.5%, Best In Over a Month
description: The association said that cumulative production for the year rose to 78,593,000 tons as of Aug. 23. That was 17.6 per cent less than the 95,415,000 tons produced by the industry by the end of the corresponding period in 1974. The production index for the year stood at 96.0 compared with 116.5 for the 1974 period.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS BUSINESS TAX AID
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25President Ford aroused an audience of hardware merchants here today by declaring that he would get the Federal Government out of your business, out of your lives, out of your pockets and out of your hair.

title: WormLike Millipedes Plague Southern Indiana
description: FLOYDS KNOBS, Ind., Aug. 25For several weeks residents here have been warring against a smelly army of wormlike creatures with many legs.

title: Ford Regrets Misunderstanding About His Wife's Comments
description: MILWAUKEE. Aug. 25 (UPI) President Ford said today he regretted that there has been some misunderstanding regarding comments by his wife, Betty, on premarital sex and their personal lives.

title: SHOP TALK
description: You've only yourself to blame if, when the excitement of the Bicentennial is over, you don't know a great deal more about your county than you did before. You can see history reenacted before your very eyes on New England battlefields and, thanks to a Bicentennial series of Landmark Models kits, bone up on Colonial architecture at home. All you need to put together a historic building such as Independence Hall or the White House is the appropriate kit and some white glue. Expenditure of time and money is minimal  one to three hours, $2 to $4.

title: REPORT OF SOVIET AID TO LISBON IS STUDIED
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 25 (AP) Belgian intelligence officials are checking persistent reports that the Soviet Union has sent political funds to Portugal through a shipping concern it runs in Antwerp.

title: Bicentennial Museum Grant
description: TRENTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The New Jersey Bicentennial Commission awarded $5,000 today to the Merabash Museum in New Egypt, in Ocean County, to sponsor an exhibition on the role of blacks in the state's history. It is scheduled to open to the public Oct. 1 and run through 1976. The commission said the museum was the only one in the state dedicated to ?? history of blacks and their ?? to the arts and ??ences.

title: Athens Cabinet Spares 3 Junta Leaders
description: ATHENS, Aug. 25The Greek Cabinet decided unanimously today to spare the lives of the three men sentenced to death Saturday for their parts in the coup of 1967.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Roman Catholic priest who helped seven major narcotics dealers escape from jail received a suspended sentence from a Federal judge who characterized him as a misguided Robin Hood.

title: Savoir Heads Field
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25 The eighthorse field for the 1mile $50,000 Challenge Cup trot at Roosevelt Raceway next Friday was announced yesterday by Larry Mallar, the track's race secretary. Included are the first five finishers in last Saturday's $200,000 International TrotSavoir (United States), Bellino II (France), Surge Hanover (Canada), Elesnar (Canada) and Dimitria (France).

title: ISABELLE STRONG JONES
description: Isabelle Strong Jones, widow of the Rev. Dr. William H. Jones, a Baptist minister at churches in Hammond, Ind., Oshkosh, Wis., Chicago and Portland, Me., died yesterday at the home of their daughter, Mrs. Gregory M. Chorlian, 188 Wilmot Road, New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: Bridge:
description: The bridge writer or teacher who cites a rule of thumb embodying the words always or never can usually be assumed to mean almost always or hardly ever. Nevertheless there are some such rules that come close to 100 per cent.

title: Iran Pushing Construction o Naval Base in South
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 25Undeterred by slumping oil revenues, the Iranian Government is pressing ahead with creation of vast naval facilities at Chahbahar, on the southeastern coast, according to Western business and diplomatic informants.

title: SOCIAL ILLS TIED TO MALNUTRITION
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 25The ordering of social structures is of far greater importance in combating world hunger than economic development or the green revolution, a nutrition specialist of the World Health Organization said here today.

title: Angola: Worse Than the Congo
description: In human suffering, disintegration and chaos, Angola's burgeoning civil war threatens to surpass the Belgian Congo disaster of 196061. It recalls Nigeria on the edge of holocaust in 196667.

title: U.S. PRICES RAISED BY VOLVOOF AMERICA
description: The Volvo of America Corporation said yesterday it had increased prices an average of 5.8 per cent on its 1975 model line, effective immediately.

title: GAINS EXTENDED BY STOCK MARKET
description: The stock market extended Friday's sharp gain with another broad advance yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: A CONSUMER CODE FOR WESTCHESTER
