description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved two consumerprotection bills to day, ending a year  long struggle over how the new code is to be enforced.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: M.A.C. Bonds: What a Court Test Could Do

title: Parseghian's Son Quits
description: SOUTHBEND, Ind., Aug. 25 (AP)  Mike Parseghian, son of Ara Parseghian, the former Notre Dame coach, quit football today because of aggravated back problems. Parseghian, a premed student at Notre Dame, is now wearing a back brace.

title: They Ask Decontrol Now
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation's call for gradual decontrol of domestic oil prices was dismissed yesterday by other major petroleum producers as unrealistic at this time.

title: People in Sports
description: The bankroll battle for the services of 27yearold Bobby Orr continued yesterday in Toronto, where the star defenseman met with officials of the Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association. Orr's contract with the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, believed to be for $225,000 a year, runs out after next season and his skills may then go to the highest bidder. Wayne Belisle, president of the Fighting Saints, would not disclose the amount offered, but said the contract would enrich Orr for life and the lives of his children and his children's children. Negotiations also were underway in Boston.

title: Anaconda Prepares to Fight Crane's Move
description: At a stage of life when most executives are deciding how to spend their retirement years, Thomas Mellon Evans, a hardnosed maverick industrialist from Pittsburgh, is making his third attempt to gain a foothold in the copper business.

title: 1.000 PENSION PLANS REPORTED INSOLVENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) About 1,000 private pension plans, more than had been expected, have reported that they are unable to pay benefits guaranteed to thousands of retired persons, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said today.

title: Giants' Sale By Stoneham Is Reported
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 A report that the San Francisco Giants had been sold to a group of Japanese businessmen was denied today by club officials, but other baseball sources said that completion of such a deal was near.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS BUSINESS TAX AID
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25President Ford aroused an audience of hardware merchants here today by declaring that he would get the Federal Government out of your business, out of your lives, out of your pockets and out of your hair.

title: Giants Encouraged but Wary Of Unbeaten Exhibition Mark
description: Halfway into their exhibition season, the Giants finally have found something in common with the Oakland Raiders and Miami Dolphins: all three still are unbeaten, the last among the 26 National Football League teams.

title: Triangles Defeat Gaters And Win W.T.T. Crown
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) Vitas Gerulaitis broke Tom Okker's service three times in men's singles and carried the Pittsburgh Triangles to a 2114, victory over the San Francisco Golden Gaters tonight in the third and deciding match of the World Team Tennis championship playoffs.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: STEEL PRODUCTION RISES 2.5% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Aug. 23 rose 2.5 per cent above that of the previous week, according to weekly steel production statistics released in Washington yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: U.S. Seniors Beat Canada in Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 25Triumphs by Vic Seixas and Hugh Stewart today enabled the United States to eliminate Canada, 20, and advance to the semifinals of the annual Stevens Cup international team Tennis tournament at the Concord Hotel.

title: Patriots Lose Marshall
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP)Al Marshall, the New England Patriots' leading receiver after three preseason games, has been lost for the year following knee surgery, the National Football League team said today.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: SOUNDS OF MUSIC The South Street Seaport Museum, which offers entertainment most nights of the week, is now stepping up its daytime, openair activities as a further diversion for visitors to the picturesque shipping area at Fulton Street and the East River. Starting today, from noon to 2 P.M., there will be a series of free biweekly musical programs aimed at noontime visitors, as well as pt general information service about the museum and seaport activities.

title: MARY BAER BEASICH
description: Mary Baer Beasich, a former editor of The New York Times Index, died Friday in Oradell, N. J. She was 76 years old and lived at 288 Kinderkamack Road, Emerson, N. J. Mrs. Beasich retired from The Times in 1969 after 42 years of service.

title: Mobil Says No
description: Mobil, third largest among American oil companies, has demonstrated a commendable sense of public responsibility in its letter opposing President Ford's plan to decontrol all domestic oil prices.

title: Potato Trading Sets a High for 103 Years
description: The largest amount of single day's trading in a commodity in the 103yearold history of the New York Mercantile Exchange was achieved yesterday when 9,068 contracts in Maine potatoes changed hands. The previous record was 8,803 contracts, also in potatoes, which was reached April 23, 1968.

title: Fare Exchange
description: A series of public hearings on proposed commuter fare hikes in the metropolitan region erupted last week into bitter exchanges between the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and state legislators and other representatives of the public. The legislators accused the board of having already made up its mind to impose punitive and damaging fare increases, averaging about 23 per centa forecast validated by the official announcement yesterday. Board members, in turn, charged that failure of the lawmakers to provide adequate subsidies had left them with no choice other than to try to balance their books through the fare box.

title: A Major Resource Awaiting Development: Women in the Third World
description: WHO DOES the major part of the work in poor Countries? Women do. Yet they are probably the most underrated eco nomic resource in resourcepoor third world countries.

title: U.S. Suit to Block Copper Range Deal With Amax Filed
description: The Department of Justice yesterday filed a civil antitrust suit in the United States District Court in Hartford, Conn., to block the proposed merger between Amax, Inc., of Greenwich, Conn., and the Copper Range Company of White Pine, Mich.

title: Wright Loses To Ginsberg In L.I. Golf
description: INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 25Roger Ginsberg of Muttontown eliminated Jimmy Wright, the defending champion today in the opening round of the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship. Ginsberg won, 6 and 4, over the 6,680yard Inwood layout, Wright's home course.

title: Joseph Durso
description: When Ken Rosewall won the national amateur tennis title at Forest Hills 20 years ago, he was rewarded with gold tennis ball and a handshake. When he won the same tournament six years ago, he got the handshake, a new car and $20,000 in cash. By then, it was known as the United States Open, meaning it was open to amateurs and pros alike, and tennis no longer was considered a genteel recreation for elderly couples or Australian whiz kids.

title: Benjamin M. Reeves, 85; Founded Packing Concern
description: Benjamin M. Reeves, a food importer and packer who founded B. M. Reeves Company, Inc., in 1924 and headed several other companies until he sold his interests in 1965 to devote himself to philanthropy, died yesterday at his home in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. He was 85 years old.

title: 3 Jersey Youths Held in High Bail on Bomb Charge
description: NEWARK, Aug. 25 (UPI)A Rutgers university student and two friends were arraigned today on charges of making a crude pipebomb and mailing it to the student's grandmother, allegedly to inherit her life insurance policy.

title: Rumors of Argentine Coup Rebutted by Military Chief
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25The commander of the Argentine Army asserted today that the military still supported civilian constitutional government.

title: The Two Messrs. Ford
description: Repealing the Federal Government in all fields except national defense seems to be the platform on which President Ford has decided to run next year His pledge to an audience of manufacturers in Chicago yesterday was that he would get the Federal Government out of your business, out of your lives, out of your pocketsand out of your hair.

title: Ladislav J. Skaloud Dies at 62; Was Pan Am's Chief of Protocol
description: Ladislav J. Skaloud, chief of protocol of Pan American World Airways, died Sunday of la heart attack at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 62 years old.

title: Broker Profits Rose To $321.5Million In Second Quarter
description: Aided by continued heavy trading, stockbrokers chalked up a strong second quarter this year, the second in a row, New York Stock Exchange figures showed yesterday.

title: Manhattan Phone Book Smaller and Bilingual
description: The Manhattan telephone directory, after years of growing in size and weight, has lost a bit of both this year. At the same time, it has learned a new language.

title: Wyman Tells of 2d Farkas Testimony
description: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 25 (AP)The Republican candidate in New Hampshire's special United States Senate election, Louis C. Wyman, said today that he had voluntarily testified before a Federal grand jury investigating the possible sale of ambassadorships during the Nixon Administration.

title: Group Plan Takes Stymie at Belmont
description: Having completed a recordbreaking summer session in both handle and attendance at Saratoga, thoroughbred racing returned to the big city yesterday as a scheduled 48day meeting got underway at Belmont Park.

title: Athens Cabinet Spares 3 Junta Leaders
description: ATHENS, Aug. 25The Greek Cabinet decided unanimously today to spare the lives of the three men sentenced to death Saturday for their parts in the coup of 1967.

title: Arrests of Policemen Upset a Small Town
description: CONNELLSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 22Usually, it's quiet enough in this somnolent little city to hear a dime drop in a parking meter half a block away. Usually Yesterday, there wasa bombscare. You've got to be kidding! said one local resident watching incredulously as patrol cars and policemen noisily descended on a downtown bank, drawn by reports that a mysterious package had been left at a teller's window. Sirens screamed, blue lights pulsed, radios crackled from inside the police cars and for the grimfaced men in the dark blue uniforms, it was all very serious business.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triagle Publications, Inc. (The Dally Racing Form)

title: Karl Bock, 87, ExHead Of Institute of Decorators
description: Karl Bock, president from 1948 to 1951 of the American Institute of Decorators, now the American Society of Interior Designers, died Saturday in Greenwich, Conn. where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: 2 Mississippi Men On RunOff Ballots Die in Plane Crash
description: DECATUR, Miss., Aug 251 (UPI)  A State Treasury candidate, Doxey Fisher, and a legislative candidate, Danny Keyes, who were to have been in runoff elections tomorrow died last night when their small plane crashed in a thunderstorm.

title: Suspect Is Seized In 7 Acid Attacks On Girls in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 25Kenneth W. Kehler, a 25yearold unemployed sportinggoods salesman from Seaford, surrendered to the Nassau County police today after a threemonth investigation of acid attacks on seven teenage girls.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Vietnam Refugees Here Find Main Task Is Getting Jobs
description: An elderly Vietnamese man, thinking in piasters, gave a vender a $10 bill for a soda and asked if that was enough. A Vietnamese woman out on a walk around the block wandered around Jackson Heights, Queens, for an hour before finding her way home. Another woman walked down Orchard Street with a broomstick across her back and a shopping bag attached at each end.

title: Market Place
description: Charles M. LaLoggia, an investment adviser in Rochester, is a stock market technician. He keeps intricate charts of the DowJones Industrial average to decide which way he believes stock prices are headed. Mr. LaLoggia at the moment is pretty pessimistic.

title: Fare Rise Upto 25% To Start on Monday On Suburban Rails
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday announced an increase in fares, effective Monday, averaging 23 per cent on the Long Island Rail Road and 25 per cent on the Penn Central's Hudson and Harlem commuter lines.

title: Rangers Invite 34 Players to Camp
description: The New York Rangers have invited 34 players to their training camp at the Nassau County Arena in Long Beach, L.I., which opens on Monday, Sept. 15. It will be the first time in their 50year history that the Rangers have trained in the metropolitan area. The camp will operate with two sessions a day while the team undertakes a 10game exhibition schedule.

title: Tomato Surprise
description: Several of us went to the country together this summer and grew tomato worms.

title: PREMIER IN LISBON DEFIES DEADLINE, CLINGS TO OFFICE
description: LISBON, Tuesday, Aug. 26As a deadline set for his ouster passed, Premier Vasco Gonalves continued to hold onto office and maneuver for support last night.

title: Magistrate Sets High Bail For Youths in Bomb Case
description: NEWARK, Aug. 25 (UPI)A Rutgers University student and two friends were arraigned today on charges of making a crude pipebomb and mailing it to the student's grandmother, allegedly to inherit her life insurance policy.

title: Stanley S. Goldfarb, 68, Law Partner Here, Dies
description: Stanley S. Goldfarb, senior partner in the law firm of Goldfarb & Fleece here, who specialized in realestate law, died Sunday at his home in Bedford, N. Y. He was 68 years old and also lived at 941 Park Avenue.

title: Pied Piper Scores In OneTon Sailing
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 (AP)After 309 miles and 51 hours of sailing, Pied Piper had only 17 seconds to spare in winning the North American OneTon yacht racing championships.

title: Scrambled Primaries
description: Governor Lucey of Wisconsin has directed his Attorney General, Bronson La Follette, to bring a suit of unusual political importance against the Democratic National Committee. Since 1902 Wisconsin has had open primaries in which Democrats have been free to cross over and help choose nominees of the Republican party; Republicans have been just as free to return the compliment. No declaration or formal party affiliation of any sort is required.

title: Conference of ThirdWorld Nations Opens in Lima, With Campaign Pressed to Oust Israel From the U.N.
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 25Foreign ministers and other officials from nearly 80 nonaligned nations opened a fiveday conference today with several Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization pressing for a formal decision to seek Israel's expulsion from the United Nations.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Vietnam Refugees Here Find Main Task Is Getting Jobs
description: An elderly Vietnamese man, thinking in piasters, gave a vender a $10 bill for a soda and asked if that was enough. A Vietnamese woman out on a walk around the block wandered around Jackson Heights, Queens, for an hour before finding her way home. Another woman walked down Orchard Street with a broomstick across her back and a shopping bag attached at each end.

title: 2 RHODESIAN SIDES CONFER INTO NIGHT AT VICTORIA FALLS
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Tuesday, Aug. 26An extraordinary diplomatic effort was made here yesterday by Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa and President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to force Rhodesian leaders, black and white, to find a new solution to their racial differences. But as the talks adjourned at midnight, it appeared that they might break down.

title: New Contract Effort Set for Firemen
description: Negotiators for the city and its firemen said yesterday that they planned to make a, new, effort later this week to resolve contract issues still in dispute and to conclude their long delayed 197476 agreement.

title: People and Business
description: The Federal income tax rebate, which has stirred much debate this year over its effectiveness as a tool for stimulating economic recovery, is still being studied by the White House as to the possibility of using it again.

title: Woolworth Profit Up 66.2% in 2d Quarter on Sales Gain of 9.8%
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, the nation's largest variety chain, made a sharp upturn in secondquarter profits surging 66.2 per cent on a sales gain of 9.8 per cent over a year ago, the company's report disclosed yesterday. The S. S. Kresge Co., its nearest competitor, had a 32 per cent profit gain in its recent report for the12 weeks to July 30.

title: Religious Groups Studying Basic U.S. Values
description: TIDY CREEK CAMP GROUNDS, Ga.Gustav Rhodes settled his beefy, 6foot frame into a straightback chair, folded his calloused hands on a small table, and spoke deliberately into a microphone.

title: Judge Withholds Ruling In Alabama Prison Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 25 (AP)A Federal judge withheld any immediate ruling today on a request that he close down an Alabama prison's punitive isolation unit known as the doghouse.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The 106 players in the New York Philharmonic plus members of the management staff are leaving today for an 18concert tour of Europe. The orchestra will give its first concert at the Edinburgh Festival on Thursday night. Later it will perform in London, Ghent, Brussels, Lucerne, Berlin, Bonn, Frankfurt, Stuttgart, Mannheim, Munich and Paris. The final concert will be given in Chartres Cathedral on Sept. 19.

title: Actors Vote Against New Equity Code
description: A special membership meeting of the Actors Equity Associationfilled with boos, hisses, applause and catcalls during heated debatevoted overwhelmingly yesterday against a new actors' code that had come under fire as a threat to the survival of Off Off Broadway as a noncommercial development movement.

title: Ulster Terrorists Kill 2
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 25  Two Roman Catholics were shot dead near Newtown Hamilton, on the border with the Irish Republic, early today, apparently by Protestant terrorists posing as British soldiers. The two, men in their early twenties, were returning to County Tyrone after attending a Gaelic football game in Dublin.

title: Carey Names Economic Board In Effort to Attract New Jobs
description: In a move designed to encourage economic growth and attract jobs to the state, Governor Carey announced the appointment of a 24member Economic Development Board and the creation of the post of Industrial Coordinator to help industry in its dealings with the state.

title: BLUE CROSS ASKS INCREASE OF 23% IN RATE FOR 1976
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York asked the State Insurance Department yesterday for permission to raise premiums for about four million of its hospitalization subscribers by an average of 23 tier cent on Jan. 1.

title: Ford Orders Cutback In White House Staff
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UPI) In line with his policy of reducing the Federal bureaucracy, President Ford has ordered a general cutback of the White House Staff, his press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

title: Indian Rookie Wins No 10
description: Dennis Eckersley, a rookie righthander who began the season in the Cleveland bullpen, hurled 6 1/3 innings of hitless ball and finished with a threehitter to lead the Indians to a 51 victory over the Chicago White Sox last night.

title: Five Women to Become Priests In New Episcopal Defiance Move
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 25 (AP) Five more women plan to be ordained to the Episcopal priesthood in defiance of their church's hierarchy.

title: AntiReds in Portugal Stir Up Crowds
description: LEIRIA, Portugal, Aug. 25Almost any public gathering in Portugal todaya country fair, a political rally, a religious paraderisks turning into a brutal antiCommunist demonstration.

title: Advertising
description: The nation's 200 leading consumer magazines reported a 3 per cent decline in total paid circulation in the first six months of 1975, according to a study released by the Gallagher report yesterday.

title: When the Woman Picks Up the CheckA Delicate Problem
description: You're a woman in a good job; you've asked a man to lunch; it's all gone very well. Now comes the moment of truth: The check arrives. An unthinking waiter plunks it down in front of him. Do you panic, wrestle him for it, slip him money under the table?

title: EGYPT MUST SELL PACT TO HER ALLIES
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 25With an interim accord with Israel apparently in sight, the Government of President Anwar elSadat faces the delicate problem of selling it to the Egyptian people and the Arab world.

title: Harris Poll Finds Ford Well Ahead of Reagan
description: The Harris Poll said yesterday that President Ford would decisively beat former Gov. Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination if the election were held now.

title: Jet With 229 Aboard Aborts Its TakeOff at Kennedy
description: An American Airlines DC10 jetliner taking off for San Francisco with 216 passengers and 13 crew members aborted its 150mileanhour rush down a runway at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and skidded to a halt off the tarmac, about 100 yards short of a blast fence.

title: Boston Teachers Get Briefing on Integration
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)Seventysix per cent of the teachers in the Boston public school system voluntarily attended workshops today to acquaint them with conditions in desegregated classes.

title: 7th Philadelphia Fire Victim
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (UPI)The fire at the Gulf Oil Corporation refinery in South Philadelphia has claimed a seventh life. Lieut. James Pouliat, 35 years old, died in St. Agnes Hospital last night of burns suffered in the 11alarm fire that erupted Aug. 17.

title: AIDE TO FORD PLANS TO HEED SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Philip W. Buchen, council to President Ford, told a Federal court today that he planned to comply with a Senate Intelligence Committee's subpoena for certain documents compiled under the Nixon Administration, unless the court ruled that he could not do so.

title: QUAKE PREDICTION CALLED VALUABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25An earthquake in a major American city could take 15,000 lives and cost $25billion in property damage, but most people would be likely to ignore warnings of such a potential disaster, according to a report released today by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Kissinger Says Parleys May Finish by Weekend
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 25Secretary of State Kissinger shuttled between Jerusalem and Alexandria today working on final details of the projected EgyptianIsraeli agreement in Sinai, which seems close to conclusion.

title: De Cavalcante Winner In TrafficTicket Battle
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 25Simone De Cavalcante, the reputed ringleader of a New Jersey organizedcrime syndicate, today won, at least temporarily his battle here to quash a $12 trafic summons for speeding.

title: TV Newsmen Attacked In a Portuguese City
description: LISBON, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  A National Broadcasting Company television crew was attacked in the northern Portuguese city of Oporto tonight and a threeman British crew was detained for questioning by the proCommunist military information services in Lisbon, according to their colleagues.

title: Moonlight Dance Opens A Congress of Sorcery
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 25 (AP) More than 150 young women in black and colored robes swirled to a voodoo dance on a moonlit outdoor stage here at the opening of the first World Congress of Sorcery.

title: Notes on People
description: Irma Vidal Santaella, a 50vearold Bronx resident who was one of the state's first Puerto Rican women lawyers, was named chairman of the State Human Rights Appeal Board yesterday. Governor Carey, in announcing the $39,650ayear appointment, said that, as a member of the board since 1968, Mrs. Santaella had written more than 600 decisions. One of them ended ladies' day admissions to Yankee and Shea Stadiums on the ground that such promotions were discriminatory.

title: Gibson Asks the State to Restore $9Million to Avert Fare Rises
description: NEWARK, Aug. 25Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson urged the Legislature tonight to restore $9million in state masstransit subsidies needed to avert proposed higher bus and commuter train fares and curtailed bus service in the state.

title: City's RealtyTax Need Added to RentControl Debate
description: The city's pervasive budget crisis has added a new element to the longstanding controversy over rent regulations that affect 1.5 million New York families who live in rentregulated apartments the city's need for all the income it can get from the property tax.

title: KENT STATE JURORS ASK A RHODES QUERY
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP)  A question raised by jurors during today's deliberations in the Kent State University trial focused on Gov. James A. Rhodes's role in the 1970 shootings.

title: WNCN Comes Bach As Classical Station
description: Bach came back to an old accustomed spot at 104.3 on the FM radio dial at 8 P.M. yesterday. WNCN celebrated its resurrection after a rocky nine months under the call letters WQIV, which made its debut last October with the recording Roll Over Beethoven.

title: Bank Vulnerability To Oil Riches Eyed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25A Senate subcommittee has quietly begun an inquiry to determine whether the American banking system is in a position of potential vulnerability because of the recent shift in wealth to the countries that produce and export oil.

title: Study Again Labels Aggressive People As High Heart Risk
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)The final report of an 8year study confirms earlier findings that the aggressive, harddriving individual is much more likely to have a heart attack than a relaxed person.

title: Protesting Tuna Skippers Threaten to Desert Flag
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 25  The American tuna fleet, parading home today in a protest demonstration, threatened a wholesale desertion to foreign flag registry unless the Government protected it from growing poaching in a conservation zone of the eastern Pacific.

title: Postal Workers Union Ratifies 3Year Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)The American Postal Workers Union announced today that its membership had ratified a new threeyear contract with the United States Postal Service.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SIXTH DIRECTORATE. By Joseph Hone, 354 pages. Dutton. $5.95.

title: U.S. Reserve Assets Off 158Million in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 25 (Reuters)United States total reserve assets fell $158million in July to $16.08billion, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: MidMonth Car Sales Fell, But Selling Rate Improved
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25  The United States auto industry today, reported new car sales in the Aug. 1120 period were off 6.2 per cent from last year but said the selling rate was the highest for the model year.

title: RUPERT VANCE, 76, SOCIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Rupert B. Vance, a former president of the American Sociological Society and the Population Association of America and emeritus holder of the Kenan Professorship at the University of North Carolina, died yesterday in the North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, where he lived. He was 76 years old.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Florida Power Corporation said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 1.3 million common shares to be sold through underwriters managed by Kidder; Peabody& Co. and Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.

title: Business Briefs
description: After a brief surge in 1971, employment in the securities industry has been gradually, declining, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday in its 1975 Fact Book. The total of personnel at Big Board member firms reached a peak of 165,000 in 1969, fell to 144,000 in 1970, climbed to 153,000 in. 1971 and declined every year after that to reach 123,000 in 1974.

title: Mobil Is to Construct Oil Refinery in Saudi
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday the board of Petromin, the Saudi Arabian state petroleum and minerals agency, had approved Mobil's construction of an oil refinery and petrochemical complex in western Saudi Arabia and a crosscountry crude oil pipeline.

title: Priest in Jailbreak Here Gets Suspended Sentence
description: A 55yearold Roman Catholic priest who helped seven major narcotics dealers escape from jail last year received a suspended sentence yesterday from a Federal judge who characterized him as a misguided Robin Hood.

title: GEN. FARUK GURLER, A LEADER IN TURKEY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 25 (AP)Gen. Faruk Gurler, military chief of staff in the final phase of Turkey's stormy martial law years, died Saturday of cancer at an Ankara military hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: The Blue Ribbon Offers Its Old Patrons Last Dish: Nostalgia Served With Regret
description: George Kocolatos, owner of the Blue Ribbon restaurant, a Times Square landmark since 1914, refers to the oncefavorite haunt of musicians and opera singers as his family store.

title: Yields Rise at Auction of Treasury Bills
description: Yields were up again yestertray in the Treasury's weekly auction of threemonth and sixmonth bills, an upturn also reflected in Monday trading of outstanding threemonth and six  month bills.

title: Concert: Made to Endure
description: WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Aug. 25Summer concert series in outdoor settings have proliferated so widely and so prosperously over the last 25 years that it has become difficult to imagine how things were in earlier

title: Grambling Set for Benefit Game
description: For the fifth straight year, Grambling College will take part in the Whitney M. Young Memorial Football Classic on Nov. 15 at Shea Stadium. The Tigers, who have won the game four times, will meet Norfolk State of Virginia. The game will be a benefit for the New York Urban League's fundraising activities.

title: A Corsican Is Flown Here And Held as Drug Shipper
description: A 53yearold Corsican accused of being the principal figure of an international drug ring was arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court and ordered held in $2.5million bail yesterday after having been flown here from Africa in the company of Federal drugenforcement agents.

title: Hawkins Dancers Set For Carnegie
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company will give two performances of works on Sept. 11 and Sept. 13 at Carnegie Hall. All four works will be given on each evening.

title: Brown Assails Alioto
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP)Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that the strike by San Francisco policemen and firemen was outrageous.

title: Pathet Lao's TakeOver Rites Followed Careful Preparations
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 25 The Pathet Lao's takeover of Vientiane, extending its rule throughout Laos, followed weeks of elaborate preparations for the formal ceremonies, according to reports reaching Bangkok from diplomatic circles.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Three New York lawyers Were ordered to turn over records sought by the state of New Jersey in connection with an investigation of alleged municipal corruption in the Camden County community of Lindenwold.

title: Mets Top Padres, on Webb 5Hitter
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 25Hank Webb and Mike Vail, both of whom spent part of the season in the minors with New York's farm club at Tidewater, held center stage tonight as the Mets defeated the San Diego Padres, 40, in the opener of a threegame series.

title: Actors Reject Code
description: A special membership meeting of the Actors Equity Association voted overwhelmingly against a new code for noncommercial productions. The code had come under fire as a threat to Off Off Broadway. Page 36.

title: Medich and Lyle Are Critical Of Yanks' Poor Performance
description: If you took a boll today, George Medich said, I bet most of the guys would vote to go home now.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Folk Musicians From Many Cultures Are High Note of Philadelphia Fete
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 25The annual Philadelphia Folk Festival, which was held for the 14th time last weekend on the rolling fields of Pool's Farm near Schwenksville, northwest of Philadelphia, made several moves this year in what may be indicative of future directions.

title: Study Indicates a Trend to Higher Birth Rate in U.S.
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 25The low birth rate in the United States seems to be bottoming out, and it looks as if the country is about to experience a mini baby boom, according to a team of California demographers.

title: They Ask Decontrol Now
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation's call for gradual decontrol of domestic oil prices was dismissed yesterday by other major petroleum producers as unrealistic at this time.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Orison Marden, a Founder Of Legal Aid Society, Dies
description: Orison S. Marden, a Wall Street corporate lawyer who was a founder of the New York Legal Aid Society and of the International Legal Aid Organization, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 11 Stonehouse Road. Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: MachineTool Orders Declined 19% in July
description: Machine tool orders in the United States fell 19 per cent last month below the June level to $96.2million and were 61 per cent below the $247.4million in the similar 1974 period, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: Brokered Democratic Convention Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The latest change in California's Presidential primary law is the fruit of some intricate Democratic maneuvering with some equally complicated effects in an earlier modification of its old winnertakeall system, California Democrats moved first to Congressionaldistrict primaries in which a strong Presidential contender might sweep up large delegate blocs (and conceivably all 280 delegates from the state) by winning districtbydistrict pluralities.

title: 2 RHODESIAN SIDES CONFER INTO NIGHT AT VICTORIA FALLS
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Tuesday, Aug. 26An extraordinary diplomatic effort was made here yesterday by Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa and President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to force Rhodesian leaders, black and white, to find a new solution to their racial differences. But as the talks adjourned at midnight, it appeared that they might break down.

title: New Yorkers Lawn Bowling Victors
description: BUSK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Aug. 24The New York doubles team of Mary McGowan and Blanche Preene won the Crowe plaque today by taking the final in the Lawn Bowling Association's Eastern Division championship. The winner of the MacIntosh Trophy for fours was the Buck Hills team of Ann Wood, Ellen Ebling, Ruby Mock and Sue

title: N.F.L. Players, Owners Resume Negotiations
description: CHICAGO, Aug, 25 (UPI)Bargainers for National Football League players and club owners agreed on short notice to resume negotiations, tonight as a result of a meeting of player representatives.

title: Shapp Plans Primary Races In at Least Three States
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug' 25 (UPI)Gov. Milton J. Shapp said today that he would enter the nation's first Presidential irimary next year, in New Hampshire, and later those in Massachusetts and Maine.

title: Byrne Gets Into Tennis Togs to Aid Party in Bergen
description: BOGOTA, Aug, 25Governor Byrne lent his person and his tennis racquet today to a major fundraising effort by the resurgent Bergen County Democratic organization.

title: Grandfather of the Film Cartoon Is Honored Here at 96
description: Mickey Mouse and Popeye are a long time gone, and these days their children are doing television commercials or teaching salesmen how to screw their samples together.

title: Donohue Is Buried In Simple Service
description: SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 25The quiet man of auto racing was buried today and Mark Donohue's funeral, fittingly, was simple.

title: New Economic Plan Set by Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25The Argentine Minister of the Economy, Antonio Cafiero, announced tonight a new antirecessionary economic policy aimed at stemming growing unemployment. He said that new Government credits would quickly be made available to businesses and public agencies, even at the risk of added inflation, in a country already suffering from hyper inflation.

title: Chris Evert Routs Miss Wade;
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 25 Virginia Wade needed more than firstaid spray to protect herself against Chris Evert today in the final of the MediQuik women's tennis classic at the Westchester Country Club.

title: BEAME PLAN LATE, IRKING M.A.C. AIDES
description: Mayor Beame failed to complete yesterday the threeyear budget plan that he hopes will convince investors that they should lend more money to New York City, irritating state and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials who waited all day to receive the Mayor's proposal.

title: Portuguese Premier Has Many Foes, But They, Too, Are Deeply Divided
description: LISBON, Aug. 25  The incompatibilities among the extraordinarily wide range of political and social groups lined up against Premier Vasco Gonalves have created the prospect of continued conflict after his expected fall.

title: German Economic Miracle Bypasses Poverty Areas
description: COLOGNE, West Germany Adolphina Kestane is poor. Her poverty makes her one of hundreds of thousands of people one never hears or reads about in West Germany.

title: INDIA'S TOP COURT HEARS GANDHI CASE
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 Lawyers opposed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi went into India's highest court today to open their legal assault on a constitutional amendment that the Government hastily put through this month to end her entanglement with the courts.

title: Timor Refugees, in Australia, Tell of Killings
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 25 Refugees from Portuguese Timor said today that bodies had littered the streets in Dili, the capital.

title: Vilas, Borg Advance to Final
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 25Topseeded Guillermo Vilas, the 1974 Grand Prix winner from Argentina, and 19yearold Bjorn Borg of Sweden, the defending champion, advanced to the final of the $100,000 United States professional tennis championship today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 25With the lightWeight competition out of the way, the bigger oarsmen competing in the fifth world rowing championships at the Holme Pierrepont course worked out today for the competition that begins tomorrow. Among them was the United States eight, coached by Allen Rosenberg, which won the heavyweight title last year. The American boat is manned by the same crew as last year with the exception of Mark Umlasuf. He is in the No. 3 seat, with last year's No. 3, John Everett, moving to the No. 5 oar.

title: Forever Farmland
description: New York State has pioneered the concept of keeping certain parkland areas forever wild. Now Suffolk County, extending from the middle of Long Island all the way to Montauk Point, is considering an equally imaginative conceptforever farmland.

title: DEROSE DROPPING LAWFIRM CLIENT
description: EAST ORANGE, Aug. 25 (AP) The relationship of former State Senator Ralph C. DeRose's law firm with an engineering concern is being terminated, but Governor Byrne declined to comment today on whether he still wanted Mr. DeRose ousted from the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: STOCKS POST GAINS ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the OvertheCounter market rose yesterday in light trading. Bargainbuying continued to be the chief reason for the advances.

title: STRIKING MINERS AND POLICE CLASH
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 25 (AP)A march by 300 striking coal miners became violent today after the police prevented them from illegally entering a oneway street.

title: Schneider Wins Satellite
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 25David Schneider of South Africa won the Eastern satellite tennis tournament today by beating Bill Lloyd of Australia, 64, 63, at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: SCHLESINGER OPENS TALKS WITH KOREANS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tues day, Aug. 26 (UPI)Sersetary of Defense James R. Schlesing er headed an American delega tion that opened a twoday meeting here today with South Korean officials. The meeting Ian annual one, was designed to work out measures to assure security in the postIndochina war era.

title: News Summary and Index
description: As a deadline set for his ouster passed, Premier. Vasco Gonalves of Portugal continued to hold onto office and maneuver for support last night. The High Council of the Revolution issued a statement after a meeting that touched only on secondary matters and omitted mention of the crucial issue that the country has been waiting to be resolved. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: HARRY FROST
description: Harry Frost, former president of the Frost Sand and Gravel Company of New Rochelle, N. Y., who served as a colonel on Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's staff in Burma in World War II, died Saturday in University Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y., and West Palm Beach. Fla.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 20 teenagers who haven't been paid for Youth Services Agency summer jobs picketed the offices of the agency at 354 Broadway. Representative Stephen Solarz said that the pickets were among 5,000 high school students who had not been paid for summer work. spokesman for the agency said the problem had arisen because some employers had failed to fill out proper timecards or had hired more youths than permitted. He said those youths properly registered would be paid when the forms were filled out.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES CITY TRANSIT PLANS
description: An independent research council said yesterday that New York City apparently was operating contrary to rational transportation planning, which requires low fares and increasins service.

title: Canada Tacitly Agrees to Let P.L.O. Unit Attend U.N. Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Aug. 25Canada, which last month blocked the Palestine Liberation Organization from attending a United Nations conference scheduled to be held in Toronto, tacitly agreed today to the group's attendance at a meeting to be held in Vancouver next summer.

title: Soviet Concessions Hinted On 2 Points in Grain Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The Soviet Union, bowing to pressure from American maritime unions, is prepared to pay higher freight rates and give preference to American vessels in shipping grain to Russia, informed Administration sources said today.

title: EGYPT MUST SELL PACT TO HER ALLIES
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 25With an interim accord with Israel apparently in sight, the Government of President Anwar elSadat faces the delicate problem of selling it to the Egyptian people and the Arab world.

title: Simon Criticizes Lockheed For Obscurity on Bribery
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon today chastised the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for apparently not having been forthright with the Government about the bribes that the company has paid overseas.

title: BLUE CROSS ASKS INCREASE OF 23% IN RATE FOR 1976
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York asked the State Insurance Department yesterday for permission to raise premiums for about four million of its hospitalization subscribers by an average of 23 tier cent on Jan. 1.

title: 5th Ave. Association Starts Litter Fight
description: The Fifth Avenue Association has appealed to its midtown business members to cooperate in what it termed the sanitation crisis by clearing away the litter in front of their establishments when the city failed to do so.

title: Propane Controls Sought
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 25President Ford plans to ask Congress soon for temporary authority to continue through next winter Federal controls over deliveries and prices of propane, the bottled gas widely used to heat rural homes.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER WINS A.P. REINSTATEMENT
description: James Moue, a photographer dismissed by The Associated Press after giving information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was ordered reinstated yesterday by an arbitrator, BenJamin Wolf.

title: Equal Rights Amendment Will Get Byrne's Support
description: NEWARK, Aug. 25Governor and Mrs. Byrne are scheduled to mark Women's Equality Day tomorrow at Morven, the Governor's official residence in Princeton, with a ceremony at which they will announce support for the passage of an Equal Rights Amendment to the state constitution.

title: I.C.C. BACKS PLAN FOR CONRAIL LINES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Interstate Commerce Commission put its support today behind the United States Railway Association's plan for Conrail, a new Governmentsponsored system, to take over most of the lines of the Penn Central and five other bankrupt railroads.

title: Board, Angry at Alioto, Seeks a Charter Change
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25This city's legislature laid the legal foundation today to alter substantially the City Charter as the political reverberations of last week's threeday police and firemen's strike continued here.

title: In Memoriam
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: PREMIER IN LISBON DEFIES DEADLINE, CLINGS TO OFFICE
description: LISBON, Tuesday, Aug. 26As a deadline set for his ouster passed, Premier Vasco Gonalves continued to hold onto office and maneuver for support last night.

title: Challenger Is Barred From Ballot in East Harlem
description: A 27yearold Democratic insurgent seeking to unseat Frank G. Rossetti from the district leadership in East Harlem that he has held since 1944 has been ruled off the ballot by a State Supreme Court justice, but will press to have his name reinstated.

title: Fare Rise Upto 25% To Start on Monday On Suburban Rails
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday announced an increase in fares, effective Monday, averaging 23 per cent on the Long Island Rail Road and 25 per cent on the Penn Central's Hudson and Harlem commuter lines.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: American League

title: The Widows of Italy Whose Husbands Emigrate and Return Only as Visitors
description: GRAVINA DI PUGLIA, ItalyAfter a short visit home, Ferdinando Allano decided to pospone his departure a day to have more time with his family. The next morning, he boarded an overcrowded train for a 15hour journey to Stuttgart, Germany. He stood in the aisle the whole way. On arrival, because of the extra day spent at home, he went straight from the railroad station to his job as a miner.

title: Getty Museum's Roman Styling, Once Criticized, Draws Crowds
description: MALIBU, Calif.  It isn't every day that they build a Roman villa beside the highway, even in Southern California, so when the J. Paul Getty Museum was finished last year, eyebrows were raised in art and architecture circles across the country. A number of critics were scandalized at the idea of erecting a fake Roman villa in the nineteenseventies. Others accepted the basic premise but quibbled about the building's authenticity. But the public laved it, and while the controversy still rages in professional circles, attendance at the museum has been so high that visitors are now being accepted only by reservation.

title: Carey Called Willing to Aid Teachers
description: Governor Carey has reportedly told Albert Shanker, president of the teachers' union, that when the crunch comes, the state may be able to come up with additional money to meet some of the teachers' contract demands.

title: SPANISH POLITICIANS ASK URGENT CHANGE
description: MADRID, Aug. 25 (UPI)A group of influential Spanish politicians on the centerright today demanded profound and urgent changes to turn the country from authoritarian government to democracy.

title: State Department Criticized by Head Of Voice of America
description: MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 25 (AP)The director of the Voice of America said today that the State Department exerts intolerable pressure to control parts of the organization's worldwide news broadcasts.

title: I.C.C.'s Chief Seeks Legislation To Speed Agency's Proceedings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Clearly stung by accusations that it is mired in paperwork and by calls for deregulation of the transportation industry, the Interstate Commerce Commission has revealed that it will ask for legislation to speed up its proceedings.

title: 24 Communities Aid Newsprint Recycling
description: BOGOTA, Aug. 25 (UPI) A municipal newspaper collection program, started in Ridgewood two years ago, has spread to 23 other New Jersey communities, officials said today. It is underway in such communities as Bergenfield, Bloomfield, Clifton, Englewood, Hackensack, Hopewell, Union City and West Orange.

title: Propane Controls Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25President Ford plans to ask Congress soon for temporary authority to continue through next winter Federal controls over deliveries and prices of propane, the bottled gas widely used to heat rural homes.

title: Montreal Transit Strike
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (AP)About 1,000 bus and subway drivers, demanding pay increases, voted overwhelmingly today to continue their strike until the next union meeting, on Thursday. The action means the city will be without public trans?? at least until then.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOREVER YOUNG After more than 40 years, the popularity of The Little Rascals or Our Gang comedies (the screen series used both titles remains undimmed. A recent survey indicated that the vintage ??medy shorts rank third in syndication popularity with young television watchers.

title: Clothing Workers to Apply for Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, contending that imports of men's suits, jackets and slacks have increased rapidly, said today that the union would apply under the 1974 Trade Act for weekly cash payments from the Federal Treasury for 20,000 clothing workers.

title: The Russians and Market Strength
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.The Soviet Union's surprise intrusion upon the world grain scene as a major buyer for the second time in three years has resulted in a significant revision in the American free market system that is not at all understood or appreciated for its considerable importance.

title: Rockefeller Would Back FordReagan
description: MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 26 (UPI) Vice President Rockefeller said tonght he would support the 1976 Republican ticket if he were replaced by Ronald Rea. Ran, former Governor of California.

title: U.S. Linking Airlift Of Angola Refugees To Shifts in Lisbon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The United States has advised Portugal that it is prepared to help airlift 300,000 refugees from Angola, but has imposed a major condition: that there be a government in Lisbon that Washington feels it can work with.

title: $5Million in Heroin Seized
description: MIAMI, Aug. 26 (AP)Officials arrested two Los Angeles residents and seized $5million worth of heroin at Miami International Airport, a United States Customs spokesman said today. The spokesman said 13.6 pounds of heroin had been found in a suitcase picked up by Barbara Gaston, 25 years old, and Charles Kyle, 24, from the baggage area yesterday, after they got off a flight from Nassau, Bahamas.

title: U. S. Tennis Starts in Conflict
description: Rain delays at other tournaments forced major scheduling revisions in the start of the United States Open tennis championships today at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: ANACONDA URGES REBUFF OF CRANE
description: The Anaconda Company formally opposed yesterday an exchange offer made Aug. 7 by the Crane Company for five million shares, or 22.6 per cent of the big copper company's common stock. In a letter to shareholders signed by John B. M. Place, Anaconda's chairman and president, the company said the proposed offer (under which Anaconda shareholders would receive a $25 10year subordinated Crane debenture for each Anaconda common share) is not in the best interest of Anaconda and its shareholders.

title: BLACK MUSICIAN IS DENIED TENURE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26A committee of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra voted overwhelmingly last night to deny tenure to Elayne Jones, one of the few black musicians in the country playing regularly with a symphony, on the ground that she was incompetent.

title: FORD, MEANY FAIL TO AGREE ON GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26President Ford met for more than 90 minutes today with George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., and five other union leaders, seeking an end to a union boycott against grain shipments to the Soviet Union, but the day's discussions ended in a deadlock.

title: Japan's Kohjin, Ltd., on Brink of Collapse
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26A major maker of paper, chemicals and synthetic fibersKohjin, Ltd.tottered on the brink of collapse today, threatening to become perhaps Japan's biggest postwar business failure.

title: Malaysia Monument Bombed
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Four Communist guerrillas today damaged Malaysia's national monument with, a bomb and exchanged shots with the police before escaping, a police spokesman said. The monument commemorates those who died fighting Communist guerrillas. It is patterned after the World War II marine monument and is by the same artist, Felix de Weldon of the United States.

title: Byrne and Carey Urge Rights Amendments' Passage
description: The Governors of New York and New Jersey urged passage of equal rights amendments in their states yesterday as Women's Equality Day was marked around the country by demonstrations both for and against Federal and state legislation guaranteeing equal rights for women.

title: 10 Invited to Marlboro Cup
description: With the ink barely dry on the invitations, six of the 10 owners asked to enter thoroughbreds in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park on Sept. 13, said yesterday they expected to be represented. Spoken for were such outstanding performers as the Lazy F. Ranch's Forego, the 1974 Horse of the Year; John L. Greer's Foolish Pleasure, this season's Kentucky Derby winner, and Mrs. Ethel Kirkland's Ancient Title, the top performer from the West Coast who came to Saratoga early this month and captured the prestigious Whitney Handicap while carrying the top weight of 128 pounds.

title: Books of The Times
description: Grande dame is the association the name Edith Wharton most readily arouses. Wealthy, cultivated, aloof, imperious, formidable  a string of other adjectives quickly attach themselves to her person. Yet as one's recollection of her booksThe Age of Innocence, The Custom of the Country, Ethan Frome and others stirs, one begins to recall the sense one had of a lambent intelligence behind them of a creative energy, a sure craftsmanship and a shrewd satirical view of morals and

title: Contract Awards
description: The M. W. Kellogg Company, Houston, Tex., a division of Pullman, Inc., announced yesterday that Techmashimport, the company responsible for chemical plant purchases for Soviet industry, has signed contracts for four 1,500toaday fertilizer ammonia plants. Kellogg will provide process design and engineering technology while the Toyo Engineering Corporation of Japan will furnish engineering and supplies. The total erected cost of the project was reported to be $245million, with completion scheduled in 1979.

title: State's Constitutional Power Over City
description: The power of the Mayor of New York City is among the broadest of any government executive in the country and much of his power comes from his ability to administer the city's budget. Governor Carey's plan to dramatically enlarge the state's role in the city's fiscal affairs would cut into this precious power given the Mayor by the State constitution and City Charter.

title: Off Off Stays On
description: The footlights will continue to glow in New York City's 140 Off Off Broadway theaters, thanks to an extraordinary display of union democracy and professional determination by hundreds of actors and actresses who make this city the most vigorous theatrical arena in the world. Instead of bowing to an unrealistic set of rules imposed by the leadership of Actors Equity Association, the performers overruled their union and voted for the shows to go on.

title: Notes on People
description: Donald (Deke) Slayton beat the odds yesterday as cancer specialists removed a tiny, benign nodule from his left lung. Before the twohour operation they had told the 51yearold astronaut that because of his age and his 30 years as a cigarette smoker, the chances were better than 50 per cent that the lesion was malignant. Mr. Slayton is expected to remain 10 to 12 days in Houston's University of Texas medical center but to be ready by Sept. 22 to make the twoweek Soviet tour scheduled for the three Americans who were on the ApolloSoyuz mission. Doctors also predicted that Mr. Slayton would qualify for areturn to flight status.

title: Nessen Sees Ford's Trips As Not Keyed to His Race
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The White House, citing terrible political liabilities of incumbency, said today that President Ford's extensive crosscountry travels bore no direct relation to his candidacy for a full term as President.

title: Italian Jail Rebellion Quelled
description: ROME, Aug. 26 (AP)Nearly 1,000 policemen stormed into Rome's Rebibbia Jail today under a barrage of teargas grenades dropped by helicopters and quelled a nightlong rebellion by convicts demanding full implementation of a prison reform act. Authorities said 13 convicts were injured.

title: Reese Is Victor In a 3Mile Run
description: Darryii Reese of the New York Pioneer Club won the open threemile run in 14 minutes 48.8 seconds today in the final meet of the Road Runners Club of New York summer program at Queensboro Community College, Bayside, Queens.

title: Portuguese Reported to Evacuate Timor
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Aug. 27The Governor of Portuguese Timor, Lemos Pires, and members of his administration have evacuated the capital of Dili, and established themselves on the nearby island of Atauro, according to a spokesman for the Australian Foreign Affairs Department.

title: Plans for Container Cargo
description: DURBAN, South Africa (AP) South Africa will spend $300million by 1978 on harbor, rail and road facilities to handle container cargo, the government reported.

title: U.S. Eight Fails in First Try
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 26The men's world rowing championships opened today and the biggest surprises occurred in the heats for eights, the most prestigious event of the regatta.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Golda Meir Demands Deletion of Sentence in Book
description: Former Premier Golda Meir of Israel has now asked Harper's Magazine Presi to retract a sentence about her in a book it has published entitled The Education of Lev Navrozov.

title: WOMAN IS CHARGED IN SONINLAW DEATH
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 26 (UPI)Gladys Pounds did not get along with her soninlaw, John F. Yuhas, and so she hired a contract killer to murder him, the police charged today.

title: Chou Meets With Sihanouk
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The Chinese Premier, Chou Enlai, today met with Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the titular head of state of Cambodia, in the Peking bospital where Mr. Chou has been staying, Hhinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported.

title: Byrne and Carey Ask Passage Of Equal Rights Amendments
description: The Governors of New York and New Jersey urged passage of equal rights amendments in their states yesterday as Women's Equality Day was marked around the country by demonstrations both for and against Federal and state legislation guaranteeing equal rights for women.

title: People and Business
description: Nearly thre years ago Jean L. Loyer left Pechiney Ugine Kuhlman, the big French metals and chemical company, to become president and chief executive officer of the Howmet Corporation, based in Greenwich, Conn., in which his old employer had acquired 50 per cent interest.

title: Evolution in Tennessee
description: A halfcentury after John Thomas Scopes was convicted of the misdemeanor of teaching evolution in a Tennessee high school, two courts in that state have decided at long last that the subject is not really one for legislators.

title: U.S. Linking Airlift Of Angola Refugees To Shifts in Lisbon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The United States has advised Portugal that it is prepared to help airlift 300,000 refugees from Angola, but has imposed a major condition: that there be a government in Lisbon that Washington feels it can work with.

title: Cottage Cheese: The Issue Isn't So Quiet Any More
description: In a recent article in The New York Times, Charlotte Curtis wrote that nobody seemed to ever talk about cottage cheese. Judging by the letters that the article drew, some of which are excerpted below, perhaps it is now about to become a great issue.

title: About Education
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 26 Connecticut's Education Commissioner, Mark R. Shedd, would like to net all highschool students in the state out of their classrooms for at least a year, for training in the community as jobholders and citizens.

title: Coal Miners Close Their Own Union Offices in West Virginia as Wildcat Strike Enters Its Fourth Week
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 26A wildcat strike by nearly 40,000 coal miners took on extraordinary dimensions today when strikers picketed and closed their own union's offices.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Aug. 26 (UPI)The Canadian Grand Prix, scheduled for Sept. 21 at Mosport Park, was canceled today amid suggestions that organizers of the United States Grand Prix may face legal action for dealing with the group that forced cancellation for the Formula One event. The race was canceled because the promoters could not come to terms with the Formula One Constructors' Association, which supplies most of the cars on the Grand Prix circuit. The Mosport president, Harvey Hudes, said he was consulting lawyers in New York and London with a view bringing a lawsuit. He implied that the constructors' association and the organizers of the Watkins Glen, N.Y., race, scheduled Oct. 5, would face legal action, either jointly or separately. The constructors and the Glen reached an independent agreement. Hudes said there would be racing Sept. 21 at Mosport and the day would be called the Canadian Grand Free. Spectators will have free access to the track for other races. Hudes said he found only six carstwo each from the Hesketh, Penske and Ensign teams, who are not members of the association that were prepared to complete.

title: City, Citing Prostitution, Moves on Belmore Hotel
description: The city began legal proceedings yesterday in an effort to clean up or close down the Belmore Hotel, scene of the slaying of a 15yearold prostitute last February and long regarded by the police as a haunt for prostitutes.

title: RHODESIA LEADERS BREAK OFF TALKS
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Aug. 26Talks between Rhodesia's whiteminority Government and black nationalist leaders here broke down today, and each side blamed the other.

title: Waldheim Issues Appeal
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Aug. 26  Secretary General. Waldheim made an urgent appeal tonight for an end of the fighting in Portuguese Timor. He called on those involved the conflict to enter into negotiations in order to achieve a peaceful settlement.

title: Gasoline Price Rise Is Set By B.P.'s West German Unit
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Aug. 26 (UPI)The West German subsidiary of British Petroleum Company, Ltd., today increased the price of gasoline sold at its service stations by 4.4 cents a gallon.

title: O'Dwyer Urges $1 Bridge Tolls To Sade 35Cent Transit Fare
description: Paul O'Dwyer, President of the City Council, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation for $1 roundtrip tolls on 12 East River and Harlem River bridges, which he estimated would yield $125million a year.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CONSUMER NOTES
description: Doityourselfers who repair their own plaster or plaster board walls should be aware of recent research indicating that some commonly available spackling compounds contain asbestos, a substance that has been linked to fatal cancers and serious lung diseases.

title: FRUIT CROPS HURT IN MICHIGAN STORM
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 26 (UPI)Severe storms that lashed western Michigan over the weekend caused more than $4million damage to harvestready peach, plum and pear crops, agriculture officials reported today.

title: South Korean Farmer Abducted In DMZ by 2 Northern Soldiers
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 27Two North Korean solders, armed with AK47 rifles, intruded into southern part of the Demilitarized Zone yesterday and kidnapped a farmer, the United Nations Command announced this morning.

title: G.M. Raises '76 Truck Prices by 7.3%
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26The General Motors Corporation said today it was raising 1976 truck prices an average of 7.3 per cent, higher than its previously announced increase of 4.4 per cent for new model cars.

title: VIENTIANE REGIME ISSUES A PROGRAM
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  The new administrative regime set up in Vientiane over the weekend by the proCommunist iPathet Lao today issued a profi gram to serve the real interests of the people and rapidly normalize the situation in the capital.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 27, 1975

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 27, 1975

title: Strong Quake in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 26 (UPI)  A strong earthquake ??ook northern Chile and southern Peru late yesterday, the police reported today. No injuries or damage were reported.

title: Stone Takes High Jump With 75
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug, 26 (AP)Dwight Stones of the United States, the world record  holder, scored an easy high jump victory today in an international track and field meet by leaping 7 feet 5 inches to beat Walter Boller of West Germany by a margin of 4 inches. Steve Williams, Al Feuerbach and Casey Carrigan of the United States also recorded triumphs.

title: A 13c Rate for FirstClass Mail Reported Favored by U.S. Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Postal Rate Commission has overruled the recommendation of an administrative law judge and opened the way for the United States Postal Service to raise first  class letter rates to 13 cents from 10, Administration sources said tonight.

title: About New York
description: Unlike most natural spectacles, the manmade profile of New York is a constantly changing montage of peaks and valleys, and there is always the question of how it can best be seen.

title: SOVIET ASKS UNITY IN FEUD WITH CHINA
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26The Soviet Union has urged a policy of smashing Maoism and has warned that any Communists remaining neutral will be serving the antiMarxist interests of Peking.

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES CITE SUBSIDY LOSS
description: ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP)An organization of private colleges said today that failure by the state to increase subsidies to independent schools had forced students to aattend public colleges and universities.

title: A Way to Keep Cream Fresher
description: Cream that has been pasteurized by a new method that extends the cream's shelf life in the store at only slight loss in taste has been introduced in food stores here.

title: T.P.C. Golf Purse Raised for 1976
description: LAUDERHILL, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP)The Professional Golfers' Association Tournament Player Championship, to be held in conjunction with the Jackie GleasonInverrary Classic next year, will offer a total purse of $300,000, officials said today.

title: Woodlands Being Converted
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. (UPI) The State Conservation Commission says Missouri lost nearly 1.5 million acres of woodland in the last 10 years because of conversion to other uses.

title: LESTER R. COHN
description: Lester R. Cohn, president and chairman of the Jamaica Food Company, Inc., institutional wholesale grocers, died Monday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L. I. He was 61 and lived in Manhasset.

title: London Extends Deadline For Convention in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Britain extended a November deadline today for the allparty convention of Ulster politicians to work out peaceful powersharing for the government.

title: A ROLE FOR LEVITT
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame announced last night that they had reached agreement on the creation of a new panel, consisting of themselves and State Controller Arthur Levitt, to supervise the city's fiscal affairs.

title: Violations Charged To 23 Food Places By City Inspectors
description: The Health Department has named 23 more food businesses including the Benihana Palace of West 44th Street as having failed their second healthcode inspection, and has warned that they face closing orders if the violations persist upon a third and final visit by inspectors. The names of the establishments and the actions follow:

title: New Hampshire Rivals Seeking Votes In a Senate Contest as Close as Ever
description: CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 26There are 21 days left in the nation's longest, most drawnout election campaign, and John A. Durkin and Louis C. Wyman are racing through New Hampshire, from factory gates to picnics to county fairs.

title: DOLLAR IS LOWER IN EUROPE TRADING
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 26 (UPI)The United States dollar fell today against all European currencies except the lire. The dollar had opened higher after steady increases over the weekend and yesterday.

title: Activist Nuns Are Changing Image Of a Sisterhood in Lovely Isolation
description: SAN FRANCISCO  I thought I was joining the convent for the glory of God, Sister Catherine Pinkerton said of her entrance into the sisterhood 32 years ago.

title: Union Seeks Benefits
description: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, contending that imports of men's clothing have increased rapidly, said yesterday in Washington that the union would apply under the 1974 Trade Act for weekly cash payments from the Federal Treasury for 20,000 clothing workers who had been laid off or had their working hours cut. Page 59.

title: What to Do With All That Money
description: The people at Philip Morris, Inc., had a problem. Because the United States Public Health Service had decided smoking cigarettes might be bad for people, the Federal Government had put a stop to advertising Marlboros, Camels and Luckies on the air, leaving the manufacturers stuck with millions of dollars that they had formerly given to the radio and television industries. The Winston cigarette people had eased their problem by giving rodeo cowboys some of the loot they used to spend on broadcasting ungrammatical doggerel, but nobody at 100 Park Avenue had come up with a solution and the office was getting wormy with unused money.

title: Pampered Animals Star at Farmers'
description: FLEMINGTON, Aug. 26It baa's; it moo's; it spins around wildly In circles. It glows in the dark. 'It is the 118th annual Flemington Agricultural Fair which opened here today and runs through Labor Day.

title: Mississippi Democrats Choose A Working Man's Candidate
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 26Cliff Finch, a Wallacestyle working man's candidate, won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Mississippi in a runoff primary today.

title: No Repentance For the City's Profligacies
description: By all means let us nave some serious belttightening if that is Kankakee's condition for buying our bonds. But there is another, implicit, proviso. What is also wanted is some kind of mea culpa: repentance for past profligacies and illconsidered programs.

title: Softening Is Seen In Kissinger Stand On Poorer Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26When Secretary of State Kissinger addresses the United Nations General Assembly next week, his aides expect him to take a more conciliatory stand toward demands from developing nations for a greater share of the world's wealth.

title: In El Salvador, The Peasants Live Like Serfs in Europe 400 Years Ago
description: AGUILARES, El Salvador Luis Garcia wandered back from his tiny cornfield to the shack where his wife was preparing a lunch of salted tortillas. Last year's corn crop has been eaten and this year's is still two months away. The money earned cutting cane on the nearby plantations has also been spent and the Garcias are going hungry.

title: MidSeptember Signing Seen
description: BONN, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The signing of a new interim agreement between Israel and Egypt has been provisionally scheduled for the middle of next month, the Israeli Transport Minister, Gad Yaacobi, said here today.

title: NONALIGNED BLOC ADDS 4 MEMBERS
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 26  The nonaligned bloc appeared to drift closer to the Communist nations today as its conference of foreign ministers voted to give full membership to North Vietnam and North Korea.

title: M.B. GARDNER, 77, ADMIRAL, IS DEAD
description: Adm. Matthias B. Gardner. who retired in 1956 as Deputy Chief of Naval Operations, died Sunday at the Naval Hospital in Pensacola, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Pensacola.

title: SOVIET SENTENCES 2 JEWS TO PRISON
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26  A Ukrainian Jewish activist who was prevented last month by the police in Odessa from traveling to Moscow to see delegation of visiting American Senators has been sentenced to two years in prison in the incident.

title: Alton Reports Progress
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 26Foreign Minister Yigal AlIon of Israel said today that remarkable progress had been made in the last two days toward the conclusion of a new Sinai agreement with Egypt under Secretary of State Kissinger's auspices.

title: Books of The Times
description: Grande dame is the association the name Edith Wharton most readily arouses. Wealthy, cultivated, aloof, imperious, formidable  a string of other adjectives quickly attach themselves to her person. Yet as one's recollection of her booksThe Age of Innocence, The Custom of the Country, Ethan Frome and others stirs, one begins to recall the sense one had of a lambent intelligence behind them of a creative energy, a sure craftsmanship and a shrewd satirical view of morals and manners.

title: 2 Gunmen in Queens Seize A Van Containing $174,000
description: A security van, reportedly containing $174.000 in cash, was hijacked by two gunmen yesterday as its driver approached an intersection in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: ILLINOIS ON ALERT FOR ENCEPHALITIS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26The recent encephalitis outbreak in Mississippi may have spread to Illinois, the state Director of Public Health warned today.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: John S. Billings of Life Is Dead; First Managing Editor Was 77
description: John Shaw Billings, the first managing editor of Life magazine and retired director for all Time Inc. publications, died yesterday in Augusta, Ga. He was 77 years old and had been hospitalized with a fractured hip, and suffered complications, including kidney failure and pneumonia.

title: TAX CUT EXTENSION FAVORED BY ULLMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Representative Al Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, proposed today making permanent the $7.7billion in tax cuts for individuals enacted this April.

title: Mrs. Abzug Backs Israel
description: A dispatch in The New York Times yesterday reported that 50 members of the United States Congress had issued a statement voicing disapproval of any action to expel or suspend Israel from the United Nations. Representative Bella Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan's West Side, whose name did not appear on the list of signers in that report, added her signature to the statement.

title: Hunter Tops A's 4th Time
description: In the brown appointment book Manager Billy Martin keeps on his desk, the one in which he lists his starting pitcher tot each game, the name Hunter appears every fourth day for the rest of the season. The Yankees can thank goodnessor Charles O. Finley, who most people will say is anything but goodnessfor Catfish Hunter.

title: Byrne Gives Legislators Plan For Borrowing of $883Million
description: and to put it on the ballot in November.

title: QUICK MUSICAL PACE BY TODD RUNDGREN
description: Todd Rundgren's Utopia group was lowkey in appearance (Mr. Rundgren has been known to flaunt green hair at times) at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Monday. Attention was obviously on the music this time around. With a large group including three backup singers and some sophisticated keyboards, Mr. Rundgren was able to move quickly through a lot of different musical moods.

title: A ROLE FOR LEVITT
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame announced last night that they had reached agreement on the creation of a new panel, consisting of themselves and State Controller Arthur Levitt, to take control of the city's fiscal affairs.

title: Governor Was Pessimistic
description: LISBON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) The Governor of Portuguese Timor has told the Lisbon Government he can hold on only until tomorrow and after that I do not know.

title: Nastase Conquers Hewitt; borg Is Victor Over Vilas
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 26Ilie Nastase, the. fiery Rumanian, ignored poor court conditions and Bob. Hewitt's temper to defeat the South African in the final of the $50,000 Tennis Week open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club tonight.

title: Failure at the Falls
