description: The white members of Rhodesia's Parliament who cheered Prime Minister Smith's announcement that his talks with African leaders about the country's political future had failed are living in a fool's paradise. In a country where blacks outnumber whites 24 to 1a country surrounded by blackruled states except for narrow border with South Africait is an expression of irrationality to reject negotiations in favor of an armed showdown.

title: Rice of Red Sox Is Top dh at 287
description: Billy Williams of the Oakland A's paced the American League's designated hitters last week, hitting .350 and scoring six runs. The former Chicago Cub star, who has appeared in 100 or more games for 15 consecutive seasons, had 7 hits in 20 times at bat and socked two home runs in a game against the Milwaukee Brewers last Saturday.

title: Japan's Output Index Up
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Japan's mining and industrial production index rose 0.8 per cent in July to 111.4 (base equals 1970) compared with June's revised 110.5. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. July's level was 11.2 per cent below the 125.4 reached in July, 1974, it

title: Governor Seeking Agreement On Plan by Legislative Leaders
description: ALBANY, Aug. 26Governor Carey hopes to have the complete agreement of Republican and Democratic legislative leaders before they convene here for a special session on the city's fiscal crisis, aides of the Governor said tonight.

title: SUICIDE NOTE LEFT BY LOCKHEED OFFICER
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP) Business pressures led to the suicide of Lockheed Aircraft's treasurer, the victim's brother said today. Norman Waters said a note left by his brother, Robert, would not be released to the public, but said, The gist of it was that it was business pressures. His last words werfe, I'm just too tired to go on Mr. Waters said. The note was personal and we have decided not to release it.

title: OPEC Meeting Ends
description: VIENNA, Aug. 26 (UPI)Financial experts of the Organization of Petroleum exporting countries today ended a weeklong meeting to prepare next month's decision of oil ministers on a possible new price of oil.

title: Return of Bikinians Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)The return of 150 islanders to Bikini, the site of 23 nuclear tests over a 12year period, has been delayed pending further analysis of a radiological survey, the Interior Department said today. Residents were moved from Bikini in the Marshall Islands before nuclear testing began in 1946 and were temporarily settled on Kili Island. The tests ended in 1958.

title: Hunter Crown To Happy Days
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Aug. 26 Karen Gilder's Happy Days accomplished a rare equestrian feat today by winning the local working hunter championship without the benefit of a blue ribbon at the Catamount Hunt horse show.

title: 10 Seized in Racial Clashes In Boston Housing Project
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP)The police arrested 10 persons today after a series of clashes between blacks and whites that began last night at the Maverick Square Housing project in the East Boston section.

title: The Fed and City Debt
description: Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in reaffirming the Fed's readiness to serve as a lender of last resort to private commercial banks whose liquidity has been jeopardized by investing in New York City obligations, has helped to brace public confidence in the ability of the national economy and the banking system to withstand the shock that would result if New York City defaulted.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CLEVELAND (AL)Claimed Bob Reynolds, righthanded relief pitcher, from Detroit on waivers.

title: U.S. TRADE SHOWS ANOTHER SURPLUS
description: The Commerce Department reported yesterday that although increased oil imports eroded the nation's foreign trade surplus in July, the account remained in surplus by nearly $1billion for the month. The unexpected surplusthe fourth largest ever recordedoomes at a time when virtually all of the nation's leading competitors are suffering severe declines in their own trade balances.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 7:55 P.M.)

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Tuesday, August 26.

title: Kuwait Official Predicts 10% Rise in U.S. Oil Price
description: COLUMBIA. S. C., Aug. 26 (UPI)The Finance Minister of the Arab Sheikdom of Kuwait predicted today that, as a result of the declining United States dollar value, oil prices will jump 10 per cent when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets next month.

title: Softening Is Seen In Kissinger Stand On Poorer Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26When Secretary of State Kissinger addresses the United Nations General Assembly next week, his aides expect him to take a more conciliatory stand toward demands from developing nations for a greater share of the world's wealth.

title: Regrets in Autobiography
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 26 (UPI)Mrs. Meir says she will always regret ignoring the warnings of my own heart and not ordering a mobilization of Israeli armed forces a day before the October war erupted in 1973.

title: New State Lifeline . . .
description: Governor Carey is taking a direct hand in operating control of New York City through his agreement with Mayor Beame to share membership in a new panel created to manage the city's fiscal affairs. State Controller Levitt will round out the threeman rescue team.

title: Yacht Race Won By Schoonmaker
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UPI)James Schoonmaker of Miami won today the third of six yacht races in the World Star Class championships on Lake Michigan.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Bangladesh in The New York Times last Thursday incorrectly quoted a message from President Khondakar Mushtaque Ahmed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India. It should have said Mr. Mushtaque Ahmed had conveyed profound regards.

title: Poor Nutrition Said to Lead To Viruses and Other Ills
description: AUSTIN, Tex. (UPI)People with poor diets have more colds, flutype viruses and other ailments, according to state health officials.

title: Philadelphia Fire Burns Out
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP)The fire at the Gulf Oil Company refinery in south Philadelphia was officially declared out today after nine days. Seven firemen were killed and three others critically burned.

title: JAPANESE RAILWAY SEEKS FINANCIAL AID
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP)  The Japan National Railway asked today for Government intervention to help solve its accumulating deficits now amounting to $7.49billion.

title: PARLEY PLANNED ON GAS SHORTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Fourteen governors have been invited to the White House for a briefing Thursday on how bad this winter's natural gas shortage could be in their states.

title: Married Women Need Not Use Surname Of Spouses, According to Hyland Ruling
description: TRENTON, Aug. 26  The State Attorney General ruled today that there was nothing in the state's statutes to require woman to change their names upon marriage.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
Ford Will Ask Congress To Revamp Trucking Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) President Ford is preparing to send Congress legislation that would overhaul Federal regulations governing the nation's trucking industry.

title: Import ShockAbsorber
description: The one conspicuous failure of .the Trade Expansion Act, which sparked the Kennedy Round of tariff cuts more than a decade ago, was its ineffectiveness in providing promised financial relief for workers and businesses injured by import competition. In contrast to that failure, the first four and a half months of adjustment allowances to workers made jobless by imports under the 1974 trade act have already seen the payment level rise to an annual rate in excess of a third of a billion dollars.

title: Israel Sees Sabotage Effort
description: I UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26Israel charged today that the Palestine Liberation Organization had stepped up terrorist attacks against Israel to sabotage the peace efforts of Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: F. D. A. Warns Birth Pill Raises Heart Attack Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Women who take birth control pills face an increased risk of heart attack, the Food and Drug Administration has told, doctors in a drug bulletin mailed to the medical profession.

title: RHODESIA LEADERS BREAK OFF TALKS
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Rhodesia, Aug. 26Talks between Rhodesia's whiteminority Government and black nationalist leaders here broke down today, and each side blamed the other.

title: Oil Delivery Decline
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Aug. 26 (AP)  Deliveries of Alberta crude oil to United States refineries are expected to average 600.184 barrels a day in September, down 1.1 per cent from August, according to the province's Energy Resources Conservation Board. Total deliveries to United States and Canadian refineries are expected to rise 1.5 per cent to an average of 1.43 million barrels a day, with Canadian deliveries up 3.5 per cent to 832,415 barrels a day.

title: 2 POINTS CLARIFIED FOR KENT STATE JURY
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (UPI) Jurors in the $46million Kent State University civil trial found today two more errors in the wording of the 76page instruction given them by Federal District Judge Don J. Young.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Gain Greater Role in Mideast
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26The United States seems destined to emerge from the present negotiations for a new EgyptianIsraeli accord as the major outside power in the Middle East, in the view of Arab, Israeli and American officials.

title: Democrats Likely to Pick New York Today for '76
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26New York City appeared today to hold a decisive edge over Los Angeles in a long and close competition for the Democratic party's 1976 convention.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Amstar Corporation and Sucrest Corporation announced yesterday a reduction in the price of sugar 30 cents per 100 pounds bringing the cost down to $24.85. The Industrial Chemicals and Plastics division of the American Cyanamid Company raised the price of aluminum sulfate. The price of liquid aluminum sulfate will be $8 a ton higher in the South and $10 a ton higher in the North. Dry aluminum sulfate will be priced $10 a ton higher in both areas.

title: Stossel of WCBSTV Loses Consumer Job; Lack of Funds Cited
description: John Stossel has been relieved of his duties as consumer reporter for WCBSTV.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the OvertheCounter market resumed their downward trend yesterday in very dull trading after Monday's rise. Bargain buying led to the decline.

title: Reaction to Dacca Coup Subsides
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 26In the first round of diplomatic sparring and posturing after the coup d'tat in Bangladesh, the Soviet Union and India took quite a negative view of the change in leadership. Now, they seem to have moderated their position, and so, apparently, have the Pakistanis, who at first could scarcely conceal their satisfaction.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Three on Mountain Saved
description: MOOSE, Wyo., Aug. 26 (AP) Three men were reported in good condition today after being rescued from near the top of 12,594foot Mount Moran where they were trapped for two days and two nights by a late summer snowstorm. The men were identified as William Growney, 21 years old, of Omaha, Neb.; Terry Thompson, 21, of Columbus, Ohio, and Mike Collantine, 20, of Milwaukee.

title: Food and Foreign Policy
description: ATHENSRussia, China and the United States are all involved in the politics of food. The Soviet grain crop has fallen far short of requirements with the result that Moscow is buying heavily overseas. Likewise, there has been a slowdown in the Chinese rate of agricultural growth.

title: Shubert Seeksto Widen Theater Chain
description: With prospects for the Broadway theater the brightest in more than 20 years, the Shubert Organization is seeking to buy more theaters here if it can get permission from the Department of Justice.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Hackensack Water Company and the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission have proposed building a $50million pipeline between Wayne and Oradell to carry 80 million gallons of water a day to communities in Passaic, Bergen, Hudson and Essex Counties. The project would involve pumping Passaic River water to the Wanaque Reservoir and the Oradell Reservoir, instead of allowing it to flow freely into the Newark Bay. The State Water Policy and Supply Council is scheduled to review the proposal Sept. 8 in Trenton.

title: A Decrease in Food Prices
description: The typical New York City family saved 75 cents1 per centon its food bill last week, as food prices, led by the prices of beef and potatoes, dropped substantially in the city's markets.

title: In Memoriam
description: HEITLERKurt, August 76, 1949. In ever lasting memory of a dearly beloved Husband. Son and Brother, now in Heaven. KURTOne of Nature's Noblemen, In THOUGHT and DEED. CARLYN BYCK HEITLER

title: Bonn M.P. Donates Sum To Pilot in Border Episode
description: BONN, Aug. 26 (Reuters)A West German Member of Parliament has offered 1,000 (marks, about $375, to the American pilot Barry Meeker to repair a helicopter he used to lift three East Germans out of Czechoslovakia nine days ago.

title: Heavy Rains in Cleveland
description: A second day of drenching rains flooded Cleveland's lowlying areas yesterday, temporarily closing major roadways and causing at least one major intersection to collapse. At least six persons were injured, according to United Press International.

title: WINE TALK
description: There are all kinds of wine tastings. Some are very simple and serve to introduce newcomers to various kinds of wine: a couple of reds, a couple of whites, a sweet wine and a ros.

title: TAXEXEMPTS GET A GOOD RECEPTION
description: Several new taxexempt offerings were well received in the credit markets yesterday, where prices and trading activity generally picked up from Monday's levels. In the Government market, for example, prices of six  month Treasury bills improved the equivalent of 10 basis points, a basis point being one hundredth of a percentage point. In Government coupon issues, prices were up  point in the twoyear maturity range with gains ranging to  to  in the longer maturities.

title: Meeting Site Changed
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 26 (AP)A meeting of OPEC finance ministers that had been set for Caracas will be held next week in Washington instead, Venezuela's Finance Ministry said today.

title: SPY PANEL TO DELAY NIXON TAPE ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities has decided to postpone the deadline on its subpoenas for tape recordings and documents from former President Richard M. Nikon's files, a committee spokesman said today.

title: Market Place
description: More than onethird of the market value of the Copper Range Company's stock was wiped away yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Assailed in West on Plan to Sell Water of Upper Missouri River
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Aug. 26Montana and Wyoming ranchers, farmers, environmentalists, and office holders descended on a United States Senate subcommittee hearing here today to denounce Federal plans for selling what is regarded as the West's most precious resource water.

title: Gillespie Praises U.S. Policy
description: TORONTO, Aug. 26 (UPI)Trade Minister Alistair Gillespie applauded recent modification of the United States' Cuban trade policy today but suggested it could have been modified more.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: MET. G.A. OPEN

title: Grant to Eliminate Its Appliance Line For Everyday Items
description: In a move to place its merchandising emphasis on soft lines, the W. T. Grant Company an nounced yesterday that it would phase out its major appliance product line from all its stores commencing Sept. 15.

title: 5 Earthquakes an Hour Detected Off California
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 26 Up to five small earthquakes occur every hour of every day in an underwater basin off the northern coast of California, according to new evidence from the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Vincent Tracy, an ExAlcoholic Who Aided Others, Dies at 64
description: Vincent Tracy, a former alcoiholic who achieved a record of nearly 90 per cent success in rehabilitating thousands of drinkers, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital of a kidney ailment and coronary failure. He was 64 years old and lived at 200 East 71st Street.

title: Police Kill Nigerian Student Cited in Error as Suspect
description: DALLAS, Aug. 26 (UPI)A Nigerian college student who was mistakenly identified as a suspect in the robbery of a grocery store was shot to death here last night by a policeman.

title: JOSEPH STRESSER
description: Joseph Stresser, who had been president of the Tatarek Penztar Bank in Budapest until he came to this country in 1957 after the uprising in Hungary, died Monday of a kidney ailment in New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Court Rules U. of Nebraska Discriminated Against Men
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (UPI)A Federal appeals court ruled today that the University of Nebraska acted illegally when it refused to pay male employes according to the same salary schedule developed for female employes.

title: Bangkok Fears New Violence As University Shutdown Ends
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 26 Bangkok's elite university reopened quietly today after a week's shutdown that followed clashes between students and the police.

title: United Airlines to Ask U.S. For 4.2% Fare Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 26 (AP)United Airlines said today it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board later this week to impose a 4.2 per cent surcharge on all passenger fares to offset rising fuel prices caused by deregulation of domestic oil.

title: Taking Measure of Past
description: TOKYO (AP)Two pottery measures excavated in Kirin province prove that the Chin dynasty 221207 B.C. had standardized weights and measures, according to Peking's Hsinhua news agency.

title: U.S. JUDGE REJECTS BOSTON BUSING PLAN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) United States District Court Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. has rejected a School Department busing plan for high school students next month.

title: Strong Quake in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 26 (UPI)  A strong earthquake shook northern Chile and southern Peru late yesterday, the police reported today. No injuries or damage were reported.

title: The Dress Called the Droop: A Success Story Despite It All
description: This summer, it's the girls in their baggy dresses.

title: CRISES THREATEN LISBON SHIPYARD
description: LISBON, Aug. 26The great green Tagus River appears to be busy as usual with Dutch, German, Norwegian freighters, a Bulgarian oilandore carrier and two Bulgarian fishing boats clocked for repairs. But there is only one supertanker in port and the big vessels are increasingly rare.

title: WOMEN PRESS U.S. ON SILKWOOD CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Women's rights activists today took their demand for a reopening of the inquiry into the death of the nuclear plant worker Karen Silkwood to the Justice Department.

title: Regrets in Autobiography
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 26 (UPI) Mrs. Meir says she will always! regret ignoring the warnings! of my own heart and not ordering a mobilization of Israeli armed forces a day before the October war erupted in 1973.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: ... Succor for Shanker?
description: The credibility of Governor Carey's quasireceivership for New York City will be gravely undermined if events bear out reportsemphatically denied by himthat he has privately assured United Federation of Teachers' president Albert Shanker of extra state school aid to help avert a teachers' strike next month.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 3 million common shares of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, at $11.25 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. and Salomon Brothers.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA, State Theater, Lincoln Center, Strauss's Salome, B.

title: Tiant's Best Fans See Him Lose, 82
description: Luis Tiant Sr., age 69, who bad not seen his son since 1961, was at Fenway Park in Boston last night to watch Luis Jr., age 34, pitch for the Red Sox against the California Angels. It was a happy reunion for Tiant Sr., his wife, Isabel, his daughterinlaw and one of his three grandchildren, Luis 3d.

title: Hoffa Grand Jury Ready to Start, With 70 Witnesses Scheduled; Foster Son Subpoenaed
description: DETROIT, Aug. 26  Th?? grand jury investigation into the disappearance of James R Hoffa will get under way next week with 70 witnesses sched tiled to testify. At least four of the witnesses have reported ly been subpoenaed.

title: Middle English Dictionary Gets A Deadline After 50 Years: 1982
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.With disdain for editorial mortality and other deadlines, the Middle English Dictionary project here has been taking forever to get to Z. But the Mellon Foundation has suddenly given the project $950,000  and a deadline only seven years away.

title: Advertising
description: The American Express Publishing Corporation threw a nice party last night at the Four Seasons Restaurant to announce a new president, John S. Connors, a new editor for its Travel and Leisure Magazine, Pamela A. Fiori and the success of Travel and Leisure's change over to a paid subscription book.

title: German Import Prices Up
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The West German import price index in July rose 1.1 per cent from June to 139.9 (base equals 1970) but was 2.6 per cent down from July 1974, the Federal Statistics Office said. In June import prices fell 0.6 per cent from May and were 3.2 per cent down from June last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Bangladesh in The New York Times last Thursday incorrectly quoted a message from President Khondakar Mushtaque Ahmed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India. It should have said Mr. Mushtaque Ahmed had conveyed profound regards.

title: City Problems: The Secret School Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: Prisoners in Spain On a Hunger Strike To Back 2 Basques
description: MADRID, Aug. 26More than 100 prisoners in jails all over Spain reportedly have gone on hunger strikes to protest the trial of two Basque militants. The two, Jose Antonio Garmendia and Angel Otaegui, will appear before a military court on Thursday in a village near Burgos. They face the death penalty.

title: W. German Car Output Off
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Aug. 26 (AP)  West German car production dropped 42.3 per cent in July compared to June, an industry federation reported today. The main reason for the unpredented decline, the federation said, was the July vacation period in which most auto plants were shut. Spread over the first seven months of 1975, car production declined 12.3 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year.

title: Bridge:
description: Thousands of summer resorts all over North America stage some kind of bridge tournament during August. Most of them are of a very primitive nature, and some have been known to resort to envelopes and rubber bands when duplicate boards were not available.

title: BYRNE EXPLAINS BORROWING PLAN
description: TRENTON, Aug. 26Governor Byrne went before the Legislature today to detail an $883  million borrowing program that he said would help the state break the economic recession, fulfill longneglected capital improvements and put 100,000 unemployed workers back on the job.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: SAIGON IS OUSTING 3 MORE NEWSMEN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (UPI)  The South Vietnamese Government has asked three more foreign newsmen to leave Saigon.

title: BUDGET SHORTFALL TIED TO OVERSIGHT
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP)Massachusetts is within days of defaulting on housing notes and bonds because of interim state budget cuts, a state official said today. However, another state official said that the alleged crisis was the result of an apparent oversight.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Seventh Avenue has embarked on a whole new round of showings. The clothes are beamed at next winter's resort season and at a lot of places they're being presented a month or so earlier than usual.

title: Governor Appoints Democratic Leader Head of Parole Unit
description: TRENTON, Aug. 26 (AP)Governor Byrne today nominated as chairman of the State Parole Board a Union County political leader who was an early supporter of his bid for election.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER FOR MOST GRAINS
description: Wheat, corn, oats and soybeans futures prices were off substantially yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and Soybeans fell the permissible daily limit of 20 cents a bushel each; corn was down 9 cents to the limit of 10 cents and oats dropped the limit of 6 cents a bushel.

title: Cassese Gets P.B.A. Post For Political Education
description: Ken McFeeley, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, announced yesterday that his organization wag forming a political education committee and that John J. Cassese had been hired as its executive director.

title: Nearby Yacht Results
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND CHAMPIONSHIP 27th Annual Jesse A.B. Smith Trophy

title: Guam Refugee Base Closes Four Months After Opening
description: AGANA, Guam, Aug. 26 (AP) Tin City, a Vietnamese refugee complex at Andersen Air Force Base, closed quietly during the weekend.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Plans for Security
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 26 (UPI)The defense chiefs of the United States and South Korea worked today on plans for a strong security posture on the Korean peninsula in the wake of the Communist victories in Indochina.

title: Symphonie Craft Launched
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 26 (UPI)A Symphonie experimental communications satellite was launched tonight aboard a Delta rocket toward a stationary orbiting position 22,300 miles above the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Africa. The Symphonie series will ultimately help France and West Germany enter the domestic communications satellite market.

title: ASSEMBLY DISSOLVED BY BAHRAIN'S RULER
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, Aug 26 (Reuters)The Emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa bin Sulman alKhalifa, issued a decree tonight disolving the Persian Gulf island's first National Assembly.

title: Firemen in Berkeley Strike; Forestry Units Sent to Help
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP)Firemen walked off the job today for higher pay and the Mayor declared a state of emergency in order to get state help.

title: Suspect Held in New Threat
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 26 (AP) A Minneapolis man who once was convicted of threatening President Johnson now has been charged with threatening to kill President Ford. Salvatore Thomas, 32 years old, was bound over to United States District Court yesterday.

title: Beneath the Harmony, an Effort to Assess Mayor's Loss of Power
New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Bonn Plans Economic Stimulus; Sees No Sign of Recession's End
description: BONN, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The West German Government, which is putting the final touches on a $2.3billion program to stimulate the economy said today it saw no sign of an end to the nation's prolonged recession.

title: U.S. TRADE SHOWS ANOTHER SURPLUS
description: The Commerce Department reported yesterday that although increased oil imports eroded the nation's foreign trade surplus in July, the account remained, in surplus by nearly $1billion for the month. The unexpected surplusthe fourth largest ever recordedcomes at a time when virtually all of the nation's leading competitors are suffering severe declines in their own trade balances.

title: U.S. Reaches Final In Seniors' Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 26The United States, the defender and Australia reached the final of the Stevens Cup senior team tennis international competition today at the Concord Hotel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: James H. Lofland, a 47yearold Kansas man, was arrested and held in $100,000 bail in Federal District Court here on charges of swindling almost $500,000 from two elderly widows. He allegedly mailed fraudulent material from here as part of a scheme to induce Myrtle Rupe of Oklahoma City and Esther Armstrong of Fort Worth to invest in a country club that he said was developing in Liberal, Kan.

title: Argentine Labor Leaders Warn of Coup
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26As dissension mounted in the armed forces the Peronist labor leadership called on trade unionists today to be prepared to defend President Isabel Martinez de Pern's Government against a possible military uprising.

title: General Electric Accord
description: LYNN, Mass., Aug. 26 (UPI)  Union and company negotiators reached agreement tonight on a sixweekold contract dispute that has idled up to 8,000 workers at General Electric turbine and aircraft engine plants here. A company spokesman said all workers suspended after the initial walkout would be reinstated.

title: Libertarian Party Meets Here To Pick Slate for '76 Campaign
description: The Libertarian party, which says that it challenges the cult of the omnipotent state and defends the rights of the individual, opened its second national convention here yesterday.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Oakland at New York (8 P.M.)Blue (1610) vs. Medich (1114).

title: Gun Is Fired at Crowd, 10 Hurt; Building Is Hit by a Fire Bomb
description: Ten persons were injured last night when several shotgun blasts were fired into a crowd that was watching a street fight involving four girls.

title: Suffolk to Withhold Funds From the Unsafe L.I.R.R.
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 26Citing what it called unsafe services by the Long Island Rail Road, particularly at the Huntington station, the Suffolk County Legislature voted unanimously today to withhold funds due the commuter line and file suit to prevent the line from collecting fares at that station.

title: Rescue Effort for Refugees
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)South African policemen set out today to try to save about 200 Portuguese refugees from Angola trapped with only a small amount of food and water in the northern desert of this territory.

title: Schoolchild's Lament In Iambic Pentameter
description: There will little learning die . . .the day thou. art. hanged.

title: Portuguese Keep Pressure on Premier
description: LISBON, Aug. 26President Francisco da Costa Gomes remained under pressure today to replace Premier Vasco Goncalves after a deadline for the Premier's removal passed.

title: FORD, MEANY FAIL TO AGREE ON GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26President Ford met for more than 90 minutes today with George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., and five other union leaders, seeking an end to a union boycott against grain shipments to the Soviet Union, but the day's discussions ended in a deadlock.

title: SUFFOLK POLITICS PERILS FARM PLAN
description: The Suffolk County Executive's ambitious $60million farmland preservation program, which was designed to stem suburbanization in this developing region, has bogged down in a political quagmire, with several County Legislators predicting the imminent demise of the project.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES TO OPPOSE A SUIT
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UPI)The American Bakeries Company announced today it intended to resist vigorously a suit to recover 178,200 shares of A.B.C. stock it previously held.

title: One Jet Who Isn't Ailing Is Gresham
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 26 That was not the cast of General Hospital walking around the Jets' camp today, sporting dozens of yards of Ace bandages, adhesive tape, casts, canes, slings and grimaces.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Aug. 26, 1975

title: Picnic Recipes (Cont'd)
description: 10 hardcooked eggs

title: Kearny Boy, 16, Dies After Inhaling Spray
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., (UPI) Ocean County authorities said today that Carl Rossi, 16 years old, of Kearny, a student at Admiral Farragut Academy, died after inhaling fumes from a spray can of deodorant.

title: New Books
description: AntoineLaurent Lavoisier, Chemist and Revolutionary, by Henry Guerlac (Scribners, $7.95; Paper, $2.95). A biographical sketch with 64 pages of illustrations.

title: Claims for Unemployment Down for Week of Aug. 15
description: There were 698,838 persons claiming unemployment benefits under four separate programs in New York State in the week ended Aug. 15, compared with 732,285 the previous week, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: We're going to put the gorilla to sleep, said Muhammad Ali. Wearing Tshirts that read Manila Gorilla, the champion and his entourage crashed a Joe Frazier news conference at the Four Seasons restaurant here to publicize the Ali  Frazier heavyweight championship fight in Manila on Oct. 1. (Sept. 30 on American calendars).

title: RIDERS PROTEST RAIL FARE RISES
description: HACKENSACK, Aug. 26Mrs. Jesse Bercher is one of the 12,500 Bergen County commuters who ride the ErieLackawanna Railroad to work in Manhattan every day and, like the others, she faces a fare increase of 32 to 52 per cent on Oct. 1.

title: Beatrice Foods Dividend Up
description: The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividend on its common stock to 19 cents from IS cents, payable Oct. 1 to shareholders of record Sept. 12.

title: Soviet Creates a Science Center in Siberia, With One Institute Devoted Entirely to Research on Volcanoes
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 26A science center with the world's only institute devoted entirely to the study of volcanoes and another institute performing the Soviet Union's most extensive marine biology research has been created in Siberia.

title: California Proposes To Stop Redlining
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26The State of California issued tentative new regulations today forbidding statechartered savings and loan associations from rejecting homeloan applications merely because the mortgaged home would be in a ghetto or declining neighborhood.

title: Fewer Are Going Abroad For Studying or Teaching
description: The number of Americans studying or teaching abroad is declining rapidly as rising costs compete with scarce tuition dollars, student priorities change and foreign countries often appear less friendly than before.

title: Play Ball! Is the Cry In Peking
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 26The World Series in Peking? Why else, Chinawatchers puzzled, is China building a major league  size baseball stadium on the outskirts of Peking. And what is the origin of those Chinese teams that played a series with two visiting Japanese squads in the last few days?

title: F.D.A. Warns Birth Pill Raises Heart Attack Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Women who take birth control pills face an increased risk of heart attack, the Food and Drug Administration has told doctors in a drug bulletin mailed to the medical profession.

title: Paper Charges U. S. Pressure
description: LISBON, Aug. 26 (Reuters)The proCommunist newspaper Diario de Lisboa said today that the United States has threatened to withhold planes needed for an airlift of white settlers from Angola unless a new government immediately replaced the Cabinet of Premier Goncalves.

title: N.B.A. Stars Triumph
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Aug. 26 (AP)A team of National Basketball Association players registered a 132125 victory today over an American Basketball Association squad. it was the N.B.A.'s third victory against one loss over the A.B.A. in Japan.

title: Golda Meir Demands Deletion of Sentence in Book
description: Former Premier Golda Meir of Israel has now asked Harper's Magazine Press to retract a sentence about her in a book it has published entitled The, Education of Lev Navrozov.

title: Gannett Dividend Is Raised
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 26 (AP)The board of directors of the Gannett Company, Inc., newspaper group voted today to increase the quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share, payable Oct. 1 to shareholders of record Sept. 17. The dividend had been 13 cents a share.

title: Tate and Vail Star for Mets In 72 Victory Over Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 26 Randy Tate, another of the young pitchers the New York Mets have been displaying lately, posted his first victory in a month tonight as he beat the San Diego Padres, 72.

title: Soccer Coach Named
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 (AP) Jim McDowell was named soccer coach today at the Universty of Cincinnati. McDowell replaces Richard Kleinschmidt, who resigned after two years.

title: New Violence in Leiria
description: LISBON, Wednesday, Aug. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)  The headquarters of two farleft parties and the office of a lawyer belonging to the proCommunist Portuguese Democratic Movement were burned by antiCommunist demonstrators in Leiria last night, in the third night of antiCommunist activity in the city 80 miles north of Lisbon.

title: U.S. Aide Sees Laotian Official
description: VIENTIANE, Aug. 26 (AP)The charg d'affaires of the United States Embassy, Thomas J. Corcoran, made his first official visit to a member of the Communistcontrolled Government of Laos today.

title: The Coming Class War?
description: MEXICO CITYPresident Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico is a serious and eloquent man who regards himself as a good friend of the United States, but this doesn't keep him from giving Washington some hard Listen, Yankee talk.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: When Sarah Caldwell conducts the New York Philharmonic on Nov. 10 in a pension fund benefit, the concert will be cosponsored by the orchestra and Ms. magazine. The Caldwell program, announced yesterday by the Philharmonic, will consist of works by five women composers, as follows:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: There was agreement among government officials last night that the plan announced by Governor Carey and Mayor Beame to save the city from default next month would cut into the Mayor's power to direct city fiscal affairs. But there were confusion and conflicting views on the degree to which the Mayor's powers had been cut.

title: I.M.M. Seat Price Is Up
description: A seat on Chicago's International Monetary Market was sold yesterday for $34,000, or $500 less than the highest price paid to date for such a seat. The record was set in June, 1974. The last sale, prior to yesterday's, was for $33,500, posted on Aug. 21, 1975. The I.M.M., organized by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, began operations in May, 1972. Seats at that time were sold for $10,000 each.

title: About New York
description: Unlike most natural spectacles, the manmade profile of New York is a constantly changing montage of peaks and valleys, and there is always the question of how it can best be seen.

title: STOCKS TUMBLE ON RATE WORRIES
description: Invstors' concern over rising interest rates and inflation sent the stock market lower yesterday in continued lackluster trading.

title: RITES FOR REYSON ATTENDED BY 1,600
description: A diversity of worlds assembled yesterday at Temple EmanuEl to pay a last tribute to Charles H. Revson, chairman of the board of Revlon, Inc., who died Sunday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

title: Deal Police Get to Root Of the Purloined Plants
description: DEAL, Aug. 26The wandering Jew has returned home.

title: Albus Gains L.I. Final
description: INWOOD, L. I., Aug. 26Jim Albus of LaTourette, Staten Island, a former Metropolitan open titleholder, gained the final round of the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship today with Roger Ginsberg of Muttontown.

title: More than 225 Finalists Vie in Housing Olympics
description: A runner carrying a flaming torch circled the track and 1,500 orangeandwhite balloons, symbolizing doves of peace, were released yesterday to begin the second annual Olympic Games of the New York City Housing Authority in Macombs Dam Park, across the street from the Yankee Stadium in the Bronx.

title: Soviet Soldiers Assisting Farms in Grain Harvest
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Soviet soldiers are helping to harvest grain in Kazakhstan and Siberia, assisting mainly with transport, the Soviet paper Pravda reported today.

title: A 13c Rate for FirstClass Mail Reported Favored by U.S. Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The Postal Rate Commission has overruled the recommendation of an administrative law judge and opened the way for the United States Postal Service to raise first  class letter rates to 13 cents from 10, Administration sources said tonight.

title: More of Food Dollar Goes to Middlemen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)Middlemen's charges for a selected market basket of foods produced on United States farms rose more last month than they had declined in the three previous months combined, the Agriculture Department reported yesterday.

title: New Yorker, 16, Scores Golf Upset
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 26 (AP) Two collegiate allAmericans, Andy Bean and Curtis Strange, advanced with ease and 16yearold John Kircher and 23yearold Torn Kelley provided the major surprises today in sweltering heat on the opening round of the 75th United States Amateur golf tournament.

title: DC10 Pilot Says He Stopped After Hearing Bangs
description: The pilot of an American Airlines DC10 jetliner who aborted his takeoff here Monday said yesterday that his decision came after he heard two bangs from under the aircraft as it was traveling at 173 miles an hourfive miles short of takeoff speed.

title: ISRAEL AWAITING MOVES BY EGYPT
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 Israeli sources expressed no more than hope today that Egypt would make all the political commitments that Israel wants in return for the military and territorial concessions to which this country has agreed.

title: Witty Observation Marks Folk Songs Of Steve Goodman
description: The music business is hardly known for justice  otherwise Steve Goodman would be reaping just rewards for what he is an acute, witty and truthful observer of the contemporary world, disguised as a folk singer.

title: H.E.W. Reported Lagging On Ending College Job Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)The General Accounting Office said today that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare had made minimal progress in getting colleges and universities to end job discrimination through affirmative action programs.

title: Felix Forte Dead at 80; Judge at the Brinks Trial
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)Felix Forte, who was the judge at the Brink's robbery trial, died here yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Congratulations Pour In to Station WNCN
description: A telegram from Mr. and Mrs. Allen Crosby with 10 Hallelujahs in a row, no spaces and no commas, hangs on a door at the sixthfloor offices of radio station WQIVFM at 2 West 45th Street.

title: U.S. Is Expected to Gain Greater Role in Mideast
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26The United States seems destined, to emerge from the present negotiations for a new EgyptianIsraeli accord as the major outside power in the Middle East, in the view of Arab, Israeli and American officials.

title: Drought Hits Quebec Town
description: GRANBY, Quebec, Aug. 26 (UPI)Mayor Paul Trepanier, faced with the worst drought we have ever seen, sought provincial government approval today of an 80 per cent cutback in water supplies to city businesses. He said that this southern Quebec town of 37,000 had only a fiveday supply of water.

title: A Summer Picnic: Fine Wine and Superb Food Came to the Rescue
description: THE SPRINGS, L.I.Dear Diary: Well, it's the end of summer, and I guess the thing I remember most about it was Claudia's wedding. That's Claudia Franey, Pierre's daughter. She married a nice young man named Rick Jensen, and there was a big striped tent and 170 guests and a 4foot wedding cake that was made by Albert Kumin, one of the world's great pastry chefs. There were also six great chefs in the kitchenJacques Pepin, Jean Vergnes, Raymond Bruballa, JeanJacques Paimblanc, JeanLouis Todeschini, plus the father of the bride. Roger Fessaguet, chef of La Caravalle, was tied up in traffic, but he got there in time for the wedding march. The chefs spent a couple of daysand a couple of nights, for that matterpreparing the food, a cold buffet with lots of aspic dishes and a hot buffet that included 10 fillets of beef with truffle sauce, 15 roasted racks of lamb and a chicken and veal Burgundy tart. The cold buffet, indecently delicious, included cold striped bass with salad russe, mussels vinaigrette, terrines of sweetbreads, pt of venison, galantines of duck, a salad of pork rind pt (would you believe it is one of the greatest pt ever devised?), and garlic sausages with lentils. A most amusing thing happened the next day. We looked in the refrigerator and found enough leftover venison pate and sweetbread terrine to feed a stnall crowd, so we called up some of our favorite picnic people (we've observed that there are some people who simply aren't picnic types) to come over for a feast and lots of them came with pinic food and wine. The weather looked threatening and the tent was still intact, so we decided to stage the picnic there. The guests included Josephine Premice and Jane White, the actresses, and Alfredo Viazzi, the owner of the Trattoria de Alfredo and the Tavola Calda da Alfredo in Greenwich Village. There was Sam Aaron, the wine and spirits man (he owns SherryLehman), plus his wife, Florence, and Sarah Lewis, a grand cook and neighbor. Josephine made a seductive smoked herring vinaigrette, a Haitian dish; Florence brought a delectable cold salad of hardcooked eggs with salmon, and Sarah showed up with her famous cold steamer clams with mustard mayonnaise appetizer plus her notable black beans vinaigrette and a fine chicken dish Mexicanstyle, which she had learned from the late Paula Peck. We rounded out the menu with tomatoes and anchovies vinaigrette. There seemed to be an awful lot of viniagrette dishes, but then it was catch as catch can. Sam brought the picnic wines, a California white, Del Mar Ranch, Monterrey Vineyard, 1974; and a French Chateau de la Chaize, 1973. It wasn't the weather that threatened the day's bliss so much as the tent movingmen who loomed exceedingly large in the driveway. There is more than one way, we learned, to stall a tentmover's mission. With a dispatch that would have heartened Amphytrion, some glasses of wine were thrust into the movingmen's hands, and they were invited to dine and a couple of hours later we were still being urged not to rush.

title: BYRNE EXPLAINS BORROWING PLAN
description: TRENTON, Aug. 26Governor Byrne went before the Legislature today to detail an $883  million borrowing program that he said would help the state break the economic recession, fulfill longneglected capital improvements and put 100,000 unemployed workers back on the job.

title: Tournament Time in Forest Hills: Boon and Bane for the Community
description: The name of the game in Forest Hills for the last years has been tennis, and the quiet Queens towninacity is putting out its nets today for the 12day United States Open Championship.

title: Ford View on Busing: Obey Law and Court
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)President Ford's record on busing and school integration is very clear, his press secretary, Ron. Nessen, said today. Mr. Ford supports obedience to the law and to the court, Mr. Nessen said.

title: Baskets: To Catch, Carry and Hold the Things You Don't Know What to Do With
description: Remember the basket? Split willow picnic hampers, mom's hemp sewing basket, the huge wicker laundry basket for back yard clotheshanging? Victims of progress, all eventually outmoded by plastics, cardboard, Styrofoam and that invention that dealt basketry its final blowthe paper bag.

title: 4 State Hospitals In Connecticut Face Protest by Doctors
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 26 (AP)Doctors, including psychiatrists, at four state mental hospitals began cutting back their work week today, refusing to work more than 35 hours and giving priority to medical rather than administrative duties.

title: 80% IN STUDY CALL JOBS REWARDING
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 26Eleven years after high school graduation, 80 per cent of Americans in a survey say they find their jobs rewarding.

title: Visconti Drama to Open Film Fete Here Sept. 26
description: The works of film makers from France, Germany, Britain, Hungary, Senegal, Switzerland and the United States as well as a series of directors' symposiums make up the 13th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, to run from Sept. 26 through Oct. 12.

title: Amstar and National Lower Sugar Prices
description: The Amstar Corporation and the National Sugar Refining Company said yesterday that effective immediately they had cut the wholesale prices on bundles holding 12 fivepound bags of sugar to $17.46 from $18.66 and lowered the price on bundles of six 10pound bags from $18.60 to $17.40.

title: United Asks Lower Air Fare
description: United Airlines filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday plans for a new fourday a week excursion fare, with discounts of up to 25 per cent, that it wants to put into effect next January on travel from 25 cities in the Northwest, the Midwest and the South to key Florida points,

title: W.R. Grace and Hanna Mining In Joint Colorado Coal Venture
description: W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday that k had reached an agreement in principle with the Hanna Mining Company of Cleveland for at joint venture to mine coal in Moffat County Colorado. The companies will hold equal interests in the property known the Colowyo tract which will require an investment of betweem $50million and $75million is near Craig, Colo., about 200 miles northwest of Denver.

title: Convention Center Directors Optimistic On Private Financing to Finish Projec
description: Directors of the proposed Convention Center told members of the Board of Estimate yesterday that they were optimistic that the $230million project would be completed with private financing.

title: 6 Held in Cocaine Seizure
description: MIAMI, Aug. 27 (AP)Five Peruvian women and an Argentine man were arrested today after Federal and local agents seized 29 pounds of cocaine, a Drug Enforcement Administration official said. A spokesman said the cocaine, valued at $6million, had been found after a customs inspector noticed some of it under the lining of a suitcase one of the women carried at Miami International Airport. She, another woman and the man, who had just got off a flight from Lima, Peru, were arrested at the airport. Three other women were arrested at hotels.

title: Steel Concern to Omit Payout
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would omit the next dividend on its common stock. The latest dividend was. 35 cents a share in July. The company posted net losses in the second quarter which it says are continuing into the third quarter.

title: J.P. Stevens Net Plunges 68.2% in Quarter and 67.8% for 9 Months
description: Earnings of J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., for the quarter and nine months ended Aug. 2 shrank dramatically from the high levels of a year ago, according to the results reported yesterday.

title: Five of 6 U.S. Crews Gain in World Rowing
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 27Five of the six United States crews racing in repechage (second chance) heats today qualified for the next round of the world rowing championships on Holme Pierrepont course. Only the American four with coxswain, which placed fourth, failed to advance.

title: JUDGE FINES UNION IN MINERS' STRIKE
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 27 (UPI)A Federal judge fined the United Mine Workers of America $500,000 today and scolded the union's leadership for what he called feeble attempts to end a wildcat strike that has brought coal production to a halt in the Appalachian coalfields and caused layoffs in the rail industry.

title: Fed Opposes a Bid By Panel of House For Staff Studies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27The Federal Reserve Board has unanimously opposed a request of the House Banking Committee for the staff projections of the economy that the board and Federal Open Market Committee use in drawing up their targets for the money supply.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOOT SOAR Twentythree companies are appearing in the 11th New York Dance Festival, the annual series of free dance programs that starts tonight at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. The event, sponsored by the New York Shakespeare Festival, will feature 10 evening performances at 8 P.M. and matinees on Saturday and Sunday at 3 P.M. for children. Programs will include three local premieres and two world premieres. Four of the companies will be making their first local appearances during the festival, which ends Sept. 7.

title: Personal Finance: Premarriage Contracts
description: Beatrice A. and Henry J., a widow and widower in their sixties with children and grandchildren, decided to marry. But before doing so, they signed a paper designed to protect the rights of their heirs to their respective estates.

title: City's Problems Dog Carey in Trip Upstate
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 27Governor Carey; who left New York City last night for two days of political fencemending in the central section of the state, spent most of his time discussing the city's fiscal problems before cutting his trip short to return to the city.

title: French Aid Public Works
description: PARIS, Aug. 27The French Government today announced a plan to improve the lagging economy with heavy spending, especially in public works.

title: GRAIN FUTURES UP IN BRISK TRADING
description: Futures prices of wheat, corn, red meat, oats and potatoes, which had been down on Tuesday, rebounded yesterday in active trading while soybean futures were off.

title: A Marijuana Farm Is Found on L.I.
description: LATTINGTOWN, L.I., Aug. 27 A wellcultivated and boobytrapped marijuana farm on what might be school property led to the arrest last night of a 22yearold Glen Cove man by detectives of the Nassau County Police Department's narcotics bureau.

title: ALLBRITTON EXTENDS STAR PURCHASE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The Perpetual Corporation, owned by Joe L. Allbritton, publisher of The Washington Star, announced today that it has extended the period for shareholders of Washington Star Communications, Inc., to offer their shares for purchase by Perpetual.

title: Germans Help Builders
description: BONN, Aug. 27In the face of a stubbornly continuing recession, the West German Government decided today on a $2.2billion recovery program for the building industry and raised the expected federal deficit to nearly $15billion.

title: ROCKEFELLER DUE AT ATTICA HEARING
description: Vice President Rockefeller has agreed to testify tomorrow before a grand jury investigating the prison uprising at Attica four years ago.

title: Key Economic Index Up in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27The Government's new composite index of leading indicators of the economy rose substantially again in July, marking the fifth consecutive monthly advance, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 3 Indian Rugs Stolen
description: SEAL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 27 (AP)Three American Indian rugs valued at $4,150 were stolen sometime during the weekend from an unlocked building on the Rockefeller compound here, the police said today.

title: Good Deed Costs $102
description: A good Samaritan who rescued an injured dog from the BrooklynQueens Expressway will have to pay $102.40 for her kindness.

title: Ozavva at 40 : A Flamboyant Bostonian
description: Seiji Ozawa, only yesterday the wonder boy of the podium, looked age 40 straight in the eye and did not wince or cry aloud. He smiled, in fact. The Japanese conductor, who holds the rare distinction of being for the momentmusic director of major orchestras on both American coasts, will reach the 40 mark on Sept. 1. But he professes to feel no pain. When I turned 20that was a shock, he told an interviewer recently while relaxing on the lawn of Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., between concerts with one of his orchestras, the Boston Symphony

title: SOVIET BIDS ANEW FOR ASIAN ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 27The Soviet Union has begun citing the success of the recent European security conference to impart new momentum to its longstanding proposal for a Sovietbacked collective security system in Asia.

title: Yanks Beaten in Ninth, 32
description: When Matt Alexander went to first base as a pinch run ner for Oakland in the ninth inning last night, the Yankees figured he would run. And he did.

title: Rockefeller, in South, Denounces Government Spending
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 27Vice President Rockefeller, who regularly asserts that he is not actively seeking the second spot on next year's Republican ticket, campaigned avidly here and in Alabama today among Southern Republicans, many of whom have never forgiven him for not supporting Barry Goldwater in 1964.

title: Giles Lose In Top Upset In U.S. Golf
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 27 (AP) Stanley Price of Pittsburgh, who couldn't make the varsity golf in tea at Duke, upset the British Amateur champion Vinny Gies, on Giles's home course today in the second round of the 75th United States Amateur.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)the Soviet union may harvest another record cotton crop to further solidify its position as one of the world's leading cotton producers according to Agriculture Department analysts.

title: FORD ASKS REVIEW OF WELFARE AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27President Ford has asked the Office of Management and Budget to review Social Security's federalized welfare programSupplemental Security Income.

title: Julio Tanjeloff of Klein's Buys StrombergShytten
description: Julio Tanjeloff, who will reopen S. Klein on Union Square on Jan. 30, announced yesterday that he had purchased StrombergShytten, A.B., of Hovmantorp, Sweden, a manufacturer of lead crystal.

title: New Clashes Over Autonomy For Corsica Kill 1, Wound 14
description: PARIS, Thursday, Aug. 28 (AP)  About 300 youths attacked government headquarters in the center of the Corsican city of Bastia early today, killing a policeman and wounding 14 persons, official sources there said.

title: Sears Forecasts Rise In 3dQuarter Sales
description: Officials of Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest merchandising organization, told retail securities analysts in Chicago yesterday that it is forecasting a 5 per cent to 6 per cent increase in general merchandise industry sales for the third quarter ending Oct. 31.

title: Still a Good Apple
description: The Democratic party's site committee has concluded that New York City is still a going concern, capable of staging the party's 1976 Presidential convention in comfort and style. The committee's choice of New York over Los Angeles was narrow (before being made unanimous), but that seems not to have been a reflection of the city's fiscal troubles so much as a simple concern over, the adequacy of floor space in Madison Square Garden.

title: British Institute Sees 12% World Trade Fall
description: LONDON. Aug. 27 (Reuters) Total world trade will fall about 12 per cent this year in volume and rise 5to 6 per cent next year, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said today in its Economic Review.

title: BURNS IS A FACTOR IN BUOYING BONDS
description: A total of $250million in new obligations, from the Inland Steel Company, Ashland Oil, Inc. and the Western Union Telegraph Company, was successfully marketed yesterday in the corporate bond market. Prices advanced generally in the credit markets with participants attributing the improvement to comments by Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in a letter to the Chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin. In his letter the Fed chairman said the central bank would continue to take steps to reduce longterm interest rates by purchasing longterm Government securities.

title: BANGLADESH REGIME RECOGNIZED BY INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 27The Indian Government said today that it was continuing to maintain normal diplomatic relations with neighboring Bangladesh.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Teachers Union Rejects a CostofLiving Pay Offer
description: The Board of Education yesterday offered city teachers a costofliving salary adjustment tied to some concessions by tae teachers, but the offer was turned down by the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Democrats Pick New York For Convention Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27The Democratic party chose New York City over Los Angeles today as the site of its 1976 convention.

title: MRS. PERON NAMES NEW ARMY CHIEF TO APPEASE FOES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27President Isabel Martinez de Pern yielded to dissident army officers today and appointed a herdline opponent of the Peronist Government as commander in chief.

title: Phoebe Dempsey Victor in Golf
description: INWOOD, L. I., Aug. 27Phoebe Dempsey, a former Metropolitan champion, and her St. George's clubmate, Carol Beinbrink, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association John B. Mackie Memorial Scotch foursomes championship today over the par73 5,856yard Inwood Course with an 80.

title: SHELL SET TO PAY HIGHER OIL PRICES
description: The Shell Oil Company, the United States subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, today announced the higher prices it will be willing to pay for domestic crude oils after the lifting of controls next week.

title: Alexandria, Site of Sinai Talks, Is a Worldly, Faded, Jaded City
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 27Every 24 hours or so, a portly, suntanned figure emerges from the helicopter and strides across the immense lawn, dotted with geranium patches, and lightly embraces a thinner, elegant man.

title: 3 BANKS REJECT CITY FISCAL PLAN; BERMECAREY ACCORD IS IN DOUBT, AND ALTERNATIVES ARE EXPLORED
description: The city's three biggest banks yesterday rejected Governor Carey's proposal for them to help raise the $2billion needed by the city in the next few months, throwing the fiscal picture back into confusion with few apparent alternatives to a city default.

title: BRITISH ARMY PUB IS BOMBED, 23 HURT
description: LONDON, Aug. 27A bomb exploded near here tonight in a pub frequented by soldiers, seriously injuring three persons. Twenty others were slightly hurt, and soldiers were among them.

title: West German Farmers' Resistance Forces Review of Plans for Nuclear Power Plant
description: WYHL., West GermanyUntil recently Johann and Emma Ganter, whose deeply tanned faces reflect 60odd years of German farm life, would never have dreamed of breaking the law.

title: AMEX ENDS MIXED IN SLOW TRADIN
description: In another day of slow trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday. Prices in the overthecounter posted a rise.

title: ManilaHavana Ties
description: MANILA, Aug. 27 (AP)The official Philippine news agency said today that Premier Fidel Castro and Imelda Marcos, wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his special envoy, signed a joint statement in Havana last night for restoration of diplomatic ties, broken off in 1961.

title: U.S. Fight on Recession Stresses Cuts in Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27American antirecession measures have consisted chiefly of tax reductions, rather than publicworks expenditures. Federal publicworks programs now average $10billion in a budget of some $200billion. This does not include state and local programs.

title: KENT STATE JURY ACQUITS ALL, 102
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 27  A Federal jury exonerated today Gov. James A. Rhodes, the former president of Kent State University and 27 Ohio National Guardsmen from any responsibility in the shootings at Kent State in 1970.

title: 3 BANKS REJECT CITY FISCAL PLAN; BERMECAREY ACCORD IS IN DOUBT, AND ALTERNATIVES ARE EXPLORED
description: The city's three biggest banks yesterday rejected Governor Carey's proposal for them to help raise the $2billion needed by the city in the next few months, throwing the fiscal picture back into confusion with few apparent alternatives to a city default.

title: HOFFA PRESENCE IN CAR IS HINTED
description: DETROIT, Aug. 27  Dogs especially trained for investigating kidnappings have re, portedly led Federal investigators to believe that James R. Hoffa had been in a car that was borrowed by his foster son, Charles O'Brien, on the day of his disappearance.

title: Free Inoculations Offered in Oregon To Stem Hepatitis
description: PORTLAND Ore., Aug. 27 (AP)An epidemic alert was issued and mass inoculations continued today to try to stem an outbreak of hepatitis that could affect up to 5,000 patrons of two Portland restaurants. Muttnomah County health officials estimate that about 5,000 persons patronized the restaurants from July 10, when the spread of the illness apparently started, until the restaurants. closed voluntarily Aug. 22.

title: CULLEN LANDIS, 79, FILM ACTOR, DEAD
description: Cullen Landis, one of the first stars of the silent screen who starred in the first alltalking motion picture, Lights of New York, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 79 years old.

title: Inouye's Ship Bill Viewed As Inflationary by Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27Despite strong objections by the State and Transportation Departments, Senator Daniel K. Inouye has won Senate Commerce Committee approval of legislation that could raise shipping costs for all consumers, particularly his Hawaii constituents.

title: Bobby Cruickshank, 80, Is Dead; Dour Scot Was Early Golf Pro
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Aug. 27 (AP)Bobby Cruickshank, the dour little Scot who was one of the leading moneywinners in the early days of the professional golf tour, died here today. He was 80 years old.

title: EXILED POET SEIZED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 27The arrest by security police of a young exiled South African poet, who allegedly reentered the country disguised as a Frenchman, has led to a fresh wave of students arrests, the local press reported today.

title: Tough New Decree By Spain Is Aimed At Terror Groups
description: MADRID, Aug. 27  A law against terrorism that went into effect today makes it obligatory for judges to sentence to death persons convicted of killing policemen, soldiers or government officials.

title: Talks on Sinai Pact Enter Final Stage
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 27Intense negotiations in the last few days have reduced differences to two or three points in the language of the projected EgyptianIsraeli accord, American officials said today.

title: Visiting an Ocean Liner Is Fun for Children
description: The new passenger ship terminal at 48th Street and Twelfth Avenue has been doing a landoffice business lately. This Saturday five liners are scheduled to sail from its docks.

title: New Courts Satisfy Fans
description: It's like returning from a year's journey to find your best girl has shaved her head.

title: The 13Cent Letter
description: At least one good thing can be said for the Postal Rate Commission's reported rejection of the recommendations of Seymour Wenner, its administrative law judge. Mr. Wenner would have cut the cost of mailing a firstclass letter from 10 cents to 81/2 but he would have had senders of parcel post packages, bulk mail and periodicals, make up for the loss.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 28, 1975

title: A Collaboration of Two 13YearOlds And One Talkative Elizabethan Mouse
description: She Was Nice to Mice is different from any biography of Queen Elizabeth I you're ever likely to read.

title: Backers and Foes of Portugal's Premier Encounter Setbacks as Confusion Spreads
description: LISBON, Aug. 27New de mands for the ouster of Premier Vasco Gonalves were made today from within Portugal's armed forces, and the Communistinfluenced military propaganda unit that has supported him was seized by troops.

title: Cahn ls Indicted on U.S. Charges Of Tax Evasion and Mail Fraud
description: William Cahn, who was District Attorney of Nassau County for 12 years, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on 20 counts involving incometax evasion, mail fraud, perjury and making a false statement.

title: Mummy Autopsy Seeks Clues to Ancients' Health
description: DETROITUnder hot floodlights and before a closedcircuit television camera. Bill Peck gently lifted a loose end of the mummy's fragile linen bandage and began to unwrap the preserved corpse.

title: Notes on People
description: Maj. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, the American commander for the ApolloSoyuz mission last month, will leave the astronaut corps Nov. 1 after 13 years. The veteran of four spaceflights will return to active duty with the Air Force as commander of its testpilot training at Edwards, Air Force Base in California. General Stafford, a Naval Academy graduate, did his testpilot training at Edwards and later headed its performbranch.

title: Smith Defeated at Start Of Open; Ashe Is Victor
description: What has happened to Stan Smith? Is his seasonlong tennis slumpreally the result of a sore arm, as Onny Parun believes? Or is his faltering play a mental collapse that more than time must heal?

title: Young Catfish Anglers Lured to Central Park
description: Three hundred disadvantaged daycamp children from the Bronx played Huckleberry Finn yesterday, fishing for catfish in Central Park.

title: FORD CRITICIZED OVER NIXON FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) President Ford has been more reluctant to turn over files from the Nixon Administration than files from the Kennedy Administration, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said today.

title: LACEY CONSIDERED AS '71 CANDIDATE
description: TRENTON, Aug. 27Some of New Jersey's top Republican leaders were reported today seriously considering the pros pects of promoting Federa Judge Frederick B. Lacey as a candidate for the G.O.P gubernatorial nomination in 1977.

title: PEYSER DISCERNS BUCKLEY CONFLICT
description: Representative Peter A. Peyser yesterday accused Senator James L. Buckley of potential conflict of interest regarding his votes on oil and gas issues, and called on him to make full disclosure of his finances.

title: New York as a CoughIn
description: The coming Increase in transit fares will have a severe, immediate and detrimental effect on public health. The political facts are equally clear: subsidies for auto users continue as usual, while the transit rider is saddled with an additional tax.

title: Fire in a National Forest In California Is Contained
description: PIRU, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP)Fire fighters, aided by an effective aerial assault and a break in the weather, contained a 1,300acre fire that had burned in the Los Padres National Forest for four days.

title: Pon Joins Classical at Musical Fetes
description: For decades, people have gone to American summer music festivals to hear classical music. But now they are just as likely to encounter the Carpenters or Neil Sedaka as Seiji Ozawa or James Levine.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Wednesday, August 27. Third day, Weather clear, track fast.

title: Opera: Salome Opens the City Season
description: When the City Opera production of Strauss's Salome was played last season, there were many, pros and cons. This writer, overseas, missed it. Last night Julius Rudel selected Salome to open the fall season of the New York City Opera, thus throwing the gage to all dissenters. Clearly he believes in this production.

title: City Area Job Loss Biggest in 25 Years
description: Employment in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area declined by 241,000 between June, 1974, and June, 1975, the largest annual job loss on record for the 25year period for which data are available, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Dr. Irwin M. Stillman, 79, Dies; Wrote Four Popular Diet Books
description: Dr. Irwin Maxwell Stillman, the author of bestselling diet books, died Tuesday evening of a heart attack in North Miami (Fla.) General Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Bal Harbour, Fla.

title: Bacardi Threat to Move Sparks Inquiry
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug., 27 (UPI)A threat by the Bacardi Corporation, the world's largest ?? distiller, to pull out of Puerto Rico has sparked a legislative investigation into possible financial relief for the company.

title: Builder of Alaska Pipeline Wins Court Order Against Teamsters
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 27 (AP)Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, builder of the transAlaska pipeline, has won a temporary restraining order against the teamsters union to stop a walkout that idled 4,200 pipeline workers.

title: Major League Baseball and Standings
description: Yachting Results

title: Garden Due for Changes To House the Convention
description: It will cost 5600,000 to $1million to refurbish Madison Square Garden for the Democratic National Convention next year, but even as New York City was selected as the site, Garden officials were not sure exactly how the money would be spent.

title: FERGUSON'S MUSIC SHAKES THE WALLS
description: If the glass walls of Buddy's Place are still standing today, it is not because Maynard Ferguson and his orchestra have not been doing their best to blow them down. Playing the downstairs room across West 33d Street from the Statler Hilton, Mr. Ferguson combines a band that works at almost constant fever pitch with a sound system that is built for volume, producing music that is sometimes buried in its own loudness.

title: Steel Output Is on Increase as PriceRise Date Nears
description: With prices for many steel products used in the automobile and appliance industries scheduled to rise Oct. 1, steel producers report that their major customers are asking them to speed delivery on orders previously scheduled to be filled after the price rise
