description: What an official in the City Controller's office described last month as the worst catastrophe that could befall the citydefaultis now staring New York in the face.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Thomas K. J. Tuso, a Municipal Court judge for four towns in South Jersey, was indicted on charges of trying to rig the award of an architectural contract for, the construction of a high school. A Delaware River Port Authority member, Dante D'Anastasio, head of an architectural concern, was named as a coconspirator in the case, which is still under investigation.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES OFF 20C A BUSHEL
description: Futures prices of soybeans, soybean oil and oats fell the daily limit yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, dragging down the prices of wheat, corn and soybean meal on the same exchange.

title: At Belmont Park ...
description: Foolish Pleasure and Wajima, 3yearolds who will face Forego, Ancient Title and other older horses in Monday's $100,000 added Governor, worked out yesterday on the main track for the 1mile event. Foolish Pleasure, the Kentucky Derby winner, was caught in a handy 1:10 4/5 for six furlongs. Wajima, who gained his third straight stakes success in the recent Travers, went over the same distance also handilyin 1:11.... Nine apprentice riders competed on yesterday's program. Georgie Martens and Roger Velez had five and four mounts respectively. With two two mounts each were Kenneth Hargrave, Rudy Greco, Tom Campanelli, James Long and Robert Gilbert. None of them, however, brought home a winner. For Velez, there was bad news. He was suspended for seven days, starting tomorrow, for his ride in Wednesday's ninth race in which he was disqualified after finishing first with Fruit Cake.... Braulio Baeza rounded out a triple by scoring with Elmendor's Sweet Old Girl ($12.60) in the $20,000 Amoret.

title: After 30 Years, Trials of Nazis Drag On
description: HAMBURG, West Germany It could have been 30 years ago in Nuremberg, but it was this July 4: Ludwig Hahn, head of the Gestapo in Germanoccupied Warsaw, was found guilty in the murder of at least 230,000 Polish Jews in World War II and was sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: The Pop Life
description: Bruce Springsteen's third album, Born to Run, should be in the record stores about now and it should be all he needs to push him over the top.

title: Payoff by Northrop Is Denied by Swiss
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28  The Swiss Government declared today that its proposed $500million contract with the American aircraft manufacturer, the Northrop Corporation, for the purchase of 72 F511 Tiger jet fighters was de Void of all undercover payoffs or other unethical commercial practices.

title: Notes on People
description: When the Democrats chose New York Wednesday for their 1976 convention; Robert S. Strauss, the party chairman, cited the selection committee's tremendous concern about possible overreaction by the Los Angeles police chief. Edward M. Davis, to convention demonstrations or related problems. The politically conservative chief has drawn publicity as well as criticism for his outspokenness on law enforcement and social themes.

title: BANKRUPTCY STIRS JAPANESE DISMAY
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28Kohjin, Ltd., a major paper, chemical, and synthetic fiber maker, with debts estimated at $490million from poor realestate investments, applied today to the Tokyo District Court to go into receivership under the corporate rehabilitation law in the biggest business failure in postwar Japan. The failure appeared to have shaken the nation's governing establishment.

title: F D. A PROPOSES LIMIT ON PLASTIC IN FOOD PACKAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to halt the packaging of many food items in polyvinyl chloride because the plastic has the potential for causing cancer.

title: SCHLESINGER'S VISIT PROTESTED IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Six people were arrested today as an estimated 18,000 leftists demonstrated at the airport and in central Tokyo against the visit here of the United States Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger.

title: Hoving, in Moscow, Thanks Old Masters
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28Soviet and United States flags fluttered in the breeze outside the whitecolumned Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts while a group of art lovers at the wroughtiron gates begged in vain for admission.

title: 1,500 FullTime Teachers Getting Dismissal Notices
description: The Board of Education began sending layoff notices yesterday to 1,500 regularly licensed elementary and juniorhigh teachers because of the schools' financial crisis, and school officials voiced concern that the number of dismissed teachers would eventually be considerably higher.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The state's unemployment rate for July was 10.7 per Cent, unchanged from June, and the city's rate increased threetenths of 1 per cent to 12 per cent, the State Labor Department reported. Jobless workers in the state totaled 828,000 in July, down 8,100 from June; in the city the number was 384,700, up 6,400 from June. The city's unemployment level is 60 per cent higher than a year ago and higher than at any time in the last 25 years.

title: U.S. AND BAHAMAS END FISHING TALKS
description: MIAMI, Aug. 28Negotiations between the United States and the Bahamas over lobstering rights have broken down, and officials here are concerned about violence by the Florida fishermen whose livelihoods are affected.

title: Blackmun Refuses to Hear Louisville Integration Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Supreme Court Justice Harry A. Blackmun refused today to review a desegregation plan requiring the busing of students between Louisville and surrounding Jefferson County suburbs.

title: Bridge:
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional Tournament beginning today at the New York Hilton Hotel is unusual in two ways.

title: Congress Unit Hits Indiana Standard Bid for Occidental
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters)The thwarted plans of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana to merge with the Occidental Petroleum Company was an outright attempt to take over the smaller concern, a Congressional study concluded today.

title: People and Business
description: Massachusetts State Banking Commissioner Carol S. Greenwald has accused Federal banking officials of undermining efforts by state officials there to get national banks in Boston to provide her office voluntarily with mortgage placement data that would help the department determine if there has been redlining in Boston.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 3%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales in the latest week were an estimated $1.21billion, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $1.09billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.42billion, up 3 per cent from last year's $11.1billion.

title: S. E. C. DISCLOSES SPONSORS OF TRIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI)Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission allow securities industry groups to pay their travel and hotel expenses, an S.E.C. spokesman confirmed today.

title: British Miners Vote By a Strong Margin To Back Wage Curb
description: LONDON, Aug. 28British coal miners, for years at the top of the wageinflation spiral, have voted to limit their demands until the economic outlook improves.

title: SPECIALS MISSING AT 27 STORES HERE
description: Some advertised specials were not on the shelves at advertised prices in 27 of 48 supermarkets checked over the last several weeks, the city's Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.

title: 1,500 FullTime Teachers Getting Dismissal Notices
description: The Board of Education began sending layoff notices yesterday to 1,500 regularly licensed elementary and juniorhigh teachers because of the schools' financial crisis, and school officials voiced concern that the number of dismissed teachers would eventually be considerably higher.

title: O'Brien Denies Hoffa Presence in Car He Used
description: DETROIT, Aug. 28Charles L. O'Brien, the foster son of James R. Hoffa, denied today that Mr. Hoffa had been in a car that Mr. O'Brien had borrowed and driven on the day the former teamster leader disappeared.

title: ROCKEFELIER KNEW OF NURSING ABUSE
description: Vice President Rockefeller said yesterday that he knew of poor conditions in some New York nursing homes as early as 1965, but that he had been powerless to prevent Medicaid abuses by nursinghome operators because of state budgetary restrictions affecting audits and inspections.

title: PRESIDENT BACKED ON GAS PRICE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28President Ford released new data on the natural gas shortage to 16 state governors today and won from all but one expressions of support for the Administration's proposed remedies.

title: Mayor Orders 24 Aides To Give Up City Autos
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered 24 assistant administrators, deputy commissioners and assistant commissioners to give up their city cars to save the city money. He directed that the vehicles be sold at public auction.

title: Mexico's Hundred Million
description: MEXICO CITYThere are so many immediate and urgent problems in the world these days that it seems almost cruel to think about the problems of the future, hut the steep rise in the population of this magnificent country may be the most alarming fact in the relations between the United States and Latin America.

title: Jersey Parkway Removes Ban On Motorcycles Starting Nov. 1
description: The Garden State Parkway shifted gears on motorcycles yesterday, bowing to cyclists' demands that they be allowed to use the 172mile road.

title: Screen: Exciting 'White Line Fever'
description: The plot is inflated, the violence is inflatedthough well-shotthere is a lot of blacktop highway and a great many roaring vehicles that swerve, crash and burn.But "White Line Fever," a movie about truckers and racketeers, stands far above its own clichs. It has genuine excitement and a frequent beauty of style. It makes an occasional effort to treat a subject virtually unheard of in the movies nowadays, despite the recession; the pressure and bone-weariness of trying to earn a living. Finally, though the plot is often cardboard, it is inhabited by some real people who manage the ordinary human accomplishmentand the much rarer movie accomplishment  of intimacy."White Line Fever," which opened Tuesday at the Columbia I and other theaters in the metropolitan area, is about a young man who gets out of the Air Force, marries his sweetheart and goes into hock to buy a trailer rig. He wants to be a trucker, like his father: He finds that the business is dominated by a network of crooked businessmen, politicians and thugs.Refusing to join in by accepting contraband cigarettes as part of his cargo he is beaten up and blacklisted. He organizes a truckers' rebellion: He is shot at, beaten some more, framed on a murder charge, has a rattle-snake planted in his truck and is nearly burned to death with his pregnant wife.He and his supporters manage to get rid of some of the crooks, and finally they organize a statewide truckers strike. It seems to be a victory, of sorts, but there are glimpses of higher-ups and still-higher-ups who seem to be doing as well as ever at the end. It is a life-like inconclusiveness.The pace is fast, and the camera conveys beautifully the movement and danger in the big rigs. In a night scene, for example, the hurtling road is photographed from the cab at a steeper and steeper angle, giving the feeling that the blackness ahead is a wall.The rarity in an action picture of this kind is the quiet and sensitive acting of the two principals: Jan-Michael Vincent as the rebellious driver and Kay Lenz as his wife. They manage, tenderness quarreling and weariness as these things really are managed. They tie the melodramatics together.

title: Benin Charges Hospital Corporation Is Bereft of Experienced Managers
description: The chairman of the board of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation charged yesterday that the corporation was afflicted with managerial deficiencies and that its top management was bereft of people who have experience in health and hospital administration.

title: A Major Season to Light Up Broadway
description: Katharine Hepburn and Milton Berle, Henry Higgins and Dolly Levi, will all be back on Broadway. Vanessa Redgrave will make her Broadway debut, and her sister Lynn will make her Lincoln Center debut. Lerner and Bernstein are returning, the choreographer Patricia Birch is driving a Truckload of a musical, and there will be a boatload of London hits in town.

title: Lock Concern Sues To Enjoin the State On PayToilet Ban
description: ALBANY, Aug 28A State Supreme Court justice today delayed implementation of a law, due to go into effect next Monday, banning pay toilets in the state.

title: For Star Athletes, New York Is at the End of the Rainbow
description: They were toting brief cases instead of carpetbags, but they had the same thing in mind when they arrived from Hertford, N. C.; Beaver Falls, Pa.; San Mateo, Calif., Atlanta and Santos, Brazil. It's the thing that is causing a crisis in Hall but a gold rush in other parts of town for New York's expanding new colony of highpriced athletes.

title: She Arouses Imaginations Of Children
description: What is a porcupine? asked the story book reader.

title: Grace Loses To Kenney In U.S Golf
description: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 28How the mighty are falling in the 75th United States Amateur championship. John Grace, last year's runnerup. today became the eighth of nine exempt players to be eliminated from this year's matchplay tournament on the James River Course of the Country Club of Virginia.

title: Advertising
description: If a man from Mars came to earth last weekend and looked at television either Saturday or Sunday afternoon he would have reported back home that all earthlings either run around a small court hitting a ball with a shortstringed racquet or walk about the countryside beating a small ball with a thin metal club.

title: Lock Concern Sues To Enjoin the State On PayToilet Ban
description: ALBANY, Aug 28.A State Supreme Court justice today delayed implementation of a law, due to go into effect next Monday, banning pay toilets in the state.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: He's 14 years old now, planning to go into ninth grade, maybe even on to college, and he thinks the panic he felt for years is gone for good. But he can vividly recall those six yearsfirst through sixth gradewhen he refused to go to school at all.

title: Ernst Loses Court Case
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (UPI) A former Cincinnati Bengals reserve quarterback, Mike Ernst, now playing with the Southern California Sun of the World Football League, has lost his bid to have a court give him disputed back pay from the Bengals.

title: Prosecutor Won't Give Wyman a Clean Bill of Health
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Watergate special prosecutor declined today to give Louis C. Wyman, the Republican Sen ate candidate in New Hampshire, the clean bill of health be requested.

title: S.E.C.'s Profit Forecast Plan Protested as a Spur to Secrecy
description: Last October, after the price of sugar had zoomed 165 per cent in 10 months, the CocaCola Company shocked Wall Street by firmly refusing to talk to security analyststhe men and women who keep investors informed on stocks to buy or sell.

title: ARABS BLACKLISTING AMERICAN CONCERNS
description: CAIRO, Aug. 28 (AP)Three major United States companies and the Rumanian airline Tarom were added to the Arab blacklist today for dealing with Israel.

title: Murillo Painting Stolen
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 28 (AP)A painting by the Spanish master Murillo, estimated by its businessman owner to be worth $1.6million, was stolen from his apartment here, the police reported today. The theft was discovered last night, when the businessman and his wife returned from vacation. The work, painted in 1676, is entitled Adoration of Death.

title: After 30 Years, Trials of Nazis Drag On
description: HAMBURG, West Germany It could have been 30 years ago in Nuremberg, but it was this July 4: Ludwig Hahn, head of the Gestapo in Germanoccupied Warsaw, was found guilty in the murder of at least 230,000 Polish Jews in World War II and was sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: Wynn Shares Golf Lead
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 28 (Ruters)  Christy O'Connor Jr. of Ireland and Bob Wynn of Britain carded eightunderpar 66's today to share the lead in the first round of the $50,000 Irish open golf championship at the Woodbrook Course. Tom Watson of Kansas City, this year's British Open champion, struggled to a 73.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN IN FARM FUTURES
description: Futures prices of most farm commodities closed lower yesterday in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Overturn in Peru
description: The overthrow of President Juan Velasco Alvarado in Peru and his replacement by Gen. Francisco Morales Bermildez is a setback for those forces, in and out of uniform, that strove for a more rapid, more drastic revolution. General Morales will not turn the clock back to 1968, when the armed forces overthrew the elected Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry, but he will almost certainly concentrate on consolidation of reforms already under way, rather than on dubious new adventures.

title: Reagan Political Aides, Convinced He Will Seek G.O.P. Nomination, Urge Early Decision
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29Despite some sharp nudging by his supporters, former Gov. Ronald Reagan is still biding his time about making a final decision on whether he will challenge President Ford for the Republican nomination next year.

title: BONN SETTING UP A PAINFUL BUDGET
description: BONN, Aug. 29The West German Government, running out of money to stimulate the flagging economy, decided today on what Finance Minister Hans Apel called a painful package of budget cuts and tax increases for 1976 and 1977.

title: RATE RISE GIVEN ON FIRE INSURANCE
description: A 38.2 per cent increase in fireinsurance rates for 91,000 New York State residents insured under the socalled Fair Plan, most of whom live in rundown neighborhoods, has been approved by the State Department of Insurance.

title: JOHN R. INMAN, AIDE OF RELIGION COUNCIL
description: John R. Inman. who retired three years ago as vice president of the Council on Religion and International Affairs after 27 years of activity in the cause of world peace, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital, in Cleveland. He was 63 years old and lived in Shaker Heights, Ohio, and formerly in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: SENATE UNIT PLANS U.S. POLICY HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee announced plans yesterday to try to deIvelop ideas on the course United States foreign policy should take in the next decade.

title: FORD SAID TO BACK A BRIEF REVIVAL OF OIL CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, conferred with President Ford today and reported afterward that Mr. Ford was willing to sign into law next month a revival of oil price controls of 30 to 45 days.

title: Opera: Sills in Top Form
description: Nobody's opera season is officially open in New York these days until Beverly Sills has appeared, and appear she did on Thursday night in the New York City Opera's I Puritani. The production was Tito Capobianco's appropriately dark and puritanical conception, but Miss Sills personally lighted it up every time she came into view as the virginal Elvira, and set fires of enthusiasm every time she opened her throat.

title: Expert Says Venice Has Stopped Sinking And Started Rising
description: ROME, Aug. 29The head of the Venice Geological Research Laboratory said today he believed that the city had stopped sinking into the sea and he did not expect it would sink any further.

title: Stage: Empty Presence
description: The wife, Louisa, through illness has become an automaton  losing power of speech and, apparently, sensibility. Her husband, Charlie, a schoolteacher, slavishly cares for her, trying to enlist the assistance of their preteenage daughter, who, more realistic and less sympathetic than the father, considers her mother dead.

title: BERGMAN AND SON TOLD TO TESTIFY
description: An acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday directed Bernard Bergman, and his son, Stanley, to appear before a stategrand jury in Trenton that is investigating Medicaid fraud and abuses in the nursinghome industry.

title: The City of Oz
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29In Washington Tuesday it was 112 degrees on the sidewalk and a cool 72 in the marble file cabinets where great men confer, lunch, nuzzle the telephone and otherwise engage in what is always called here, with no trace of selfmockery, the exercise of power.

title: I.T.T. PROVIDES FUND TO SETTLE 3 SUITS
description: Federal Judge Charles J. Brieant Jr., has approved settlement of three suits in which stockholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiary, the. Hartford Accident Indemnity Company claimed damages for the alleged misuse of inside information, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: 2 of Anfiola's 3 Rival Groups Agree on CeaseFire
description: LISBON, Aug. 29Two of Angola's three rival independence movements have reached an agreement on a ceasefire and an exchange of prisoners, official Portuguese sources announced today.

title: Thousands Ineptly Get Away From It All
description: In the railroads, some people read clearly printed departure signs and then proceed to ask several times what they say. On airplanes, they demand things they know they cannot have. In their cars, they load, up, drive away, and then suddenly realize they don't know where they're going. They can be cranky, bewildered, giddy, frustrated and sometimes moved to acts of violence.

title: 4 ON RAFT DROWN IN NIAGARA RIVER
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 29Four persons drowned today when a large raft carrying 29 persons on a test run through the treacherous whitewater rapids of the lower Niagara River was struck by a powerful wave and capsized, dumping its occupants into the swirling waters.

title: W. T. Grant Continues Its Big Deficits For the Second Quarter and First Half
Soviet Grain Outlook Reported Gloomier
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Agriculture Department today cut by five million tons its estimate of the Soviet Union's droughtravaged grain crop, but officials indicated that they did not expect the Russians to seek more United States grain to make up the shortage.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Gen. Vasco Goncalves, opposed for weeks by overwhelming military and political forces for trying to promote Communist rule in Portugal, was dismissed yesterday as Premier by President Francisco da Costa Games. He was replaced by Vice Adm. Jos Batista Pinheiro Azevedo, the 58yearold Chief of Staff of the navy. But a new conflict was seen possible: General Goncalves has been appointed Chief of Staff of the armed forces, a move his opponents also resisted. [Page I, Column 1.]

title: Bets and Boos
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 29It makes no difference to me now that people can bet on the Hambletonian, Stanley Dancer was saying today outside the executivesuite stall of the favorite, Bonefish. But my wife's not happy. When they began betting the other day, she was sitting in the grandstand and the people started to boo over a couple of false starts because now they had parimutuels. She just thought. This won't be the Du Quoin State Fair anymore. Rachel Dancer's qualms were being shared by some other traditionalists on the pleasant old fairgrounds in the corn fields of southern, Illinois because the Hambletonian reaches 50 years of age tomorrow and something new has been added. Besides the $2 windows recently installed in the grandstand where they used to sell souvenirs and tractors, the country setting will include modern touches like network television, a record purse of $232,192 and an early line established by Jimmy the Greek, who came all the way from Las Vegas to do the numbers.

title: Judge Refuses Bid to Open Robert Kennedy Death Data
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (UPI) A Superior Court judge dedined today to order the Los Angeles Police Department to open its files on the investigation of the 1968 assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York.

title: Karpov Loses First Game As World Chess Champion
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 29 (Reuters)The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, today lost his first game since he won the title last April by default from Bobby Fischer.

title: F.T.C. ACTS TO CURB GASMILEAGE ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission, seeking to bring some order out of the chaos, issued guidelines today to force auto makers to tell the whole truth about their cars' fuel economy.

title: Ford Bids Congress Limit Federal Pay Rises to 5%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29President Ford proposed today a 5 per cent increase in pay for all Federal employes, including members of Congress.

title: 3 Die as Test Raft With 29 Capsizes in Niagara River
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 29Three persons drowned today when a large raft carrying 29 persons on a test run through the treacherous whitewater rapids of the lower Niagara River was struck by a powerful wave and capsized, dumping its occupants into the swirling waters.

title: An Act Of Charity By Giants
description: The size of the crowd and not so much the outcome of the game will be of interest today when the New York Giants play the Super Bowl champions, the Pittsburgh Steelers, at Princeton's Palmer Stadium.

title: PAUL E. PADDOCK JR., WRITER ON FAMINE
description: Paul E. Paddock Jr., who with his brother William wrote Famine1975! America's Decision: Who Will Survive? in 1967, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 67 years old.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday. London: Morning fixing $161.50, off .20; afternoon fixing $159.00, off $2.10.

title: Reordered World
description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which will be meeting all next week in Washington, were war babies. These sister organizations, whose membership includes almost every nation in the nonCommunist world, were born at Bretton Woods, N. H., in 1944when, with World War II victory in sight, the United States was clearly emerging as the most powerful leader of the postwar world.

title: Notes on People
description: The longdelayed return of Prince Norodom Sihanouk to Cambodia, ending five years of exile, has been set for Sept. 9 or 10, Peking sources said yesterday. Going with him, they said, will be his wife, Princess Monique, and two of his sons: Penn Nouth, the titular Cambodian premier, and his wife, and perhaps two or three others of the Prince's retinueinexile of 50 members.

title: Festival at Great Falls To Help Mark Holiday
description: PATERSON, Aug. 29A high wire walk by a family over the Great Falls here, a parade in Lodi honoring the patron saint of workers and a splash of multicolored fireworks are some of the events scheduled for the Labor Day weekend in Passaic and Bergen Counties.

title: Dance: Park Festival Off to Fine Start
description: It just demonstrates the popularity of dance, said a recent convert, Joseph Papp, explaining why he and his staff had been obliged to turn ticketseekers away front the capacitystrong opening of the New York Dance Festival Thursday night in Central Park's Delacorte Theater.

title: A Police Sharpshooter Kills Jones Beach Shark
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 29 (AP)A police sharpshooter killed a 10footlong shark at Jones Beach today as thousands of bathers watched from the sand after being ordered out of the water. No one was injured.

title: 18 Oil Companies Pick Offshore Tracts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Department of Interior announced today that 18 oil comipanies had nominated 10.9 million acres on the Georges Bank Trough on the Outer Continental Shelf off Massachusetts and Rhode Island that they would like offered for oil and gas leases.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was time somebody set the record straight and showed how American expatriates transformed literary Paris in the nineteentwenties and thirties, and not the other way round. Too many memoirs of that period have played up the impact of the international scene on the lost generation of American writers, while barely acknowledging that it was a group of talented, plucky Americans who got the modernist movement (begun in France and England) off the ground. Though Hugh Ford's chunky, awkwardly assembled chronicle includes British expatriates as

title: RUSSELL SMITH, 60, N.Y.U. DEAN, DIES.
description: Russell F. W. Smith, dean of New York University's School of Continuing Education for the last 10 years, died yesterday at N.Y.U.'s Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine of complications growing out of a cerebral hemorrhage he suffered on Aug. 6 while vacationing in Vermont. He was 60 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: People and Business
description: Knut Hagrup, president of the International Air Transport Association, predicted yesterday a twopart increase in lair fares that could total as much as 12 per cent by the end of next year. But he added that such an advance would be insufficient to pull the industry out of its immediate economic difficulties.

title: Rugged Defensive Line of Falcons Is Woodall's Problem, Not Namath's
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 29No one ever blamed the Falcons' front four for last season's 311 wonlost record. When a club puts an average of only 8 points a game on the scoreboard, even the best defense is hopeless to prevent a losing campaign.

title: Antiques: Tracing the Shakers' Legacy of Design
description: HASTINGS, N. Y.A detour taken 52 years ago to buy freshfromtheoven bread dramatically changed the course of Faith and ward Deming Andrews's lives. For beyond the loaves in that immaculate basement cookroom at Hancock (N. H.) Shaker Village, they saw austere benches, spare, slatback rockers, a lean trestle table and asymmetric cupboards, all of haunting grace and unlike anything they had before.

title: FlipTop Cans Banned
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. last night signed a conservationist bill banning fliptop beverage cans, effective in 1979.

title: Firemen Tentatively Accept Pact, and a Pay Freeze
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association reached a tentative contract settlement with the city yesterday, then voluntarily agreed to a wage freeze, shortly before Mayor Beame signed an executive order imposing the pay freeze on city employes as of Monday.

title: PARLEY GOES ON AS COUP OCCURS
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29The President of the host Government was deposed today, but the weeklong conference of foreign ministers of 82 developing nations continued here without interruption.

title: Beating Gerulaitis Is No Upset to Jauffret
description: Vitas Gerulaitis bent down to gather his tennis gear from the court after he had just become the first men's seeded player to lose in the United States Open at Forest Hills. When he straightened up he was confronted with a mural of disappointed and accusing faces stretched across one entire side of the court.

title: Tomahawks End Season by Winning
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 29 Brian Keegan and Chuck Medhurst scored in the closing 55 seconds to give the Long Island Tomahawks, a 1917 victory over the Philadelphia Wings in the final regularseason game of the National Lacrosse League tonight before 4,322 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Governor Is Considering A Session on Fiscal Panel
description: Governor Carey plans to call a special session of the Legislature next week if an intricate package of financing arrangements can be worked out this weekend to raise the cash the city needs to avert a default in the days ahead.

title: Tourism Called Peril To Culture in Pacific
description: VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 29Millions of tourists are invading the Pacific islands, and this last week ethnologists met here to discuss whether the native cultures can survive the invasion.

title: In Memoriam
description: KONOWITZBernard. Gone 25 years ago today. Greatly loved and respected. Always ??ed. JOE, CHARLIE, SHIRLEY, MILTON AND MARVIN.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Boeing Company received a $106million Air Force contract for improvement of Minuteman Intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: Schlesinger Chides japan on Defense
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger criticized the Japanese today for having been too much a passive partner in security and urged them to assume a more active role.

title: Bridge:
description: Players who open substandard hands are likely to create swings, sometimes in their favor, sometimes not.

title: I.B.M. FILES A BRIEF OPPOSING TELEX SUIT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has filed a brief with the United States Supreme Court in opposition to an earlier petition by the Telex Corporation. Telex had requested a review of the Appeals Court decision, which held that I.B.M. had not violated the antitrust laws as charged in a 1972 suit filed by Telex.

title: British Find Deck of a Ship From the Spanish Armada
description: LONDON, Aug. 29The deck of a ship of the Spanish Armaada, the fleet that was to convoy an invading army to England and seize the throne of Queen Elizabeth I, has been found at Tobermory Bay, on the island of Mull, off western Scotland.

title: After Soviet Inquiry, U.N. Bars Private Conference
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 29United Nations officials, apparently worried about displeasing the Soviet delegation, have abruptly revoked permission for the use here of a large conference hall by accredited private groups for a nineday forum on economic matters.

title: Texturizing Device Expected to Yield Many New Fabrics
description: A new method for processing polyester and nylon filament into textured yarns at a very high rate of speed promises to give the apparel and home furnishings trades a wide variety of new fabrics.

title: North Gets 27 for Nine, Leads at 63
description: ENDICOTT, N. Y., Aug. 29 (AP)Andy North shot a recordtying 27 for nine holes and an eightunderpar 63 today to takethe firstround lead in the B.C. open golf tournament.

title: Soybeans Offer Varied Dairy Foods
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29A beverage base made of soybeans offers what are depicted as varied cheap and nutritious substitute dairy products, including milk, yogurt, margarine, puddings and ice cream. Three professors in the department of food science at the University of Illinois, Urbana, were awarded. Patent 3,901,978 this week for the process. Licenses have been granted for production in the United States and many other countries.

title: Penn Central Asks Rises of Up to 25% In Commuter Fares
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (UPI)The Penn Central said today that it intended to raise commuter fares between Philadelphia and New York and New Jersey points by as much as 25 per cent on Oct. 1.

title: Treasury Bill Decline In Three and Six Month
description: WASHINGTON, Aug., 29  Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today, in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: UNITED PUTS OFF BOEING PURCHASE
description: United Airlines announced yesterday that its directors, at a meeting on Thursday, had deferred indefinitely a decision on purchasing 50 Boeing 727300 threeengine jet planes, costing $600million.

title: Token Sellers to Offer Free Copy of The Times
description: The New York Times said yesterday that it would try to relieve the gloom of subway riders next week when they start paying the new 50cent transit fare by giving away a complimentary copy of The Times with each purchase of a token at booths set up in Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station.

title: Redskins Conquer Lions, 3413
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)Bill Kilmer and Randy Johnson each threw two touchdown passes tonight as the Washington Redskins beat the Detroit Lions, 3413, in a National Football League exhibition.

title: FORD SAID TO BACK A BRIEF REVIVAL OF OIL CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, conferred with President Ford today and reported afterward that Mr. Ford was willing to sign into law next month a revival of oil price controls of 30 to 45 days.

title: Indonesia Bids Portugal Let Her Hold Timor Talks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Indonesian Government said today that it wanted to help end the fighting on Portuguese Timor and was seeking Portuguese authorization to hold talks on the island.

title: Nuptials Held for Mary T. Shanley and Tyler G. Hicks
description: Mary T. Shanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Shanley of East Rockaway. L.I., was married last evening to Tyler G. Hicks of Hicksville, L.L. a widower, who is editor in chief Tor engineering, science and management at the McGrawHill Book Company.

title: Basil Waters, a Top Editor With Knight and in Chicago
description: FRANKFORD, Ind., Aug. 29 (AP)Basil (Stuffy) Walters, former executive editor and a director of Knight Newspapers, Inc., and later editor of The Chicago Daily News, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at Clinton County Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Exploding Star Sighted; Biggest in 30 Years
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 29 (AP)An astronomer discovered a brilliant exploding star tonight, the biggest nova seen in 30 years, according to the Center of Astrophysics.

title: Ridley, Bean Post Upsets In U.S. Golf
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 29 Five students and three selfsupporting older guys that is, from age 26 to 40 shared honors today in the fourth and fifth rounds of the 75th United States Amateur, a matchplay golf championship being played on the picturesque James River Course of the Country Club of Virginia.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OSAKA, Japan. Aug. 29 (UPI)United States swimmers, headed by Jim Montgomery, Shirley Babashoff and Kathy Heddy, took five of six races tonight in the Japanese national swimming championships. Only Nobutaka Taguchi, 1972 Olympic Games gold medal winner, prevented American swimmers from sweeping all six events by winning the men's 100meter breaststroke. The Americans, who won all eight events yesterday, had little competition in the other races today.

title: Matlack Wins, 61, For Mets
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29Six runs in the first inning, before he had to throw a pitch, were all Jon Matlack needed tonight to pitch his 16th victory of the season, a 61 decision for the New York Mets over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: While in St. Tropez, It's the Jumpsuit Coverup
description: ST. TROPEZ, FranceIt's late afternoon and the crowd is seated at the terrace of Senequier, the most popular cafe, waiting for the beautiful women to come back from the beaches and stroll in front of the yachts lining the port. And what do they see? The silhouette of a garage mechanic, a carpenter, an army nurse, a house painter and a pilot. Jumpsuits are A la mode and, depending on how many zippers you want and where you want them, you choose your professional attire.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: John Joseph Kehn, a 20yearold Federal fugitive and bankrobbery suspect, was arrested in the Albany County village of Green Island by local police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation after a car chase. The suspect escaped on Aug. 5 from the Hernando County Courthouse, Brooksville, Fla.

title: P.S.C. Study Tells Why Con Ed's Rates Are High
description: A Public Service Commission investigation of why the Consolidated Edison Company's electric rates are the highest in the country has found that the most important reasons are the company's lack of cheap hydropower, its greater use of obsolete plants and the extraordinary hourly and seasonal peak demands made on its service along with sharp offpeak declines in usage.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Still Cutting White Man's Cane, Still Being Treated as Tools
description: THE three black men standing round the gas pump drinking beer that Sunday afternoon looked up at a car inching down the road of the sugarcane plantation.

title: Arthur Thompson, Who Wrote Novels as Francis Clifford, Dies
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  Arthur Bell Thompson, a wellknown writer of crime fiction under the pen name Francis Clifford, died Monday at the age of 57.

title: Tentatively Accept Pact and a Pay Freeze Firemen
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association reached a tentative contract settlement with the city yesterday, then voluntarily agreed to a wage freeze, shortly before Mayor Beame signed an executive order imposing the pay freeze on city employes as of Monday.

title: Earthquake in Alabama
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 29 (UPI)A minor to moderate earthquake shook homes and jarred residents awake in north Alabama late last night but there were no reports of injury or major damage.

title: Flying Tigers Will Buy Boeing Jumbo Jets
description: The Flying Tiger Line, the largest allcargo airline, said it has arranged to purchase three Boeing 747 jets that Delta Airlines has in passenger service and which. Doing expects to take back from Delta.

title: ROSENBERG DATA RELEASED BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Federal Bureau of Investigation has released to a professor of history at Smith College the first of its secret material on the espionage investigation of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, a 725page portion of the bureau's 48,000page file.

title: New Bangladesh Courts
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  The Bangladesh Government last night set up two special martiallaw courts to try individuals recently arrested on charges of corruption and illegal possession of arms. Those convicted face life imprisonment or execution.

title: Eamon de Valera, 92, Dies; Lifelong Fighter for Irish
description: Eamon de Valera, a chief strategist and fighter in the cause of Irish independence, who became Prime Minister, President, and revered elder statesman of the Republic of Ireland, died early yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: Soviet Grain Outlook Reported Gloomier
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Agriculture Department today cut by five million tons its estimate of the Soviet Union's droughtravaged grain crop, but officials indicated that they did not expect the Russians to seek more United States grain to make up the shortage.

title: Market Place
description: Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation have sunk to just about their lowest levels since public trading began July 21 in the original $1billion issue. The agency was created with the aim of saving New York City from defaulting on its securities and lately, with the outlook still uncertain on putting together another patchwork plan of financing most prices have eased anew.

title: Bridge:
description: Players who open substandard hands are likely to create swings, sometimes in their favor, sometimes not.

title: Antiques: Tracing the Shakers' Legacy of Design
description: HASTINGS, N. Y.A detour taken 52 years ago to buy freshfromtheoven bread dramatically changed the course of Faith and Edward Deming Andrews's lives. For beyond the loaves in that immaculate basement cookroom at Hancock (N. H.) Shaker Village, they saw austere benches, spare, slatback rockers, a lean trestle table and asymmetric cupboards, all of haunting grace and unlike anything they had ever seen before.

title: Farm Produce Prices Steady in MidMonth
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Average prices for raw farm products held unchanged in the month ended Aug. 15 as a drop in cattle, potato, and tonato prices offset further increases in other commodities, he Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Eamonde Valera, 92, Dies; Lifelong Fighter for Irish
description: Eamon de Valera, a chief strategist and fighter in the cause of Irish independence, who became Prime Minister, President, and revered elder statesman of the Republic of Ireland, died early yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an erroneous transmission by the Associated Press, The New York Times reported in its dividend table yesterday that Time Inc. had omitted its dividend Last week, the publishing company declared a dividend of 50 cents a share.

title: Bid to Buy Copperweld
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (UPI) The Copperweld Corporation said today it had been advised that a foreign company had offered to purchase all its stock. The concern said it had no comment on the offer.

title: Lima Regime an Enigmatic Blend
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29After seven years in power, the leftist military Government that had vowed to carry out a revolutionary transformation of Peruvian society still remains an enigma to both its supporters and critics.

title: He Found That You Can Add Apples and Politics
description: Oscar Bell is a fruiterer. Peaches, pears and plums are part of the business, and for him, so is politics.

title: 85 Yachts Leave From Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29The 41st annual Stamford Vineyard Race drew 85 yachts ranging from 30 to 80 feet in length for the start off Stamford Harbor today.

title: GOLDIN IS UPHELD
description: New York City has an accumulated deficit of $3.3billion, Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, State Controller Arthur Levitt, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation agreed yesterday.

title: SWITCH FROM GAS BY INDUSTRY SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Most industrial users of natural gas in the Northeast can substitute other fuels and can probably ride out this winter's expected gas shortage without major losses of production or jobs, according to a Government analysis.

title: 46BILLION LOST IN CROP FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) Faulty crop forecasting by the Agriculture Department resulted in wrong policy ddoisions that cost the Government $1.67billion in a year, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: Rockefeller Remembers
description: Vice President Rockefeller's testimony before the Moreland Commission on nursing homes was an imaginative exercise in retrospection. The core of the former Governor's defense of his policies and actions was twofold: Either the damage didn't happen on his watch the remedies to the wrongs which did happen on his watch were too expensive. Neither answer is persuasive.

title: F.H.A. Rate of 9% Set for Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The interest ceiling on Governmentbacked mortgage loans will be raised to 9 per cent Tuesday, Housing Secretary Carla Hills said today.

title: Gold Price Slumps In Europe Trading
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 29 (UPI)The price of gold fell sharply in Europe today, closing in London at its lowest level this year. The United States dollar, after vacillating during the week, closed stronger against all European currencies except the pound.

title: ISRAELI TIES PACT ON SINAI TO ROLE BY U.S. IN PASSES
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 29Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel said tonight that the presence of American technicians in the Sinai passes was one of the central conditions of Israel's willingness to agree to a new disengagement accord with Egypt. He called on Congress and the American public to support this overseas involvement.

title: Foreclosure Action Is Begun Against the Chrysler Building
description: Foreclosure proceedings have begun against the Chrysler Building, a city landmark since it was opened in 1930.

title: AID ON BOND ISSUE ASKED BY SAGNER
description: TRENTON, Aug. 29State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner met with Hudson County officials for four hours today to outline state plans for highway and local road projects and he hoped to convince county Democratic leaders to drop their threatened opposition to a proposed $560million transportation bond issue.

title: Miller Will Raise Capacity Of Its Brewery at Fulton
description: The Miller Brewing Company has announced that it will increase the annual capacity of its brewery under construction in Fulton, N.Y., to 3.3 million barrels annually from the initial 2 million previously announced.

title: Soviet, Reflecting Concern, Tightens Harvesting Rules
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29Soviet legal authorities have ordered tighter supervision of the grain harvest and warned that those guilty of theft and spoilage will be prosecuted.

title: ;Controversy Was the Order of 5 Days At U.S. Sociologists Meeting on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 Consensus has its devotees, but the 70th annual meeting of the American Sociological Association is concentrating on conflict and controversy.

title: Dietz Is Eliminated In World Rowing
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 29The United States had a dismal day today in the semifinal rounds of the world rowing championships, qualifying only one crew for medal honors.

title: Tokyo Also Has Some Financial Problems, but They Are Not in New York's League
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29  Officials of the Tokyo metropolitan government disclosed recently that they had projected a previously unexpected $500million drop in tax revenue in the current fiscal year.

title: People in Sports
description: If you keep your mouth shut, you can sit in here, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, was told by Bud Grant, coach of the Minnesota Vikings at the National Football League club's training quarters in Mankato, Minn. The Senator had been brought into Grant's daily news conference by Max Winter, the Vikings' president. Humphrey grinned and answered, I'm just here to watch. Later he jokingly said he was on hand to do a little scouting for the Washington Redskins... Damien Nygaard, a former football player from Australia, was signed yesterday by the Green Bay Packers of the N.F.L. The 30yearold kicker had played for 10 years Down Under.

title: Hurricane Caroline Stalls 270 Miles Off Texas Coast
description: MIAMI Aug. 29 (AP)Caronline, the season's second hurricane, gathered strength late today, but remained virtually stationary in the Gulf of Mexico off the Texas coast.

title: Saigon Gives Governing Share To Some NonRed Foes of Thieu
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 29A number of former members of the socalled third force opposition in South Vietnam have quietly begun appearing in the governing bodies being set up by the Communist Government, according to intelligence reports, broadcasts and reports from travelers from Vietnam.

title: PROCOMMUNIST PREMIER IN PORTUGAL IS REPLACED IN APPARENT COMPROMISE
description: LISBON, Aug. 29  Gen. Vasco Gonalves opposed for weeks by overwhelming military and political forces for trying to promote Communist rule in Portugal, was dismissed as Premier tonight by President Francisco da Costa Gomes.

title: U.S. Assured on Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  United States Energy Administrator Frank Zarb said today Venezuela's nationalization of foreign oil companies would not affect United States consumers. Venezuela is the major foreign supplier of oil to the United States, providing about 23 per cent of total American imports. Mr. Zarb said in a statement that Venezuelan officials had assured the United States the transition from private to state ownership would not result in any disruption of supply of petroleum or its price.

title: President of Peru Ousted In Coup Led by the Military
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29The President of Peru, who has headed a leftist military government for seven years, was overthrown today in an apparently bloodless military coup.

title: Floyd Barger, Former Editor Of The Daily News, Dies at 68
description: Floyd Barger, who retired Aug. 1 as editor and a senior vice president of The Daily News, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I. Mr. Barger, who had been ill for several weeks, was 68 years old and lived in Garden City, L. I.

title: F.H.A. Rate of 9% Set for Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The interest ceiling on Governmentbacked mortgage loans will be raised to 9 per cent Tuesday, Housing Secretary Carla Hills said today.

title: Walker Wins Mile in 3:53.62
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters)John Walker of New Zealand, the world recordholder, won the mile in 3 minutes 53.62 seconds in an international track meet tonight at the Crystal Palace.

title: PRESENT TOKENS KEPT FOR FARES
description: The present token will remain in use when subway and bus fares rise from 35 to 50 cents at 12:01 A.M. Monday, David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Governor Reports Cut Of 5,820 State Jobs
description: ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP)Governor Carey's office says that 5,820 permanent state jobs were vacated between Jan. 8 and Aug. 20, reducing the state's permanent work force to 178,017.

title: Ford Hails de Valera as Symbol of Ireland
description: President Ford expressed profound regret yesterday over the death of Eamon de Valera of Ireland, who, he said, had been a symbol of Ireland's ideals and aspirations for more than half a century.

title: Gas Works Is Centerpiece of Seattle Park
description: SEATTLESince 1906, an enormous gas refining plant has occupied a prominent site at the edge of Lake Union in the center of this city, and for almost as many years, local residents have been complaining about the way it marred the landscape.

title: Appliance Makers Join Plan to Save Energy and Money
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)Manufacturers who produce 94 per cent of all the home appliances sold in the nation have pledged to take part in a voluntary program aimed at conserving energy and helping consumers pick the most effective products.

title: The Eagle Has Landed
description: Just after 1 P.M. yesterday the Coast Guard sailing ship Eagle appeared in the Narrows, a lone stand of masts on the gray horizon.

title: Thousands Ineptly Get Away From It All
description: In the railroads, some people read clearly printed departure signs and then proceed to ask several times what they say. On airplanes, they demand things they know they cannot have. In their cars, they load up, drive away, and then suddenly realize they don't know where they're going. They can be cranky, bewildered, giddy, frustrated and sometimes moved to acts of violence.

title: DR. LASZLO RAVASZ, HUNGARIAN BISHOP
description: Dr. Laszlo Ravasz, retired Bishop of the Reformed Church of Hungary, died Aug. 6 in Budapest, church officials here learned yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: Lisbon Sees Arson in Rash of Forest Fires
description: LISBON, Aug. 29Portuguese fire fighters are struggling to contain this country's worst wave of forest fires, said to have been in large part by saboteurs.

title: 25 Protest Brutalization Of Raped Women in U.S.
description: MORRISTOWN, Aug 29 About 25 women, members of two local chapters of the National Organization for Women, concluded a weeklong observance of the 55th anniversary of woman's suffrage tonight by staging a mock funeral cortege on the sidewalks this town's main street.

title: CHARLES E. HONCE, EDITOR, DIES AT 79
description: Charles E. Honce, who rose from a $14 a week reporter in Keokuk, Iowa, to become an assistant general manager of The Associated Press, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 30 Beekman Place.

title: Barbara Ann Liebig Married to Lawyer
description: Barbara An Liebig, a music therapist at the Children's Day Treatment Center and School here, was married yesterday afternoon to William Jay Thomashower, a lawyer with the firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in the BethEl Chanel of Temple EmanuEl.

title: M.A.C. on City Budget Picture
description: Following is the text of the document released yesterday by the Municipal Assistance Corporation summarizing past and present deficits of New York City and containing current projections of city revenues and expenses through the fiscal year 197778.

title: Investor Confidence Based on Belief Peak Is Reached
description: Growing investor confidence that interest rates might ave peaked helped the stock market advance yesterday in slightly higher trading.

title: Black Racer Is Backed By Sponsor
description: Benny Scott, an associate professor of psychology at Mission College in Los Angeles, broke a color barrier in auto racing yesterday when the Brown and Williamson Tobacco Corporation announced it would sponsor the Black American Racers team in Formula 5000 race Sept. 28 at Long Beach, Calif.

title: Call for Volunteers
description: In appealing to its members to help clear away litter in front of their stores, the Fifth Avenue Association has spotlighted a priority that should not stop with tidying up the city's principal shopping areas. Volunteer action can be a help all over the city in keeping up standards of civic housekeeping while bringing down the costs of urban government.

title: PESTICIDE FOUND IN WORKERS' KIN
description: HOPEWELL, Va., Aug. 29 (UPI)The number of persons in this bluecollar city with traces of the pesticide Kepone in their blood increases as the authorities try to determine the poison's longterm effect on humans.

title: GOLDIN IS UPHELD
description: New York City has an accumulated deficit of $3.3billion, Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, State Controller Arthur Levitt, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation agreed yesterday.

title: Governor Is Considering A Session on Fiscal Panel
description: Governor Carey plans to call a special session of the Legislature next week if an intricate package of financing arrangements can be worked out this weekend to raise the cash the city needs to avert a default in the days ahead.

title: Some in Congress Oppose A U.S. Presence in Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that he was against the stationing of an American monitoring team in Sinai to police an EgyptianIsraeli peace agreement.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: PESTICIDE FOUND IN WORKERS' KIN
description: HOPEWELL, Va., Aug. 29 (UPI)The number of persons in this bluecollar city with traces of the pesticide Kepone in their blood increases as the authorities try to determine the poison's longterm effect on humans.

title: Toward the Reconstruction of Portugal
description: LISBONPortugal is facing one of the gravest crises of her 800year history as a consequence of a halfcentury of fascist dictatorship and also of the direction that the revolution, initiated April 25, 1974; has taken in the last few months.

title: Merrill Will Offer OddLot Purchases Without Extra Fee
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., notified the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that effective Oct. 1 it expected to offer its customers an opportunity to buy odd lotsstocks in amounts of less than 100 shareswithout having to pay an extra fee for buying an odd lot.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FLOATING Starting today, people here can test their sea legs either at dockside, with the Coast Guard's sailing ship Eagle, open for free public inspections at the South Street Seaport, or out on the bay aboard the sloop Clearwater, in paid excursions leaving Staten Island.

title: Moscow and Met Museum Agree on 5 Art Exchanges
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29  Five major exchanges of art exhibitions between the United States and the Soviet Union will take place between now and 1980 wider an agreement signed today by Soviet cultural officials and Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: PRESENT TOKENS KEPT FOR FARES
description: The present token will remain in use when subway and bus fares rise from 35 to 50 cents at 12:01 A.M. Monday, David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced yesterday.

title: Board and Teachers Seek State Aid in Reaching Pad
description: The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers called yesterday for state help to avert a teachers' strike threatened for Sept. 9, the day after the fall school term begins.

title: INDIANA STANDARD HOLDS OIL PRICE
description: Standard Oil CompanyIndianaannounced yesterday that it planned to continue its present posted prices for crude oil because of uncertainties over future legislative and executive actions. The posted price is the price that oil companies will pay to any producer of oil, including themselves.

title: SONNY STITT, LONER, PLAYS AT VANGUARD
description: Sonny Stitt, the persistent loner of jazz who has been traveling as a single for 16 years, picking up local rhythm sections wherever he goes, is at the Village Vanguard this week for the first time in a decade. Backed by Ron Burton on piano; Major Holley, bass, and John Lewis, drums, Mr. Stitt, playing alto saxophone, continues to be one of the few jazz musicians of the postWorld War II era who stay within easy hailing distance of the melody when improvising.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an erroneous transmission by the Associated Press, The New York Times reported in its dividend table yesterday that Time Inc. had omitted its dividend. Last week, the publishing company declared a dividend of 50 cents a share.

title: A Maker of Ireland
description: If I wish to know what the Irish want, said Eamon de Valera, I look into my own heart. It was a claim that recalled Charles de Gaulle's selfidentification with France; but not even Mr. de Valera's onetime British enemies nor his most implacable foes on Ireland's political battlefronts would seriously challenge its validity.

title: Newark Headquarters Emptied by a Grenade
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29 (UPI)An auxiliary Newark policewoman walked into Police Headquarters here today with a grenade she said he had taken from her brother after he allegedly had threatened to kill members of her family.

title: Venezuela Nationalizes Her Petroleum Industry
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 29President Carlos Andrs Prez of Venezuela signed into law today a bill ordering the nationalization of the country's petroleum industry, with the Government taking complete control on Jan. 1, ending more than half a century of dominance by foreign oil companies.

title: Savoir Is Victor In Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. Aug. 29  Savoir again was being saluted as the top trotter in the world tonight after capturing the $50,000 Challenge Cup at Roosevelt Raceway with ease in the sixhorse field before 20,488 spectators.

title: ISRAELI TIES PACT ON SINAI TO ROLE BY U.S. IN PASSES
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 29Foreign Minister Yigal Alton of Israel said tonight that the presence of American technicians in the Sinai passes was one of the central conditions of Israel's willingness to agree to a new disengagement accord with Egypt. He called on Congress and the American public to support this overseas involvement.

title: Tass Denies Soviet Sent Money To Portugal's Communist Party
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29The Soviet press agency Tass denied today that the Soviet Union had transferred funds to the Portuguese Communist party by laundering them through a SovietBelgian shipping company in Antwerp.

title: 2 Judges Bid Alabama Prisons Stop Accepting New Convicts
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 29 Two Federal judges ordered Alabama prison authorities today to stop accepting any new prisoners until the inmate population of the state's penal institutions reached a manageable proportion.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Moscow and Met Museum Agree on 5 Art Exchanges
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29  Five major exchanges of art exhibitions between the United States and the Soviet Union will take place between now and 1980 under an agreement signed today by Soviet cultural officials and Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 30, 1975

title: The Uninhibited Summer Dressing for Work in the City
description: When they're covering up as parachute jumpers at St. Tropez, the sandy strip where toplessness started, it figures that in the concrete canyons of Gotham they're letting it all hang out. This August's beachheads are the office, the subway and the sidewalks of New York.

title: Kent State Juror Calls Recordings Crucial to Verdict
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP)A juror in the Kent State damage trial said today that the deciding factor in the case had been film and tape recordings made during the seconds before Ohio National Guardsmen opened fire on antiwar demonstrators on May 4, 1970.

title: Ships Turned Into Steel Scrap On South Camden Waterfront
description: The South Camden waterfront, just above the Walt Whitman Bridge, is alive these days with the hiss of cutting torches and the clanging of sledge hammers. The sounds emanate from a shipscrapping operation started in 1973 by Ships, Inc. The company, headed by Louis M. Sarco, took over four covered shipbuilding berths of the defunct New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

title: 7 Seeded Players Lase In. U. S. Tennis
description: The United States Open tennis championships lost seven seeded players yesterday, all in the second round. Five of the upsets occurred in the Men's singles and two in women's competition. A record crowd of 16,299 persons attended the matches at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Bell Seeks Wider Charges for Information
description: The Bell Telephone System and most of the nation's major independent telephone companies are pressing state utility regulators to approve increases in charges to customers for directory assistance and paytelephone calls.

title: Lu Ahead by 5 Strokes
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 29 (AP)Lu LiangHuan of Taiwan shot a sevenunderpar 65 today and widened his lead to five strokes after two rounds of the $66,666 Hiroshima open golf championship. The 38yearold Lu has a 36hole total of 131.

title: 1,200 Apartments Going Up at Guttenberg
description: GUTTENBERG, Aug. 29Among the proliferating high rises marching along the Palisades in growing ranks is the Galaxy, a 1,200  apartment, multilevel complex here that will include a twolevel shopping mall built into the sides of the cliff and is scheduled to open next July.

title: Rockefeller Testifies on Attica For 3 Hours Before Grand Jury
description: WARSAW, N. Y., Aug. 29Vice President Rockefeller, arriving here to testify before a grand jury investigating the prison uprising at Attica four years ago, said today that guards and state police should have been sent in at the outset of the rebellion to retake the orison.

title: Lutherans Switch College Aides In Light of Missouri Synod Split
description: ST. PAUL. Minn., Aug. 29The controversy between conservatives and moderates in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod has brought changes in leadership in two more synod colleges.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Kallinger Seeks Change of Venue

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Layoffs or workers in manufacturing dropped sharply again in July to their lowest Jevel in almost a year, the Labor Department reported today. At the same time, factory hiring rose substantially.

title: Wit of Glaser Adds Snap To GraphicDesign Show
description: Milton Glaser is a witty fellow. This in itself would not qualify him for an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, but it adds a most welcome fizz and snap to the show of his graphic designs  posters, record sleeves, stationery, book jackets and many other things besidesthat is on now at the Modern Museum and will be there through Sept. 14.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SovietCuban Pact Signed
description: HAVANA, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Cuba and the Soviet Union signed a cooperation agreement for peaceful use of nuclear energy, the newspaper Juventud Rebelde said here today.

title: Spain Dooms 2 Basque Rebels; Area Swept by Demonstrations
description: BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 29 (Reuters)Two Basque nationalist guerrillas were condemned to death today as a wave of protest demonstrations and strikes swept the Basque country.

title: At Belmont Park . .
description: The 83d running of the Lawrence Realization will be this afternoon's feature. Ten 3yearolds have been named for the 1mile contest on the turf. Each will carry 117 pounds and, if all start, the event will be worth $57,900. Happy Hill Farm's Brian Boru is the 3to1 morningline favorite.... Introduced yesterday was a procedure by the track's announcer of naming horses claimed (and by whom) at the conclusion of each event for platers. . . . Phil G. Johnson, the trainer, is now pointing Tom and Judy Whitney's Bubbling for the Brighton Beach Handicap on Sept. 17. Bubbling is the filly purchased for $100,000 for strictly broodmare purposes. She acted as if she was eager to run and so was sent by the Whitneys to Johnson. On Aug. 16, he entered her in a grass race at Saratoga and she won by 6 lengths. She returned to the barn kicking and begging for her oats, said Johnson. To me that was a sure sign that this was one girl who loved to raceand that's what we're going to have her do.... Green Mill Farm's favored Frankie Adams was a 6length winner of yesterday's feature, the $20,000 Fast Count. The 4yearold colt, who had been sidelined since last May, beat Be a Native, coming home in 1:11 1/5 for six furlongs. He returned $5.40 for $2.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 208.4 from 207.8 last week.

title: H. STEWART WARNER
description: H. Stewart Warner, president and director of the Warner Label Company of Paterson, N.J., died Thursday at his home in HoHoKus, N.J. His age was 67.

title: M.A.C. on City's Budget Picture
description: Following is the text of the document released yesterday by the Municipal Assistance Corporation summarizing past and present deficits of New York City and containing current projections of city revenues and expenses through the fiscal year 197778.

title: Red Sox Conquer A's, 61 As Wise Hurls 17th Victory
description: Rick Wise, who won only three games for the Boston Red Sox last season because of injuries, has made a complete turnaround this year.

title: President of Peru Ousted In Coup Led by the Military
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29The President of Peru, who has headed a leftist military government for seven years, was overthrown today in an apparently bloodless military coup.

title: Foreclosure Begun on Chrysler Building
description: Foreclosure proceedings have begun against the Chrysler Building, a city landmark since it was opened in 1930.

title: Laos Officially Postpones Elections Until April
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 29 (AP)The royal council of Laos has officially postponed general elections until April, a Vientiane newspaper reported today.

title: Beame Is Stanch in Defense of Cavanagh
description: Mayor Beame refused publicly yesterday  as he had privately earlier in the weekto bow to pressure from bankers and dismiss his most trusted aide, First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh.

title: PRICES MOVE UP ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the OvertheCounter market advanced for the second straight day yesterday. Investors seemed confident that the economy would show advances toward the end of the year, said one analyst.

title: Libertarians Nominate Lawyer As '76 Presidential Candidate
description: Roger Lea MacBride, a 46yearold lawyer and television producer from Charlottesville, Va., was nominated by the Libertarian party yesterday as its Presidential candidate in next year's election.

title: Adlai: The Springfield Years
description: In 1949, when thenVice President Alben Barkley was married at age 71, his wedding was covered by Patricia Milligan (afterward Harris), then chief of bureau for International News Service out of Springfield, Ill. After all, weddings were women's news, I was a woman, and therefore automatically qualified to do the job. What INS didn't know was that I was almost totally ignorant of fashions, I had very little clothes sense, I had difficulty recognizing any but the most vivid hues, and I had never covered a wedding in my life.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: NEW LONDON, CONN. The American Dance Festival is not what it used to be. That observation was easy to come up with in 1969 when the annual summer festival, established in 1948 on Connecticut College's campus here, acquired a new director who promised new directions. Surprisingly and seven summers later, it is still possible to say that the American Dance Festival is not what it used to be. Flux, in fact, has become the policy of the festival regime headed since 1969 by Charles Reinhart.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: threw the spade queen, leaving this position:

title: Repairs Stall Opening of Barnegat Lighth
description: BARNEGAT LIGHTMuch to the disappointment of the thousands of tourists who visit the state park here daily, there is little hope that Old Barney, the storied Barnegat Lighthouse, will be opened to the public soon.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne may be on the lookout soon for a new Commissioner for the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Letters
description: Try, try again

title: N.CA.A. Football Cutbacks Irk Major College Powers
description: Fifty to 75 of the major college football powers are near a point of decision break off from the National Collegiate Athletic Association and form their own conference complete with all the television revenue and large gate receipts or remain and accede to N.C.A.A. regulations that could include increased taxation on TV income.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE COMMERCE DEPARTMENT reported a trade surplus of $971million for July, the fourth largest in history but down from the record $1.73billion of June....The index of Leading Economic Indicators rose 1.7 per cent in July to 179.2 [with the 1967 level as 100].... Newcar sales in the second 10 days of August totaled 201,177 units, 6.2 per cent less than the yearearlier figure.... General Motors says it will raise prices of its 1976 trucks by an average of 7.3 per cent, or $357 a vehicle.

title: West Indians Celebrating THE Carnivalin Brooklyn
description: When Rufus Gorin leads his group of 400 calypso steel bandsmen and costumed, bouncy merrymakers down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn tomorrow, he will be one of nearly a million persons whose heart and soul return home to the West Indies at this time each year.

title: LEE KONITZ LEADS NINEPIECE BAND
description: Somewhat to his surprise, Lee Konitz, who has spent most of his career playing alto or soprano saxophone with small jazz groups, now finds himself leading a ninepiece band. The band was organized specifically for a a tour of Italy last July, but when the tour fell through Mr. Konitz decided to keep it together. The band has been playing every Wednesday at Stryker's Pub, 103 West 86th Street, and, starting Sept. 10, will be there on Wednesdays and Thursdays.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: Hamptons Crafts Shop With a Worldly Outlook
description: EAST HAMPTON  Lynn Kroll loves to travel. This wanderlustand a desire to put down roots in the community she and her fabricdesigner husband, Boris Kroll, selected for a second homehave. resulted in The Beach Plum Tree, an unusual shop bursting with the crafts she has discovered on her journeys around the world and throughout the United States.

title: The Dakota Bans Some Cooling Units
description: The board of directors of the Dakota apartment house at 1 West 72d Street has voted unanimously not to permit the use of throughthewall airconditioners in the landmark building.

title: Feisty Young Dancer With a Company of His Own
description: The Manhattan debut of a new ballet company that includes American Ballet Theater stars Martine van Hamel and Bonnie Mathis is an event for dance buffs to look forward to. But they will have to look fast this week in order to catch Dancers, the fledgling company treated by Dennis Wayne, an impetuous, strongwilled, 30yearold soloist with Ballet Theater. Dancers makes its New York debut Tuesday evening with a oneweek season at the City Center Downstairs.

title: Average Wage on Farms Shows Rise of 7.5% in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)  The average wages of farm workers have risen about 7.5 per cent during the last year, an Agriculture Department survey shows. The Department's Crop Reporting Board said wage rates in all farm labor payment systems during the week ended July 12 averaged $2.29 an hour, up 16 cents from a year earlier.

title: The Good Old Days of Furillo, Pafko and the Elusive Baseball
description: Major league baseball has gone soft on the youth of this country. It has nothing to do with television, high salaries or even the vehicles that are used to drive relief pitchers in from the bull pen. During our annual visit to Shea Stadium it all became clear. It was Ball Day, an invention, no doubt, of someone who wants to ruin America by spoiling its young people.

title: Nassau Supervisors Set Hearing Tuesday on Plan for a New County Legislature
description: MINEOLA The a Nassau County Board of Supervisors will hold a public hearing Tuesday on a plan mandated by the State Supreme Court for a 15member legislative body to replace the present sixmember board.

title: Turkey Vultures Undergo Banding
description: STANHOPEThere's just no way to get a Turkey vulture sick. They've been fed hogs with cholera, plus all kinds of poisons, but their digestive juices are so strong that they seem to neutralize everything. However, there've been reports that some of them haven't felt well after eating strychnine.

title: Record Enrollment Foreseen for Community Colleges Despite State Budget Cuts
description: TRENTON  Despite new budget restrictions imposed by the state, New Jersey's county community colleges appear headed for a record enrollment this fall. According to the Department of Higher Education, the total will be 4 to 5 per cent higher than it was for the 197475 term. There are 18 of these twoyear schools, including a new one in Hudson County, and early projections indicate a total enrollment of about 80,000 full and parttime students.

title: Sheriff Fights Back After Control of Jail Is Shifted to a Woman
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 30Sheriff John Duffy, ordered by the Board of Supervisors to surrender his control of San Diego's troubleplagued county jail to a woman, threatened this week to boycott the jail and transport its inmates out of the county.

title: DRUG RAID CHARGE CALLED MODIFIED
