description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AF)A man whose family filed a $4million suit against Federal agents who raided their home by mistake during a drug raid has changed his version of what happened according to an article published in The St. Louis GlobeDemocrat.

title: Illinois Abortion Bill Vetoed
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 30 (UPI)An abortion bill requiring parental consent or a husband's approval before an abortion is performed has been vetoed by Gov. Daniel Walker. The Governor said yesterday he was forced to veto the measure because there would have been two overlapping abortion laws in Illinois if he had signed it.

title: Ford Aides Now Fear Impact of City Default
description: After months of apparent unconcern over New York City's deteriorating fiscal condition, President Ford's principal economic advisers are now suggesting that default by the city could have serious national implications.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I am cutting down a maple tree in front of my house. How can I preserve the slices from the trunk? I would like to use them, bark and all, for serving and cheese trays.S.S., Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayKnoll Farms, Suffolk Avenue, Brentwood, L.I. Regular, green, amateurowner, special, junior and children's working hunters; junior and intermediate jumpers, adult horsemanship, equitation, 8:30 A.M.

title: National Security Agency Reported Eavesdropping On Most Private Cables
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The National Security Agency eavesdrops on virtually all cable, Telex and other nontelephone communications leaving and entering the United States and uses computers to sort and obtain intelligence from the contents, sources familiar with the operations said today.

title: Why Congress Should Not Kill the DISC
description: Exports have been the one significant area of growth in employment during the recession. Without rising exports, employment in the private sector would have declined by an additional 750,000 jobs. The number of private sector jobs has declined by a drastic 3.5 million since the fourth quarter of 1973. But it would have declined by more than 4.2 million if we had not had the increase in exports.

title: State Police Signing Up Minorities and Women
description: HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Aug. 30 A campaign to recruit more blacks, Hispanic people, Orientals, American Indians and women into the New York state police force has attracted more than 1,000 applications, with more expected before the deadline this Wednesday.

title: Preseason Football
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Dodgers Snap Streak at 5
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30A fivegame New York Met winning streak ended tonight in a 70 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers, but it didn't cost them any ground in the pennant race because the other three contenders in the National League East also lost.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: WASHINGTON. The veteran sat alone. Puffing at a cigarette. Sipping at a CocaCola. Alone with his crippled back and his injured ego. He had just made a weekend fool of himself on the stage of a strip joint in Boston with Panne Foxe, the Tidal Basin Bombshell. Now it was Monday, and he sat on a sofa, alone in the cloakroom of the House of Representatives of the United States, as a few yards away, on the House floor, the Democratic caucus was deciding to divest his Ways and Means Committee of its traditional power to assign new Democratic members to standing committees. He looked older than 65.

title: INDIANS PLAN SUIT IN LIQUOR FIGHT
description: MESCALERO, N.M., Aug. 30 Wendell Chino, president of the 2,500member Mescalero Apache Tribe, said today that a suit would be filed in Federal court to determine the authority of the State of New Mexico to license and regulate liquor sales on tribal lands.

title: Off Off Broadway Takes Center Stage
description: After reading the code, I realize that the people who made it do not understand me. They do not know what is going on.

title: SPENDERS BACKED IN A GALLUP POLL
description: Congressional candidates promising to support Federal spending programs carry slightly more public support than those who support an antispending position, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Turkey Sets Deadline For U.S. Troop Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)  The Defense Department says it has been told by Turkey that packages for United States troops stationed there  including Christmas gifts  must be mailed by Sept. 1.

title: Small Party for Stars Of State and Screen
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 30 (UPI)  Secretary of State Kissinger and his wife Nancy stayed up until 2 this morning, giving a small party in their hotel suite for Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, aides said.

title: A Tennis Umpire: Calm and Decisive
description: Will you yield? the umpire asked the linesman. The score was 44 in the tense final set of yesterday's duel between Wotjek Fibak of Poland and Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md. The rallies had been long and arduous, with neither player willing to desert the security of the backcourt.

title: CHESS
description: Different constellations of material are adapted to differing pawn formations; that is why one can put little faith, for example, in the formal material equivalents of rook plus two pawns with two minor pieces.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lawyers for a Soviet fishing trawler that the Coast Guard seized two weeks ago off Cape May, N.J., paid a $100,000 settlement of a civil complaint by the United States Government in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Friday. The Government had accused the trawler, the Zaraysk, of fishing illegally for lobster and crab on the Continental Shelf, but it agreed to release the 247foot trawler as a result of the settlement.

title: Megan Reilly Wed to Floyd Sisterhenm
description: Megan Dean Reilly and Floyd Allen Sisterhenm were married yesterday at noon in the garden of the bride's parents home in Darien, Conn.

title: Late Score Gives Cards 149 Victory
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP)  Jim Otis, a fullback, ran 5 yards into the end zone with 29 seconds remaining and lifted the St. Louis Cardinals to a 149 victory over the San Diego Chargers in a National Football League preseason game tonight.

title: Spring Nuptials Set By Robin Ann Leslie
description: The engagement of Robin Ann Leslie to Robert French Johnston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston of Lake Geneva, Wis., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Thompson Leslie 3d of Buenos Aires, Guadalajara, Mexico, and Walnut Creek, Calif., parents of the future bride. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Dr. Erica E. Johnson Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor L. Johnson of Sparta and Hackettstown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Erica Ellen Johnson to Victor A. Machcinski. Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor A. Machcinski of Danbury, Conn., and West Chatham, Mass.

title: Benji, a Doghouse Hero
description: For the motion picture industry, Labor Day has long been a significant date. This weekend is a tallying point that marks the end of a prime playing season, particularly for family films. which are genera?? ?? at the beginning of summer to capitalize on the audience potential of children out of school and adults on vacation.

title: Preseason Record Is Raised to 40
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 30 Yes, it was only an exhibition game. But it was quite an exhibition the New York Giants staged today in Princeton's Palmer Stadium as they defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 247, before a crowd of 38,185. Defeated? The Giants trounced the Steelers.

title: Pointers for Paperhangers
description: Today's wallcoverings (they are no longer called wallpapers because so many are made of plastic or fabric) are easier than ever for the doityourselfer to hang, but a few tricks of the trade will help the neophyte to avoid disappointment.

title: Bonefish, 3d Heat Victor, Takes Hambletonian Final
Fergus, Ridley in Golf Final
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 30Fred S. Ridley, a 23yearold law student, and Keith Fergus, a 21yearold businessadministration major, will play tomorrow for the 75th United States Amateur golf championship in a 36hole match over the pleasantly rolling James River Course of the Country Club of Virginia.

title: Bobby Fischer Files Suit Over Unauthorized Book
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (Reuters)Bobby Fischer, the former world chess champion, has filed a $20million suit for invasion of privacy against the writer and publishers of an unauthorized book about him.

title: Weehawken Looms As a HighRise Site
description: WEEHAWKEN  Beneath the grassy plot in the Palisades where Aaron Burr mortally wounded Alexander Hamilton in their famous duel in 1804, the Seatrain Corporation has proposed to build on 80 acres of its property a $600million, highrise apartment complex that could triple the town's population.

title: Coke Murchison Bride Of Richard H. Saunders
description: Coke Ann Murchison was married here last evening to Richard Harding Saunders by the Rev. Kenneth Jones, minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: ARGENTINE AIDE ON MISSION HERE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30The Argentine Minister of Economy, Antnio Cafiero, flew to the United States today to try to obtain new loans and renegotiate Argentina's crushing foreign debts.

title: September
description: So August ends and autumn comes, not by the equinox or in the stars but by the year's weather right here on earth. The rhythms of life are constant, certain as the spinning earth and its orbit around the sun.

title: CITY COLLEGE SETS $10MILLION DRIVE
description: City College seeks to raise at least $10million over the next, two years to finance its career programs, and for the creation of scholarships and interdisciplinary courses designed to maintain academic excellence.

title: Asian Countries Are Plagued By Loss of Trained Personnel
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 30 (Reuters)A drain of professional and skilled workers is plaguing Asian countries.

title: George Lawrence, 60, Is Dead; Chairman of Taylor Wine Co.
description: George A. Lawrence, chairman and chief executive of the Taylor Wine Company, Inc., of Hammondsport, N.Y., died Thursday in Rochester. He was 60 years old and lived in Hammandsport.

title: Canadians Ask a Polish Vessel To Leave Disputed Arctic Area
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 30A Polish, vessel that appeared unexpectedly in the Canadian Arctic this week has been asked to leave the northern waters, where Canada has a disputed claim to sovereignty.

title: WhitesOnly Signs Vanish in Windhoek
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)The Whites only and Nonwhites only signs on most of Windhoelc's public buildings were removed today, two days before the opening of the constitutional conference on the future of SouthWest Africa (Namibia).

title: Tragic Kent State
description: The Federal jury in Cleveland which found no grounds for holding Ohio Gov. James A. Rhodes and 28 other defendents financially liable for the 1970 shootings at Kent State University, may itself have been the victim of an inexcusable legal vacuum in the relationship between aggrieved citizens and the state.

title: Henry Versus Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30In the Middle East, Henry Kissinger has negotiated a period of peace at a fairly stiff price. Nothing has been settled, and the Congress is worried about the cost and dangers of putting American men and arms on the line, but the worst has been avoided or at least postponed, and Mr. Kissinger probably deserves more credit for the pause than he will get.

title: Pay TV Gaining on the Island
description: WASHINGTONThe Long Island area has been found one of the best in the nation in the development of pay cable television, according to recent studies by private and public organizations.

title: Woodcock Criticizes Ford
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30 (UPI)Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that an unelected President had contributed to the nation's deepest economic crisis since the nineteenthirties by ignoring the pleas of the working man. There is small cause for celebrating labor's past triumphs on Labor Day, Mr. Woodcock said in a special Labor Day message, adding that President Ford's policies had forced workers to bear the twin burdens of higher inflation and increasing unemployment.

title: 200.000 Jobless Teachers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) More than 200,000 qualified teachers will get no jobs in American classrooms this fall, Albert Shankers, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said today.

title: THE RETIRED HERE FIND LIFE COSTLY
description: In the fall of 1974, the cost of living for a retired couple in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area who had an intermediate standard of living was $1,000, or 18 per cent above the national average for 40 urban areas.

title: Israelis on Golan Heights Uneasy on Future of Area
description: MEROM GOLAN, IsraeliOccupied Syria, Aug. 27While the internal Israeli battle over territorial concessions to Egypt rages in the streets of the cities, a potentially more anguished struggle is taking shape on the Golan Heights.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 30A bomb exploded tonight outside a bank building in central London, the fourth bombing in the London area on successive nights.

title: Vote Set on Byrne Bond Plan
description: TRENTON  Democratic leaders in the Legislature predicted yesterday that Governor Byrne's $882million bond plan would be approved next week for submission to the voters in November.

title: Elise Catharine Will Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Catharine Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elise Holliday Catharine, to James Larry Johnson; a studiofield engineer with NBC. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Loammi Johnson of Ramseur, N. C.

title: Beads  Mysterious, Varied and Useful
description: When I first started doing beadwork I thought only in terms of making jewelry, but I soon learned to use beads for making belts, headbands, window hangings, room dividers and purses. I began to explore different types of beads and different working techniques. Beads strung on wires are used to make rigid shapes such as flowers, baskets, trivets, mobiles, toy animals and even doll house furniture. Beads can also be embroidered onto fabrics for decoration, or they can be combined with other crafts such as knitting, crocheting or macrame.

title: Miss Cook Breaks U.S. Track Record
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI)  Carol Cook of Iowa State, running the distance for the first time in her life, broke the American record in the women's 10,000meter run yesterday at Drake Stadium, of the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: OSLO SAYS RUMANIAN EXPOSED A SPY RING
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 30 (Reuters)  A spy turned defector and revealed the existence of a Rumanian industrialespionage ring operating in northern Europe, the Norwegian Foreign Ministry confirmed today.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: TV VIEW
description: For a television critic to spend one week of a month's vacation at a seminar on TV criticism, the circumstances, understandably would have to be compelling. Simply knowing that the seminar was to be held in the glorious setting of Aspen, Colo., proved compelling enough for this writer. But the jaunt, made several weeks ago, turned out to be considerably less scenic than anticipated. As sessions on the significance, cosmic or otherwise, of The Mary Tyler Moore Show followed sessions on the analysis of TV as collective dreams, the grandeur of Aspen faded into a dimly perceived background for humming TV monitors and anxious declarations on the significance of it all.

title: The Oil Oracle of Wall Street
description: Charles T. Maxwell went, into the brokerage business just as the bull market of the late 1960's was crumblingnot, perhaps, the best beginning for someone expected to earn his living forecasting stock market trends. However, in choosing to specialize in oil stocks, he at least picked the right field.

title: Food
description: Last winter I contributed to this magazine an article, Taste is falling! Taste is falling! (Feb. 16). A dissenting opinion was published shortly afterward in the Letters columns. The writer did not dispute the fact that taste is falling; he maintained simply, if I read him aright, that it is immoral to object to this fact.

title: MINE UNION OFFICIAL ASKS END TO STRIKE
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 30 (UPI)An officer of the United Mine Workers called today for an end to a massive unauthorized walkout and for Federal mediation of the dispute that caused it.

title: H. B. Chapin to Marry Amy Darley
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Darley of Dallas, formerly of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., have announced that their daughter, Amy Blanchard Darley, and Henry Burden Chapin of Roxbury, Mass., will be married Sept. 14.

title: Into the Wasteland
description: Another effort to rescue New York City is underway, this time being managed by Governor Carey. After a week of groping by the Governor, the likelihood of default is greater, not leas, and Mr. Carey seems only to have been drawn into the same wasteland as everyone else.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Tremendous strides have been made in recent years in the automation of electronic flash units. Today's compact models, which are scarcely larger than their nonautomatic older cousins enable the photographer to cover all flash picturetaking situation with just one setting of the camera's lens (aperture)  as long as he sticks to the limitations of th'at particular unit, based on the ASA rating of the particular film being used. Thus, there is no longer any need for timeconsuming mathematical calculations or resetting of calculator dials each time the distance from flash to subject is changed.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Tomorrow starts the ordering period for the fourth unit of the America's First Medals series offered by the U. S. Mint. The fourth unit, like the first three, consists of two medals honoring heroes of the American Revolution; the medals can only be purchased as a pair, or unit, and the price per unit is still $10. The ordering address is: Numismatic Service, Bureau of the Mint, 55 Mint Street, San Francisco 94175. The maximum number of units per order is five. The ordering period ends Oct. 31.

title: ThirdWorld Parley Asks U.N. Pressure on Israelis
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 30Delegates from 82 nonaligned countries concluded a weeklong conference today, urging the Security Council to take all necessary measures to force Israel to comply with the United Nations resolutions on the Middle East.

title: U.S. HALTS SEIZURE OF I.R.S. PROPERTY
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 30Armed with a new law aimed at collecting child support payments from deserting fathers who are Federal employes, deputy sheriffs acting for nine Georgia mothers tried twice yesterday to seize furniture and equipment in the Internal Revenue Service office here.

title: Anne Sato Is Bride of Nicholas Danforth
description: Anne Turid Sato of Flesberg, Norway, and Nicholas Wellington Danforth of Weston, Mass., were married yesterday in the garden of the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas W. Danforth of Weston. The bride's mother, Mrs. Tora Hoimyr of Flesberg, attended the ceremony, which was performed by Rev. Carl Scovel of Kings Chapel in Boston.

title: Yanks Bow, 52, to Royals
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter and the Yankees had a peculiar outing last night in chilled and windy Shea Stadium. The millionaire righthander retired the first nine men he faced and also the final 10, but in between that perfection was a full measure of ineptitude, and the Kansas City Royals took advantage of it to top the Yankees, 52.

title: Willoughby Now Pitching
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30Back around 1930 when the Phillies wouldn't dream of taking the field with fewer than eight .300 hitters in the batting order, they had a pitcher named. Claude William Willoughby alias Weeping Willie. Eight or nine other characters were described on the roster as pitchers, but their names elude memory because they worked so briefly and departed so swiftly that they were but walking shadows. As they hastened toward the showers, a man with a megaphone would step out and intone a refrain that came to sound like a crackled record: Willoughby Now Pitching.

title: 5 IN BRONX GANG ACCUSED OF RAPE
description: Five members of a Bronx motorcycle gang have been arrested on the separate complaints of two women who charged that they were raped repeatedly over several hours in an abandoned tenement used by the gang as its headquarters.

title: 41 Gab Bag Wins On Belmont Grass
description: John M. Schiff's Gab Bag, who spent the first season of his eligible racing career just marking time, continued to demonstrate yesterday that his late start at the races was redounding to hid advantage.

title: Revolt Against the Junta Grows
description: LONDONThe death of former Emperor Halle Selassie has formally closed a chapter in Ethiopia's history, although the old regime had effectively died with his dethronement a year ago. Since then the frail and isolated old Lion of Judah had ceased to be a force in the empire which he had done so much to make and, by his stubborn clinging to power, had done so much in the end to unmake.

title: Headliners
description: The death of Eamon de Valera at 92 ends the career of a man who, for many, symbolized the Irish struggle for independence from Britain, For more than 50 years, de Valera was a major figure in Irish politics, first as one of the leaders of the rebels who fought the British intermittently from 1916 to 1923, later as Prime Minister of the Irish government for 21 years. His supporters were fanatic in their devotion. His opponents, though not as fanatic, were legion. Many praised him for the gradual moderation of his views on Irish independance and unification and others attacked him for the same reason. He stepped down to the largely ceremonial post of President in 1959, and entered a nursing home in 1973. On his deathbed, he was reported to have said, All my life I have done my best for Ireland; now I am ready to go.

title: Food News
description: LONG BRANCH  Every spa has its formula for feeling fit: waters, exercise, Dams, diet. The Harbor Island Spa, here at the Jersey shore, focuses on food.

title: KENNEDY INQUIRY IS VOTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI)The city council will investigate police handling of the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy. The Senator's son, however, says the family opposes reopening the investigation.

title: But a New Law Is Not Likely to Be a Panacea
description: SALINAS, Calif.Though nobody in California is as euphoric as a few months ago and predicting peace in the fields, a major'advance has occurred in the decadelong effort to give some, rights to the farm workers.

title: Divided Scotch Plains Stands United
description: SCOTCH PLAINSLike many other communities in Union County, Scotch Plains was settled in Colonial times. It is now a thriving suburban township of 24,000 peo ple, and its residents say that their greatest concern is maintaining a place that has proved livable, wellkept and free of the urban problems that plague other parts of the county.

title: Sheik Mujib's Single Party is Banned by Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Aug. 30 (Reuters)  President Rhondakar Mushtaque Ahmed today banned the Awami League, which was the country's only political party and which had been led by Sheik Mujibur Rahman, who was overthrown and killed on Aug. 15.

title: SubwayToken Sales Limited to One as Bargain Hunters Line Up
description: Long lines of budgetconscious New Yorkers anxious to buy as many 35cent tokens as possible before the 50cent transit fare goes into effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow have forced the Transit Authority to limit purchases to one token a person.

title: Women's Tennis: A Call For a Realistic Appraisal
description: American television viewers, accustomed to watching women's tennis played before packed galleries, must have been shocked recently to observe that the Chris EvertMartina Navratilova final in the Italian open was played in the eerie atmosphere of a nearempty stadium. Responding to this poor turnout, the television commentator. Julie Heldman, noted somewhat bitterly, The Italian men just come to these matches to watch the girls' legs. Later, as if to assuage Miss Heldman's hurt feelings, the announcer, Jim Simpson, apologized for saying that Miss Evert had manhandled Miss Navratilova in three straight sets.

title: An innocence died
description: I am writing this review in France, almost exactly 61 years after the outbreak of the Great War. A few kilometers down the road is a small town with a large war memorial, an obelisk with four artillery shells planted at its corners. On the stone scroll are inscribed the words To Our Glorious Dead, 19141918, elegantly laid out to fill the space; but the dates 1939 and 1945, in numerals necessarily smaller, have been squeezed into the bottom corners of the scroll. Nobody, when this elaborate cenotaph was designed, imagined that it might be necessary to commemorate the dead of a further great war; and when the time came nobody seems to have felt like building another. The monument may accordingly be seen, in one sense, as illustrating a belief which Paul Fussell shares with the late Winston Churchill, namely, that there was really only one war, the Thirty Years War of 191445; in another sense, it is an emblematic demonstration of another of Fussell's doctrines, which is that the earlier war predominates over the later in the modern memory and the modem imagination.

title: BRIDGE
description: In highlevel competition the state of the match affects different players in different.ways. A few of the greatest play equally well whatever the score, but some experts betray a weakness. Some find it difficult to withstand the pressure of a close match. Some give up too readily when all seems lost. And others relax too much when In possession of a commanding lead.

title: Joyce Carol Oates honoring the complexities of the real world
description: The suspicion that especially productive writers may be secondrate is a tiresome literary phenomenon. Recently it has gained strength from the heavy betting by the critics in favor of authorial selfconsciousness: theirs is a preference for books that twist and turn themselves on the rack of language in order to becomeviable. The struggle with privacy and paralysis, which is at the center of some very interesting recent fiction, is obviously quite alien to the work of Joyce Carol Oates. But she is not as naive about matters of form and questions of narrative as some people contend; her productivity is simply a matter of her having solved these problems at least to her own satisfaction. Still she is often accused of being uninterested in technique or in the fact of writing itself, as if she were perhaps an inspired idiot penning away at the behest of various voices.

title: OPEC Nations Flex Monetary Muscles
description: WASHINGTONThis year's meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which have brought the top financial officials, of 126 nations here for the coming week, are taking place at a time of intense uncertainty and strain in the world economy.

title: Paul Molitor Jr. And Missy Kalat Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Kalat of Providence, R.I., and Wianno, Mass., ave announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Barkley Kalat, to Paul E. Molitor Jr. of Milton, Mass., where lie is director of the Museum of the American China Trade.

title: Births
description: Ghezzo

title: Criminal Penalties Studied In Rhode Island Legislature
description: PROVIDENCE, Aug. 30 (AP) A legislative commission on criminal sentencing has urged Rhode Islanders to offer suggestions, on which crimes carry penalties that are out of line with their seriousness.

title: Grand Central Getting A $1Million Facelift
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has embarked upon a refurbishing of the interior at Grand Central Terminal that is expected to cost about $1million.

title: U.S. Open Results
description: MEN'S SINGLES

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: For some unfathomable reason, about 90 per cent of all neophyte bowlers are unable or unwilling, to impart a right to left spinning action to their shot. Naturally, I'm talking about righthanded bowlers. It could be that these bowling newcomers can't seem to comprehend the necessity of keeping the wrist firm through backswing and delivery, or it could be that they're actually afraid that the weight of the ball may be too much and they try to compensate by gripping the ball improperly.

title: Barbara W. Bours Bride in Delaware
description: Barbara Wadsworth Bours, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alsop Bours of Centreville, Del., and Vail, Colo., was married yesterday afternoon in Greenville, Del., to Stephen Walter Gould, sales manager for the Seattle Packaging Corporation in Portland, Ore. The Rev. John C. Scobell performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred.

title: Unprecedented Action
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30A spokesman for the Department of Justice said yesterday that the Georgia case was the first use of a new Federal law permitting the attachment of Government property when valid court garnishee orders against Federal employes were not enforced.

title: Nola Healy Married To Robert D. Lynch
description: Nola Teresa Healy and Robert Donald Lynch of New York, candidates for Ph.D. degrees in musicology at New York University, were married yesterday afternoon in the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Chapel at N.Y.U. by the Rev. Peter Meehan.

title: Aid for the SpanishSpeaking
description: PASSAICA consumeroriented program that is designed to teach this city's large Hispanic community how best to use such basic institutions as banks, utility companies and governmental agencies is now under way.

title: The Nation
description: The Federal Government is planning to lease to developers shortly another sizable portion of its enormous reserves of coal in the West and of oil and gas lying off the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts. But the plans are being vehemently opposed by a number of governors, Congressmen, and environmentalists, who contend that the GovernInent's existing mineral leasing policies do not provide either a safe or sensible system for tapping the nation's energy resources.

title: ADOLF D. KLARMANN, PENN PROFESSOR, 70
description: Dr. Adolf D. Klarmann, professor of German literature at the University of Pennsylvania and the first president of the American Council for the Study of Austrian Literature, died Wednesday in the University Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. He was 70 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: After 50 Years, Airline Service Is Ending at Berlin's Tempelhof
description: BERLIN, Aug. 30  After more than 50 years of service as Berlin's central airport, Tempelhof will phase out of all civilian operations this weekend.

title: Germany, France to Spend Billions in Public Funds
description: LONDONThe size of the world economic pie from which the poorer countries hope to take increasingly bigger slices depends heavily on the health of the major industrial nations. These nations have been ailing. But last week two of them reached for reflationary remedies.

title: Breathing Course Planned in Clifton
description: CLIFTON  Citing the continued increase in respiratory disorders, the BergenPassaic Lung Association will conduct a course in better breathing at Clifton High School this fall.

title: Young Dobe Named Best
description: NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 30It was a day for youth at the 32d annual show of the Newton Kennel Club today in a pastoral setting on the beautiful grounds of St. Paul's Abbey. For an 1yearold Doberman pinscher, Talacon Daisy Upsula, whom Joseph and Barbara Micallef of West Islip, L.I., bought as a pet, came out of the open class to go all the way and lead a field of 1,357.

title: Far Hills Mansion a Mecca for Golf Fans
description: FAR HILLSI was fascinated, and I don't even play golf.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Two recent British studies have added to the equations by which riskbenefit ratios for oral contraceptives are calculated. The new evidence shows that, increasingly with age, women from 30 to 44 who take the pill to prevent pregnancy are from 2.7 to 5.7 times more likely to have heart attacks than women who do not. Among women over 40, the likelihood of a fatal heart attack is four times as great among pillusers as among nonusers.

title: Minority Entry to Mainstream Markets
description: For Carter Wilson, a black man in Norfolk, Va., the American dream has come true. In June, after nearly 20 years as a policeman, Mr. Wilson became the owner of the Resins Research Corporation, a manufacturer of adhesives and sealants with sales of some $400,000 a year.

title: The HogCorn Ratio and the Farmers' Side of Bacon
description: With the nation's pork supply standing some 20 per cent below the level of last August and at the lowest point on a per capita basis in 40 years, it's not surprising that bacon during this sandwich season costs more than $2 a pound.

title: Miss Veague Plans Bridal
description: Pamela Chiles Veague plans to be married Sept. 19 to Dr. Kenneth Richard Krauss of New York at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John M. Veague Jr. of New Ipswich, N. H., who have announced the engagement.

title: Living History: The Patriots and Redcoats Are at It Again
description: WHEN George Woodbridge takes off for a weekend these days, he usually goes back to the 18th century. He puts aside his pencils and padsWoodbridge is an artist on the staff of Mad Magazinepacks his breeches, leggings and dress sword and leaves his Brooklyn studiohome for some distant place hallowed by history. There he transforms himself into a major in the New England Corps of Light Infantry, an American Wray unitnow extinctthat was formed during the Revolutionary War.

title: JOHN R. BARNETT, 37, OF WALL ST. JOURNAL
description: John R. Barnett, Page 1 editor of The Wall Street Journal, died Friday in an auto accident on the Pennsylvania Turnpike at the Township of Lower Swatara, near Harrisburg, Pa. He was 37 years old and lived in HoHoKus. N.J.

title: Driver and Flagman Faulted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)Both a school bus driver and a Southern Railway flagman were at fault in a Georgia train and bus collision that killed seven students and injured 71 others last year, Federal safety investigators said today. They said the driver had disregarded a law that he stop before pulling onto the tracks, and that the flagman had failed to comply with rules to guard the crossing.

title: Royal Glint First In Rich Arlington
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP)Royal Glint, leading all the way in sloppy going under top weight of 125 pounds, won the $127,400 Arlington Handicap by four lengths in record time before a crowd of 22,130 at Arlington Park today.

title: Long Island Draws the Line on Groupers
description: Long Island municipalities are moving to enact, tighten or more strictly enforce laws that regulate groupers, unrelated people who share singlefamily homes.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayK.C. of Northern New Jersey allbreed, Bergen Mall. Paramus, N.J.; 1,233 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: City Is Accused of Stalling on Housing
description: The sponsor of a proposal to build housing on a cityowned parking lot in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyna proposal that has been frustrated for more than a decade nowcharged last week that deliberate or inadvertent inefficiency by city housing officials had led to yet another threat to the proposal.

title: Five Victims of Tick Bites Recovering on Nantucket
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP)  Five persons bitten by tiny ticks carrying a rare disease that is sometimes fatal were reported doing well after they contracted the malady on Nantucket Island off the Massachusetts coast.

title: Hollywood Babylon
description: Movie buffs tend to fall into one of two major categoriescinema theorists who take people like Siegfried Kracauer seriously, and fans who just want to know if it's true that Lupe Velez used to dance the cancan at Hollywood parties without wearing any underpants. To entertain the second, and I should imagine somewhat larger group, Kenneth Anger has fashioned a delicious 306page box of poisoned bonbons.

title: U.S. JUDGE REFUSES GRAIN SHIPPERS' BID
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 (AP)A Federal judge refused today to order longshoremen to load grain on a Sovietbound ship. He said no order was needed yet because a strike had not been called.

title: An Operatic Performance Is Always One Beat Away From Chaos
description: When George Posell, one of the three prompters of the Metropolitan Opera, recently addressed a Colony Club luncheon on the subject of his unseen labors, he was introduced as the most unheard but most important ??oice at the Metropolitan.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The combination of such a superb theater piece as A Chorus Line and the record production skills of Goddard Lieberson (who all but invented the craft of producing original cast musical albums) inevitably raised high expectations for the cast recording of Michael Bennett's show. Add to that the news that Mr. Lieberson's enthusiasm for A Chorus Line brought him out of retirement as a producer for one last fling.

title: Walker Fails In Try for 2d Record
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 30 (AP) John Walker of New Zealand, the world recordholder in the onemile run, failed by only sixtenths of a second today in an attempt to better the world record for 2.000 meters.

title: Gasoline Station Owners Create Fund on Holdups
description: NEWPORT, Me., Aug. 30 (AP)  Gasoline station owners in Maine are setting up a reward fund aimed at gaining information about holdups.

title: Audition Is Slated For Nutcracker
description: CLOSTER  The Classic Ballet Company of New Jersey will hold an audition Thursday for boys and girls interested in appearing in this season's performances of The Nutcracker. The audition will be conducted at the company's studio, 253 Closter Dock Road, beginning at 4:30 P.M.

title: Notes: Autumn Brings New Fares and Plans
description: WITH Labor Day at hand, it's time to start thinking about trips in the fall, a time when offseason price reductions ana special packages are being offered by airlines, shipping lines and hotels. A sampling:

title: CatholicSchool Lay Head Is Pressing for Public Aid
description: EAST ORANGE  Earlier this summer, when Richard T. Corrado arrived here from Orlando, Fla., to assume his duties as the first layman to head the vast school system of the Newark Archdiocese, he announced his intention to become positively aggressive in promoting public aid to private schools.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Periodically, the question Is raised: Should a news reporter or an editor, a newspaper or magazine publisher or a network executive, be involved in organized political activity? Should, that Is, a person whose business is the gathering and presenting of news reject, for reasons relating to the ethics of the profession, a constitutional right and traditional duty?

title: Bruce S. Wagner Is the Fiance Of Elizabeth Pearsall Winslow
description: Elizabeth Pearsall Winslow and Bruce S. Wagner plan to be married here in October.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The big three lawn nutrientsnitrogen, phosphorus and potashare the prime needs for good lawn growth. Nitrogen is the most perishable as it is used up quickly or easily leached during heavy rains. Lawn fertilizer manufacturers rely heavily on ureaform sources to supply nitrogen and overcome this fault.

title: Black Group to Aid Minority Officials
description: CAMDENA private black organization is developing a program aimed at helping minority officials in South Jersey to serve their constituents better, thus improving their reelection chances.

title: Kuwaiti Investors Reported To Buy Boston Properties
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30. (AP)A group of Kuwaiti investors has reportedly taken title to 23 downtown Boston properties for an estimated $23million.

title: And then there's Mary Cassattshe must not be left out
description: One of the best ways to get run out of town is to suggest to admirers of Mary Cassatt that she was a good minor artist to whom quite enough homage has lately been paid.

title: Militants Attack Sadat
description: ALEXANDRIA  The interim agreement between Egypt and Israel has already become an apple of discord in the Arab camp.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Is there need for a new history of photography that will update, revise, even radically recast the standard histories of Beaumont Newhall and Helmut and Alison Gernsheim? Yes, there is. But the flood of new monographs and subject books has not yet washed up anything comparable in scope and consistency with the standard works. There are, however, three recent books that are worthy of being placed on the shelf just below Newhall and Gernsheim. Each adds something important to the story, and each does this in such a different way that it is sometimes hard to remember that they are all dealing with the same subject.

title: American Conference: Easy Road for Steelers; Raiders Boast Excess Talent
description: Eastern Division

title: Political Supremacy At Issue in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE  A little quietly but definitely, the 1975 political season has started in Suffolk County, with Republicans and Democrats engaging in what what one G.O.P. official says is a struggle that could determine political supremacy in the county for the next decade.

title: President, in Maine, Sees No Holiday for Jobless
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 30President Ford prodded business and industry today to expand production and create new job opportunities to help maintain the social fabric of America.

title: W. B. Marshall Weds Mrs. Wadsworth
description: Betty Nevin Wadsworth of Port Washington, L.I., widow of Arthur L. Wadsworth, was married yesterday to William B. Marshall of ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y. a widower and partner in the New York law firm of Craveth, Swain & Moore.

title: ART VIEW
description: Money is tight in New York City these days, and nowhere more so than at the Metropolitan Museum. So there was bound to be an uproar when it was made known that the Met is paying $5.1million for 412 works of Japanese art from a collection that most people have never heard of.

title: KENT VERDICT LINKED TO RULING OF JUDGE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (UPI) The judge's decision to divide defendants into separate groups in the Kent State University civil damage trial influenced the jury to return a verdict exonerating the defendants of all civil liability, a juror reported today.

title: A. P. Rosenberg to Wed Miss Unger
description: Frieda Sara Unger, who is in her second year at Hofstra University School of LaW, and Alexander Peter Rosenberg, a trial lawyer with the National Labor Relations Board here, plan to be married in January.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FROM the Ukraine to Siberia, from Texas to the Dakotas, from Manitoba to Alberta, the wheat harvest in the northern hemisphere has reached a climax in these waning days of summer. In simpler times, the harvest was taken for granted. But in the last few years it has become a highly charged political event with ramifications from supermarkets to the salons of international diplomacy.

title: No Nicklaus Yet, But He Is Only 7
description: MONTAGUEMost golfers would be extremely unhappy if their ninehole scores were only two strokes lower than their weight, but that's not the case with Michael Mattarazzo Jr. The reason is that Michael, the 7yearold son of the pro at the Holiday Lake Country Club here, packs only 58 pounds into his 3foot frame.

title: Parmers Angry Over Doubling of Machinery Costs
description: TRALAICE PLANTATIONS, Aug. 28The back of the store here is where William A. Percy keeps his office and runs his farm. It is also where he and his planter friends drink Cokes and console each other.

title: Is BacktoCampus BacktoTurmoil?
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.In a few weeks, the nation's colleges and universities begin their fall terms. Shortly after that, we should be able to tell whether the student protest of the late 1960's really ended in 1970 or whether it has only been in a state of dormancy.

title: About the Mets ..
description: Jon Matlack enjoyed a rare pitching privilege Friday night in his 61 victory over the Dodgers: He pitched an entire game in which the potential tying run never reached the ondeck circle. This can arise only in rare circumstances. ... It can happen only to the visiting team's pitcher, since the home pitcher must start working with the score 00. Then, if the visiting team scores three runs in the first inning and the visiting pitcher hurls a perfect game (with no one reaching base), he has done it. If his team scores four runs in the top of the first, he must allow no more than one man on base at a time (and pitch a shutout) to do it. Otherwise his team has to score five or more runs its first turn at bat... The Mets got six, two of which Matlack knocked in himself. The pitching significance of this oddity is that Matlack never had to face a batter who, if he got on, would have brought the tying run to the plate.

title: Net Training Camp Will Open Sept. 24
description: The New York Nets will open their training camp on Sept. 24 at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N. Y. Coach Kevin Loughery plans two drills daily until the team leaves on Sept. 30 for its first exhibition game, against the Denver Nuggets in Greensboro, N. C.. Oct, 1.

title: Adult School Is Offering Bicentennial bourses for 197576
description: MAPLEWOODThe South OrangeMaplewood Adult School, the oldest communitysponsored institution of its kind in the state, has scheduled three courses on American history and culture for 197576.

title: STUART CAMEN
description: Stuart Camen, a United Press International sportswriter, died of cancer yesterday at Brooklyn Methodist Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Ridgefield Park, N.J.

title: King Ousted As Pilot Of Braves
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 (UPI) The Atlanta Braves, mired in fifth place in the National League Western Division, dismissed Manager Clyde King today and replaced him with Connie Ryan for the remainder of the season.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: New & Novel
description: Back when Robert Nathan first began writing fantasies. Central Park was a place where a gang of his quaint characters could spend a season living in a tool shed, disturbed by little more than the rumbling of their empty tummies. But that was over 40 years ago. The last novel I read about Central Palle featured a gang of teen  age cannibals who mugged their victims and then ate them. Mr. Nathan, conscious of this environmental change, sends an angel and a fiend down to New York City to find what in hell has gone wrong. (Up above,  it is felt that there may be a dearth of souls to save; and down below it is feared that there may be no more innocents left to corrupt.)

title: C. F. Hovey Jr. to Wed Nancy Meyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Appleton Meyer of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Saltonstall Meyer, to Charles Fox Hovey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hovey of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: College Is Offering A Course on China
description: CONVENT STATION  A fourcredit lecture on China, Its History and Culture, will be offered this fall by the College of St. Elizabeth.

title: JOHN B. GEORGE
description: John B. George, who retired in 1971 as president of the McLellan Stores Company, a variety chain store concern, where he began as a stock clerk in 1924, died Thursday in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in Pine Plains. N.Y.

title: Ian Karin Is Fiance Of Miss Underberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Underberg of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosanne Underberg, to Ian Karin, son of David Karin of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Karin. The wedding is planned for Sept. 28.

title: Flaws been in Law On Election Funds
description: TRENTON  The state's campaigndisclosure law will control the raising and spending of funds for the coming general election, but the measure is under a cloud that may have to be dispelled by new legislation.

title: Relevance Is Out, Classics Are In
description: Note: The following memo was found near the coffee urn at the recent Return to Basics conference sponsored by I.C.S. (Institute for Confidence in Our Schools).

title: Van Nostrand Victor
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 30  King Van Nostrand defeated Rey Garrido, 61, 62, today in the final of the Summer Jamboree circuit 35er tennis tournament at the Glen Cove Racquet Club.

title: A Glimpse of Yesteryear In basement of a Home
description: WESTFIELDOne has to go underground if he wishes to explore a museum here, for the attraction  Shepherd's Country Store Museumis situated in the basement of a spacious suburban home on Winchester Way.

title: A Lot of Democratic Horses at the Finish Line?
description: WASHINGTONThe rules of the presidential nomination game, for Republicans as well as Democrats, have been changed for 1976, and the adjustment of the ways in which delegates are selected is going to change the way the game is played and perhaps the outcome, too.

title: Bilingual Funding in Dispute
description: A new court decision has overturned an order that had called for giving a special English language test to thousands of students attending barochial schools in the Williamsburg and Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: FARM UNION STRIFE SEEN DESPITE LAW
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 30  California's new farm labor law went into effect this week, but two days of hearings on its provisions indicated that the controversy, after a decade of strife in the state's $6billion industry, was far from over.

title: Blood Donors Sought
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP)The Reb Cross appealed today for blood donors. Marge Gandolfi, a spokesman, said the blood center here had had requests for 388 pints of blood from Massachusetts hospitals and began the weekend with less than 400 pints.

title: TV VIEW
description: One of the difficulties with being highminded is that it can leave you with nothing much to write about. I decided this week to be highminded about Beacon Hill, the American answer to Upstairs, Downstairs, of which there were two hours on Monday night on CBS. Sitting through those hours was, as a friend has suggested, like going to a huge party where the host insists on introducing you to every single person on the premises. By the end of the evening, you have met a lot of people but you don't know anything Besides, everybody else in the world is writing reams of copy about Beacon Hill, as though it were actually as important as the network publicists claim it is. So let it simmer for a couple of weeks and see if mold forms.

title: September Is Grand Finale For Summer Yacht Racing
description: The summer's sailing is going out with a bang. From the World One Ton championship off Rhode Island to the Governor's Cup race in New York Harbor, September is the grand finale, the last time around in a summer marked by a steady stream of major races.

title: U.S. MOVE HAILED BY CUBAN EXILES
description: MIAMI, Aug. 30Last Saturday, two days after the United States announced a partial lifting of its trade embargo against Cuba, about 200 Cuban exiles carrying signs marched through the street of Little Havana, the Cuban district here.

title: CABINDA OPPOSES TIES WITH ANGOLA
description: CABINDA, Aug. 30 (Reuters) Every afternoon, work in Many hamlets around the sleepy capital of this Portu, guese exclave stops temporarily as villagers huddle around radio sets to listen to the Voice of Cabinda broadcast by the Kinshasa radio in neighboring Zaire.

title: INDONESIA CHIDES LISBON ON TIMOR
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia Aug. 30 (LIPI)  Indonesia is ready to send troops to Portuguese Timor, as the first step in a peacekeeping mission involving four nations, but is holding back until she gets Portugal's approval, Acting Foreign Minister Muchtar Kusmaatmadja said today.

title: Middle East Questions
description: All reports from the Middle East indicate that Secretary of State Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy is about produce the new IsraeliEgyptian agreement that eluded him earlier this year. It is a complex package, one in which most of the major concessions will be made by Israel. Indeed, the limited scope of Egyptian counterconcessions makes it clear that Israel will be staking its future security as never before on United States fidelity to the explicit and implicit commitments this country will be making under the pact.

title: What Length of Life Is Acceptable
description: It is virtually impossible to discuss motor racing in a detached way, when you have recently lost someone who was very close to you. Americans are more affected by Mark Donohue's death than they would be if a driver from a foreign country were to die in a similar racing accident, even if he were equally loved and famous in his own home country. Nevertheless, let me try.

title: Jane Howard, Wheaton Alumna, Wed to Roger Pierce Cheever
description: Jane Howard of Cambridge. Mass., and Roger Pierce Cheever, executive director of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society in Boston, were married yesterday afternoon in Little Compton, R.I.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to BadenBaden, you will find that the spa has become a yearround resort, with the main season extending from early April to late October. Hotels are av,ailable for every taste, pocketbook and state of health. At the top of the list is the Brenner Park, where the bluebloods always. stayed and which is still considered one of the finest hotels in Europe. The rates range from $45 to $85 a day for a double room with bath and breakfast. Only slightly less plush are the Europaischer Hof and the Bellevue. Their rates range from $38 to $64 a day for a double with bath and breakfist. The Badischer Hof has thermal water taps in every bathroom and charges $34 to $44 a day fur a double with bath and breakfast. The hotel, built more than 100 years ago but modernized many times, has an enclosed center courtyardjust like modern hotels in the United States. There is also a selection of sanatoriums, which are merely pensions with medical and health facilities on the premises. They charge about $45 or $50 a day for a double room with bath and breakfast. Less expensive are the small hotels and guesthouses, which charge about $15 a day for a double with breakfast but bath.

title: U.S. Asks Tighter Curbs on Cabs Here
description: The Federal Government, in an effort to force New York City into adopting further steps to clean up its air, has ordered the city to put sharp limits on taxicab cruising by Oct. 14 in midtown Manhattan and to begin to plan for more efficient delivery of goods by trucks.

title: Solomon Averts Loss; Ashe. Miss Evert Win
description: The Human Ball Machine prevailed again yesterday.That's the futility Wotjek Fibak of Poland endured in dropping a dramatic twohour, threeset struggle to Harold Solomon in the United States Open championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: The Region
description: With relatively little attention and controversy, the cost of mass transportation in and around New York City is going up drastically tomorrowOnly the general preoccupation with the city's dire financial condition has diverted attention from what otherwise would beand in the recent past has beena matter of universal concern.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: That all young people do not fit into the same highschool mold has long been an educational reality. Now more and more school systems are providing alternatives to the conventional high school program.

title: Old Era Is Evoked At a Shop
description: The tone is firmly romantic at Rubicon, a Madison Avenue shop where old lace and fine fabrics go into the creation of the sort of dresses that look as though they were the top of the line of the best designers somewhere between 1900 and 1920.

title: Leone Moves to Cut Possible Improprietie's in Bid Awards
description: TRENTONState Treasurer Richard C. Leone has instituted a wide range of reforms designed to reduce the possibility of influencepeddling in the awarding of state contracts.

title: GETTING AT THE FEELINGS
description: After centuries of neglect in mercantile America, the inner life is finally getting its due. Every popular magazine, every rock record, every commentary on the American scene contains reference to a hunger for change, away from the emptiness and sterility which are said to be the price of our material comfort, and toward a more emotionally meaningful, spiritual, fulfilling personal life.

title: Garden Spot, '76
description: When the delegates, alternates, families, press and, not least, candidates, descend on Madison Square Garden next summer to nominate the next President of the United States, they will among other glories get a chance to see New Yorkers plain instead of through the cracked prism of a M.A.C. bond. The last time the Democrats came here, in 1924, it took a third week and 103 ballots to nominate a Wall Street lawyer, John W. Davis, who, for better or worse, was defeated by President Calvin Coolidge. The Republicans have never held a national convention here and won't next year; New York never bothered to apply for the honor, though there are closet Republicans about, plus a couple of United States Senators who represent the alpha and omega of Republicans.

title: Jet Fighter Grounded Again Because of Engine Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) For the second time since June, the Air Force has grounded, its A7D jet fighters, as a precautionary measure because of engine troubles, this time involving a fatal crash.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 31, 1975

title: Kuwaiti Hints a Delay on Oil Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Kuwait's minister of finance hinted today that the 13nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might make no increase in prices before January even though its selfimposed freeze expires Sept. 30.

title: Engagements
description: BuzinSperber

title: Kissinger's Plan on Sinai Is Criticized in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30In the first direct Soviet comment on Secretary of State Kissinger's latest round of shuttle diplomacy, the Communist party newspaper Pravda declared today that a disengagement accord being worked out in Sinai Would only further complicate the Middle East situation.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTONEdwin Harley Yeo 3d loves candy, hates inflation and delights in the financial markets.

title: Outdoor Events Today
description: Coast Guard Cutter Eagle: Visitors welcome aboard squarerigged training ship from 9 to 11 A.M. and 1 to 4 P.M., South Street Seaport Museum, East River, foot of Fulton Street.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Brooke Miller, F. B. Wachs 3d Set Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald James Miller of Lexington, Ky., formerly of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Brooke Suzanne Miller, to Frederick Bernard Wachs 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bernard Wachs Jr., of Castle Lawn Farm in Lexington.

title: Philadelphia Fireman Dies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (UPI)An eighth city fireman died today as a result of burns he suffered fighting a spectacular oil refinery blaze here Aug. 17. Carroll K. Brenek, 33 years old, died at St. Agnes Hospital Burn Center.

title: ThirdFlag Ships Accused Of Predatory Rate Cuts
description: Local maritime interests last week expressed strong support for Congressional passage of a measure that would provide minimum ocean rates for cargo carried in thirdflag ships. Thirdflag ships ply trade routes between foreign ports, and some of them operate for years without ever calling at a port in the country in which they are registered.

title: MICHIGAN LIMITS CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: LANSING, Mich., Aug. 30Gov. William G. Milliken signed this week a bill requiring 20,000 public officials to disclose their finances, providing for taxfunding of governorship elections and setting limits on campaign contributions.

title: The Nation
description: Democratic Congressional leaders, apparently fearing the political consequences of a sudden rise in fuel costs, have reached a tentative agreement with President Ford to end their opposition to his plan for gradual decontrol of domestic oil prices.

title: White Man Held for Murder After Black in Shooting Dies
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 30 (UPI)A 24yearold white man was charged with firstdegree murder today, barely an hour after the death of 13yearold black girl who was shot in the back while picking peaches in his back yard Aug. 17.

title: Business Index Falls
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 401.6 from 409.9 a week earlier. A year ago it was 414.9.

title: Pro League Attempts An Americanization
description: The owners of the 20 franchises in the North American Soccer League agreed last week that their rosters would include at least six American or Canadian players and that the players on loan to each club from foreign countries would be limited to five.

title: Costlier Cards
description: It's getting more expensive to avoid paying your credit card bills at some banks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Maurice S. Paprin supposes that lengthening waiting lists for public and subsidized housing are evidence of a real housing shortage in New York [Letters, Aug. 17].

title: State Investigating 4th Health Facility
description: A fourth health facility was added to the three in, Nassau County that have come under the scrutiny of. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ant other investigatory agencies in searching out abuses of Medicare insurance by physicians and other health professionals.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayNASCAR Pocono 150 at Pocono Raceway, Long Pond, Pa., Practice 9 A.M.; qualifying 12:30 P.M.; first 25mile heat at 2:30; final 3:30 P.M.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Juliet Bleecker Carter Married To Piers H. de la Force in Rye
description: Juliet Bleecker Carter and Piers H. de la Force were married in Rye, N.Y., yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips, rector of Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, performed the ceremony on the lawn at the Manursing Island home of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Walker Peniston.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLANKLeah, Aug. 31, 1955. In loving memory of a beloved mother. George

title: A Massachusetts Official Calls State Bridges Unsafe
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP)Some 13 per cent of all stateowned bridges in Massachusetts are unsafe and some should be closed, Department of Public Works Commissioner John Carroll told a legislative committee this week.

title: People/Business
description: The Center for Laboratory Medicine, Inc., is a Metuchen  headquartered organization that was established, according to its board chairman and chief executive officer, with the concept that medicine is costing too much today.

title: George Jewett Plans to Marry Miss Nichols
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Willlis Nichols Jr. of Cincinnati, Lexington, Ky., and East Hampton, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Rowe Nichols, to George Morrison Jewett of New York. He is a son of Edward H. Jewett Jr. of East Hampton and the late Mrs. William C. Kruger.

title: Oklahoma Official Chafes at Law On Bilingual Ballots for Indians
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 30 Recent amendments to the Voting Rights Act of 1965, requiring bilingual ballots for American Indians, are posing problems for state election officials here.

title: Increasing Number of Women Are Seeking Help at Brooklyn Infertility Clinic
description: With adoptions becoming scarcer because of relaxed abortion laws, business has been on the increase at the Downstate Medical center's Infertility Clinic at 455 Lenox Road in Brooklyn.

title: State Agency to Air Vast Water Project
description: POMPTON LAKESA plan to divert more than 50 miltion gallons of water a day from the Ramapo, Pompton and Passaic Rivers is expected to help communities in at least four counties meet their demands for supplies through the rest of this century.

title: Falcons Fall, 1613 Leahy Kicks 3
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 Unfortunately and ironically for Al Woodall, who for years was hidden in the shadow of Joe Namath, the quarterback tonight again was overshadowed by J. J. Jones.

title: Banjos Emerge To Twang Anew
description: AMITYVILLE  Their theme song is. Let's Get the Banjo Out of the Attic. And for the 80 members of the Long Island Banjo Society ?? is also a creed.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BadenBaden: Help for the Sick and Fun for the Healthy
description: CAN a healthy, skeptical American physician and his wife find enjoyment and invigoration in the thermal waters and mud baths of a spa? The answer is a resounding YES if the spa is BadenBaden in Germany, where the wellknown and welltraveled have been taking the waters for much of recorded history. As far back as the third century, the Roman Emperor Caracalla visited BadenBaden to relieve himself of a host of ailments. And even then, the results of balneology, as water therapy is called, were open to dispute. According to BadenBaden accounts, Caracalla was so improved that he practically skipped all the way back to Rome. Contemporary Roman chronicles disagree, however. They say Caracalla returned home not one ?? better.

title: Forecast for Pro Football: Old Faces to Remain on Top
description: Do not anticipate change in the pro football picture this season. The same teams are likely to be on top and the same ones on the bottom, too. The structure of the everexpanding National Football League has become so rigid that the fortunate stay fortunate and the poor remain improvident.

title: JANE ENGEL, 68, DIES LED SPECIALTY SHOPS
description: Jane Engel Shattuck, who founded and headed the Jane Engle women's specialty shops from 1930 to the midnineteenfifties, died Thursday in Phoenix, Ariz. Her age was 68.

title: Editors'
description: Fiction

title: Snow From Ice Age Found to Be Dirtier Than Today's Snow
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30 (AP)An Ohio State University study of ice cores from the last glacial period about 14,000 years ago shows that snow was much dirtier than that falling today.

title: Excerpts From Communique Issued by the Lima Conference of Foreign Ministers of Nonaligned Countries
description: The conference reaffirmed its complete solidarity with the struggle of the people of Kampuchea [Cambodia], who, in this new stage of their history, must insure the defense of their independence, their national sovereignty and territorial integrity and, at the same time, rebuild the country on a basis of independence and selfconfidence, in accordance with their aspiration.

title: Schools in Nassau Face Tough Road
description: By Backtoschool days in Nassau County will bring new severities but few surprises.

title: Medical Profession Acting On AddictDoctor Problem
description: The problem of drug abuse among physicians, long hidden behind the traditional closed ranks of medicine but highlighted recently by the deaths from bariturate addiction of Drs. Cyril and Stewart Marcus, is beginning to be dealt with more openly by the medical profession.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Latest in the paperback espionage sweepstakes series: MAX GALAN: HUNTER OF MEN by C.H. Guenter (Pinnacle, $1.25). This is the first in a projected series. The ingredients include the Mafia, a hit man, microfilm stolen from the C.I.A. a safecracking job on a safe that can't be cracked. And Max Galan, the hunter of men. The ingredients are familiar enough, the writing is routine enough, and there is absolutely nothing here to distinguish the book from so many others along this line.

title: Sunday Observer
description: After all the political protests about President Ford's refusal to receive Aleksand?? Solzhenitsyn at the White House, the President first tried to recoup by telling the famous novelist to drop in anytime and then, when Mr. Solzhenitsyn refused, by persuading some other famous writers to visit.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Three years ago, one of New York's most colorfuland successful  policeman, Albert A, Seedman, retired as chief of detectives. He was only 54 years old, but for some time, private industry had been beckoning, and he now is vice president in charge of loss prevention for the chain of 12 Alexander's department stores.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: As a rule, I get to the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., just once each summer (vacations do get in the way sometimes), which means that I am normally faced with a very hard choice. The Goodspeed's been confining itself to two or three productions a season lately, the demand for seats in the attractively fudgy Court House on the riverbank being so healthy, and the production styles are poles apart, products of different musicalcomedy worlds.

title: 22,000 Adults Seeking High School Equivalency Diplomas
description: TRENTON  When the school bell rings throughout the state this week, an increasing number of adults will be among those heeding the call. In their case, they will be seeking a high school equivalency diploma.

title: Group Including 2 Blacks Assaulted at Klan Meeting
description: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Aug. 30 (UPI)A group of five Northern men, including two blacks and an Asian, were assaulted and hustled out of the National Knights of the Ku Klux Klan convention tonight.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Contest for Elderly Is Scheduled Sept. 13
description: ASBURY PARKThe third annual Ms. Senior Citizen Contest, a competition sponsored by the state's Office on Aging, will be held at Convention Hall on Sept. 13.

title: THIRD WORLD HINTS SOFTER U.N. STAND
description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Aug. 30  Thirdworld diplomats are busily spreading the word that they would moderate some of their more radical demands for changes in the world economic system if only the United States comes to next week's special session of the General Assembly with conciliatory proposals.

title: Pirates Lift Suspension On Ellis
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates reinstated Dock Ellis today, lifting the suspension on the righthanded pitcher after 14 days.

title: Speer Asserts Hitler Spoke Of Setting New York Afire
description: BONN, Aug. 30Hitler was obsessed with the idea of destroying New York City in a firestorm of bombs as World War II was drawing to a close, according to a new book by his intimate, Albert Speer.

title: Junior Jumping Begins Thursday
description: The junior international jumping competition, long a popular event in Canada but brought to the United States only two years ago, is scheduled to be held Thursday, Saturday and Sunday.

title: Records Fall Prey to Jaws
description: There are two schools of thought about the Jaws phenomenon: Either it's the crassest promotional stunt ever pulled on the masses or it's a classic case of skillfully orchestrated business strategy producing a pop culture craze.

title: Edith Wharton
description: In this biography, one of the very best we have of an American writer, Edith Wharton (18621937) emerges as a person so salient and commanding that one wonders whether her fiction will fade in the light of her evoked presence. It does not; it is in fact enhanced in interest, and one turns from the life to the works with an increased sense that they are of a piece. R. W. B. Lewis puts The House of Mirth, The Custom of the Country, the less familiar short novel Summer (1917). The Age of Innocence and a dozen short stories in the front rank. He persuades us that Edith Wharton's art has quite specific origins; it is the play of her fine intelligence over the field of her life. Both the books and the woman who wrote them take on the pathos and the dignity of a brilliantly conducted public struggle for personal freedom within fixed conditions.

title: The United States Gets Off a Simple, Hard Line
description: WASHINGTONThe struggle for political and economic equality that lasted for centuries within the nations of the West is now taking place between these industrialized states and the developing countries. It will intensify greatly in the coming weeks in the special session of the United Nations, the World Bank, in Paris and Geneva over matters of equity versus efficiency, pride versus practicality, power and money.

title: Ohio Air Show Canceled
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (UPI) Rainy weather forced cancellation of the Cleveland National Air Show today, scrubbing an overflight by the Lockhood SR71 spy plane, holder of the world absolute speed mark of 2,070 miles an hour. Jesson71

title: Paperbacks
description: BED/TIME/STORY, by Jill Robinson. (Fawcett, $1.75.) She's divorced, mother of two, on speed; he's erratically brilliant, an alcoholic: love conquers their selfhatred in her autobiographical story.

title: Clurman Resigns
description: David Clurman has resigned as a New York State Assistant Attorney General, effective this week.

title: Life Is a Lonely Place
description: A real fagandahalf. Tinker Bell. Fifteenyearold Tink Rowlandson lives in a small town on the lonely Maine coast. His best friend has left for New York, his parents don't understand him, he hasn't got a girlhe hasn't got a friend in the world. Besides all this, Tink has nothing in common with his older brother, a real jock; so he spends his hours alone with his dog, observing wildlife and collecting beach glass.

title: School for Truck Drivers Agrees with F.T.C. on Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) The Federal Trade CommisMon said Wednesday that a truckdriver training school has agreed not to use deceptive hales tactics, such as placing ads for students in the Help Wanted section of a publication and implying it was affiliated with a trucking company.

title: Richest Horse Race CoExists With Memories of a Western Frontier Town
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N.M., Aug. 30 (AP)Down the valley a ways there's a place called the Roundup Bar.

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: The Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., has sold the land under the 40story skyscraper at 1411 Broadway. The property, the block bounded by Broadway and Seventh Avenue and 39th and 40th Streets, was once the site of the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Guerrillas in Mexico Preying On Police for Their Weapons
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30Mexico's faltering urban guerrilla movement has apparently abandoned such ambitious actions as political or diplomatic kidnappings in favor of assassinations, often indiscriminate, of policemen.

title: Australia May Take Role
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 30 Australia is believed to be reconsidering her refusal to join in efforts to end the fighting in Portuguese Timor.

title: Exhibition Traces Princeton Libraries
description: PRINCETONThe fascinating development of the library facilities at Princeton University is the subject of an exhibition at the university's Firestone Library.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Unveilings
description: LINZERCelia. A store will be unveiled in loving memory of our beloved Celia Linzer on Sunday Afternoon Aug. 31, at 2 o'clock, at the Linzer Mausoleum, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I., NY.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Everyone knows women can't compose. Writers on music, psychologists, bartenders and other authorities have been saying so for as long as the oldest citizen can remember. And everyone knows why, too. Women, who have the ability to create babies, find artistic creativity silly by comparison. Besides, experiments with chimpanzees and stray cats have shown that the males are aggressive and willing to fight for commissions and foundation grants, while the females prefer to sit home and worry over the possibility that the female next door has a whiter sink.

title: World Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Oil Spilled Off Chile in 1974 Said to Still Cause Damage
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 30 (UPI)A huge oil slick near Chile's southern tip a year ago is still causing ecological damage and has killed 4,000 birds, mostly penguins, according to a Chilean study.

title: RETARDED GETTING A SIGN LANGUAGE
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., Aug. 29A new sign language using the simplest of hand movements Is being fashioned at the Southbury Training School here for mentally retarded people who are also unable to move easily and unable to speak.

title: Is There Something Wrong With Us
description: For 12 years there has always been the next race. It lies ahead like an iceberg. On the surface I see its obvious pointsthe travel, the hotel, the racetrack, the car, the people. Beneath the surface, I have come to realize there is the greater part. The enormous possibility for glory, ecstasy, and sorrow. But there is always the next race. In my case it is usually two weeks distant. Whatever the triumph or tragedy of today, I think of the next race.

title: The Real Nashville
description: Country star Webb (I Ain't Never) Pierce and countrypop singer Ray (The Streak, Misty) Stevens live across from one another on Nashville's exclusive North Curtiswood Lane, not far from Minnie Pearl and the Governor of Tennessee. Pierce's home is a popular stop on the many homesofthestars tours that flourish in Nashville. The tourists can admire Pierce's guitarshaped swimming pool, can buy his records and, indeed, can shake his hand if he happens to be home and in a mood for handshaking.

title: Police Cruisers Given To Bay State Towns
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP)In an effort to reduce traffic accidents, each of 40 Massachusetts communities has received a new $7,500 fully equipped police cruiser from the state.

title: Great NeckMineola Bus Run Starting
description: MENEOLA  Additional Nassau County bus service from Great Neck to Mineola will begin on a trial basis tomorrow.

title: Blood Donors Sought
